column3: Reading this kanji from the top down, we have: _horns_ . . . _nose_. Together they bring to mind the picture of a moose-head hanging on the den wall, with its great _horns_ and long _nose_. Now while we would speak of cutting off a moose's  "head" to hang on the wall, the Japanese speak of cutting off its **neck**. It's all a matter of how you look at it. Anyway, if you let the word **neck** conjure up the image of a moose with a very l-o-n-g **neck** hanging over the fireplace, whose _horns_ you use for a coat-rack and whose _nose_ has spigots left and right for scotch and water, you should have no trouble with the character. Here we get a good look at what we mentioned when we first introduced the element for _horns_ : that they can never be left floating free and require an extra horizontal stroke to prevent that from happening, as is the case here.
column5: 1) [[bakamono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bakamono)] 20-8-2007(130): The V shape is your **neck** on top of your collar bone, or the straight line. _Yourself_ , or the rest of your body is below that!
column6: 2) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 24-8-2006(96): The mooses **neck** supports it's big horns and long nose.
column7: 3) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 30-9-2009(74): One has a strong **NECK** if one can carry HORNS on ONESELF.
column8: 4) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 25-4-2008(58): There are no goddamn animal legs in the Kanji for **neck**. Stop thinking there are animal legs in the Kanji for **neck**. There are NONE!
column9: 5) [[cloudstrife543](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cloudstrife543)] 30-10-2008(31): With horns on oneself, you need a strong **neck**.

column3: The kanji shown here actually represents the "second" position in the old Chinese zodiac, which the Japanese still use as an alternate way of enumeration, much the same way that English will revert to Roman numerals. Among its many other meanings are "pure," "tasteful," "quaint," and - get this! - **fish guts**. Since it is a pictograph of a fishhook, it should not be hard to associate it with the key word.
column4: * We will keep _fishhook_ as the primitive meaning. Its shape will rarely be quite the same as that of the kanji. When it appears at the bottom of another primitive, it is straightened out, almost as if the weight of the upper element had bent it out of shape. And when it appears to the right of another element, the short horizontal line that gets the shape started is omitted and it is stretched out and narrowed, all for reasons of space and aesthetics. Examples follow.
column5: 1) [[Jeremy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jeremy)] 11-7-2006(113): This is a fish hook, that pulls out the **fishguts**.
column6: 2) [[bakamono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bakamono)] 20-8-2007(41): You cut a fish in a z shape on the belly to make it easier to open the fish and rip out its **fish guts** silly!
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 3-11-2007(35): "Knife goes in, guts come out" (-Bart Simpson's mantra as he guts fish in "30 Minutes Over Tokyo"). To be more specific: first, cut a 乙 -shape in the belly of the fish, **second** , pull the **fishguts** out. (Note that the most common meaning of this kanji is not 'fishguts' as Heisig connotates, but 'second').
column8: 4) [[Cruger](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cruger)] 26-7-2008(25): Fishgutz.
column9: 5) [[GrimPanda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GrimPanda)] 21-9-2010(18): Really this will rarely be seen as **fishguts** as a Kanji, usually it's 2nd party, or latter, generally always meaning 2nd in some way. It's easy to remember this as "2nd" since it looks like a 2. Then just remember it's a fishhook primitive like any other kanji that changes it's meaning as a primitive.

column3: In a **riot** , manners are laid aside and tempers get short, even in so courtesy-conscious a land as Japan. This kanji shows what happens to a **rioting** _tongue_ : it gets "barbed" like a _fishhook_ , and sets to attacking the opposition, to _hook_ them as it were.
column5: 1) [[rotifera](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rotifera)] 11-11-2007(216): The **riot** police broke up the **riot** by dragging the **riot** ers away by their _tongues_ with _fishooks_.
column6: 2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 18-8-2007(87): A _tongue_ with a _hook_ can cause a **riot**.
column7: 3) [[lostdog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lostdog)] 20-12-2007(56): If my daughter took her _tongue_ and pierced it with a _fishhook_ , that would cause her mother and I to **riot**!
column8: 4) [[Xtophe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Xtophe)] 7-9-2006(31): During a _riot_ in a totalitarian country, the leftist's _tongues_ are _fishhooked_ by the police ( a way for me to remember that tongue is on the left of the kanji).
column9: 5) [[pollodepalo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pollodepalo)] 11-11-2008(16): **Riot** ers are punks with fish hooks in their tongues.

column3: Begin with the top two primitives, _needle_ and _eye_. Together they represent the _eye of a needle_. Below them is a _fishhook_ that has been **straightened out** and its barb removed so that it can pass through the _eye of the needle_.
column5: 1) [[moojitsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/moojitsu)] 5-10-2006(333): If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital **straightaway**.
column6: 2) [[zdude255](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zdude255)] 20-3-2008(126): I caught a freaky creature with ten eyes on my fish hook, so I threw it back **straightaway**.
column7: 3) [[lilpea](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lilpea)] 26-7-2007(27): "Cross my heart, hope to die, stick a _needle_ in my _eye_ "… and sit on a _fish hook_ if I ever tell a lie! Slight variant on what kids say **straightaway** if their word is put in doubt.
column8: 4) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 22-7-2007(22): Ten eyes knew **straightaway** that there is something wrong with the hook.
column9: 5) [[ttrent](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ttrent)] 19-2-2008(17): The hook goes **straightaway** through the eye of a needle.

column3: Here is the full kanji on which the last frame is based. If you can think of a table full of carpenter's **tools** of all sorts, each equipped with its own _eye_ so that it can keep a watch over what you are doing with it, you won't have trouble later keeping the primitive and the kanji apart.
column5: 1) [[Rinifett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rinifett)] 25-9-2007(200): Keep an eye on your **tool** s while you work at the table.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 27-8-2007(107): One **tool** nobody should be without - a Mordor-type eye that floats over the workbench. It jerks around, monitoring all who come near, and if anyone so much as removes a stapler from the bench - ZAP.
column7: 3) [[alimasag](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alimasag)] 28-10-2007(83): You need a strong **tool** to remove the legs from a shellfish.
column8: 4) [[jonmayes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonmayes)] 11-7-2008(26): You need a strong a **tool** to separate the legs from a shellfish.
column9: 5) [[wreckz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wreckz)] 23-1-2008(19): Like my shop teacher always said… In order to use any **tool** at your _workbench_ you must first make sure to wear your safety goggles to protect your _eyes_.

column3: Here again we meet the composite element, _eye of the needle_ , which here combines with _tool_ to give us a measure of what is **true** and what is not.
column5: 1) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 2-10-2007(262): A compass is a _tool_ with a _needle_ on top that points to **true** north.
column6: 2) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 5-12-2007(159): _Ten_ _tools_ are all a **true** craftsman needs.
column7: 3) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 8-9-2007(57): It's **true** that I got a needle stuck in my eye once. Luckily, we had a tool to pull the needle out from my eye. **True** story.
column8: 4) [[eltheoldsoul](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eltheoldsoul)] 12-9-2008(56): Ten eyes working together are the best tools to see what's **true**.
column9: 5) [[dmohamed](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dmohamed)] 4-7-2008(46): Cross my heart and hope to die, stick a _needle_ in my _eye_ is a _tool_ used by children to affirm what they said as being **true**.

column3: The pictograph of an I beam, like the kind used in heavy construction work on buildings and bridges, gives us the character for **craft** in general.
column4: * As a primitive element, the key word retains the meaning of _craft_ and also takes on the related meanings of _I beam_ and _artificial_.
column5: 1) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 15-11-2005(78): I consider **craft** to be one of the harder primitives to use in stories so I've personified it as Bender the **craft** y robot from Futurama who was designed to bend I-beams.
column6: 2) [[C00ki3M0nst3r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/C00ki3M0nst3r)] 29-8-2007(37): I **craft** y.
column7: 3) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 4-2-2008(30): Icraft, beautifully **craft** ed by apple!
column8: 4) [[brandon7s](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brandon7s)] 1-10-2009(23): I-beams are used to **CRAFT** skyscrapers.
column9: 5) [[TerryS](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TerryS)] 22-11-2008(23): I **CRAFT** ed an _artificial I-beam_.

column3: By combining the primitive and the kanji of the last two frames and reading the results, we get: _by one's side_ . . . _craft_. Conveniently, the **left** has traditionally been considered the  "sinister" _side_ , where dark and occult _crafts_ are cultivated. Note how the second stroke droops over to the **left** and is longer than the first.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 19-2-2008(92): The **LEFT** _side_ of my brain _posesses_ the faculties needed for logical _crafts_ , like engineering.
column6: 2) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 4-2-2008(65): The **left** _side_ of my brain, is for _crafts_.
column7: 3) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 26-5-2010(49): **FOR THOSE ABOUT TO PUZZLE OVER THE CHANGING STROKE ORDER, IT'S THIS SIMPLE:** Look at the second primitive! Here, the first stroke of _by one's side_ should match the first stroke of _craft_ so that the stroke direction alternates in writing. So 左 is written horizontal, vertical, horizontal… 右 is written vertical, horizontal, vertical… 有 is vertical, horizontal, vertical… etc. (The ONLY exception to this rule comes with elbow [[masculine/male](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/743) (#743 雄) 雄 ], which is written horizontal, vertical, vertical(ish)…).
column8: 4) [[martin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/martin)] 22-11-2005(35): To remember which one is right/left, think "(l)Eft", as it contains the katakana "e".
column9: 5) [[paulk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paulk)] 29-7-2007(24): Sinister craft is done with the **left** hand.

column3: When thinking of the key word **right** , in order to avoid confusion with the previous frame, take advantage of the double meaning here, too. Imagine a little _mouth_ hanging down by your _side_  \- like a little voice of conscience - telling you the **right** thing to do. Here the second stroke should reach out to the **right** and be drawn slightly longer than the first.
column5: 1) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 31-3-2011(61): The **right** hand is for putting food in your _mouth_. (The other hand is for ass-wiping!). 左右 (さゆう) : left and **right** , influence, control, domination, 右 (みぎ) : **right** hand side.
column6: 2) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 4-2-2008(53): The **right** _side_ of my brain is for _speaking_.
column7: 3) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 28-7-2007(50): Always keep your **right** to free speech (mouth) by your side!
column8: 4) [[nesert](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nesert)] 27-9-2009(13): _By my side_ is a big _mouth_ who thinks they're always **right**.
column9: 5) [[hissatsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hissatsu)] 17-6-2010(7): A voice of reason _by your side_ steers you **right**.

column3: The picture here is of someone with a slab of _meat_ dangling _by the side_ , perhaps from a belt or rope tied around the waist. Think of it as an evil spirit in **possession** of one's soul, who can be exorcized only by allowing fresh _meat_ to hang _by one's side_ until it begins to putrefy and stink so bad that the demon departs. Take careful note of the stroke order.
column5: 1) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 7-9-2007(221): **Possess** ed by the Earth's gravity, the moon stays by its side.
column6: 2) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 12-3-2007(47): By my side I **POSSESS** a _moon of flesh_ , better known as your big ass!
column7: 3) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 18-1-2007(32): To **possess** = have or own something. In the fight for survival in prehistoric times, the most important thing to **possess** was meat by your side which could be eaten at any time. Imagine a caveman after a hunt having meat by his side.
column8: 4) [[Jeromin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jeromin)] 21-12-2008(29): The moon stood by my side: I was **possess** ed, a lunatic.
column9: 5) [[xzseth](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xzseth)] 15-4-2009(21): With the moon at my side I transform into a werewolf. Oh no, I am **possess** ed.

column3: To the left we have the primitive for a _shellfish_ , and to the right the kanji we just learned for _possess_. Keep the connotation of the last frame for the word _possess_ , and now expand your image of _shells_ to include the ancient value they had as money (a usage that will come in very helpful later on). Now one who is _possessed_ by _shells_ is likely to abandon any higher principles to acquire more and more wealth. These are the easiest ones to **bribe** with a few extra _shells_.
column5: 1) [[Jiten](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jiten)] 16-3-2006(185): To **bribe** someone, money is a necessary possession.
column6: 2) [[martinirwin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/martinirwin)] 23-10-2007(162): If you possess enough shellfish, you can **bribe** anyone.
column7: 3) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 28-11-2007(58): In order to **bribe** me you will have to give me all the _clams_ you _possess_.
column8: 4) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 25-2-2008(34): A **shellfish** is not the 'right' **possession** to **bribe** with. (It's on the left).
column9: 5) [[Branduil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Branduil)] 22-2-2006(22): If money is what possesses you, you will accept many **bribe** s.

column3: A **tribute** has a kind of double-meaning in English: honor paid freely and _money_ collected by coercion. Simply because a ruler bestows a noble name on a deed is hardly any consolation to the masses who must part with their hard- earned _money_. Little wonder that this ancient _craft_ of getting _money_ by calling it a **tribute** has given way to a name closer to how it feels to those who pay it: a tax.
column5: 1) [[Aploosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aploosh)] 27-6-2007(326): "This next song is a **TRIBUTE** to a little SHELLFISH friend of mine who was tragically crushed by an I-shaped table.".
column6: 2) [[ablindmouse](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ablindmouse)] 28-8-2007(114): **Tribute** is the craft of raising money.
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 4-11-2007(46): I gladly pay my **tribute** to the tax collector: but what he doesn't know is that this is carely _craft_ ed _money_ \- counterfeit!
column8: 4) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 16-1-2011(45): **Tribute** is another form of taxation - a _craft_ y way of collecting " _clams_ " (money). 貢献 (こうけん) : contribution, services, 西貢 さいごん Saigon.
column9: 5) [[Po0py](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Po0py)] 14-12-2008(36): We must pay **tribute** to the crafty shellfish who always appears in our kanji.

column3: To the right we see a _head_ and to the left an element that means _craft_. When we think of a **paragraph** , we immediately think of a _heading_ device to break a text into parts. (Think of the elaborate _heads_ often seen at the start of medieval manuscripts and the task becomes easier still.) Just where and how to do it belongs to the writer's _craft_. Hence, we define **paragraphing** as the  " _heading craft_ " to remember this character.
column5: 1) [[crazy88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crazy88)] 19-9-2007(237): To write a **paragraph** is the _craft_ of grouping sentences on a _page_.
column6: 2) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 5-2-2008(115): To _craft_ a _page_ well, we need **paragraph** s.
column7: 3) [[martinirwin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/martinirwin)] 2-12-2007(45): Page and craft = pacraft -> paracraft, said properly as **paragraph**.
column8: 4) [[libsrone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/libsrone)] 15-1-2009(23): Well, I tried using craft and headings and pages and none of it stuck, so: Reading a block of text that isn't broken down into **paragraph** s makes me want to hit myself in the head with an I-beam.
column9: 5) [[therapysessions](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/therapysessions)] 3-1-2009(14): A well CRAFTED PAGE is full of beautiful **PARAGRAPH** S.

column3: Although this character no longer looks very much like a **sword** , it does have some resemblance to the handle of the **sword**. This is to our advantage, in that it helps us keep make a distinction between two primitive elements based on this kanji.
column4: * In the form of the kanji, this primitive means a _dagger_. When it appears to the right of another element, it is commonly stretched out and takes the sense of a great and flashing _saber_ , a meaning it gets from a character we shall learn later (Frame 1801).
column5: 1) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 15-8-2008(134): This **SWORD** is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.
column6: 2) [[mrcool](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mrcool)] 22-5-2008(47): If you look really close this kanji looks like a person bending over touching the ground Waiting for someone to put there **sword** in his ass!
column7: 3) [[saturnine13](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saturnine13)] 3-9-2009(44): Samurai carry two **sword** s on their belt: a curved katana and a straighter, shorter wakizashi.
column8: 4) [[snifty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snifty)] 17-2-2009(15): Looks like the handle on a pirate cutlass, a kind of **sword**.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 6-1-2006(14): Note : this is the kanji for the famous Japanese **sword** , also pronounced かたな (katana). As a primitive when it is compressed on the right of a kanji, its meaning becomes "saber". In that case I like to associate the image of a ninja, making sure to keep it distinct from the "samurai". The samurai would be the historical japanese warrior, while the ninja would be the more stealthy character popularised through modern martial arts movies.

column3: Think of using a _dagger_ as a razor **blade** , and it shouldn't be hard to imagine cutting yourself. See the little _drop of_ blood clinging to the **blade**?

column3: To the right we see the _dagger_ and next to it the number _seven_ whose primitive meaning we decided would be _diced_ (Frame 7). It is hard to think of **cutting** anything with a knife without imagining one of those skillful Japanese chefs. Only let us say that he has had too much to drink at a party, grabs a _dagger_ lying on the mantelpiece and starts _dicing_ up everything insight, starting with the hors d'oeuvres and going on to the furniture and the carpets....

Imagine the seven samurai flailing about the kitchen dangerously swinging their katanas about, to **cut** stuff up for dinner.).

column3: A _sword_ or _dagger_ posed over a _mouth_ is how the character for "beckoning" is written. The related but less tame key word **seduce** was chosen because it seemed to fit better with the - how shall we put it? - Freudian implications of the kanji. (Observe if you will that it is not sure whether the long slender object is **seducing** the small round one or vice versa.)
column4: * The primitive meaning remains the same: _seduce_. Just be sure to associate it with a very concrete image.
column5: 1) [[arekuru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/arekuru)] 24-6-2008(172): A man is easily **seduce** d by a mouth to his "sword.".

column7: 3) [[rakutenka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rakutenka)] 2-7-2007(87): To **seduce** is to make a _sword_ of one's _mouth_.
column8: 4) [[rotifera](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rotifera)] 11-11-2007(23): To **seduce** is to accomplish with the _mouth_ what cannot (or should not) be done with a _sword_.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 7-8-2008(17): 召す 【めす】 (v5s,vt) (1) to call, to send for, (2) to put on, to wear, to take (a bath), to ride in, to buy, to eat, to drink, to catch (a cold), (P) This kanji isn't anything sexual or anything. It means SUMMON/TO SEND/CALL FOR (as well as honorific form of eat/drink). STORY: A king is having a hard time EATING a piece of of meat b/c it can't fit in his MOUTH, so he CALLS FOR/SUMMONS someone to bring him his SWORD. (this keeps the eat/drink meaning of the kanji true as well).

column3: The character depicts a _clam_ alongside a great and flashing _saber_. Think of digging for _clams_ in an area where there are gaming **rules** governing how large a find has to be before you can keep it. So you take your trusty _saber_ , which you have carefully notched like a yardstick, crack open a _clam_ and then measure the poor little beastie to see if it is as long as the **rules** say it has to be.

column3: The key word **vice** has the sense of someone second-in-command. The great and flashing _saber_ to the right (its usual location, so you need not worry about where to put it from now on) and the _wealth_ on the left combine to create an image of dividing one's property to give a share to one's **vice** - _wealth_ holder.
column5: 1) [[geisel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/geisel)] 27-4-2007(174): The _wealthy_ guy with the _sword_ standing next to the king, that's the **vice-** roy who does all the dirty work.
column6: 2) [[applesuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/applesuki)] 10-2-2006(106): **Vice-** president Cheney: a wealthy saber rattler.
column7: 3) [[demiurge](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/demiurge)] 22-3-2008(92): **Vice-** President Cheney shot a man in the face while hunting, as is common knowledge, I imagine. So think of it like a Clue answer and you will remember the symbol order as well. _One_ shot, in the _mouth_ , on a _field_ , with a _gun_ (a modern-day sword).
column8: 4) [[Jeromin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jeromin)] 21-12-2008(18): The Shogun's second in command, handling the wages: One mouth controlling the rice fields to pay for the swords (Japanese samurai got paid in rice).
column9: 5) [[frychiko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/frychiko)] 25-5-2008(17): The VICE president protected my WEALTH with his army of SABER wielding soldiers.

column3: In the Old East, the samurai and his _saber_ were never **separated**. They were constant companions, like the cowboy of the Old West and his six-shooter. This character depicts what must have been the height of **separation** -anxiety for a samurai: to be _bound up with a rope_ and unable to get at his _saber_ leaning only a few feet away from him. Look at that _mouth_ bellowing out for shame and sorrow! Note the order in which the element for _tied up_ is written - just as it had been with the character for _ten thousand_.
column5: 1) [[leviathan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/leviathan)] 20-3-2006(154): I don't know about you but to me this seems like someone's head is about to be **separate** d from his body. You can see he's kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take.
column6: 2) [[thatkidpercy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thatkidpercy)] 16-11-2007(119): A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their _mouths bound up_ to keep them quiet) in a **separate** room from his _sabers_. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.
column7: 3) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 3-8-2007(69): The prisoner with the BOUND MOUTH was **separate** d from his SABRE.
column8: 4) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 12-11-2009(16): They **separate** d me from the group. They gagged my _mouth_ , _bound_ me up, and threatened me with a _saber_.
column9: 5) [[canji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/canji)] 3-1-2010(13): In Empire Strikes Back, Luke was hanging upside down, muttered with his _mouth_ "Ben, Ben, Ben", his feet _bound_ in ice, he was **separated** from his light _sabre_. And he could hear the monster coming for him.

column3: The picture here is of a **street** sign on a long pole: Hollywood and Vine, if you please, or any _street_ that immediately conjure sup the image of a **street** sign to you.
column4: * Used as a primitive, we change the meaning of the key word and take the shape to signify a _nail_ or a _spike_. Should it happen, on reviewing, that you find the pictographs get jumbled, then think of jerking a _street_ sign out of the ground and using it as a _nail_ to repair your garage roof.
column5: 1) [[steves](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/steves)] 10-10-2007(167): Today, the program "Sesame **Street** " is brought to you by the letter "T".
column6: 2) [[yoshi_features](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yoshi_features)] 5-4-2008(82): Two **street** s make a T-intersection.
column7: 3) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 24-9-2007(22): Any **street** with _nails_ on it had best be avoided.
column8: 4) [[Daffydus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Daffydus)] 3-6-2009(16): The **street** sign is nailed with a spike.
column9: 5) [[rakutenka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rakutenka)] 2-7-2007(14): The word on the **street** is, "Mr. T is a bad-ass!".

column3: _Street_ signs standing at the corner of the _rice fields_ depict the **village** limits. (Remember what was said earlier: when used as a primitive, a kanji may either take its primitive meaning or revert to the original meaning of its key word.)
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 19-11-2006(150): Actually this means **town** , like one that has lots of _streets_ and is surrounded by all the _rice fields_.
column6: 2) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 20-8-2008(84): Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. "Pillage the **village** , for the _rice_ and and the _tea_." the street primitive on the right looks like a 't'.
column7: 3) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 25-8-2007(63): Note: the keywords of [village](../v4/92.html) (#92 町) and [town](../v4/208.html) (#208 村) swap places in translated editions of RTK I. In fact, according to different dictionaries, 町 is closer to 'town' whereas 村 is closer to 'village'.
column8: 4) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 1-7-2008(20): _Streets_ through _rice fields_ are only found in small **villages**.
column9: 5) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 29-3-2008(13): チョウ まち A **village** /TOWN is nothing more than rice fields connected by streets.

column3: Remember the story about the "Little Engine that **Could** " when you hear this key word, and the rest is simple. See the determined little locomotive huffing and puffing up the mountain - "I think I **can** , I think I **can**.... " \- spitting railroad _spikes_ out of its _mouth_ as it chews up the line to the top.
column5: 1) [[moojitsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/moojitsu)] 10-10-2006(193): A mouth on the street asking for things: "Can I get some help?! **Can** I get directions, **Can** I have some money? **Can** you please speak English?!".
column6: 2) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 8-1-2008(88): I **can** eat nails.
column7: 3) [[annabel398](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/annabel398)] 17-8-2008(34): On Main STREET America, what you hear in people's MOUTHs is "Yes We **CAN**!".
column8: 4) [[Phil_Spring](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Phil_Spring)] 19-7-2009(29): A square box **can** fit in a corner.
column9: 5) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 12-2-2008(18): **Can** you _speak_ _street_? (as in street _talk_ ).

column3: The key word is actually a formal metaphor meaning "humble acceptance." Reading off the two primitive elements in the order of their writing, we have: _nail_ . . . _head_. As in  "hitting the _nail_ on the _head_. " Now one presumes that most people can handle metaphors, but if you were to run into a dimwit working in a hardware store who only knew the literal meaning of things, and were to ask him, in your best Japanese, to **place on your head** a nail, he might miss the point and cause you considerable torment.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 30-8-2007(284): If I put a _street sign_ on my _head_ what do I get ? A **place on the head** !
column6: 2) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 7-2-2008(68): _NAILS_ \- **place directly on the _fore_ head**, _NAILS_ \- **place directly on the _fore_ head**, _NAILS_ \- **place directly on the _fore_ head**, The **HEAD ON** commercial _nail_ s it into your _head_ ……
column7: 3) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 25-2-2008(57): You've probably noticed that even the rudest and crudest Japanese say "Itadakimasu" before every meal. Why? Because each person who failed to say it as a child had a _nail_ driven straight into that tender **PLACE ON THE HEAD** (i.e. the very top of the head). That's a lesson no one will forget!
column8: 4) [[wfreeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wfreeman)] 3-2-2007(52): Driving down the STREET, looking at a PAGE in the map, I hit another car, and started bleeding from a **place on the head**.
column9: 5) [[Matty0187](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matty0187)] 30-7-2009(21): _Nail_ the _page_ to the wall! _Place_ a Bounty _On the head_.

column3: This kanji is a pictograph of a **child** wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young **children** who cannot get around by themselves. The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air, the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up, and the final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother's neck.
column4: * As a primitive, the meaning of _child_ is retained, though you might imagine a little older _child_ , able to run around and get into more mischief.
column5: 1) [[lbphenom](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lbphenom)] 12-1-2008(43): A **child** who is _ten_ will still ask for his _ma_ (top looks a bit like katakana ma).
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 28-1-2008(30): A pictograph of a **child** , with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).
column7: 3) [[Po0py](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Po0py)] 15-12-2008(21): A ten year old **child** with a baseball cap.
column8: 4) [[Jeromin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jeromin)] 21-12-2008(9): A **child** , from one to ten, before becoming a teen.
column9: 5) [[NyahK](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NyahK)] 6-6-2010(6): I'd imagine most people knew this long before starting RTK. When they were still a **child** of kanji, perhaps?

column3: Probably the one thing most _children_ fear more than anything else is the dentist's chair. Once a _child_ has seen a dentist holding the x-rays up to the light and heard that ominous word **cavity** , even though it is not likely to know that the word means "hole" until it is much older, it will not be long before those two syllables get associated with the drill and that row of shiny _hooks_ the dentist uses to torture people who are too small to fight back.
column5: 1) [[ssmoler](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ssmoler)] 21-6-2007(157): The child's arms flailed around at the sight of the hooked tool the dentist was going to use to fill his **cavity**.
column6: 2) [[thequietfox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thequietfox)] 20-1-2008(93): I warned him about **cavities** , but the _child_ is still _hooked_ on sweets.
column7: 3) [[ederu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ederu)] 26-11-2008(36): When a _child_ falls into a **cavity** we need a _hook_ to get them out.
column8: 4) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 8-7-2009(19): A _child hooked_ on candy canes (sweets) is bound to get a **cavity**.
column9: 5) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 29-3-2008(10): コウ // HOLE // "Confucius pulled the child out of the hole using a big hook." 鼻孔 （びこう）nostril. 孔子 （こうし）Confucius.

column3: Learn this character by returning to frame 99 and the image given there. The only difference is that the "arms" have been left off (actually, only tucked inside). Thus a _child_ with its arms wrapped up into the back-sack is the picture of a job successfully **completed**.
column5: 1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 8-9-2007(252): The experiment was a **complete** failure! The child was made without any arms!
column6: 2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 23-7-2007(73): A child with the arms inside the blanket will be **complete** ly wrapped up.
column7: 3) [[P2daGn3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/P2daGn3)] 2-6-2008(56): The child in not **complete**. He's got no arms!
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 23-12-2008(42): Don't be tempted to write another stroke and make 子 . This kanji, 了 , is already **complete**.
column9: 5) [[burritokun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burritokun)] 8-8-2008(21): No parent can say their child rearing is **complete** until the child stops holding out his hand for money.

column3: You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting **woman** drawn behind this character, with two legs at the bottom, two arms (the horizontal line) and the head poking out the top. A little farfetched, until you draw the character and feel the grace and flow of the three simple strokes. Remembering the kanji is easy, being able to write it beautifully is another thing.
column4: * The primitive meaning is the same: _woman_.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 14-1-2007(216): To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a "kunoichi". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一 (kanji, ichi=one).

column9: 5) [[dystopian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dystopian)] 20-1-2011(4): To remember the stroke order, a female ninja is called a " くノ一 ".

column3: The phrase "to be **fond** of someone " has a natural gentleness about it, and lends a tenderness to the sense of touching by giving us the related term "to **fondle**. " The character likens it to a _woman_ **fondling** her _child_.
column5: 1) [[snozle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snozle)] 8-10-2006(182): A _woman_ is **fond** of her _child_.
column6: 2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 23-7-2007(13): Women are **fond** of children.
column7: 3) [[bakamono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bakamono)] 20-8-2007(7): If you are **fond** of a _woman_ , she will make you a _child_.
column8: 4) [[geisel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/geisel)] 11-11-2006(7): Your wife and child: the thing you are most **fond** of.
column9: 5) [[carperhe1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/carperhe1)] 16-7-2008(5): There is no **fond** ness greater than what a _woman_ feels for her _child_.

column3: Pardon me if I revert to the venerable old Dr. Freud again, but his eye for symbolism is often helpful to appreciate things that more earthy imaginations once accepted more freely but that we have learned to cover over with a veneer of etiquette. For instance, the fact that things like the _mouth_ of a cave served as natural ritual substitutes for the opening through which a _woman_ gives birth. Hence, in order to be reborn as an adult, one may have to pass through the psychological equivalent of the womb, that is, something that bears a **likeness** to the _opening_ of the _woman_ from whom you were born.
column5: 1) [[smujohnson](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smujohnson)] 17-7-2008(363): _Women_ share a common **likeness**. Their _mouth_ s are always open, whining about this and that.
column6: 2) [[At0m5k](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/At0m5k)] 21-8-2008(133): A _woman_ 's _mouth_ has the **likeness** of a vaccum cleaner, it's noisy and all it's good for is sucking. Do not confuse with [resemblance](../v4/114.html) (#114 肖). **Likeness** is purely conceptual, whereas resemblance refers to actual physical similarities.
column7: 3) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 25-9-2006(105): From a woman's other 口 comes a baby with a perfect **likeness**.
column8: 4) [[PrettyKitty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PrettyKitty)] 2-7-2007(53): As a woman with a big mouth, Angelina Jolie was a perfect **likeness** for Lara Croft.
column9: 5) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 30-6-2009(51): Women share one **likeness** : They have a big mouth! (I don't actually hold this view at all, but it does make it easy to remember).

column3: Look closely at this kanji and you will find the outline of the kanji for _woman_ in it, the second stroke of which has been expanded to make space for the two breasts that make her a **mama**. Likening this sound to a baby nursing at its mother's breast has afforded some scholars of comparative linguistics a way to explain the presence of the same word across a wide range of language groups.
column4: * As a primitive we shall add the meaning of _breasts_ in accord with the explanation given above. Take careful note of the fact that the form is altered slightly when this kanji serves as a primitive, the final two dots joining together to form a longer stroke. An example follows in the next frame.
column5: 1) [[mr_hans_moleman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mr_hans_moleman)] 5-7-2007(76): The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.
column6: 2) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 14-10-2007(34): This **mama** had twins, one _mouth_ for each _nipple_.
column7: 3) [[kat1420](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kat1420)] 11-3-2008(16): To remember strokes: it's a _breast_ exam: 1)start like a _woman_ 2) cross your heart (the lower right is crossed) 3) check your "nipples" 4) lift and separate (the last stroke parts the two "breasts").
column8: 4) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 11-2-2010(13): _L7_ … To remember the strokes: this begins by writing "L7", which is 50s slang for "square" or uncool. (As a teenager I thought my **mama** was really square) Add the "nipples" and then use the last stroke to part the two "breasts"… 母 [はは] [、お母さん](midori://search?text=、お母さん) [おかあさん] [、母乳](midori://search?text=、母乳) [ぼにゅう] [、伯母](midori://search?text=、伯母) /叔母[おば].
column9: 5) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 23-7-2007(13): The **mama** has two babies (drops) in the cradle.

column3: If one is asked to think of associations for the word **pierce** , among the first to come to mind is that of **piercing** one's ears to hold earrings, a quite primitive form of self-mutilation that has survived into the 21st century. The kanji here is read, top to bottom: _mama_ . . . _oyster_. All you need to do is imagine **piercing** an ear so that it can hold a mother-of- pearl (actually, a _mama_ -of-pearl) you have just wrested from an _oyster_.
column5: 1) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 12-2-2008(190): Ariel the Little Mermaid's _clamshell_ bra was held to her _breasts_ by **piercings**.
column6: 2) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 28-11-2007(67): The sad fate of _Mama_ _shellfish_ was to be captured and **pierced** to make an earring.
column7: 3) [[snozle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snozle)] 21-10-2006(40): _mama_ **pierces** her ears in order to wear pearl earrings (which come from _shellfish_ ).
column8: 4) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 3-6-2008(25): Boobs **PIERCE** D by shellfish! AAAH!!!
column9: 5) [[Samchan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Samchan)] 9-2-2009(22): "Mama" sat on a "shellfish" and it **pierce** d her bottom! Ow!

column3: By now kanji like this one should "look like" something to you even though it is more of an "ideogram" than a "pictograph." The large _mouth_ on top and the _human legs_ below almost jump off the page as a caricature of **elder brother** , the one with the big _mouth_ (or if you prefer a kinder image, the one who  "has the say" among all the children).
column4: * As a primitive this character will take the meaning of _teenager_ , in accord with the familiar image of the big _mouth_ and the gangling, clumsy _legs_.

column8: 4) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 7-11-2008(10): My **elder brother** has a big MOUTH and LONG LEGS.
column9: 5) [[Teango](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Teango)] 8-3-2010(9): My **elder brother** always let his _mouth_ _run_.

column3: For some reason, the inventor of this kanji associated a **curse** with the _mouth_ of an _older brother_. I leave it to you to decide if he is on the giving or receiving end of the sorcery.
column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 24-6-2008(107): Caution: this means a spell, not to swear. I put a **curse** on my _elder brother_ so that he can never open his _mouth_.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 14-2-2007(22): Your _older brother_ 's _mouth_ often **curses**.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-2-2007(15): There's an ancient **curse** in this region whereby the firstborn son, i.e. the _elder brother_ , is always born with an extra _mouth_. And regardless of the elder brother's own personality, the extra mouth is bad tempered and always **cursing**.

column9: 5) [[terozen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/terozen)] 10-2-2012(3): It's interesting how Halparn, Henshall and "Kanji Learners Dictionary" all forfeit to include this kanji, yet kana-heavy games like Final Fantasy assumes their gamer has knowledge of this kanji. Just sayin'. Story: I put a **curse** on the _mouth_ of my _older brother_ to shut him up. He's an annoying bugger, after all.

column3: In this frame we get a chance to use the kanji we just learned in its primitive meaning of _teenager_. The _needle_ on top indicates one of the major problems confronting the _teenager_ growing up in today's world: drugs. Many of them will fall under the shadow of the _needle_ at some time during those tender years, but only when a whole generation rises up and decides that "We Shall **Overcome** " the plague, will the _needle_ cease to hangover their heads, as it does in this character.
column5: 1) [[wfreeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wfreeman)] 3-2-2007(184): Ten elder brothers can **overcome** anything.

column7: 3) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 12-2-2008(29): **Overcome** your _elder brother_ with a _needle_ to his head.
column8: 4) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 29-11-2008(24): Having **ten** older brothers would be hard to **overcome**. **Ten** mouths, and **ten** sets of legs kicking the crap out of you.
column9: 5) [[FauxSho](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FauxSho)] 16-3-2013(19): _Ten teenagers_ were chosen to **OVERCOME** all odds and save the world. The start of almost every JRPG.

column3: The sense of **little** that this character represents is not the same as  "a little bit." That meaning comes in the next frame. Here **little** means "small" or "tiny." The image is one of three **little** _drops_ , the first of which (the one in the middle) is written larger so that the kanji has some shape to it. The point of writing it three times is to rub the point in: **little** , **little** , nothing but **little**.
column4: * The primitive of the same shape keeps the same meaning. Written above a horizontal line, its form is slightly altered, the last two strokes turning inwards.
column5: 1) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 3-9-2008(121): A **little** penguin with its wings at its side.
column6: 2) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 13-9-2007(37): A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he's too **little** to ride the roller coaster.
column7: 3) [[moojitsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/moojitsu)] 11-10-2006(17): Hold something **little** in-between your fingertips and it'll look like this Kanji here. :).

column9: 5) [[Uli_S](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Uli_S)] 10-9-2009(10): Ohh, how cute - a **little** penguin!

column3: First we need to look at the fourth stroke, the _drop_ at the bottom that has been extended into a longer diagonal stroke leaning left. This happens because a single, isolated drop will NEVER appear beneath its relative primitive in its normal size, for fear it would drop off and get lost. As for the meaning, let the tiny _drop_ indicate a further belittling of what is already _little_ \- thus making it a **few** of something _little_.
column5: 1) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 6-2-2008(129): Only a **few** people can make an ugly face like that.
column6: 2) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 3-8-2007(60): **Few** usually refers to three. To emphasize three, we underline the three drops in little.
column7: 3) [[Easytarget](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Easytarget)] 3-3-2009(27): A happy grin, after a **few** drinks.
column8: 4) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 23-7-2007(21): That playground has a **few** little ones sliding down the slide.
column9: 5) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 6-10-2009(18): A **few** _little penguins_ slide belly-first down an ice _slide_.

column3: Here we have a simple pictograph of a person, taking up the space of an entire character and giving it the sense of **large**. It should not be too hard to locate the two legs and outstretched arms.
column4: * As a primitive, we need a different meaning, since the element representing the human person will come up later. Therefore, this shape will become a _large dog_ or, if you prefer, a _St. Bernard dog_. In frame 253 we will explain why this choice was made.
column5: 1) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 13-9-2007(79): A person stretching their arms and legs to look **large** and scare a bear away.
column6: 2) [[Teango](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Teango)] 8-3-2010(23): How **large**? This **large**!
column7: 3) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 23-7-2007(21): Think of a **large** St. Bernard dog with his paws all stretched out.
column8: 4) [[LeoOra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LeoOra)] 27-1-2008(13): A person ( 人 -fr.951) showing itself **large** r widening its arms.
column9: 5) [[xiteru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xiteru)] 9-10-2007(6): That volcano is so big, or **large** , it goes over the clouds (the clouds being the horizontal line).

column3: **Many** _moons_ ago,  begins much of Amerindian folklore - a colorful way of saying "Once upon a time" and a great deal of help for remembering this kanji. Here we have two _moons_  (three of them would take us back to the beginning of time, which is further than we want to go), lacking the final stroke because they are partially hidden behind the clouds of time.
column5: 1) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 13-2-2008(105): _Two evenings_ too **many**!
column6: 2) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 17-3-2006(46): This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme: "He who eats **many** prunes sits on toilet **many** _moons_ ".
column7: 3) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 3-6-2008(40): These look like the katakana "ta" therefore, There are **MANY** tatas! WOO~~~!
column8: 4) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 18-12-2007(16): The ninja waited **many** evenings for the right moment to strike.
column9: 5) [[FauxSho](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FauxSho)] 9-2-2013(13): **Many** _moons_ ago.. or perhaps it was just a couple of _evenings_ , I can't remember.

column3: Just as the word **evening** adds a touch of formality or romanticism to the ordinary word  "night," so the kanji for **evening** takes the ordinary looking _moon_ in the night sky and has a cloud pass over it (as we saw in the last frame).
column4: * The primitive keeps the same meaning and connotation as the kanji.
column5: 1) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 13-2-2008(113): The **evening** is young, the _moon_ is not full.
column6: 2) [[ctalbottclark](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ctalbottclark)] 7-3-2008(33): In the **evening** , the crescent _moon_ hangs in the sky.
column7: 3) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 23-7-2007(27): In the **evening** , I try my best to remember the katakana symbol for "TA" (ie. "ta ta!").
column8: 4) [[sprutnik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sprutnik)] 4-10-2008(19): When I come back home from work in the **evening** I say _ta_ daima.
column9: 5) [[TerryS](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TerryS)] 26-11-2008(11): This **EVENING** , there is only a half- _moon_.

column3: In the next lesson we will meet the character for morning- _tide_ and the element for _drops of water_. Meantime we have a perfect blend of picture and idea in this kanji to play on the English word for nightfall, **eventide** : _drops of water_ inching their way up the shore in the _evening_.
column5: 1) [[mcdreamer374](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcdreamer374)] 1-4-2007(163): **Eventide** is just another word for evening, and it has the word tide in it which we associate with water.
column6: 2) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 13-2-2008(72): _Drops_ of water shower the beach as the _evening_ tide approaches: **eventide**.
column7: 3) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 12-12-2007(24): **Eventide** is when the drops of water are attracted to the moon. This is the tide which occurs in the evening.
column8: 4) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 24-7-2007(10): In the **eventide** (nightfall), drops of water start forming in the evening.
column9: 5) [[maikunari](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/maikunari)] 25-7-2006(10): The viking hordes arrive on the **eventide** , water spashes as the evening sky turn red with blood.

column3: On the left, the primitive for _evening_ , and on the right, that for the _magic wand_. Now, as every magician worth his abracadabra knows, bringing your _magic wand_ out into the _evening_ air makes your magic much more powerful than if you were to stay indoors. Hence, _evening_ and _magic wand_ takes you naturally **outside**.
column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 7-7-2008(134): A young magician likes to practice **outside** in the _evening_ with his _magic wand_ (as opposed to the old magician who wakes _early_ to practice with his _wand_ in [eminent](../v4/51.html) (#51 卓)).
column6: 2) [[jondesousa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jondesousa)] 19-6-2006(77): **Outside** in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.
column7: 3) [[toddiceton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/toddiceton)] 16-11-2008(58): Your _evening_ is successful if you get to pull your _wand_ **outside** your pants.
column8: 4) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 27-9-2007(15): Fairies live **outside** , and only come out in the _evening_. When they do, they wave their _magic wands_ as they dance.
column9: 5) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 11-2-2010(13): All the gaikokujin ( 外国人 =" **outside** country person") guys in Roppongi on a Saturday _evening_ are looking to get their _magic wands_ polished… 外す [はずす] [、外](midori://search?text=、外) [そと] [、外国人](midori://search?text=、外国人) [がいこくじん].

column3: Perhaps you have heard of the custom, still preserved in certain African tribes, of a father creeping into the tent or hut of his newborn child on the night of the child's birth, to whisper into its ear the **name** he has chosen for it, before making his choice public. It is an impressive **naming** custom and fits in tidily with the way this character is constructed: _evening_ . . . _mouth_. At _evening_ time, a _mouth_ pronounces the **name** that will accompany one throughout life.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 24-7-2007(165): In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your **name** so that people can recognise you.
column6: 2) [[panikbuton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/panikbuton)] 20-1-2008(81): In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my **name**.
column7: 3) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 2-6-2006(34): Because it's dark in the _evening_ , you need to open your _mouth_ and speak your **name** to identify yourself. (This is a traditional mnemonic for this kanji).
column8: 4) [[vinniram](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vinniram)] 24-5-2009(19): In African tradition, the father sneaks up to the baby in the EVENING, and whispers using his MOUTH the **NAME** which the baby will carry for his entire life.
column9: 5) [[jay168](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jay168)] 27-9-2009(9): My real **name** is eveningmouth, but you can call me Bob :).

column3: With a _mouth_ under a _cliff_ , what else could we have here but the entrance to a secret cavern, before which a great **stone** has been rolled so that none may enter. Perhaps it is the hiding place where Ali Baba and his band of thieves have stored their treasures, in which case that magic word known to every school child who ever delighted over the tales of the _Arabian Nights_ should be enough to push the **stone** aside. But take care - the _cliff_ is steep, and one slip will send you tumbling down into the ravine below. This is the one and only time that the second stroke in _cliff_ will reach over to the middle of the horizontal stroke. If you think of the edge jutting outwards (in keeping with the story above), the problem should be taken care of.
column4: * The _stone_ is a quite common primitive element, which is not restricted to great boulders but used of _stones_ or _rocks_ of any size or shape.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 31-12-2007(142): Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of _cliff_ just in time to evade the huge **STONE** rolling out of the _mouth_ of the cave!
column6: 2) [[Nayelianne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nayelianne)] 19-9-2008(37): There's a VERY simple way to remember this, in case the _cliff_ thing isn't working for you… Just see it as a **stone** [いし] being _hammered_ by a miner searching for jewel **stone** s [ほう **せき** ] ,).
column7: 3) [[Uli_S](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Uli_S)] 4-9-2009(33): If you pick the _right_ **stone** , and hit the kanji 右 _right_ on its head really hard, you can chip off the upper stroke from it.
column8: 4) [[ssavage2004](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ssavage2004)] 20-8-2006(22): A [mouth](../v4/11.html) (#11 口) open beneath a cliff is bound to swallow some **stone**.
column9: 5) [[zer0range](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zer0range)] 19-3-2009(14): A **stone** covers the entrance to a cave hidden under a cliff.

column3: The word **resemblance** should suggest, among other things, a son's **resemblance** to his father. A  "chip off the old block" is the way we often put it, but the character is more simple. It speaks of a _little_ bit of _flesh_.
column4: * When used as a primitive, the sense of _resemblance_ is replaced by that of _spark_ or _candle_. (If you want an explanation: the kanji for _moon_ also carries a secondary sense of _fire_ , which we omitted because we are keeping that meaning for other primitives.)
column5: 1) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 12-1-2007(246): Using DNA matching, a very little bit of flesh can be used to show the **resemblence** between family members.
column6: 2) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 29-1-2008(122): Hey baby, it might be a _little_ bit of _flesh_ now, but in a moment it'll bear a strong **resemblance** to a _candlestick_.(nudge nudge, wink wink).
column7: 3) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 19-10-2007(83): This kanji bears a **resemblance** to sparks on a candle. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.).
column8: 4) [[FloconDeNeige](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FloconDeNeige)] 19-2-2010(28): _**あやか-る**_ : to share, goodluck—Resemblance = To have LITTLE difference in the FLESH.
column9: 5) [[czaplinsky](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/czaplinsky)] 18-11-2007(18): God breathing a _sparkle_ of life into _flesh_ to make human **resemblant** to him.

column3: The word **nitrate** should immediately suggest a beaker of **nitric** acid, which, as every high-school chemistry student knows, can eat its way through some pretty tough substances. Here we imagine pouring it over a _rock_ and watching the _sparks_ fly as it bores a hole through the rock.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 10-7-2007(174): That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured **nitrate** acid on it.
column6: 2) [[Xtophe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Xtophe)] 18-9-2006(74): Salpetre is the common name for **Nitrate** coming from Latin "sal petrae" or _stone_ salt. It is also a component of gun powder so including a _candle_ in this kanji can be quite explosive!
column7: 3) [[nurupo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nurupo)] 24-4-2008(41): People I study Kanji with kept talking about some **nitrate**. I didn't even know what **nitrate** is, so I hit them with a stone so hard there were sparks flying everywhere. Months later my cell-mate in jail told me it's some sort of acid, but I didn't care any more… Thanks to this Kanji I got 30 years, thank you.
column8: 4) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 25-2-2008(18): That stone resembles **nitrate**.
column9: 5) [[bakamono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bakamono)] 30-9-2007(16): A stone containing **nitrate** and a candle are not good together.

column3: We begin with the two elements on the right, _baseball_ and _needle_. Since they will be coming together from time to time, let us give the two of them the sense of a _game of cricket_ in which a _needle_ is laid across the wicket. Then imagine using a _rock_ for a ball. A **smash** hit would probably splinter the bat in all directions, and a **smashing** pitch would do the same with the _needle_ wicket.
column5: 1) [[kendobc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kendobc)] 18-5-2008(338): To **SMASH** a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.
column6: 2) [[Shounenbat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shounenbat)] 8-10-2007(73): The Stones (the Rolling Stones) are 90 aged but they've done a new **SMASH** hit!
column7: 3) [[rotifera](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rotifera)] 12-11-2007(33): Hulk **smash**! Hulk **smash** _stone_! Hulk decimate _stone_! What does "decimate" mean, Hulk? Uh, means destroy _nine_ _tenths_ of. **SMASH**!
column8: 4) [[Clouded](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Clouded)] 27-6-2008(23): A _stone_ will **smash** a car-window _nine_ times out of _ten_.
column9: 5) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 4-8-2008(17): Hulk **SMASH**! Hulk throw ROCK! Hulk hit 9 people! No! Hulk hit 10 people! Bad people! Hulk **smash**!

column3: Good **sand** for beaches has _few_ or no _stones_ in it. That means that all of us whose feet have been spoiled by too much time in shoes don't have to watch our step as we cavort about.
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 31-5-2006(143): Here's how I remember that _stone_ is on the left. This is because **sand** starts as _stones_ , and only later they become _few_.
column6: 2) [[TerryS](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TerryS)] 26-11-2008(112): In good **SAND** , _stones_ are _few_ , if any.
column7: 3) [[nagisa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nagisa)] 5-3-2007(28): Over time, _rocks_ are worn down into just a _few_ grains of **sand**.
column8: 4) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 24-7-2007(27): To make **sand** , start by grinding a few stones.
column9: 5) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 4-6-2009(11): **Sand** has _stones_ _few_ and far between. 砂 【すな】 (n) **sand** , grit, 砂糖 【さとう】 (n) sugar,.

column3: It should not be hard to leep from the key word to the image of a _woman_ who is **jealous** of the _rock_ that another _woman_ is sporting on the third finger of her left hand.
column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 18-5-2007(75): The **jealous** _woman_ bashed the brains in of the guy who betrayed her, with a _stone_.
column6: 2) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 6-11-2011(14): WOMEN are **JEALOUS** of the STONE on my wife's ring.
column7: 3) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 9-1-2009(5): I'm **jealous** that my _woman_ has a crush on _The Rock_.
column8: 4) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 10-12-2008(4): A **jealous** _woman_ is as cold and hard as a _rock_.
column9: 5) [[meeatcookies](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meeatcookies)] 24-8-2012(3): The _woman_ is **jealous** of her man, the _rock_ star.

column3: Long before the invention of the carpenter's **plane** , people used knives and machetes (or here, _sabers_ ) to smooth out their woodwork. If you have ever seen the process, you will have been amazed at the speed and agility with which the adept can **plane** a hunk of wood into shape. Indeed, you can almost see the _sparks_ fly from their _sabers_.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 21-12-2007(258): _Sparks_ will fly if you attempt to **PLANE** your _sabre_.
column6: 2) [[snozle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snozle)] 21-10-2006(85): With today's strict air regulations, carrying a _sabre_ onto a **plane** could _spark_ quite a commotion.
column7: 3) [[LazyNomad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LazyNomad)] 21-2-2010(62): Not " _a **plane** "_, but _"to **plane** "_. To carve a sculpture from wooden block, you cut it (with a _sword_ ) little by little, until there is _resemblance_ with whatever it was meant to _resemble_.
column8: 4) [[sprutnik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sprutnik)] 4-10-2008(36): The carpenter's **plane** _resembles_ a _saber_.
column9: 5) [[ederu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ederu)] 15-12-2008(12): _sparks_ fly from the _blade_ as they **plane** the surface to perfection.

column3: There are really only 2 primitives here, _little_ and _human legs_. The 4th stroke that separates them is added for reasons of aesthetics. (If that doesn't make sense, try writing the kanji without it and see how ugly the results look, even to your beginner's eye.) Now if you have wondered what those little particles of  "dust" are that dance around in the light- **rays** that come through the window and fall on your desk, try imagining them as _little_ and disembodied _human legs_ , and you should have no trouble with this character.
column5: 1) [[guidedog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/guidedog)] 9-2-2007(132): A **ray** of light is not a wave but made of _little_ photons with _human legs_.
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 27-9-2007(86): The **ray** from Honey I Shrunk the Kids made people _little_ \- ha! look at them run around on their tiny _legs_!
column7: 3) [[cloudstrife543](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cloudstrife543)] 1-11-2008(47): Imagine a **ray** gun shooting someone and their body exploding (sparks) and just their legs left.
column8: 4) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 25-2-2008(30): **Little legs** at play are a **ray** of light in my day.
column9: 5) [[oRis1024](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oRis1024)] 20-7-2008(24): **Ray** is _tiny_ _legs_ of light…

column3: **Plump**  is one of those delightful English words that almost sound like their meaning. No sooner do you hear it than you think of a round and ample- bodied person falling into a sofa like a _large drop_ of oil plopping into a fishbowl - kerrrr- **plump**!
column5: 1) [[lilpea](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lilpea)] 3-8-2007(152): A _large_ person with a big _drop_ of sweat dripping off of him because he is so **plump**.
column6: 2) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 27-2-2006(80): Fat("plump") men always have small penises…..the kanji is a combination of "large" with a drop(representing the small penis between his legs).
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 28-1-2008(36): A big, **plump** sumo wrestler with a loincloth covering his little drop. (Thanks Fabrice).
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 5-2-2006(19): To keep this distinct from the primitive meaning of "round" ("fat man") I suggest to use a specific image, such as that of a **plump** Japanese sumo wrestler, and let the _drop_ between the legs be the loincloth (which compared to their _large_ body size, is quite a _drop_ ). To illustrate the importance of this, have a look at the kanji for "tenacious" (frame 1506) and "burdensome" (frame 1986).
column9: 5) [[ctalbottclark](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ctalbottclark)] 8-3-2008(15): The **plump** _dog_ _drop_ ped its tail between its legs.

column3: The picture in this kanji is not a pleasant one. It shows a large and fluffy _St. Bernard dog_ stretched out on a table all stuffed and stewed and garnished with vegetables, its paws in the air and an apple in its mouth. At each corner of the table sits an eager but empty _mouth_ , waiting for the **utensils** to arrive so the feast can begin.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 2-9-2007(184): Imagine four hungry _mouths_ all sitting around the table. They are all banging their **utensils** on the table waiting for a _big_ meal to be placed in the centre.
column6: 2) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 16-4-2008(53): Note: 器 by itself means **container/caliber/vessel**. And 食器 means eating **utensil** s ("food container", hehe).
column7: 3) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 26-2-2008(39): Four _mouths_ sit at the four corners of the table, waiting for their **utensil** s, ready to devour the large, spread eagled St. Bernard stretched out on the table!
column8: 4) [[lee101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lee101)] 28-7-2011(25): I swear RevTK has got too politically correct, I mean people on here are copying Heisig's original story only shortening it which is fine, yet they are getting dislikes, only due to the fact its about eating a dog!? Other instances include where people make slight reference to sex, race, violence - Heisig clearly states that it's fine to do this. (part 1, part two on the next frame).
column9: 5) [[squirrelscuba](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/squirrelscuba)] 14-5-2010(13): Four jgirl's mouths surrounding my large **utensil**.

column8: 4) [[jannahj](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jannahj)] 17-8-2007(33): If you put your NOSE directly on top of a ST. BERNARD, you'd surely be able to smell it's **stinking** wet fur.
column9: 5) [[NyahK](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NyahK)] 4-11-2009(16): Should one let _oneself_ get too _large_ , bodily functions may start **stinking**!

column3: You have seen those scratch'n' **sniff** advertisements for perfumes. This one is for a _mouth_ wash that replaces one _stinking_ oder with another.
column5: 1) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 27-6-2010(30): **Smell**. _Mouth_ agape, _nose_ in the air, a _chihuahua_ **smells** some BBQ miles away. NOTE: Assigned keyword "sniff" in RTK Newly Approved General Use Kanji Supplement.
column6: 2) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 8-12-2009(16): **smell** : You open your mouth and gasp for air, that stinking (notice the chihuahua instead) smell is too much.
column7: 3) [[aaroncp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aaroncp)] 6-2-2011(9): You open your _mouth_ and gasp for air, 1 **sniff** of that _stinking_ chihuahua is too much. *Edited thecite's to reflect the keyword in the supplement.
column8: 4) [[spleenlol](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/spleenlol)] 7-10-2010(7): Only 12 strokes. Dot over dog is not there anymore.
