column3: The primitive for _woman_ is on the left (there and at the bottom of another primitive is where you will always find her), and to the right the element for _few_. When we refer to a _woman_ as **exquisite** , we mean to praise her as the sort of person we meet but _few_ and far between. If you are interested in etymologies, it might help to recall that the Latin phrase lying at the root of the English word **exquisite** carries this same sense of  "seeking out" the rare from the ordinary.
column5: 1) [[amthomas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amthomas)] 11-6-2007(305): **Exquisite** _women_ are _few_ and far between.
column6: 2) [[LeoOra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LeoOra)] 27-1-2008(44): A geisha is an **exquisite** and **delicate** (another meaning of this kanji) women, however, even in the past there was only few of them.
column7: 3) [[oohansel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oohansel)] 16-4-2009(31): **Exquisite** women are few.
column8: 4) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 5-11-2009(16): All WOMEN are beautiful, only a FEW are **EXQUISITE** …
column9: 5) [[oRis1024](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oRis1024)] 20-7-2008(7): _Women_ have **exquisite** taste - they only like _few_ things.

column3: When we think of **focusing** on something, we usually take it in a metaphorical sense, though the literal sense is not far behind. It means to block out what is nonessential in order to fix our _eye_ on a _few_ important matters. The kanji suggests picking up a _few_ things and holding them before one's _eye_ in order to **focus** on them better.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 18-8-2007(251): You **focus** by concentrating your _eye_ on _few_ er objects.
column6: 2) [[smujohnson](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smujohnson)] 26-8-2008(48): To remember the order: When **focusing** , keep a _few_ things your TOP priority, so only they come UNDER your _sight_.
column7: 3) [[Xtophe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Xtophe)] 7-9-2006(41): Success (or survival?) method for accelerated juggling course: _focus_ on a _few_ nitroglycerine filled juggling balls flying OVER your _eyes_ —(I have trouble with this _few_ primitive that can be anywhere in a kanji. To build in its location in the story is important somehow).
column8: 4) [[TerryS](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TerryS)] 27-5-2009(22): _Few_ distractions will catch your _eye_ if you have **FOCUS**.
column9: 5) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 30-9-2007(12): _few_ people can **focus** their _eyes_ perfectly, that is 20/20, the rest of us have to wear glasses because we see out of **focus**.

column3: When we refer to someone as **thick** -skinned or **thick-** headed, we are usually quick to add - even if only under our breath - something about their upbringing. Perhaps it is because deep down we cherish the belief that by nature people are basically tender and sensitive. Be that as it may, the Japanese character for **thick** depicts a _child_ abandoned out on the wild _cliffs_ , exposed to the heat of the _sun_ , and thus doomed to develop a head and skin as **thick** as the parent who left it there.
column5: 1) [[potempkin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/potempkin)] 26-8-2008(209): The **thick** _cliff_ walls protected the _children_ from the _sun_.
column6: 2) [[kfactor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kfactor)] 7-7-2007(142): In Sparta we throw our Children over a Cliff. Under the Sun, they fight other Children. In the end, if they survive, they sure have **thick** skin.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 28-9-2007(28): **Thick** skinned _child_ , got that way by burning under the _sun_ while playing at the bottom of a _cliff_ which reflects and intensifies the light. (He's safe though, because there's no overhang).
column8: 4) [[theBryan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theBryan)] 30-5-2008(25): The japanese word for **thick** is atsui which is a homophone for hot, a kid under a cliff with the sun baking down on him would be hot indeed, especially if he had a **thick** sweater on. An atsui seetaa under the atsui sun.
column9: 5) [[dinmamma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dinmamma)] 9-8-2009(14): A _child_ who grew up under the burning _sun_ on dry, bare _cliffs_ is bound to be **thick** -skinned.

column3: The elements we are given to work with here are _St. Bernard dog_ and _can_. Lots of phrases pop to mind to attach these words to the key word, but they end up too abstract because of the word _can_. It is important in such cases (and there will be plenty of them as we go along)  to stick closely to the elements, in this case, _mouth_  and _nails_. Now all we need do is create a fictitious  " **Strange** But True " column in the Sunday funnies, featuring a _St. Bernard_ whose _mouth_ has been _nailed_ shut because he was hitting the brandy keg around his neck too hard.
column5: 1) [[Beeber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Beeber)] 12-6-2007(238): I find it **strange** that so many people commit suicide in Tokyo by throwing themselves in front of the train. To me when I look at this kanji, I see a train just about to come out of a tunnel, and above the man waiting for his oppourtunity where he can end it all.
column6: 2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(77): Imagine a ST. BERNARD DOG carrying a CAN instead of a barrel in rescue missions. How **strange**!
column7: 3) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 12-12-2007(58): A _dog_ that _can_ do the "Can Can" would be a **STRANGE** sight indeed.
column8: 4) [[Shishimai](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shishimai)] 22-1-2006(26): It's 'strange' to see a St. Bernard driving 'The Little Engine That Could'.
column9: 5) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 20-8-2008(18): A _St. Bernard_ that _can_ eat _nails_?! How **strange**!

column3: We have taken the image of a river **stream** over into English to describe things that fall down in straight lines, or ripple along in lines. All of this is more than evident in the kanji given here, a pictograph of a **stream**.
column4: * As a primitive, this character adds to the meaning of _stream_ the more vivid image of a _flood_. Note, however, that there are certain small changes in the writing of the element, depending on where it appears relative to other elements: on the left, it is written the same. on the top, it is written with the three strokes more like less-then signs on the bottom, it is written with the third stroke similar to a fishhook
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 2-9-2007(86): So as not to confuse this with [river](../v4/146.html) (#146 河) think of **stream** ers falling down.
column6: 2) [[dogen2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dogen2)] 17-3-2007(63): There are _three_ default I/O **Streams** in UNIX, stdin, stdout, and stderr.
column7: 3) [[aquanoodle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aquanoodle)] 25-3-2008(18): _Three_ **stream** s grouped together might cause a flood!
column8: 4) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 27-2-2008(14): **Stream** ers, **stream** ing down.
column9: 5) [[a_d_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/a_d_g)] 8-10-2008(8): In Ghostbusters, Egon warned that crossing the **streams** would result in total proton reversal, that's why the lines should not intersect.

column3: Here we see _drops of_ land (little islets) rising up out of a _stream_ , creating a kind of sandbar or breakwater. Ever wonder how the **state** -line is drawn between **states** separated by a river? If there were little _drops of_ land as in the kanji, there'd be nothing to it.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 3-9-2007(202): There were 3 little islands in the _stream_ who all decided to set themselves up as independent **states**.
column6: 2) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 29-3-2008(28): シュウ The original meaning of this character was "sandbar", and for me this conjures up images of the Mississippi River, which is very wide with many sandbars and which was used to define the borders in ten American **state** s. Picture Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer floating by **state** after **state** as they adventure down the mighty Mississippi, occasionally beaching their raft on sandbars.
column7: 3) [[alatown](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alatown)] 21-2-2009(15): All powerful **STATE** S grew from a few small settlements along RIVER.
column8: 4) [[panikbuton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/panikbuton)] 20-1-2008(12): Three votes in a **state** election are as meaningless as as many drops in a stream.
column9: 5) [[cyberclops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cyberclops)] 17-1-2010(7): The **state** of a _stream_ is not changed by adding three _drops_.

column3: In primitive language, this character would read _stream_ . . . _head_. And that turns out to be convenient for remembering its meaning of **obey**. Either one **obeys** the person who is _head_ of an organization or else **obeys** by following the _stream_ of opinion ( "current" practice, we call it). Both these senses come together in this kanji.
column5: 1) [[steves](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/steves)] 10-10-2007(185): "Obey, **Obey**!" says the brain-washing scientist as he sends a _stream_ of orders to fill your _head_.
column6: 2) [[jonny49cc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonny49cc)] 4-7-2008(92): **Obey** the orders streaming down from head office.
column7: 3) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 17-4-2008(59): An ancient form of militaristic torture: I'll hold your _head_ in the _river_ until you **obey**. Or, if you'd prefer, to get the order of primitives correct: In the _stream_ I'll dunk your _head_ until you **obey**.
column8: 4) [[skellyfish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skellyfish)] 9-12-2008(53): In Japan, **obey** ing means following the _stream_ of collective opinion BEFORE using your own _head_.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 23-8-2008(21): 順 【じゅん】 (adj-na,n,n-suf) order, turn, (P) "Your book must have its PAGES in ORDER so that the story flows as clear as a STREAM".

column3: This character, which looks a bit like a snowflake, is actually a pictograph of **water**  \- not any particular body of water or movement of water, but simply the generic name for **water**. Should you have any difficulty remembering it, simply think of a _walking stick_ being dropped vertically into the **water** , sending _droplets_ out in all four directions. Then all you need to learn is how to write it in proper order.
column4: * As a primitive, this character can keep its form, or it can be written with three drops to the left of another primitive. This latter, as we will see, is far more common.
column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 8-11-2007(67): The kanji for **water** is an abstract primitive itself, so unless one is willing to break down its etymological development, it should just simply be memorized by strokes, constructing a story is not necessarily useful unless it strongly denotes its shape (I find that Heisig's story doesn't do this).
column6: 2) [[CandyCane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CandyCane)] 5-10-2008(54): For those having issues with this* "A 7K foot pool of **water** " Notice it looks like a 7, and a K. Might have to practice writing it a few times.
column7: 3) [[Ozmos](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ozmos)] 10-9-2009(34): When you squeeze a stream you get **water**.
column8: 4) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 24-7-2007(6): Dropping a hooked walking stick into the **water** causes a splash. (The primitive is often contracted to just two drops and a walking stick).
column9: 5) [[foros](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/foros)] 7-3-2010(4): Dropping the _walking stick_ into the **water** sent out _droplets_ in 4 directions.

column3: The appearance of the primitive for _water_ in its full form tells us that we have something to do with _water_ here. The extra _drop_ to the left, added as a second stroke, changes the picture from a splash caused by a _walking stick_ dropped into _water_ to form an **icicle**. If it helps, when you hold an **icicle** up to the light, you can usually see little crystallizations of five-pointed stars inside of it, which is the shape we have in this kanji.
column5: 1) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 28-8-2007(238): **Icicle** s start with 1 frozen _drop_ of _water_.
column6: 2) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 27-2-2008(73): _A drop_ in temperature turns _water_ into an **icicle**.
column7: 3) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 22-2-2008(15): Ooooh (う） Look at the drops of water from that **icicle**. (Hiragana う looks like the left side).
column8: 4) [[haole](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/haole)] 27-10-2009(8): Just as you dot the "i" in **icicle** , so should you dot the water!
column9: 5) [[undead_saif](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/undead_saif)] 29-1-2009(7): **Icicle** s form when water drops drop down on each other and freeze. look <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Icicle>.

column3: This kanji also uses the full form of _water_ , though its meaning seems to have nothing at all to do with _water_. Remember what William Blake said about seeing  "infinity in a grain of sand and **eternity** in an hour "? Well, reading this character from top to bottom, we see " **eternity** in a _drop of water_. "
column5: 1) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 7-9-2007(177): It would take an **eternity** to count all the drops of water.
column6: 2) [[lilpea](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lilpea)] 3-8-2007(50): It takes but one _drop_ from the most special _water_ : the fountain of youth (and it is written in a special way to with an extra horizontal line on the top) to live for an **eternity**. (In order to remember that the drop is at the top, think that the drop must come from the topmost water in order for its effects to be true).
column7: 3) [[lucianreign](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lucianreign)] 22-11-2006(36): What is your life? A DROP of water on a mini FLOOR when compared to **ETERNITY**!
column8: 4) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 22-2-2008(28): It will take **ETERNITY** for that drop of water above to drip. Especially since theres a ledge below it…
column9: 5) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 25-1-2009(16): The _drop_ hung on the ledge above the _water_ for an **eternity**.

column3: Call to mind the image of a fresh, bubbling **spring** of _water_ , and you will probably notice how the top of the **spring** you are thinking of, the part where the  "bubbling" goes on, is all _white_. Happily, the _white_ is just where it should be, at the top, and the _water_ is at the bottom.
column4: * We will keep this image of a _spring_ when using this kanji as a primitive, but not without first drawing attention to a slight change that distinguishes the primitive from the kanji. The final 4 strokes (the element for _water_ ) are abbreviated to the three small drops that we learned earlier as the kanji for _little_.
column5: 1) [[lilpea](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lilpea)] 3-8-2007(181): _White_ is a symbol of purety, so _white_ _water_ is pure water, the precise definition of **spring** water.
column6: 2) [[hikarudo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hikarudo)] 19-8-2008(123): Perhaps the most common appearance of this kanji is in the word 温泉 (おんせん, onsen), a Japanese hot **spring**. The kanji is an excellent image of someone enjoying a Japanese hot **spring** : a little _white_ towel on top, _water_ below. (This helps keep all associations: **spring** , little and onsen).
column7: 3) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 18-2-2008(43): A fresh **SPRING** has plenty of frothy _white_ bubbles in its crisp, cool _water_.
column8: 4) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 3-2-2008(23): A **spring** has _white_ frothy _water_.
column9: 5) [[akane99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akane99)] 8-7-2010(7): When **SPRING** comes, _white_ snow melts and becomes _water_.

column3: Dig into your _flesh_ and pull out a lymph **gland**. Now give it a squeeze and watch the _spring_ of lymph spout out of it.
column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(88): A _body part_ that acts like a _spring_ for hormones is a **gland**.
column6: 2) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 2-4-2010(17): Sweat and saliva **gland** s act like a spring for fluids. (combining everyone's stories in one mnemonic, thanks mantixen).
column7: 3) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 28-8-2009(4): Part of your body that springs out sweat, your sweat **gland** s.
column8: 4) [[Hazevi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hazevi)] 20-11-2011(2): If you were to dig into your FLESH and pull out a lymph **GLAND** , a lot of WHITE WATER will SPRING forth from it.
column9: 5) [[Louismi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Louismi)] 18-4-2011(1): Part of the body that acts as a spring of body fluids.

column3: Though the kanji is broad enough to embrace both meanings, the **meadow** you should imagine here is not a flatland plain but a mountain **meadow** in the Austrian Alps. (Perhaps the opening scene of  "The Sound of Music" will help.) Simply think of little _springs_ bubbling up across the **meadow** to form a sort of path that leads you right to the brink of a precipitous _cliff_. Now if you can see Schwester Maria skipping along merrily, dodging in and out of the _springs_ , and then falling headlong over the _cliff_ , you have a ridiculous story that should help fix this kanji in memory.
column5: 1) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 28-8-2007(148): Follow the _springs_ down the _cliff_ and you will find a nice **meadow**.
column6: 2) [[LeoOra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LeoOra)] 7-2-2008(73): Sorry about this, but Heisig was stupid calling this kanji **meadow** , used in composite words the most common meaning is **ORIGIN** … To remember just think that life may have begun in _pound_ s or _spring_ s in a land with many _cliff_ s … Just to answer correctly the review lessons think of **meadow** as the _origin_ of a huge forest.
column7: 3) [[Pangolin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pangolin)] 16-4-2009(62): Forget about "spring" because the water primitive is abbreviated to "little". This is easy to forget by the time you've finished RTK1. Instead, imagine standing on an exceedingly high _cliff_. Not overlooking the sea, but overlooking **meadow** s. And what on earth are those _white little_ things? Wow, they're sheep! This cliff must be really high!
column8: 4) [[findus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/findus)] 22-10-2007(57): When in a **meadow** , the japanese girls who are _white_ and _small_ search for the shadow of a _cliff_ to avoid taning.
column9: 5) [[mazel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mazel)] 29-8-2007(26): [L2]. Under a CLIFF is a **meadow** with WHITE SMALL flowers.

column3: A _meadow_ and a _head_ are all we are given to work with in the kanji for **petition**. Since the key word already suggests something like a formal request made of some higher power, let us imagine a gigantic Wizard-of-Oz _head_ located in the middle of the flowery _meadow_ we used in the last frame. Then just picture people kneeling hopefully before it, **petitioning** for whatever it is they want. (The scarecrow wanted brains, the lion, courage, and the tin man a heart. What about you?)
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 27-7-2007(310): Let's **petition** to save that beautiful MEADOW from overdevelopment by signing on this PAGE.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 9-11-2007(107): Japanese hippies **PETITION** to save a _meadow_ by getting people on the street to sign their _page_ \- as you pass by they call out: " [お願いします、おねがいします。”](midori://search?text=お願いします、おねがいします。”) .
column7: 3) [[ketsensei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ketsensei)] 10-2-2013(32): Dorothy, the Scarecrow, the Tin Man, and the Cowardly Lion cross the _**meadow**_ to get to the large _**head**_ that is Oz and make their **PETITION** s for brains, heart, courage and a way home.
column8: 4) [[shorinsakka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shorinsakka)] 20-6-2007(24): In the meadow a giant head has appeared. Everyone signs a **petition** so that it won't eat everyone.
column9: 5) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 3-3-2008(19): To save the _meadow_ from development, a _page_ of signatures was submitted as a **petition**.

column3: The primitive to the left, you will recall from Frame 137, represents _water_. To the right, we see the kanji for _eternity_. Knowing how much children like **swimming** , what could be a better image of _eternal_ bliss than an endless expanse of _water_ to **swim** in without a care in the world?
column5: 1) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 18-3-2008(163): If you don't know how to **swim** , you'll be in that _water_ for _eternity_.
column6: 2) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 18-8-2007(72): With that much WATER (2 actually) you would need to **swim** for an ETERNITY.
column7: 3) [[moojitsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/moojitsu)] 18-10-2006(35): It'll seem like an eternity in the water if you cannot **swim**.
column8: 4) [[crd88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crd88)] 12-4-2010(14): There's enough _water_ in the world to **swim** for _eternity_.
column9: 5) [[activeaero](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/activeaero)] 20-8-2008(11): Michael Phelps can **SWIM** for "eternity" if you give him enough "water".

column3: Unlike the meadow with its cliffs, the **marsh** lands are low and near a source of _water_ that feeds them until they get soggy through and through. Why certain land becomes **marshy** is probably due to the fact that it felt thirsty, and so tried its best to _seduce_ the _water_ over to its side. But, like most inordinate _seductions_ , the last state of the victim is worse than the first. Hence the slushy **marsh**.
column5: 1) [[moojitsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/moojitsu)] 19-10-2006(175): The **marsh** lands near Mordor seduce Frodo into gazing upon them, and he falls into the water–splash!
column6: 2) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 3-2-2008(156): A **marsh** is where _water_ is _seduced_ into the ground.
column7: 3) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 3-9-2007(42): The **marsh** looks just like dry land. Really it's _water_ and it _seduces_ people to step onto it and they sink to their death.
column8: 4) [[mattoc_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattoc_g)] 28-3-2006(17): A **marsh** maid (similar to a mermaid) seduces men into her watery area.
column9: 5) [[rejam](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rejam)] 23-8-2007(8): **Marsh**. To where all the _water_ was _seduced_ to.

column3: This kanji could hardly be simpler. The key word **open sea** readily suggests being out _in the middle of_ a great body of _water_ .Thinking of it in this way should avoid confusion with the kanji for  "open," which we will meet later on.
column5: 1) [[zdnks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zdnks)] 31-10-2007(141): **Open sea** is a lot of water in the middle of nowhere.
column6: 2) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 9-3-2009(69): _Water_ in the _middle_ of the ocean is referred to as **open sea**.
column7: 3) [[akimoto](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akimoto)] 21-6-2006(23): Out in the water, in the middle of the ocean, is **open sea** with no land for miles and miles.
column8: 4) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 4-8-2007(18): OpIN sea.
column9: 5) [[Ningen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ningen)] 30-7-2008(5): When you are on the **OPEN SEA** , you are completely _in_ the _middle_ of the _water_.

column3: The sense of the key word here is the "all-inclusive" we find in terms like " **Pan-** American Games." (It is also the character used in mathematics for "partial" as in partial differentials, in case you are a math major and want to take your story in that direction.) Instead of a _water_ sports event that brings together the best talent, think of a meet of the region's most _mediocre_ athletes, many of whom cannot even tread _water_. Now try to find a sponsor for the  " **Pan-** _Mediocre_ _Water_ Sports Competition. "
column5: 1) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 23-1-2009(54): This is **pan** \- as in the prefix meaning "all". I think of **Pan** gea as being a mediocre continent with water covering the rest of the planet. This was before it broke up into the first-class, well-distributed continents we got now.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 17-6-2007(22): Yeah, all our _water_ is fairly _mediocre_ , but if we work together in some **pan** -continental union, we can make some better _water_! As if.
column7: 3) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 9-6-2009(20): After **Pan** -Am crashed yet another plane into the _water_ , their reputation dropped to _mediocre_.
column8: 4) [[dancingblade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dancingblade)] 14-7-2010(6): A person sneezes. The _water drops in the wind_ are about to start a **pan** demic and put the whole world in **pan** demonium.
column9: 5) [[FoxintheStars](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FoxintheStars)] 30-7-2010(5): **Pan-** Am was such a lousy airline, even the _water_ in their in-flight meals was _mediocre_.

column3: Unlike the river, the ocean, the lake, and the pond, the **creek** is often no more then a dribble of _water_ trickling down a small gully. While the geological history of the larger bodies of _water_ is hard to surmise sometimes, all of us know from our childhood how **creeks** are made. You probably even dug one or two in your time. All you need to do is find a mainstream of _water_ somewhere and dig a little path into dry land. The **creek** is thus a lesson in _water-craft_ , as this kanji would agree.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 12-12-2007(136): A **CREEK** is a small trail of _water_ easily _craft_ ed with a stick.
column6: 2) [[nwatkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nwatkins)] 18-9-2007(83): **Creek** s are small water, easily crossed with a simple i-beam.
column7: 3) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 21-12-2007(35): Using _water_ and some _craft_ , one can make a **creek**.
column8: 4) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 15-3-2007(24): This Kanji can carry the meaning of "creek", "inlet", or "bay" actually. Although the meaning of inlet and bay seem to pop up for me more than instances of it meaning **creek** (I often question Hesig's choices of these key words, even if his method does seem to be effective). Still… I guess right now I'm using the image of a witch who practices her "craft" next to a watery **creek** leading into an inlet/bay.
column9: 5) [[kirihitokiri](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kirihitokiri)] 9-3-2008(19): It is best to practice operating _water_ _craft_ in a **creek** before going to rivers or the sea…

column3: This character can mean both to **cleanse** and to make dirty. We will choose the latter and imagine someone who is displeasingly _plump_ going to a skinny spa whose medicinal _waters_ promise to **cleanse** him of his unwanted corpulence. Picture him sitting in the spa as the pounds melt away, leaving a greasy scum on top of the _water_.
column5: 1) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 28-11-2008(71): I couldn't find any reference to this kanji as meaning **cleanse**. It seems to be most often used in the following compound 沙汰 （さた）to mean affair. The other meanings seem to be closer to 'select' so maybe Heisig meant **cleanse** in the ethnic sense here.. I'm going to use the keyword "selection", as in natural selection. Story: natural selection first began in the water, and those that were too plump were selected out.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(27): _Water_ is used to **cleanse** a _plump_ man's colon.
column7: 3) [[brendanmacdonald](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brendanmacdonald)] 29-9-2008(13): If you are FAT, it takes more WATER to **CLEANSE** you.
column8: 4) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 27-4-2008(6): The [plump](../v4/120.html) (#120 太) goes one a **cleansing** diet to restore his health. Each day he drinks his 3l of _water_ , swim half a hour in _water_ …
column9: 5) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 5-8-2009(4): The very plump man selected the Japanese toilet seat which will **cleanse** him with water automatically since he's too fat to reach back and wipe… (consider herman's explanation and think of "selection").

column3: To make **soup** , one begins with _water_ and then starts adding things to it, often leftovers from the icebox. This is how the thick **soup** or stew called  "seven-in-one" is made. This kanji does it three better, giving us a _ten_ -ingredient **soup**.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 3-9-2007(169): To make **soup** you just take _water_ and _add_ (+) the rest of your ingredients.
column6: 2) [[ostracon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ostracon)] 4-12-2007(158): To make **soup** you just take _water_ and _add_ _ten_ tasty ingredients.
column7: 3) [[silkcherryblossoms](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/silkcherryblossoms)] 10-6-2007(18): Water and ten ingredients can become a good **soup**!
column8: 4) [[samesong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samesong)] 28-6-2008(15): This **soup** is just water and needles - I can't eat this.
column9: 5) [[Filanator](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filanator)] 18-2-2009(5): _Water_ is _ten_ times less tasty than **soup**.

column3: We have already learned the kanji for _sand_ (Frame 122), so let's use it to remember the character for **grains of sand**. Instead of the  "few stones" that make for nice sand, here we have a _few drops of water_ , one for each **grand of sand** \- a beach in perfect ecological balance.
column5: 1) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 15-7-2009(58): To keep this separated from [sand](../v4/117.html) (#117 砂): _Water_ erodes away stone a _few_ **grains of sand** at a time until there is no stone left.
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 15-2-2007(31): Wet sand is simply sand but to see beautiful **grains of sand** , the _water_ must be _few_.
column7: 3) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 22-5-2009(18): Each _water_ wave washes away a _few_ **grains of sand**.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 8-10-2010(5): This kanji is used in a lot of girl’s names. 理沙 (りさ) [、沙織](midori://search?text=、沙織) (さおり) [、沙百合](midori://search?text=、沙百合) (さゆり). Maybe guys can think of this kind of like the classic advice there a lots of fish in _water_ (ocean), lots of girls out there for you. You might think that it's hopeless and there are only _a few_ girls out there, but girls are like **grains of sand**. Keep looking for the right one!
column9: 5) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 15-4-2008(5): Where there are many **grains of sand** there are _few_ drops of _water_.

column3: Before we get to explaining this character, take a look at it and see if you can figure out the primitive elements on your own.... On the left is the _water_  \- that much is easy. On the right we have only one primitive, the kanji for _morning_ learned back in Frame 53. See how an apparently complex kanji falls apart neatly into manageable pieces? To get the meaning of the key word **tide** , just think of it in connection with the character for _eventide_ that we learned back in Frame 115. Here we have the _morning_ - **tide** , its complement. By the way, if you missed the question about the number of primitives, it is probably because you forgot what we said earlier about kanji becoming primitives, independently of the pieces that make them up. As a rule, look for the largest kanji you can write and proceed from there to primitives stranded on their own.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 27-7-2007(205): The morning **tide** is basically, well, WATER in the MORNING.
column6: 2) [[Mesqueeb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Mesqueeb)] 19-4-2009(46): If it's not Eventide ( 汐 ) it must be _morning_ **tide**!
column7: 3) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 12-6-2008(46): This is not the eventide, but the water of the morning **tide**.
column8: 4) [[dogen2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dogen2)] 17-3-2007(20): The water rises with the morning **tide**.
column9: 5) [[kyotokanji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kyotokanji)] 28-3-2007(13): Imagine falling asleep drunk on the beach, you wake up quickly in the morning as the water from the **tide** hits you and makes you wet.

column3: With the advice of the last frame in mind, it is easy to see _water_ and _meadow_ in this character for **source**. Both in its etymology (it has a common parent with the word  "surge") and in popular usage, **source** suggests the place _water_ comes from. In this kanji, it is under the _meadow_ , where we just saw it breaking the surface in those bubbly little _springs_.
column5: 1) [[dogen2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dogen2)] 17-3-2007(146): The _water_ that flows from the _meadow_ is the **source** of life for the wild antelope.
column6: 2) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 14-8-2006(74): The **source** of clean _water_ is from the [meadow](../v4/134.html) (#134 原): it comes from that _spring_ at the bottom of the _cliff_. Pay no attention to Julie Andrews lying face down in _spring_. The water's clean. Trust me.
column7: 3) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 11-2-2009(65): _Water_ is the **source** of a _meadow_ 's beauty.
column8: 4) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 11-11-2007(31): Here the **SOURCE** of water is deep beneath the ground ( _cliff_ ) - it seeps up, joins the water _springs_ , flows through the meadow, and down the waterfall at the end. (NOTE- to keep **spring** (133) and **source** separate, remember that a spring can be anywhere above ground, but the **source** of water is deep beneath the ground ( _cliff_ ), and flows up through the ground to join springs and streams - which is why there are two primitives for _water_ in this kanji).
column9: 5) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 20-5-2007(23): Bottled _water_ companies assure us that the **source** of their water is from some beautiful _meadow_ -spring in the Swiss Alps, but we all know they just bottle up tap water.

column3: When we speak of a **lively** personality or a **lively** party, we immediately think of a lot of chatter. This kanji depicts the idea of **lively** by having _tongues_ babble and splash around like flowing _water_.
column5: 1) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 18-5-2008(201): I'm sure I can get her pretty **lively** and _wet_ using my _tongue_.
column6: 2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 18-8-2007(176): Conversations can become more **lively** after everyone has had a few drinks. It's because " _water_ y _tongue_ s" loosen lips!
column7: 3) [[AryllWind](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AryllWind)] 31-1-2008(23): This keyword makes me think of animals. I picture a big dog running through the grass, saliva dripping from his tongue.
column8: 4) [[grivitz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/grivitz)] 4-8-2006(19): Water comes off the **lively** speaker's tongue.
column9: 5) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 26-9-2008(16): **Lively** tongues need water.

column3: Among the many things _water_ is useful for is **extinguishing** fires, and that is just what we have here. First of all, take the _water_ at the left as the _drops of water_ that are used to depict _water_ in general. In the best of all possible worlds, the most efficient way to **extinguish** a fire would be to see that each _drop of water_ hits one _spark_ of the conflagration. An unthinkable bit of utopian fire fighting, you say to yourself, but helpful for assigning this key word its primitives.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(127): To **extinguish** a SPARK, you need WATER.
column6: 2) [[zdnks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zdnks)] 31-10-2007(55): You need a few drops of water to **extinguish** the candle.
column7: 3) [[Sevenhelmets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sevenhelmets)] 3-6-2008(44): To **extinguish** fire, use _water_ or something _resembling_ it.
column8: 4) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 5-8-2007(14): Each _drop of water_ **extinguish** es a _spark_ from the fire, causing the campfire to eventually **dissapear** , with the _moon_ remaining the only thing sure ( しょう) to(き) keep it light.
column9: 5) [[hotsw4p](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hotsw4p)] 12-12-2009(12): Use _water_ to **extinguish** that _spark_ before it gets out of hand.

column3: This key word is a connector used to link contrasting phrase sand sentences together with much the same flavor as the English phrase **but of course**. Just picture yourself ready to go off on your first date as a _teenager_ , and having your mother grill you about your manners and ask you embarrassing questions about your hygiene. "Did you have a good shower?" " **But of course** ," you reply, annoyed. So _water_ and _teenager_ combine to give us **but of course**.
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 21-9-2006(174): If you ask your _teenager_ if what he's drinking is _water_ (and not Vodka), he will answer "but of course".
column6: 2) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 10-4-2008(137): キョウ **But of course** , this character really means "situation/condition". "Elder brother gulped some water and said, 'What the hell was Heisig's mental CONDITION when he came up with this definition? Heisig must have a drinking CONDITION. **But of course** , if Heisig sticks to water, rather than sake (like me, _water_ quaffing, situation assessing, sober _elder brother_ ), his SITUATION may improve.'" [MODEL COMPOUND: 状況 (じょうきょう) state of affairs, conditions].
column7: 3) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 15-9-2008(61): A wet teenager is good , **but of course** it is illegal.
column8: 4) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 12-2-2008(52): Would you like to throw _water_ on your _elder brother_? **But of course**!
column9: 5) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 11-12-2006(35): This kanji is actually used the normally in the words " 況して " and " 況や ", which mean "Even more so…" or "Even less so…" depending on the context. So, everyone should use _water_ to clean themselves, _even more so_ _teenagers_ prone to body odors.

column3: The character in this frame represents a step up from the _stream_ we met in Frame 134, it is a full-sized **river**. The _water_ to the left tells us what we are dealing with, and the _can_ at the right tells us that our  "little engine that _could_ " has now become amphibious and is chugging down the Mighty Mississip' like a regular riverboat.
column5: 1) [[gsantise](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gsantise)] 25-8-2007(175): A **river** CAN exist only if there is WATER.
column6: 2) [[Avispa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Avispa)] 29-8-2007(85): I kept confusing this with _stream_. My Japanese friend said that to him this is for an artificial **river**. Looking at kanji compounds with this there are two that struck me: One is the Yellow **River** in China ( 黄河 ), and the other is the Milky Way ( 銀河 ). Now I either think of the Little Engine that _could_ dragging a bunch of stuff down a **river** in China and polluting it (so it turned yellow) or I see the Little Engine that Could flying across the sky making the Milky Way.
column7: 3) [[aspr8045](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aspr8045)] 2-2-2009(72): "I CAN has WATER?" sez **river** cat.
column8: 4) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 11-3-2008(44): With enough _water_ you _can_ make a **river**.
column9: 5) [[Ningen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ningen)] 26-8-2008(24): The lesson of persistence: even drops of _water can_ become a **RIVER**.

column3: When you stop at an inn for an **overnight** rest, all you expect is a bit of _water_ for a wash and a set of clean _white_ sheets to wrap your weary bones in.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 27-7-2007(171): Please supply a guest who stays **overnight** with WATER and WHITE sheets.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 27-8-2007(99): When I go to an **OVERNIGHT** party, all I need is a bit of **water** and some of that hard **white**. (crack). (not really, but come on. much easier to recall than white sheets).
column7: 3) [[peepiceek](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peepiceek)] 1-5-2008(54): **Overnight** water white (it rhymes).
column8: 4) [[Jared](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jared)] 11-2-2008(34): I asked the soaking wet white girl to stay **overnight**.
column9: 5) [[moojitsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/moojitsu)] 19-10-2006(26): If you let your daughter's boyfriend stay **overnight** , expect white drops of water to be in unsettling places. (Sorry if this offends anyone.).

column3: _Water_ . . . _old_ . . . _flesh_. You have heard of legends of people being abandoned in the mountains when they had become too old to work. Well, here is a legend about people being set adrift in the _waters_ of a stormy **lake** because their _flesh_ had gotten too _old_ to bear the burdens of life.
column5: 1) [[Shizuru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shizuru)] 2-8-2007(305): This is my favorite story. Simply associate the sad moment of an OLD person, standing near the WATER of the **lake** and looking at the MOON reflected in the **lake**. The created primitives themselves are put so beautifully, that you will not forget this kanji.
column6: 2) [[DBJ07](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DBJ07)] 17-2-2007(94): Water reflects the old moon in the **lake**.
column7: 3) [[I_pity_the_fool](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/I_pity_the_fool)] 21-5-2008(51): Water + old + flesh. Imagine a group of senior citizens skinnydipping in a nearby **lake**.
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 20-2-2008(38): Tip: Heisig later combines _old_ and _moon_ into 胡 [uncivilized](../v4/2470.html) (#2470 胡). Story: Drinking _water_ straight from the **lake** is rather _uncivilized_. (OR: _Uncivilized_ communities get their _water_ straight from the **lake**.
column9: 5) [[krungthep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/krungthep)] 26-3-2008(23): Some **lake** s are used by criminals to dump _old_ _body parts_ in the _water_.

column3: Connoting the measurement of the depth of _water_ , the keyword **fathom** begins with the _water_ primitive. To its right, we see the compound-primitive for _rule_ (Frame 92) which we learned in the sense of a  "ruler" or "measure." Hence, when we _rule_ _water_ we **fathom** it. What could be simpler? But be careful, its simplicity is deceptive. Be sure to picture yourself **fathoming** a body of _water_ several hundred feet deep by using a _ruler_ of gargantuan proportions.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 11-1-2007(150): A _fathom_ is the unit you use when making **rules** about **water** 's depth.
column6: 2) [[XanthosDeia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/XanthosDeia)] 13-7-2008(76): You can't **fathom** how deep this _water_ is. Perhaps you should use a _ruler_ to measure it?
column7: 3) [[cornfed](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cornfed)] 20-1-2008(28): Imagine jumping in the water and riding a shellfish down to the bottom, measuring **fathom** s with your ruler.
column8: 4) [[anroo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anroo)] 15-7-2009(20): **Fathom** s beneath the _water_ , a _shellfish_ defends the depths with his _sabre_.
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 17-10-2009(17): HINT: I find 測 and 則 confusing. For 則 [rule](../v4/88.html) (#88 則)Heisig describes the keyword as a rule (regulation). Then in [fathom](../v4/149.html) (#149 測) he suggests 則 is a ruler or measure! Whatever stories you choose, don't loose sight of the meaning: 則 = rule (regulation, law), 測 = **fathom** (measure, conjecture).

column3: I don't like it any more than you do, but this kanji is not the pictograph it is trumped up to be: a mound of **soil** piled on the ground. All I can recommend is that you memorize it as it is. Anyway, it will be occurring with such frequency that you have almost no chance of forgetting it, even if you try.
column4: * As a primitive, the sense of _soil_ is extended to that of _ground_ because of its connection with the kanji for the same (Frame 554). From there it also takes the added meanings of _dirt_ and _land_.
column5: 1) [[mparrett1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mparrett1)] 18-6-2006(87): Remembering **soil** is easy. If **soil** is soft, you can take a _walking stick_ and plunge it two* feet into the ground.
column6: 2) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 11-3-2008(32): The grave was marked by a cross sticking out of the **soil**.
column7: 3) [[Gendal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Gendal)] 9-2-2009(24): **Soil** is neither positive nor negative.
column8: 4) [[skeeter3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skeeter3)] 15-8-2007(19): King Arthur pulled the magical sword Excalibur out of the hardened **soil** to claim his place as king.
column9: 5) [[TerryS](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TerryS)] 27-11-2008(7): I tried to stick a _needle_ in the _ground_ but it wouldn't go through the hard **SOIL**.

column3: We have here a rather small _mouth_ (it is always compressed when set on the left) next to a much larger piece of _dirt_. It is not hard to imagine what you might do if you got a _mouth_ full of _dirt_. As least I know what I would do: **spit** it out as fast and far as I could!
column5: 1) [[zoletype](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zoletype)] 8-4-2008(123): **SPIT** goes from my MOUTH to the GROUND.
column6: 2) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 30-7-2007(69): The only things that come out of my MOUTH and onto the GROUND are **spit** and vomit. Everything else (words, song) floats on the air.
column7: 3) [[twincy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/twincy)] 20-6-2007(27): Means _vomit_ as well. a more decent way to say what you thow up could be " _mouth_ _soil_ ".
column8: 4) [[Josh_Teperman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Josh_Teperman)] 9-1-2009(23): When you get _dirt_ in your _mouth_ , you have to **spit** it out.
column9: 5) [[smujohnson](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smujohnson)] 27-8-2008(10): Usually when people **SPIT** , it's because something is LEFT IN THEIR MOUTH … In that case, they just **spit** it out.. RIGHT on the GROUND!

column3: One of the things that causes the erosion of _soil_ is the excessive **pressure** of the top _soil_ on the lower _soil_. This can be caused by any number of things from heavy rainfall to heavy buildings to the absence of sufficient deep-rooted vegetation to hold the layers together. Here we see a steep _cliff_ without a tree in sight. The **slightest** pressure on it will cause a landslide, which, with a little help from your imagination, you will be able to see happening in this character.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(212): The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous **pressure**.
column6: 2) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 4-8-2007(52): For physics people: p = F/A (p:pressure, F:Force, A:Area). Where the force is from the immensity of the cliff. The area on the cliff is covered by soil. So the equation becomes p = F/A = cliff/soil which preserves the position of the primitives.
column7: 3) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 11-3-2008(38): The _cliff_ exerts a lot of **pressure** on the _ground_ beneath it.
column8: 4) [[rasteps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rasteps)] 1-10-2006(24): The taller the _cliff_ , the more **pressure** on the _soil_ below it.
column9: 5) [[Ningen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ningen)] 26-8-2008(10): Be careful of landslides! The _soil_ under the _cliff_ is under enormous **PRESSURE**.

column3: The **cape** pictured here is a jut of _land_ like **Cape** Cod. The _soil_ on the left tells us we have to do with _land_ , and the _strange_ on the right tells us it is a **_cape_** where unusual things go on. Put a haunted house on it, an eerie sky overhead, and a howling wind rustling through the trees, and you have yourself a picture of **Cape** _Strange_ (or, if you prefer, **Cape** _Odd_ ).
column5: 1) [[frychiko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/frychiko)] 3-7-2008(160): This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear.
column6: 2) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 27-5-2007(77): **Cape** Cod "odd" is a land where odd=strange things happen.
column7: 3) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 18-1-2009(57): A **CAPE** is a piece of LAND that stands out STRANGLY in the sea.
column8: 4) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 4-8-2007(43): It's quite strange. When I go to **Cape** Odd, I always end up soiling myself!
column9: 5) [[thegreatkaizo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegreatkaizo)] 19-7-2008(20): What the hell does the NASA do at **Cape** Canaveral? The _soil_ there looks kinda _strange_ …

column3: The **hedge** depicted in this frame is the miraculous **hedge** of briar roses that completely _spanned_ the castle _grounds_ in which Sleeping Beauty lay for a hundred years, so that none but her predestined beloved could find his way through it.
column5: 1) [[Wahlin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wahlin)] 29-8-2006(134): Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt **hedge** that spanned across.
column6: 2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 20-12-2007(76): The **HEDGE** of roses growing from the castle _grounds_ fully _spanned_ the castle walls.
column7: 3) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 10-3-2008(50): The **HEDGE** spans the **GROUNDS** of the estate.
column8: 4) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 5-9-2007(23): The entire grounds were spanned by a **hedge**.
column9: 5) [[eri401](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eri401)] 31-12-2009(18): The kanji also means a fence. Think of a dirt wall that spans your property. 石垣 = いしがき = stone wall.

column3: When we hear the world **inlay** , we usually think of setting precious stones in pieces of jewelery, but the primitive elements here suggest _truth_ being **inlaid** in the _soil_. You might think instead of the cosmic wisdom that **inlaid** the _truth_ of the universe in the stuff of the earth.
column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 9-4-2007(63): In a hole in the _ground_ , the body of the victim was placed. And then the killer **stuffed it up** so that the _truth_ would not be found out, he hoped.
column6: 2) [[Ragnarocko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ragnarocko)] 22-7-2008(26): I stuffed up his mouth with dirt to keep the truth from coming out.
column7: 3) [[Corodon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Corodon)] 11-7-2009(16): There is no _ground_ s for what you are saying. It's not _true_. You're just making **stuff up**. I ought to **stuff up** your mouth to make you STFU.
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 12-11-2012(11): The _ground_ appeared **stuffed up** with with random deposits, or was it **inlaid** with the _truth_ of the universe?
column9: 5) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 6-11-2011(9): I STUFFED DIRT into his mouth to keep the TRUTH from coming to out.

column3: Now I am going to do something unusual. The character in this frame is going to get one meaning and the primitive another, with no relation at all between the two. In time, I hope you will see how helpful this is. The kanji key word, **square jewel** , depicts a mammoth precious stone, several feet high, made by piling up large heaps of _soil_ on top of one another. Not something you would want to present your betrothed on your wedding day, but a good image for remembering this rare character, used chiefly in personal names nowadays.
column4: * As a primitive, we shall use this character to mean _ivy_ , that creepy vegetation that covers the surface of the _ground_ to form a sort of  "second" _ground_ that can get somewhat tricky to walk on without tripping.
column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 9-10-2005(166): Piling _SOIL_ upon _SOIL_ for aeons is how **SQUARE JEWEL** S are formed deep in the earth.
column6: 2) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 14-4-2008(62): How would you stop someone stealing your biggest **square jewel**? Bury it deep in the _soil_ under _ground_. Then plant _ivy_ to mark the spot.
column7: 3) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 3-2-2008(27): Layering _soil_ over _soil_ can create many things, from precious **SQUARE JEWEL** S to lush beds of _ivy_.
column8: 4) [[nesert](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nesert)] 3-10-2009(21): The pirate wanted to hide his **square jewel** well. So, he buried it in the _soil_ , under the _ground_ and planted poison _ivy_ over the spot.
column9: 5) [[keizai](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/keizai)] 4-11-2009(10): Soil upon Soil compressed to make Diamond **Square Jewel** s.

column3: Think of the key word **seal** as referring to a letter you have written and are preparing to close. Instead of using the traditional wax **seal** , you _glue_ a sprig of _ivy_ on the outside. In this way the elements _ivy_ and _glue_ give you a curious and memorable way to **seal** your secret letters.
column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 11-1-2006(128): The king used a special **seal** of ivy leaves glued onto his document.
column6: 2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 12-12-2007(64): A bit of _ivy_ _glued_ to a letter can make a lovely **SEAL** when in a pinch, says Martha Stewart.
column7: 3) [[tatsuya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tatsuya)] 20-10-2008(62): _Squared jewels_ with the right _measure_ ments receive the jeweler's **seal** of approval.
column8: 4) [[mafried](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mafried)] 26-2-2007(44): Be careful with the order. FIRST you wrap it up in _ivy_ , THEN you **seal** it with _glue_.
column9: 5) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 15-3-2011(20): Think of an old book of magic, **seal** ed to prevent it from harming the uninitiated. The **seal** ing spell is contained in a _square jewel_ which is _glue_ d to the cover. The cover of the book possibly also has an _ivy_ motif embossed in the cracked leather. 封 ふう sea, 封筒 ふうとう envelope, 封切る ふうぎる release a film, 封建 ほうけん feudalistic.

column3: After seeing a constant **horizon** of _water_ , _water_ everywhere for months at sea, could there be anything more delightful to the eyes than to look astern and see the _ivy_ -clad _cliffs_ of land on a new **horizon**? Of course, you'd need the eyes of a stellar telescope to recognize that the vegetation was in fact _ivy_ , but the phrase " _ivy_ -clad _cliffs_ " has such a nice ring to it that we won't worry about such details.
column5: 1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 10-9-2007(230): Try to reverse Heisig's story in this Kanji: imagine being trapped in one of those prison towers on an ivy cladcliff like in the movies. From your prison ontop the ivy clad cliff all you can see in the distant **horizon** is nothing but water.
column6: 2) [[jljzen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jljzen)] 3-1-2009(72): From the water, I can see the ivy-clad-cliffs on the **horizon**.
column7: 3) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 8-5-2008(39): Over the WATER and past the **HORIZON** there is said to be a CLIFF that holds a very rare JEWEL.
column8: 4) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 14-4-2008(17): Across the _water_ , I can see _ivy_ covered _cliffs_ on the **horizon**.
column9: 5) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 23-3-2007(11): Since Hesig doesn't have another Kanji with the keyword of "shore" it might be worth pointing out to folks here that this is the alternate meaning for this kanji asides from **horizon**. Also meshes well with Hesig's story spotting those Ivy clad Cliffs on the **horizon**. Spotting green and beautiful shore- land off in the distance across the water!!

column3: You have heard of people "attaching" themselves to a particular sect? Here is your chance to take that metaphor literally and imagine some fellow walking into a **Buddhist temple** with a fervent resolve to attach himself to the place. Since there is plenty of unused _land_ around the precincts, he simply picks out a suitable patch, brushes the soles of his feet with _glue_ , steps down firmly, and so joins the **Buddhist temple** as a  "permanent member."
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 3-9-2007(179): At the **Buddhist temple** the monks are seated on the _ground_ , _glued_ there in meditation.
column6: 2) [[Murjab](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Murjab)] 2-9-2007(45): To be allowed to join the **Buddhist temple** , imagine an aspiring monk being asked to stand still in the _soil_ for a long time in a _measurement_ of his resolve.
column7: 3) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 3-2-2008(21): How long a **BUDDHIST TEMPLE** has stood on its _grounds_ is often a _measure_ of its worth.
column8: 4) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 12-9-2007(12): The Buddhist in the temple sit on the _ground_ for years contemplating life, the universe, and everything. Not because they want to but because someone switched the floor wax with _superglue_.
column9: 5) [[hornlo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hornlo)] 12-5-2011(7): [ **Buddhist temple** = _soil_ / _glue_ ] - in a **Buddhist temple** , you can free yourself of the _earth_ that _glues_ you to this world.

column3: What is **time**?  asked St. Augustine in his memoirs. "Ask me not, and I know. Ask me, and I cannot tell you." Here we have the kanji's answer to that perennial riddle. **Time** is a _sun_ rising over a _Buddhist temple_. It sounds almost like a Zen kōan whose repetition might yield some deep secret to the initiated. At any rate, imagining a monk seated in meditation pondering it might help us remember the character.
column5: 1) [[zdnks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zdnks)] 31-10-2007(120): When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it's **time** to get up.
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 27-2-2008(102): In ancient Japan, **TIME** of ''day'' was announced at the ''buddhist temples''. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the **time** of day.
column7: 3) [[Ningen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ningen)] 26-8-2008(45): A _day_ at a _Buddhist temple_ is **TIME** well spent.
column8: 4) [[Tatiana](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tatiana)] 19-10-2006(21): You will fully understand the concept of **time** if you spend a _day_ in a _Buddhist temple_.
column9: 5) [[raye505](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raye505)] 5-6-2009(9): **Time** is marked by the sun at buddhist temples.

column3: The **level** this key word refers to is not the carpenter's tool but rather the even surface of a thing. It pictures _soil_ being scooped up into a _ladle_ and then made **level** (apparently because one is measuring _soil_ ). The excess _drops of soil_ are brushed off the top, which accounts for the added _drop_ at the _ladle's_ edge.
column5: 1) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 4-2-2008(268): _Soil_ is scooped up into a _ladel_. The extra _drop_ is brushed off to make it **level**.
column6: 2) [[mafried](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mafried)] 6-4-2009(49): To remember the extra stroke in the ladle, make a vivid image of a big drop of excess soil fr0m the ladle falling out onto the ground when you **level** it.
column7: 3) [[trebors](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/trebors)] 28-7-2010(41): 匀 = equal, not ladle 勺 = ladle. > so the story would be equal soil is equal to **level** ed ground.
column8: 4) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 12-12-2007(25): Kids like scooping _dirt_ with plastic _ladles_ when making mud pies and often sweep off the extra _bits of dirt_ to get it exactly **LEVEL**.
column9: 5) [[Aerithina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerithina)] 21-11-2008(7): Per LIVELLARE il SUOLO, prendi il MESTOLO e rimuovi quel BRICIOLO/GOCCIA di terreno in piú.

column3: Just as sitting before a **fire** enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames, this kanji is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of **fire** you want to see. It no longer makes a good pictograph, but I invite you to take a pencil and paper and play with the form - first writing it as shown below and then adding lines here and there - to see what you can come up with. Everything from matchbooks to cigarette lighters to volcanic eruptions to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah have been found here. No doubt you, too, will find something interesting to bend your memory around these four simple strokes.
column4: * To avoid confusion later on, it is best to keep to the meaning of a _fireplace_ (or _hearth_ ) or a raging _conflagration_ like a forest fire for this kanji's primitive meaning. Another primitive element for _fire_ , based on this one, is written as 4 small drops and will mean _flames_ , _cauldron_ , _cooking fire_ , or an _oven fire_.
column5: 1) [[munia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munia)] 22-2-2008(57): For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on **fire**!
column6: 2) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 16-6-2008(29): A tepee getting shot at by **fire** arrows.
column7: 3) [[mistamark](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mistamark)] 3-9-2008(23): To be honest, it just looks like the flames of a **fire** to me.
column8: 4) [[LoneDeranger](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LoneDeranger)] 7-2-2009(11): Looks like a flame of a campfire with two _drops of_ sparks flying off.
column9: 5) [[ryowarrior18](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ryowarrior18)] 16-8-2009(8): A **FIRE** bender from Avatar, wielding flames in both hands.

column3: A _fire_ belongs IN the _hearth_ , not OVER it. When the _fire_ spreads to the rest of the house, we have an **inflamed** house. And as with any **inflammation**  \- including those that attack our bodies - the danger is always that it might spread if not checked. This is the sense behind the reduplication of element for _fire_ , one atop the other.
column5: 1) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 28-2-2008(176): To fight **fire** with **fire** would just **inflame** a situation.
column6: 2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(52): An **inflammation** can often feel like FIRE upon FIRE burning.
column7: 3) [[TerryS](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TerryS)] 27-11-2008(32): If you have an **INFLAMMATION** , it feels like there's _fire_ above and below your skin.
column8: 4) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 5-8-2007(15): "Inflammable means flammable? What a country!" - from the Simpsons. Saying both flammable and inflammable helps you remember that there are two fires. **Inflammation** and inflammable have almost the same spelling.
column9: 5) [[ninalaura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ninalaura)] 1-11-2009(13): When you suffer from a bad **inflammation** , i.e. an infection, your body will fight it with a high fever. So it fights _fire_ with _fire_.

column3: The existential condition of **anxiety** that arises from the inevitable frustration of our worldly passions is contained in this character. The _head_ is set _afire_ , causing deep torment of spirit (and a whopper of a headache).
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(173): An **anxiety** feels like FIRE in the HEAD.
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 9-10-2007(96): Imagine the **anxiety** a librarian would feel if the library caught _fire_ and all the _pages_ of his books were burning up.
column7: 3) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 21-12-2005(70): Many performers get "Michael Jackson **anxiety** " wherein they fear their head will catch on fire.
column8: 4) [[PrettyKitty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PrettyKitty)] 4-7-2007(22): In ancient times, they said **anxiety** was cause by "fire in the head." Picture doctors prescibing many different crazy/silly ways to get the fire out of the patient's head. Now picture it like your watching a documentary on the History Channel about it. Not going to forget it anytime soon now. :).
column9: 5) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 5-11-2008(12): I would be feeling **anxiety** too if there was a _fire_ on my _head_!

column3: The primitives in this kanji read: _water_ . . . _inflammation_. Taking _inflammation_ in its medical sense, the first _water_ -related _inflammation_ that pops into mind is dehydration, the principal symptom of which is that it makes one shrivel up and look very, very **thin**. If that is hard to remember, try thinking it backwards: a very **thin** chap passes by and you imagine him suffering from (being _inflamed_ with) dehydration (hence the element for _water_ ).
column5: 1) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 11-10-2006(328): Drink _water_ and _burn twice_ as many calories as you eat… you'll definitely get **thin**. Imagine inside your body, all those calories literally being _burned_ from above and below… THAT's what it takes to become **thin**.
column6: 2) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 5-11-2008(182): **Thin** girls are twice as hot when they're wet.
column7: 3) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 29-9-2007(35): To become **thin** , simply go into a sauna. It may be as hot as a _conflagration_ , but you'll sweat ( _water_ ) and lose 10 pounds.
column8: 4) [[kaminix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaminix)] 31-7-2008(32): Adding _water_ to an _inflammation_ sure will make it a **thin** _fire_.
column9: 5) [[xingji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xingji)] 24-4-2008(25): Water + Fire over fire Faint, pale, fleeting, dim. (NOT **THIN**!) I remember it using its kun yomi : awa(i), because i see volcanic islands with water around. Yes Hawaii… (the kanji key whose keyword is dilute actually means **thin** ).

column3: Since it is very hard to read by the _fireplace_ without going blind from the flickering of the flames or burning up from the heat, our ancestors invented a way to _nail_ down a bit of that _fire_ , just enough to light up the text of their evening newspapers and no more. Voilà! The **lamp**.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 3-9-2007(202): Imagine old gas **lamp** s which had a _flame_ to light up the _street signs_.
column6: 2) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 5-10-2007(85): A **lamp** is _fire_ you can hang from a _nail_.
column7: 3) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 21-4-2008(21): When this symbol was created, a **lamp** was simply a _fire_ at the side of the _street_.
column8: 4) [[Evangelo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Evangelo)] 20-8-2008(19): _Warning: This story is graphic._ In Rome, after the Third Servile War, the losing rebels were crucified (on T shaped crosses) and set _on fire_ along the _road_ back to Rome. These human **lamp** s lit up the massive _road_ with burning corpses as a reminder not to lose against the Romans. Thanks Latin 3!
column9: 5) [[ACGalaga](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ACGalaga)] 5-2-2010(9): A long time ago they used _fire_ for _street_ **lamp** s.

column3: Looking at the primitives, a _fireplace_ and a _rice field_ , we find the essential ingredients for a **farm** : a warm _hearth_ to sit by at night, and a well-plowed _field_ to grow one's crops in by day.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(245): Many **farm** s are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 16-7-2007(49): When creating a **farm** , the prospective **farm** er must first set _fire_ to the forest to clear the ground. Only then can he plow the _fields_. _Fire_ before _fields_ to make a **farm**.
column7: 3) [[kashikoi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kashikoi)] 9-1-2009(45): This kanji actually makes a boatload of sense. In Japan, rice **farm** ers are constantly making little fires on their rice **farm** s burning up all the old stalks and things probably to be used as fertilizer. In moving to Japan, I found this practice to be very new and odd to me. So I would venture to guess that's exactly where this kanji comes from. If not, it certainly makes it really easy to remember.
column8: 4) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 5-10-2008(14): Crap! the _field_ in our neighbour's **farm** is on _fire_!
column9: 5) [[johngwk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johngwk)] 23-6-2010(5): On a Japanese **farm** , _fire_ is often set to the _rice_ fields (after harvest).

column3: Of all of nature's **disasters** , this kanji picks out two of the worst: _floods_ and _fires_. To recall the disposition of the elements, think of nature's solution to nature's own problem: a great _flood_ pouring down over a great forest _fire_.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(178): What a **disaster**! First a FIRE, then on top of it came FLOODs.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 2-5-2007(28): Don't know about Japan, but here in Australia, flooding rivers and bushfires are the most common natural **disaster** s.
column7: 3) [[colonel32](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/colonel32)] 20-1-2007(26): Godzilla pissing a _stream_ of _fire_ all over Tokyo. That is a **disaster**!
column8: 4) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 29-2-2008(17): _C_ -autioun- _C_ -aution- _C_ -aution: because of the _fire_ this is now a **disaster** area.
column9: 5) [[Marshall3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Marshall3)] 21-8-2009(12): There's a flood upstairs, and a fire in the basement. I think it's safe to say that this is a **disaster**.

column3: The kanji for **ashes** naturally includes the primitive for _fire_ , or more specifically, a _fireplace_. Now what do you do with that bucket of **ashes** you have just cleaned out of the _fireplace_? You walk to the edge of a _cliff_ and tip it upside down, watching as they are swept away in the wind like a swarm of gray mosquitoes. Thus the _fire_ , once it has turned to **ashes** , ends up at the bottom of the _cliff_.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 18-8-2007(125): The _fire_ underneath the _cliff_ will eventually turn everything above to **ashes**.
column6: 2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 2-2-2008(83): After the cremation _fire_ , many prefer to scatter their loved-one's **ASHES** from seaside _cliffs_.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 9-8-2007(57): Scene from "The Big Lebowski" : Walter scatters Donny's **ashes** , but a wind blows much of the **ashes** into "The Dude" Lebowski's face. Upset, The Dude lashes out at Walter. Walter apologizes and hugs The Dude, before suggesting "Fuck it, man. Let's go bowling." I bet you that The Dude wanted to cremate ( _fire_ ) Walter right there and then, at the top of the _cliff_! (thanks Elktapestry).
column8: 4) [[kirihitokiri](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kirihitokiri)] 9-3-2008(21): After _fire_ erupts from under the _cliff_ s (volcano) everything is covered in **ashes**. Thnx khooks!
column9: 5) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 13-6-2006(11): After fire erupts from the ground (volcano) the cliffs will be covered in **ashes**.

column3: If you look into the flickering of a _fire_ for a long time and then turn aside, you will see **spots** before your eyes. Although nobody ever thought of such a thing before - as least as far as know, they didn't - imagine using those **spots** as a technique for _fortune-telling_. The old witch sits before her _cauldron_ and watches the **spots** that show up when she turns to look at you, and from that _tells your fortune_. Think of it as a kind of **spot** -check on your future.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 27-7-2007(226): The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the **spot** because she was accused of being a witch.

column7: 3) [[noushina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/noushina)] 23-11-2012(33): The _Fortune Teller_ stares into an _Campfire_ until she sees **SPOTS**. She then interprets those **spot** s in the same manner than another fortune teller would look at tea leaves or the bumps on your head.

Like japanese tests are graded from 0 to 100 depending on how many **percent** of the questions they got correct. Before I learned any alternate meaning to this I took it as **percentage** = statistics. Now, wouldn't some pure and concrete **statistics** be just the thing you need to set that _fortune tellers_ mind on _fire_? Relate the setting him/her on fire to the entry for [anxiety](../v4/163.html) (#163 煩) if it helps. :).

column3: Although the range of possible meanings that the kanji for **illuminate** can have is about as rich as the connotations of the English word, we need to focus on just one of them: to make something _shine_. If you glaze a pot and put it into the _oven_ to _fire_ it, you in fact _illuminate_ it. Hence the kanji for **illuminate** compares the kanji for _shining_ with the primitive element for the _oven's fire_.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 27-7-2007(276): SHINING FLAMES **illuminate**!
column6: 2) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 16-9-2007(91): The sun was seduced to give us fire, by which we **illuminate** the night.
column7: 3) [[rotifera](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rotifera)] 16-11-2007(43): Just _shining_ is not enough to **illuminate**. The shiny thing needs to be even brighter. Maybe set it on _fire_?
column8: 4) [[wzafran](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wzafran)] 2-6-2007(27): You find yourself trapped in an unfamiliar cavern, engulfed in darkness. You wield a Rod of Light with your right hand, its tip is _shining_ , but faintly. Thence, with your other hand, you cast a spell and set _fire_ to the rod. And this rod, which shines with much greater fervour than before, is what would **illuminate** a path before you, that you then follow until you reach the outer caverns.
column9: 5) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 28-3-2008(23): The man who shines shoes in the day stands alone at night in the cold, dark city. He keeps himself warm in front of a burning trash barrel, his face **illuminated** by the flames.

column3: The composition of this kanji shows three elements, which we list in the order of their writing: _bound up_ . . . _rice field_ . . . _cooking fire_. Not much to work with at first sight. But we can join them together by thinking of a three-part story: first a **fish** is caught and _bound up_ on a line with its unfortunate school-mates, when the fisherman gets home, he cuts off the head and tosses it, with the entrails, out into the _rice fields_ for fertilizer, and the rest he sets in a skillet over a _cooking fire_ for his supper.
column5: 1) [[silkcherryblossoms](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/silkcherryblossoms)] 10-6-2007(106): The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind **fish**.
column6: 2) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 12-2-2008(56): _Bind_ that **FISH** and _cook_ his _brains_! Yarhh!
column7: 3) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(42): That **fish** was caught, BOUND UP, then carried across RICE FIELDS, and finally cooked over an OVEN FIRE.
column8: 4) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 20-9-2010(18): Think of (cooked) salmon onigiri. The **fish** is _bound up_ in _rice_ and cooked over a _fire_ … 魚 [さかな] [、金魚](midori://search?text=、金魚) [きんぎょ] [、魚市場](midori://search?text=、魚市場) [おういちば].
column9: 5) [[Keiran_Halcyon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Keiran_Halcyon)] 9-7-2009(9): I like my **fish** _bound_ with _rice_ over a nice _fire_. Sushi!!

column3: To the story we have just made about _fish_ , this kanji for the profession of **fishing** adds yet another element BEFORE the others: namely the _water_ , where the fish was happily at home before being caught, disemboweled, and eaten. Be sure to get a clear image of the _water_  when you put it all together.

column9: 5) [[bspitz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bspitz)] 9-2-2010(10): **Fishing** is taking _fish_ out of _water_.

column3: That's right - a **_ri_**. Don't bother looking it up in your English dictionary, it's a Japanese word for measuring distances. One **_ri_** is about 4 kilometers or 2.5 miles. The kanji depicts how the measure came to be used. Atop we see the _rice field_ , and below the element for _land_. Those four sections you see in the _rice field_ (and which we made mention of when first we introduced the character in frame 14) are actually measurements of _land_ , much the same as farm-sections in the United States have given us the notion of a "country mile." The _land_ division based on the size of a _rice field_ is called a **_ri_**.
column4: * To get a more concrete primitive meaning for this kanji, we shall refer to it as a _computer_ , a meaning deriving from the kanji for _logic_ , which we will meet in Lesson 12.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(141): The **ri** is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a **RI** CE FIELD.

You'll save a lot (and I mean, a whole lot) of trouble later by giving it instead its intended meaning: **House of the Parents**.
