column8: 4) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 27-2-2011(35): My **parents' house** is on a _rice field_ , I _compute_ the _ground_ area being one **ri** by one **ri**. 古里 (ふるさと) : home town, birthplace, old village, historic village, native place, one's old home, 郷里 (きょうり) : birth- place, home town.
column9: 5) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 1-2-2009(33): It frustrates me that Hesig doesn't give any mention to another prominent meaning of the 里 / **Ri** Kanji being used for さと meaning a country village or home. perhaps he thought it would be too confusing for one to remember two different types of villages and distinguish this from 町 … however… If I think of that one as まち and this one as さと it keeps things straight in my head and allows me to skip the whole confusing path of thinking of this as a "computer" which just seems somewhat wrong.

column3: Like most things electrical, a _computer_ , too, can overheat. Just imagine _flames_ pouring out of it and charring the keyboard, the monitor, and your desk a sooty **black** color.

column3: Besides meaning **black ink** , this kanji also appears in the word for an inked string that is pulled taut and snapped to mark a surface, much the same as one might used a chalked string. Here it is used to mark off the _dirt_ with _black_ lines for a foot ballgame (played, I presume, on a white field).

column3: No doubt you will find it in your heart to forgive me for forcing yet another Japanese word on you in this frame. It is not the last time it will happen in this book, but I can assure you they are used only when absolutely necessary. One **_rin_** is equal to about 1/1000 of a yen - or rather was worth that much when it still made economic sense to mint them. While inflation took its toll on this kanji as a monetary unit, it survived with the not at all surprising sense of something  "very, very tiny." The kanji shows a _cliff_ with a _computer_ under it, apparently because it has been pushed over into the abyss by someone fed up with the thing. The total market value of one home _computer_ that has fallen over rock and bramble for several hundred feet: about one **_rin_**!
column5: 1) [[krungthep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/krungthep)] 26-3-2008(198): I threw my **Rin** dows _computer_ off a _cliff_ because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it's worth less than a **rin**.
column6: 2) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 16-2-2008(76): A _computer_ dropped off of a _cliff_ would be worth about 1 **RIN**.
column7: 3) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 7-4-2008(50): The Square Root of 1 RI = 1 **RIN**.
column8: 4) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 12-7-2007(33): He dropped his _computer_ from the top of the _cliff_ and it turned to smithe- **rin** -s.
column9: 5) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 26-3-2007(25): Looking down at the 里 from the high cliff above such a tiny country village looks even smaller like something very very tiny and insignificant… Like a りん / **Rin**. Also might be worth-while to note now that this isn't just 1/10th of a 銭 but also 1/10th of a 分 or rather… 0.3mm in length. Perhaps imagine holding up a ruler from that high up to measure the tiny speck of a 里 below and note it coming out to 0.3mm in length. [ずっとずっと小さいですね～](midori://search?text=ずっとずっと小さいですね～) !!

column3: When we speak of **burying** something (or someone, for that matter), we usually mean putting them under _ground_. Only here, we are **burying** our beloved _computer_ that has served us so well these past years. Behind us a choir chants the  "Dies irae, dies illa" and there is much wailing and grief among the bystanders as they pass by to shovel a little _dirt_ into what will be its final resting place. R.I.P.
column5: 1) [[Rowan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rowan)] 21-9-2007(120): You can't **bury** computers underground, because of the dangerous heavy metals, so you hide them behind an equally large mound of soil and hope no-one notices.

column3: The primitives in this kanji show us _one_ and _mouth_ under a _hood_. Let us take the key word to connote the **sameness** that characterizes the life in community of the monk. They all have the **same** habits, including the "habit" they wear on their backs. Here we see the monk's _cowl_ , drawn down over the eyes so that all you can see when you look at him is a _mouth_. But since monks also speak their prayers in common, it is but a short step to think of _one mouth_ under a _hood_ as the kanji for the **sameness** of monastic life.
column4: * As a primitive, this will mean _monks_ dressed in a common habit.

column3: The key word **den** refers to an animal lair hollowed out in the side of a mountain. Now if we keep to the image of the monastic life as an image for _same_ , we can picture a **den** of wild beasts dressed up in habits and living the common life in a mountain cavern. To bring in the element of _water_ we need only give them a sacred  "puddle" in the center of their **den** , the focus of all their pious attentions.

So a **den** is where you'd find nothing but _water_ (to drink) and a _monk_. 洞 ほら cave, **den** , grotto, 洞窟 どうくつ cave, 洞察 どうさつ discernment, insight.

column3: Something referred to as "over **yonder** " is usually far off in the distance and barely within sight - like a wee _drop_ in the distance - and is usually an expression used in giving directions or pointing something out. Hence this kanji begins with a _drop_. Then we find a sort of transparent _helmet_ with no eyes or nose, but only a prominent _mouth_ under it, obviously an extraterrestrial. And what is it jabbering on about with its _mouth_ open like that? Why, about his spaceship way over **yonder** with its fuel tank on empty.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 5-9-2007(142): Look over **yonder** ! That tiny _dot_ is robin _hood_ at the _mouth_ of his secret cave !

As his last _DROPs_ of oxygen escaped into the vastness of space he thought to himself, So much for flying off into the wild blue _YONDER_.

column3: Above we see the primitive for _little_ attached to one of those _glass canopies_ you might use to display a family heirloom. The _littleness_ is important, because what is in fact on display is the shrunken, stuffed, and mounted _mouth_ of an **esteemed** ancestor. We may be used to **esteeming** the words our forebears leave behind, but here we also **esteem** the very _mouth_ that spoke them. I leave it to you to imagine a suitable place in your room for displaying such an unusual conversation piece.
column5: 1) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 14-10-2007(242): An especially **esteem** ed alien has three antennae on his helmet.

That was Obi-Wan's trick to get Luke to build his self- **esteem** , or his confidence in the Force.

column3: Here is the character for **character** itself. Not just kanji, but any written **character** from hieroglyphs to Sanskrit to our own Roman alphabet. It shows us simply a _child_ in a _house_. But let us take advantage of the double-meaning of the key word to note that just as a _child_ born to a Japanese _house_ is given **characters** for its name, so it is also stamped with the **character** of those who raise it from infancy on.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(110): CHILDren learn Kanji **character** s underneath a HOUSE.
column6: 2) [[komodo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/komodo)] 22-6-2008(82): "Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father?" "Shut up! It builds **character**!".
column7: 3) [[axelb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/axelb)] 19-3-2008(53): The first kanji **character** s you will learn in Japan is probably learnt at home (in the _house_ of your family) when you are still a _child_. Imagine a really small preschool child doing this (to prevent confusing house with school like in [study](../v4/324.html) (#324 学)).
column8: 4) [[harusame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harusame)] 30-4-2009(22): The way a child grows up in his house determines his **character**.
column9: 5) [[applesuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/applesuki)] 15-2-2006(19): Imagine a child in his home (under the roof) sitting at the kitchen table practicing his kanji **character** s.

column3: The notion of **guarding** something easily brings to mind the image of someone standing **guard** , like the royal soldiers in front of Buckingham Palace or the Pope's Swiss **Guard**. The whole idea of hiring **guards** is that they should stick like _glue_ to your _house_ to protect it from unwanted prowlers. So go ahead and _glue_ a **guard** to your _house_ in imagination.
column5: 1) [[certain](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/certain)] 5-4-2006(173): A **GUARD** is usually "glued" to the house he watches.
column6: 2) [[rakutenka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rakutenka)] 2-7-2007(65): A **guard** provides a _measure_ of security to those under a _roof_.
column7: 3) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 16-12-2007(37): A good **GUARD** should stick to your _house_ like _glue_ and be willing to take any _measures_ to protect you.
column8: 4) [[strobrod](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/strobrod)] 5-4-2009(12): A good **guard** never leaves the _house_ he watches over. He's practically _glued_ to it.
column9: 5) [[jshield1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jshield1)] 21-4-2009(6): A **guard** gives those under a roof a measure of security.

column3: In order not to confuse the key word **perfect** with others nearly synonymous in meaning, pull it apart to have a look at its native Latin roots. _Per- factum_ suggests something so  "thoroughly made or done" that nothing more needs to be added to it. Now look at the kanji, which does something similar. We see a _house_ that has been made **perfectly** from its _beginnings_ in the foundation to the roof on the top. Now return to frame 101 and make sure not to confuse this key word with the kanji for _complete_.
column5: 1) [[yukina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yukina)] 3-11-2006(172): Make the **perfect** impression in the _beginning_ by removing your shoes upon entering a Japanese _home_.
column6: 2) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 2-12-2007(154): In the beginning, Adam and Eve had a home in Eden. It was **perfect**.
column7: 3) [[kokeshidoll17](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kokeshidoll17)] 20-8-2008(51): Their new _house_ was the **perfect** place to _begin_ a family.
column8: 4) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 10-4-2009(30): At the _beginning_ of the party the _house_ was **perfect**. Now look at it!
column9: 5) [[zanthan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zanthan)] 31-12-2006(29): My idea of **perfect** is just the _two_ of us ( _human legs_ ) under one _roof_. Like how it was _original_ ly, _in the beginning_ of our relationship. He _completes_ me. 完全 [かんぜん] (adj-na,n) **perfect** ion, completeness, (P) 完璧 [かんぺき] (adj-na) **perfect** , complete, flawless, (P).

column3: Under the primitive for _house_ we meet the kanji for _span_. Think of the key word in its religious sense of missionary preaching:  " **proclaiming** the good news to all nations " and "shouting it from the _housetops_. " That should be enough to help you remember this simple kanji, used in fact both for traditional missionary work as well as for one of its contemporary replacements: advertising.
column5: 1) [[frychiko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/frychiko)] 14-2-2008(304): You can **proclaim** your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet.
column6: 2) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 27-8-2007(59): I heard young Muslims have to memorise the Koran and **proclaim** it aloud as a kind of rite of passage. Imagine the SPAN of hours spent under a ROOF practising that! It must surely be worse than trying to get through Heisigs RTK - count yourself lucky.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 25-10-2007(42): A local official **proclaim** s a curfew _spanning_ sunset to sunrise - you must stay under your own _roof_ during that time _span_. I keep wanting to add in the "words" 言 primitive. Don't think about someone reading it aloud - focus on the CURFEW that was **proclaim** ed. I also tend to confuse this one with [imperial edict](../v4/342.html) (#342 詔). Remember this proclamation comes from a petty local official.
column8: 4) [[tstuhldreher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tstuhldreher)] 16-6-2008(36): I keep thinking about the Irish one-hit band the **Proclaim** ers, who promised to walk 500 miles – quite a long SPAN – to reach your HOUSE.
column9: 5) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 26-2-2008(23): **Proclaim** something loud enough that **spans** the **roof** tops.

column3: As the key word hints, the kanji in this frame refers to the late evening or early morning hours, well after one should be in bed asleep. It does this by picturing a _house_ with a _candle_ in it. The reason is obvious: whoever is living there is  "burning the _candle_ at both ends, " and working night after night into the **wee hours**.
column5: 1) [[mikes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mikes)] 7-5-2007(239): I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the **WEE HOURS** reviewing the kanji!!!
column6: 2) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 3-4-2008(87): I agree with elktapestry. This kanji really means "early evening", not "wee hours" [Heisig really should have done his homework on this and several other characters (e.g., #145 "but of course" – what the hell???). Oh well.] "Every _house_ lights _candles_ in the EARLY EVENING which stay lit until the **wee hours** ". E.G. 宵の口 （よいのくち）early evening, 今宵 （こよい）this evening, tonight.
column7: 3) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 27-3-2007(55): The fixed definition of this Kanji that Hesig gives seems deceptive and misleading. This not only refers to **wee hours** of the morning but also Evening and Early Night. So it seems to span the whole range of times when one might need a candle to work within the confines of one's house without daylight. Shows me that I can never trust one source of information exclusively, especially not Hesig. I thank him for this sytem of memorization, but still…
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 8-2-2007(12): In the log _house_ the **wee hours** are spent studying by _candle_ light.
column9: 5) [[krungthep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/krungthep)] 9-5-2008(5): In the **wee hours** I usually stay at _home_ lit by a _candle_ playing with my _little_ bit of _flesh_ until it bears _resemblance_ to a _candle_.

column3: To be told that the place of the _woman_ is in the _house_ may not sit well with modern thought, but like all cultural habits the Chinese characters bear the birthmarks of their age. So indulge yourself in a Norman Rockwell image of **relaxing** after a hard day's work: the scruffy and weary _woman_ of the _house_ slouched asleep in the living room chair, her hair in curlers and a duster lying in her lap.
column5: 1) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 27-3-2007(142): It's funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive… well… if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. Sometimes I wonder if Hesig just thinks our little brains would be too easily confused by multiple meanings. Regardless, think of that woman **relax** ing. Cheapest place to do that is in one's own home rather than at some fancy resort, eh? [家で休暇を取るは安いですね。](midori://search?text=家で休暇を取るは安いですね。) .
column6: 2) [[enerccio](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enerccio)] 22-7-2007(83): You can only **relax** , when you have woman under roof to do all chores.
column7: 3) [[Po0py](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Po0py)] 20-12-2008(65): Cheapest place for a woman to **relax** is in her own home.
column8: 4) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 22-3-2008(31): To me, this kanji has always meant "cheap/inexpensive." The way to remember this kanji is: A woman under a roof is cheap, because she isn't off spending your money! Now you'll never forget it!
column9: 5) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 21-1-2008(22): No one who has ever been to Japan could have failed to notice the **relax** ed life of the housewifes. While the husband slaves 14 hours a day at work, the _woman_ of the _house_ meets up with friends in cafes, takes piano lessons, goes shopping (no wonder Heizig didn't want to use **cheap** as keyword), watch TV dramas…oh, and take care of their 1.2 (and going down) children. A _woman_ in a _house_ is the perfect symbol for _relax_.

column3: To carry on from the last frame, we note the entire _day_ of work that comes between a _woman_ and her _house_ in preparing for a dinner **banquet** , pictorially "interrupting" her _relaxation_.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(216): The WOMAN spent all DAY preparing a **banquet** in the HOUSE.
column6: 2) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 12-4-2008(88): Under the _roof_ , all _day_ long, the _woman_ prepared for the **banquet** (this wording helps me remember the order of this kanji's elements).
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 15-11-2007(42): The _woman_ cannot relax 安 in her _house_ because she only has one _day_ to prepare a **banquet**.
column8: 4) [[General_Maxon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/General_Maxon)] 24-11-2009(10): An entire _day_ of work for the **banquet** stands between the _woman_ and the _relaxation_ in her _house_.
column9: 5) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 29-1-2009(9): To prepare for a **BANQUET** , you need to stay in the HOUSE whole DAY, and you need the help of a WOMAN!

column3: Let the idea of **drawing near** suggest something dangerous or eerie that one approaches with fear and trembling. Here we see a _strange house_ \- perhaps the haunted _House_ of Usher that Edgar Allen Poe immortalized, or the enchanted Gingerbread _House_ that lured Hansel and Gretel to **draw near**.
column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 14-11-2007(195): The _strange house_ has a sign saying "DRAW NEAR" in its window, instead of a 'Beware' sign. It must be a trick!
column6: 2) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 9-10-2007(66): Imagine a horror movie set in a haunted mansion. The _house_ is very _strange_. The characters **draw near** to one another for protection against the unknown.
column7: 3) [[jonny49cc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonny49cc)] 17-7-2008(54): There is something strange in this house. Do you dare to **draw near**?
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-4-2007(24): Hans and Gretel slowly and carefully **drew near** the _strange_ gingerbread _house_ in the clearing.
column9: 5) [[lexuten](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lexuten)] 15-8-2008(19): As I **draw near** , I see something strang in the house.

column3: Here we have the original character on which the primitive element for **wealth** is based. In keeping with the story introduced back then, note how all the **wealth** is kept under the roof of the same _house_.
column5: 1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 10-9-2007(102): Remember Ducktales? That rich duck had that room in his house where he kept all the **wealth**! He had so much in that house you could even swim in it!
column6: 2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(88): In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of **wealth** as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE.
column7: 3) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 9-11-2008(36): A HOUSE with only ONE MOUTH and a RICE FIELD has a lot of **WEALTH**.
column8: 4) [[MRT88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MRT88)] 23-9-2009(16): The family kept all the **wealth** under one _roof_.
column9: 5) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 23-1-2008(8): **Wealth** can be assessed only when it's under the _roof_.

column3: To avoid confusing this frame with the last one, try to think of **savings** as actual money. The only difference is that our currency is not paper bills but _shells_ , a not uncommon unit of exchange in older civilizations. The _nail_ under the roof of the _house_ points to a hiding place in the rafters on which one strings up one's _shells_ for safekeeping.
column5: 1) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 9-10-2007(158): It takes a lot more than one _clam_ of **savings** to buy a _house_ on a _street_.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 17-6-2008(68): My **SAVINGS** plan - I _nail_ my _money_ bags up in the rafters below my _roof_. I'm very secretive about it, and I wear a disguise with a big **mustache** (another meaning of this kanji) while I stash my loot.
column7: 3) [[trurlo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/trurlo)] 14-2-2011(56): **savings** = _money_ kept under the _roof_ rather than spent on the _street_.
column8: 4) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 18-4-2008(53): **Savings** are the _clams_ you have _nailed_ down under your _roof_.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 27-8-2007(14): A slightly smarter guy has all of his **SAVINGS** \- in the form of **shells** \- **nailed up** just under the eaves of the **floating roof**.

column3: Here we see a pictograph of a **tree** , showing the main trunk in the long vertical stroke and the boughs in the long horizontal stroke. The final two strokes sweep down in both directions to indicate the roots. Although it may look similar at first sight to the kanji for _water_ (Frame 137), the order in which it is written is completely different and this affects its final appearance.
column4: * As a primitive, this kanji can be used to mean _tree_ or _wood_. In those cases where the last two strokes are detached from the trunk, we shall change its meaning to _pole_ , or _wooden pole_.
column5: 1) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 28-6-2008(137): If you need a story for a **tree** , then you need to be hit by one.
column6: 2) [[beth266](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/beth266)] 2-8-2009(18): Pictograph of a **tree**.
column7: 3) [[fiminor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fiminor)] 16-3-2007(10): As a primitive, I often use Tolkein's Ents as they have more scope for adventure than ordinary inanimate **tree** s.
column8: 4) [[pjdekl](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pjdekl)] 28-1-2010(9): _<http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VaRBrHxNcFA>_ watch it!
column9: 5) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 16-10-2007(7): [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The **tree** ( 木 ) is not yet ( 末 ) vermilion ( 朱 ).

column3: Learn this frame in connection with the next one. A **grove** is a small cluster of _trees_. Hence the simple reduplication of the kanji for _tree_ gives us the **grove**.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(92): A **grove** has at least two TREEs.
column6: 2) [[coolbananas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/coolbananas)] 6-3-2009(23): If you need a mnemonic to remember this then you had better give up now!
column7: 3) [[hornlo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hornlo)] 15-5-2011(12): [ **grove** = _tree_ \+ _tree_ ] - a **grove** is between a single [tree](../v4/195.html) (#195 木) and a many-treed [forest](../v4/197.html) (#197 森).
column8: 4) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 21-12-2007(6): Two _trees_ together make up a **GROVE**.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 8-6-2008(4): "I must…safe guard the **GROVE** " says the Keeper of the **Grove** as he uses his treant ability to cast TWO TREE minions. (warcraft III reference).

column3: A **forest** is a large expanse of _trees_ , or " _trees_ , _trees_ everywhere, " to adopt the expression we used back in frames 22 and 23.
column5: 1) [[sharak10](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sharak10)] 27-10-2007(60): The higher you go up a mountain the less trees there are, that's so u dont mess up with their possition like i do.
column6: 2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 21-12-2007(32): Another _tree_ planted within a _grove_ turns it into a **FOREST**.
column7: 3) [[axisj](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/axisj)] 2-8-2009(14): Many Trees make a **forest**.
column8: 4) [[KREVA](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/KREVA)] 13-9-2008(12): A triangle of _trees_ is all that's needed to depict a **forest**.
column9: 5) [[Kimya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kimya)] 4-11-2011(8): A triforce of trees makes a **forest**.

column3: Unless you are a botanist, you are not likely to know what a **Japanese Judas- tree** looks like, and probably never even heard of it before, but the name is sufficiently odd to make remembering it easy. Using the primitives as our guide, we define it as a _tree_ with _ivy_ growing down its branches in the shape of a hangman's rope.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 26-1-2006(158): Simple mnemonic : "The **Japanese Judas-tree** is the _tree_ on which Judas hang himself to the _ivy_ " (Judas the traitor of the Christian bible). Just picture Judas hanging himself, using _ivy_ as a if it was a rope.
column6: 2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 6-1-2008(92): A _tree_ covered in poison _ivy_ will quickly betray you, thus the name **JAPANESE JUDAS-TREE**.
column7: 3) [[kaminix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaminix)] 2-3-2008(35): The **Katsura** ( **Japanese Judas-tree** ) is a thin _tree_ (sort of like the stretched out 木 used in this kanji) with little green (the color of an emerald, a _jewel_ ) leaves. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsura_>(tree).
column8: 4) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 4-8-2008(15): Japanese JEWEL TREE sounds like JUDAS-tree.
column9: 5) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 28-3-2007(13): Interesting… this tree is called a かつら (Katura) Tree in Japan. It got the **Japanese Judas-Tree** distinction because it bears a similar leaf-type to the Judas Tree found in Europe and such. For fun word-play with both the Judas & Katsura distinctions… it might be good to learn that a homonym for Katsura (w/different Kanji 鬘) is a hairpiece or wig! So now imagine some dishevled business man with a funny hairpiece stringing ivy around the Katsura/Judas tree to hang himself with!!

column3: This kanji calls to mind the famous myth of the "golden bough." As you may recall, what made the sacred **oak** in the forest of Diana the Huntress outside of Rome  "golden" were the _white_ berries of the mistletoe that grew in the branches of the tree. When the light of the sun shone through them, they turned yellow and the branch to which they clung appeared to be made of gold. (If you don't know the story, take a break today and hunt it down in a dictionary of myth and fable. Even if you forget the kanji - which of course you won't - the story of the mistletoe and the fate it brought to Balder the Beautiful is most memorable.)
column5: 1) [[lilpea](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lilpea)] 12-8-2007(121): The wood from **oak** _trees_ can be used to make barrels in which _white_ wine is aged. What's more, I love _white_ wine with an **oaky** flavour…
column6: 2) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 31-3-2008(104): An **oak** _tree_ is _white_ , from left to right!
column7: 3) [[Mesqueeb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Mesqueeb)] 1-2-2009(69): [Pokemon] Ash :: "Going to **Oak** for my first Pokemon!" Mom :: " **Oak** , **Oak**? That _tree_?" Ash :: "Noo! Professor **Oak**! You know, he always wears a _white_ coat!" Mom :: "Okay dear! Don't forget clean underwear!".
column8: 4) [[lbphenom](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lbphenom)] 28-1-2008(39): The white tree of Minas Tirith was an **oak**!
column9: 5) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 19-10-2011(13): Prof. **Oak** ( オオキド博士 to Japanese fans) is named after a tree and has white hair.

column3: You might think of the **frame** this character refers to as the sort of **frame** we have created by drawing a dark line around this kanji and its explanation. Then think of that line as made of very thin _wood_ , and finally note how each time the line bends it forms a 90° angle, thus giving us the _nine_ and the _ten_.
column5: 1) [[alkulp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alkulp)] 22-10-2007(176): **wood** at **90 (9 * 10)** degrees.
column6: 2) [[javiergakusei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/javiergakusei)] 24-10-2007(93): Nine out of ten picture **frame** s are made out of wood. The rest are made of metal or plastic.
column7: 3) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 11-12-2010(40): A good _wood_ en **frame** has perfect right angles at each corner: _ninety_ degrees at each one. 枠 (わく) : **frame** , slide.
column8: 4) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 8-5-2008(12): **Nine- tenths** of all **frame** s are made of **wood** (9 over 10).
column9: 5) [[Es2Key](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Es2Key)] 27-1-2011(9): Wooden **frame** 9x10.

column3: As the days grow shorter and shorter, or so the northern European myth goes, the fear grows that the sun will take its leave of us altogether, abandoning the world to total darkness. Fixing _candles_ to the branches of evergreen _trees_ , it was believed, would lure the sun back (like things attracting like things), whence the custom of the lighted tree that eventually found its way into our Christmas customs. The story is a lot longer and more complex than that, but it should help to fix the image of climbing high up into the **treetops** to fix _candles_ on the _tree_.
column5: 1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 30-9-2007(184): At Christmas time, on the **treetops** , people used to place great big _candles_ (Now we usually place a star instead).
column6: 2) [[Tatiana](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tatiana)] 22-10-2006(46): If you cut off the **treetops** , they still _resemble_ the _trees_ they used to be part of. **Treetops** = _tree_ _resemblance_.
column7: 3) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 14-4-2007(25): A gigantic _candle_ is standing to the right of the _tree_ , the flame rising higher than the **treetops**.
column8: 4) [[Ji_suss](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ji_suss)] 24-8-2008(17): Doesn't really mean **treetops**. It means the end of a branch. In English, the name for each year's new growth at the end of every branch is a "candle". Same in Japanese.
column9: 5) [[LeoOra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LeoOra)] 28-2-2008(12): The tops of the trees, as in the fractal theory, resembles a whole tree if you look from afar.

column3: One often thinks of books as "good _companions_ ," but here it is the **shelf** we store them on that is the _companion_. The reasons should be obvious: it is made of the same stuff, _wood_ , and spends a lot more time with them than we do! Here again, be careful not to let the rationality of the explanation get in the way before you turn it into a proper story.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 11-10-2007(247): A **shelf** is a _wooden companion_ to books.
column6: 2) [[TaylorSan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TaylorSan)] 2-3-2009(75): I think of an Otaku, with a _wooden_ **shelf** full of anime action figure statures, who are sadly his only _companions_.
column7: 3) [[komodo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/komodo)] 17-6-2008(28): My ideal _companion_ would have an ass I could use as a **shelf**. Just look at those two _flesh_ y hemispheres. The association of _wood_ should come easily.
column8: 4) [[joxn_costello](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joxn_costello)] 22-11-2008(14): A **shelf** is made out of _wood_ , and it is a _companion_ to books. But most importantly for me, the _two moons_ look like the spines of hardbound books standing next to one another as _companions_ on a **shelf**.
column9: 5) [[terozen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/terozen)] 25-3-2012(7): A _wooden_ **shelf** is the perfect _companion_ to all my lovely books!

column3: Since **apricots** can be eaten just as they fall from the _trees_ , picture this _mouth_ agape at the bottom of a _tree_ (just as the elements have it), waiting for **apricots** to fall into it.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 21-12-2007(195): From the _tree_ straight into the _mouth_ is the best way to eat an **APRICOT**!
column6: 2) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 8-9-2006(37): Imagine Totoro sleeping under his _tree_. As he snores a giant **apricot** falls nicely into his open _mouth_ and he emits a giant burp of satisfaction. I can hear that music alreay….to - to to - to - ro…
column7: 3) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 12-8-2007(28): If you eat **apricot** s too fast, you'll end up eating the pits too. And we all know what happens then - an **apricot** tree will grow out of your mouth.
column8: 4) [[oohansel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oohansel)] 9-8-2009(18): The **apricot** fell from the TREE into my MOUTH.
column9: 5) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 24-2-2009(7): I lay under the **apricot** _tree_ and let the delicious **apricot** s drop into my _mouth_.

column3: Since you probably don't know what a **paulownia** _tree_ is, we shall let the key word suggest the phrase  "the Little Brothers of St. **Paulownia.** " It is a short step to associate the _tree_ with the _monks_ to its right. (For the curious, the name of this oriental _tree_ really comes from a Russian princess, Anna Pavlovna.)
column5: 1) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 29-3-2007(371): In Japan, a **paulownia** (きり）is known as the "princess tree". It was once a traditional TREE planted at the SAME time as the birth of a daughter. It would grow fast enough that, at the time of her wedding, it could be used to make a dresser as a wedding present for her.
column6: 2) [[akira](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akira)] 1-2-2007(98): **Paulownia** is a Japanese tree which looks same as any other tree.
column7: 3) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 8-2-2013(32): In the forest, there's a tree that my goofy friend PAUL claims he OWNS. I think he's nuts, because the tree looks the SAME as all the others.In Japan, a **paulownia** (きり）is known as the "princess tree".
column8: 4) [[totokan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/totokan)] 6-11-2007(12): Also called Phoenix tree. After the wood is harvested the tree regenerates from its roots. The same tree comes up again.
column9: 5) [[gagge_tah](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gagge_tah)] 13-8-2009(7): Paul owns the _same_ _tree_ as everyone else, a **paulownia**. // not every tree as in [plum](../v4/460.html) (#460 梅).

column3: You have no doubt seen how people practicing the Japanese art of bonsai take those helpless little saplings and twist them into crippled dwarves before they have a chance to grow up as they should. The more proper way to **plant** a young _tree_ and give it a fair shake in life is to set it into the earth in such a way that it can grow up _straight_.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 18-8-2007(273): **Plant** s don't become _tree_ s _straightaway_.
column6: 2) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 28-6-2008(109): When you **plant** **plant** s, you use a piece of WOOD to make the **plant** grow STRAIGHT.
column7: 3) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 10-9-2007(33): If you get a new tree it is of course best to go **plant** it straightaway. Without **plant** ing it straightaway the roots won't have enough time to be healthy and strong like the tree needs.
column8: 4) [[JohninJapan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/JohninJapan)] 9-1-2007(19): **PLANT** a TREE with tottoro and it might start growing STRAIGHTAWAY. (see tonari no tottoro :D).
column9: 5) [[kuraujiokun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kuraujiokun)] 10-7-2009(11): To **plant** : act of putting that small _tree_ _straight_ into the ground.

column3: Instead of making a **chair** out of wood from a _tree_ , this kanji has us making the whole _tree_ into a **chair** , which looks most _strange_ sitting in your living room where the sofa used to be.
column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 11-6-2007(156): To the Japanese, the first time they saw a **chair** , it looked like a _strange_ use of _wood_! Probably why they still like to sit on the floor…
column6: 2) [[Earthlark](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Earthlark)] 15-2-2011(29): <Http://www.pooktre.com/>.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 6-10-2007(14): A _strange_ kind of _tree_ grows in the shape of a **chair**.
column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 29-10-2009(8): Traditionally a _wooden_ **chair** would have been a _strange_ object in a Japanese home.
column9: 5) [[KanjiVirtuoso](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/KanjiVirtuoso)] 29-4-2012(1): _Wooden_ rocking **chair** s must've seemed pretty _strange_ to those seeing them for the first time.

column3: What makes a _tree_ begin to **wither** up, and perhaps even die, is a kind of arteriosclerosis that keeps its sap from flowing freely. Usually this is due to simple _old age_ , as this character shows us. Be sure to picture a wrinkled _old tree_ , **withering** away in a retirement center so that the commonsense explanation does not take over.
column5: 1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 16-10-2007(189): A tree **wither** s away as it gets old.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 15-11-2007(68): When flowers get old they _suffer_ (frame 225), but _old trees_ just **WITHER** away painlessly. (Picture flowers crying in pain, but a dried up tree silent and sad).
column7: 3) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 28-1-2008(17): The _tree_ is _old_ and **withered**.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 15-3-2009(7): I had trouble remembering this one using tree and old, so I just thought of what the _wood_ of an _old_ man would look like, and that did the trick.
column9: 5) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 29-5-2006(7): When flowers get old they are said to be _suffering_ (225) but there is no sympathy for the poor _old tree_ which simply **wither** s!

column3: As all magicians who have passed their apprenticeship know, one makes one's _wand_ out of a hazel branch and is careful not to alter the natural form of the _wood_. For the magic of the _wand_ derives its power from its association with the hidden laws of nature, and needs therefore to be kept in its **crude** , natural state.
column5: 1) [[simple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/simple)] 12-9-2007(153): _Wooden wands_ are the **crudest**. They are nothng compared to their carbon fibre equivilents.
column6: 2) [[wingedge](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wingedge)] 17-12-2007(78): A beginner magician starts with a **crude** _wooden magic wand_. Later he'll upgrade to magicite, of course.
column7: 3) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 4-9-2008(40): You can make a **crude** magic wand from any tree.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 16-9-2009(25): First year boys at Hogwarts tend to compare their _wood_ to their _wand_ , but this is considered **crude** behavior.
column9: 5) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 3-7-2009(22): This guy is so **crude** he doesn't face the tree when he relieves himself.

column3: The character for _village_ was associated with _rice fields_ (Frame 96). That for **town** , a step up on the evolutionary path to cities, shows a circle of _trees glued together_ to measure off the confines of a **town**.
column5: 1) [[zhangqiezi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zhangqiezi)] 29-5-2008(230): If you've ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you'll remember that every _town_ was all bordered off by a line of _trees_ with no space in between to get out through. Imagine that the trees were _glued together_ so you could only exit **town** through the main or side gates, (so you couldn't escape the important scripted scenes.).
column6: 2) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 3-4-2009(162): Pfft. At it's core, a **town** is just a bunch of _wood_ _glued_ together. Edit - Stop starring this piece of crap story! xD.
column7: 3) [[Sunday](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sunday)] 8-3-2008(65): There is a mix up, this kanji means むら=village, not **town**. The one for **town** is まち = 町 . 100% shure because my teacher is native Japanese.
column8: 4) [[Kieron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kieron)] 3-7-2007(57): I swap the _town/village_ keywords. See also [village](../v4/92.html) (#92 町). As the old Siberian joke went, there's nothing to do in a small rural **village** but count ( _measure_ ) the _trees_.
column9: 5) [[MikeNeko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MikeNeko)] 21-6-2008(48): 村 means village! See [village](../v4/92.html) (#92 町). Please don't get them confused like Heisig seems to have done. Story: See the _tree_ s surround the little **village** so densely it looks like they are _glued_ together. Imagine a little village on a hillside surrounded by trees with glue dripping off the trees.

column3: The prefix **inter-** stirs up associations of cooperation among people. From there we read off the elements: _tree_ . . . _eye_. With only a slight leap of the imagination, those two words call to mind the scriptural proverb about first taking the block of timber out of one's own _eye_ before helping your neighbors with the splinter in theirs. What more useful rule for **inter-** human relationships, and what more useful tool for remembering this kanji!
column5: 1) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 25-3-2008(225): The prime minister is having **inter-** course behind that _tree_! All you can see are his _eyes_ poking out from the righthand-side of the _tree_.
column6: 2) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 8-4-2008(94): ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. "Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb _trees_ to _eye_ each other's aspects and **inter-** act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government _ministers_ , with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck ( 首 , [neck](../v4/70.html) (#70 首)) becoming the prime _minister_ [「首相](midori://search?text=「首相) (しゅしょう)".
column7: 3) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 16-10-2007(39): I changed my story to remind myself there are other primary meanings for this character: The Minister of _Trees_ has a good _eye_ for **inter-** action.
column8: 4) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 26-2-2008(30): A piece of wood went "inter" my eye. This is an internal injury.
column9: 5) [[meredithcat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meredithcat)] 29-6-2010(25): **Inter** course usually occurs between two people lying beneath a _tree_ , gazing into each other's _eyes_.

column3: We need to fix imagination here on two things to learn the kanji for **desk** : the wonderful rough _wood_ of which it has been hewn and the _wind_ that blows across it, sending your papers flying all over the room. These two elements, written in that order, dictate how to write the character.
column5: 1) [[Kieron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kieron)] 3-4-2007(170): My _wooden_ **desk** is so messy, it looks like a strong _wind_ blew my things all over it.
column6: 2) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 19-1-2008(101): Whenever I'm alone at my computer **desk** , I'm always getting _wood_ and breaking _wind_.
column7: 3) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 23-3-2008(40): The tree was blown down by the wind - so I made a **desk** from it.
column8: 4) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 15-11-2007(18): Studying at my _wooden_ **desk** , a great _wind_ sweeps away all my papers - there goes all my hard work - I can see all the kanji disappearing into the sky.
column9: 5) [[trikatu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/trikatu)] 3-10-2006(8): A _tree_ blown over in the _wind_ makes a **desk**.

column3: Recalling that **books** are made of paper, and paper made of _trees_ , one might think of a **book** as a slice of a _tree_. Can you seethe  "cross-cut" in the trunk of the _tree_? Picture it as a chainsaw cutting you out a few **books** with which to start your own private library.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(73): The origin of a **book** is paper made out of TREEs. ONE tree can make many **book** s.
column6: 2) [[ggwar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ggwar)] 7-8-2009(25): A **book** is _one_ slice of a _tree_.
column7: 3) [[burento5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burento5)] 14-3-2008(24): An axe cutting a tree to make **book** s.
column8: 4) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 10-7-2006(11): **Book** s are the root of all knowledge (in Chinese this character means root or basis).
column9: 5) [[Raitasar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raitasar)] 6-5-2009(5): Sad 'Fact': You have to _cut_ down _ten_ oriental _tree_ s just to produce one **book**!

column3: The **tags** you see hanging on _trees_ in public places in Japan are helpful to identify what sort of _trees_ they are. Next time you see one, imagine the bit of wire that fixes the **tag** to the branch as a large _fishhook_. REALLY imagine it, illogical as it is, and you will never have trouble with this kanji again.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(173): Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing **tag** s on them.
column6: 2) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 30-3-2007(69): Might be good to note that this is also the Kanji for "Paper Money" w/ the reading さつ ( [千円札＝](midori://search?text=千円札＝) 1000 Yen paper bill)… It also takes on the meaning of Playing Card with the reading of ふだ as in 花札 (Hanafuda cards) or トランプの札 ("trump" playing cards). For the **tag** meaning I like to think of wooden **tag** s hung on hooks from trees… but for these other meanings I like to think of both paper money and playing cards as paper (tree) products with the ability to "hook you in" so to speak.
column7: 3) [[peepiceek](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peepiceek)] 5-5-2008(20): In order to put a **tag** on a _tree_ you need a _hook_.
column8: 4) [[xxinde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xxinde)] 30-3-2010(12): A **tag** was _hook_ ed on a _tree_. Since the **tag** was actually a banknote (さつ), it's no wonder that it's gone now and only the _hook_ remains sticking out from a _tree_.
column9: 5) [[certain](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/certain)] 17-4-2006(9): A little piece of paper (wood) attached by a hook makes a **TAG**.

column3: Look at this character in reverse order, from bottom up. First we see the primitive for _days_ , an appropriate enough way to begin a **calendar**. Next we see a _grove of trees_ growing under a _cliff_. The laws of nature being what they are, the _trees_ would be stunted under such conditions, unless they were strong enough to keep growing upwards until they passed through the layers of rock and soil, right up to the surface. Now imagine that in those little boxes marking off the _days_ on your wall **calendar** , you see that very process taking place step by step: 365 or so time-lapse pictures of that _grove of trees_ each month, from January under the _cliff_ to December on top of the _cliff_. The story is not as complex as it sounds, particularly if you happen to have a **calendar** nearby and can flip through it with this image in mind.
column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 15-11-2007(241): Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a _cliff_ to form or erode. A _tree_ takes many months to grow. But _days_ pass by regularly - so in this way, we see the movement of time such as with a **CALENDAR**.
column6: 2) [[cbogart](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cbogart)] 21-9-2006(122): This is just a picture of a wall **calendar** with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days, the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page.
column7: 3) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(68): You can use a **calendar** to count the number of DAYs it takes to grow two TREES under a CLIFF.
column8: 4) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 13-1-2009(47): **Calendar, almanac.** A **calendar** measures time in years, months and days. A _cliff_ (厂) takes years to form, a _grove_ ( 木木 ) of trees takes months to grow, but the _sun_ ( 日 ) rises and falls every day. All of these periods can be recorded in a **calendar**.
column9: 5) [[Ningen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ningen)] 1-9-2008(28): I love those nature **CALENDAR** s with all the photos of _cliffs_ and _trees_ and the setting _sun_.

column3: Without much effort, the elements _relax_ . . . _tree_ suggest a hammock strung between two _trees_ in your backyard, and you stretched out in it, hands folded behind your head, **planning** something or other. After all, it's something we all do from time to time: kick up our legs on the nearest piece of furniture and daydream about the best **plan** of action to take. Be sure to relate the _relaxation_ to the _tree_ , so that you don't end up with something else in its place (like "legs" or "desk" or "table").
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(250): I **plan** to RELAX on top of that TREE.
column6: 2) [[MichaelAnd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MichaelAnd)] 15-4-2008(189): If you bring a woman to your house, generally its not a good **plan** to stick your wood up her bottom, she may scream in pain あん!
column7: 3) [[dziewuliz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dziewuliz)] 3-5-2008(133): Man's **plan** of life: build a house, find a woman, **plan** t a tree.
column8: 4) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 17-6-2008(31): Calvin and Hobbes sit in their _treehouse_ , which has a big "no _girls_ " sign on it, deviously making their **PLAN** for their next water-balloon attack against the 'stinky girls'.
column9: 5) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 14-8-2007(29): How can you relax when you have a tree jammed up your ass?! Quickly make a **plan** to get down from there!

column3: **Parch** ment, made from animal skins, was the most common form of writing material used until the beginning of the nineteenth century. When paper took over, a method was devised to make artificial **parch** ment from _wood_ pulp. The _fire_ at the left and in the  "strong" position serves to remind us of the root word, " **parch** ," since nothing dries, puckers, wrinkles, and scorches quite like _fire_. And here is how we put it all together. Take a sheet of paper (a  " _wood-good_ ,"), wet it, and hold it over a _hearth_ in your mind's eye. Now watch as it **parches** the paper, leaving it with a strange and bumpy surface resembling **parch** ment.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-2-2008(273): Tip: _goods_ \+ _wood/tree_ : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest " _furniture_ " (a common type of _wooden goods_ ). REF: _parch_ (FRAME 215) , [maneuver](../v4/671.html) (#671 操), [winding](../v4/1369.html) (#1369 繰), [seaweed](../v4/2035.html) (#2035 藻). Story: It's been so **parch** ed recently that your _furniture_ suddenly catches _fire_.
column6: 2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 18-8-2007(76): The **parch** ment says you need _fire_ to make _good_ s from _tree_ s.
column7: 3) [[crayonmaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crayonmaster)] 24-1-2009(42): When a FIRE is **parch** ed, it isn't thirsty for water, it wants to gobble up some WOODEN GOODIES!
column8: 4) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 5-4-2008(33): ソウ "A _fire's_ heat will **parch** /dry out any _goods_ made from _wood_." E.G. 乾燥する （かんそう・する）to dry up.
column9: 5) [[LazyNomad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LazyNomad)] 12-1-2010(29): Hint: Actually the element - 喿 - is itself a rare kanji, that has the meaning of "chirping of birds" (see these little mouthes on the tree). On - ソウ/ ショウ Kun さわ.ぐ/ かしま.しい/すき.

column3: As the key word suggests, this kanji has to do with something not quite over and done with. More concretely, it shows us a _tree_ that is **not yet** fully grown. The extra short stroke in the upper branches shows new branches spreading out, leaving one with the feeling that the _tree_ has a ways to go yet before it reaches maturity. In other words, the kanji conveys its meaning pictographically, playing on the earlier pictograph of the _tree_.
column5: 1) [[dat5h](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dat5h)] 15-11-2008(148): I believe a better version of that by mameha1977: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree ( 木 ) does **not yet** ( 未 ) have exremities ( 末 ) of vermilion ( 朱 ).
column6: 2) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 16-10-2007(64): [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree ( 木 ) is **not yet** ( 末 ) vermilion ( 朱 ).
column7: 3) [[DeadLugosi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DeadLugosi)] 13-8-2008(41): This TREE is **not yet** fully grown: it's only ONE year old.
column8: 4) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 26-2-2008(41): "Have you sawed off those two smaller branches at the top of the tree?" "Not yet…".
column9: 5) [[squeaky_lill_mk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/squeaky_lill_mk)] 5-4-2009(20): The top branch of the tree is **not yet** as long as the bottom one.

column3: This character is best learned in connection with that of the previous frame. The first stroke shows a branch that is longer than the main branch, indicating that the tree has reached the **extremity** of its growth, so that its branches stop spreading and start drooping downwards. Be sure to keep this imagery in mind, to avoid confusing this key word with synonyms that will appear later.
column5: 1) [[amema](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amema)] 20-11-2007(108): The tree has reached the **extremity** of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer.
column6: 2) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 8-4-2008(30): There are no great stories for this one yet, and I always forget it.. So, let's try something ridiculous: The man lived by himself in the wilderness, with no females within miles. So, his only way of relief was to stick his **extremity** into a small hole in a _tree_.. The poor guy. Which horizontal stroke is the **extremity**? The longer one or the shorter one? That, my friends, is up to your own imaginations. I'd prefer not to dwell on that point, myself. ,).
column7: 3) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 13-3-2008(29): The **tree's** top branches have grown to **extremities**.
column8: 4) [[NyahK](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NyahK)] 3-12-2009(23): Another version of that by mameha1977 and dat5h: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The _tree_ ( 木 ) has _not yet_ ( 未 ) reached the **extremity** ( 末 ) of its _vermilion_ ( 朱 ) foliage.
column9: 5) [[arthur](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/arthur)] 18-1-2009(9): It's near the upper **extremity** of the tree that grows the larger branches.

column3: The most **obscure** ideas are those that the _sun_ of reason has _not yet_ dawned on. Be sure to give the _sun_ a professorial demeanor, complete with spectacles and a pipe.
column5: 1) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 18-11-2007(90): Something that is **obscure** has _not yet_ been brought before the light of _day_.
column6: 2) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 11-1-2009(48): 'Can't you go outside and get some _sun_?' ' _Not yet_ , I have to learn all these **obscure** RTK3 kanji!'.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(10): Things look **obscure** when the _sun_ is _not yet_ out.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 11-11-2010(6): Unlike us, some people finish RTK 1 and think "Should I learn all those **obscure** kanji in RTK 3? Nah, NOT YET. I'll learn them some other DAY." We're just extra Kanji sadistic. (Although, I should say, this kanji is not very **obscure**. 曖昧 is in the vocab list for JLPT level 2).
column9: 5) [[FoxintheStars](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FoxintheStars)] 31-7-2010(5): An **obscure** artist or personage is one whose _day in the sun_ has _not yet_ come.

column3: The **splash** this kanji refers to is the dash of _water_ against the rocks, with all the foam and spray that this creates. If you think of a **splash** in this sense as a wave that has run its full course and reached its _extremity_ , namely the seashore, and if you think of it pictorially in your mind's eye, this somewhat rare (but oh so-easy-to-learn) kanji is yours for good.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 5-10-2007(153): The _extremity_ of a wave of _water_ is the **splash**.
column6: 2) [[gametip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gametip)] 21-7-2008(78): A **splash** is WATER that has reached its EXTREMITY.
column7: 3) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 12-7-2007(34): Timber! …the _extremity_ of the tree fell into the _water_ the nearby lake. What a **splash**!!
column8: 4) [[eri401](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eri401)] 8-6-2012(13): **SPLASH** = _water_ being scattered to the _extreme_ 泡沫 = うたかた, ほうまつ = bubble on surface of liquid, transient o マツ o バツ k あわ k しぶき k つばき.
column9: 5) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 31-10-2008(10): Imagine the _extremity_ of a **splash** attack from a magikarp.

column3: When a tree has _not yet_ finished growing, it produces fruit with a full **flavor**. When the official taster (the professional _mouth_ to the left) determines that full flavor has been reached, the tree is pruned back so that it remains permanently _not yet_ grown. A neat little agricultural trick and an easy to way see the sense of **flavor** hidden in this character.
column5: 1) [[lilpea](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lilpea)] 17-8-2007(251): My _mouth_ has _not yet_ swallowed the food because the **flavor** is so delicious that I keep chewing it.
column6: 2) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 6-4-2008(134): To enjoy a food's **FLAVOR** , it must be in one's MOUTH but NOT YET swallowed.
column7: 3) [[NyahK](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NyahK)] 2-8-2010(51): "Not in my _mouth_!" she cried. " _Not yet_! You know how much I hate the **flavor**!" (I know, the story is silly… but it works!).
column8: 4) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 17-10-2007(14): My _mouth_ is _not yet_ ready to taste the **flavor** of a tree.
column9: 5) [[raijne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raijne)] 24-8-2011(8): My _mouth_ has _not yet_ experienced such **FLAVOR**.

column3: The **younger sister** in the family is the _woman_ in the family who, like the newest branch in a tree, is _not yet_ old enough or mature enough to do everything the elder sister can do (See frame 442).
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(172): My **younger sister** is NOT YET a fully grown WOMAN.
column6: 2) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 12-6-2007(50): Is your **younger sister** a woman? Not yet! Damn!
column7: 3) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 17-1-2008(34): My **YOUNGER SISTER** is a _woman_ who will always be _not yet_ my age.
column8: 4) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 31-1-2009(12): My **younger sister** is a _woman_ who is _not yet_ fully grown.
column9: 5) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 7-12-2007(11): My **younger sister** is not a girl, but NOT YET a woman (Brittany Spears).

column3: That red-orange color we call **vermilion** is found in nature during the fall when the leaves lose their sugar and begin to change color. This kanji depicts the very last leaf on a tree in the fall (the _drop_ hung in the first stroke), the leaf that has _not yet_ fallen as it one day must. Look at its color - vermilion. (Well, not really. The truth is, **vermilion** is made from a mercuric sulfide, but I'm sure you will agree that autumn leaves area lot easier to work with.)
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 5-10-2007(204): It's autumn: only one **vermilion** leaf on the tree has _not yet_ fallen.
column6: 2) [[solarmist](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/solarmist)] 30-6-2008(29): [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree ( 木 ) is not yet ( 未 )[correction wrong character before] **vermilion** ( 朱 ).
column7: 3) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 22-2-2009(20): **VERMILION** is the color of the last leaves on the TREE which have NOT YET fallen in autumn.
column8: 4) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 21-6-2009(13): [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree ( 木 ) is not yet ( 未 ) **vermilion** ( 朱 ). (thanks solarmist) in late summer there's a _drop_ of color on the _trees_ but it's _not yet_ **vermilion**.
column9: 5) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 16-10-2007(7): [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree ( 木 ) is not yet ( 末 ) **vermilion** ( 朱 ).

column3: The **stocks** bought and sold on the market by the tens of millions each day get their name from a comparison to a healthy _tree_ , in which one takes " **stock** " in the hopes that it will grow and produce more and more _trees_ like itself. Usually good **stocks** are referred to as  "blue chip," but here we are asked to associate the key word with the color _vermilion_ , perhaps because one can assess the value of a tree from the color of its autumn leaves.
column5: 1) [[cellophane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cellophane)] 12-10-2007(306): Which _tree_ would you buy **stocks** in - the healthy one on the left, or the one with only one _vermilion_ leaf left on the right?
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 2-3-2007(145): Ideally, one buys **stocks** when a company is young, "green," and rapidly growing – then sells them just before the last vermillion leaf falls off, and a period of dormancy or limited growth begins.
column7: 3) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 27-3-2008(40): I have a hot tip for you. Buy **stocks** in a company called "Tree and Vermillion Ltd".
column8: 4) [[CarlKenner](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CarlKenner)] 7-7-2007(25): Don't think of the **stock** -market. Instead imagine the _wood_ en medieval **stocks** used to hold a prisoner's head and hands between two blocks of _wood_. The _wood_ in this case is _vermilion_ coloured, as it often was. Imagine **SHOO** ING away the guards and blowing the **stocks** open with a big " **kaboo** m" sound. (ON reading SHU, Kun reading kabu).
column9: 5) [[oRis1024](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oRis1024)] 24-7-2008(21): You buy **stocks** when they're new and green like a _normal tree_ and sell it when it's _vermillion-HOT_ and pricy.

column3: Here we see a _flower_ held in the _right_ hand. You can imagine yourself in a magic garden where _flowers_ picked with the _right_ hand grant eternal **youth** , and those picked with the left, premature senility. Go ahead, pick one with each hand and watch what happens.
column5: 1) [[Ramchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ramchip)] 30-10-2006(165): The **young** little girl held a cute flower in her right hand.
column6: 2) [[kat1420](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kat1420)] 19-3-2008(71): **Young** love puts a _flower_ in her _right_ hand (true love puts a ring on her left!!).
column7: 3) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 10-4-2008(24): Imagine Alice reading a note in Wonderland: 'The _flowers_ on the _right_ will make you **younger**. Those on the left will make you older.'.
column8: 4) [[gaboblar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaboblar)] 28-6-2008(15): **Young** people are always right.
column9: 5) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(11): Ah, **young** love! A man holding FLOWERs (well, better than GRASS) in his RIGHT hand.

column3: Perhaps you know the custom of seeding **grass** randomly or in some particular pattern with the _flower_ called the crocus, which blooms for a few days each year in _early_ spring. As the **grass** begins to turn green again after winter has passed, these tiny _flowers_ dot up here and there. Now just look out your window at a patch of **grass** somewhere and think what a nice idea it would be to have your name spelled out in _flowers_ once as a sort of _early_ harbinger of spring.
column5: 1) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 22-7-2007(266): **Grass** grows in _earlier_ than _flowers_.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 1-6-2008(46): This **grass** is very long. The only _flowers_ you can see are _sunflowers_ – the rest are hidden by the **grass**.
column7: 3) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 9-10-2007(35): My Dad always made me cut the **grass** _early_ in the morning - it sucked.
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 5-6-2011(26): **Grass** grows _early_ , before the _flowers_ which eventually grow above.
column9: 5) [[vertigo959](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vertigo959)] 25-3-2009(18): My Dad said "Cut the **grass** _early_ , and watch out for the _FLOWERS_!!!". ソウ [草履。くさ](midori://search?text=草履。くさ) .

column3: The picture of **suffering** we are given here is that of a _flower_ that has grown _old_. When a _flower_ ages, it pales and dries up, and probably even **suffers**. If you think that plants are incapable of such feelings, then ask yourself why so many people believe that talking to their flowers helps them bloom better.
column5: 1) [[applesuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/applesuki)] 20-9-2006(190): Flowers for the old man **suffering** in the hospital.
column6: 2) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 9-5-2007(26): The derivates from opium _poppies_ such as morphine can be used to tame the **suffering** of the _old_.
column7: 3) [[MichaelAnd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MichaelAnd)] 21-4-2008(20): Old people smoke pot to ease their **suffering**.
column8: 4) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 26-12-2009(18): FLOWERS **SUFFER** when they grow OLD. Trees slowly wither( 枯 ) and die. I find I can remember these together.
column9: 5) [[salvw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/salvw)] 5-12-2008(16): If someone dies you suffer. You then put a _flower_ on the _gravestone_.

column3: A nosegay of _flowers_ make a nice gift, but if those flowers are poison oak, they _can_ amount to **bullying**. Be sure to emphasize the word _can_ when you repeat this little phrase to yourself.
column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 27-5-2007(68): "How many _flowers_ _can_ I stuff in your nostrils? Well I'm just gonna have to go and see." **Bullying** at its worst!
column6: 2) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 16-12-2008(22): The _Little Engine that Could_ , drawing from his own experiences, has become a spokesman against **bullying**. He visits schools with the slogan "Bullying CAN be stopped," and hands out _flowers_ of peace and understanding.
column7: 3) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 4-8-2009(13): 苛める （いじめる） "If you don't give me those _flowers_ , I'll drive this _spike_ into your _mouth_.".
column8: 4) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 22-12-2008(10): _Flowers_ , you ask if they _can_ feel _pain_ , do you? ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ They sure _-can-_!! ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^!!
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 3-11-2012(9): "With _flowers_ , I think I _can_ stop the **bullying** ," said the Little Engine that Could. Indeed the **bullying** stopped, as the tormentors were covered by a trainload of flowers.

column3: The _house_ of _flowers_ or  "hothouse" has become a metaphor for a narrow- minded, biased, and intolerant attitude distrustful of change. **Tolerance** , in contrast, is open-minded and welcomes novelty. The way to encourage **tolerance** in those who lack it is first to have them _see_ through their own hothouse attitudes, which is the very counsel we are given in this kanji.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(343): A **tolerant** person will ignore SEEing GRASS (marijuana) in the HOUSE of a friend.
column6: 2) [[saruwatari](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saruwatari)] 30-12-2007(178): To be **tolerant** is to see flowers (meaning "beautiful things") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks.
column7: 3) [[Ningen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ningen)] 3-9-2008(82): Kanji Zen: _See_ the _flowers_ in the _house_. _See_ the good in people. Be **TOLERANT**.
column8: 4) [[Foddy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Foddy)] 12-11-2007(82): My wife grows flowers in the house and I see them every day. I don't really like them, but I have to be **tolerant**.
column9: 5) [[axelb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/axelb)] 21-7-2008(23): Into my _house_ someone brought a monstrous _flower_ with a big, _walking eye_ , _see_ ing everything, like a spy. But I am trying to be **tolerant** , although it is getting on my nerves. Remember: The _flower_ is IN the _house_ (that is, underneath its roof-sign).

column3: Take a good look at this kanji: the "strong" element here is really the _flower_ , not the _water_ as you might have thought on first glance. To the right is the _acupuncturist_ from frame 48. Taking the key word to connote **diluting** the vital humors of the body, we can imagine our _acupuncturist_ performing his task with _flowers_ in place of needles, and using their hollow stems to pipe _water_ into the body of the patient.
column5: 1) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 17-10-2007(173): A _Dr._ missing his needle can only use **dilute** _flower water_ for medicine.
column6: 2) [[pm215](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pm215)] 15-2-2008(112): [As suggested by stehr and on the forum (<http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079>), we create a new keyword 'seaweed' for the _flower_ on top and _water_ below and to the left. See also [fall](../v4/299.html) (#299 落), [clan](../v4/1912.html) (#1912 藩),[seaweed](../v4/2035.html) (#2035 藻). This story is for people using that idea.] The _homeopath_ (a doctor without any needle) specialises in **dilute** medicines. This one's an essence of _seaweed_ – just dip the seaweed into the beaker, swish it about and remove. Barmy!
column7: 3) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 29-12-2007(94): **Note** This character belongs to a set of characters which share the _flower/water_ primitive such as:: [dilute](../v4/227.html) (#227 薄), [fall](../v4/299.html) (#299 落), [clan](../v4/1912.html) (#1912 藩), and [seaweed](../v4/2035.html) (#2035 藻)…. ( 落 薄 藩 藻 ) It may be helpful to create a primitive keyword for this occurrence (like _seaweed_ or _watering can_ ) which can save a lot of time distinguishing them from characters like _Sino_ 満 and _Full_ 満 , where the _water_ primitive is larger than the _flower_ primitive.
column8: 4) [[wzafran](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wzafran)] 17-6-2007(22): A man with thick blood dripping out of his hands visits an _acupuncturist_. "Please **dilute** my blood!" he says. The _acupuncturist_ gives the man a seat, punctures his skin with many _flower_ stems, and inserts a _drop of_ cold _water_ through the holes at the top of those stems. The man's blood becomes soft pink in colour . As too much blood had been **diluted** , he dies.
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 15-1-2008(19): A homeopathy _specialist_ takes _flowers_ and _dilutes_ them in some _water_ … (picture my hippie aunt with her homeopathist diluting flowers in water.).

column3: Three elements are given here: _flower_ . . . _generation_ . . . _tree_. The first and last seem logical enough, since it is the **leaf** that feeds the _flowers_ on a _tree_. The element for _generation_ interposed between the two suggests that the movement of a _tree_ from one _generation_ to the next is like its  "turning over a new **leaf**. "
column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 13-7-2007(246): On top of the **leaves** a _flower_ appears, promising new _generations_ for the old _tree_ below.
column6: 2) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 29-3-2008(120): The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-2-2008(85): Tip: New primitive: Let _Tarzan_ = _generation_ \+ _tree_ – because _Tarzan_ lives with several _generation_ s of his family at the top of a _tree_. (This combination appears five times: _leaf_ (FRAME 228), [butterfly](../v4/521.html) (#521 蝶), [chatter](../v4/2158.html) (#2158 喋), [secret agent](../v4/2726.html) (#2726 諜), [label](../v4/2926.html) (#2926 牒)). Story: In the _flower_ shop you see _Tarzan_ trying on various **leaves** (which he wears to cover his private parts).
column8: 4) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 2-2-2009(42): A **LEAF** is like a FLOWER that lasts only one GENERATION on a TREE and then it dies.
column9: 5) [[nesert](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nesert)] 2-11-2009(16): The _flower_ _generation_ were **leaf** smoking _tree_ -huggers.

column3: Ah, but haven't modern _graveyards_ become a parody of their ancestors! The flowers are plastic, the writing on the stones is unimaginative and cold, and the whole thing looks more like a marble orchard than a right and proper graveyard. This kanji continues with the modernization trend by picturing **imitation** _trees_ in the _graveyard_. But of course, how convenient! They don't need pruning or fertilizing, their leaves don't fall, and they remain the same color all year long.
column5: 1) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 21-1-2008(149): If I find out this furniture you're selling me is made of **imitation** _wood_ , I'll put you in the _graveyard_.
column6: 2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 15-1-2008(67): The Japanese are so enamored of everything plastic, they even put **IMITATION** plastic _trees_ in their _graveyards_! (No, not really, but I wouldn't be surprised).
column7: 3) [[elanlan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elanlan)] 29-12-2009(40): This kanji was a real asshole. No one liked this kanji. That is why that when this kanji died, no one cared, and it received a _wooden_ , **imitation** tombstone, not a fancy marble one, at its resting place in the _graveyard_.
column8: 4) [[peepiceek](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peepiceek)] 14-5-2008(22): The **imitation** _tree_ looked like a _big sun flower_.
column9: 5) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 8-5-2006(21): **imitation** : we left a wodden sculpture (an **imitation** ) at the _graveyard_ of our old dog. ( **graveyard** : were we put _flowers_ for our deceased _big St. Bernard_ , good ol' _Sunny_ ).

column3: Think of the key word as having to do with something viewed through a haze, or in the twilight and from a distance, so that only its outlines are **vaguely** discernible. Now we are back again to the essence of the true _graveyard_. The _water_ may be taken as the sound of waves dashing up against the rocks or the dripping of moisture on cold rock - anything that helps you associate **vagueness** with the _graveyard_ and keep it distinct from the imitation we met in the last frame.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 3-8-2007(263): The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are **vague**.
column6: 2) [[jjazz_kanji_first](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jjazz_kanji_first)] 12-4-2007(147): The water in the graveyard has worn away the headstones, so the writing is **vague**.
column7: 3) [[nicjsb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nicjsb)] 6-9-2008(54): **Vague** , **vague** , watery grave. (Repeat this phrase several times).
column8: 4) [[roderik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/roderik)] 11-4-2008(26): _Water_ and _graveyard_ can only result in a **vague** mnemonic for this kanji.
column9: 5) [[akimoto](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akimoto)] 21-6-2006(18): The mist and fog surrounding the graveyard make things appear **vague** and unfamiliar.

column3: The mounds of _soil_ with crude wooden crosses set at their head suggests those boot-hill **graves** we all know from cowboy lore. The only odd thing about this kanji is that the _soil_ comes UNDER the _graveyard_ , rather than to its left, where we might expect. Just think of the bodies as "lying under boot-hill" if you have any trouble. By the way, this is not the first time, nor will it be the last, that we learn a kanji whose key word is the same, or almost the same, as a primitive element based on it, but whose shape differs somewhat. There is no cause to worry. By using the primitive in a variety of other characters, as we have done here, the confusion will be averted as a matter of course. In most cases, as here, the primitive element is taken from a part of the fuller kanji.
column5: 1) [[simple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/simple)] 14-9-2007(212): The _soil_ under a _graveyard_ is full of **graves**.
column6: 2) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 14-10-2007(64): A **grave** is a patch of _soil_ in a _graveyard_.
column7: 3) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 21-7-2006(28): **Grave** s are in the soil beneath the **grave** yard.
column8: 4) [[Cirion](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cirion)] 30-6-2008(21): The _flower_ s were blooming, the _sun_ was shining, when I let my St. Bernard off his leash and he lifted his leg and peed ON some freshly turned _soil_ that was dug out for a **grave**. [Thanks to dwhitman for the idea of the peeing dog because the way the last stroke for 大 is shifted rightwards would mess me up, but if the dog's got his leg up in the air… it's a nice visual image for the change from the primitive _graveyard_.).
column9: 5) [[stungunjones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stungunjones)] 23-3-2008(11): The _soil_ under the Kakariko _graveyard_ is full of many more things than **graves**.
