column3: Imagine that you have chosen the occupation of the keeper of a _graveyard_ and spend your _days_ tending to other's dead hood in order to make your means of **livelihood**.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(215): He made a **livelihood** out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight.
column6: 2) [[Ryuujin27](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ryuujin27)] 31-12-2006(61): I like trikatu's simple way to remember this, but just in case the primitive placements confuse you, change it around to this: Before you complain about your **livelihood** , think about spending your days _under_ a graveyard. Life is always better than death, eh?
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 22-1-2008(32): The gravedigger makes his **LIVELIHOOD** digging in the _graveyard_ all _day_ For graveyard, imagine an idyllic picture: beautiful grass with the sun shining down…and a dog peeing on one of the graves. Don't confuse with [occupation](../v4/1034.html) (#1034 営). Hold onto the irony of making your LIVElyhood from tending dead people.
column8: 4) [[trikatu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/trikatu)] 16-1-2007(30): Before you complain about your **livelihood** , think about spending your _days_ in a _graveyard_.
column9: 5) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 14-12-2009(11): You have to earn a **LIVELIHOOD** until you go to the GRAVEYARD, when your DAYS are over, and your SUN went down…

column3: The _part of the body_ first affected by a stroll through a haunted _graveyard_ is the skin, which gets goose bumps. But we save the word  "skin" for another kanji, and use the odd word " **membrane** " here. Think of being so scared through and through that the goose flesh moves from the outside in, giving you goose **membranes**.
column5: 1) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 25-3-2007(287): In the _moon_ light of the _graveyard_ I hear a zombie say, **MMMMM..EMM…BRANE** sssss.
column6: 2) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 5-9-2007(96): The **membrane** s in your flesh rot when placed in the graveyard.
column7: 3) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 6-4-2008(65): マク **Membrane** s (thin layers of connective tissue) are the _part of the body_ that decompose first (i.e., before the organs, ligaments, bones, etc.) after one dies and is buried in a _graveyard_.
column8: 4) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 4-9-2008(29): The **membrane** between the dead and the living is thinnest in a graveyard in moonlight.
column9: 5) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 28-1-2008(14): _Flesh_ eaten by zombies in the _graveyard_ is **mem~brai~ns**!!!

column3: To avoid confusion with the image of rice seedlings to appear later, we shall take these **seedlings** out of their agricultural setting in the _rice fields_ and into the frame of Brave New World surgery, where  "ideas" or "values" are being implanted into _brains_ like **seedlings** to insure a harmonious society. Then you need only imagine them taking root and breaking out into _flower_ right through the tops of the skulls of people walking around on the streets.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(184): If you plant **seedling** s in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.
column6: 2) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 5-6-2008(61): Crap! There are _flowers_ in the _rice field_ … Who let those **seedlings** get in there?!
column7: 3) [[tanaquil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tanaquil)] 15-4-2007(43): This is obviously a flower sprouting from a rice field, and means " **rice **seedling**** " in Japanese. My problem is keeping this kanji distinct from 圥, which Heisig dubs the " **rice **seedling**** " primitive (see [land](../v4/1513.html) (#1513 陸) ff.). It might help to keep in mind that 圥 is a rare kanji (not used in Japanese) meaning "mushroom," so I will call 圥 the " **mushroom **seedling**** ".
column8: 4) [[cmayernik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cmayernik)] 25-5-2009(24): All the _flowers_ in the _field_ started as **seedlings**.
column9: 5) [[Chocobonstrife](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Chocobonstrife)] 26-4-2012(16): Pikmin have FLOWERS growing out of their **seedling** BRAINS.

column3: Here we have a pictograph of the back of a turtle, the two sloping vertical strokes representing the central ridge and the four short strokes the pattern. Think of reading turtle shells as a way to foretell the future, and in particular things that **portend** coming evils.
column4: * When this character is used as a primitive in its full form, we keep the key-word sense of a _portent_. When it appears to the left in its abbreviated form (namely, the left half only), we shall give it the pictographic sense of a _turtle_.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 17-9-2007(146): When your wife's _LEGs_ get huge hairs on them it is surely a bad **portent** for things to come.
column6: 2) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 13-7-2006(110): A bad **portent** makes the hairs on your legs stand.
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-12-2007(35): Two persons turning _their backs_ is a bad **sign**. Hint: Don't use "turtle" as a primitive. You'll save a lot of troubles with following kanji if you give this primitive the meaning "a person's back".
column8: 4) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 27-4-2009(26): The actual derivation of this Kanji is a pictograph of the cracks on a heated _turtle_ shell which was used in divination. The way the cracks occur on this _turtle_ are a **portent** of evil bad luck.
column9: 5) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 23-4-2008(9): To me it looks like a "black angel" or something (four wings and its human-looking legs). Maybe seeing it is a bad **portent**?

column3: To associate the **peach tree** with the primitive for a _portent_ , recall the famous Japanese legend of Momotarō, the **Peach** Boy. It begins once upon a time with a fisherman and his wife who wanted badly to have a child, but none was born to them. Then one day the old man caught a giant **peach** , out of which jumped a healthy young lad whom they named **Peach** Boy. Though the boy was destined to perform heroic deeds, his birth also _portended_ great misfortune (how else could he become a hero?). Thus the _tree_ that is associated with a _portent_ of coming evil comes to be the **peach tree**.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 5-10-2007(92): The pits of a **peach tree** look like _turtles_.
column6: 2) [[JetSetArnett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/JetSetArnett)] 11-3-2008(80): King Koopa consistently captures Princess Peach. Eventually he's going to run out of castles and just set her in a tree.
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-12-2007(56): If you gave the meaning "a person's back" to the primitive in [portent](../v4/235.html) (#235 兆), you can easily discover that a **peach tree** is the _tree_ with _butt_ -shaped fruits.
column8: 4) [[jettyke](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jettyke)] 16-9-2009(47): If you used the story about hairy woman´s legs for portent, then: **PEACH TREE** is the TREE that has HAIRY fruits.
column9: 5) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 11-9-2007(26): It's a little known fact, but when the ninja turtles were young Splinter actually made them follow rigid diet. Those turtles actually ate nothing but peaches. In fact, the turtles even planted a **peach tree** in their hideout not only to decorate the place with a tree, but because they were eating nothing but peaches.

column3: To give someone the "evil _eye_ " is to **stare** at them, wishing them evil. The roots of the superstition are old and almost universal throughout the cultures of the world. In this kanji, too, being **stared** at is depicted as an _eye_ that _portends_ evil.
column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 11-1-2006(140): Sauron's One fiery eye **stare** at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon.
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 13-11-2007(62): People **stare** d, _eyes_ wide, at the girl in the bathing suit - she had extremely _hairy legs_!
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 13-11-2007(54): You lost a **staring** contest with a _turtle_ because you blinked your _eye_ before he did. (The contest wasn't fair, because turtles have nictitating membranes, and don't need to blink so often.) _Eye_ comes first, because **stare** is most associated with eyes. And compare with [challenge](../v4/658.html) (#658 挑) where this same obstreperous turtle _challenges_ you to a finger wrestling contest. (Sibyl's story with some notes that helped me).
column8: 4) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-12-2007(31): If you gave the sense "a person's back" to the primitive in [portent](../v4/235.html) (#235 兆), you can easily discover an old-man _staring_ at a good-looking girl: he doesn't apart his _eyes_ from her _back_.
column9: 5) [[kaminix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaminix)] 2-3-2008(27): Litterally this kanji reads " _eye_ of _portent_ ". Imagine an old lady **starring** into the crystal sphere trying to _portend_ the future.

column3: We know that the character for _large_ takes on the meaning of the _St. Bernard_ **dog** when used as a primitive. In this frame we finally see why. The _drop_ added as a fourth and final stroke means that we have to do with a normal-sized **dog** , which compared to the _St. Bernard_ is no more than a _drop_ in the kennel.
column4: * As a primitive this character can take two meanings. In the form given here it will mean a very small dog (which we shall refer to as a _chihuahua_ for convenience sake). When it takes the form 犭 to the left of a character, we shall give it the meaning of _a pack of wild dogs_.
column5: 1) [[LucidFaia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LucidFaia)] 9-4-2008(76): A large **dog** , dripping drool.
column6: 2) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 24-3-2008(17): If we remember [large](../v4/107.html) (#107 大) as a man with his arms outstretched, the **drop** represents man's best friend - a **dog**.
column7: 3) [[basch2020](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/basch2020)] 6-9-2009(13): An average **dog** is made to look like a little drop next to a St Bernard.
column8: 4) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(11): A LARGE ST. BERNARD **DOG** with a DROP of saliva.
column9: 5) [[cryonic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cryonic)] 2-1-2012(9): I don't know why not one single person before me has seemingly thought of this, but when I first encountered this character, it just seemed SO natural for me. It looks just exactly like a guy throwing a stick for his **DOG** to bring it back to him. Or am I really the only one seeing this picture?

column3: Did you ever hear of the _turtle_ who fell madly in love with a _chihuahua_ but could not have her because their two families did not like the idea of their children intermarrying? Like all classic stories of ill-fated love, this one shows how the young upset the **status quo** with an emotion older and more powerful than anything their elders have devised to counter it: blind love.
column5: 1) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 31-7-2007(161): It was _left_ to the **turtle** to make _right_ with the **dog** and thus maintain the **status quo.**.
column6: 2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 13-12-2006(91): A _turtle_ mounting a _chihuahua_ clearly disrupts the **status quo**.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 4-12-2007(43): After beating the hare in a race, the _turtle_ is now acknowledged to be the fastest animal. But the chihuahua is challenging the **status quo** , demanding a new race. And look - the dog is on the right, meaning he's passed the turtle! Hope he doesn't take a nap.
column8: 4) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-12-2007(35): If you gave the sense "a person's back" to the primitive in [portent](../v4/235.html) (#235 兆), you can see that a _dog_ , wanting to preserve its **status quo** among its pals, tries to bite the _back_ of a poor postman.
column9: 5) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 27-1-2009(28): The **STATUS QUO** was broken when the TURTLE and the DOG got married! You should have see the offspring… Dogs with shells on!!

column3: Oddly enough, the character for **silence** shows us a _black chihuahua_. Actually, the cute little critter's name is Darkness, as I am sure you remember from the famous song about **silence** that begins,  "Hello, Darkness, my old friend...." Note how the four dots reach all the way across the bottom of the character.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 25-10-2006(366): The _computer_ won't stop beeping, which is making the _chihauhua_ bark, and it's driving this guy insane. The only solution he can come up with is to throw them both on the _fire_ and finally enjoy the **silence**.
column6: 2) [[Wakela](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wakela)] 23-3-2007(56): Your neighbor is so sick of you playing Led Zeppelin that he takes your copy of the song Black Dog and burns it. Finally, **silence** in the neighborhood.
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 28-11-2007(45): A scene of calm SILENC: You're typing away on your COMPUTER, while your pet DOG lies beside, a nice FIRE warms you both. No noise to disturb the **SILENCE**.
column8: 4) [[kalamies](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kalamies)] 30-7-2006(34): **Silence** is a paramount for any _black_ ninja _dog_.
column9: 5) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 29-3-2009(27): HINT: this is NOT black and dog. It is computer, dog and fire. So my risque but memorable story is: sitting at the naked at the _computer_ watching _doggystyle_ porn with a _fire_ to keep me warm. It suddenly gets louder and I have to hit the mute, or **silence** button so as not to disturb the neighbours… Apologies for the rudeness, but was having trouble remembering and this made it stick.

column3: The key word in this frame refers to a suffix that gives the word before it an adjectival quality, hence we refer to it as " **sort of thing**. " Reverting to the time when dog was more widely eaten than it is today (See frame 127), we see here a large cauldron boiling over an _oven flame_ with the _flesh_ of a _chihuahua_ being thrown into the whole concoction to make it into a  "hot- diggity, dog-diggity" **sort of thing**.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 11-10-2007(322): _Flesh_ of a _dog_ over a cooking fire = "hotdog". There are all **sorts of things** in _hot dogs_. Believe me, you don't want to know what **sort of things** . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr's. Thanks!).
column6: 2) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 9-9-2006(98): There are all **sorts of things** in _hot dogs_. (I use _hot dog_ for this primitive ( _meat_ of a _dog_ over a _cooking fire_ ). I swear I can actually see the 月 here as a hot dog, with its slight curve and grill marks.).
column7: 3) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 16-10-2007(39): Putting the _flesh_ of a _dog_ on a _fire_ is the **sort of thing** that will get you arrested.
column8: 4) [[vxnine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vxnine)] 21-9-2008(22): Imagine the _flesh_ of a _dog_ roasting OVER a fire. Gross. I'd never want to eat that **sort of thing**.
column9: 5) [[Sonofswin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sonofswin)] 2-2-2009(18): The _moon_ in the _evening_ is the **sort of thing** that makes a _dog_ howl as if _on fire_.

column3: You've no doubt seen cattails, those swamp **reeds** with a furry _flower_ to them like the tail of a cat. This might just turn out to be a good way to get rid of a troublesome _pack of wild dogs_ : lure them into a swamp of these **reeds** with the cattail _flowers_ and then set _fire_ to the swamp. Take care to focus on the _flower_ rather than the  "cattail" to avoid confusion with frame 259 below.
column5: 1) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 22-2-2007(218): **REED** S are the only FLOWERS that WILD DOGS like to FIRE up and smoke while they are playing poker.
column6: 2) [[sindhikara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sindhikara)] 30-6-2008(137): A **reed** is a flower that looks like a hot dog.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 8-10-2007(50): Picture a Gary Larson cartoon of a pack of _dogs_ sitting around a _campfire_. They misunderstood something they overheard, and can't understand why they're not getting high smoking **reed**. In the kanji, you can actually see the dog smoking the **reed** in a crack pipe held over the fire. (Thanks, chamcham!).
column8: 4) [[snagger](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snagger)] 9-7-2008(34): **Reed** s: the only flowers that can survive fire and dogs.
column9: 5) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 20-9-2009(14): _pack of dogs_ hanging out by the _fire_ smoking _reed_ _flowers_.

column3: One of the worst problems you have to face when you go **hunting** is to _guard_ your take from the _wild dogs_. If you imagine yourself failing at the task, you will probably have a stronger image than if you try to picture yourself succeeding.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 27-3-2007(186): Actually when **hunting** it may be a good idea to use a _pack of dogs_ as your personal _guard_.
column6: 2) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 1-4-2008(85): After a _pack of wild dogs_ **hunt** some food, they will _guard_ it fiercely.
column7: 3) [[tstuhldreher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tstuhldreher)] 7-7-2008(69): In every prison escape movie, the **hunt** for the escapees involves a pack of WILD DOGS unleashed by the GUARDS.
column8: 4) [[samesong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samesong)] 30-6-2008(9): In Duck **Hunt** , that _dog_ is damned lucky the game _protects_ him, or I'd shot him by now.
column9: 5) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 18-3-2008(8): Imagine: you sit in the porch of your _house_ , rub your pack of _wild dogs_ vigorously with _glue_ and send them off to **HUNT** rabbits by rolling on them and returning with the poor little critters _glued_ to them. Supposedly, the Russians trained dogs with mines on their backs to run under German tanks in WWII, so the idea is feasible.

column3: Knowing how much dogs love to chase **cats** , picture a _pack of wild dogs_ planting  " **cat** - _seedlings_ ," watering them, and fertilizing them until they can be harvested as a crop of **cats** for them to chase and torment. If you begin from the key word and think of a  "crop of **cats** ," you will not confuse this story with the apparently similar story of two frames ago.
column5: 1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(169): The **cat** hid in the FLOWERS of the FIELD from the WILD DOGs.
column6: 2) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 15-6-2009(98): Dawgs always wanna put their seedlings in pussies.
column7: 3) [[Kvaien](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kvaien)] 29-5-2009(27): It looks like a **cat**. The flowers are the ears, the field is the face, and the dog is the tail.
column8: 4) [[srothroc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/srothroc)] 28-2-2010(16): Packs of wild dogs will chase a **cat** through flowers and fields.
column9: 5) [[jezerey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jezerey)] 11-2-2008(11): The crafty **cat** hid from the pack of dogs among the seedlings.

column3: Can you the "doodle" of a **cow** that has just been run over by a steamroller? The small dot in the first stroke shows its head turned to one side, and the next two strokes, the four legs.
column4: * As a primitive, the same sense of _cow_ is kept. Note only that when it is placed OVER another element, its tail is cut off. In this case, and when the element appears on the left, the stroke order is changed.
column5: 1) [[Georgi87](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Georgi87)] 1-4-2008(210): A **cow** tried to climb up a vermilion tree, but in doing so, it broke its two bottom branches off.
column6: 2) [[dannyfartmaxwell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dannyfartmaxwell)] 6-5-2009(44): Mooooooooooooooooooo!!!!
column7: 3) [[LoneDeranger](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LoneDeranger)] 4-3-2009(25): A **cow** bleeds _vermilion_ when you cut off two of it's legs.
column8: 4) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 29-8-2006(9): No matter how many times you roll over the **cow** with a steam-roller, it will still be two strokes short of looking as vivid red as _vermillion_ pigment.
column9: 5) [[Silwing](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Silwing)] 15-12-2009(6): This is a **cow** … **Cow** \- How you say? Imagine a **cow** which has just been run over by a steamroller. Now you see, the head to one side, four legs and the tail backwards. Yes that is indeed a **cow**.

column3: Despite the strong phonetic similarity, there will be no problem keeping the key word **special** distinct from the character we met earlier for _specialty_ (Frame 47), since the latter has immediate connotations lacking in this kanji. Anyway, we shall let the key word of this frame refer to something in a **special** class all its own - like the sacred _cows_ of India that wander freely without fear of being butchered and ground into hamburger. Even though the practice is originally a Hindu one, and in any case no longer followed among the majority of Japanese Buddhist monks, the Buddha's refusal to take the life of any sentient being makes it only fitting that the _cows_ should be placed on the sacred grounds of a _Buddhist temple_ in this kanji.
column5: 1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 25-10-2007(200): Think of not **special** people, but **special** animals. The sacred Hindu _cows_ are **special** \- they can wander around the _temple_ without fear of becoming roast beef.
column6: 2) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 5-10-2007(45): The Church Lady is traveling through Japan and notices with distaste a sacred _cow_ relieving itself inside a _Buddhist Temple_. "Well, isn't _that_ **special** ".
column7: 3) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 31-3-2008(31): _Cow_ s at a _Buddhist temple_ are **special** \- they are holy cows! Sadly a few days later I find the same _cow_ s' meat on **special** at the supermarket. Holy Cow, what have we done!?
column8: 4) [[Dualta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dualta)] 22-4-2008(21): **Cows** are **special** when _left_ **in temples**.
column9: 5) [[thegreatkaizo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegreatkaizo)] 22-7-2008(16): Mixing up Hinduism and Buddhism, the _cow_ ended up as today's **special** at the _Buddhist temple_.

column3: Folklore throughout the world tells us of talking animals who show a wisdom superior to that of human beings, and that same tradition has found its way into television shows and cartoons right into our own century. This character depicts **revelation** through the _mouth_ of a _cow_ , suggesting oracular utterances about truths hidden to human intelligence.
column5: 1) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 18-9-2007(412): The **revelation** makes the cow's mouth drop down, "Hamburgers are made of what?!".
column6: 2) [[Ningen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ningen)] 6-9-2008(29): In ancient times, the words from a _primitive cow's mouth_ were considered a **REVELATION** because they were the "udder truth.".
column7: 3) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 18-8-2007(23): When you get a **revelation** , you may _drop_ to the _ground_ with your _mouth_ wide open.
column8: 4) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 20-9-2008(17): Ask an enlightened Zen monk for a single word of **revelation** , then go and ask any cow for the same thing. You"ll probably get the same answer– "Muuuuu!" Spiritual **revelation** coming out of the mouth of a cow.
column9: 5) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 5-10-2007(16): The **revelation** makes the _cow_ 's _mouth_ drop open. "Hamburgers are made of _what_?" Think of a Gary Larson cartoon. (Slight tweak of pageturner's).

column3: Take this key word in its physical, not its temporal, sense (even though it refers to both). If you have a _cow_ with _human legs_ , as the elements show us here, it can only be because you have two people in a _cow_ -suit. I always thought I'd prefer to be the one standing **before** , rather than the one that holds up the rear and becomes the "butt" of everyone's laughter.
column5: 1) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 20-10-2007(232): I've never seen a _cow_ with _human legs_ **before**!
column6: 2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 9-6-2008(158): Nasty story but it keeps the meaning true to the kanji. "BEFORE you stick it in a COW and SPREAD the legs (the bottom stroke of this cow looks like two legs) make sure she has HUMAN LEGS"————-sorry, I'll remove if I get enough reports, but will keep if I get more stars.
column7: 3) [[LorenPaul](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LorenPaul)] 28-7-2009(67): **Before** Human Beings Existed.. Minotaurs Ruled The Earth! Their Top Half A Cow And Their Bottom Half Human Legs! Also: Using Minotaur as a primitive can make stories a doddle!
column8: 4) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 8-12-2007(65): I've never seen a cow with human legs **before**! (from gaijinda) I keep mixing this up with [in front](../v4/290.html) (#290 前). Remember that **before** sounds like "beef or", so it must be the one with the cow in it.
column9: 5) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-12-2007(30): Note: If you are confusing "before" 先 with "in front" 前 , then note that "before" sounds like " **beef** or", so that must be the one with the _cow_ in it.

column3: This character is so logical that one is tempted to let the elements speak for themselves: _water_ . . . _before_. But we have already decided we will not allow such rationalism to creep into our stories. Not even this once. Instead, let us change the character from the Peanuts comic strip called  "Pigpen," who is always preceded by a little cloud of dust and grime, and rename him " **Wash** -Out." Everywhere he walks, a spray of _water_ goes _before_ him to sanitize everything he touches.
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 10-2-2008(286): In Japan, you always **wash** with _water_ from the shower _before_ you enter the bathtub.
column6: 2) [[undershaft](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/undershaft)] 27-2-2007(80): You **wash** things with WATER to get them back to the clean state they were in BEFORE.
column7: 3) [[stephjapan2004](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephjapan2004)] 25-10-2007(41): **WASH** with WATER BEFORE doing anything.
column8: 4) [[mcbainpc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcbainpc)] 25-6-2008(29): You need _water_ _before_ you can **wash**.
column9: 5) [[Melamelachan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Melamelachan)] 3-8-2007(16): In 1525, the city of Salzburg was occupied. Legend has it that there was nothing left to eat, except for one _cow_. To trick the occupying forces, people would paint the cow, and send a human (with _human legs_ ) and the _cow_ out for a walk, clearly visible to the enemies. Then, they would use some _water_ to **wash** the _cow_ and paint it with a different colour and so on. Seeing there were still plenty of _cows_ left, the occupiers finally gave up. The people of Salzburg are still called _cow_ - **wash** ers.

column3: The idea of something getting **jammed into** something else is depicted here by having a _walking stick_ get **jammed into** an _umbrella_ frame by someone shoving it into an already occupied slot in the _umbrella_ stand at the door. First notice the vertical strokes: on the left is the curved umbrella handle, and on the right the straight _walking stick_. Now try to imagine the two parties tugging at their respective properties like two kids on a wishbone, creating a scene at the entrance of an elegant restaurant.
column5: 1) [[LucidFaia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LucidFaia)] 9-4-2008(194): The two strokes at the bottom look like a J and I, which stands for "jammed in.".
column6: 2) [[alkulp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alkulp)] 29-10-2007(63): Two people **jammed in** under an **umbrella**. A woman with a dress and a man (straight). It's always me that ends up getting wet…. but the tail of the skirt is this time!
column7: 3) [[Yozora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yozora)] 19-5-2009(55): J and I are "Jammed Into" an UMBRELLA.
column8: 4) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 18-10-2007(13): The _beach umbrella_ is **jammed in** to the sand using _two poles_ instead of one, so it's extra steady. I was a little rough though so I accidentally bent one of them.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 9-6-2008(12): 介する 【かいする】 (vs-s,vt) (1) (See を介して ) to use as an intermediary, to mediate, to assist, (2) to worry, to mind, to care. STORY: It's raining out and you are arguing with your bf/gf about why they didn't bring their own UMBRELLA. Now the two of you are **JAMMED IN** under one (J and I just how lucidfaia said). Then imagine another person who forgot their UMBRELLA JAMMES IN with you and offers to MEDIATE your argument in exchange for protection from the rain.

column3: As the **world** gets _jammed_ with more and more people, there is less and less space. Imagine yourself taking an air flight over a **world** so densely populated that every bit of it is sectioned off like a gigantic checkerboard (the _rice fields_ ). If you look closely at the character, you should be able to see a kind of movement taking place as still more is being **jammed into** that already narrow space.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 22-8-2007(116): One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire **world** is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD.
column6: 2) [[eltjopoort](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eltjopoort)] 12-5-2008(93): A famous philosopher once said that his **world** consisted of all the things he could _jam into_ his _brain_.
column7: 3) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 9-2-2009(51): If you fit everyone in the **world** into a _rice field_ , they would be pretty _jammed in_.
column8: 4) [[tsenita](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tsenita)] 18-5-2009(22): The **world** is just one big ol' RICE FIELD with billions of people JAMMED IN.
column9: 5) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 12-3-2009(15): This is a pictograph of a MISS **WORLD**. She was the only contestant with a BRAIN, and the curved stroke is her bent leg (think curtsy) or her sweeping elegant dress.

column3: As everyone knows, **tea** is made from **tea** leaves. But the **tea** plant itself has its own _flowers_ , which can be quite beautiful and add a special flavor to the _tea_ , as the Chinese found out already over 4,598 years ago. With the image of a terrace of _flowering_ **tea** bushes in mind, picture a number of brightly painted and very l-o-n-g _wooden poles_ (Frame 207) placed here and there in their midst, with a tiny _umbrella_ at the top to shade the delicate-tasting **tea** _flowers_.
column5: 1) [[wreckz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wreckz)] 21-1-2008(214): Some people think drinking **tea** is boring and quaint. That's why I spice mine up by adding a cocktail umbrella, which of course is made from a _wood_ -en toothpick supporting a paper _umbrella_ with _flowers_ printed on top.
column6: 2) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 13-9-2007(92): When I drink _herbal_ **tea** I like to drink it under a _parasol_. If it's too hot I go "ho, ho, ho !!" (katakana ホ).
column7: 3) [[gsantise](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gsantise)] 26-8-2007(39): **Tea** is made from _flowers_ dried under a _canopy_ held up with _wooden poles_.
column8: 4) [[activeaero](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/activeaero)] 20-8-2008(30): The "flowers" of the "umbrella tree" make the best **TEA**.
column9: 5) [[ChieShorts](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ChieShorts)] 23-2-2012(18): That sexy ho (ホ) under the flowery umbrella is just my cup of **tea**.

column3: The **spinal column** has sprouted out of the _flesh_ of your back into an _umbrella_ that you always have with you, rain or shine. The pair of 2s on each side are the  "ribs" of the _umbrella_. Take care to keep your image of the key word distinct from that for spine (Frame 24).
column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 8-5-2007(71): "Look", says the teacher in biology class. "The **spinal column** holds your _flesh_ together, just like the metal rod of this _umbrella_ (he demonstrates this with an umbrella covered in _I-Ching_ symbols) holds the umbrella together".
column6: 2) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 27-4-2009(31): A pictograph of a **spinal column**. The _umbrella_ representing the shoulder blades, the _I Ching_ as the shoulder muscles and the _part of the body_ as the spine itself.
column7: 3) [[FutureBlues](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FutureBlues)] 6-10-2008(10): The **spinal column** functions in the same way the rod does in an _umbrella_ … To hold one's _umbrella of flesh_ together, much like the _I Ching_ does for the universe.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 21-7-2009(8): In a horrific accident, a _body part_ got _jammed in_ the _grill_ of my car: a **spinal column**!
column9: 5) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 28-1-2008(6): When my Korean girlfriend (from the I CHING symbols on the Korean flag) stands under an UMBRELLA and stretches her BODY, you can see the outline of her **spinal column**.

column3: The kanji for **fit** reads literally, top to bottom, as a _meeting_ of _mouths_  \- which is a rather descriptive way of speaking of a romantic kiss. We all know what happens when there is no meeting of minds and when people's ideas don't **fit**  with one another. But this kanji invites us to imagine what would happened to the romance of a certain unfortunate couple whose _mouths_ didn't **fit**.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 13-9-2007(159): I wouldn't mind a _meeting_ of _mouths_ with her, she's really **fit** !
column6: 2) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 13-7-2007(102): He had such a big _mouth_ that he could easily **fit** _one_ whole _umbrella_ in it.
column7: 3) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 23-4-2008(47): _Meeting_ of _mouths_! We **fit** together so well, darling ,).
column8: 4) [[kendobc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kendobc)] 15-6-2008(39): This umbrella is so small you can only **fit** one mouth under it (one person).
column9: 5) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 12-11-2008(12): Only _one_ _mouth_ can **fit** under an _umbrella_. (If you don't believe me try to **fit** two and see how they will get wet.).

column3: On the left we see a mound of _dirt_ , and to the right _flowers_ made to _fit_ together. The two sides combine to create a great **pagoda** made of _dirt_ , with _flowers_ by the tens of thousands _fitted_ together for the roofing of each of the layers. Be sure to put yourself in the scene and _fit_ a few of the _flowers_ in place yourself so that the image works its way into memory with full force.
column5: 1) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 14-8-2007(165): In order to build a **pagoda** in this small Japanese garden everything has to _fit_ : the _soil_ to the left and the _flowers_ in the upper right corner.
column6: 2) [[xeyes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xeyes)] 21-5-2007(48): Pictograph- o-rama. This is a corner of a Japanese garden, with a small mound of _soil_ on the left, and a little concrete **pagoda** in the front with _flowers_ behind it. (To my eye, the _fit_ looks a lot like a little **pagoda** anyway. This may or may not cause confusion for you, though…).
column7: 3) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 13-7-2007(39): The _ground_ next to the **pagoda** could barely _fit_ all the _flowers_ the empress wanted planted.
column8: 4) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 7-7-2008(34): Thankfully I was in a **pagoda** when I, ummm, _soil_ ed myself, the _flowers_ covered up the smell and the mess _fit_ out one of the holes in the side while no one was watching…
column9: 5) [[Yasser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yasser)] 9-11-2008(23): A **pagoda** is a place of harmony in Japan. This means that even the "soil" where "flowers" are planted must "fit" together (good for remembering the order of writing).

column3: See what you can do to come up with a pictograph of a **king's** scepter here that suits your own idea of what it should look like. You might even begin with the basic element for _I beam_ and then try to fit the remaining third stroke in.
column4: * As a primitive, this can mean either _king_ or _scepter_ , but it will usually be taken to mean _ball,_  as an abbreviation of the character in the next frame.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 13-9-2007(141): To be **king** you have to be a real _crafty one_ !
column6: 2) [[negreality](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/negreality)] 27-5-2010(102): A **King** is one（ 一 ） who rules over the land （ 土 soil）.
column7: 3) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 2-4-2008(33): The **king** unites heaven and earth. (imagine heaven being the top line over the _soil_ ).
column8: 4) [[nwatkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nwatkins)] 29-9-2007(26): Everyone made fun the **king** because the end of his scepter had three pancakes on it.
column9: 5) [[salokin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/salokin)] 13-3-2008(22): In a card game, **king** is 13 ( 十 and 三 ) together. i.e. queen is 12, jack is 11….

column3: Note the _drop_ here in the king's _scepter_ , which is exactly what you would expect it to be: a precious **jewel** handed down from of old as a symbol of his wealth and power.
column4: * As a primitive, we can use this to mean either _jewel_ or _ball_. When it appears anywhere other than on the left side of a kanji, it takes the same shape as here. On the left, it will be lacking the final stroke, making it the same as the character in the previous frame.
column5: 1) [[Ramchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ramchip)] 24-4-2007(200): The king is said to have only one family **jewel** below the belt…
column6: 2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 20-1-2008(36): The king is said to have only one family **jewel** below the belt…and he hangs left! (I always screw up the direction of the "drop").
column7: 3) [[indiana23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indiana23)] 28-12-2009(35): I can tell you that there is only one thing that Japanese people think when they see this Kanji, and that's BALLS(no joke). Kintama, or gold balls, means testicles. Funny story, we met a European girl not to long ago who had this as a tattoo, and she thought it actually meant **JEWEL**. But as I said, the Japanese guys wanted to know why she liked BALLS so much. lol (True Story).
column8: 4) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 7-12-2007(15): Only Kings can poop **jewel** s.
column9: 5) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 30-6-2009(13): King dropped his pants to reveal his **jewel**.

column3: Every _house_ has its **treasure** , as every thief knows only too well. While the things we **treasure** most are usually of sentimental value, we take the original sense of the term **treasure** here and make it refer to _jewels_ kept in one's _house_.
column5: 1) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 7-11-2007(99): On **treasure** island is a single _house_ \- where all the _jewels_ are stored.
column6: 2) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 23-4-2008(84): Put a " _roof_ " (lid) on your _jewels_ and voila! You've got a **treasure** chest.
column7: 3) [[szreter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/szreter)] 30-3-2008(50): I have **treasure** : _jewels_ which I hide in my _house_.
column8: 4) [[noushina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/noushina)] 14-1-2007(21): If Wealth and Savings aren't confusing enough, we now add **Treasure**. They all have House. Savings account had a nail and a shell. While Wealthy had the Wealth primitive in it. In this case, our **Treasure** is a HOUSE full of JEWELS.
column9: 5) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 21-11-2008(13): The **treasure** chest houses the jewels.

column3: Take care to keep the meaning of this kanji distinct from that for _jewel_. Think of the most enormous **pearl** you have ever seen, a great _vermilion_ -colored _ball_ sitting on your ring and making it extremely difficult to move without falling over from the weight of the thing.
column5: 1) [[Christoph](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christoph)] 18-4-2007(191): The king of the Oysters produces special Vermillion **pearl** s!
column6: 2) [[quety101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/quety101)] 25-1-2008(79): King Vermillion is a little queer and likes to wear **pearl** necklaces.
column7: 3) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 19-1-2008(58): Usually **pearls** are white, or black. Only a very rare, very expensive **pearl** is _vermillion_ colored. Such a **pearl** would be fit for a _king_.
column8: 4) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 1-2-2008(57): The _king_ made everyone turn a bright shade of _vermilion_ when he showed up wearing a **PEARL** necklace. (Tweaked for positioning purposes. Thanks ngoli1).
column9: 5) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 10-7-2008(23): I gave the princess a **pearl** necklace and the [king](../v4/255.html) (#255 王) turned a bright shade of [vermilion](../v4/221.html) (#221 朱) when he saw it on her.

column3: Do not think of a "gift" here, but of the **present** moment, as distinct from the future and the past. The kanji gives us a _ball_ in which we see the **present**  \- obviously a crystal _ball_ that enables us to _see_ things going on at the **present** in faraway places.
column5: 1) [[mimiko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mimiko)] 20-8-2007(176): _The KING_ … can _SEE_ clearly the **PRESENT** state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?).
column6: 2) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 4-1-2008(67): Hey, I want my money back! This crystal _ball_ is out of order, I can _see_ the **present** instead of the future!
column7: 3) [[lmcrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lmcrtk)] 10-4-2009(37): Many people claim that Elvis (The KING) has been SEEN walking around in the **PRESENT**.
column8: 4) [[lucianreign](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lucianreign)] 6-12-2006(28): The king came…the king saw…thus, the king was **present**.
column9: 5) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 29-10-2007(18): The palintir shows only what's happening NOW - the **present** \- to the all- _see_ ing eye of Sauron. Unfortunate overlap of keywords. I sometimes write 贈 [presents](../v4/503.html) (#503 贈) when given this keyword for review.

column3: If, at some aboriginal level, **Toys** Я Us, then the archetypal _ball_ must have been there at the _beginning_ , before evolving into beach balls, ping- pong balls, rugby balls, and marbles.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 14-11-2006(53): The _ball_ was the only thing that people at the _beginning_ of time had to use as a **toy**. Poor cavemen.
column6: 2) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 18-9-2010(37): Even the _king_ played with **toy** s in the _beginning_.
column7: 3) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 23-8-2009(25): And so it was, the _ball_ marked the _beginning_ of all the **toys** that were to come.
column8: 4) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 7-5-2010(9): 玩 depicts one of the most ancient **TOY** s known to mankind: _MARBLES_. The use of such small _BALL_ s for play goes back to the _BEGINNING_ of recorded history. ( **TOY** _MARBLES_ were found in Egyptian pyramids, for example.).
column9: 5) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 20-3-2007(4): Mnemonic " **toy** boy" - From the days of the garden of eden boys have used their _balls_ as **toy** s.

column3: A **lunatic** is literally one driven mad by the light of the moon, and the most famous of the  " **looneys** " are the legendary lycanthropes or "wolfmen." Sometimes the transformation is only a temporary phenomenon, sometimes it is permanent. In the latter case, the poor chap takes off on all fours to live with the beasts. To remember this kanji, imagine one of these lycanthropes going **looney** and setting himself up as _king_ of a _pack of wild dogs_ that roams about and terrorizes innocent suburban communities.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 13-9-2007(201): Oh no ! A _pack of dogs_ has bitten the _king_. He has turned into a rabid **lunatic** !
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 19-11-2006(32): Think of _King_ Nebuchadnezzar, who for 7 years **lost his sanity** and had to live like a _wild animal_.
column7: 3) [[Jaunty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jaunty)] 13-6-2009(27): The _wild dog king_ (Red XIII) had an awesome limit break - **Lunatic** High!
column8: 4) [[jonobugs](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonobugs)] 3-5-2008(19): Only a **lunatic** would use a _wild pack of dogs_ to protect the _king_.
column9: 5) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 5-2-2010(16): The _Dog king_ was a **lunatic**. In fact, he was a laughing hyena. Use the **lunatic** hyena(dog) in the Lion _King_ if it helps.

column3: The radiant, **effulgent** splendor of he _sun_ makes it _king_ of all the planets and other stars. Just to be sure you don't take this too abstractly, picture the _sun_ seated on a throne, flourishing its _scepter_ this way and that.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-6-2007(60): The _Sun King_ (Louis XIV) was known for his **effulgent** reign.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 2-8-2008(19): [+katsuo] This is the _Sun King_. Sayeth Wikipedia: "The _Sun King_ (in French le Roi Soleil) because of the idea that, just as the planets revolve around the _Sun_ , so too should France and the court revolve around [the _king_ ] ("<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France>). And just like the _sun_ , he was quite **effulgent** and actually emitted _sun_ light.
column7: 3) [[Woodsei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Woodsei)] 10-3-2012(13): The _sun_ is the **effulgent** _king_ of stars.
column8: 4) [[montecristo73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/montecristo73)] 17-6-2010(7): The sun is the king of **effulgent** bodies in the sky.
column9: 5) [[amillerchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amillerchip)] 4-1-2012(4): Eeffulgent? I'll never remember that. Renaming this **full of vigor**. The _king_ always started the _day_ **full of vigor** , ready to rule his kingdom like the nobles of old.

column3: An **emperor** , as we all know, is a ruler - something like a _king_ but higher in status. The _white bird_ perched above the _king_ , elevating him to **imperial** heights, is the messenger he sends back and forth to the gods to request advice and special favors, something that _white birds_ have long done in folklore throughout the world.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 4-10-2007(151): Ancient Rome had **Emperor** s instead of Kings, and they wore white robes. Thus an **emperor** is a _king_ in _white_. (make sure you picture a roman **emperor** not a japanese one and you'll be ok).
column6: 2) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 13-10-2008(63): I don't think the Japanese would be happy if their **emperor** was a _white king_ …
column7: 3) [[lucianreign](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lucianreign)] 6-12-2006(50): The white dove descended on the king and he was promoted to **emperor**.
column8: 4) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 14-7-2006(24): An **emperor** is a holy king. In Japanese Shinto white is the holiest color.
column9: 5) [[vxnine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vxnine)] 7-12-2008(15): Whenever I think an **Emperor** I always think of **Emperor** Palpatine from Star Wars. He is the _king_ of all the _white_ stormtroopers.

column3: The trick to remembering this character lies in associating the key word with the line from the nursery rhyme about 4 and 20 blackbirds baked in a pie: "Wasn't this a dainty dish to set before the _king_? " If we think of **display** in terms of that famous line, and the _king_ with his head thrown back and his _mouth_ wide open as 4 and 20 blackbirds fly in one after the other, we shall have satisfied both the elements and their position.
column5: 1) [[Georgi87](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Georgi87)] 5-9-2007(157): The mouth of the king is **display** ing his bling.
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 21-10-2007(131): What a pathetic **display**! The _king_ is sprawled on his throne, head back and _mouth_ wide open, fast asleep. We should never have let him drink so much at that banquet last night.
column7: 3) [[jezerey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jezerey)] 11-2-2008(57): The mouth of the king **display** ed what a fool he was.
column8: 4) [[Twentytw0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Twentytw0)] 9-7-2008(30): Think of an evil museum that **display** s the _mouths_ of the previous dead _kings_. Imagine the tour guide dressed up in sinister clothing saying, "And on **display** here, we have the _mouth_ of _King_ Henry VIII".
column9: 5) [[thatkidpercy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thatkidpercy)] 29-11-2007(23): The original court jesters had a terrible job, if the _king_ 's _mouth_ yawned during your **DISPLAY** , it was the end of you.

column3: **Wholeness** suggests physical and spiritual health,  "having your act together." The kanji-image for **wholeness** depicts being  " _king_ under your own _umbrella_ ," that is, giving order to your own life. I know it sounds terribly abstract, but what could be more abstract than the word **whole**?
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 18-10-2007(168): The fat _king_ hogs the **whole** space under his _umbrella_. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. "fat" makes a more vivid image for me.).
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 20-12-2005(121): The _king_ takes up the **whole** space under his _umbrella_.
column7: 3) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 4-4-2008(69): King Arthur united the **whole** of England under his umbrella. (The umbrella methophore works pretty good here, due to England's miserable weather).
column8: 4) [[baldy514](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/baldy514)] 3-1-2009(17): You need a king sized umbrella to keep your **whole** body dry.
column9: 5) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 4-6-2006(10): This is similar to radical_tyro's story, but has a few points that help me. Whenever it rains, the _king_ hogs the **whole** _umbrella,_ and we can't do anything about it (because, after all, he is the _king_ ).

column3: Here we think of **plug** in the sense of a cork or stopper used to seal the mouth of a bottle, water faucet, or something with liquid running out of it. Forgetting the abstract picture of the former frame, let us work with all the primitive units: _tree_ . . . _umbrella_ . . . _ball_. Imagine a _tree_ with a faucet in the side out of which tennis _balls_ are flowing, bouncing all over the ground by the hundreds. You fight your way up to it and shove your giant beach _umbrella_ into the _tree_ to **plug** it up.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 12-10-2007(155): The fat _king_ under his _umbrella_ offers useless advice to the workers. "You'll need the _whole_ _tree_ to **plug** that gap". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they're doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the "whole" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. ).
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 12-11-2007(92): To **plug** the hole, you need to use a _whole_ piece of _wood_ \- like a cork or something.
column7: 3) [[wreckz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wreckz)] 22-2-2008(75): Best example of a **plug** is a cork. A piece of _wood_ that covers the _whole_ opening (else it would leak).
column8: 4) [[Jared](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jared)] 11-2-2008(34): Trees and umbrellas are some king sized butt **plug** s. Ouch.
column9: 5) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 24-4-2010(28): To **plug** the hole in the dam, use the **whole** damn **tree**.

column3: We first referred to this character back in frame 185, to which you might want to return to have a peek. The image of **logic** we are given is something like a central _jewel_ in a _computer_ , like the _jewels_ in old clocks that keep them running smoothly. Try to picture yourself making your way through all the rams and roms and approaching this shining _jewel_ , a chorus of voice sand a blast of trumpets in the background heralding the great seat of all- knowing **logic**.
column5: 1) [[Birdsong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Birdsong)] 26-4-2007(341): The king of **LOGIC** is the computer.
column6: 2) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 16-7-2006(33): Computers are ruled by **logic** (it is the king of computers).
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-12-2007(29): If you used the meaning "House of the Parents" for [ri](../v4/173.html) (#173 里), you will know then that, as **logic** dictates, the _King_ must rule on his own Kingdom (the _House of his Parents_ ).
column8: 4) [[fjolnir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fjolnir)] 29-10-2009(17): The _king_ of **logic** is the _computer_!
column9: 5) [[eri401](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eri401)] 16-2-2009(12): **LOGIC** reigns _king_ at my _parent's house_ = no bullshitting my wise mom or dad with silly stories!

column3: A man's home is his castle, goes the proverb from an age where it was the male who was **lord** of the household. Fundamentally, it means only that every one of us is a bit (or _drop_ ) of a _king_ in our own environment. As for the positioning of the elements, if you take care to  "read off" the primitives in this way, you won't end up putting the _drop_ down below, where it turns the kanji into a jewel.
column4: * As a primitive element, we set the key word aside entirely and take it as a pictograph of a solid brass _candlestick_ (with the drop representing the flame at the top).
column5: 1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 22-10-2007(196): A **lord** is a little _drop_ down from _King_ in hierarchy.
column6: 2) [[Spoonz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spoonz)] 15-2-2009(79): A **lord** only has a drop of the king's power.
column7: 3) [[Murjab](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Murjab)] 20-9-2007(28): Although this kanji's meaning hasn't caused me much trouble, I've had problems remembering the direction of the _drop_ above _king_ , since _drops_ at tops of kanji often seem to appear in different directions. To remember this one, I think of the placement of the _drop_ in _jewel_ (#256 玉). Both of them use the _king_ primitive and include a short _drop_ stroke going from the top left to bottom right.
column8: 4) [[trevlaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/trevlaw)] 8-11-2008(23): Oh **lord**! someone spat on the king.
column9: 5) [[MidoriTori](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MidoriTori)] 7-8-2009(10): The **lord** wants to DROP something on the KING'S head so he can become king himself.

column3: Picture **pouring** water from a lighted _candlestick_. What could be more ridiculous, or simpler, as a way to recall this kanji?
column5: 1) [[gsantise](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gsantise)] 1-9-2007(120): Visualize an idiot trying to figure out how to extinguish a candle. He sees a glass of WATER and decides to **pour** it onto the CANDLESTICK to put it out. Water spills everywhere.
column6: 2) [[Calchas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Calchas)] 20-12-2007(65): Like water the hot wax **pour** ed down the side of the candlestick.
column7: 3) [[pgp27](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pgp27)] 14-6-2009(57): "WATER, my LORD ? I'll **pour** ".
column8: 4) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 4-10-2007(40): When you **pour** you are the _water lord_.
column9: 5) [[Guoguodi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Guoguodi)] 10-1-2008(27): The lord always **pour** s for the king.

column3: The **pillar** referred to here is the _wooden_ beam that stands at the entrance to a traditional Japanese house. Carve it in imagination into the shape of a gigantic _candlestick_ and your work is done.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 9-10-2007(216): The main **pillar** in a house should be made of the biggest and strongest tree - the _lord_ of the _trees_.
column6: 2) [[potempkin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/potempkin)] 30-9-2008(79): "Why has this **pillar** been carved in the shape of a giant penis?!" "You said that 'it should be made of _wood_ ', My _Lord_.".
column7: 3) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 9-9-2010(49): " _Wood_ _Lord_ , what a **pillar**!", she said.
column8: 4) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 13-12-2008(33): This _wood_ en **pillar** is like the _lord_ of the house… (remove it and the whole house will collapse).
column9: 5) [[yawfosu88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yawfosu88)] 23-6-2007(19): Imagine a **pillar** that looks like a huge _kingly candlestick_ with a flame at the top, that is leaning to the left about to set a _tree_ next to it on fire.

column3: If this were not one of the most common characters you will ever have to write, I would apologize for having to give the explanation that follows. Anyway, we want to depict bars of **gold** bullion with an _umbrella_ overhead to shade them from the heat (and perhaps to hide them as well). The bullion is made by melting down all the _scepters_ of the kingdom, _drop_ by _drop_ , and shaping them into bars.
column4: * As a primitive, it means not only _gold_ but any _metal_ at all.
column5: 1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 22-10-2007(173): The fat _king_ taking up the _whole_ space under the _umbrella_ actually isn't fat - he just has two big **gold** bars hidden under his clothes.
column6: 2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 31-1-2008(39): Under the _umbrella's_ shade, the king sang, " _Drop_ it to the left, _drop_ it to the right, give me all the **GOLD** in sight!".
column7: 3) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 11-11-2006(25): The [king](../v4/255.html) (#255 王) walks under the _umbrella_ with a bag of **gold** on both side.
column8: 4) [[namakemono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/namakemono)] 13-10-2009(21): _King_ Midas shelters from the rain under his _umbrella_. Every now and again he reaches out with his hands to turn a couple of rain _drops_ into **gold** , and puts them in his pockets.
column9: 5) [[hugh2323](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hugh2323)] 22-5-2010(5): Give me two DROPS of **gold** and I will give you my WHOLE body.

column3: **Pig iron** refers to iron in the crude form in which it emerges from the smelting furnaces. Of all the various forms _metal_ can take, this one shows us _metal_ _before_ it has been refined. Imagine two photographs labeled  " _before_ " and "after" to show the process.
column5: 1) [[wzafran](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wzafran)] 16-6-2007(174): **Pig iron** is basic/crude _metal_ , that is, _before_ it has been processed.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 7-7-2008(121): **Pig- iron** is crude _metal_ ( 金 ) _before_ ( 先 ) it is refined. If you have trouble with this character, envision a big minotaur ( _cow_ head with _human legs_ ) as a blacksmith, smelting metals and making swords for war.
column7: 3) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 17-9-2007(33): 100% of Japanese university graduates claim to have never seen this character, so impress them by remembering it, **Pig-iron** is metal _before_ it has been processed. (Just a copy of the most common used story but with this little fact added, really impress your japanese friends or teachers by learning this one).
column8: 4) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 27-5-2009(8): **PIG- IRON** is the condition of IRON BEFORE it has been processed.
column9: 5) [[Lazerbeat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lazerbeat)] 17-8-2011(5): GOLD BEFORE an alchemist touches it is pig iron.

column3: Let **bowl** suggest a large and heavy _golden_ **bowl** into which you are throwing all the _books_ you own to mash them into pulp, for some outrageous reason you will have to think up yourself.
column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 17-6-2008(202): This is the **BOWL** of an alchemist: see how he mixes _metals_ in his **bowl** , as he follows the instructions from his _book_?
column6: 2) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 20-11-2006(66): If I was begging with a **BOWL** , I would want GOLD and BOOKS.
column7: 3) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 31-3-2008(27): I actually picture a _book_ made of _gold_ that's been warped (due to the malleability of gold) so that it has a dent in the middle that can be used as a **bowl**.
column8: 4) [[skinnyneo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skinnyneo)] 13-8-2007(23): This is a great way to learn a lot of knowledge in a little bit of time. You get a _metal_ **bowl** and throw in as many _books_ as you can! Keep'em coming! Once you have every book you can think of that you have read or want to read in that **bowl** grind'em all up!
column9: 5) [[applesuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/applesuki)] 13-12-2006(21): The winners of the super **bowl** get _gold_ rings, while the losers just get a mention in the record _book_.

column3: Picture an order of _monks_ serving as chaplains for the police force. Their special habit, made of protective _metal_ , is distinguished by a row of **copper** buttons just like the  " **cops** " they serve.
column5: 1) [[kaminix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaminix)] 2-3-2008(350): I can't believe no one has used this one yet: **Copper** is _metal_ which looks almost _the same_ as _gold_. Really, look it up on Wikipedia, it's yellow and it's shiny (atleast in some compounds)!
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 4-6-2006(51): **Copper** is an excellent conductor. In other words, it's a _metal_ for which the voltage is the _same_ everywhere. That's why it's used for wires.
column7: 3) [[sethg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethg)] 29-1-2009(22): A _metal_ that looks the _same_ as _gold_ is **COPPER**.
column8: 4) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 13-11-2007(14): **Copper** and _gold_ are in the _same_ column of the periodic table. And now what am I going to do for 銀 [silver](../v4/1459.html) (#1459 銀)????
column9: 5) [[Sevenhelmets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sevenhelmets)] 27-7-2008(10): **Copper** is a metal, the _same_ as _gold_.

column3: The character we learned for _fishing_ (Frame 184) refers to the professional, net-casting industry, while the **angling** of this character refers to the sport. The odd thing is that your **angling** rod is a _golden_ _ladle_ which you are using to scoop _gold_ fish out of a river.
column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 28-8-2007(152): All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I'm a pro. I bring a big-ass **golden** **ladle**. I'm a true **ANGLING** professional.
column6: 2) [[mcbainpc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcbainpc)] 25-6-2008(90): The easiest **angling** is pulling _gold_ fish out with a big _ladle_.
column7: 3) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 17-10-2007(56): Imagine an effeminate Roman 2000 years ago **angling** with a _golden ladle_ instead of a rod because it matches his eyes and hair better and it impresses the boys. (Why a Roman? Because 'angling' is just the roman-derived way to say 'fishing' - use this to distinguish fishing from **angling**.).
column8: 4) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 18-8-2006(27): **Angling** is not fishing (avoid [fishing](../v4/172.html) (#172 漁)). It is the art of bending _golden ladles_ into lures which which you catch the fish. But the fish aren't that important (and do not appear in this kanji). only the _golden ladle_ matters.
column9: 5) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 17-9-2007(14): I use a _gold_ _ladle_ when I'm **angling** , the golden reflection in the water draws the fish straight to it, who needs a hook and bait when you have this!

column3: In frame 10 we referred ahead to this full character from which the primitive for _needle_ (on the right) derives. Since we already expect that **needles** are made of _metal_ , let us picture a set of solid _gold_ darning **needles** to complete the kanji.
column5: 1) [[gsantise](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gsantise)] 26-8-2007(149): Remember the story of the **needle** in the haystack. Why would someone even look for a **needle** if it wasn't a GOLD **NEEDLE**?
column6: 2) [[sprutnik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sprutnik)] 28-10-2008(80): A _golden_ **needle** is worth _ten_ times more than an ordinary **needle**.
column7: 3) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 12-9-2007(24): The golden **needle** is the true **needle**.
column8: 4) [[dtstutz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dtstutz)] 28-1-2008(15): **Needle** s need to be metal (or they'll break).
column9: 5) [[Spoonz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spoonz)] 15-2-2009(11): Final fantasy reference! If you've been petrified by one of those damned monsters, get a team mate to use a golden **needle** on you!

column3: Take **inscription** in the sense of the _name_ you ask the jeweler to carve on a _gold_ bracelet or inside a _gold_ ring to identify its owner or communicate some sentimental message. It will help if you can recall the first time you had this done and the feelings you had at the time.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 27-9-2007(194): A piece of _metal_ with a _name_ on it. Well, this is basically the definition of **inscription**.
column6: 2) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 28-4-2008(35): I imagine ancient Egyptian **inscription** s: Pharaohs' _names_ written in _gold_.
column7: 3) [[elmaestrokgb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elmaestrokgb)] 23-5-2009(17): The _gold_ ring I gave her had an old girlfriend's _name_ written inside. Here's hoping she doesn't notice the **inscription**.
column8: 4) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 17-4-2007(8): **INSCRIPTION** S are done on GOLD plaques by writing your NAME on it.
column9: 5) [[skellyfish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skellyfish)] 15-12-2008(7): If you've got some METAL and you want to put a NAME on it, you've got no choice but to use an **inscription** \- everything else will rub off or fail to stick in the first place. (Imagine a bunch of people trying to write on metal with pencils, pens, etc. and then one guy with a Eureka moment thinking of **inscription** ).

column3: The first lie-detector machines of the twentieth century worked by wiring pieces of _metal_ to the body to measure the amount of sweat produced when questions were asked. It was discovered that nervousness produced more sweat, indicating subconscious reactions when the _truth_ was getting too close for comfort. Nowadays, people can take drugs that **tranquillize** them in such a way as to neutralize the effect of the device, which is why other means have had to be developed.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 11-10-2007(157): **Tranquilize** \- using a _metal_ syringe to get the _truth_.
column6: 2) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 17-2-2008(114): Enough _gold_ can **tranquilize** the _truth_ in anyone.
column7: 3) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 22-7-2008(68): James Bond was **tranquilize** d by **Gold** finger before trying to get the **truth** out of him. Picture James Bond waking up on the table with the laser.
column8: 4) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 6-6-2008(62): No need to **tranquilize** … enough _gold_ will get the _truth_ out of anyone.
column9: 5) [[viphe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/viphe)] 31-10-2006(50): To **tranquilize** your wife, you give her either _gold_ or the _truth_.

column3: The key word carries both the sense of a **road** for transit and a **way** or method of doing something, but the former is better for forming an image. The primitives read: the _neck_ of a _road_. Think of a crowded **road-way** where traffic has come to a standstill - what we commonly refer to as a  "bottle _neck_. "
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 5-2-2008(198): When we go out on the **ROAD-WAY** , we often risk our own _necks_ (that's why I take the train! ).
column6: 2) [[whistler11](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/whistler11)] 19-12-2005(39): Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel's _neck_ over a dusty _road_. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time? Or will her _neck_ be ground into the _road_ , spilling it's precious contents into the dust?
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 7-7-2008(30): Good keyword selection by Heisig: while the primitive on the left means _road_ , the whole kanji also has the meaning of **way** , or 'tao (teaching)'. Thus, road + way. (Check out the wikipedia article on the Chinese Philosophical concept of "Tao": <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tao>. It's this character!).
column8: 4) [[kaminix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaminix)] 3-3-2008(26): I have a very abstract view for this one. Remember when the kanji for [neck](../v4/70.html) (#70 首) was first introduced to us it was compared to a great moose head, cut off by it's _neck_ and hung on the wall? As we all know, mooses have very long _necks_ , if you imagine widening and stretching it a little you'll probably be able to picture yourself taking a stroll on the hairy ' _neck_ - ** _road_ -way**' of the moose. It's a very abstract mnemonic, but I swear, I was not high when coming up with it!
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 22-1-2008(13): You're going to break your _neck_ on the **road way**!

column3: When we accept someone's **guidance** , we permit ourselves to be _glued_ to a certain _road_ or _way_ of doing something, and try to  "stick" to it.
column5: 1) [[jez321](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jez321)] 27-2-2006(263): For **guidance** on the _road-way_ , _glue_ a GPS unit to your car.
column6: 2) [[cosby](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cosby)] 19-7-2008(112): Good **guidance** will help you stay _glued_ to the right _path_.
column7: 3) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 22-8-2007(38): I will glue myself to this roadway before I go to an all **guy dance** (guy dance = **guidance** :P ).
column8: 4) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 5-1-2007(25): In his quest, our hero comes to a river of _glue_ that he cannot cross. Desperate, he prays for **guidance** , and a _roadway_ magically appears _over_ the _glue_.
column9: 5) [[alatown](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alatown)] 19-9-2009(14): His **guidance** was simple: don't risk your neck, just stay glued to this road- way.

column3: Take the first two strokes in the sense we gave them back in frame 10, as the pictograph of a _cross_ , and set it on a _road_ to create a  " **crossing**. "
column5: 1) [[aevangelica](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aevangelica)] 18-7-2007(152): Cross-road.
column6: 2) [[tanaquil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tanaquil)] 28-4-2007(57): This kanji appears in the remarkable compound, 辻斬り 【つじぎり】 (n): killing a passerby in order to test a new sword. Imagine a _cross_ by the _road_ , at a busy **crossing** , marking the spot of the unfortunate passerby's death.
column7: 3) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 4-8-2008(43): A **crossing** is where the ROAD makes a CROSS with another road. Easy.
column8: 4) [[vinniram](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vinniram)] 10-12-2009(29): Why is there an extra drop on this website, but in the book there is no extra drop?
column9: 5) [[hotkiller123](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hotkiller123)] 18-1-2009(13): _Cross_ - _road_ – > **CROSSING** The extra drop is a _drop of blood_ on the road because of the many accidents that happen there. (Addition to aevangelica's story to explain the extra drop.).

column3: Here we see a _crossing_ in the form of a barbed _fishhook_ , suggesting a **swifter** alternate not only to the roundabouts used in Europe but also to the  "cloverleaf" design used on superhighways in the United States.
column5: 1) [[jezerey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jezerey)] 11-2-2008(219): The car went too **swift** ly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops.
column6: 2) [[mbagsh55](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mbagsh55)] 13-9-2007(74): In the Heisig version of Frogger, you can image _ten_ giant _fish hooks_ sweeping across the _road_ , with our hapless hero 'froggy' forced to make a **swift** crossing or end up as fish bait.
column7: 3) [[KANJI](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/KANJI)] 10-10-2006(37): Indy Jones imperative: Be **SWIFT** at the **CROSSING** or you'll be **HOOKED**. (How many times have we seen Indy Jones defy death. But is he so quick and nimble to conquer the travails on the road through RTK?).
column8: 4) [[joxn_costello](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joxn_costello)] 21-11-2008(36): If you spread _fishguts_ all over a _crossing_ , people will definitely want to cross over it very **swiftly** to get away from the awful smell!
column9: 5) [[cellophane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cellophane)] 5-12-2007(25): You cannot simply walk across a busy _crossing_ \- you must be far **swift** er than that to avoid being squished by the traffic. Instead, you need a piece of Link's gear - a _fish-hook_ -shot, to grab onto a railing on the other side and pull you across in time.

column3: Think of **creating** as making something out of nothing. Then recall how the _way_ of _revelation_ laid out in the Bible begins with the story of how God **created** the world out of a dark and chaotic nothingness.
column5: 1) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 23-12-2007(284): A _cow_ **creates** a _road_ by _eating_ all the grass on its _path_.
column6: 2) [[saleem](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saleem)] 23-3-2008(151): CREATION is the ROAD to REVELATION (if you're feeling artsy) :).
column7: 3) [[krungthep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/krungthep)] 25-4-2008(124): Creationist say that the universe was **create** d as it is now. This is the " _way_ of _revelation_ " or 'bullshit-do'.
column8: 4) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 16-11-2007(61): Like Jack Kerouac, you **create** by having revelations on the road.
column9: 5) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 4-5-2007(25): A revelation that comes to you on the road lets you **create** something brilliant.

column3: To **urge** someone to do something, you make the _way_ as appealing as possible, perhaps even _white_ washing it a bit.
column5: 1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 13-10-2006(179): When you have the **URGE** to go to _White_ Castle, you know it's time to hit the _road_.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 28-8-2007(106): When you start down the **road** of **cocaine** , you're sure to feel some pretty bad **URGE** s soon.
column7: 3) [[graham6565](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/graham6565)] 26-10-2006(91): White lines on the road are there to **urge** you to stay on the correct side of the street.
column8: 4) [[applesuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/applesuki)] 17-12-2006(42): If you have a unrelenting **urge** to pee while on the _highway_ , you have to cross the _white_ line and pull off into the breakdown lane.
column9: 5) [[ouroborosatx](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ouroborosatx)] 31-5-2008(33): The two paths one can take in life are the _white_ _road_ and the dark road. I **urge** you to take the _white_ _road_.

column3: When **escaping** from something or someone, one always feels as if one is not going fast enough, like a _turtle_ on an expressway. (Since the _turtle_ is on the _road_ and not on the left, it can keep its full kanji shape as given in frame 250.)
column5: 1) [[Georgi87](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Georgi87)] 3-4-2008(93): I used my pants to make a rope, which I then used to **escape** from prison, hence the naked, hairy legs running along the road!
column6: 2) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 1-3-2010(64): MARIO KART: When you're blasting down the **road** in Mario Kart, it's REALLY hard to **escape** from **turtle shells**. Especially the red and blue ones!!
column7: 3) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 30-9-2007(60): When your wifes _legs get hairy_ ([portent](../v4/235.html) (#235 兆)) its time to hit the _road_ and **escape**.
column8: 4) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 11-1-2006(34): A scene right out of a 30's Cartoon. A tortoise in black-white striped jailsuit is making his **escape** from the prison, sirens howling and lightthrowers searching the road, where the tortoise in painful s lowness walks away looking scared.
column9: 5) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-12-2007(18): If you used the meaning "a person's back" in [portent](../v4/235.html) (#235 兆), you will have it easy here. Adopting Georgi87: I used my pants to make a rope, which I used then to **escape** from prison, which is why you can see _my back_ while I run along the _road_!
