column3: To keep the **environs** clean and safe, you could cement _daggers_  in the _road_ , blades pointed upwards, so that no polluting traffic could pass by. You could, if you were an ecologically-minded terrorist.
column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 18-4-2007(205): Caution: this kanji doesn't mean environment, it means "environs, boundary, border, vicinity". To separate the **environs** , create the border by placing _daggers_ on the _road_.
column6: 2) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 19-1-2009(122): To protect the **environs** around their village, samurai would travel the _road_ s with their _swords_.
column7: 3) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 11-6-2008(18): This kanji means area, vicinity. Such as this or that area. STORY: My mom told me not to go across the ROAD because the kids on the other side use drugs and carry KNIVES.
column8: 4) [[grubin30](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/grubin30)] 8-6-2009(12): Caution: this kanji doesn't mean environment, it means "environs, boundary, border, vicinity". To separate the **environs** , create the border by placing _daggers_ on the _road_. Imagine cars trying to cross and having their tires popped. Stand there wagging your finger: "This is my house!".
column9: 5) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 27-11-2007(6): Protect the **environs** by patrolling the _road_ with your _dagger_. I tend to mistakenly put the abbreviated version of the sword primitive in this kanji.

column3: A virtual  _flood_ of motorcycle police washing down a _road_ is this kanji's image for a **patrol**.
column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 28-8-2007(134): The cops don't **PATROL** anymore - they just **flood** the **road**.
column6: 2) [[diracbracket](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/diracbracket)] 16-11-2007(71): The Venice cops **patrol** on river roads.
column7: 3) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 11-6-2008(47): Crime has increased so the police have been recruiting PACMAN's to **PATROL** the STREETS. Here we see THREE of them **PATROL** LING around with their MOUTHS open.
column8: 4) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 19-1-2009(21): A **patrol** of rescue workers arrive to help clear the _flood_ in the _road_.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 23-2-2008(16): This should be easy. Imagine any news broadcast that shows the **PATROL** of police and national guard after the ROADS were FLOODED. Just to rescue the needy and stop the looters.

column3: You may keep the whole range of connotations for this keyword, **car** , provided it does not interfere with the pictograph. Look for the front and back wheels (the first and last horizontal strokes) and the seat in the carriage in the middle. As an exercise, try to isolate the primitives on your own and make a story out of them.
column4: * _Car_ , _cart_ , _wagon_ , and _vehicle_ may all be used as primitive meanings.
column5: 1) [[Twentytw0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Twentytw0)] 19-7-2007(151): My **car** is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.
column6: 2) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 20-1-2006(17): Actually, this is a 10x10 **car** that can get you through a rice field.
column7: 3) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 23-12-2007(15): Rather than hobbling along with a _walking stick_ to cross through a _span_ , it's much better to use a **car**. (Imagine an old man with a _walking stick_ creeping along a _span_ of road, and you, in a **car** , whizzing right by him. It's funny 'cause it's true.) Also, it's important to include the word "through," so you know the _walking stick_ goes right THROUGH the _span_.
column8: 4) [[hotsw4p](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hotsw4p)] 21-12-2009(12): The travelling _time span_ is _cut in half_ if going by **car**. / The **car** allows you to _cut your travelling time span by half_.
column9: 5) [[nycity](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nycity)] 2-5-2007(8): My **car** cost me the equivalent of 10 rice fields .. 10!!

column3: What you are meant to **take along** in this kanji are not things but people. The image of the _car_ on the _road_ should ground your image for picking up your friends to _take_ them _along_ to wherever you are going.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 16-9-2007(161): When you put your _car_ on the _road_ you should always **take along** a few friends. Don't confuse with [carry](../v4/303.html) (#303 運).
column6: 2) [[Ji_suss](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ji_suss)] 24-8-2008(31): This kanji also means "linked" or "series" so I've changed the kanji meaning to "GO ALONG (WITH EACH OTHER)." Well, a ROAD and a CAR certainly GO ALONG with each other. And the CAR will help you to GO ALONG the ROAD. This Kanji is the "Union" in Soviet Union and the "United" of United Nations (the countries that "go along with each other" at least some of the time).
column7: 3) [[Lizzie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lizzie)] 24-5-2008(30): When I am on the road I always **take along** my car.
column8: 4) [[eri401](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eri401)] 29-6-2009(20): The difference between [transport](../v4/289.html) (#289 輸), [take along](../v4/287.html) (#287 連) and [carry](../v4/303.html) (#303 運)? **Transport 輸** = when your car moves big items, like meat and sabers for that one butcher's hut. **Take Along 連** = when you take a guest in your car on the road. **Carry 運** = the luck you carry when the king's carriage is out on the road, tossing gold coins to bystanders.
column9: 5) [[Mesqueeb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Mesqueeb)] 5-12-2008(9): [Borat] I want **take along** many garls in _pussymagnet_ (= _car_ ) on my _road_ back to Kazakstan.

column3: Combine the primary and secondary meanings of this keyword to form your story. Begin with the _car_ whose tires get caught in a **rut** and spin without going anywhere. Then go onto the _baseball team_ who can't win a game because it has fallen into a **rut** of losing.
column5: 1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 25-10-2007(262): My _car_ got so stuck in a **rut** it required _nine_ people pushing to get it out again.
column6: 2) [[Verdana](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Verdana)] 24-2-2009(47): My _car_ got so stuck in a **rut** it required _a baseball team_ pushing to get it out again.
column7: 3) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 16-9-2007(38): I got my _car_ stuck in a **rut** ! I'm gonna have to call 999 !
column8: 4) [[Twentytw0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Twentytw0)] 11-7-2008(35): Imagine a broadcast over a police radio saying, " _Car nine_ is stuck in a **rut** … I repeat _car nine_ stuck in **rut**. All units please proceed to _car nine_ ".
column9: 5) [[MeinKraftDinner](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MeinKraftDinner)] 17-12-2012(13): Hitler gets his CAR stuck in a **RUT** , so he yells "Nein! Nein! Nein! Nein! Nein! Nein!!!!…" Also, the Kanji is made up of NINE strokes.

column3: On the left we see a _vehicle_ used for **transport**. On the right, we see a new tangle of elements that need sorting out. The first three strokes, you will remember, are the primitive for _meeting_. Below it we see the elements for _flesh_ and _saber_ , which combine to create a compound element for a _butcher_ and his trade. Together they give us the image of a  "trucker's convoy."
column5: 1) [[jmadsen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jmadsen)] 17-12-2005(219): The _car_ is a cattle-car, used to **transport** animals for the _butcher_ 's _meeting_ \- a convention on new butchering techniques. Hear the screams of the animals as it pulls up in front of the convention hall, where the butchers are waiting with their knives out front.
column6: 2) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 18-9-2007(109): The vehicle **transport** s animals for a meeting with the butcher.
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 3-8-2008(53): When _flesh_ and _saber meet_ … it's probably time to find some **transport** to the hospital. A _car_ maybe?
column8: 4) [[Wisher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wisher)] 15-8-2008(32): In the movie Star Wars: A New Hope, Luke and Obi-Wan needed a **Transport** (VEHICLE) to get to Alderon. They had a (MEETING) with Han Solo. Things got rough in the cantina and an arm (FLESH) got cut off with a light saber (SWORD).
column9: 5) [[eri401](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eri401)] 27-8-2011(21): The difference between [transport](../v4/289.html) (#289 輸), [take along](../v4/287.html) (#287 連) and [carry](../v4/303.html) (#303 運)? **Transport 輸** = when your car moves big items, like meat and sabers for that one butcher's hut. **Take Along 連** = when you take a guest in your car on the road. **Carry 運** = the luck you carry when the king's carriage is out on the road, tossing gold coins to bystanders.

column3: People who try to sound literary often end up butchering the language. Here we see a _meeting_ of _butchers_ whose _mouths_ are producing the **metaphors**.
column5: 1) [[Themistoclaus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Themistoclaus)] 24-4-2011(51): **Metaphor** ically speaking, all the equipment in your _mouth_ is basically just a _meeting of butchers_ , designed to pulverize whatever meat you put in there.
column6: 2) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 16-7-2010(18): **Metaphor** : A good **metaphor** flows from the _mouth_ like the _meeting of flesh and saber_ , smoothly piercing the listener with its meaning. But a bad **metaphor** is like when you barely nick the _flesh_ and only spill _two drops_ of blood or when your _saber_ doesn't penetrate at all but rather bends into a くく shape when you whack the _flesh_. (Note: This story incorporates both the traditional form of the kanji ( [口＋兪](midori://search?text=口＋兪) ) and the simplified form ( [口＋俞](midori://search?text=口＋俞) )) .
column7: 3) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 24-11-2009(13): **Metaphor** : (Let this altered butcher primitive = _koo-koo butcher_ , notice the kana くく). _Koo-koo butcher_ s sell even the _mouth_ of an animal and support their actions with crappy **metaphors** such as "I ain't never meat the man who doesn't like his mouth.".
column8: 4) [[aaroncp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aaroncp)] 6-2-2011(11): A _meeting of butchers_ is a perfect **metaphor** for the supposed secret talks( _mouth_ ) between Hitler and Stalin.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 7-11-2011(3): 喩え ( 例え ), 比喩 , 隠喩 , 暗喩 , 直喩 , [metaphor](../v4/3009.html) (#3009 喩) ユ( 輸 ), たとえる, たとえ … Parts: 口 , 兪/俞 (cf: 輸入 [transport](../v4/289.html) (#289 輸), 真鍮 [Unicode-0x936e](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/37742) (#37742 鍮)) … Story: A **Meat-aphor** for modern times: What we put into our _mouths_ , the dead flesh from a thousand _Koo-Koo Butchers_ , is the cause of the that which comes out of those same mouths. We speak of nothing but death from our mouths, because we put nothing but death into our mouths.

column3: We waited to introduce this character until now, even though the pieces have been available for some time, because it helps to reinforce the odd kanji of the last frame. Picture the _butcher_ hacking away with his knife at a slab of meat on his table with a pair of ram's _horns_ placed **in front** of him (or on his head, if you prefer). There is no need to worry about confusing this kanji with that for _before_ (Frame 263), since it will not appear as a primitive in any other character used in this book.
column5: 1) [[diracbracket](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/diracbracket)] 26-12-2007(354): When I get _horn_ y my _flesh sword_ sticks out **in front** of me.
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 25-10-2007(74): If you stand **in front** of a bull's _horns_ , you are asking for your _flesh_ to be _cut_ (or _butchered_ if you prefer).
column7: 3) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 23-2-2007(63): **IN FRONT** of the BUTCHER shop, there is a sign made of HORNS.
column8: 4) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 19-1-2008(21): At the bullfight, the matador stands bravely **in front** of the bull's _horns_. With his _sword_ , he'll dig into its _flesh._.
column9: 5) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 31-3-2008(11): The bullfighter stands **IN FRONT** of the _animal's horns_ while he pokes its _flesh_ with his _sword_ to rile it up.

column3: Think of **roasting** the guest of honor at a party - literally, in _front_ of an _oven-fire_.
column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(82): In many asian restaurants, meat is **roast** ed right _in front_ of you over _flames_.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 27-6-2007(8): At the **roast** , they make the **roast** ee sit _in front_ of everyone else, _over the flames_ to speak, as the comedians **roast** him a new one!
column7: 3) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 5-1-2009(6): "I'm going to **roast** you over a _fire_ , お前 ," the angry gangster said.
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 9-5-2011(4): They would **roast** marshmellows _in front_ of an _oven fire_ (as no fire place was available).
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 2-12-2010(3): 煎餅 , 煎茶 , 煎る =炒る, 煎じる , 二番煎じ [roast](../v4/2548.html) (#2548 煎) セン(cf 前 ), いる, せんじる … Parts: 前 [in front](../v4/290.html) (#290 前), 灬 … Story: Some people like to buy Senbei 煎餅 precooked, but I like it when they **Roast** it in an _Oven Fire_ right _In Front Of_ me.

column3: Suum cuique goes the popular Latin proverb. A certain disease of the English language makes it almost impossible to translate the phrase without gender bias. In any event, here we see someone walking with his/her _mouth_ between his/her _walking legs_ , giving us an image of "To **each** his/her own. "
column4: * The sense of the proverb should help when using this kanji as a primitive, otherwise, reduce it to its original elements. But do not associate it in any way with the word "every," which we shall meet later in another context.
column5: 1) [[penne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/penne)] 16-3-2008(260): Son, I've never told you this but **each** woman has a second _mouth_ between their fiiiiiine _walking legs_.
column6: 2) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 18-7-2006(156): **Each** and every one of us walks and talks differently.
column7: 3) [[miki76](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/miki76)] 15-12-2008(87): **Each** person is gifted with a _mouth_ to get us into trouble and a pair of _walking legs_ to get us out!
column8: 4) [[Zareon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zareon)] 12-2-2007(67): It's easier for me to remember a concrete object. This combination occurs often enough for me to make it a primitive element. Walking legs and mouth combine to give a "walky talky" or mobile phone. Imagine one of those old big ones which looked like refridgerators. Mobile phones are so popular that **each** of us seems to want one.
column9: 5) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 6-2-2008(39): **EACH** of us learns first to use our _legs to walk_ and then to use our _mouths_ to talk.

column3: If you can imagine _trees_ as **status** symbols (as they might well be for those living in Japan's congested cities, where greenery has become something of a luxury item), then _each_ might be aiming to have his/her own _tree_ , just to keep up with the Suzukis.
column5: 1) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 13-6-2007(250): "Ranger! I want you to go check the **status** of each tree." "Errr, Each tree sir?" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. "That's Right, I want the **status** of each tree! Move out!".
column6: 2) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 22-10-2010(80): A man measures his own **status** by the size of his _wood_ y…and compares it to _each_ one he sees. 性格 (せいかく) : character, personality, 合格 (ごうかく) : success, passing (e.g. exam), eligibility.
column7: 3) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 11-12-2007(73): I find I need a more concrete image for this. EACH TREE has it's own **STATUS**. For example, the Christmas Tree is holy, the Willow is of high class while the lowly Bonsai is of low class.
column8: 4) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 14-5-2006(32): A person looking for **status** wants a _tree_ of _each_ kind in his garden.
column9: 5) [[takoman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/takoman)] 11-1-2008(26): (カク, コウ) In Japan, where land is so precious, _each tree_ you have helps elevate your **status** in society. Unless you are Kumi KOUda and can actually afford to buy lots of trees, the only way you will get them is if you KAKU them.

column3: To those who believe in the inevitability of **graft** in government, everything has a price - or as this character has it, to _each_ office its outlay of _shells_.
column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 16-7-2007(68): It might sound simple to bribe someone, but then you have to **graft** the guy above him and the guy below him, and soon you're just giving _shells_ to _each_ and everyone!
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 28-11-2008(18): When I was caught by the police doing some **graft** (graffiti), I gave _each_ cop some _clams_ and told them to be on their way. 賄賂 【わいろ】 bribe.
column7: 3) [[hunchbag](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hunchbag)] 7-9-2011(10): _Graft: the acquisition of money, gain, or advantage by dishonest, unfair, or illegal means, especially through the abuse of one's position or influence in politics, business, etc. ._ _STORY:_ The evil corporate extortionist **graft** s all who get within his power. He **GRAFT** s a different amount of MONEY from EACH of his victims. If they have more, he extorts more. He even plots it out on an evil graph!
column8: 4) [[doviende](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/doviende)] 23-10-2011(6): **Graft** is like bribing. You have to give _MONEY_ to _EACH_ person. There's a guy with a briefcase full of money and a walky-talky, and he's going around asking on the walky-talky about who he should give money too. "This guy gets money? Roger.".
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(5): I take this to mean the verb **graft** , and so simply see a bunch of shellfish being **grafted** onto _each_ other, _each_ to _each_.

column3: _Each field_ has its own **abbreviations** (chemistry, philosophy, sports, etc.). Needless to say, the  "stronger" primitive - thatis to say, the simpler and more often used one - takes the dominant position on the left, even though the story would read them off the other way around.
column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 26-4-2008(200): There are so many **abbreviation** s and acronyms nowadays that no _brain_ can remember _each_ of them. Mnemonic: ab-brain-each-ation.
column6: 2) [[whistler11](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/whistler11)] 4-9-2006(73): A very anal farmer wants to catologue _each_ grain of rice in his _rice field._ Imagine him scribbling a tiny _abbreviation_ of his name and a number on _each_ grain.
column7: 3) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 11-10-2007(47): _Each_ landing _field_ has it's own **abbreviation** , e.g. BNE for Brisbane, SYD for Sydney, DRW for Darwin etc.
column8: 4) [[sethg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethg)] 2-2-2009(28): My _brain_ cannot remember _each_ **ABBREVIATION** I see. There are just too many!!!
column9: 5) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 28-11-2007(21): _Each field_ has it's own **abbreviation** \- no _brain_ could remember _each_ one! My _brain_ can't remember _each_ of the readings for this kanji! My foray into this _field_ will be **abbreviated** if I can't _walk_ the _talk_!

column3: When you are a **guest** in a courteous town, _each house_ hold has its own way of welcoming you, and _each house_ becomes your home.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 16-9-2007(283): _Each_ person under my _roof_ is treated as a **guest**.
column6: 2) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 15-11-2008(30): In my house I welcome each **guest**.
column7: 3) [[kaminix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaminix)] 3-3-2008(17): Quite a rude **guest** walking around talking in his _walky talky_ in someone else's _home_!
column8: 4) [[pgp27](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pgp27)] 21-8-2010(12): If you are my **guest** , under my ROOF you can open your WALKING LEGS and I'll put my mouth down there to please you, that's hospitality !
column9: 5) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 14-4-2010(8): [each](../v4/291.html) (#291 各) is given the meaning KEITAI (Mobile Phone). I hate it when **guest** s answer their **Keitai** in my **house**.

column3: As Miss Manners will be the first to tell you, out of respect, one does not look straight into the eyes of one's _guests_ , but focus on the top button of their collar. Here, however, you are told to look above the eyes to the **forehead** of your _guest_.
column5: 1) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 15-3-2008(231): Sign the _guest_ book _page_ with your **forehead**. (Picture a guestbook full of **forehead** prints like thumbprints).
column6: 2) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 7-12-2007(70): In New Zealand, people welcome guests by touching their **forehead** s together.
column7: 3) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 3-10-2006(47): Thankful _guests_ bow so much, you never see their entire _heads_ , just their **foreheads**.
column8: 4) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 11-7-2007(40): The **guest** lowers his **forehead** as he turns the **page** in a **guest** book.
column9: 5) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 26-6-2008(33): As a _guest_ in Japan, being too tall for their standards, I have to bow my _head_ every time I enter someone's house, or else I'll smack my **forehead**.

column3: In the **summer** , fatigued by the heat, your _head_ hangs down nearly as far as your _walking legs_ , or rather, your "dragging legs." Note how the _walking legs_ (instead of  "animal legs") are the only thing that distinguishes this character from that for _page_ (Frame 64).
column5: 1) [[Birdsong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Birdsong)] 8-5-2007(172): In **SUMMER** you are hot from the top of your _head_ down to your _walking legs_.
column6: 2) [[rachels](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rachels)] 28-7-2008(114): _One_ _drop_ of sweat runs into my _eye_ , when I go _walking_ on a hot **summer** day.
column7: 3) [[ouroborosatx](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ouroborosatx)] 27-5-2008(94): I personally think it was too confusing to try and use _head_ as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the _animal legs_ are replaced with _walking legs_ instead of _human legs_?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot **summer** and you want to keep _oneself_ under a _ceiling_ not out _jogging_ around.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 15-8-2011(33): Tip:Don't use Head/Page( 頁 ) as a primitive, or it will just screw up. 頁 is used hundreds of times as primitive, and _always_ needs the animal legs. Repetition makes RTK work. Little changes make life hard … The smell of sweat in **Summer** rises to the _ceiling_ , leading you to take your 自 _nose_ out on 夂 _walking legs_ for fresh cool air. Remember a set with 冬 [winter](../v4/427.html) (#427 冬) where the sweat ( _two drops_ in fact), has fallen down and frozen below those same _walking legs_.
column9: 5) [[whistler11](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/whistler11)] 22-4-2006(14): The heat of **summer** is so powerful, it swells your _head_ so big, you need a bigger set of _walking legs_ to hold it up.

column3: Both the stretching out of the _walking legs_ and the little bit of _wind_ tucked in on the right suggest using one's legs to kick something out of the way, or **dispose** of it.
column5: 1) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 16-5-2007(278): The best way to **dispose** of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.
column6: 2) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 12-7-2008(146): To **dispose** of rubbish you should _walk_ it to the bin not throw it to the _wind_.
column7: 3) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 11-7-2007(65): Contrast this with [discard](../v4/655.html) (#655 捨). Disposing of something implies a degree of care, whereas discarding something is generally careless. You want to associate this with a careful way to get rid of something. You throw a piece of garbage into the _wind_ to get rid of it, but remember that you should **dispose** of it responsibly and your walking legs carry you off to fetch it.
column8: 4) [[Pete171](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pete171)] 23-9-2008(28): To **dispose** of something you can either kick it away with your _walking legs_ or you can wait for the _wind_ to blow it away.
column9: 5) [[NyahK](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NyahK)] 2-1-2010(12): I thought to **dispose** of my _wind_ secretly, but it appears I 'left' a trail behind whilst _walking_ away.

column3: Geppetto made _walking legs_ for his little Pinocchio from two **twigs** of a _tree_ , giving him a set of " **twiggy** " shanks.
column5: 1) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 28-1-2008(586): They all say they have a _TREE_ between their _WALKING LEGS_ but most only have a **TWIG**.
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 8-11-2007(103): Don't confuse with branch or bough - think of snapping **twig** s. A **twig** is always the kind of _wood_ that snaps when the hunter's _walking legs_ just barely touch it, making a snapping sound that alerts the prey to the hunter's presence.
column7: 3) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 11-6-2008(50): I don't believe this means **twig** as in a tree **twig**. 条 【じょう】 (n) (1) article (in document), provision, (2) stripe, streak, line. STORY: If TREES had WALKING LEGS they would march right up to congress and demand they put in a new ARTICLE into the constitution against deforestation.
column8: 4) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 13-11-2009(24): (Doesn't mean **twig**!) I read an **article** in the Weekly World News about a _walking_ _tree_.
column9: 5) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 8-5-2007(14): I once read an **ARTICLE** about a guy who shoved a **TREE** between his _WALKING LEGS_. he was pulling out **TWIG** s for a long time.

column3: When _water_ **falls** , it splats and splashes, when _flower_ petals **fall** , they float gently in the breeze. To _each_ thing its own way of **falling**.
column5: 1) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 18-9-2007(184): Water each flower or the petals will wither and **fall**.
column6: 2) [[pm215](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pm215)] 15-2-2008(120): [It's been suggested on the forum (<http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079>) that _flower_ across the full width of the kanji and _water_ on the left below it should have its own keyword, _seaweed_ is a popular choice. See also [dilute](../v4/227.html) (#227 薄), [clan](../v4/1912.html) (#1912 藩), [seaweed](../v4/2035.html) (#2035 藻). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers **fall** ing through the sky – suddenly _each_ one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori _seaweed_ to carry them safely down.
column7: 3) [[Yasser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yasser)] 20-11-2008(75): "Flowers" need "water" "each" day or they'll bend and **fall** over (helps with the order of writing).
column8: 4) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 9-4-2007(25): The _flowers_ **FALL** over the _water each_ hanami season.
column9: 5) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 12-11-2008(13): "each" is impossible to visualize, instead I picture a guy **fall** ing down with his mouth open in a scream and his walking legs above him flailing as he's **fall** ing. Works well for this kanji if you imagine him **fall** ing from a waterfall. At first he's holding on to some flowers, but they finally give and he tumbles into the water below.

column3: Picture a _weather vane_ beneath a regal _crown_ , spinning round and round. It is not only **superfluous** but makes a perfect ass out of the one who wears it.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 14-1-2006(418): The king's crown was blown off by the wind. "Oh well," he said, "it's just a **superfluous** symbol.".
column6: 2) [[emanalo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/emanalo)] 6-7-2008(51): The court jester wears a _crown_ and is full of _wind_ with bad jokes. He is **superfluous** to the King's court. This kanji is read as "JOU" and commonly used to create the compound for _jou-dan_ 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also _jou-go_ 冗語 (redundancy) and _jou-in_ 冗員 (useless workers) 員 -[employee](../v4/56.html) (#56 員).
column7: 3) [[tanaquil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tanaquil)] 23-4-2007(28): Trying to put a _crown_ on the _wind_ is like gilding the lily: entirely **superfluous**.
column8: 4) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 12-2-2008(17): The _wind_ bags who wear the _crown_ are almost always **SUPERFLUOUS** to the governance of their countries.
column9: 5) [[TadghD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TadghD)] 30-6-2009(10): Instead of just fluous, like the flow of the wind, I crown you **superfluous**.

column3: The key word in this frame refers to the underworld, the world of the dead. By way of the classic Greek association, it is also used for the "dwarf planet" Pluto. Since no one knows precisely when this part of the cosmos was finished, we may imagine it as the _crowning_ deed of _day six_ of the creation.
column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 2-11-2007(68): The beast of **hades** one _day_ will wear a _crown_ , and the number of the beast is _666_.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 30-7-2009(45): In **Hades** you have to work _six days_ a week before _crowning_ it with something vaguely resembling a weekend. Oh wait, that's Japan.
column7: 3) [[cb4960](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cb4960)] 16-2-2009(21): In **Hades** , as punishment, souls are forced to wear _crowns_ as hot as the _sun_ for _6_ 66 days.
column8: 4) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 21-2-2009(7): If you can survive **Hades** for _six days_ they give you a _crown_ as a reward.
column9: 5) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 18-7-2007(7): It's dark in **Hades** , for the _sun_ is covered by a _crown_. Oh, yeah, and the number _six_ is just a wee bit popular down there.

column3: The _crowned vehicle_ depicted here is a  " _chariot_ ," symbol of an **army**.
column4: * Used as a primitive this kanji means only _chariot_.
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 19-1-2008(150): British **army** _cars_ are at the service of the _crown_.
column6: 2) [[RickN](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RickN)] 11-12-2007(45): Imagine a _crown_ is the hood ornament on every **army** _car_.
column7: 3) [[Cirion](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cirion)] 23-7-2008(31): The **army** has _cars_ that are under the command of the _crown_ \- in ancient days these would have been _chariots_. (NB: "under" to help remember placement of the primitives.).
column8: 4) [[joxn_costello](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joxn_costello)] 23-11-2008(17): A _vehicle_ _crowned_ with a turret is a tank – and obviously a tank belongs in the **army**!
column9: 5) [[yukkuri_kame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yukkuri_kame)] 24-8-2008(7): There is an **army** of taxi drivers in Japan driving the Toyota Crown model of car.

column3: Take advantage of the first syllable of the key word to think of the _ray_ of light to the left. Now add the glittering _chariot_ that is emitting those _rays_ and you have **radiance**.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 29-10-2007(197): Rays of light emitted from Apollo's chariot = **radiance**. Don't put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!
column6: 2) [[erlog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erlog)] 18-7-2008(134): **Radiance** is an army of rays.
column7: 3) [[anroo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anroo)] 25-7-2009(59): **Radiance** isn't just a few _rays_ , but a whole _army_ of them.
column8: 4) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 25-10-2007(30): When I think of **radiance** I think of the greek god Zeus - picture him throwing _rays_ of lightning (hence the extra jaggedness of the character) from atop his _chariot_ riding through the heavens.
column9: 5) [[brendanmacdonald](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brendanmacdonald)] 21-4-2008(13): Ray's little legs joined the army - so Ray-did-a-dance (radiance).

column3: A long string of "sweet" _chariots_ "swinging low" to our _roads_ is a sure sign that the Lord is  "comin' for to **carry** " someone home.
column5: 1) [[javiergakusei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/javiergakusei)] 27-3-2007(245): Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to **carry** military supplies (sorry no room for you).
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 3-10-2007(66): Roads **carry** armies (in contrast to seas **carry** ing navies or skies **carry** ing air forces).
column7: 3) [[kinkypete](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kinkypete)] 13-1-2008(40): "swing low, sweet _chariot_ , coming for to **carry** me hoooommmee.
column8: 4) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 11-11-2008(24): In the past, _road_ s were established mainly to **carry** the _army_.
column9: 5) [[eri401](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eri401)] 27-2-2009(16): The difference between [transport](../v4/289.html) (#289 輸), [take along](../v4/287.html) (#287 連) and [carry](../v4/303.html) (#303 運)? Transport 輸 = when your car moves big items, like meat and sabers for that one butcher's hut. Take Along 連 = when you take a guest in your car on the road. **Carry** 運 = the luck you **carry** when the king's carriage is out on the road, tossing gold coins to bystanders.

column3: By having the **crown** pass from one age to the next, a people keeps itself _glued_ to its _beginnings_.
column5: 1) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 13-5-2007(313): Remember the SUPERFLUOUS **CROWN** that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying "i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING".
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-7-2007(133): A **crown** , from the _beginning_ of the new king's life, is _glued_ to him. He must inherit it.
column7: 3) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 29-11-2008(26): That **crown** was **glued** together from the **beginning** …I swear!
column8: 4) [[pinnine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pinnine)] 26-2-2008(18): **Crown** ing is when the child _begins_ to emerge from the vagina, covered in _gluey_ mucus.
column9: 5) [[Samchan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Samchan)] 18-2-2009(14): I liked wasurenaide's story, but the superfluous and wind bits just confused me, so changed it a bit: Remember the **CROWN** that kept falling off the kings big shiny bald head while he's making a long speech? Well now the king is saying "i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING".

column3: To have a **dream** after going to bed is really the _crown_ to a perfect _evening_. The _flower_ petals over the _eyes_ (instead of the  "sand" that Westerners are used to finding there when they awake in the morning) only confirms the image of a pleasant **dream** suggested by the rest of this rather complex kanji.
column5: 1) [[mameha1977](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mameha1977)] 13-11-2007(164): Last night's date with Miss Sweden was like a **dream**. She even laid _flowers_ over my _eyes_ to _crown_ the perfect _evening_.
column6: 2) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 27-3-2007(59): In the movie American Beauty, Kevin Spacey liked to **DREAM** about his daughter's friend and have a _rose petal_ fall onto his _eye_ from the _ceiling_. He did this lying in his bed each _evening_. You can almost see him lying in his bed in this kanji.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 7-10-2007(58): Sweet **dream** s like flowers for the eye are the crown of a perfect evening.
column8: 4) [[dbooster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dbooster)] 16-12-2009(39): In Japan, "flowers over your eyes" is a metaphor for falling asleep and **dream** ing (just as the sandman is in the West). So we can make a little poem: _Flowers_ over your _eyes_ , The _crown_ of a perfect _evening_.
column9: 5) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 18-10-2006(30): I like to think of the sideways eye as a _cyclops_ , either the monster of Greek mythology or the X-Men character. The primitive reappears in [demolition](../v4/400.html) (#400 壊) and others. So: Odysseus and his mates carefully hang magical _flowers_ above the evil _cyclops_. These allow them to take the monster's _crown_ and escape in the _evening_ , while the monster is peacefully **dreaming**.

column3: A _whirlwind_ begins to dig its way into the _soil_ like a drill until it makes a deep **pit**.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 6-2-2007(155): A _whirlwind_ digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of _dirt_ until it ends up with a giant **pit**.
column6: 2) [[Wahlin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wahlin)] 7-9-2006(59): Tazmanian Devil whirlwinds a **pit** into the soil. Note: Take care difference between **pit** and rut.
column7: 3) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 17-2-2008(41): All the _soil_ was thrown to the left as the Tasmanian Devil's _whirlwind_ swirled out a **PIT**.
column8: 4) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 29-3-2008(22): Down in the earth, there's a **pit** where you'll find miners in top hats constantly breaking wind.
column9: 5) [[Alunalun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Alunalun)] 19-7-2010(13): A **pit** is cut into the _soil_ by a magician archaeologist. He uses a _whirlwind_. (and for the primitive:) A **whirlwind** is made by a magician from his _top hat_ , he holds it up and a ferocious _wind_ whirls out of it, messing up the attire of everyone in the front row. _[RTK2 #221, pure group, コウ. signal primitive_ whirlwind _is コウ because you will get コウght in it unless you are at the very コウ=core]_.

column3: Recalling an image from frame 195, first see the _mouth_ under the extraterrestrial's glass _hood_ , and then the _mouth_ under the _top hat_ of one of his mates who has tried on the strange earthling's headgear only to find that it makes him look much, much **taller** than everyone else.
column4: * As a primitive, this character keeps its sense of _tall_ and its position at the top of other primitives, but its writing is abbreviated to the first 5 strokes.
column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 30-11-2007(149): Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and _top hat_ , trying to look **TALL**. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.
column6: 2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 13-6-2008(82): Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a **TALL** hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).
column7: 3) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 26-3-2010(34): Woody and Buzz-light year. Woody (in the cowboy **hat** ) being **Tall** er than Buzz ( in the **space helmet** ) both with big _mouths_. Thx Minlawc! (adjusted for clarity).
column8: 4) [[Alunalun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Alunalun)] 14-5-2009(19): This is the classic two children trying to be **tall** enough to get on a fairground ride. The lower child hides under a _cover_ while the upper child stands on his shoulders and talks like he's an adult. But they're still not **tall** enough! So the top child gets a _top hat_ which j-u-s-t pokes above the 'you must be this **tall** ' line. (and they both have hungry _mouths_ for eating candyfloss once the deception is complete).
column9: 5) [[Yasser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yasser)] 19-11-2008(12): A cowboy (here represented by a "top hat" revealing only his "mouth") looks always **tall** against a ninja wrapped up in his "hood" that reveals only his "mouth".

column3: _Tall children_ **receive** more attention. _Tall children_ grow up to make better wide **receivers**. Take your pick, depending on whether you prefer child psychology or American football. At any rate, be sure you have some particular _tall child_ in mind, someone who really was outstanding and always attracting attention, because he or she will come in handy in the next two frames.
column5: 1) [[Ramchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ramchip)] 22-1-2007(138): In basketball however, tall children **receive** all the attention.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 30-11-2007(87): _Tall children_ **receive** all the attention. They also make great **receive** rs in football… this kanji also means 'catch' (therefore a football **receive** r is a great image).
column7: 3) [[Dragonslayer131](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dragonslayer131)] 19-11-2009(31): Kinda weird but I remember the weird ones best: A giant MOUTH wearing a TOPHAT **RECEIVE** S its next victim to munch on. This time its a small CHILD whimpering under the figure on the floor, scared of what is to come.
column8: 4) [[Chaze](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Chaze)] 11-5-2010(21): A word of warning: With Heisig's story I keep associating this with "attention"! I use something closer tied to the word **receive** : Imagine a bunch of kids finding an old radio. It's antenna is broken, so the _tallest_ _kid_ has to hold it up, and becomes the designated **receiver**.
column9: 5) [[cefreddffo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cefreddffo)] 15-10-2009(13): Usually in yaoi couples the short guy is the one who "receives". But here we see how the **tall boy** is _receiving_ and he _enjoys it_ ( 享楽する ）. RTK2: キョウ 享楽主義 きょうらくしゅぎ(hedonism).

column3: **Cram schools** are after-hours educational institutions where kids can do concentrated preparing for their coming entrance examinations or drill what they missed during regular class hours. The exception are the _tall children_ who are out on the school _grounds_ practicing sports, and the _fat_ ones who are out there burning off calories. So this character depicts those who do NOT go to the **cram schools** , rather than those who do.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 12-1-2007(286): Welcome to our **cram school** : you will _receive_ a _rounded_ education on our _grounds_.
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 6-11-2007(71): "You can _receive_ a well- _rounded_ education if you study at our **cram school** " says the advertisement. "Just come to our school _grounds_ and check it out yourself!".
column7: 3) [[trurlo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/trurlo)] 6-1-2010(20): In **cram schools** _tall_ kids treat the _round_ ones like _dirt_.
column8: 4) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 18-9-2007(16): _Tall children_ who are well _round_ ed play on the _ground_ s and go to **cram school**.
column9: 5) [[Amhran](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Amhran)] 28-5-2009(9): Tall and Round kids go to **Cram School** on Saturday. I use Saturday instead of ground in this one since it is the first part of 土曜日 【どようび】.

column3: The _tall_ and _fat children_ from the last frame are here cast into a cauldron over an _oven flame_ until they have sufficiently **mellowed** that they can return to the normal life of a student.
column5: 1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 28-11-2007(162): Imagine _tall children_ sitting _round_ the _fire_ toasting marsh- **mellow** s.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 4-12-2007(107): The cram school (309) tortures its students - especially the _tall_ and _fat_ ones who need to grow up - over a fire until they **mellow**. (Note that here the keyword 'mellow' only means to mature, ripen, or acquire skill, not the colloquial meaning of 'chill out').
column7: 3) [[metacall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/metacall)] 27-12-2007(30): **Mello** , from Death Note, was the more _fiery_ student at the [cram school](../v4/309.html) (#309 塾)-like orphanage. He _receive_ d a well _round_ ed education there, in order to succeed L.
column8: 4) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 25-10-2007(22): Even if **mellow** , shy children _receive_ a well- _rounded_ education, they too will have a chance to _burn_ brightly and succeed.
column9: 5) [[JohtoKen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/JohtoKen)] 3-11-2008(15): Thank goodness, the _cram school's_ on fire. Life is all **mellow** and stress-free once again, now that the stress of cram school is over with.

column3: Think of all the **pavilions** at County Fairs or World Expos you have wandered into or seen advertised in the media, and you will no doubt see rising up among them the towering _tall crowned nail_ (the _crown_ being a revolving restaurant) - that architectural monstrosity that has become a symbol of science and technology at such events.
column5: 1) [[Henke](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Henke)] 15-10-2007(236): The _tall_ est **Pavilion** _crowns_ the _street_.
column6: 2) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 13-6-2007(143): The Pavillion on crown street is the tallest I have ever seen.
column7: 3) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 21-8-2006(44): The upper **pavilion** of Tokyo Tower is very _tall_. Godzilla attacks Tokyo Tower, wears the upper **pavilion** of Tokyo Tower as a _crown_ , and then uses the rest of the tower as a spike to skewer some other monster. Avoid [pagoda](../v4/254.html) (#254 塔): pagodas are for fitting flowers above the ground, **pavilion** s are from Tokyo Tower to wear as a crown.
column8: 4) [[yLaguardia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yLaguardia)] 26-10-2012(16): The king's **PAVILION** is easy to notice. It's the _TALL_ one with a _CROWN_ **nailed** at the entrance…
column9: 5) [[vinniram](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vinniram)] 9-4-2010(9): The _tall_ **PAVILION** _crowns_ the _street_.

column3: When we think of a **capital**  city today we think of _tall_  skyscrapers dwarfing the endless swarms of _little_  folk scurrying here and there about their business.
column5: 1) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 21-9-2006(243): Tokyo, **capital** of Japan: _tall_ buildings, _small_ people (compared to the buildings).
column6: 2) [[Cirion](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cirion)] 20-7-2008(69): The **capital** is where the powerful act formal wearing _top hats_ , open their _mouth_ s, and get _little_ done.
column7: 3) [[ibardell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ibardell)] 27-7-2007(17): Both the tall and the small are found in the **capital**.
column8: 4) [[WithLoveFromExIA](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/WithLoveFromExIA)] 24-7-2008(7): The **capital** letter in a word is the _tall_ one, the one that's higher then the other _little_ letters.
column9: 5) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 29-8-2009(6): Kyoto ( 京都 ), the old **capital** : _tall_ pagodas, _small_ town mentality.

column3: Since few things are as **refreshing** on a warm day as a cool shower (the _water_ ), here we picture an entire _capital_ city treating itself to one, and in full view of everyone.
column5: 1) [[aboros](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aboros)] 13-10-2006(160): When you're a tourist in the _capital_ during the heat of summer, finding a _water_ fountain is oh, so **refreshing**.
column6: 2) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 11-2-2008(42): The water from the capital of Japan, Tokyo, is so **refreshing**!
column7: 3) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 1-7-2008(32): Imagine a British guy praising his drink. "This _water_ is absolutely _Capital_! .. How **refreshing**!" NOTE: This isn't intended to be disrespectful.
column8: 4) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 11-1-2008(26): It is a well known fact that the most **refreshing** _water_ of a country can be found in the _capital_.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 13-6-2008(11): This means **REFRESHING** and COOL (such as temperature). STORY: During those hot summers in the CAPITAL of Japan (Tokyo) WATER from the sky (rain) can be **REFRESHING** and COOL despite getting soaked.

column3: **Scenery** is depicted as a _sun_ rising over a _capital_  city, which is a bit of natural **scenery**  the city dwellers themselves rarely get to see!
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 14-1-2006(227): Imaging the sun rising over the capital–classic postcard **scenery**.
column6: 2) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 12-3-2009(33): Anyone who's been to Kyoto doesn't need to think too deeply into this Kanji! Imagine a _sunny_ day in the old _capital_ , and there's no better **scenery**.
column7: 3) [[Aouwra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aouwra)] 6-11-2007(11): There's no **scenery** quite so nice as the sun setting over China's ancient _capital_ , the forbidden city.
column8: 4) [[Akeiko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Akeiko)] 1-2-2011(5): The _sun_ shining _over the capital_ is a nice **scenery** indeed.
column9: 5) [[Gibbun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Gibbun)] 7-7-2012(4): When the SUN rises over the CAPITAL, the **SCENERY** is just amazing.

column3: The **whale** swallows a whole school of fish, who turn their new abode into a proper little _fish-capital_.
column5: 1) [[tanaquil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tanaquil)] 25-4-2007(234): If _fish_ were cities, the **whale** would surely be the _capital_.
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 25-10-2007(29): When the _whale_ was first discovered it was the biggest _fish_ people had ever seen. Stories exaggerated its size - people said it was as big as the entire _capital_ city!
column7: 3) [[Dakoina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dakoina)] 8-1-2009(20): When you're saying a **whale** is just a _fish_ , you're making a _capital_ mistake!
column8: 4) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 3-12-2007(11): Remember when a **whale** swam up the Thames. Everyone thought there was a big _fish_ in the _capital_ , but it was really a **whale**.
column9: 5) [[mtheory7](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mtheory7)] 1-1-2010(10): A **whale** is like a [fish](../v4/171.html) (#171 魚) except it is as big as the [capital](../v4/312.html) (#312 京).

column3: A _lidded crock_ with an _umbrella_ overhead gives us a mixture of the modern and the nostalgic in this design for a **cottage**.
column5: 1) [[ibardell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ibardell)] 27-7-2007(260): The **cottage** is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof, soil for the floor and room for only one mouth.
column6: 2) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 13-11-2006(57): Picture a _lidded crock_ full of tasty **cottage** cheese… yum! Now all we need is an _umbrella_ over it to protect the **cottage** cheese from the sun.
column7: 3) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 15-9-2007(25): The homeless man stuck an _umbrella_ over his _lidded crock_ in the country side and declared it his **cottage**. It looks just like a shack (しゃ) though! Under local government legislation, after 7 years, the "cottage" and land were his.
column8: 4) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 18-6-2009(18): I call it my **cottage** , but it's really just an _umbrella_ over a _dirty hole_ in the ground.
column9: 5) [[elitentity](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elitentity)] 31-1-2006(14): To further Heisig's explanation, imagine a **cottage** made out of a giant lidded crock and an umbrella. The mouth can also represent a door.

column3: Look more closely at your _lidded crock_ and you will see little ruler marks along its bottom edge. This is so you can use it to calculate the **circumference** of your _motorcycle helmet_ : just begin at a fixed point and turn the _lidded crock_ around and around, keeping it flush against the side of the _helmet_ , until you come back to your starting point. If you kept track of how many turns and part-turns your _lidded crock_ made, you now know the **circumference**.
column4: * As a primitive, this character can take the added significance of a _lap_.
column5: 1) [[hanako1975](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hanako1975)] 8-1-2008(188): If my LIDDED CROCK has the same **CIRCUMFERENCE** as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET.
column6: 2) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 3-4-2009(47): When the _ground_ has an _opening_ (a hole), you need to cover the entire **circumference** or you will fall in.
column7: 3) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 20-8-2007(36): You're at a motorcycle store looking to buy a helmet. The only way to check the **circumference** of your head is to put increasingly larger lidded crocks on your head until one slips on just right. Now you know what size helmet to buy.
column8: 4) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 10-11-2008(16): The **CIRCUMFERENCE** of the Earth's soil _surface_ ( 土 ) has been the _same_ ( 同 ) for a long time.
column9: 5) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 29-12-2007(15): There's a _hole_ (mouth) in the _ground_ , so the men at work have put a _barrier tape_ (hood) forming a circunference, to prevent people from falling into it.

column3: Picture a circular _road_ with 7 markers on it, one for each day of the **week**. When you have walked one complete _lap_ on this _road_ , you shall have completed one **week**.
column5: 1) [[jschekkerman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jschekkerman)] 5-5-2007(183): Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a **week** to travel the circumference of the earth.
column6: 2) [[axelb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/axelb)] 11-4-2009(100): Actually the **week** is like a never ending _road_ where we travel in a circle through the same seven days again and again, the _circumference_ is always the same. [circumference](../v4/317.html) (#317 周) also means circuit or lap, so that also makes think about the rotations of the moon, sun and the earth – all important for measuring all kinds of time periods.
column7: 3) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 1-6-2008(21): This city is so big, it takes a **week** to travel around its _circumference_ by _road_.
column8: 4) [[activeaero](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/activeaero)] 18-8-2008(13): It takes a **WEEK** to walk the "circumference" of this "road".
column9: 5) [[johngwk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johngwk)] 9-2-2011(6): The _circumference_ of Japan would take at least a **week** on the _road_ to navigate.

column3: The shape of this kanji, slightly differing from that for _soil_ by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted warrior standing at attention. When feudalism collapsed, these warriors became Japan's **gentlemen**.
column4: * The primitive meaning reverts to the more colorful image of the _samurai_ , Japan's warrior class.
column5: 1) [[gsantise](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gsantise)] 27-8-2007(132): What a handsome **gentleman**. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He's like a modern samurai!
column6: 2) [[mightymiff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mightymiff)] 17-7-2009(49): A **gentleman** has broad shoulders and doesn't soil himself.
column7: 3) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 16-3-2008(22): The **gentleman** stretches his arms wide to balance so he doesn't fall onto the ground and get mixed up in it.
column8: 4) [[AdamLeliel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AdamLeliel)] 26-7-2008(10): Gentlemen are the opposite of dirty.
column9: 5) [[Yasser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yasser)] 20-11-2008(8): A samurai **gentleman** starts a duel with open arms to show he has no personal grudges against the challenger.

column3: Here we see a _samurai_ standing on a street with an open _mouth_ , which people walk up to and look down deep inside of for **good luck**.
column4: * As a primitive, we shall take this shape to mean an _aerosol can_ , from the _mouth_ and the very tightly-fitting _lid_ (note how it differs here from the _lidded crock_ ).
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 6-2-2007(310): The _samurai_ 's wife gives him a (uhum) before battle for **good luck**.
column6: 2) [[jonobugs](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonobugs)] 27-5-2008(117): A true samurai gentleman will always mouth, " **Good luck** " to his opponents before a match.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 8-10-2007(43): A gentleman going into a hole = **good luck**. Think about it. (nudge, nudge, wink, wink).
column8: 4) [[Ji_suss](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ji_suss)] 26-8-2008(22): From the cow's mouth came a revelation. From the samurai's mouth comes just "Good Luck!".
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-8-2007(17): Tom Cruise - the best samurai evar - with a **shoop da woop** mouth saying "GOOD LUCK" just like that robot voice does before every mission on Star Fox 64. Then of course he fires his lazer.

column5: 1) [[bendyarm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bendyarm)] 13-4-2011(160): The image is a **robust** green bulging-muscle cartoon turtle. A TMNT with hachimaki. _turtle_ - _samurai_.
column6: 2) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 25-4-2008(69): The Teenage Mutant Ninja _Turtles_ are **robust** _gentlemen_ aren't they?
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 8-10-2007(44): _Turtle_ samurai are more **robust** than regular samurai, because of their shells. (I'm trying to avoid TMNT here, because I tend to get the order of the primitives wrong. It's TURTLE SAMURAI, not Ninga Turtles).
column8: 4) [[zodiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zodiac)] 24-10-2008(19): The back of a samurai is very **robust**.
column9: 5) [[Cirion](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cirion)] 20-7-2008(13): A _hairy leg_ is a good sign that a _gentleman_ (or _samurai_ ) is **robust** with plenty of testosterone.

column3: The **villa** pictured here is filled with exotic _flowers_ at every turn, and has a pair of _turtle-samurai_ standing before its gates.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 12-1-2007(122): A **villa** is fancier (decorated with _flowers_ ) and more _robust_ than the average.
column6: 2) [[eieneverafter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eieneverafter)] 19-2-2008(86): The teenage mutant samurai turtles live in a **villa** with flowers on the roof so that the neighbours don't get suspicious.
column7: 3) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 26-4-2008(43): The **villa** was full of many gardens of _flowers_ , and was guarded by a _robust_ _samurai_ with his _turtle_ -shell shield.
column8: 4) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 6-12-2007(21): The beautiful _flowers_ make the **VILLA** look quaint and beautiful, but the _robust_ samurais guarding it reminds you that this kanji also means "feudal manor.".
column9: 5) [[GenPDP7](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GenPDP7)] 20-12-2007(13): The wealthy owners of the **villa** only plant robust flowers.

column3: A _samurai_ , out of a job, is going door-to-door **selling** little windup _crowns_ with _human legs_ that run around on the floor looking like headless monarchs.
column5: 1) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 4-4-2008(101): The _samurai_ happened to find an extra large _crown_ that he wore as a belt on his waist, just above his _legs_. I wonder if he will **sell** it to me?
column6: 2) [[Yasser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yasser)] 20-11-2008(91): A "samurai" will never **sell** his "crown" (king), even it meant having both his "human legs" chopped off!
column7: 3) [[gwadonna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gwadonna)] 9-8-2008(47): The victorious samurai **sell** s crowns and human legs.
column8: 4) [[RachelleUdell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RachelleUdell)] 10-7-2008(40): The _SAMURAI_ was down to his last _CROWN_ , so he hiked up his kimono to show off his shapely _LEGS_ in an attempt to **sell** himself!
column9: 5) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 10-9-2009(19): A samurai **sell** s small _Miss World_ statutes. ( _Miss World_ = _crown_ / _mini skirt_ \+ _long human legs_ , this combination appears several times).

column3: The _child_ in the little red _schoolhouse_ is there for one reason only: to **study**. Anyone who has gone through the schooling system knows well enough that **study** is one thing and _learning_ quite another again. In the kanji, too, the character for _learning  _(Frame 616) has nothing to do with the _schoolhouse_.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 12-1-2007(78): In the _school house_ there are _kids_ always **studying**. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字 ).
column6: 2) [[gwadonna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gwadonna)] 9-8-2008(51): Children in schoolhouses are there to **study** , nothing else!!!
column7: 3) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 5-5-2007(10): Imagine a schoolhouse full of thousands of children in a deadly trance **study** ing japanese style…repetition.
column8: 4) [[munkiipoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munkiipoo)] 1-10-2010(7): A child in a schoolhouse **study** ing. His brain is sparkling with knowledge!
column9: 5) [[kanjidummy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjidummy)] 16-8-2010(4): A _school house_ is a place for a _child_ to **study**.

column3: The idea of **memorizing** things is easily related to the _schoolhouse_ , and since we have been at it for more than a hundred pages in this book, the idea that **memorizing** involves _seeing_ things that are not really there should make it easy to put the two elements together.
column5: 1) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 25-4-2008(180): In a _schoolhouse_ in class: 1) you _see_ something on the blackboard, then 2) you **memorize** it.
column6: 2) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 1-7-2008(82): You'll never **memorize** all the kanji by _seeing_ them in a _school house_. You need Heisig and RtK!
column7: 3) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 20-8-2007(21): Imagine you had the ability to speed read like those people who claim they can read an entire book in like 10 minutes. Then everything you see in the schoolhouse can be **memorize** d instantly - you'll never have to take notes again!
column8: 4) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 2-2-2009(15): When you are in the _schoolhouse_ you must **memorise** what you _see_.
column9: 5) [[Cirion](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cirion)] 20-7-2008(12): In the Heisig _School_ of learning Kanji we **memorize** how to write the kanji by _seeing_ a story in our minds.

column3: The botanical connotations of the word **flourish** (to bud and burst into bloom, much as a _tree_ does) are part of the ideal of the _schoolhouse_ as well.
column5: 1) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 21-2-2007(151): The TREES **FLOURISH** in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there's no room for the students any more.
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 11-3-2008(95): Students are like young trees. They tend to **flourish** in the schoolhouse.
column7: 3) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 24-11-2011(53): Within the _schoolhouse_ , the _tree_ of knowledge does **flourish**.
column8: 4) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 1-11-2007(31): Knowledge can only truly **flourish** when it is taught openly and freely in the _schoolhouse_ , and not guarded and kept secret like the forbidden _tree_ of knowledge.
column9: 5) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 2-7-2008(30): This is a very special _schoolhouse_ , were _trees_ are taught how to **FLOURISH**. It is important to imagine the image of _trees_ sitting down and taking classes on **FLOURISH** ING in a _schoolhouse_. You could even use an actual _schoolhouse_ to make your mental image more realistic. You would even imagine the graduation ceremony of a class of sakura flowering all at the same time while holding their diplomas.

column3: The sage talks rapidly with his _tongue wagging in his mouth_ , while the _brush_ of the scribe runs apace to **write** down the master 'swords.
column5: 1) [[jinka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jinka)] 27-4-2006(213): Make sure you practice **writing** kanji with a _brush_ every _day_ before the _sun_ goes down.
column6: 2) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 28-10-2007(36): The calligrapher had a peculiar habit: when using her _brush_ to **write** , she would stick out her _tongue_ , just slightly.
column7: 3) [[zer0range](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zer0range)] 22-3-2009(30): With a brush, it takes all day to **write** anything.
column8: 4) [[yawfosu88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yawfosu88)] 30-6-2007(25): Imagine dipping a _brush_ into an inkwell full of the _sun_ , so that what you **write** can be seen at any time of day.
column9: 5) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 10-7-2006(11): Rita Skeeter, from Harry Potter, has a magic brush that **write** s anything that comes from the tongue wagging in her mouth.

column3: Seeing the tiny boats of poor mortals tossed about in a stormy sea like so many corks, the All-Merciful took its _brush_ and drew little inlets of _water_ where the hapless creatures might seek shelter. And so it is that we have **havens**.
column5: 1) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 13-10-2007(215): A brush laying in dirty water is a **haven** for bacteria.
column6: 2) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 4-7-2008(78): The **haven** for a BRUSH is in WATER.. Otherwise they get dry and withered and cant be used?!
column7: 3) [[elitentity](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elitentity)] 31-1-2006(27): A toothbrush with some water moisture kept in a nice temperature is a **haven** for germs.
column8: 4) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 24-4-2008(26): With his _brush_ , Link draws a route over the _water_ to a safe **haven**. (phantom hourglass).
column9: 5) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 9-10-2007(16): A **haven** is somewhere you can pull your boat out of the _water_ and use a _brush_ to repaint it.

column3: When it is time to **breed** new cattle, the bull is usually willing but the _cow_ is often not. Thus the _taskmaster_ to the right forces the _cow_ into a compromising position, so to speak, so that she and her mate can **breed**.
column5: 1) [[roderik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/roderik)] 21-6-2008(158): Imagine a _taskmaster_ giving a _cow_ the command to "start **breed** ing, and start doing it now!", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to **breed** with. Hence, you see the _taskmaster_ running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the _cow_.
column6: 2) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 26-12-2007(78): Hint: This is the kanji from which _taskmaster_ is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with **breed** , and a lot to do with **pastures** and **shepherds** (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don't differenciate between animals). Think of a _cowboy_ (taskmaster) who brings his _cows_ to the **pasture**.
column7: 3) [[laner36](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laner36)] 19-7-2007(35): I think of Hitler for the taskmaster primitive. This has worked really well. Hitler can be the real person (and works well for kanji such as 激 [violent](../v4/497.html) (#497 激)). Or it can be more comical, such as a homosexual man dressed as Hitler for a costume party. As in, a homosexual Hitler has no hope of **breed** ing. (Here you imagine him wearing leather bondage bands). *Also, the taskmaster primitive seems to generally be on the right side of kanji in this book.
column8: 4) [[Hashiriya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hashiriya)] 22-12-2012(32): Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to "start **breed** ing, and start doing it now!", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to **breed** with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow.
column9: 5) [[mrgrimm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mrgrimm)] 30-9-2009(11): The _cow_ is forced by the _taskmaster_ to **breed**.

column3: The special _craft_ of successful _taskmasters_ is their ability to remain constantly on the **aggressive** , never allowing their underlings a moment to ponder a counter- **aggression** of their own.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 24-2-2008(140): **AGGRESSION** is a well-honed _craft_ for any decent _taskmaster_.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 17-4-2007(100): **Aggression** is the _craft_ of a good _dominatrix_.
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 6-10-2008(54): If the _task master_ hits you with an _I-beam_ … I'd say that's **aggression**!
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-8-2007(25): The special _craft_ on which _Hitler_ relies is AGRESSION. Without it, they never would have taken Poland, France, etc.
column9: 5) [[erlog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erlog)] 14-7-2008(21): **Aggression** is the craft of the taskmaster.

column3: The _taskmaster_ is acknowledging the **failure** of a _clam_ to make the grade in some marine school or other.
column5: 1) [[akira](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akira)] 16-4-2007(145): If you end up in **failure** , you give money to the taskmaster to train you.
column6: 2) [[eltjopoort](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eltjopoort)] 28-5-2008(142): The _shell_ who was defeated before ([defeat](../v4/63.html) (#63 負)) is being chastised by the _taskmaster_ for his **failure** to win.
column7: 3) [[Jupiter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jupiter)] 3-12-2008(60): **Failure** occurs if you let money become your taskmaster.
column8: 4) [[annabel398](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/annabel398)] 8-9-2008(24): Remember the TASKMASTER who was trying to breed a cow? With a LOBSTER in the same position, it was a terrible **FAILURE**.
column9: 5) [[alkulp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alkulp)] 3-12-2007(15): **FAILURE** to **pay** the **taskmaster** will result in **FAILURE**!

column3: English counts thin, flat objects, like bed linen and paper, in **sheets**. The kanji does this with a _taskmaster_ whipping a _tree_ into producing **sheets** against its will.
column5: 1) [[applesuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/applesuki)] 14-12-2006(142): The _taskmaster_ is a strict bathroom monitor who hands out only one **sheet of** really rough, splintery toilet paper per person. You can see the _wood_ fibers.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 6-12-2007(60): This _taskmaster_ is the bathroom nazi: he counts how many **sheets of** toilet paper and tissue you use, and then tells you what % of a tree you just killed.
column7: 3) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 14-10-2007(53): The mean _taskmaster_ declared, "You **sheet** on my _tree,_ I keel you.".
column8: 4) [[Wahlin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wahlin)] 13-9-2006(40): The taskmaster whips sheets of paper off the tree.
column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 16-7-2008(24): The poor _trees_ are processed by the _taskmasters_ of industry into **sheets of** paper.

column3: Call it fate or providence or plain old Lady Luck, **happenstance** is the _oldest taskmaster_ we know. It nearly always has its way.
column5: 1) [[Deborah](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Deborah)] 27-10-2007(127): An _OLD TASKMASTER_ is no **happenstance** (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.
column6: 2) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 23-7-2007(51): Need to disambiguate from [enemy](../v4/443.html) (#443 敵) as it's easy to mix up **antique** and **old** here. Let's think of an accidental president – he is an **old** **taskmaster** who has managed to win the election by **happenstance** .
column7: 3) [[binky](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/binky)] 29-7-2009(30): Only an old taskmaster uses a stupid word like "happenstance" instead of the many less pretentious synonyms for luck or chance.
column8: 4) [[dogray77](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dogray77)] 22-1-2008(30): It's not just a **happenstance** that the taskmaster looks old before his time.
column9: 5) [[meredithcat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meredithcat)] 4-4-2010(18): I recently ran into my _old taskmaster_ purely by **happenstance**.

column3: Standing in **awe** of someone, you get self-conscious and may try to speak in _flowery phrases_ out of veneration or fear. The _taskmaster_ at the right is drilling you in the practice of your  "honorifics."
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 30-10-2011(155): The _flowery phrases_ of **keigo** ( 敬語 ) with which you must address the _schoolmaster_.
column6: 2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 14-6-2008(75): 敬 【けい】 (n) reverence, respect. 敬語 【けいご】 (n) honorific, term of respect, (P) STORY: The TASKMASTER demands RESPECT. If you don't talk to him in HONORIFICS and FLOWERY PHRASES you will be sorry.
column7: 3) [[Lowther](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lowther)] 19-2-2008(52): Hitler's flowery phrases held the nation in **awe**.
column8: 4) [[Beartron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Beartron)] 30-1-2009(27): In Japan, the culture says that one should in be **awe** of one's TASKMASTER, thus we are expected to use FLOWERY PHRASES when standing before them.
column9: 5) [[eightbitbanzai](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eightbitbanzai)] 2-2-2007(21): If you're a girl you can try to woo your _taskmaster_ with _flower_ y _phrases_ to get an **awe** some grade.

column3: Of all the things we can do with our _mouths_ , speech is the one that requires the greatest distinctness and clarity. Hence the kanji for **say** has four little sound-waves, indicating the complexity of the achievement.
column4: * This kanji, which appears often as a primitive, can mean _saying_ , _speech_ , or _words_ , depending on which is most useful.
column5: 1) [[jinka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jinka)] 28-4-2006(109): A pictogram of someone **saying** a _four_ letter word from their _mouth_ after the censors have gotten a hold of it.
column6: 2) [[sethg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethg)] 4-2-2009(68): This is simple a pictogram of a _mouth_ **SAY** ing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.
column7: 3) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 4-11-2005(22): This is such a hard one for me to remember in stories so I use Socrates to personify **say** since he is an orator. Just make Socrates the subject of your stories and whenever Socrates shows up you'll know this character should be written. Just picture him in his toga with a hand up in the air looking philisophical. You can try some other well spoken individual as long as they bring to mind speech, words, or **say**.
column8: 4) [[matstc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matstc)] 9-6-2008(18): Before you **say** something in chinese, make sure you master the _4 tones_ that can come out of your _mouth_ so that you don't embarrass yourself.
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 20-1-2008(7): Facciamo **quattro chiacchere..**.

column3: Here you have a perfect example of how an apparently impossible snarl of strokes becomes a snap to learn once you know its elements. The idea of being **admonished** for something already sets up a superior-inferior relationship between you and the person you are supposed to stand in _awe_ of. While you are restricted to answering in honorifics, the superior can use straightforward and ordinary _words_.
column5: 1) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 13-8-2007(232): To **admonish** is to enforce _awe_ by means of _words_.
column6: 2) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 22-11-2007(105): Watch in _awe_ as mom **admonish** es the rude clerk with _words_ that you've never heard her use before.
column7: 3) [[caeliean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/caeliean)] 10-7-2008(82): Japanese police officers prefer to **admonish** perpetrators by _awe_ ing them with their _words_. You've never had a talking down to, until you've been a Japanese high school student caught littering in a small Japanese town. Just imagine the talking to that kid would get! Incidentally, this kanji is the first kanji in the word for police.
column8: 4) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 12-10-2009(27): I will now **admonish** every person here who used WORD as a keyword in this story. There is no WORD ( 語 ) in this kanji! I know Heisig himself teaches it that way. Doesn't make it right, does it? This is about _SAY_ ing something that inspires _AWE_. You will regret it when you get to [word](../v4/347.html) (#347 語)! ,)… 警察 [けいさつ] [、警告](midori://search?text=、警告) [けいこく] warning.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-8-2007(16): To **ADMONISH** is to simply _say & a lot of _awe*ful words (excuse the liberties taken with spelling).

column3: _Words_ and a meter's _needle_ combine to form the sense of **plot** : to talk over plans and to calculate a course of action.
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 12-6-2006(222): A **plot** is a summary of a book that can be given in _ten_ _words_.
column6: 2) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 28-10-2007(124): _Say-ten_ 's (satan's) evil **plot**.
