column7: 3) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 19-7-2008(110): This does NOT mean a "summary of a book." It means plan, project, or to measure. STORY: A TEN WORD PLAN is a very efficient PLAN.
column8: 4) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 17-10-2006(55): It took only the _words_ of _ten_ men to **plot** the downfall of Caesar.
column9: 5) [[diracbracket](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/diracbracket)] 30-3-2011(33): I have only _ten words_ to say about this kanji: "Remember, remember the fifth of November, gunpowder treason and **plot** ".

column3: Think of **elucidating** as presenting something in _whole words_ , as distinct from broken fragmented sentences.
column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 28-7-2009(63): _Words_ that tell you the results of the _whole_ story really **elucidate**.
column6: 2) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 10-8-2009(27): **Elucidate** me. Tell me, in your own _words_ , the _whole_ story.
column7: 3) [[Goldom](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Goldom)] 11-8-2011(7): Imagine a grumpy old guy wishing those darn kids would **elucidate** their texting **discussions** on their _cellphones_ by writing in _whole_ _words_. Of course, the kids don't even know what " **elucidate** " means…
column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(4): The _whole words_ of the trendy name of the new Chinese dating service, **elucidate**.com, are 'electronic lucky dating service company'.
column9: 5) [[oharawinter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oharawinter)] 15-7-2012(3): _Saying_ the _whole_ thing should **elucidate** it for me…

column3: Although we did not make note of it at the time, the kanji for _dog_ is also a low-grade term for a spy. And later (Frame 1517) we will meet another association of criminals with _dogs_. The **prison** here depicts a _pack of wild dogs_ (the long-timers and hardened criminals) into which the poor little c _hihuahua_ (first offender) has been cast. The only thing he has to protect himself against the pack are his shrill and frightened _words_.
column5: 1) [[f98plow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/f98plow)] 25-5-2007(226): The wild dog family visits their cousin in **prison**. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 13-12-2007(41): The only thing keeping the new _chihuahua_ inmate from being 'initiated' by the _pack of wild dogs_ were his quick _words_ in **prison**.
column7: 3) [[scuda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scuda)] 6-11-2008(34): **Prison** is a dog-say-dog world.
column8: 4) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 5-7-2008(20): **PRISON** is a place where WILD DOGS SAY "DOG!!" to eachother and fight like animals.
column9: 5) [[Erubey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Erubey)] 19-1-2008(13): Where men talk like beasts and fight like dogs.

column3: After completing the first draft, you **revise** it by _nailing_ down your _words_ and  "hammering" them into shape.
column5: 1) [[mattoc_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattoc_g)] 2-4-2006(242): **Revise** , **revise** and **revise** until you have all the words nailed down.
column6: 2) [[Hinode](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hinode)] 27-12-2008(71): Remember how Martin Luther **revised** the _words_ of the catholic church and _nailed_ his 95 Theses at the door of the church in Wittenberg?
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 23-10-2006(26): The signmaker first carves all of his _words_. He then arranges them. But he will only _nail_ them into place (thus making them final) when he has had the chance to sufficiently **revise** the message.
column8: 4) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 4-4-2008(19): You must **revise** your speech until you've _nail_ ed it.
column9: 5) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 13-6-2008(13): Keep **revising** your words until you have what you want to _say_ really _nailed_ down.

column3: The _words_ of this **obituary** work like a _magic wand_ , conjuring up the desceased.
column5: 1) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 23-3-2010(40): **Obituary**. As a famous man lay dying, the media were already preparing the _words_ of his **obituary** until a magician, with a wave of his _wand_ , restored the man back to health.
column6: 2) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 24-3-2011(25): In the Harry Potter world, **obituary** 's are magical. If you wave your wand over them you can hear the person's last words. Creepy!
column7: 3) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 11-1-2010(10): **obituary** : Harry Potter's **obituary** was just a few _words_ long: 'Guy who killed Voldemort'. He was buried with his favourite _magic wand_ that he used to perform all of his _augury_.
column8: 4) [[gyouza](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gyouza)] 28-12-2010(3): If you know how people _talked_ about someone before his death, and then read the _words_ in his **obituary** , it seems as if by means of a _magic wand_ their opinion of this person has changed over night.
column9: 5) [[manubear](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/manubear)] 10-8-2012(2): Harry Potter can bring people back from the dead by reading the _words_ on an **obituary** while waving his _magic wand_ ( 訃報 ).

column3: _Words_ spoken to **chastise** us stick to us like _glue_ in a way no other _words_ can.
column5: 1) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 13-6-2007(155): I said some bad words, and my mother **chastise** d me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 18-3-2007(110): In Colonial New England, people who committed adultery had _words_ _glued_ to them. A famous example is the "A" worn by Hester Prynn for committing adultery (i.e., not being chaste). In this way, _words_ _glued_ to you are supposed to **chastise** you and prevent further breaches of chastity.
column7: 3) [[NickCooper](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NickCooper)] 27-7-2008(50): If you **chastise** someone correctly the words will stick like glue.
column8: 4) [[mcbainpc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcbainpc)] 25-6-2008(42): I said some bad _words_ and my mom _glue_ d my mouth shut to **chastise** me.
column9: 5) [[stephjapan2004](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephjapan2004)] 17-10-2007(21): Chastising _words_ _stick_ to your mind.

column3: The personalism connoted by the word **instruction** , as opposed to "teaching" or "discipline," suits the picture here of _words_ guiding one's progress like the gentle flowing of a _stream_. Even the etymology of the word **instruction** suggests the sense of  "pouring into".
column5: 1) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 2-3-2008(155): The best type of Japanese **INSTRUCTION** is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the _stream_ of _words_ that surrounds you every day.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 10-11-2008(87): Listen carefully to the _words_ of **instruction** before you try swimming in the _river_.
column7: 3) [[markjohnquinn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/markjohnquinn)] 6-11-2007(39): The best teachers and those we remember most are those that are most patient with us, their WORDS as gentle as a STREAM.
column8: 4) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 1-1-2007(35): (technical) A _stream_ of _words_ (byte pairs) carries assembly **instructions** that are executed upon reception.
column9: 5) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 6-9-2006(23): This is the first half of the kanji combination with [obey](../v4/129.html) (#129 順). Watch at the person's _words_ , their **instructions** , turn into a _stream_ which then can be put into the subjects head for them to [obey](../v4/129.html) (#129 順).

column3: The **imperial edict** , spoken with the force of unquestionable law, is made up of _words_ intended to _seduce_ the masses - be it through fear or respect - to follow obediently.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 9-2-2006(207): The mnemonic "words to seduce the masses" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the **imperial edict** to the masses, thus "seducing" the masses.
column6: 2) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 12-8-2008(56): The emperor did not need an **imperial edict** , his _words_ were more than enough to _seduce_ Anakin to the dark side.
column7: 3) [[RachelleUdell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RachelleUdell)] 17-7-2008(31): The _WORDS_ of an **IMPERIAL EDICT** are meant to _SEDUCE_ the people and make them obey.
column8: 4) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 24-1-2008(19): Palpatine's **imperial edict** is a propaganda _speech_ to attempt to _seduce_ the masses to the Dark Side. (If you need extra help to remember the _seduce_ part, think about some sexy photos of Darth Vader being included in it as well. The resulting image should be seared into your mind forever.).
column9: 5) [[dusmar84](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dusmar84)] 30-11-2009(13): The Patriot Act is the modern day version of an **imperial edict**. It uses a lot of fancy _words_ to _seduce_ people into giving up their freedoms.

column3: A piece of writing that is pregnant with meaning and needs to be reread several times to be understood we refer to colloquially as " **packed**. " The character sees the _words_ as sealed tightly inside an _aerosol can_.
column5: 1) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 26-1-2007(533): WORDS of GOOD LUCK are **PACKED** into fortune cookies.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 25-10-2006(77): Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of _words_ and _aerosol cans_ and then makes sure the words get tightly **packed** inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!
column7: 3) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 5-7-2008(27): Words **packed** into an aerosol can: the tool of the graffiti artist.
column8: 4) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 21-4-2008(16): _Sayings_ of _good luck_ are **packed** into little things like fortune cookies.
column9: 5) [[alatown](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alatown)] 17-7-2009(11): Once the samauri had **packed** his things, his wife would say "Good Luck".

column3: That the _words_ of the _tongue_ should come to mean a **tale** is clear from the etymology: a **_tale_** is something  "talked," not something read from a book.
column5: 1) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 22-7-2007(178): **Tale** s are always spoken, not written, and because of this, _words_ fly out of your _tongue_ , rather than your pen.
column6: 2) [[Rivvie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rivvie)] 28-1-2008(55): **Tale** s are _spoken words_ , passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a _thousand mouths_.
column7: 3) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 17-2-2008(29): **Tale** s are words from the tongue.
column8: 4) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 5-7-2008(21): **Tale** s are Told from Tongues (TTT mnemonic).
column9: 5) [[BigAmish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BigAmish)] 2-8-2008(9): Beowulf is an epic **TALE** composed of _WORDS_ in a foreign _TONGUE_.

column3: Listening to the _words_ of poets **reciting** their poetry is like being transported for a moment into _eternity_ where the rules of everyday life have been suspended.
column5: 1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 3-11-2007(154): If you study some _words_ for a **recitation** , there is a good chance they will be stuck in your memory for all _eternity_.
column6: 2) [[cangy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cangy)] 1-4-2008(110): Listening to the _words_ in a **recitation** of Vogon poetry is worse than spending an _eternity_ in hell. [ **Note:** I assume those 2 reports are to warn against possible confusion with [poem](../v4/346.html) (#346 詩) but how can you confuse _Vogon poetry_ with an actual _poem_? Anyway, it's the next frame, so it should be easy to keep them straight… Or maybe there's a kanji for _Vogon_ in RTK3?].
column7: 3) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 17-1-2008(57): Don't confuse with [poem](../v4/346.html) (#346 詩). Focus on the re- part of re- citation: making a citation of _words_ over, and over, and over, and over, and over again, until _eternity_.
column8: 4) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 5-2-2008(15): [for catholics only:] During the **recitation** of the holy rosary, the _words_ feel like they will take an _eternity_ to say…it takes soooo long.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 14-10-2005(14): For me, the keyword suggests something not as pleasant as in James's Heisig story. In my mind, a **recitation** is when someone reads out loud something that they have read, without the slightest bit of improvisation or impersonation, in a very monotonous, and extremely dull manner. Hence, a **recitation** is a long-winded _speech_ that seems to go on for an _eternity_ (because it's so dull and you're so bored).

column3: Since silence is treasured so highly at a _Buddhist temple_ the _words_ spoken there must be well-chosen. Perhaps this is why the records of the monks often read to us like **poems**. Before going on, back up a frame and make sure you have kept **poem** and _recitation_ distinct in your mind.
column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 20-12-2006(188): A **poem** is a _temple_ of _words_.
column6: 2) [[kashikoi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kashikoi)] 14-1-2009(79): I'm saying this **poem** just for you, I built this temple from dirt and glue.
column7: 3) [[gsantise](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gsantise)] 30-9-2007(45): WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That's why most people will speak using a **poem** if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.
column8: 4) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 24-7-2008(21): A **poem** isn't made up of _words_ that come from nowhere, they are derived after deep meditation at your local _Buddhist Temple_!
column9: 5) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 14-1-2009(9): Reciting a good **poem** is like _saying_ a prayer in the _temple_ of language. 悪魔の詩 (Satanic verses). 英詩 (English poetry). 狂詩 (Kyoushi, Edo era humorous **poem** ). 詩を作る (compose a **poem** ). 詩才 (poetic genius). 詩想 (poetical imagination). 詩文 (poetry & prose). 詩的正義 (poetic justice).

column3: Whereas the character for _say_ focused on the actual talking, that for **words** stresses the fact that although it is _I_ who _say_ them, the **words** of a language are not my own. You can see the clear distinction between _I_ and **words** just by looking at the kanji.
column5: 1) [[rosie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rosie)] 28-7-2008(226): The simplest **word** to _say_ is _I_.
column6: 2) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 15-12-2009(43): Jesus said, "I am the **WORD**.".
column7: 3) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 8-8-2006(28): May I say a **word** about that?
column8: 4) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 15-2-2006(21): The rap group, the _Five_ _Mouths_ , always go around _saying_ "word".
column9: 5) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 9-12-2007(20): _I_ , the perceiving subject, need all _five senses_ to learn the **WORDS** and **language** of Japanese…. holistic learning, not just rote memory work!

column3: In the age of advertising, most _words_ we **read** are out to _sell_ some product or point of view.
column5: 1) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 10-11-2008(160): People will _say_ ( 言 ) almost anything to make a _sale_ ( 売 ), don't believe everything you **read** ( 読 ).
column6: 2) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 28-6-2009(84): **Read** the WORDS used to SELL things.
column7: 3) [[j0k0m0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/j0k0m0)] 22-2-2009(39): Extra! extra! **Read** all about it! words for sale here.
column8: 4) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 3-3-2009(24): Most of the _words_ that we **read** are meant to _sell_ something.
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 21-1-2008(23): I'm a freelance journalists, so the _words_ I _sell_ are the words you **read**.

column3: A complete **tune** is composed not only of a succession of notes but also of one _lap_ of the _words_ that go with it.
column5: 1) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 7-2-2009(220): To **tune** an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the _circumference_ , until you can clearly hear what's being _said_.
column6: 2) [[canji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/canji)] 24-8-2008(127): _words_ \+ _circumference_ The most catchy **tunes** are _words_ the go round and round the _circuference_ of your head and you can't get it out of your mind.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 9-10-2007(40): The _words_ to this catchy **tune** run around the _circumference_ of my head.
column8: 4) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 14-6-2008(36): This kanji also means "to investigate, check up, to search." STORY: You ever get a **TUNE** stuck in your head that someone was SPEAKING earlier in the day? It runs LAPS around your head and you cannot get relief until you 調べる the song online, download it, and listen t it.
column9: 5) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 18-2-2008(35): This is the song that never ends, yes it goes on and on my friends! Some people started singing it not knowing what it was, and they'll continue singing it forever just because this is the song that never ends… The words go around in a lap in this **tune** , in case you didn't notice…

column3: In almost every attempt to **discuss** an issue, the fervor of one's convictions comes to the surface and creates an _inflammation_ of _words_ (if you will, the  "cuss" in **discuss** ).
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 10-10-2007(218): Think of an online **discuss** ion group where misunderstanding someone's _words_ leads to _flaming_. An angry **discuss** ion = _inflamed_ _words_.
column6: 2) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 3-8-2008(104): Internet **discuss** ions often involve inflammatory words. Flame war!
column7: 3) [[Kieron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kieron)] 7-5-2007(10): **Discuss** ing politics on the Internet always leads to heated _words_ and _flame_ wars.
column8: 4) [[annabel398](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/annabel398)] 8-9-2008(7): When people **DISCUSS** politics, the things they SAY often shed more HEAT than LIGHT.
column9: 5) [[RachelleUdell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RachelleUdell)] 17-7-2008(6): I hate to **DISCUSS** religion or politics because people's _WORDS_ always become _INFLAMED_.

column3: The _words_ of the _young_ do not have legal validity unless backed up by "parental **consent**. "
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 19-2-2008(158): The _words_ of the very _young_ are useless without **CONSENT** from their elders.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 19-4-2007(102): Delores might _say_ , "Yes!", but she's way too _young_ give any legal **consent**.
column7: 3) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 2-4-2008(29): **Consent** is _words_ given to the _young_.
column8: 4) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 11-3-2008(16): You may get her **consent** if you _say_ romantic things and she is too _young_ to know any better.
column9: 5) [[Levence](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Levence)] 29-11-2008(8): Picture a cute loli holding flowers in her right hand, and you want to go over and talk to her, but you need parental **CONSENT** otherwise you will go to jail.

column3: The stern tone of a **rebuke** is seen here in the image of _words_ spoken at a _meeting_ of _butchers_ (See frame 307) waving their choppers at one another and  "cutting one another down" as only _butchers_ can.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 10-10-2007(289): A PETA activist _speaks_ at a _meeting_ of _butchers_ to **rebuke** them.
column6: 2) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 16-3-2008(54): I imagine _Socrates_ gate-crashing a _meeting of butchers_ and REBUKING them: 'You've been killing things again, you have, haven't you?' while the embarrassed butchers blush and try to hide their knives behind their backs and stand in front of hanging sides of beef.
column7: 3) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 26-2-2007(36): I had to SPEAK to the MEETING OF BUTCHERS and **REBUKE** them for mad cow disease, e-coli, and the bird flu.
column8: 4) [[jshield1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jshield1)] 23-4-2009(18): To **rebuke** is to take what someone _says_ , and _butcher_ it.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 14-6-2008(9): 諭す 【さとす】 (v5s,vt) to admonish, to persuade, to warn, to remonstrate, (P) STORY: Be careful what you SAY at the BUTCHERS MEETING because they only give you one WARNING and then you become part of a hot dog.

column3: Take **style** in its sense of some fashion design or model. Then let the element _arrow_ and _craft_ stand for the well-known **style** of shirts known as  " _Arrow_ shirts " because of the little _arrow_ sewn on each one.
column5: 1) [[kiisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kiisu)] 17-2-2008(196): Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain **style**..
column6: 2) [[shirahime](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shirahime)] 20-8-2006(64): The latest **style** is shirts crafted out of arrows.
column7: 3) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 16-4-2007(40): To say someone has **STYLE** is to say they _craft_ their image as sharp as an _arrow_ .
column8: 4) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 8-10-2008(29): Legolas mastered the CRAFT of shooting ARROWS, so shoots with **style**.
column9: 5) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 19-2-2008(9): When you've _crafted_ your look to be as sharp as an _arrow_ , then you've got **STYLE** , baby ,o) !

column3: When a manufacturer produces a new _style_ for the market, the first thing that is done is to run a **test** on consumers, asking them to _speak_ their opinions frankly about the product. Never mind the anachronism (the kanji was there well before our capitalistic market system) if it helps you remember.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 13-10-2007(351): In an essay **test** , you are judged on both your choice of _words_ and your writing _style_.
column6: 2) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 19-3-2008(53): The Japanese oral exam was a **test** of my _speaking_ _style_.
column7: 3) [[matstc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matstc)] 14-6-2008(24): Think about rap: the real **test** is if the _words_ are as good as the _style_.
column8: 4) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 4-2-2010(16): Tip: This kanji and a few others have keywords whose meanings overlap in English which may be confusing - [test](../v4/354.html) (#354 試) 試 : **test** (the water), try (and see), [exam](../v4/1278.html) (#1278 校) 校 : examine (text), [examination](../v4/1673.html) (#1673 検) 検 : examine, inspect (not a school exam or **test** ), [check-up](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1724) (#1724 診) 診 : (medical) check-up, [verification](../v4/1980.html) (#1980 験) 験 : examination, experiment (similar to 試 ) .
column9: 5) [[atomiton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atomiton)] 1-3-2010(9): Your _speaking style_ is NOT **test** ed on the JLPT (the JLPT is a little more concrete as a **test** for me).

column3: We use the Roman numeral II here to stress that this kanji is an older form of the kanji for _two_. Think of _two_ arrows in a _quiver_ , standing up like the numeral II.
column5: 1) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 20-1-2007(155): **II** (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left).
column6: 2) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 1-12-2008(25): Once you have _two_ old arrows left in your _quiver_ , you better start running…!
column7: 3) [[Remember](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Remember)] 30-8-2010(17): **II** : To remember this Roman numeral, give each soldier _I quiver_ and **II** _arrows_.
column8: 4) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 6-7-2008(10): For some reason i'm using the kanji for I to remember the **II** kanji. Its just Arrow + single stroke under the arms, there is no 'quiver' stroke, why? because you dont need a quiver to hold ONE arrow. As a result of the above explanation for the old kanji for ONE (which is never used) you need a QUIVER to hold 2 Arrows. <http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%BC%8C> Thats the character for the old I incase you cant picture what im saying.
column9: 5) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 16-2-2008(9): **II** Roman soldiers carry _two_ _quivers._.

column3: From its original meaning of a defined area or zone, a **range** has also come to mean a grazing _land_ where cowboys roam and do whatever it is they do with cows. When the herds have all been driven to market, there is a great homecoming _fiesta_ like that pictured here. As soon as the cowboys come home, home on the **range** , the first thing they do is kiss the ground (the _mouth_ on the _floor_ ), and then get on with the _fiesta_.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 10-10-2007(208): An astronaut lands back at the launch **range** , kisses the _earth_ beneath him with his _mouth_ , then heads off to a _fiesta_ to celebrate a safe flight.
column6: 2) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 23-7-2008(62): Instead of Heisig's "Fiesta" I use "Spear". Why? A spear is just a DROP extra on an Arrow. 域 , **range** actually means **range** as in limits/boundary/border sort of **range** (In a box it was the old meaning for Country 國 (581). Ok way too much etymology here, but back to story. With your SPEAR standing in a HOLE on the FLOOR with SOIL to its left9as you dug some out), you can see the **RANGE** of the spear in attacking a possible enemy (re Diablo and other RPGs, spear's have **range** ).
column7: 3) [[jHerbin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jHerbin)] 8-4-2010(30): When the _land_ was within **range** , the pirates _kissed the deck_ and had a _fiesta_.
column8: 4) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 19-2-2008(23): Dora and her party must travel over the **range** of earth, find the mouth of a cave on the ground, and then enter within to get to the fiesta. Remember: Land, Mouth on the ground, Fiesta!
column9: 5) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 27-11-2008(19): Dirty mexicans like to kiss the floor at the fiestas on the **range**.

column3: From a **burglar's** point of view, a _fiesta_ is an occasion to takeout the old lock picking _needle_ and break into the unattended safe filled with the family _shells_ (the old form of money, as we saw in frames 84 and 206).
column5: 1) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 11-3-2008(238): **Burglar** s… those guys!!! **Burglar** s only want money (clams) so that they can get needles (drugs) and party (fiesta)!
column6: 2) [[twincy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/twincy)] 31-8-2007(71): After the _fiesta_ , we found out that some **burglar** had stolen our _money_ , probably breaking in with a lockpick _needle_ …
column7: 3) [[stephan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephan)] 4-10-2008(30): The **burglar** tried to steal my _money_ by using a lockpicking _needle_ , so I impaled him to the wall with my _spear_.
column8: 4) [[jamestaverner](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jamestaverner)] 3-2-2008(13): I had trouble remembering if this was during a _fiesta_ or a _parade_ / _march_ \- so I've pictured the **burglar** escaping from the scene of the crime in a clapped-out old Ford _Fiesta_.
column9: 5) [[RachelleUdell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RachelleUdell)] 12-3-2009(12): The **BURGLAR** tried to steal my _CLAMS_ so I impaled him with _TEN SPEARS_.

column3: On a fruit **plantation** it is the _trees_ that one is particularly grateful for at the time of _Thanksgiving_. Imagine yourself inviting a few representative _trees_ from the fields and orchards to join you around the table to give thanks.
column5: 1) [[PrettyKitty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PrettyKitty)] 11-9-2007(180): The **plantation** is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 16-4-2007(43): During _Thanksgiving_ , all the _trees_ on the **plantation** celebrate the harvest. It's a good time for them, too.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 10-10-2007(33): During the _harvest festival_ , all the _trees_ on the **plantation** celebrate what a good job they did producing fruit.
column8: 4) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 1-7-2008(19): All _ten trees_ at the **plantation** rebelled and destroyed their human owners. They then had a _festive_ celebration for their new found freedom.
column9: 5) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 22-5-2007(11): On Thanksgiving day Kunta Kinte tied to a tree being slapped because he tried to flee from the **plantation** while the master was distracted with dinner.

column3: One **loads** bales on a wagon or _cart_ in preparation for the great Hay Ride that follows the _Thanksgiving_ dinner each year.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 11-9-2007(177): After eating a big _Thanksgiving_ dinner, you have to be careful in the _car_ ride home not to drop a **load** in your pants.
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 11-3-2008(126): After 'Thanksgiving' dinner, my girlfriend gave me a BJ on the drive back home. I blew my 'load' and 'soiled' the 'car'. But it was **LOAD** S of fun! Please report this story if this makes you feel uncomfortable :).
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 10-10-2007(85): **Load** the crops into the _wagon_ in preparation for the _harvest festival_.
column8: 4) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 14-8-2008(25): Every November I **load** my car with turkey, ham, sweet potatoes, dressing, cranberry sauce, mashed potatoes, gravy, corn, rolls. There's so much food, it sticks out the windows. I drive to my family's house for–that's right–a Thanksgiving dinner feast!
column9: 5) [[yawfosu88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yawfosu88)] 7-7-2007(24): Imagine a _thanksgiving_ dinner where a _car_ is **load** ed onto the table instead of turkey.

column3: The sense of the key word **overgrown** is of something growing luxuriously, though not necessarily in excess - in this case a whole _parade_ of weeds (outcast   _flowers_ ). By way of exception, the _flowers_ take their normal place over the enclosure.
column5: 1) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 14-8-2007(189): The _gay parade_ looks astonishing, as if **overgrown** with _flowers_.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-8-2007(108): When your garden gets **OVERGROWN** , it's like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!
column7: 3) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 11-3-2008(90): At the flower parade, (hippies' parade) all I can see is walking masses of **overgrown** hair!
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 3-1-2010(40): It's important that the word **overgrown** leads to the elements, rather than have the elements lead to **overgrown** as I see too often in the other examples. So I turned one of the other stories around. STORY: **OVERGROWN** hair appears the most in a _FLOWER_ power _PARADE_ (of the hippies in the late 60's).
column9: 5) [[stephan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephan)] 3-10-2008(28): I use _scythe_ as a primitive instead of _parade_. A _scythe_ is like a _spear_ (see [356]) whose tip has been bent to use for scything. When _flowers_ have **overgrown** your front yard, use a _scythe_ to cut them!

column3: If you think of a _parade_ of particularly disagreeable **relatives** , it should not be hard to imagine them as large bodies with _little_ pea-brains _above_.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 26-10-2007(72): Your _half-uncle_ is leading a _parade_ of your **relatives**. (Note: 上 + 小 makes up part of "uncle" 叔 , so I've called it "half-uncle".).
column6: 2) [[FoxintheStars](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FoxintheStars)] 1-8-2010(54): (Using the RTK1 supplement so I haven't had "uncle" yet.) When you take visiting **relatives** to a _parade_ , hold the _little_ ones _up above_ so they can see over the crowd.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 31-7-2009(9): Your _uncle_ organizes a _parade_ of all your **relatives** , which he himself is only half in because he's busy taking pictures of it.
column8: 4) [[ghinzdra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ghinzdra)] 7-5-2009(9): All my **relatives** seems to be here .They even organized a PARADE for me .Wait a minute : my UNCLE isn't here! oh I got it , I just noticed where he is but he has been forbid to scratch his crotch as usual and so I had trouble to recognize him ,.
column9: 5) [[wio_dude](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wio_dude)] 2-8-2010(7): People carry their _small_ **relatives** _above_ their shoulders so they can see the parade.

column3: Let the phrase " **turn into** " suggest some sort of a magical change. What happens here is that the _parade_ marching down main street **turns into** a _dagger_ -throwing bout between competing bands. Note how only one stroke has to be added to make the change.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 19-2-2008(248): It only takes a single stroke of a _dagger_ for a _parade_ to **TURN INTO** a bloodbath.
column6: 2) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 4-11-2007(26): The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.
column7: 3) [[jonobugs](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonobugs)] 26-6-2008(15): The peaceful protest parade turned into an ugly riot when some idiot pulled out a knife and started to threaten the police.
column8: 4) [[stephan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephan)] 3-10-2008(12): Let us beat swords into plowshares and **turn** _daggers_ **into** _scythes_. (see my story for [overgrown](../v4/360.html) (#360 茂)).
column9: 5) [[colonel32](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/colonel32)] 28-1-2007(8): The glorious socialist _parade_ **turns into** a _knife_ fight between Fidel and Raul Castro after they both give 3-hour speeches.

column3: In this frame, we see a mound of _dirt_ that is being _turned into_ a **castle** (the way you may have done as a child playing on the beach).
column5: 1) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 21-11-2006(154): The sand **castle** is just the [soil](../v4/150.html) (#150 土) that _turns into_ a **castle**.
column6: 2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 3-3-2008(71): "Someday this mound of _dirt_ here will _turn into_ our **CASTLE** ", the ants think to themselves when scoping out a new ant hill.
column7: 3) [[Rivvie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rivvie)] 29-1-2008(22): Sand sculptors can _turn_ even the most ordinary _soil_ _into_ the most beautiful **castle** s.
column8: 4) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 29-12-2010(9): A **castle** is just _land_ that has been _turned into_ something else: stone walls, a keep, armouries, barracks, etc. 城下 (じょうか) : land near the **castle** , 城 (しろ) : **castle**.
column9: 5) [[akira](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akira)] 20-2-2007(8): A **castle** is built on the ground where a parade was turned into a bloodbath.

column3: The sure sign of **sincerity** is that one's mere _words_ are _turned into_ deeds.
column5: 1) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 25-4-2008(213): **Sincerity** happens when what you _say_ actually _turns into_ something.
column6: 2) [[gwadonna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gwadonna)] 3-9-2008(93): **Sincerity** is _turn_ ing your _word_ s into actions.
column7: 3) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 30-9-2007(15): _Words_ _turning into_ actions is a sign of true **sincerity** . You do what you say (せい) you will. Marco and (まこと) his Brazilian friends need to learn this - they say they won't smoke pot inside anymore, but still do it – that's not being very **sincere**.
column8: 4) [[mdspencer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mdspencer)] 5-12-2010(14): When your _words_ _turn into_ something of true meaning, that is **sincerity**. [Not sure why this was reported twice… 'words' is perfectly OK here….].
column9: 5) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 7-8-2008(10): Socrates said " If said with **sincerity** , words can turn in to anything". Very similar to "castle", #362.

column3: Here we see a _march_ of _women_ demonstrating on behalf of equal rights, something extremely **intimidating** to the male chauvinist population.
column5: 1) [[bigloui](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bigloui)] 2-2-2006(164): The _march_ of _women_ \- against _intimidation_ in the workplace - is pretty _intimidating_ in itself!
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 10-12-2007(64): Interesting that this kanji also has the meanings of "dignity" and "threaten." I can see how a _march_ of _women_ in Japan would be seen as _intimidating_ by most men.
column7: 3) [[Nekesu04](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nekesu04)] 12-11-2008(52): A _one woman_ _parade_? How is that supposed to **intimidate** me?
column8: 4) [[stephan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephan)] 3-10-2008(27): I use _Grim Reaper_ instead of _march_ for the primitive, because he's the _one_ holding the _scythe_ (see [360]). Now imagine a female Grim Reaper - that's even more **intimidating**!
column9: 5) [[kaeru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaeru)] 31-10-2008(25): A group of feminist WOMEN are MARCHING for their rights, theyre so ugly it's INTIMIDATING.

column3: Picture a _march_ of _flames_ demonstrating against the Fire Department for their right to **destroy** , but being doused with _water_ by the police riot squads.
column5: 1) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 20-7-2007(208): Water flows down to **destroy** the march of fire.
column6: 2) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 26-10-2007(98): Use a _water_ cannon to **destroy** a line of _march_ ing _fire_ monsters. I keep mixing this one up with [disaster](../v4/167.html) (#167 災) and [demolition](../v4/400.html) (#400 壊). Remember, you **DESTROY** monsters (think of the Godzilla movie "Destroy All Monsters!"). Fires and floods are natural DISASTERs. And DEMOLITION is something you carefully do while wearing protective garments. (vaguely based on stefanot's balrog story).
column7: 3) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 11-12-2007(41): Lord of the Rings: Orcs, all carrying _torches_ (in the night, for visuals) and intent on _destroying_ everything in their path, are utterly **destroy** ed by the releasing of the waters (by the Ents).
column8: 4) [[RickN](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RickN)] 26-1-2008(27): Use _water_ to prevent the _march_ of the _fire_ before it **destroy** s everything.
column9: 5) [[gibler](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gibler)] 21-11-2011(12): I mix this up with 壊 demolition (#400 壊) alll the time, so i need to say: the MARCH to **destroy** TROY (the ancient city). TROY which comes from **desTROY**! They came across the WATER with the horse, secretly MARCHED in the city and BURNED the city down. **DESTROY** : The march of flames on troy. . . 絶滅 ぜつめつ － Extinction RTK2: メツ 滅亡 めつぼう(destruction) 滅ぶ ほろぶ － To collapse, go under, be **destroy** ed. .

column3: A group of unquenchable _mouths_ sets out on a _march_ across the country, drinking _water_ wherever they find it until the _water_ supply has **dwindled** to a trickle, triggering a national disaster.
column5: 1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 26-7-2007(206): When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to **DWINDLE**.
column6: 2) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 10-10-2007(75): When water supplies **dwindle** d, the population became a horde of dry _mouths_ , _marching_ to seize the water in the neighboring kingdom.
column7: 3) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 28-6-2008(34): When _water_ supplies **dwindle** d, _one_ _mouth_ raised a cry and led a _march_ on the city!
column8: 4) [[stephan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephan)] 3-10-2008(22): As the _water_ supply **dwindle** s, the _Grim Reaper_ (see [364]) looms over the thirsty _mouths_.
column9: 5) [[erlog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erlog)] 16-7-2008(9): The water **dwindle** s as the parade of thirsty mouths goes by.

column3: The verbal abuse involved in **reviling** those who do not deserve it can be compared to a _march of flowers_ in full boom having an _eyeball_ of nastiness cast over them (literally, of course).
column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 20-6-2008(75): They gays were **reviled** by society, so they put _flowers_ above their _eyes_ and _marched_ around.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 1-1-2010(27): Note: Whether you see a "drop" or a "one" in the bottom left of 蔑 depends on the font your computer is using at the time. Newer fonts prefer the "one".
column7: 3) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 26-7-2009(23): The _gay pride parade_ (flowers + march) was going smoothly until it caught the _eye_ of the religious right, who **revile** d the demonstration so much that they tried to interrupt it.
column8: 4) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 17-5-2008(10): Flower, eye, march: After the Trojans had defeated the cyclops, they planted _flowers_ in his only _eye_ (blinding him) and then _marched_ him back to Troy to be marched around and **reviled** by the citizens.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 2-2-2007(7): In Northern Ireland, bitter religious groups **revile** their opponents by _marching_ defiantly under their very _eye_ , holding _flowers_ that symbolize their beliefs.

column3: Prior to the use of metal, _trees_ were once cut down and bound together for use as **scaffolding** material. In the case of this kanji, what is being constructed is not a skyscraper but a simple _float_.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-8-2007(158): Japanese festival _floats_ are often so tall they need _wood_ **scaffolds** to be completed. (<http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html>).
column6: 2) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 23-4-2007(34): You need a **SCAFFOLD** made of WOOD to build a FLOAT if it will be several stories high.
column7: 3) [[RachelleUdell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RachelleUdell)] 18-7-2008(30): HINT: Near as I can tell from the Zhongwen site, the figure that Heisig designates as a "float", actually means "lances broken into pieces" (though there's a third stroke in the Japanese version of the kanji rather than two in the Chinese), thus I'm using _broken into pieces_ to identify that particular pictograph. STORY: A **scaffold** is made of _WOOD BROKEN INTO PIECES_.
column8: 4) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 7-7-2008(15): Not using Heisigs float. im extending the meaning of my Spear (see previous kanji).Think a VERY LONG SPEAR/TRIDENT (Trident as this is like an ARROW with 3 spikes) or, a LONG SPEAR because its just a SPEAR with TWO extra arrow lengths. STORY: **SCAFFOLD** s' are made of VERY LONG SPEARS's as tall as TREES that allow us to build huge structures.Tridents allow TRIPLE interlocking between each other, making their use in **SCAFFOLD** S good enough to be able to build structures as strong and naturally perfect as TREES.
column9: 5) [[dtstutz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dtstutz)] 5-9-2008(10): A **scaffold** is where you hang witches. In order to know whether they're witches or not, you put them on a scale to see whether they whether they weigh more than **wood** , a duck, or other things that **float** , like very small rocks. (Monty Python: Search for the Holy Grail).

column3: Those special _gold_ -colored tokens minted each year for the Mardi Gras and thrown into the crowds from people on the _floats_ give us the kanji for **coins**.
column5: 1) [[Squintox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Squintox)] 3-10-2008(125): Interesting fact: The Japanese one yen **coin** is the only **coin** in the world that can float on water. <http://www.hanamiweb.com/floatingyen.jpg>.
column6: 2) [[PParisi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PParisi)] 12-10-2007(118): Political hopefuls in Rome threw gold **COIN** S from floats when they were campaigning for office.
column7: 3) [[quety101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/quety101)] 27-2-2008(71): Gold **coin** s will not float.
column8: 4) [[Spartan1841](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spartan1841)] 8-10-2009(55): Think of the gold **coin** s floating in Super Mario games.
column9: 5) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 28-8-2007(18): Picture a large golden float…you know, made of gold. Every year when they bring this float out there are people waiting at the sides of the float to take their **coin** shaped hole punchers and punch out some very valuable gold **coin** s.

column3: An entourage of _floats_ going from one town to the next must always seek a **shallow** place to cross the _water_. Try to picture what happens if they don't.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 3-3-2008(135): The _water_ can't be too **SHALLOW** if you expect to _float_.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-8-2007(52): The water isn't **shallow** enough to [ford](../v4/372.html) (#372 渉). We'll have to cross by _float_!
column7: 3) [[certain](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/certain)] 10-7-2006(26): The water is too **SHALLOW** to float in it.
column8: 4) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 6-11-2007(20): A _parade float_ full of devout Christians is attempting to recreate Jesus' walking on _water_ phenomenon. They claim to be able to do it because of faith, but only reason they are managing to do it is because the water is **shallow**.
column9: 5) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 14-5-2007(19): When you encounter water and can't find a **shallow** spot while driving a float, you will find out if it can float!

column3: The character for **stop** is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint: the first 3 strokes represent the front of the foot and the last the heel. The big toe (stroke 2 sticking out to the right) on the right indicates that this is a left foot.
column4: * Although the meaning of _stop_ will be retained, we will return often to the pictographic meaning of _footprint_.
column5: 1) [[brunosprak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brunosprak)] 6-1-2008(83): If you find in the _ground_ a _walking stick_ with a _magic wand_ , **STOP**! Maybe it's some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.
column6: 2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 15-6-2008(53): This looks like a little police officer sticking his hand out (first two strokes) signaling for cars to **stop** as a schoolboy/girl is following behind (third stroke). The final stroke is the road.
column7: 3) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 23-1-2008(31): If you don't remember this one from the 10,000,000 **STOP** signs on roads all over Japan, you're beyyond help!
column8: 4) [[alkulp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alkulp)] 10-4-2008(23): **STOP**! I put my foot down.
column9: 5) [[EmiBD208](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/EmiBD208)] 4-11-2011(13): Gandalf took his _magic wand_ , which looked like an old _walking stick_ , and stuck it in the _ground_ , before bellowing, " **STOP**! YOU SHALL NOT PASS!".

column3: _Footprints_ that follow one another a _few_ at a time indicate **walking**.
column5: 1) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 24-1-2006(188): When **walk** ing your pet, you must _stop_ a _few_ times along the way when nature calls.
column6: 2) [[Delina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Delina)] 28-2-2008(79): When you learn to **walk** , you take your _steps_ a _few_ at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every _few_ _steps_ but keeps getting up to try again.
column7: 3) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 4-3-2009(27): When you take a **walk** you should _stop_ a _few_ times to smell the roses.
column8: 4) [[drivers99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/drivers99)] 1-5-2009(13): When you **walk** you leave a _few_ _footprints_.. not as many as when you run.
column9: 5) [[kaminix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaminix)] 3-4-2008(6): To **walk** is to _stop_ a _little_ now and then while going somewhere. (not exactly true, but that made it stick for me!).

column3: To **ford** a body of _water_ means to _walk_ across it.
column5: 1) [[ngoli1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ngoli1)] 26-9-2007(174): The new **Ford** Jesus. It can do everything except WALK on WATER.
column6: 2) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 6-8-2006(95): A **ford** is a place where one can walk through the water, a place only a few footsteps deep.
column7: 3) [[Lowther](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lowther)] 19-2-2008(75): **Ford** ing is simply walking through water.
column8: 4) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 23-7-2007(22): Did you hear about the new **ford** model out? They're calling it the "Jesusmobile" – It's able to _walk_ across _water_!
column9: 5) [[Renaissance](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Renaissance)] 15-12-2008(17): The new **Ford** Jesus. It can WALK on WATER. (edit on ngoli1. I think negations make stories hard).

column3: The image of something occurring **repeatedly** , over and over again, is of having one's _head walked_ on.
column5: 1) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 6-4-2008(252): I **repeatedly** _walk_ around hoping this kanji will come into my _head_. I **repeatedly** _walk_ around hoping this kanji will come into my _head_. I **repeatedly** _walk_ around hoping this kanji will come into my _head_. I **repeatedly** _walk_ around hoping this kanji will come into my _head_. I **repeatedly** _walk_ around hoping this kanji will come into my _head_.
column6: 2) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 24-1-2006(136): Are you familiar with the joke about the ditzy secretary who **repeatedly** _walked_ back and forth forcibly over all the _pages_ of her boss' most important letters. When confronted she just says "Well you said they needed to be stamped before they're mailed.".
column7: 3) [[jamiemw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jamiemw)] 20-9-2007(109): FACT: Saddam Hussein put a mosaic of Bush on the floor of the Al Rashid hotel so as people would be forced to **repeatedly** _walk_ on his _head_. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Rashid_Hotel>.
column8: 4) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 3-11-2011(62): Notice a pigeon how it _walks_. Its _head_ bobs up and down **repeatedly**.
column9: 5) [[stephan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephan)] 4-10-2008(31): “If you want a picture of the future, imagine a boot stomping [ _walking_ ] on a human face [ _head_ ] – forever [repeatedly].” – George Orwell, Nineteen Eighty- Four.

column3: Seeing _footprints_ on someone's _flesh_ indicates a rather brutal way of having secured that person's **agreement**.
column5: 1) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 24-1-2006(176): A secret **agreement** between a covert gov't agency and aliens states that we will not step _foot_ on the _moon_ again in return for alien technology.
column6: 2) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 21-12-2007(118): NASA and Armstrong made an **agreement** : They'd never tell anyone that no-one actually stepped _foot_ on the _moon_.
column7: 3) [[ambrokusa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ambrokusa)] 28-3-2007(117): The peace **agreement** put a _stop_ on the fighting for a _month_.
column8: 4) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 23-1-2008(43): Neil Armstrong had an **agreement** with NASA: I will be the first one to leave a FOOTPRINT on the MOON. REMEMBER the position: the FOOTPRINT is over the MOON.
column9: 5) [[earlneath](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/earlneath)] 3-12-2005(34): Vegetarians are in **agreement** about stopping the flesh trade.

column3: To **undertake** a project is to take some idea floating in the air and _stop_ it so that it can be brought down to earth and become a reality. Here we see some **undertaking** made to _stop_ under a beach _umbrella_.
column5: 1) [[yukina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yukina)] 11-11-2006(262): Mary Poppins floated down with her _umbrella_ to **undertake** the job of _stop_ ping the children's misbehaving.
column6: 2) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 10-4-2009(169): In Resident Evil, you **UNDERTAKE** a mission to STOP UMBRELLA from infecting the country with the T-Virus.
column7: 3) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 19-11-2007(54): The **Undertake** r is an evil WWE wrestler - he beat his opponent with an _umbrella_ until he stopped _moving_.
column8: 4) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 8-11-2007(37): I will **UNDERTAKE** this project: To sell UMBRELLAS in a bus STOP.
column9: 5) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 13-12-2007(16): Think of a crowd of people, standing under their _umbrellas_ at a funeral in the pouring rain, honoring a friend/relative whose life has _stopped_. For extra reinforcement think of **undertake** as coming from **undertake** r.

column3: That same _grove of trees_ we met in frame 226 shows up here in the character for **curriculum** (in the sense of a record of one's life or academic achievements, the **curriculum** vitae). Instead of the _grove_ making its way slowly through the surface of the _cliff_ as before, here we see it _stopped_ , much the same as a **curriculum** vitae calls a halt to the calendar and talks only about the past.
column5: 1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 25-2-2008(314): A **CURRICULUM** is a _calendar_ that replaces days with reasons to _stop_ having fun.
column6: 2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 19-1-2007(96): A little like a _calendar_ , your **CV** records your _footsteps_ through time.
column7: 3) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 17-10-2011(91): A **curriculum** (vitae) is similar to a _calendar_ except that, instead of mentioning every _day_ in your life, it only mentions the main _stop_ s. (Compare [calendar](../v4/213.html) (#213 暦)).
column8: 4) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 25-8-2007(25): Stop underneath a grove of trees by the cliffs to sit down and write your CV.
column9: 5) [[TwoGoats](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TwoGoats)] 6-9-2009(20): When the school **CURRICULUM** started covering TREES that grow in cliffs, I decided to STOP attending.

column3: With a _quiver_ of _arrows_ set on one's back, the goal of the **warrior** depicted here is not to attack but merely to _stop_ the attack of others: the oldest excuse in history!
column5: 1) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 13-3-2008(208): ONE- ARROW can STOP a **warrior**.
column6: 2) [[RickN](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RickN)] 19-12-2007(81): A great **warrior** can _stop_ any 0pponent with _one arrow_.
column7: 3) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 20-11-2007(35): The traditional **warrior** carries a quiver of ARROWS. But the **warrior** must never forget his real purpose: to STOP conflict, not cause it.
column8: 4) [[eatyoda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eatyoda)] 3-9-2008(20): Remember the story of "Achilles the **Warrior** ," who was put down by _one_ _arrow_ (the drop in the quiver) among many _quivers_ which hit just above his _foot_.
column9: 5) [[Buronzu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Buronzu)] 23-5-2009(17): _Lord of the Rings:_ It took a _quiver_ of arrows to _stop_ the **warrior** Boromir in Fellowship of the Ring.

column3: A certain portion of _shells_ (money) is collected by the _warrior_ from the local villages as he passes through to defray the costs of keeping the land safe, and this is called a **levy**.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-8-2007(167): A _warrior_ stands guard at a bridge collecting _shells_ as a **levy** for any who want to pass.
column6: 2) [[lb4269](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lb4269)] 28-2-2006(69): "Drove my Chevy to the **levy** but the **levy** was dry. And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you'll die. Pay up the clams or you'll die…".
column7: 3) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 19-7-2008(39): A **levy** is _money_ collected to fund kingdom's _warriors_.
column8: 4) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 23-1-2008(39): "Gimme some _clams_ " said the _warrior,_ collecting his **levy.**.
column9: 5) [[nintendomaniac64](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nintendomaniac64)] 5-7-2009(8): Bush always used the excuse that the _money_ from the Iraq **levy** was to support America's _warriors_ overseas.

column3: A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step, says the Chinese proverb. Here we see _one footprint_ , complementing that proverb with the sound advice that if the first step is not made **correctly** , the whole point of the journey will be forfeited. This is the ideal that teachers are supposed to have in **correcting** their students, and parents in **correcting** their children.
column5: 1) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 19-10-2007(223): If you do it **correct** on the _first_ attempt you can _stop_.
column6: 2) [[tom2000](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tom2000)] 4-8-2009(43): My (Japanese) wife tells me that Japanese people use this kanji to tally up numbers (instead of 4 vertical lines and a diagonal across). I remember this one by writing the kanji while counting out the strokes to myself and saying this is the **correct** way to tally numbers.
column7: 3) [[burritokun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burritokun)] 20-8-2008(22): The **correct** way of learning Japanese? _First_ , _stop_ everything you're doing. Then, go pick up a copy of Heisig's book and work from there.
column8: 4) [[muddyhill](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/muddyhill)] 31-1-2009(9): The **correct** way to tackle any problem is _one_ _step_ at a time.
column9: 5) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 10-9-2008(9): You want a **correct** answer in one stop? Google is your friend…

column3: _Words_ that testify to the _correctness_ of some fact are classified as **evidence**. (Here we see a good example of how the more common primitive element takes the  "strong" position to the left, even though it has more strokes.)
column5: 1) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 26-2-2007(273): Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as **evidence**.
column6: 2) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 26-11-2008(68): "If what you _say_ is indeed _correct_ , we could use use your testimony as **evidence** ".
column7: 3) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 3-8-2007(25): The **evidence** you find at the crime scene is misspelled WORDS scrawled everywhere– think of Se7en. But you can't resist, and you have to CORRECT their spelling.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 7-5-2009(22): **Evidence** proves that your words are correct.
column9: 5) [[ninjagaijin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ninjagaijin)] 16-3-2011(14): **Evidence** proves that what you [say](../v4/335.html) (#335 言) is [correct](../v4/379.html) (#379 正).

column3: To the many definitions for **politics** that already exist, this character offers yet another: _correct taskmastering_. Think about what the primitives tell us. On the one hand, we see the pessimistic wisdom that **politics** has to do with _taskmastering_ , maneuvering people with or without their will. And on the other, we see the campaign assurances that this duty can be performed _correctly_ if only the right candidate is given a chance.
column5: 1) [[nagisa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nagisa)] 19-5-2007(219): Those involved in **politics** are always trying to elect the _correct_ _taskmaster_.
column6: 2) [[cosby](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cosby)] 16-7-2008(189): Insane political _correctness_ on the left, and facists _taskmasters_ on the right- thats **politics** in a nutshell right there.
column7: 3) [[dtstutz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dtstutz)] 5-5-2008(23): The Left is careful to be politically correct in speech. The Right whips people into a frenzy of outrage!
column8: 4) [[stephan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephan)] 14-10-2008(14): Insane political _correctness_ on the left, and a fascist _Hitler_ on the right – thats **politics** in a nutshell right there.
column9: 5) [[Pangolin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pangolin)] 3-10-2006(8): I like immacolata's "chief whip" (helps if you are British!) as _taskmaster_. But let us not forget **policital** _correct_ ness. The _taskmaster_ (chief whip) is there to see that party members observe **political** _correct_ ness at all times, especially in a socialist party, _correct_ ness is on the left!

column3: **Determination** , in the sense of settling on a certain course of action, is likened here to _mending_ one's _house_.
column5: 1) [[jrothenberg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jrothenberg)] 31-1-2007(231): In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher's HOUSE in various ways.
column6: 2) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 25-1-2007(88): Prior to buying a home, the _home_ inspector will come into your house and **determine** everything that needs _mending_.
column7: 3) [[hanako1975](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hanako1975)] 14-1-2008(50): People who decide to renovate (ooh, that's a fancy word, let's say _"mend"_ ) their _houses_ must be very **determine** d DIYers. (Using DIY helps me remember this story when I see **DEtermine** ).
column8: 4) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 4-7-2008(36): 定める 【さだめる】 (v1,vt) to decide, to establish, to **determine** , (P)The primitive "mend" is too arbitrary and I can never remember it. New primitive meaning: CORRECT PERSON: Do you see the 4th and 5th stroke? They look like the kanji for "person." Therefore, CORRECT + PERSON = CORRECT PERSON. STORY: I DECIDED/DETERMINED I would fix my HOUSE this summer but am still looking for the CORRECT PERSON to do it (i.e. a contractor).
column9: 5) [[davcarruth](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/davcarruth)] 7-5-2009(25): The Determinator Arnold Schwarzenegger has **determined** to get out the ladder and the tools and start _mending_ the _roof._ "I'll be back - after mending the roof," he utters dramatically.

column3: _Metal_ of itself doesn't **lock**. It needs to be so _determined_ by a **lock** smith. Now make a concrete image of that.
column5: 1) [[ngoli1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ngoli1)] 26-9-2007(211): Even if you **lock** up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.
column6: 2) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 14-3-2008(173): The best stories for this kanji tend to have a thief in them, which always makes me confuse them with the kanji for burglar (357). So, let's try this one: My girlfriend wears a _metal_ chastity belt with a **lock** but I am _determined_ to open it! I must get inside!
column7: 3) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 3-3-2008(81): A **LOCK** is _metal_ that is _determined_ to keep intruders out.
column8: 4) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 16-7-2008(73): A **lock** is a piece of _metal_ that will _determine_ who can or can't get in.
column9: 5) [[hoolan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hoolan)] 2-3-2009(15): A METAL **LOCK** DETERMINES who can get in.

column3: **Running** , we are told here, _mends_ the _soil_. Observe in the following frames how this kanji can embrace other elements from below, much the same way as the element for _road_ does, and how, in order to do this, the final stroke needs to be lengthened.
column5: 1) [[Samchan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Samchan)] 4-8-2008(319): Hint: This kanji is NOT _soil_ on top of _mend_ , as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is _10_ on top of _mend_. So my story is: If you **run** _10_ miles, you will need to _mend_ your socks!
column6: 2) [[poseid0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/poseid0n)] 11-7-2007(33): The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been **RUN** NING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.
column7: 3) [[jonjimbo2000](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonjimbo2000)] 11-4-2007(29): The _soil_ needs _mending_ after the cross-country **run**.
column8: 4) [[fjolnir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fjolnir)] 6-12-2009(18): If you **run** _10_ miles you'll need to _mend_ your socks.
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 16-5-2009(9): With ten things to mend, you've got to **run** to get it all done.

column3: When one is _running_ after something, the goal that _seduces_ one is said to **transcend** the seeker.
column5: 1) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 2-8-2007(220): A successful marathon runner needs to be able to **transcend** seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer.
column6: 2) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 16-7-2008(178): To **transcend** to a higher path you need to _run_ from the _seduction_ of earthly desires.
column7: 3) [[lb4269](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lb4269)] 29-1-2006(105): To **transcend** oneself is to reach a higher plane of reality. A head shaven monk is telling me this. We are in a Tibetan monastery. He was once an athlete, a runner. He used to run everywhere, until one day, he saw a beautiful cheerleader along his path. She tried very hard to seduce him, but he forced himself to **transcend** his urges. He did reach his running goal, and he has became a lonely monk. He wishes now he had just broken down back then and….
column8: 4) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 17-2-2008(21): Pamela Anderson was able to **transcend** the Television world and become a superstar after her years of _seductive running_ on the beaches of Baywatch.
column9: 5) [[Nandaro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nandaro)] 6-8-2009(12): To **transcend** life you must run from anything that seduces you.

column3: In **proceeding** to a new city or a new job, something in you _runs_ ahead with excitement, and something else holds you back, like a _divining rod_ built into your psyche warning you to check things out carefully before rushing in too wildly.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-8-2007(289): "Don't _run_ into trouble," Dumbledore tells Harry. " **Proceed** with caution with your _wand_ out.".
column6: 2) [[tstuhldreher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tstuhldreher)] 19-5-2008(73): You go through airport security. "Proceed," mumbles the guard after he wands you. You run like crazy, because you're late for your flight.
column7: 3) [[mcbainpc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcbainpc)] 25-6-2008(65): While running, my magic wand tells me where to **proceed**.
column8: 4) [[Erubey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Erubey)] 20-1-2008(32): I've got to run and take a piss before **proceed** ing.
column9: 5) [[stephan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stephan)] 4-10-2008(30): In a relay race, the baton ( _wand_ ) must **proceed** from one _runner_ to the next.

column3: Here we see two _parades_ in competition, each trying to **surpass** the other by _running_ at high speed from one town to the next. Note the little  "hook" at the end of the first stroke of the element for _parade_. This is the ONLY time it appears like this in the kanji treated in this book.
column5: 1) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 4-9-2007(223): The person in charge of _running_ the _parade_ **surpass** ed all our expectations (by just a extra drop…).
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 7-1-2008(102): The _parade_ of _runners_ are all trying to **SURPASS** each other - and they end up running all the way to _Vietnam_ (note that this kanji is also used for the country of Vietnam).
column7: 3) [[hoolan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hoolan)] 2-3-2009(36): A RUNNER will always **SURPASS** a PARADE.
column8: 4) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 16-6-2008(32): This kanji is read the same way as # 385 "transcend." The difference is that this kanji talks about **surpass** ing or crossing over a mountain (or the like) while 385 is used when **surpass** ing or transcending a amount of money, an expectation, etc. STORY: Some punk kids dared one of their friends to PASS/SURPASS the PARADE. So the kid got a RUNNING start but slipped on a DROP of something and landed face first in front of the PARADE ruining it.
column9: 5) [[eri401](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eri401)] 6-3-2010(13): To make the marathon more challenging for the runners, they made them try to out-[run](../v4/384.html) (#384 走) a parade going down the same path. The runners must come out before the parade, and **SURPASS** it, to win a shopping spree at Mitsukoshi or a trip to Vietnam. Oddly, this is a kanji in Mitsukoshi Dept store ( 三越 ) and Vietnam ( 越 ).

column3: In this kanji we are shown someone spending an entire _day_ at _mending_ one stocking, because they want the job done  " **just so**. " Be sure to make a clear image of a finicky old fusspot to make the abstract idea as concrete as possible.
column5: 1) [[Brad_Thomas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Brad_Thomas)] 22-6-2006(135): 'Sun' 'Mend' - It **just so** happens that _sun_ shine can _mend_ your gloomy spirits.
column6: 2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 24-1-2008(72): My image here is of Fabrice (the guy who runs this website) spending all _day_ obsessively _mending_ the code so this page looks **just so…**.
column7: 3) [[brendanmacdonald](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brendanmacdonald)] 28-4-2008(47): I spent all _day_ _mending_ to make things **just so**.
column8: 4) [[igordesu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/igordesu)] 22-11-2008(26): It takes me aaaaallll flipping day to mend these stories so they're **just so**!
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 23-8-2008(21): 是 【ぜ】 (n) righteousness, justice, right. 是か非か 【ぜかひか】 (exp) right or wrong, 是非 【ぜひ】 (adv,n) (1) (uk) certainly, without fail, (2) right and wrong, pros and cons, (P) STORY: See 382: Only someone who practices RIGHTEOUSNESS and JUSTICE every DAY is the CORRECT PERSON for Presidential position.

column3: In many kinds of research, one can find information on a given **topic** only if the _headings_ are prepared _just so_.
column5: 1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 26-7-2007(279): The "TOPIC" of the day's newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention.
column6: 2) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 28-8-2007(76): You spend ALL DAY, mending your socks JUST SO. Then you have a look at the HEADING of the newspaper. The **topic** —FREE SOCKS TO BE GIVEN AWAY!!!!
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 7-1-2008(57): The **TOPIC** is written as the _heading_ of the _page just so_ readers know what the article is about.
column8: 4) [[Yonosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yonosa)] 14-5-2009(27): This **topic** is just so boring turn the page…!
column9: 5) [[Yenniku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yenniku)] 3-7-2008(23): It **JUST SO** happens that girls giving **HEAD** seems to be the number 1 **TOPIC** of high school gossip.

column3: A **dike** is a successful bit of engineering only if the amount of _earth_ piled up is measured _just so_ for the height and pressure of the water it is meant to contain.
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 23-2-2008(198): Making a **dike** is all about arranging the _soil just so…_.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 30-8-2007(73): The little Dutch boy has his finger stuck in the **dike** , and that's the only thing keeping his town from going under. He really really needs to go to the bathroom though, so he devises a plan to carefully add a bit of dirt - there, place individual bits in **just so** \- there, I think it's good enough. Pull it out —–yes! Success!
column7: 3) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 9-8-2007(44): Imagine Indiana Jones replacing a gemstone with a small bag of soil. If he doesn't weigh the soil just so, a huge **dike** behind the wall will break, washing him away.
column8: 4) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 30-11-2008(38): **Dike** s are just so dirty.
column9: 5) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 16-7-2007(24): The **dike** was very close to breaking. The people worked all _day_ bringing _earth/soil_ to _mend_ it.

column3: To construct a **building** , you first draw a set of plans (the writing _brush_ ) and then _s-t-r-e-t-c-h_ your drawing out to scale in reality.
column5: 1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 12-9-2007(151): **Build** is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in **build** ing. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it's just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 16-3-2008(95): A construction worker's classic morning. _Stretch, brush_ his teeth, and then start to **build**.
column7: 3) [[opie226](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/opie226)] 16-7-2008(54): To **build** a skyscraper, you have to stretch it upwards until it brushes the sky.
column8: 4) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 18-8-2008(18): To **build** your Kanji ability, you must _brush away_ the cobwebs from your head and _stretch_ your imagination.
column9: 5) [[vicnet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vicnet)] 25-10-2009(14): **Building** seen through the architect's eyes: Step 1: draw blueprints with best _brush_ Step 2: _stretch_ out on a lawn chair while other people **build** it!

column3: The _golden_ **key** you have been presented by the mayor gives you access to all the _buildings_  in the city.
column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 16-2-2007(99): The _metal_ thing you need in order to enter things you _build_ is a **key**.
column6: 2) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 5-11-2010(15): 鍵盤 [key](../v4/2761.html) (#2761 鍵) ケン, かぎ … Parts: 金 , 建 (cf 建物 [build](../v4/391.html) (#391 建), 健康 [healthy](../v4/974.html) (#974 健)) … Story: The most important _Metal_ in any _build_ ing is the **lock** on the front door, and without a **key** you ain't getting in. This kanji means both lock and **key** to most Japanese people. 錠前 is technically the word for lock but it's not used in daily conversation.
column7: 3) [[francajun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/francajun)] 15-4-2012(9): They use metal to build **key** s.
column8: 4) [[jusenkyoguide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jusenkyoguide)] 10-11-2012(5): In Zelda, the _gold_ **key** will let you into any _building_.
column9: 5) [[ZxHIROxZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ZxHIROxZ)] 26-6-2012(4): Many have tried and failed in seeking the **key** to El Dorado, the land of _golden buildings_ (Imagine if El Dorado kept up with modern times).

column3: This character is a kind of pictographic image of how **prolonging** is a clever way of _stopping_ things by trying to _stretch_ them out a little bit at a time (the extra _drop_ at the top of _stop_ ). Be sure to get a concrete image of this process, by imagining yourself **prolonging** something you can really, physically, _stretch_.
column5: 1) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 24-3-2008(289): _Stretch_ ing _correct_ ly **prolong** s life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching…
column6: 2) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 14-4-2008(99): If you want to **prolong** your sexual encounters, the best way to _stretch_ them out is to _stop_ your orgasm after just one _drop_ has come out. (with inspiration from gorgon).
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 8-1-2008(68): Here's a great mnemonic: "stop, drop, and stretch (!?)." Now let's associate it with 'prolong': if you're ever in an uncomfortable spot, like being asked tricky questions or caught in a lie, just **PROLONG** the situation - stop, drop, and stretch. They may be confused by your odd behaviour, but it'll buy you a few moments to think up another good lie to get out of the sticky situation!
column8: 4) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 10-11-2007(29): The inquisitor **prolong** ed the torture because his victim didn't answer the question _correctly_. He turned the wheel _stretching_ out his limbs even further.
column9: 5) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 9-8-2006(20): To **prolong** means to stretch time for a drop (a little while) because you do not want something to stop.

column3: The key word of course calls to mind the feast of Christmas. As the famous poem at the start of St. John's gospel tells us, the **nativity** we celebrate at Christmas had its origins at the very start of time and governs all of human history: it represents the _prolongation_ of the eternal _Word_ in time and space.
