column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 8-1-2008(207): **Nativity** = born, being born. Think of **birth** as a painful and _prolong_ ed event. And of course, all the _words_ and curses being yelled at the soon- to-be father for doing this to her!
column6: 2) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 15-6-2009(173): When you are being born ( **nativity** ), your mother's WORDS are PROLONGED. (Thiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiis huuuuuuuuuuuuuurtss a lottttttttt~!! Owwwwwww!!!).
column7: 3) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 7-4-2008(105): The **nativity** story: A child born to a virgin mother? Sounds to me like the _words_ have _stretch_ ed what is sensibly _correct_. Sadly, those _words_ have continued to be spread through the _prolonged_ use of the bible.
column8: 4) [[javiergakusei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/javiergakusei)] 17-4-2007(61): At **Nativity** (christmas), the priest says more Words (sermon) than the rest of the time, Prolonging mass duration.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 16-6-2008(34): 誕生日 【たんじょうび】 (n) birthday, (P) 誕生石 【たんじょうせき】 (n) a birthstone STORY: On your BIRTHDAY people say WORDS of good luck and fortune to PROLONG your life.

column3: This character depicts a **cornerstone** as a _stone_ set at the end of a wildlife preserve (the  " _zoo_ in the _grove_ ").
column5: 1) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 24-9-2007(245): Features like _stones_ and _groves of trees_ are the **cornerstone** s of a happy _zoo_.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 9-11-2007(60): A zoo which is still under construction is already full of animals. At the moment, only the **cornerstone** has been set in place. To temporarily keep the animals from escaping, a closely-packed grove of small trees is planted around the stone. (Note that this zoo needs some serious _mending_.).
column7: 3) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 4-7-2008(39): _Stone Grove Zoo_ is the new **cornerstone** in animal exhibits! If you love animals you need to check out _Stone Grove Zoo!_.
column8: 4) [[jshield1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jshield1)] 23-4-2009(29): How am I the only one who doesn't see how mend turned into zoo with one stroke.
column9: 5) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 17-12-2007(15): To make room for the new _zoo_ , they use dynamite sending all the _grove's_ trees flying in the air. That big _stone_ on the left now serves as **cornerstone**. (Variation on ziggr's story, with more emphasis on placement that was giving me trouble).

column3: What makes a man a **bridegroom** is obviously a _woman_ and her dowry, here presented as a small _zoo_ (animals were often used for this purpose in earlier societies) and a _month_ away from it all (the  "honey _moon_ ").
column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 24-6-2008(174): The virgin **bridegroom** tries to understand the new, mysterious _part of_ his _woman's body_ \- but with little success. It's a _zoo_ down there! (primitives placement: the part of the body is 'down there' - the woman is 'left' unsatisfied).
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 30-8-2007(122): The only reason anyone talks about a **bridegroom** is if they're about to or have just gotten married. Of course, then you have to go on your honeymoon. So you take your _woman_ to the _zoo_ for a _month._ Pretty cool honeymoon.
column7: 3) [[yawfosu88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yawfosu88)] 3-3-2008(73): Imagine a **bridegroom** having his wedding with his _woman_ in a _zoo_ on the _moon._ That will impress her! Fill out the details with the bride and groom floating with a menagerie of animals with astronaut helmets floating, bumping and attacking one another.
column8: 4) [[munia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munia)] 15-8-2008(32): How did the eccentric **bridegroom** convince the _woman_ to marry him? He built a _zoo_ in the surface of the _moon_ just for her!
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 24-1-2008(29): The **bridegroom** will take his _woman_ to the _zoo_ for a _month_ long honeymoon. (Simplifying dihutenosa).

column3: At the top we see the _top hat_ , and at the bottom a pictographic representation of the folds of a **garment**. If you break the  "4-fold" fold into 2 sets of 2 strokes, you will find it easier to remember.
column4: * Used as a primitive, the additional meanings of _cloak_ or _scarf_ will come in handy. What has to be noted particularly are the changes in shape the kanji can undergo when it becomes an element in other kanji. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the kanji we shall treat, and for that reason deserves special attention here. When it appears to the left, it looks like a hiragana ne (ネ) with an extra drop on the right, and we shall take it to mean _cloak_.  At the bottom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the _top hat_ ) are omitted, which we shall take to mean a _scarf_. On rare occasions, the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first 2 strokes appearing at the top and the last 4 at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitive, in which cases we shall speak of a _top hat and scarf_. And finally, of course, it can keep its original kanji shape, along with its original meaning of _garment_ in general. Note that when any of the above forms have something beneath them (as in frame 429), the third from final stroke is  "unhooked."
column5: 1) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 18-1-2008(133): The only **garment** s allowed in this club are _top hat_ and _scarf_.
column6: 2) [[jackhuddleston](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jackhuddleston)] 19-4-2008(82): The **garment** s most commonly associated with the _craft_ of a magician are the _top hat_ and the _magic wand_. (It's a stretch, but the way I remembered this kanji is through that phrase. This way you can remember it through using primitives we have already learned.).
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 20-7-2007(11): Dr. Who always wore a TOPHAT and SCARF, his most memorable **GARMENT** S.
column8: 4) [[crocker](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crocker)] 4-1-2007(8): A TOPHAT and a SCARF form a **GARMENT** that makes you barf.
column9: 5) [[catJapan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/catJapan)] 27-6-2012(7): A snowman wears a _top hat_ and a _scarf_ for _**garments **._

column3: You might think here of _garment_ that have been specially **tailored** for _Thanksgiving_ celebrations to look like traditional Pilgrim garb.
column5: 1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 13-11-2007(191): The **tailor** was hard at work making sure all the pilgrims were dressed in their best _garments_ for _thanksgiving_.
column6: 2) [[Buronzu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Buronzu)] 18-7-2009(49): The **tailor** worked hard after _thanksgiving_ to alter _garments_ so they'd fit people who'd eaten too much at their _thanksgiving_ dinners.
column7: 3) [[jwy2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jwy2k2)] 20-3-2007(18): If you can make ten garments then you qualify as **tailor** and we will have a party to celebrate. Congratulations! You are all invited to the TenGarmentFiesta.
column8: 4) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 1-4-2008(15): My **TAILOR** made me _10 garments_ for the upcoming _fiestas_.
column9: 5) [[Wisher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wisher)] 23-8-2008(11): The **TAILOR** was invited to THANKSGIVING so he could sew up the turkey after the stuffing was put in. Too bad his GARMENT got dirty during the process. They should have killed the turkey first.

column3: The character for **attire** can be remembered as a picture of what we may call a  " _turtle-samurai_ " sweater. At the top we see the _turtle-samurai_ and at the bottom the element for _garment_.
column5: 1) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 26-2-2007(146): The TURTLE SAMURAI needs special GARMENTs for his **ATTIRE** since his body is much more ROBUST than others.
column6: 2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 13-11-2007(69): The _ninja turtles_ tried to go eat at a fancy restaurant, but they were told to come back after their were dressed in proper **attire**. However, it's too difficult for them to find proper _garments_ because they bodies are so _robust_! (sannomiya + drwarrior12).
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 10-6-2008(59): **Attire** is more _robust_ than a _garment_.
column8: 4) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 26-8-2008(39): Only a _robust_ _garment_ is worthy of being called **attire**.
column9: 5) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 30-8-2007(12): The TMNT tried to enter an expensive restaurant wearing nothing - they were told to come back with the appropriate **attire**. Not understanding the word **attire** nor how to wear clothes, they put on some clothes and, instead of buttoning stuff up, they put on **a tire** to hold their clothes up (inspired by synewave's story).

column3: An innocent looking _top hat and scarf_ lying there in front of you, turned over, reveal a hidden _computer_ sewn into the **back** of each - obviously the tools of a master spy. Such experiences teach one always to have a look at the **back** side of things.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 9-1-2006(248): The _computer_ had carefully dressed up in _clothes_ to look human. It was n't until I looked at the **back** and saw the cables and stuff that I realized what it was.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 15-6-2008(178): Can computers be gay? I'm not sure, but mine always wears a top hat and scarf, and for some reason its **back** door port is always open…
column7: 3) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 26-5-2007(102): I'll be **back** ! says the _computer_ Terminator, disguised with a _top hat and a scarf_.
column8: 4) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 9-4-2008(25): The COMPUTER wore a TOP HAT and SCARF to hide it's cables at the **BACK**. ( 裏 うら bottom/back/reverse).
column9: 5) [[elanlan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elanlan)] 17-6-2009(15): I was looking at porn on my _computer_ and my roommate came in the room, so I hit the **back** button on the browser and pretended to be shopping for _top hats_ and _scarves_.

column3: The right half of this character shows a _garment_ woven so fine that it can pass through the _eye_ of a _needle_ , fittingly draped around the slithering, ethereal form of a poltergeist. In this frame, our eerie visitor brushes its robes against a nearby block of apartments and completely **demolishes** them, razing them to the _ground_.
column5: 1) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 3-5-2007(410): If you stand too close to a **DEMOLITION** site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty.
column6: 2) [[Rakushun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rakushun)] 16-10-2007(108): Since that needle eye thing turns up a lot, I turned it into Darth Vader. It kinda looks like him to me, with the eye being his metal mouth piece thing. So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt.
column7: 3) [[lukearns](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lukearns)] 2-4-2008(51): During **demolition** , _dirt_ and debris can feel like _needles in your eyes_ if you're not wearing ther proper _garments_.
column8: 4) [[eightyd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eightyd)] 8-7-2009(16): The dirt to the left is all that remains of the WTC on 9/11. On the right we have george bush wearing a perfectly clean and expensive suit/garment putting eyedrops in his eye to force an emotion over the victims of 9/11. He has to fake this emotion since 9/11 was a controlled **demolition**.
column9: 5) [[ew8049](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ew8049)] 29-6-2008(15): The **demolition** expert doesn't want DIRT in his 10 EYES, so he covers them with a SCARF.

column3: A drunken sod in a tattered _top hat_ and soiled silk _scarf_ with a giant _mouth_ guzzling something or other gives us a **pathetic** character role in which W. C. Fields might find himself right at home.
column5: 1) [[Asgard](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Asgard)] 28-8-2006(188): One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a _tophat_ and a _scarf_ so that you can't see his whole face but only his _mouth_. He thinks it's cool. I think it's **pathetic**.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 9-8-2007(76): A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is **pathetic** – in the original sense of the noun "pathos." The tattered _tophat and scarf_ he wears only adds to the pathos.
column7: 3) [[jwy2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jwy2k2)] 20-3-2007(36): Other definitions include grief, sorrow, pathos, pity, and sympathize. IMO the english word **pathetic** is often used nowadays to mean a sort of "contemptuous pity" but I think we need a more compasionate definition to understand 哀 , now and especially later when it starts being combined with other words…So, here's the top part of frame 308 享 (receive) but where the child was is now replaced by a scarf. Whatever fate befell the child is up to your imagination. grief, sorrow, pathos, sympathy, **pathetic**.
column8: 4) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 8-4-2008(27): That _tall_ guy with the _scarf_ is just so **pathetic**! (I can't help but see "tall" when I look at this kanji).
column9: 5) [[DeadLugosi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DeadLugosi)] 26-8-2008(13): A hat, a mouth and a cloak, I think that's all that beggar owns. How **pathetic**!

column3: A **distant** figure on the _road_ is such a blur it looks like a _lidded crock_ wearing a silk _scarf_.
column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 16-3-2007(319): Keep **distant** from a _lidded crock_ on the _road_ wrapped in a _scarf_. It might be a bomb.
column6: 2) [[eieneverafter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eieneverafter)] 3-3-2008(27): When traveling to a **distant** land, what better way of keeping warm on the road is there than carrying a warm lidded crock and wearing a scarf?
column7: 3) [[ojousan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ojousan)] 29-10-2009(23): (NOTE: I am combining _lidded crock_ and _scarf_ into one NEW PRIMITIVE: _picnic_. As in, a _lidded crock_ is filled with the food and the _scarf_ is the picnic blanket.) When I'm on the _road_ to **distant** lands and know there will be quite a **distance** between proper _road_ side stops, I'm always extra careful and bring a _picnic_.
column8: 4) [[whistler11](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/whistler11)] 19-11-2006(16): In a game called 'spin the _lidded-crock_ ', contestants see how far **distant** they can roll a crock down the _road_ by wrapping it in a _scarf_ and spinning it like a top, the only rule is that the lid must stay on the crock. Picture a referee measuring the distance on the _road_ to see how far **distant** you've spun the crock.
column9: 5) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 17-5-2008(14): It is best to stay **distant** from the _dirt_ y _mouth_ ed wino with the tatty _scarf_ laying on the _road_.

column3: This clever little **monkey** has captured an entire pack of _wild dogs_ , locked them inside a _lidded crock_ , and wrapped the whole thing up in a silk _scarf_ to present to the dogcatcher.
column5: 1) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 6-5-2007(147): The **MONKEY** likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 25-2-2007(129): To catch a **monkey** , chase him with _wild dogs_ into a _lidded crock_ , then tie it with a _scarf_.
column7: 3) [[koiulpoi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koiulpoi)] 21-6-2009(77): Honestly, I hate the "Lidded Crock with a scarf" metaphor. It makes no sense, and I just can't get an image that "sticks" with it, at all. Besides, it sounds retarded. The original meaning of the whole right side of this Kanji is "Long Kimono." So, put a wild dog in a kimono, stand him on two legs, and you've got something that looks like a man but still feral - a **monkey**.
column8: 4) [[Supraman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Supraman)] 15-11-2010(18): We should be starring the 2009– stories, The 2006–2007 stories totally have a monopoly. GIVE THE NEW GUYS A CHANCE! ,) All you new guys star this.
column9: 5) [[mickymay](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mickymay)] 1-5-2011(13): The upper right part means long kimono. 袁 is not in Heisig list, but if you remember it, you have an easier time later on. "Long kimono" is easier than "lidded crock with scarf." For its story look at Kanji 34945. Story for 猿 : If you put wild dogs in long kimonos, they look like **monkey** really.

column3: The primitives here take care of themselves: _cloak_ and _dagger_ .What I leave to you is to decide on an appropriate connotation for  " **first time** " to take advantage of them.
column5: 1) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 17-12-2007(219): "This is the **first time** we've been out of the Shire, Mr. Frodo!" Says Sam, covering himself with his cloak and clutching his dagger.
column6: 2) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 4-3-2008(127): On his **FIRST TIME** , he _cloaked_ his _dagger_ with a Trojan.
column7: 3) [[Captain_Thunder](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Captain_Thunder)] 28-12-2008(50): Not only did I put on my robe and wizard's hat for my **first time** , but also my cloak and my dagger. That's when she walked out on me.
column8: 4) [[Codewolke](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codewolke)] 16-6-2009(25): Your GF can get pregnant even on the **first time** … so from the **first time** on you should put a _cloak_ on your _sword_ (condom).
column9: 5) [[Atomik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Atomik)] 30-9-2009(16): The **first time** I tried on my new _cloak_ , I discovered the inside was lined with _daggers_. There was no second time.

column3: This character depicts a bolt of cloth wrapped around a pole. From there it gets its meaning of a **towel**.
column5: 1) [[hknamida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hknamida)] 8-12-2007(63): If it looks like a _towel_ , speaks like a _towel_ and walks like a _towel_ … I wonder why Heisig didn't include this one (as an actual kanji) in RtK 1.
column6: 2) [[NeoGlitch](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NeoGlitch)] 6-11-2010(21): Obvious **towel** is obvious.
column7: 3) [[sabretou](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sabretou)] 14-9-2011(11): If you got this far and need a story for **towel** , then you sir, have failed.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 12-10-2008(11): A **towel** is used as a _belt_ to hold in your " _walking stick_ ".
column9: 5) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 23-2-2007(9): Primative from RTK1.

column3: The maid, _towels by her side_ , distributes the **linen**.
column5: 1) [[inuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/inuki)] 15-9-2006(138): A matador holding his red **linen** by his side.
column6: 2) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 18-3-2008(93): The first rule of the _Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe_ is "DON'T PANIC!" The second rule, of course, is to always have a towel by your side. Personally, I prefer the **linen** sort.
column7: 3) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 16-2-2008(44): A **linen** _towel_ should always be _by your side_ just in case .
column8: 4) [[dogray77](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dogray77)] 29-1-2008(13): If you made a towel showing all the great Communists of our time, 'linen' would be the furthest to the left.
column9: 5) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 25-10-2006(13): Think of **LINEN** S 'N THINGS opening up a new location in outer space. All they sell are _towels_ , and we all know no outer space journey is complete without a _towel_ _by one's side_.

column3: A **sail** made of a _towel_ makes a _mediocre_ vessel.
column5: 1) [[gsantise](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gsantise)] 28-8-2007(156): When stranded at sea, we needed a **Sail**. The best we had was a TOWEL, which was MEDICORE, only catching a DROP of WIND.
column6: 2) [[mcbainpc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcbainpc)] 25-6-2008(131): A towel makes a mediocre **sail**.
column7: 3) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 16-7-2007(21): A **sail** is a piece of _cloth_ used to catch every _drop of wind_.
column8: 4) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 18-3-2008(7): One handy use for a towel, according to the _Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe_ , is as a **sail**. The effect will be mediocre, however, if there is little wind.
column9: 5) [[stan_in_japan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stan_in_japan)] 13-2-2012(5): A _towel_ makes a _mediocre_ **sail**.

column3: A _towel_ owned by the _wealthiest_ tycoon in the world is made into a **hanging scroll** after his death and auctioned off to the highest bidder.
column5: 1) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 26-8-2007(138): In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars… In Japan, after showering, when the wealthy don't have any clean towels, they simply grab a **hanging scroll** off the wall and use it to dry off!
column6: 2) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 20-3-2008(83): The towels of the wealthy: **hanging scroll** s.
column7: 3) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 24-10-2006(56): Check out <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanging_scroll> to get a visual image of a **hanging scroll**. The _wealthiest_ man in Japan uses such precious **hanging scroll** s as _towels_.
column8: 4) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 5-7-2008(25): In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars… In Japan, after showering, when the _wealthy_ don't have any clean _towels left_ , they simply grab a **hanging scroll** off the wall and use it to dry off! (Thanks Zazen! I can't seem to get the placement right here so I stuck the word left after towel to remind me where to put it!).
column9: 5) [[KANJI](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/KANJI)] 24-11-2006(18): **WIDTH** (keyword change) **TOWEL** wrapped around an enormous waist, associated with **WEALTH** in Japan.

column3: Because of the _risk_ involved (of getting the _sun_ in one's _eyes_ ),one puts together a makeshift **cap** out of a dirty old _towel_.
column5: 1) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 9-10-2007(380): If you wear a towel as a **cap** , you are at risk of being seized and searched in U.S. airports.
column6: 2) [[kinkypete](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kinkypete)] 11-1-2008(97): Originally the first **cap** was a turban which was a _towel_ wrapped around the head to keep the _sun_ out of the _eyes_.
column7: 3) [[LordGolem](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LordGolem)] 29-8-2007(37): Because it's a _risk_ to stay under the sun in the desert, Arabs use to wear a _towel_ as a **cap**.
column8: 4) [[skellyfish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skellyfish)] 15-12-2008(10): When I think of a Japanese-style **cap** , I think of a TOWEL wrapped around someone's head. And we all know that the Japanese are obsessed with using **cap** s, hats, umbrellas, etc. to minimize the RISK of skin damage. So know we have the form and the purpose of a **cap** in Japan.
column9: 5) [[JohtoKen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/JohtoKen)] 5-11-2008(10): A **cap** is a _cloth_ , which can help reducing the _risk_ of the _sun_ getting into your _eyes_.

column3: A dirty _towel_ draped over the entrance to the old _graveyard_ is painted to look like the **curtain** of death that leads to the otherworld.
column5: 1) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 22-10-2007(203): There is a _graveyard_ outside my house that scares me, so I put a huge towel over the window to serve as a **curtain** so I can get a good nights sleep.
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 21-11-2007(59): When you're dead in the _graveyard_ , "it's **curtains** for you.".
column7: 3) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 17-7-2008(34): When a mobster says "It's gonna be **curtain** s for you!" He means you'll be wrapped in a towel, dead in a graveyard.
column8: 4) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 19-6-2008(24): After Towelie died, instead of burying him in a grave, we hung him up as a **curtain** so the neighbours couldn't see us hitting the bong.
column9: 5) [[xeyes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xeyes)] 21-5-2007(17): If you've read Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (SPOILERS AHEAD!)…think of the **curtain** in the depths of the Department of Mysteries, and what happens when Sirius encounters that **curtain**. (Well, yes, it's technically a veil, but since Heisig doesn't use that as a keyword, think of it as a really big…um… _towel_.).

column3: A large _towel_ stretched overhead with only a few of the _sun's rays_ breaking through represents a **canopy** over one's bed.
column5: 1) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 19-12-2008(269): A **canopy** is a _towel_ to block the _suns_ _ray_ s.
column6: 2) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 18-3-2008(62): From the _Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe_ : A towel is useful, among other things, as a **canopy** to keep out the sun's rays from your face while napping.
column7: 3) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 15-5-2006(36): Picture a cafe in wartime Japan. Its' **canopy** is made of a big beach _towel_ which has the imperial flag (the one with the _sun's rays_ ) printed upon it.
column8: 4) [[lb4269](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lb4269)] 2-3-2006(10): (fighter **canopy** and tree **canopy** ) Luke Skywalker is flying to see Yoda on Dagobah. He starts to crash, and he pops his **canopy** and uses a towel as a parachute. He gets stuck in a tree too high to jump down. The sun comes and starts to get very hot. He feels like he will be cooked alive. Yoda comes and tells him to use the Force. Luke concentrates, and he takes a ray of light from the sun and makes it solid. He then climbs down it like it is a pole.
column9: 5) [[johngwk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johngwk)] 5-8-2010(7): For a **CANOPY** , we improvised, using a _towel_ to protect us from the _sun's rays_.

column3: A strip of _white towel_ and some scraps of _metal_ have the makings of a primitive kind of **brocade**.
column5: 1) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 18-1-2008(190): **Brocade** is the art of sewing _gold_ on a _white towel_.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 30-8-2007(90): Never heard of this word before encountering it here. So it turns out that the fanciest **brocade** in the world is actually a towel used by a Turkish monarch. It's embroidered with _gold_ and _cocaine_. Yes, _cocaine_ \- what you thought it'd be something else? That is some true art right there. I think a great many people would want to own this towel.
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 12-1-2008(30): "Brocade" means 'twisted thread', and is usually made with gold and silver. Here it is written as a _towel_ woven with _gold_ and _white_.
column8: 4) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 25-8-2008(23): First, the meaning of **brocade** in English: fabric woven with an elaborate design, esp. a raised pattern. Imagine GOLD threads embedded in a WHITE silk TOWEL. I carried my **brocade** to the airport and the GOLD set off the METAL detector!
column9: 5) [[duzymichal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/duzymichal)] 8-7-2009(13): The problem with this kanji was that the towel pictured by me was white in the first place (and I'm not changing colours/shapes/overall appearance of my primitives only to adjust them to new kanji, oh no sir…). So I have a white dove pecking golden **brocade** out of the towel.

column3: Dressed in nothing but a bath _towel_ and _top hat_ , one sets off to the **market** place in search of a bargain or two.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 14-10-2007(166): My recurring nightmare: Walking through the **market** , and suddenly realizing that I'm wearing only a top hat…and a towel.
column6: 2) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 13-7-2008(51): At the **MARKET** you find lots of nice TOP HATS and TOWELS.
column7: 3) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 3-3-2008(28): An investor gets a tip while in the shower. With no time to loose he runs down to the stock **market** , only wearing a bath _towel_. And the _top hat_ , of course, according to the dress code at the stock exchange.
column8: 4) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 13-11-2007(15): I was walking in the **market** , minding my own business, when an old man in a _top hat_ and _towel_ flashed me. I still have nightmares.
column9: 5) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 26-10-2006(10): After European contact in the 19th century, many Africans adopted aspects of European dress mixed with their own style. So imagine a dusty West African town where the men roam around in _top hats_ and _towels_ as they wander the busy **market**.

column3: Imagine a village _market_  with stalls set up around an immense **persimmon** _tree_  with watermelon-sized fruit. If it weren't for the fact that the _tree_  is sacred to the village, people would get impatient as the **persimmons**  fall from the _tree_  and wreak havoc on buyers and sellers alike.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 2-4-2009(75): Nobody buys **persimmon** s at the _market_ , because there's a _tree_ in the middle where you can pick them for free.
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 19-2-2007(18): **Persimmon** = かき - they grow on _trees_ and are sold at the _market_.
column7: 3) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 20-6-2007(11): The guy at the _market_ says: I'll give you one **persimmon** _tree_ per every Simon you bring me!
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(6): The _tree_ growing in the _market_ bears **persimmons**.
column9: 5) [[drkdve](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/drkdve)] 24-5-2011(5): The official TREE of the MARKET is the **PERSIMMON**. (because somehow the vendors believe it keeps shoppers from being "persimmonious".).

column3: Of all the _women_ of the family, it is the **elder sister** who has the duty to go to _market_ to do the shopping.
column5: 1) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 10-6-2008(260): Unlike the _younger sister_ ( 妹 ), who is _not yet_ old enough to date… the **elder sister** is on the _market_!
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 9-1-2006(28): She's old enough to be allowed to go to the market.
column7: 3) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 21-2-2007(17): My **ELDER SISTER** is a WOMAN who works at the MARKET.
column8: 4) [[zoletype](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zoletype)] 30-4-2008(9): The GIRL who goes to MARKET is the **ELDER SISTER**.
column9: 5) [[katmcgo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/katmcgo)] 21-7-2010(6): The **elder sister** is the woman who does the chores and goes to market while her mother is at work.

column3: One is surprised, strolling through the _market_ , to find among the _meats_ hung out for sale a slab marked: **lungs**.
column5: 1) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 20-2-2007(145): The PART OF THE BODY most important if you work at a MARKET is your **LUNGS** so that you can shout out at the top of your voice "IRASSHAIMASEEE" to attract customers.
column6: 2) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 25-10-2006(92): **LUNGS** are a PART of the BODY that can be found at any meat MARKET or black MARKET.
column7: 3) [[thatkidpercy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thatkidpercy)] 5-12-2007(39): So that I could breathe when I got there, I visited the _moon market_ to buy a new set of **LUNGS** for my trip to the moon.
column8: 4) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 23-2-2011(19): When you hear **lungs** , think of a) a _body part_ , and b) a smoker. A smoker will be in the _market_ for a new _body part_ : a fresh pair of **lungs**. 肺 (はい) : lung, 片肺飛行 かたはいひこう flying on one engine.
column9: 5) [[TwoGoats](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TwoGoats)] 7-9-2009(14): This month **lungs** are being sold at the market.

column3: The part of the _apron_ where one finds the _buckle_ (represented pictorially by the first 5 strokes) is on the **sash**.
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 10-6-2006(166): First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of _one_ and _mountain_. Of course, the " _number 1_ " _mountain_ in Japan is _Mt._ Fuji. The bottom half, under _Mt._ Fuji, consists of _crown_ and _towel_. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under _Mt._ Fuji (Japan's _#1_ _mountain_ ) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it's royal because of the _crown_ ) discover what looks like a _towel_ , but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal _sash_ for the king's kimono.
column6: 2) [[LazyNomad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LazyNomad)] 28-3-2009(160): WARNING: Try to avoid thinking of the upper element as a combination of _one_ and _mountain_ , because in this case you will get used to the incorrect stroke order.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 15-10-2007(56): Beautiful "Miss Housewife Japan" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the _number one_ _mountain_ ) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an _apron_ tied with a **sash**. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.).
column8: 4) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 17-10-2011(54): The _buckle_ is on the **sash** of the _apron_. (Note that according to the dictionary, breaking down this Kanji includes only the radicals for "walking stick", "one", "crown" and "towel". Hence, "mountain" is not part of the radicals.).
column9: 5) [[deedriod](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/deedriod)] 5-5-2012(30): Heisig fails to go into detail about the top kanji, but, It's not a mountain like everyone is saying. It actually means _Thirty_ 丗 the stroke order starts with a _One_ , then draw in the three vertical lines from left to right. Then the last stroke at the bottom closing it up. Then comes the _Apron_ which makes up a **Sash**. (-Story: I made a **Sash** out of _Thirty_ cut up _Aprons_.

column3: People that have been " _sashed_ " to something (whether their mother's apron strings or a particular job) for too long become like _water_ that has stopped moving: they start to **stagnate**.
column5: 1) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 1-12-2008(246): History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean _water_ , so samurai usually had to wash their _sashes_ in **stagnant** puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one's karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren't their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????
column6: 2) [[jwy2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jwy2k2)] 20-3-2007(72): A moat is a **stagnate** ring of water like an obi (sash) of water tied around the castle.
column7: 3) [[stringy_cow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stringy_cow)] 1-1-2009(46): WATER that is "tied up" as if with a SASH and unable to flow properly will become **stagnate**.
column8: 4) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 20-12-2007(46): This is one I keep missing, and always because of the right-hand side. I can easily associate **stagnate** with _water_ but never with _sash._ And so I will now try to associate **stagnate** with something around the house that often **stagnate** s and smells awful: the kitchen _washrag_. From washrag, I will make the association with _sash_.
column9: 5) [[nesert](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nesert)] 14-10-2009(41): The _water_ became **stagnate** because the drain was clogged with a _sash_.

column3: **Thorns** grow on a bush here that has wrapped itself around a _tree_ like a _belt_ , cutting into the poor _tree_ like little _sabers_.
column5: 1) [[wazato](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wazato)] 30-9-2007(166): A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like **THORN** S.
column6: 2) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 7-9-2006(34): The BELT TREE has **THORN** S like SABERS.
column7: 3) [[Sevenhelmets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sevenhelmets)] 4-8-2008(24): The crown of **thorn** s on Christ was a _belt_ from a **thorn** bush _tree_ , and cut him like _sabers_.
column8: 4) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 10-6-2008(16): The tree was covered with a _belt_ of **thorn** s. They cut like a _sabre_!
column9: 5) [[Yonosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yonosa)] 14-5-2009(13): The **thorn** s were wrapped around the tree like a belt of sabers.

column3: This kanji show a unique **system** for leading _cows_ to the slaughterer's _saber_ : one ties a _belt_ about their waist and fixes that _belt_ to an overhead cable, pulling the _cow_ up into the air where it hangs suspended, helpless against the fate that awaits it.
column5: 1) [[Kelly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kelly)] 25-6-2007(168): The **system** for making leather _belts_ involves slicing up a _cow_ with a _sword_.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 7-2-2009(61): Why all the gore and violence? How about a samurai cow? He doesn't have to be a violent samurai, either. He only wears the sword because he's part of the _bushi_ **SYSTEM**. Actually, he studies ikebana, shodo, and zen. Imagine him sitting cross-legged in a Zen temple (a very _Special_ Zen temple). The master asks him if a dog has buddha nature and, shifting the swords in his belt, he calmly replies, "Moo!".
column7: 3) [[potempkin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/potempkin)] 11-9-2008(45): Gary Larson cartoon of the feudal Japanese **system** : _cows_ walking around with _belts_ , complete with katana _sabers_. The Sa-MOO-rai class **system**.
column8: 4) [[tenricefieldsglue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tenricefieldsglue)] 21-5-2009(32): Jurassic Park has a **system** for feeding velociraptors. First a _cow_ gets _belt_ ed. Second the cow is lowered down into the raptors' cage. Third the raptor ruptures the cow with his _saber_ like talons.
column9: 5) [[fredde79](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fredde79)] 4-9-2007(26): I used Heisig story here but i tweaked it a little. It works better for me if i imagine the belt is around the tail of the cow, cause that it what it looks like in the kanji.

column3: A label indicating that a _garment_ was **made in** U.S.A. or Taiwan or Japan is itself a symbol for the _systematization_ of the _garment_ industry.
column5: 1) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 24-10-2006(155): **Made in** china - a system of exploitation . making garments for nothing.
column6: 2) [[gwadonna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gwadonna)] 12-8-2008(89): **Made in…** is a _system_ of labels you can find on every _garment_ s.
column7: 3) [[thermal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thermal)] 13-5-2008(72): A SYSTEMATICALLY made GARMENT will no doubt have **MADE IN** on the label.
column8: 4) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 23-5-2009(14): We have a _system_ in the US where all _garments_ have labels saying what country they are **made in**.
column9: 5) [[Vladas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Vladas)] 1-10-2006(14): You find a curious toy: a _cow_ wearing a _belt_ and a _saber_ , and also _clothes_ under them. You look at it wondering where it was **made in**.

column3: As the wheels of the _car_ **revolve** , they kick up small _rising clouds_ of dust and debris behind them.
column5: 1) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 5-3-2007(153): The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with **REVOLVE** R blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.
column6: 2) [[komodo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/komodo)] 20-6-2008(125): Just a note to remember the _cloud_ primative: The name of Goku's pet _cloud_ that he used to help him rise (fly) in the Dragonball anime series (and also the scientific name for a certain type of cloud) is _Nimbus_ [ <http://www.rpgclassics.com/shrines/gba/dbztlog/screen2.jpg> ]. The katakana- ization of this is **ニム** バス, so the _rising cloud_ primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style.
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 24-12-2008(62): Burnout! As the car's wheels _revolve_ the rubber burns making a _rising cloud_ of smoke!
column8: 4) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 10-11-2005(15): You could just think of someone smoking their tires before taking off. They're staying in one place, but the wheels of the car keep revolving round and round as a cloud of burnt rubber rise from them. To keep distinct from rotation (1046), think of rpms (revolutions per minute).
column9: 5) [[philiphoward123](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/philiphoward123)] 16-6-2009(11): The _car_ 's wheels **revolve** , sending up a _rising cloud_ of dust.

column3: The secret **technique** of making a _rising cloud_ of smoke turn into a bouquet of _flowers_ is shown here.
column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 30-8-2007(154): Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: "Try my _rising cloud_ _flower_ **technique**!!!" _smash_ _pow_ _crack!!_.
column6: 2) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 11-10-2007(92): One **technique** to smoke weed is to vaporize it and inhale those rising clouds to create a stronger effect.
column7: 3) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 16-7-2008(80): I've mastered a **TECHNIQUE** for making my farts (the _cloud_ ) smell like roses (the _flower_ ).
column8: 4) [[PParisi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PParisi)] 4-1-2008(37): David Copperfield throws a bouquet of flowers into the air, whereupon they turn into a rising cloud of smoke. The audience gasps in admiration of his **technique**.
column9: 5) [[tstuhldreher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tstuhldreher)] 23-5-2008(22): Think of the "Daisy" ad used against Goldwater in the 1964 campaign. A little girl counts as she picks petals off a FLOWER, then you hear a countdown and see a mushroom CLOUD. It's one of the most famous examples of advertising **technique**.

column3: This kanji, also a primitive, is one of the clearest instances we have of a complex pictograph. The top line is the sky, the next 3 strokes a pair of clouds, and the final 4 dots the **rain** collected there and waiting to fall.
column4: * As a primitive it can mean either _rain_ or _weather_ in general. Because it takes so much space, it usually has to be contracted into a crown by shortening the second and third strokes into a crown.
column5: 1) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 4-4-2007(132): From the _ceiling_ hangs a _towel_ dripping four _drops_ like **RAIN**.
column6: 2) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 19-3-2008(22): The **rain** falls from the sky, landing like teardrops on my windows.
column7: 3) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 20-2-2008(18): It **rain** ed so hard that we had to put a _towel_ under the _ceiling_ to contain the _drops_ that came through.
column8: 4) [[j0k0m0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/j0k0m0)] 1-3-2009(13): Towel hung out on a line to ….oops, it's **rain**.
column9: 5) [[ellasevia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ellasevia)] 13-1-2010(10): A pictograph of a window with **rain** falling outside.

column3: Here is the full character for **cloud** from which the primitive for a _rising cloud_ derives. _Clouds_ begin with vapors _rising_ up in small _clouds_ from the surface of the earth, and then gathering to make **clouds** that eventually dump their _rain_ back on the earth.
column5: 1) [[roderik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/roderik)] 22-4-2008(199): Every _rising **cloud**_ is a potential _rain_ **cloud**. (Thanks astridtops).
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 9-6-2006(65): Every **cloud** is a potential _rain_ **cloud**.
column7: 3) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 31-7-2008(26): A **cloud** represents the stage of the earth's water cycle between when _rising **clouds**_ of water vapor head for the sky and when _rain_ falls.
column8: 4) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 18-12-2007(11): That's a funny **cloud** … it seems to be shooting rain up above it instead of letting it drop to the earth…
column9: 5) [[childofthetao](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/childofthetao)] 4-2-2010(7): This kanji shows the weather cycle. Rain falls from the rain **cloud** s, and then becomes a **cloud** of vapour that rises up and the whole thing begins again.

column3: We refer to days when the _sun_ is covered by the _clouds_ as **cloudy weather**.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 6-2-2007(248): **Cloudy weather** is when a _cloud_ blocks the _sun_ (up above).
column6: 2) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 18-9-2007(17): I have difficulty remembering that the rain is ABOVE the clouds, which is not its logical spot. This is **cloudy weather** , not rainy weather. So I imagine the _sun_ _raining_ down on the _clouds_ instead.
column7: 3) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 29-11-2009(7): DO NOT MISTAKE CLOUD AND **CLOUDY WEATHER** . Remember that CLOUD is a smaller kanji, as well as a smaller keyword. Also in Japanese it is smaller (kumo vs. kumori).
column8: 4) [[Harmony](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harmony)] 14-11-2008(7): The _sun_ is above the _clouds_ , the definition of **cloudy weather**.
column9: 5) [[kresobilan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kresobilan)] 11-4-2008(5): **Cloudy weather** is actually the English weather: _sunny_ , _rainy_ and _cloudy_ at the same time.

column3: The full rumble and roar and terror of **thunder** is best felt not with your head tucked under your pillow safe in bed, but out in an open _rice field_ where you can get the real feel of the _weather_.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 5-4-2007(137): If it's _raining_ and you're standing in the middle of a _rice field_ , you're sure to soon become acquainted with the **thunder** up close and personal.
column6: 2) [[Keith](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Keith)] 21-7-2006(67): **Thunder** is a sure sign of _rain_ coming. When you hear the **thunder** , you've got time to get out of the _field_ before it starts _raining_.
column7: 3) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 28-3-2008(44): I've been told by Japanese people that this word, 雷 （かみなり） means BOTH **thunder** and lightning together. Though there is no individual word for **thunder** , there is for lightning (いなずま）, so I understand where Heisig is coming from. Just remember a powerful storm over an empty field and you're sure to remember this kanji.
column8: 4) [[Bullwhip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Bullwhip)] 3-5-2008(20): It's the **Thunder** with the _rain_ that'll rattle your _brain_.
column9: 5) [[James87](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/James87)] 21-3-2011(9): In the Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, once you obtain the third Spiritual Stone, you head to the castle to see the Princess. By the time you get there, RAIN is lashing down on Hyrule FIELD and **thunder** crashes overhead. And then you're nearly flattened by a horse, attacked by a madman and made to jump into a moat! Life's tough.

column3: Think of **frost** as a cooperative venture, an _inter_ -action of the malevolent forces of _weather_ that sit around a conference table and finally decide to allow a very light amount of moisture to fall just before a short and sudden freeze.
column5: 1) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 5-3-2006(154): **FROST** is kind of an _inter_ - _weather_ , phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s.
column6: 2) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 5-9-2008(75): The freezing RAIN formed **FROST** on the TREE right before your EYES. If you want, **frost** -y then think **Frost** Tree to get to the mnemonic. SECOND STORY: **FROST** Y the snowman? It's RAIN that **FROST** S that can then INTER-act with the kids, till he melts of course.
column7: 3) [[wholefnfro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wholefnfro)] 16-4-2008(58): **rain** changes **"inter"** **frost**.
column8: 4) [[tgray88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tgray88)] 4-10-2008(57): The _inter_ -action between _rain_ and cold makes **frost**.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 26-7-2008(21): It was _raining_ outside onto the trees, and you dared your friend to stick his tongue out on the tree (you weren't quite sure if it would stick, like your tongue will to metal when it gets cold). Your friend decided to one-up you and stick his _eye_ on the _tree_ , and just then, it got super cold and a layer of **frost** covered the city. Your friend's _eye_ got stuck on the _tree_ , but he had to go home to do his homework, so he dashed off with his _eye_ stuck there on the tree.

column3: _Walking legs_ slipping on the _ice_ are a sure sign of **winter**.
column5: 1) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 30-3-2008(78): Don't slip off your legs in **winter** , strap two skis to your feet.
column6: 2) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 10-6-2008(50): In **winter** my _walking legs_ feel like blocks of _ice_.
column7: 3) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 5-8-2008(46): In **Winter** , there's _ice_ beneath your _walking legs_! Be careful, even just two icelets could slip you up!
column8: 4) [[andresito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/andresito)] 30-4-2009(23): A pair of _walking legs_ skating over _ice_ during **winter**.
column9: 5) [[vinniram](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vinniram)] 10-4-2010(11): In **WINTER** , I always slip on ICE with my WALKING LEGS.

column3: This character is meant to be a pictograph of a great man, said to represent the Lord of the **Heavens**. (You may, of course, use the elements _ceiling_ and _St. Bernard_ instead.)
column4: * The primitive can mean either the _heaven_ of eternal bliss or the general term for sky, the _heavens_. Pay special attention to the fact that in its primitive form the first stroke is written right to left, rather like the first stroke of thousand (Frame 40), rather than left to right. From the next character, we shall give it the primitive meaning of a _witch_.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 14-1-2006(123): If you think of the sky as a _ceiling_ above our heads, here you have the **heavens** as the _largest ceiling_ you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the _ceiling_ primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 26-10-2006(48): The _ceiling_ that all _large dogs_ aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, _All Dogs Go to Heaven_.
column7: 3) [[igordesu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/igordesu)] 29-11-2008(32): The BIG ONE lives upstairs, in the **heavens** …
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-5-2009(20): Tip: 天 and 夭 ( _heavens_ and _sapling_ ) are different, but RTK confuses them sometimes. The latter appears in numbers 634, 938, 2078, 2079, 2080, and all characters containing _angel_ 喬 (429, 430, 1221, 2104, 2120, 2369).
column9: 5) [[jmlst79](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jmlst79)] 2-9-2009(16): Not all dogs go to heaven - only _one_ _St. Bernard_ gets to go (because he's a "Saint" Bernard).

column3: You are **bewitched**  by a _woman_ who is, of course, a _witch_.
column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 19-2-2007(56): If you don't want to get **bewitched** (and who would?), then avoid any _woman_ you see carrying what might appear to be a _sapling_. It's really a wand in disguise, and if you're not aware you might get **bewitched**.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 12-10-2008(26): I was **bewitched** by the _woman fairy_ (like an angel, but not as tall).
column7: 3) [[iSoron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/iSoron)] 14-12-2008(11): Primitive: fallen angel.
column8: 4) [[Hoticehunter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hoticehunter)] 23-3-2012(10): _sigh_. For some reason, Heisig never seems to understand the difference between 夭 and 天 . This uses the former, which means young/sapling. Surely it's not hard to imagine a young witch messing up a spell and accidentally bewitching everyone around her?
column9: 5) [[Dartlak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dartlak)] 31-5-2012(7): **Bewitched** _women_ can't come into the _heavens_.

column3: Suffering from a drought, the farmers call on a _witch_  who conjures up _water_  to **irrigate**  their crops.
column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 16-5-2007(62): You use _water_ to **irrigate** your _saplings_.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 12-10-2008(22): A _fairy_ needs a lot of _water_ to **irrigate** those beating wings, so you have make sure they drink a lot to be well **irrigate** d (see [bewitched](../v4/2078.html) (#2078 妖).
column7: 3) [[lernsky](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lernsky)] 10-1-2013(14): _Water_ from the _heavens_ is nature's way of **irrigating**.
column8: 4) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 7-6-2008(5): **Irrigation** is the method used to _water_ crops instead of relying on the gods in the _heavens_ to send them _drops_ as if they were _dogs_ waiting for a _sapling_ to be tossed for them to catch and retrieve.
column9: 5) [[saizen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saizen)] 13-11-2008(3): _Water_ being used to **irrigate** the _sapplings_ as it is a drought.

column3: The **bridge** shown here is made of _trees_ in their natural form, except that the trunks have been carved into the forms of _angels_ , a sort of "Ponte degli Angeli."
column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 27-7-2006(130): The nicest **bridge** is not in Holly _wood_ or Los _Angel_ es, but in San Francisco.
column6: 2) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 30-10-2007(93): A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, "Don't worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you." The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, "What are you doing with that wood?" "I'm trying to build a **bridge** to heaven to visit the angels.".
column7: 3) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 23-3-2008(52): **BRIDGE** makes me remember a tacky religious icon of my youth, showing a guardian _angel_ guiding two bonny children over a dangerously tatty _wooden_ **BRIDGE** , by pure chance (ahem) I found the picture online, see <http://www.sacredtreasures.org/yahoo_site_admin/assets/images/Guardian_angel_on_the_Bridge.199121024_std.jpg> 'Angel', incidentally, means 'messenger', hence two mouths - one who gave the message above, the other who delivered it here below.
column8: 4) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 28-7-2008(45): The _wooden_ **bridge** is guarded by an impressively tall _angel_.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 16-6-2008(23): ANGEL primitive: On the bottom there is a HOODED MOUTH, which you can think of as a NUN, and shes praying to an ANGEL, which is the HEAVENLY MOUTH above.

column3: Associating a particularly **attractive** _woman_ you know with an _angel_ should be no problem.
column5: 1) [[Deonnn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Deonnn)] 21-11-2007(139): The most **attractive** _woman_ in the world is obviously _Angelina_ Jolie.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 23-4-2007(125): The most **attractive** of _women_ are said to resemble _angels_. Similarly, _angelic_ _women_ tend to be **attractive**.
column7: 3) [[whistler11](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/whistler11)] 3-7-2006(40): Be careful not to confuse this with _exquisite_ (women + few - frame [123]). I try to keep them distinct by remembering that all _women_ _angels_ are **attractive** , but few women are truly exquisite.
column8: 4) [[abbott](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abbott)] 24-6-2008(21): **Attractive** _women_ are usually no _angels_. On the contrary, they are usually quite bitchy.
column9: 5) [[harusame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harusame)] 7-8-2009(13): Just because a _woman_ is **attractive** doesn't mean she's an _angel_.

column3: This picture of a vase **standing up** has its meaning extended to represent the general posture of anything **standing up**.
column4: * Used as a primitive, it can also mean _vase_. Using its kanji meaning, think of something _standing up_ that is normally lying down, or something standing up in an unusual way.
column5: 1) [[kitchen_sink](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kitchen_sink)] 14-8-2007(88): A vase that can't **stand up** won't be a vase for long.
column6: 2) [[andrewlandry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/andrewlandry)] 30-3-2009(26): This is a real **stand up** vase. It even wears a top hat!
column7: 3) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 2-9-2007(26): He was a **stand up** guy: he'd lend you the top hat he wears everyday if you asked, and he will turn everything upside down to help you find your tools.
column8: 4) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 12-12-2008(13): **Stand up** a vase on a table and put a top hat on it and then represent it pictographically and there you have this kanji!
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-7-2009(8): If i'm feeling _horn_ y, I cover the area with my _top hat_ when I **stand up**.

column3: One **cries** and **cries** until one is _standing up_ knee-deep in _water_ (or until one has a _vase_ -full of _water_ ).
column5: 1) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 25-10-2007(104): Guys have two ways of watering when they are standing, the less common one is **cry** ing.
column6: 2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 1-2-2008(71): She _stood up_ to leave the room when her eyes started to _water_ …
column7: 3) [[vxnine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vxnine)] 20-1-2009(36): This won't make sense for anyone who hasn't played the game, but for those who have, it'll make this character very easy to remember. Just picture that one scene in Final Fantasy VII where Cloud is _standing_ in the _water_ about to let Aeris go… A very sad scene which can make anyone **cry**.
column8: 4) [[phauna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phauna)] 19-2-2008(28): I imagine Alice (in Wonderland) standing in a pool of her own making, **cry** ing to herself.
column9: 5) [[salvw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/salvw)] 17-12-2008(25): If you **cry** really hard you can fill up a vase with the water from your tears.

column3: Try to imagine a club **badge** pinned to your lapel in the form of a mammoth _sunflower_ protruding from a wee little _vase_.
column5: 1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 21-11-2007(189): In the military, **badge** s are given out _early_ in the day, with everyone _standing_ at attention.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 9-1-2006(121): Ash Ketchum _stood_ up _early_ in the morning, and said, "Pikachu, let's go get us another **badge**!".
column7: 3) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 12-1-2010(36): Those who STAND UP EARLY receive a **BADGE**. ショウ 文章 ぶんしょう(a sentence).
column8: 4) [[kyotokanji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kyotokanji)] 18-4-2007(24): Only British people will understand this, sorry. Remember the Blue Peter **badge** s and the yearly sunflower competition? Imagine a group of sunflowers, many of then dropping but one is standing well and looking great. This is the obvious winner for the Blue Peter **badge**.
column9: 5) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 13-5-2007(15): Taking a bunch of _vases_ and painting _sunflowers_ on the bottom is the only way for a Girl Scout to get her arts and crafts merit **badge**.

column3: Two _teenagers_ are seen here _standing up_ to one another, **vying** for the attention of their peers.
column5: 1) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 26-2-2008(158): TWO twin BROTHERS are competing (VYING) for the title of who is the older BROTHER. The game is that they must balance a VASE on their head and the one who drops his looses and becomes the younger BROTHER!
column6: 2) [[mbagsh55](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mbagsh55)] 18-9-2007(66): Two crazy brothers vying for the guiness records books of stupidity by trying to stand on their heads the longest.
column7: 3) [[tummai](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tummai)] 23-6-2008(31): Roman times. Coliseum. Two _teenagers_ with _vases_ of acid strapped to their heads. They **vie** with one another, each trying to break the vase on their opponent's head. Imagine what happens to the loser when his vase breaks. To avoid confusion with "contend", "war", etc, remember that **Vie** and Vase both start with "v".
column8: 4) [[rhclaghorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rhclaghorn)] 26-12-2007(26): Twin _brothers_ lined up side to side, each **VIE** to _stand_ taller than the other.
column9: 5) [[stupiddog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stupiddog)] 31-5-2009(10): My two _elder brothers_ **vied** to impress the same girl by singing under her window. Unimpressed by the performance, both of her neighbours dropped their _vases_ on them.

column3: An uncommon, but not altogether unlikely picture of a reigning **sovereign** has him _standing up_ in his _apron_ , presumably at the behest of HIS **sovereign** (she who is to be obeyed), who needs help with washing the dishes.
column5: 1) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 6-7-2006(254): The crazy **sovereign** stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That's why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public.
column6: 2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 16-2-2008(51): This one is so tricky for me. The key is to remember that the bottom stroke on the _standing_ element takes those little crown "winglets" on the right and left. The most effective image might be of QEII (who is quite short) using her crown as a kind of stool. She's _standing_ on her _crown_ rummaging through a high cupboard looking for her _apron._ I guess the **sovereign** 's servants have the day off.
column7: 3) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 31-3-2007(34): Imaging queen Elizabeth…england's **SOVEREIGN** as she STANDS at the sink doing dishes wearing nothing but an APRON.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 21-7-2009(15): The **sovereign** likes to make his female servants _stand_ around in nothing but _aprons_. Can't say I blame him.
column9: 5) [[Wisher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wisher)] 31-8-2008(12): The first thing you need to be a **SOVEREIGN** , is to STAND TALL above your people and inspire them with confidence. The second would be to wear a cool CROWN. Third and most important, please wear underwear or at least a TOWEL to cover up you privates. People are going to be "looking up to you." (Inspired by WithLoveFromExIA's post).

column3: The key word **renunciation**  has to do with the wisdom and clarity of mind in knowing when to "let go." This is what makes the  _words_  of acquiescense _sovern_.
column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 1-7-2007(61): The _words_ of the _sovereign_ king inspire the people: never **give up**! Never surrender! Okay…maybe it wasn't a king.
column6: 2) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 8-8-2009(47): Anytime I think to **give up** Japanese, I remember giving my _word_ that I would become _sovereign_ of Japanese! And I watch あきら to get pumped about it. Note: to **give up** \- 諦める is read あきらめる).
column7: 3) [[GoodSirJava](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GoodSirJava)] 28-6-2008(31): You can go to Wikipedia and hear the _words_ of Japan's _sovereign_ Emperor Hirohito announcing that Japan would be **giving up** World War Two. (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gyokuon-h%C5%8Ds%C5%8D> under External Links).
column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(16): The _words_ of the _sovereign_. Abridged translation of Hirohito's _words_ of 15 August 1945: 'We **give up** '.
column9: 5) [[Puchatek](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Puchatek)] 25-7-2011(3): _Socrates_ convinced the _sovereign_ to proclaim his own renunciation - he was a bad _sovereign_ after all, _standing up_ all the time wearing only his _crown_ and _towel_.

column3: This frame shows up the image of a **juvenile** hacker _standing_ on top of a _computer_ , or rather jumping up and down on it, because it refused to come up with the right answer.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 15-10-2007(260): The **juvenile** stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 16-1-2008(39): The movie Zoolander is a little **JUVENILE** and silly, but I love it nonetheless. Just remember Owen Wilson _standing_ on the desk, hitting the _computer_ like a monkey. (The files are IN the computer - IN the computer…).
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 22-12-2007(29): This one is really easy if you gave [ri](../v4/173.html) (#173 里) the meaning "House of the Fathers". Most **juvenile** people _stand_ on the _house of their fathers_ , because they can't yet afford their own house.
column8: 4) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 22-10-2009(15): Watch this **juvenile** at youtube and you will not forget the **juvenile** _standing_ on _the computer_! ([http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GwOv0xg31nk&feature=related](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GwOv0xg31nk&feature=related), or search: "angry German kid").
column9: 5) [[slats70](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/slats70)] 9-10-2008(11): **Juvenile** stands up in from of the computer so you cant see the porn hes looking at.

column3: Begin with the double meaning of the key word **pupil** : "student" and the "the apple of one's _eye_. " Now all you have to do is dwell on the phrase " _juvenile_ of one's _eye_ " (the meaning here) until it provides you with an image.
column5: 1) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 20-6-2007(346): In Japanese comics, the eye's of juvenilles all have enormouse **pupil** s.
column6: 2) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 6-12-2007(116): WARNING: This kanji only means the **pupil** of the _eye_. It can be confusing to use a story that has **pupil** meaning student in it.
column7: 3) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 15-11-2008(97): In Japanese comics, the eye's of juveniles all have enormous **pupil** s. WARNING: This kanji only means the **pupil** of the eye. It can be confusing to use a story that has **pupil** meaning student in it. (greenapple + codexus).
column8: 4) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 3-4-2006(27): The _juvenile_ hacker stared at his monitor for so long in the dark that his _eye_ s no longer have **pupil** s.
column9: 5) [[Jupiter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jupiter)] 22-12-2008(11): Juveniles on drugs have dilating **pupil** s.

column3: This **bell** is made of cheap _metal_ , and so badly made that when you ring it, it lets out a noise like the " **bell** owing" of _juveniles_ who aren't getting their own way.
column5: 1) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 24-9-2007(303): The METAL **bell** rings to call the JUVENILES to class.
column6: 2) [[LouiseD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LouiseD)] 5-12-2009(29): The golden moment for juveniles is when the **bell** rings at school.
column7: 3) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 4-8-2008(27): The METAL **bell** rings to call the JUVENILES to COMPUTER class.
column8: 4) [[CSBarnes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CSBarnes)] 14-12-2008(13): Remember that show, Saved by the **Bell**? It had a bunch of _juveniles_ in it, and in one episode they actually tried stealing the **bell** because it was made of _gold_!
column9: 5) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 29-3-2008(11): What _metal_ object would a _juvenile delinquent_ be forced to carry around? Why, the little **BELL** locked on his ankle to warn people he's coming.

column3: See the peddlar _standing_ atop his _motorcycle helmet_ as if it were a soapbox, hawking his wares to passersby. The _legs_ and _mouth_ represent the tools of the trade of **making a deal** any way you can.
column5: 1) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 21-2-2007(327): I use what I think is the real etymology for this kanji which is so shocking it sticks. The STANDING member at the top is a certain part of the body that all men have and it is approaching the HOLE between TWO LEGS (the HOOD) with extra marks to show they are FLESHY - ie a womans legs. So this shows the oldest DEAL of all time - prostitution.
column6: 2) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 21-3-2006(86): Slick Willy standing on the motorcycle helmet he's trying to sell you to demonstrate how rugged it is. His legs crash through the top of it and after a moment of awkward silence his mouth opens and says, "hey, we can still **make a deal**.".
column7: 3) [[Dagur](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dagur)] 6-11-2008(76): _Four_ loud _mouths_ trying to **make a deal** on a _vase_.
column8: 4) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 10-3-2009(33): NOT a vase or stand up but actually represents a penis, as subtly pointed out by samuize. The kinky man goes to see the _hooded_ prositute to **make a deal** involving his _penis_ and her _legs_ and _mouth_ ). Apologies for the rudeness, but that's what it's about.
column9: 5) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 31-7-2008(21): At the beginning of **Star Wars VI: Return of the Jedi** , Luke Skywalker is _standing_ at the edge of a giant sand pit, awaiting to to be consumed by the Sarlacc, a giant ant lion-like creature that lives in the pit. While Luke is standing there, _legs_ dangling over the huge mouth of the creature, he makes a last plea with Jabba the Hut to **make a deal** , but Jabba only laughs.

column3: The phrase **legitimate wife** would have no meaning if there were not such things as  "illegitimate wives," taken because one's legal _woman_ has turned into an _antique_. The very offense of the idea should help you remember the kanji.
column5: 1) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 11-5-2007(170): Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.
column6: 2) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 5-12-2009(91): Your **legitimate wife** is like an antique bong. Its not your favorite but you still hit it sometimes…
column7: 3) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 24-3-2008(81): The _woman_ you'll want to be with even when you're both _antique_ should be your **LEGITIMATE WIFE**.
column8: 4) [[Biene](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Biene)] 19-5-2012(36): When the **legitimate wife** finds her husband flirting with another _woman_ , she'll take the valuable _antique Ming-vase_ and whacks him with it over the head. That should teach him a lesson!
column9: 5) [[isharabash](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/isharabash)] 17-7-2009(16): The **legitimate wife** is the woman who gets your antiques when you die!

column3: Can you imagine anything less **suitable** to do with one's precious _antiques_ than to display them in the middle of a crowded _road-way_?
column5: 1) [[fredde79](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fredde79)] 2-9-2007(320): Think of the term from televison "suitable for all audiences" to get the sense of the word. What program could be more **suitable** for the whole family than the " _antiques_ _road_ (show)".
column6: 2) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 26-4-2008(75): It's an _antique_ , but it's still **suitable** for the _road_.
column7: 3) [[OrangeNut](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/OrangeNut)] 11-1-2009(54): Even today, some _antique_ Roman _roads_ are **suitable** for travel.
column8: 4) [[chrislewisca](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chrislewisca)] 13-9-2006(48): That old thing in your attic might be **suitable** to be shown on the _Antiques_ _Road_ show.
column9: 5) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 7-6-2008(17): That **antique road** isn't **suitable** for travel.

column3: Picture _water_ **dripping** on what you thought were precious _antiques_ , only to find that the artificial aging painted on them is running!

column7: 3) [[elhnad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elhnad)] 9-1-2008(46): The _antique_ faucet **DRIPS** _water_.

column9: 5) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 14-7-2008(14): I don't get where people are pulling vases' out of, (antique already INCLUDES vase….) ANYWAY… AN ANTIQUE TAP WILL ALWAYS **DRIP** WATER…. new ones are better designed and never **drip**.

column3: Picture your most precious _antique_ (it doesn't matter how old it really is, so long as it is the oldest thing YOU own) being knocked over by your most unlikeable _taskmaster_ , and you have a good picture of how people make themselves **enemies** for life.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 15-10-2007(173): The _taskmaster_ became my **enemy** for life when he smashed the _antique vase_ holding my wife's ashes.
column6: 2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 28-1-2008(31): For us Miami Cubans, that _antique taskmaster_ (Fidel) is the **enemy**.
column7: 3) [[elanlan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elanlan)] 7-2-2009(25): For the academics: (I always view a taskmaster as being a professor) An _antique taskmaster_ \- or professor with an outdated and inefficient teaching philosophy - is your **enemy** in regard to accumulating knowledge.
column8: 4) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 19-3-2009(22): Link must destroy ANTIQUE vases to replenish items when fighting the TASKMASTER, his main **ENEMY**.
column9: 5) [[Lozza](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lozza)] 22-10-2008(17): In Indy Jones movies the **enemy** is always a taskmaster who is after antiques.

column3: This character, a pictograph of a **spoon** , is easy enough to remember, provided you keep it distinct from that for _seven_ , where the first stroke is written left to right (the opposite of here) and cuts noticeably across the second.
column4: * As a primitive, this kanji can take on the additional meaning of someone _sitting on the ground_ , of which it can also be considered a pictograph. In general, the second stroke does not cut through the first - or if it does in some fonts, only slightly.
column5: 1) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 3-9-2007(146): To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku…with a **spoon**. <http://tinyurl.com/co48k>.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 16-1-2008(52): Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the _direction_ of a stroke. In both 'spoon' and 'seven', the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in 'seven' it is a strong line from left to right.
column7: 3) [[delbertmon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/delbertmon)] 22-2-2010(41): Just remember it.
column8: 4) [[samesong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samesong)] 13-7-2008(13): I sat on the ground, feeding myself jelly with a **spoon**.
column9: 5) [[checkmoruk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/checkmoruk)] 2-11-2010(3): Imagine Winnie the Pooh sitting on the ground eating honey with a **spoon**.

column3: Recall some particularly harsh **scolding**  you got as a child in school. This character has you _sitting on the ground_  in the corner as your teacher stands over you, her _mouth_  wide open as she reprimands you in front of the entire class.
column5: 1) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 20-3-2006(78): A kid gets **scold** ed if they don't put the _spoon_ properly into their _mouth_ when eating.
column6: 2) [[Yozora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yozora)] 6-9-2009(36): Kids get **scold** ed if they don't open their MOUTH to take their SPOONFUL of medicine.
column7: 3) [[paasan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paasan)] 5-7-2010(12): Here's a story I read many years ago in a magazine. It was about a girl who was lonely and wanting and decided to play with a banana. While doing this, she suddenly heard her parents returning home, and being startled, the banana broke inside her. Her mom then had to use a spoon to get the banana out of this poor girl while she was being **scolded**. So actually, this is a pictograph..
column8: 4) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 21-6-2008(12): Well, how do you picture getting **SCOLD** ED? You listen to that MOUTH while you have to SIT DOWN there and take it.
column9: 5) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 11-11-2010(5): This is NOT spoon. The first stroke of the RHS goes beyond the second stroke. It's diced. STORY: When I try to make dinner, my wife **scold** s me because of my poor dicing technique. "This is too big! It will never fit in our mouths! Dice it again!".

column3: You will have to imagine "capturing" a favorite **aroma** by having it gagged and _bound up_  in a _spoon_.
column5: 1) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 5-7-2008(41): The BOUND UP SITTING MAN is going crazy because he can smell the **aroma** of fresh cinnamon buns, but can't get out of the ropes.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 13-10-2008(34): The muchacho _sits down bound up_ to enjoy his own **aroma**.
column7: 3) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 10-6-2010(26): The **aroma** of any delicacy is _bound up_ in a _spoon_.
