column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 16-7-2009(16): Your girlfriend comes up from behind you in bed on a cold winter's night and _spoons_ you. She gets the blankets and tucks them in on both sides so the two of you are _bound up_ tightly. Everything's perfect, until you release your foul **aroma** \- silent but deadly, like a ninja.
column9: 5) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 3-4-2010(15): Note that 匂 （ におい） means good smell and 臭 （におい） [stinking](../v4/122.html) (#122 臭) means bad smell. Story: Cheech/the muchacha (#451 渇) smells the **aroma** of tacos but he spent all his money on dope.

column3: When Uncle Bob starts his comic routine of sticking _spoons_ on his _head_ , you know it is **about that time**  to come up with a reason to excuse yourself.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 24-6-2007(164): An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at **about that time** the clock reaches out with a _spoon_ and hits you on the _head_.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 29-11-2008(47): After _spooning_ for hours it's **about that time** he got some _head_. Dayum woman.
column7: 3) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 22-11-2008(9): **About that time** to sit down and get some head.
column8: 4) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 5-6-2010(7): 子供の頃 I used to hit my HEAD with a SPOON.
column9: 5) [[manubear](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/manubear)] 10-8-2012(4): When your host starts hitting himself on the _head_ with a _spoon_ , you realise it's **about that time** to make your excuses and leave! ( この頃 ).

column3: The cold air from the **north** is so strong that we see _two people sitting on the ground_ back to back, their arms interlocked so they don't blow away. (Pay special attention to the drawing of the first 3 strokes.)
column5: 1) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 17-12-2007(148): **Warning:** The left part is NOT the primitive _turtle_! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!
column6: 2) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 20-3-2008(122): In the **north** , the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.
column7: 3) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 25-6-2008(70): Codexus wrote: **Warning:** The left part is NOT the primitive _turtle_! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference! My 'story': There are NO _turtles_ at the **North** Pole. What looks like turtle-backs are actually Igloos, so small you can barely _sit_ inside them.
column8: 4) [[alatown](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alatown)] 5-8-2009(17): The **north** is cold, so why doesn't this couple spoon to keep warm?
column9: 5) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 9-4-2008(11): People! this has nothing to do with turtles. The strokes are different. Don't use turtle in this story. Just stick to the people sitting back to back in the cold **north**.

column3: One's **stature** is measured according to the  " _northern_ -most" _part of the body_.
column5: 1) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 23-5-2007(144): While japanese people are generally small, people in the northern contryes have taller **stature** because of all the flesh they eat!
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 16-1-2008(68): Up in the Great White _North_ , we eat a lot of _meat_ \- thus giving us great **STATURE**. Mmmm…. baby seals.
column7: 3) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 5-6-2009(46): Peter _North_ is well known for his **stature**. You know, the size of his _flesh_.
column8: 4) [[stringy_cow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stringy_cow)] 12-1-2009(38): **Stature** /height has to do with how far "NORTH"(upward?XD) your FLESH/BODY goes.
column9: 5) [[vinniram](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vinniram)] 20-12-2009(19): Your **STATURE** is measured from the _northern_ most _part of your body_.

column3: With _two spoons_ , one in each hand, you are **comparing** your mother's cooking with your mother-in-law's.
column5: 1) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 13-10-2008(169): **Compare** the two spoons… the one on the left is funny-looking.
column6: 2) [[gpetroce](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gpetroce)] 9-6-2007(160): A gay couple about to turn around to **compare** which role is better…
column7: 3) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 3-9-2007(38): "Its like **comparing** apples and oranges," you say as you hold an apple in a spoon in one hand and an orange in a spoon in the other.
column8: 4) [[Kieron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kieron)] 7-5-2007(25): In the kitchen, **compare** the taste of the two dishes you're stirring with a _spoon_ in each. Mmm!
column9: 5) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 16-1-2008(15): **Comparing** cooking with two _spoons_ \- my mother's homemade in one spoon, and Philipino food, oddly enough, in the other. There's no comparison! (Note that this kanji can also be used for the Philipines).

column3: By _comparing_ apes with anthropoids, we not only discover the latter have **descended** from those progenitors educated in the higher branches, but that the very idea of seeing everything **descended** from everything else, one way or another, means that there is  "nothing new UNDER the _sun_. "
column5: 1) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 21-2-2007(241): Grandparent spends all DAY COMPARING photos of their **DESCENDANTS**.
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 10-3-2008(114): Japanese people have compared themselves as being **descendants** of the sun. (Amaterasu, the sun godesss). Sun, comparing = **descendants**.
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 16-1-2008(48): Ask a Japanese person what this kanji means, and they will surely spout 昆布 (konbu, seaweed) and 昆虫 (konchu, insect) - but beyond that they will likely be mystified. Here's my best crack at it: imagine a grandfather watching his DESCENDENTS (grandkids) playing outside under the _sun_ , silently _comparing_ them, considering which of them will grow up and make him proud. Suddenly, grandma calls them in for a snack of 昆布 and for a re-application of repellent to keep the 昆虫 away.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 30-8-2007(46): My official rebuttal to racism: We're all **descendants** of the _sun_ \- there's no reason to _compare_ us.
column9: 5) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 25-6-2008(32): We're all **descendants** of chimps, get over it, don't spend all [day](../v4/12.html) (#12 日) trying to [compare](../v4/447.html) (#447 比) various religious fairytales.

column3: Think of the housewives in TV commercials " _comparing_ the _whiteness_ " of their laundry across the fence, a typical advertisement for the popular detergent known as **All**. (If you don't know the brand, surely you've heard the phrases  " **all** -purpose detergent" or " **all** -temperature detergent.")
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 25-1-2007(227): If you _compare_ colors, you will find that _white_ is produced from the mix of **all** the others.
column6: 2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 29-1-2008(141): Sometimes, Dr. Heisig's keyword choices are really quite bizarre. This doesn't mean **all** , it means **everyone**!! Picture two ku klux klansmen _comparing_ whose _skin_ is whiter…finally, they agree that **everyone** there is white.
column7: 3) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 10-2-2008(42): **皆** さん、 **みんな** さん, lets **all** _compare_ our _whites_! This could be a line from a Japanese soap commercial or analysis the Republican presidential candidates…..
column8: 4) [[Deonnn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Deonnn)] 26-11-2007(34): If we _compare_ ourselves to the perfect purity (the _whiteness_ ) that God demands of us, we see that " **all** have sinned and fall short of the glory of God" (Romans 3:23).
column9: 5) [[stupiddog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stupiddog)] 31-5-2009(21): **All** detergents claim that, when _comparing_ to other brands, they produce the _whitest_ laundry. But you can save lots of cash when you realize that they're **all** ok.

column3: The key word refers to kanji that are written in full, squared form, as opposed to cursive writing which is more flowing andabbreviates some of the strokes. Here **block letters** are pictured as tidy rows of _trees_ that are _all_ the same size and can be read easily by _all_ , whatever calligraphic skills they possess.
column5: 1) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 5-7-2010(25): **Print-style writing** (as opposed to cursive): _All_ **print-style writing** looks rather _wooden_ to me. I prefer the fancy curves of cursive. (Note: Heisig gives this character the official keyword "block letters," but based on what I've read about the meaning of the character in the Yahoo! Japan Dictionary, I prefer "print-style writing").
column6: 2) [[Magnus13](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Magnus13)] 10-7-2011(15): **Block letters** (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like _wood_ , they're _all_ the same size so that _all_ can read them.
column7: 3) [[enoonyllaer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enoonyllaer)] 21-8-2010(15): _all_ the hiragana are in "block letters" on _wooden_ blocks, like children's toys.
column8: 4) [[FoxintheStars](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FoxintheStars)] 14-1-2011(4): Literally the **block letters** on children's blocks, carved into _wood_ so clearly that _all_ can read them.
column9: 5) [[Aeryon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aeryon)] 24-1-2012(3): At the base of the tree, in white **block letters** is written the following, "In 1911, 3 men sat here and compared the whiteness of their skins. In the end it was determined that they were all white.".

column3: The harmoney of "a place for everything and everything in its place" is applied here to the **orderliness** of _all_ the _words_ one speaks.
column5: 1) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 11-1-2010(38): **harmonious** : If a choir is to be **harmonious** , _all_ the voices need to combine to hit the right notes, and say the right _words_.
column6: 2) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 14-9-2010(14): Think of a chat in which _everyone_ is writing _words_ at once, of the lack of **orderliness** of such a chat.
column7: 3) [[chameleoncoder](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chameleoncoder)] 19-8-2010(11): To have **orderliness** , your _words_ must be in _all_ the right places.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 1-6-2011(8): 起立 (きりつ)！ Hearing these _words_ , _all_ the students immediately stand at attention. The **orderliness** of classes in Japan is incredible.
column9: 5) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 5-7-2010(8): **to be in sync** : The _words_ a choir sings must _all_ **be in sync**. ~~~ (Note: According to Yahoo! 辞書 , this character means something like "to harmonize/to mitigate." I chose **to be in sync** as the keyword to both avoid conflicting with other keywords and to capture the general meaning of the kanji that can be applied to the various compounds that use it.).

column3: **Mixed** marriages, this character suggests, _water_ down the quality of one's _descendants_  \- the oldest racial nonsense in the world!
column5: 1) [[zwarte_kat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zwarte_kat)] 16-10-2006(439): People have to **mix** their fluids (have sex), in order to create descendants.
column6: 2) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 2-6-2009(52): **Mixed** kids are _watered_ down _descendants_. But often the most attractive!
column7: 3) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 29-11-2008(23): **God's recipe for Life:** _1 spoonful of water (raw material), 1 spoonful of sunlight (energy)_. **MIX** thoroughly, and let stand very briefly. Don't let it sit for too long after **mix** ing (a few million years), or the **mix** may destroy itself, the **mix** ing bowl, and possibly the entire kitchen.
column8: 4) [[brunosprak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brunosprak)] 12-1-2008(14): It was a **MIX** of elements, happened millions of years ago, that created the first bacterias in the WATER. From them we are DESCENDANTS.
column9: 5) [[mcmike2099](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcmike2099)] 28-6-2009(9): Our **WATER DESCENDANTS** (i.e., mermaids), are a **mix** of man and fish.

column3: As you pass by the muchacho taking the _siesta_ , he cries out that he is **thirsty** and asks for something to drink. So you turn the _water_ hose on him.
column5: 1) [[wazzab](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wazzab)] 10-3-2007(133): You awaken from your _siesta_ because you feel extremely **thirst** y so you go looking for some _water_.
column6: 2) [[onsen_monkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/onsen_monkey)] 23-9-2006(72): The muchacho taking his SIESTA cries out that he is **THIRST** Y. So you pull out a bottle of WATER and pretend you're going to give it to him…but then you dump it all on the ground before his eyes. HAHA, sucked in muchacho!!
column7: 3) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 13-6-2007(36): This whole series is easy to me if you picture Cheech as the man taking the Siesta. "He man, you gotta drinka water man? I am like so **thirst** y I could die man.".
column8: 4) [[chibilchan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibilchan)] 1-9-2009(22): If anyone is having difficulty creating stories with the primitive _siesta_ , try changing it to _beggar_ \- a _beggar_ sits in his box begging for food/money under a hot sun. I have used _beggar_ as a primitive in several frames and it works like a charm. Here a _beggar_ develops a deep **thirst** for _water_ as he crouches in his box under the hot sun.
column9: 5) [[Bullwhip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Bullwhip)] 5-6-2008(18): Have some _water_ before you take a _siesta_ , or you will wake up **thirst** y!

column3: Imagine an **audience** with the emperor or the pope in which all those in attendance are sitting down, leaning against the wall, sleeping like our muchacho on _siesta_ as the honorable host delivers his _speech_.
column5: 1) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 26-11-2007(231): The _talk_ was so boring the **audience** took a _siesta_.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 30-10-2008(59): Note: The keyword meaning is "Have an **audience** with . . . (Pope, King, etc)". Story: When you arrive for your **audience** with the Pope, he appears to be dozing. His assistant says, "Sorry about your **audience** , but you won't get a _word_ out of him while he's having his _siesta_ ".
column7: 3) [[GenPDP7](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GenPDP7)] 20-12-2007(36): The man talking during his siesta (in his sleep) is saying strange things and drawing an **audience**.
column8: 4) [[lasercorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lasercorn)] 5-6-2008(24): A good **audience** doesn't _talk_ or take a _siesta_.
column9: 5) [[FuDaWei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FuDaWei)] 30-5-2010(10): The Pope granted an **AUDIENCE** to the entire Mexican village, but since he didn't _talk_ in Spanish, it quickly turned into a mass _siesta_.

column3: The color of the serape or _cloak_ of our muchacho on _siesta_ is a dull **brown** , the color this kanji indicates.
column5: 1) [[rhclaghorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rhclaghorn)] 26-12-2007(110): Why is my package late? Imagine a UPS driver dressed in **BROWN** _garments_ taking a _siesta_. What can **BROWN** do for you?
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 8-4-2008(88): Mexicans use a _cloak_ (pancho) for their _siestas_. Their color is usually **brown**.
column7: 3) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 31-1-2007(42): The hobbits from "The Lord of the Rings" just had to crawl under their **brown** _cloaks_ and they could take a _siesta_.
column8: 4) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 13-6-2007(30): Cheech, "Oh jeez, I Shit myself man! Now my clothes are all **brown** man…".
column9: 5) [[Stevieman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stevieman)] 19-3-2010(17): If you break up SIESTA into _tongue wagging in mouth_ , _bound up_ , _sitting man_ , you have somewhat the image of a prisoner begging. This gives you the general sense of _BEGGAR_. Using _BEGGAR_ as a primitive is better I think. A [thirst](../v4/451.html) (#451 渇) beggar begs for water. A beggar speaks requesting an [audience](../v4/452.html) (#452 謁)(to beg for money), a _BEGGAR'S GARMENTS_ are usually **brown** (dirty), and beggars sleep so much when they open their mouth, their voice is [hoarse](../v4/454.html) (#454 喝). (btw, chinese etymology: the bottom part of siesta means to beg).

column3: When the muchacho on _siesta_ looks up at you and opens his _mouth_ to talk, his voice is so **hoarse** that you cannot understand him.
column5: 1) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 1-4-2008(185): If you have a _siesta_ with your _mouth_ open, you will wake up with a **hoarse** voice.
column6: 2) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 17-7-2007(27): After taking a siesta, you find that your mouth is **hoarse** (after all you ARE thirsty remember).
column7: 3) [[zodiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zodiac)] 31-10-2008(25): When you are **hoarse** , it's time for your _mouth_ to have a _siesta_. (I don't like relating this to thirst, mixed them up a few times).
column8: 4) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 13-6-2007(10): Cheech's voice is always **hoarse**. Cheech, "Hey man you seen what happened to my mouth man? I can't talk right man.".
column9: 5) [[Stevieman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stevieman)] 19-3-2010(9): If you break up SIESTA into _tongue wagging in mouth_ , _bound up_ , _sitting man_ , you have somewhat the image of a prisoner begging. This gives you the general sense of _BEGGAR_. Using _BEGGAR_ as a primitive is better I think. A [thirst](../v4/451.html) (#451 渇) beggar begs for water. A beggar speaks requesting an [audience](../v4/452.html) (#452 謁)(to beg for money), a beggar's garments are usually [brown](../v4/453.html) (#453 褐)(dirty), and _BEGGARS SLEEP_ so much when they open their _MOUTH_ , their voice is **hoarse**. (btw, chinese etymology: the bottom part of siesta means to beg).

column3: **Kudzu**  is a word taken over from Japanese to name the crawling vines that creep up and completely take over trees. Seeing it at its worst in the Georgia countryside makes it easy to understand why it has a reputation as the "plague of the South." From there it should not be hard to arrange the primitives, _flowers_  and _siesta_  into a memorable image.
column5: 1) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 17-5-2008(78): Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a _siesta_ in the **kudzu** field. The **kudzu** grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the **kudzu** _flowers_ mark his grave.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(15): The muchacho takes a _siesta_ under the _flowers_ of the **kudzu**.
column7: 3) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 11-1-2009(10): **Kudzu** is a _flowering_ plant that never takes a _siesta_ …it grows constantly and has already overtaken most of the southeastern United States. Beware the **kudzu**!
column8: 4) [[aaroncp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aaroncp)] 21-2-2011(6): Ok so I don't know about anyone else, but the bottom part of this kanji does not look like _siesta_ on this site. In the supplement pdf it does, but not here so I came up with this: **Kudzu** vines and _flowers_ grow so fast by _day_ that by night they have _bound up_ all the _animal legs_ in the forest like _fish hooks_ bind fish. It is long and convoluted, but it contains everything similar to the elements here.
column9: 5) [[amillerchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amillerchip)] 8-1-2012(3): My Windows font is displaying the traditional form of this character, however the bottom primitive is _siesta_ as listed. A couple of links to confirm: <http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/845b/browsertest.htm> <http://jisho.org/kanji/details/%E8%91%9B> Also I'd never heard of **kudzu** before, so thought I might as well rename this to **くず** and learn the reading too.

column3: Something is so downright **delicious** that one spends the entire _day_ with a _spoon_ in hand gobbling it up.
column5: 1) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 5-4-2007(133): Use a _spoon_ to eat a **DELICIOUS** hot fudge _sun_ dae. Duh..
column6: 2) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 11-6-2008(105): It's sooo **delicious** I could _spoon_ it in all _day_.
column7: 3) [[Sevenhelmets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sevenhelmets)] 5-8-2008(45): Instructions for **delicious** : 1. Find said **delicious** 2\. Get _spoon_ 3\. Spend all _day_ eating.
column8: 4) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 13-4-2010(24): In Japan, you basically have to _wag your tongue_ after each _spoonful_ you eat in order to talk about how **delicious** the food is. To learn this just watch Japanese television, on basically any channel, for 15 minutes. Girls say 'oishii', but guys usually use 'umai,' which is written with this very kanji: 旨い (うまい).
column9: 5) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 14-12-2008(24): That girl was so **delicious** I could spoon her all day :P.

column3: This kanji tells us that if you feed the _flesh_ with too many _delicious_ things, it soon picks up a thick layer of **fat**.
column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 17-7-2007(212): Every chef will tell you, **fat** is what make the meat taste delicious.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-8-2007(60): **Fat** is the most _delicious_ part of the _flesh_. (Note this refers to physical **fat** , not the concept of obesity [obese](../v4/494.html) (#494 肪)).
column7: 3) [[Lizzie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lizzie)] 21-6-2008(18): Well, after months with nothing else but delicious food - of course you get **fat**!
column8: 4) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 18-12-2007(13): Delicious SUNdaes will put some **fat** on your FLESH.
column9: 5) [[swamijade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/swamijade)] 9-5-2010(6): Think of the famous kobe beef: why is its _flesh_ so _delicious_? Why, it is so finely marbled with **fat**!

column3: Here you "savor your _words_ " as something _delicious_  when you describe your recent **visit to a shrine**  or pilgrimage site.
column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 20-6-2009(66): You **visit a shrine** to _say_ your wishes and offer _delicious_ offering to the gods.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 24-7-2007(29): To fat, effete Japanophiles (cheerily munching on 肉まん in the back of the tour bus) hearing the _words_ of the tour guide "Now we will **visit a shrine** " elicits squeals of joy. "Oooooh, how absolutely _delicious_!".
column7: 3) [[kioku3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kioku3)] 25-8-2009(11): On New Year's Day, Japanese people usually read the _words_ written on their New Year's cards (nengajou - 年賀状 ), eat _delicious_ special New Year's foods and **visit a shrine** to pray for good luck in the coming year (thx mantixen).
column8: 4) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 27-7-2008(5): As a man of reason, _Socrates_ knows the only reason to **visit a shrine** is for the _delicious_ food.
column9: 5) [[paasan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paasan)] 26-7-2010(4): The only reason for me to **visit a shrine** is to see those _deliciously_ young shrine maidens. Oh, did I _say_ that out loud?

column3: The Roman numeral I - like that for II we met earlier in frame 379 - is only rarely used now. In the midst of all the _samurai_ , we notice one in particular _sitting on the ground_ with a _crown_ on his head, indicating that he is  "number I" in the current rankings.
column5: 1) [[phate1313](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phate1313)] 29-2-2008(187): I am 'the one' , says the samurai with the crown around his waist and a spoon up his a***.
column6: 2) [[p02115150](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/p02115150)] 4-11-2008(138): The samurai who has been crowned number one is so good he uses a spoon to fight with rather than a sword.
column7: 3) [[burritokun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burritokun)] 26-8-2008(39): Imagine Neo (a futuristic _samurai_ aka _The One_ ) wearing a Burger King crown, in the famous scene from the Matrix where he's told "There is no _spoon_.".
column8: 4) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 29-10-2007(23): Amidst all the rich _gentlemen_ the one with a _crown_ was born with a silver _spoon_ in his mouth, setting his place as the number I (one) richest person in the room.
column9: 5) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 18-12-2007(16): For those that live in Japan- There is a Curry shop chain called "CoCo ichiban", and they use this kanji on their sign. So…….. Picture an ancient CoCo ichiban, and the samurai get together for a "Super Number I Curry eating champion challenge." The winner dances around wearing a crown, while the losers sit on the ground with aching bellies.

column3: Behind **every** successful person _lies_ a woman...,  who usually turns out to be one's _mama_!
column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 4-1-2007(238): Freud believed **every** man wants to _lie down_ with his _mother_.
column6: 2) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 18-12-2007(60): Who does **every** person want to lie down with? Yo' MAMA!
column7: 3) [[marydj](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/marydj)] 8-10-2007(41): **Every** mother looks forward to the end of the day when she can finally lie down.
column8: 4) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 1-8-2008(25): Freud believed **every** man wants to _lie down_ with his _mother_ (see decameron)– AND he asked **every** one of his patients to recline on the sofa and talk about his Mom.
column9: 5) [[gopineapples](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gopineapples)] 28-5-2009(7): **Every** MAMA deserves to RECLINE and have a good rest.

column3: Behind _every_ successful _taskmaster_ , the **cleverness** of a fox to outwit his charges.
column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 28-3-2007(167): Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of **cleverness**.
column6: 2) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 15-4-2008(73): **Cleverness** is something _every_ _taskmaster_ must have. _Every_ _taskmaster_ has **cleverness**.
column7: 3) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 18-12-2007(34): For Assistant Language teachers….. It takes a lot of **cleverness** on the ALT's part to correct the JTE (TASKMASTER of the class) EVERY time he messes up his pronunciation, without embarassing him.
column8: 4) [[Dakoina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dakoina)] 6-2-2009(28): Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of **cleverness**. Note the "ever" in **cleverness** - > every.
column9: 5) [[jschekkerman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jschekkerman)] 23-4-2007(19): When mom's reclining on the sofa and the housework still gets done when and how she wants it (because she's the perfect taskmaster), that's **cleverness**.

column3: Behind _every_ Jack Horner's pie maker, a _tree_ full of **plums**.
column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 30-8-2007(185): **Plums** actually grow on every single tree. What, you didn't know that? They do. Orange trees, apple trees, cantaloupe trees. **Plum** s are simply mutant fruits that have been installed in the root software of every single tree. I hear that some **plum** -loving scientists are working on a way to hack _every_ _tree's_ genetic code so that _every tree_ will bear nothing _but_ **plum** s.
column6: 2) [[Spoonz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spoonz)] 1-3-2009(74): _every_ man's _wood_ has 2 **plum** s.
column7: 3) [[henroski](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/henroski)] 30-1-2008(66): EVERY Japanese person asks you if you like UMEBOSHI. No I say, I prefer to eat my **PLUM** S fresh from the TREE.
column8: 4) [[Sevenhelmets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sevenhelmets)] 30-7-2008(30): _Every_ _tree_ should be a **plum** _tree_.
column9: 5) [[Dagur](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dagur)] 19-11-2008(28): **Plum** _trees_ have fruit on _every_ branch.

column3: Behind _every drop of water_ , a **sea** from which it originated.
column5: 1) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 6-12-2007(184): _Every_ drop of _water_ will eventually return to the **sea**.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 9-8-2008(22): As depicted in the classic SF film _Fantastic Voyage_ , every drop of water is a **sea** , if you look close enough. Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast **sea** teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). **Note:** Take care not to confuse with [ocean](../v4/549.html) (#549 洋).
column7: 3) [[Ceryn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ceryn)] 24-3-2008(17): "WATER, WATER, EVERYwhere, And all the boards did shrink, WATER, WATER, EVERYwhere, Nor any drop to drink." Remember to take enough water with you when you go out to **SEA** or die like the sailors in The Rime of the Ancient Mariner.
column8: 4) [[kiisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kiisu)] 28-2-2008(16): There is water in every **sea**.
column9: 5) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 8-8-2007(11): My way of distinguishing this from [ocean](../v4/549.html) (#549 洋) 海 -うみ rhymes with **sea** 洋服 -ようふく (first syllable) rhymes with (first syllable) ocean.

column3: See someone _lying down_ in a public place with a _hook_ in place of a hand, **begging** a morsel of rice or a few pence.
column5: 1) [[Pauline](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pauline)] 4-6-2006(145): _Lying down_ , Captain _Hook_ is **beg** ging to be spared from the ticking crocodile.
column6: 2) [[penot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/penot)] 13-9-2008(90): Men **beg** _lying down_. Women **beg** as _hookers_.
column7: 3) [[Lizzie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lizzie)] 9-7-2008(36): People that **beg** have a hard time in Japan. They have to lay down, and for most of the time they only get fishguts.
column8: 4) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 9-10-2007(25): The girl **beg** ged to lie down with the heroin dealer because she was hooked and out of cash.
column9: 5) [[Cheesemaster64](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cheesemaster64)] 27-7-2008(23): The homeless man _lying_ on the street with a _hook_ for an arm **beg** ged us for anything we could spare.

column3: In times of **drought** anything at all will do. Here we see the victims _begging_ for just a little _mist_ for relief.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-8-2007(211): During a **drought** , everything _begs_ for even a _mist_ for relief.
column6: 2) [[TheMage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TheMage)] 11-10-2008(75): During a **drought** , even _mist_ is _begged_ for.
column7: 3) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 28-2-2007(56): Beggar has to drink mist because there is no water in the **drought**. I get this one confused with thirst 451 but try to remember that there is no water element beacuse it is a **drought**.
column8: 4) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 29-2-2008(23): The beggar is licking the ten sunflowers to get some moisture from the mist. Why? It has been a **drought**.
column9: 5) [[roderik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/roderik)] 21-6-2008(13): _Ten sunflowers_ _begged_ the rain gods for even a drip of mist, for there had been a **drought**.

column3: If you _double back_ (fold over) most animals - or people, for that matter - in the middle, the _part of the body_ where the crease comes is the **abdomen**.
column5: 1) [[KANJI](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/KANJI)] 28-11-2006(127): The only **body** part that **doubles over**.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 30-8-2007(66): Imagine getting punched in the **abdomen** , a fairly tender part of _flesh_ , and instead of doubling forward, you _double back_. That would be pretty painful.
column7: 3) [[elanlan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elanlan)] 17-6-2009(40): The _part of the body (flesh)_ that is exercised when we lie down and bring our _walking legs_ toward the _sun_ is the **abdomen** (aka: leglifts).
column8: 4) [[Ramchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ramchip)] 23-2-2007(19): Try not to confuse the primitive 'double back' and [fold](../v4/1130.html) (#1130 折). After I _backtracked_ from a long day of hiking, my **abdomen** was hungry for _flesh_ , so I ate a huge steak.
column9: 5) [[kiisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kiisu)] 3-3-2008(13): Well, flesh doubled over..and over .. think of the guts …in the **abdomen**.

column3: In its original and etymologically transparent sense, to **duplicate** something means to _double_ it _back_ with a fold, like the fold of a _cloak_.
column5: 1) [[akimoto](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akimoto)] 14-3-2007(238): My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change!
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 13-8-2007(187): In _Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban_ , Hermione uses a device called a "time-turner" to _double back_ in time, but this creates **duplicate** s. The smart thing to do would be to combine Hermione's time-turner with Harry's invisibility cloak. That way, one could _double back_ in time without creating any visible **duplicate** s.
column7: 3) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 13-7-2008(52): The magician took his CLOAK, FOLDED IT (DOUBLE BACKED IT) and **DUPLICATED** it!! Amaaaazing.
column8: 4) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 11-7-2007(32): St. Martin took his _cloak_ , _doubled it back_ , and cut it into two pieces effectively making a **duplicate** of his cape (duplicape) for the beggar.
column9: 5) [[Nihonnub](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nihonnub)] 29-5-2009(14): My girlfriend noticed that someone was wearing an exact **duplicate** of the _cloak_ she was told was one of a kind! So, she _laid_ there, _tongue wagging_ , _legs_ kicking throwing a right hissy fit![[I have trouble remembering 'double back'.. hope this helps anyone else who has the same problem! Also, thanks to akimoto for the girlfriend story]].

column3: The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back, the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth, and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a **lack** of something (psychologically, interest, physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see.
column4: * As a primitive, it can mean either _yawn_ or _lack_.
column5: 1) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 13-8-2007(138): To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who **lack** s a head.
column6: 2) [[bendyarm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bendyarm)] 5-10-2007(56): When your body **lack** s oxygen you _yawn_.
column7: 3) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 16-7-2008(40): A PERSON BOUND UP due to work is tired and **LACK** S sleep, hence YAWNS.
column8: 4) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 11-6-2008(14): I _yawn_ when I **lack** interest.
column9: 5) [[sprutnik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sprutnik)] 12-12-2008(12): A _bound up_ _person_ **lack** s his freedom.

column3: To **blow** is really no more than a deliberate effort to make one's _mouth lack_ all the air that is in it.
column5: 1) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 6-7-2008(281): This is clearly a **BLOW** JOB, we can see the MOUTH and the LACK OF condom. (I am sorry for the image, but it sticks forever in your mind).
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 21-1-2008(70): How am I supposed to **BLOW** if I _lack_ a _mouth_? (Imagine a kid at his own birthday party, and - like Neo in the Matrix - had no oriface where his mouth was to be. And yet, the people cruelly cheer him on to **blow** out his candles…).
column7: 3) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 29-7-2007(58): I keep confusing this with [suck](../v4/689.html) (#689 吸). Consider someone **blow** ing bubbles using their chewing gum because they're _lack_ ing attention in class.
column8: 4) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 6-4-2007(41): After your _mouth opens_ and you _yawn_ , you **BLOW** out a lot of air.
column9: 5) [[meredithcat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meredithcat)] 4-4-2010(25): **Blowing** makes your _mouth_ _lack_ air.

column3: Better to picture what happens when you do not pay attention to your work in the kitchen. Here we see a blazing _fire_ and an inattentive, _yawning_ **cook** who let things get out of control.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 8-1-2006(271): Japanese **cook** ing sometimes _lacks_ _fire_ , e.g., sashimi.
column6: 2) [[Deonnn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Deonnn)] 29-11-2007(63): This character shows the difference between a **cook** and a chef: a chef prepares food with passion and love, a **cook** only stands there with a pan over a _fire_ , with no passion and just _yawning_.
column7: 3) [[Lizzie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lizzie)] 21-6-2008(26): How can you **cook** something when you lack fire?
column8: 4) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 9-12-2006(26): This is the first kanji for rice **cook** er ( 炊飯器 ). The reason they came up with that device is the sheer amount of incidents of people's morning rice going up in flames while they were yawning, trying to keep awake.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 18-10-2005(17): Tip : if you have seen Hayao Miyazaki 's animated movie "Howl's moving castle" (Le Château Ambulant), you may use the image of the flame demon Calcifer for the fire primitive. Somewhere in the first part of the movie, after Sophie arrives at the castle, she tries to **cook** some ham with the help of _Calcifer (the flame demon)_ but he just complains and _yawns_!

column3: The **song** in this kanji is being sung by a chorus line of _can-can_ girls. Why it should be eliciting nothing but _yawning_ from the audience, I leave to you to decide.
column5: 1) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 4-4-2008(138): **Can- Can** -ers **lack** the ability to sing a **song** , so they just dance.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 17-12-2006(64): _Can-can_ dancers are supposed to be big-bosomed girls who dance. Yet these so called can-can dancers are flat-chested and singing a **song** , so audience of men is _yawn_ ing in boredom.
column7: 3) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 5-6-2009(38): Do you know the "Obama **song** "? It goes like: "Yes we _can_ , yes we _can_!" The problem is, the lyrics repeat so often that everybody starts _yawning_ sooner or later. - This is no political comment ,-).
column8: 4) [[BigAmish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BigAmish)] 15-8-2008(36): Modern **SONG** stresses have _doubly-nice CANs_ , but _LACK_ true musical talent.
column9: 5) [[kaeru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaeru)] 7-11-2008(18): The Idol contestants think "I CAN I CAN SING THIS **SONG** " but most of them LACK talent.

column3: If the cushions of one's _car_ are too **soft** , one may begin _yawning_ at the wheel.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 8-1-2006(166): Cars are rough steel things, lacking **soft** ness.
column6: 2) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 18-12-2007(115): If your _car_ has really **soft** seats, you may start _yawning_ and eventually fall asleep at the wheel (imagine that this seat is a huge **soft** beanbag that nearly swallows the driver, and it will be easier to remember).
column7: 3) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 4-10-2008(40): Someday, they will invent **SOFT** **cars**. The **cars** will be so safe that accidents will become no big deal. (Imagine drivers **yawning** as their cars crash into each other and bounce harmlessly away).
column8: 4) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 11-10-2008(20): If you play **SOFT** rock in the CAR while driving, you'll soon start YAWNING.
column9: 5) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 28-12-2007(10): A **soft** ener commercial, but with anthropomorphized _cars_ (similar to Pixar's Cars for example). The little baby _car_ is wrapped in some kind of **soft** fabric and _yawning_. So cute!

column3: This key word connotes the " **next** in line " of a succession of people or things. Let there be a _lack_ of _ice_ on the hottest day of summer, and you stand impatiently in line waiting for the distributor to call out  " **Next**! "
column4: * As a primitive, this character can either retain its key word meaning of _next_ or the related meaning of _second_.
column5: 1) [[g33kette](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/g33kette)] 4-3-2008(121): Is this store _lack_ ing _ice_? Let's try the **next** one, then.
column6: 2) [[Lozza](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lozza)] 18-7-2008(89): A rapper called "Ice" went for auditions but was told he lacked talent. **Next** …
column7: 3) [[panjin79](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/panjin79)] 31-5-2009(42): A lack of ice is the **next** phase of global warming.
column8: 4) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 18-10-2007(26): Global warming has gotten extreme. You're sweltering in line at the ice rationing board. Every few minutes the sullen clerk yawns and says "next", and someone shuffles forward to get their ice cube.
column9: 5) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 31-7-2009(18): The **next** time you _yawn_ , I'm going to put _ice_ down your shirt to wake you up!

column3: Earlier we made mention of the story of **Briar** Rose (or  "Sleeping Beauty," as we called her in frame 165) and drew attention to the **briar** hedge that grew up all about her castle. But in the _second_ part of the story, these **briars** blossomed into _flowers_. Hence her name, **Briar** Rose. Be careful not to confuse this character with that for _thorn_ (Frame 446).
column5: 1) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 15-8-2007(225): To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant **briar** bushes immediately _next_ to them.
column6: 2) [[bendyarm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bendyarm)] 26-9-2007(69): The **briar** patch may look unremarkable now before it blooms, but there will be _flowers_ _next_ , and it will be beautiful.
column7: 3) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 1-3-2007(38): Once you plant your _flowers_ , what inevitably come up _next_ are **briar** s.
column8: 4) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 28-9-2008(34): An important life lesson: **Briar** s are always _NEXT_ to _FLOWERS_.
column9: 5) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 14-12-2006(18): **Briar** s are the kind of _flowers_ that comes up _next_ after a property is abandoned….it's an ecological succession.

column3: The first _shells_ (money) you earn, you use to pay your debts. From then on, the _next shells_ you accumulate become your **assets**.
column5: 1) [[peace123](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peace123)] 12-1-2006(246): **Assets** are the next best thing to money.
column6: 2) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 25-8-2006(86): The first SHELLS you get you obviously spend, but the NEXT SHELLS are your **ASSETS** , you should bury them in a low safe place (placement!).
column7: 3) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 8-7-2008(51): I invest my **assets** in NEXTEL and SHELL.
column8: 4) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 13-10-2008(22): "I've already taken your **assets**!" says your ex-wife, adding " _Next_ , I'm taking your _money_!" as she walks away with a satisfied grin on her face.
column9: 5) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 27-3-2008(15): The topless model was concerned about protecting her **ASSETS** so she went to _Next_ (British high street clothes shop) and bought a tasteful pair of colourful _shells_. _Next_ she stood outside in the street, with the sign for _Next_ clearly visible over her head, and fixed them in position with chewing gum.

column3: This kanji depicts a _woman's_ **figure** as a sort of _second_ self.
column5: 1) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 25-10-2007(212): The next woman always has a better **figure**! Thinking like that, you'll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!
column6: 2) [[elanlan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elanlan)] 30-1-2009(110): Whenever I am _next_ to a _woman_ , I can't help but take notice of her **figure**.
column7: 3) [[rachels](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rachels)] 23-1-2009(47): The _next_ _woman_ always has a better **figure** ! Thinking like this is a burden weighing down many women. - (Thanks to alantin, but the last statement helps me get the placement right - it always used to be a problem with this kanji).
column8: 4) [[ew8049](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ew8049)] 31-5-2006(40): First you see her **FIGURE** , NEXT you get to know the WOMAN behind the curves.
column9: 5) [[TwoGoats](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TwoGoats)] 8-9-2009(12): When i am next to a woman, i imagine her **figure** under me =D.

column3: To seek the _words_ of a _second mouth_ is to **consult with** someone about something.
column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 28-4-2007(171): Having a _word_ with the _next mouth_ over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to **consult with** somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.
column6: 2) [[g33kette](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/g33kette)] 4-3-2008(96): "Consulting with" is having _words_ with the _next mouth_.
column7: 3) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 10-3-2009(57): Don't like the _words_ of the first one? **Consult with** the _next mouth_ available.
column8: 4) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 6-10-2006(12): If you've ever had to deal with **consultants** in business, you'll find that once you bring in one, there's always a reason to drag in more, a real drain on your resources. So I see this as the constant steam of _words_ from the _next mouth_ , all telling you that you need more **conultants**.
column9: 5) [[burritokun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burritokun)] 26-8-2008(10): Tim Allen always used to _speak_ and **consult with** his _next_ door neighbor, Wilson. You could never see Wilson's whole face, just his _mouth_.

column3: Picture a _clam_ used as a _muzzle_ to quiet the complaints of a fisherman's widow asking **compensation** for her husband lost at sea.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 8-1-2006(329): **Compensation** is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth).
column6: 2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 3-2-2008(45): **Compensation** is a kind of euphemism for hush money here. Money that _muzzles_.
column7: 3) [[Jenelle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jenelle)] 20-5-2008(34): I expect **compensation** for the bite I recieved when you didn't _muzzle_ your dog.
column8: 4) [[akahige](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akahige)] 30-1-2009(14): In "compensated dating", Japanese girls earn _shells_ from oyaji. The oyajis' members _stand_ at attention and the girls use their _mouths_ to earn their **compensation**.
column9: 5) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 12-4-2008(8): When I see this keyword I think of 'compensated dating' (AKA enjo kosai). A man hands over his _money_ to the girl and then _stands up_ , and she then opens up her _mouth_ to **compensate** him. If that girl's parents want to fix her problem, they are going to need to put a _muzzle_ on her!

column3: The barrel hoops used by many Japanese farmers to stretch clear plastic over row of vegetables in a garden patch in the hopes of **cultivating** bigger and bigger vegetables is a way of _muzzling_ the _soil_.
column5: 1) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 15-10-2010(186): To **cultivate** the _land_ is to tame it, control it. In short, you _muzzle_ it's unruly, chaotic nature. 培う つちかう to **cultivate** , to foster, 栽培 (さいばい) : cultivation.
column6: 2) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 13-3-2008(137): The illegal immigrants **cultivate** the _land_ but are socially and politically _muzzled_ (wear muzzles while they work too).
column7: 3) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 20-8-2007(64): In olden times the _land (soil)_ was **cultivate** d by farmers who were _muzzled_ by the land owners: they were prevented from expressing their opinions.
column8: 4) [[fiddle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fiddle)] 15-6-2006(28): The SOIL is MUZZLED to stop it screaming as it is **CULTIVATE** D (torn up with blades).
column9: 5) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 19-7-2007(17): Image people **cultivating** , _standing in a hole in the ground_ , preparing the soil to receive the next crop.

column3: To " **divide** and conquer " you use a _saber_ and a _muzzle_.
column5: 1) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 27-11-2006(302): When you **DIVIDE** someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That's why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.
column6: 2) [[PacifistGod](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PacifistGod)] 8-6-2008(80): **Divide** and Conquer: Shut 'em Up and Cut 'em Up.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 31-8-2007(67): **Divide** and conquer - first you cut them up (saber) , then you shut them up (muzzle).
column8: 4) [[cbogart](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cbogart)] 22-11-2006(36): The two women keep arguing about whose baby it is. So Solomon muzzles the both of them, pulls out a sword, and prepares to **divide** the child between the two.
column9: 5) [[tstuhldreher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tstuhldreher)] 6-6-2008(17): In order to MUZZLE the two complaining women, Solomon offered to **divide** the child with a SABER.

column3: The kanji for **sound** depicts something _standing_ in the air over a _tongue wagging in a mouth_ , much the same as a **sound** does for the briefest of moments before disappearing.
column4: * The primitive from this kanji also means simply a sound.
column5: 1) [[Aploosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aploosh)] 23-8-2007(201): If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you'd be making **sound**.
column6: 2) [[HMiettinen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/HMiettinen)] 21-10-2007(75): The _tongue wagging in a mouth_ produces a very high-pitched **sound** , breaking a nearby _vase_.
column7: 3) [[wazato](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wazato)] 1-10-2007(62): Imagine the **SOUND** s a woman makes as she is STANDing above a WAGGING TOUNGE.
column8: 4) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 23-12-2006(27): Note that **sound** is very close to the **muzzle** primitive (it has the _sun_ instead of the _mouth_ at the bottom) - but in meaning they are precisely opposite!
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 16-6-2008(21): I STAND UP every DAY to the **SOUND** of [insert **sound** here].

column3: When " **darkness** covered the earth " at the beginning of time, there was neither _sun_ nor _sound_.
column5: 1) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 5-9-2007(160): Picture the sun exploding - there would be a gigantic noise and then…nothing. Everything would plunge into **darkness**.
column6: 2) [[sarek05](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sarek05)] 20-6-2008(63): In places of complete **darkness** , such as caves where the _sun_ can't reach, creatures such as bats have learned to navigate by _sound_ rather than sight. The poor guys must have to fly around screaming "Marco!" and "Polo!" all the time.
column7: 3) [[eatyoda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eatyoda)] 6-9-2008(45): Total **darkness** lacks _sun_ and _sound_.
column8: 4) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 6-4-2008(36): In the **darkness** of that dank solitary confinement cell, all you can do is fantasize about _sun_ and _sound_.
column9: 5) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 8-8-2007(29): Heisig was careless with his story for [silence](../v4/240.html) (#240 黙). i have a really hard time confusing it for this one now.

column3: Poetry restricted to verses that **rhyme** often finds it has to abandon clarity of thought in order to make the **rhyme** of the words work. In this kanji's picture, one becomes a kind of  " _sound-employee_. "
column5: 1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 6-8-2007(106): What is a **RHYME** but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.
column6: 2) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 24-3-2008(87): Dr Seuss's _employee_ finally rebels against him: "I'm tired of odd _sounds_ all the time, I will not, cannot, speak in **RHYME**!".
column7: 3) [[Alunalun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Alunalun)] 4-7-2009(56): A **rhyme** is the _sound_ of an _employee_ going off to work. Everyone knows that ever since 'Snow White' in 1937 all employees sing 'hi ho, hi ho, it's off to work I go' (because it's so catchy! And it's so catchy because 'ho' **rhyme** s with 'go'!).
column8: 4) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 2-7-2006(40): " _Sound_ as a pound" is a **rhyme** that fits the kanji. _Sound_ \+ pound. Pounds being what you make when you're an _employee_ (living in the UK that is).
column9: 5) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 12-1-2006(34): Employees of The Ministry of Sound are paid to **rhyme** every day.

column3: A person of **discriminating** intellect can tell the difference between mere _kazoo_ -buzzing and _words_ spoken wisely.
column5: 1) [[amthomas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amthomas)] 15-3-2007(261): _Words_ are difficult to discriminate/discern from _sounds_ in the middle of a _fiesta_.
column6: 2) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 14-2-2008(72): I have **discriminating** taste. I'd rather listen to the _words_ of a lecture than attend a _kazoo_ concert. (Picture some snobby guy in a tweed jacket turning up his nose at entering a loud raucous kazoo recital).
column7: 3) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 28-1-2007(59): I wonder why Heisig didn't use **discernment** for this kanji. It fits the meaning equally and it is not as loaded as **discrimination**. // It is quite hard to **discern** _words_ in the middle of a _noisy fiesta_.
column8: 4) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 10-5-2009(14): **Discriminating** someone's _words_ from other sounds is hard to do in the middle of a _noisy fiesta_. (Thanks esaulgd).
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 31-8-2007(12): Socrates has apparently joined the KKK, and is actively **discriminating** against Black people. But to add a bit of artistic flair, as the ancient Greeks were wont to do, he says his racist words through a kazoo. _Socrates_ humming the n- _word_ through a _kazoo_ \- who would have thought?

column3: After lakes but before glass, polished _metal_ was used for **mirrors**. These _metal mirrors_ are recalled in this character for a **mirror**.
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 3-2-2008(270): **Mirror** should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a _Golden_ **mirror** so she can _stand_ in front of it all _day_ vainly admiring her lovely _human legs_.
column6: 2) [[digicult](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/digicult)] 16-4-2009(23): The _metal_ **mirror** makes a _sound_ \- it's answering the question "who has the fairest _human legs_ of all?".
column7: 3) [[tritonxginnenglish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tritonxginnenglish)] 5-10-2006(23): _metal + stand up + sun + legs_ remember the legend of **Amaterasu** who retired in a cave. the other Gods brought a **MIRROR** made of polished **METAL** at the entrance of the cave. Amaterasu who was **STANDING UP** saw her image of the **SUN** and began to dance with her **LEGS**.
column8: 4) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 13-4-2008(12): Remember how Archimedes burnt an approaching fleet with **mirror** s? **Mirror** s then were _metal_ and the sailors must have thought: "What're those _metal_ things up there, _standing_ on the city walls? They look like _little suns_ on _human legs_. Warm today isn't it?".
column9: 5) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 9-12-2007(11): WARNING: Be extra careful not to confuse the _sun/tongue-wagging mouth_ and _human legs_ part of the **mirror** primitive with 見 [see](../v4/57.html) (#57 見).

column3: Imagine the **boundary** of a plot of _land_ marked with gigantic _mirrors_ enabling the landowner to keep trespassers in sight at all times.
column5: 1) [[nyquil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nyquil)] 13-3-2007(195): In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put _mirrors_ on the **boundary** of his _land_ so it feels much bigger.
column6: 2) [[brose](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brose)] 16-12-2006(108): This is an old trick to keep out migrants. You put a bunch of dirty mirrors on the **boundary** of your land and theirs. When they approach the **boundary** , what they see in the mirror is their own land and someone that looks like themselves, only dirtier, so they figure your country isn't any better than their own and they head back home.
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 25-1-2008(33): **Boundaries** and borders (another meaning of this kanji) used to be protected by daggers and swords (see **environs** , frame 284), but today our _lands_ are protected by one-way _mirrors_ at airport customs with video cameras and interrogation rooms behind them.
column8: 4) [[tstuhldreher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tstuhldreher)] 6-6-2008(20): In Japan, you often see MIRRORS at intersections. That's because the walls that form the **boundary** of people's LAND make it hard to see around corners.
column9: 5) [[Rujiel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rujiel)] 30-7-2009(19): Be aware the right-hand character 竟 really means "endpoint" or "finally", it's commonly read "つい" (as in "ついに") and usually written in kana alone. A **boundary** represents a country's _land_ 's _endpoint_ (awkward phrasing for order) .

column3: A _top hat_ hanging on a _hook_ in the front hall, right where the **deceased** left it the day he died, reminds us of him and his kanji.
column4: * In addition to _deceased_ , the primitive meaning of _to perish_ will also be used for this character.
column5: 1) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 29-10-2007(124): The _top hat_ hanging on a _hook_ belonged to the now **deceased** Charlie Chaplin.
column6: 2) [[Robatsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Robatsu)] 5-3-2009(43): The recently **DECEASED** are said to hang their _hats_ on a _hook_ by the door to the afterlife.
column7: 3) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 14-8-2007(16): Tophat resting on top of a tombstone. The horizontal bottom line is the shadow of the tombstone (and/or hat) on the ground.
column8: 4) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 16-12-2008(10): I think of this as a pictograph of a coffin.
column9: 5) [[terozen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/terozen)] 25-3-2012(6): The **deceased** 's _top hat_ still hangs on his old _fish hook_ … It makes me sad every time I see it, but I will never take that hat down.

column3: If one's _eyes perish_ before death, one remains **blind** for the rest of life.
column5: 1) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 18-7-2007(156): Deceased eyes! Easy ,).
column6: 2) [[tgray88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tgray88)] 4-10-2008(73): A person with _deceased_ _eyes_ is **blind**.
column7: 3) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 18-7-2007(18): Rather than "dead eyes," break down DECEASED into TOPHAT and FISHHOOK, and picture each **blind** person's EYES as being unable to see because their eyes are covered with a TOP HAT, that's attached to a FISHHOOK stabbed in their eyeballs.
column8: 4) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 25-7-2007(10): I keep messing up the order of the primitives here. To emphasise the position, imagine the **blind** person wanting to take his _top hat_ off the _hook_. Before he does that, though, he needs to re-attach his _eye_ balls, which are rolling around on the floor.
column9: 5) [[crayonmaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crayonmaster)] 8-2-2009(3): The **blind** man could not see anything with his EYES, but he claimed, when he looked up, he could see the DECEASED existing above.

column3: The "ideal _woman_ " one daydreams about is no more than a **delusion**. Hence, _perish_ the thought of her.
column5: 1) [[Georgi87](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Georgi87)] 7-10-2007(227): I had a problem with remembering that "deceased" went over the "woman". So, here's my story: The **delusion** al woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 27-4-2007(84): If you think you should _perish_ for that _woman_ , you have a major **delusion**.
column7: 3) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 13-1-2008(65): Remember "The Corpse Bride"? Well, she is under the **DELUSION** that someday someone will marry her. Too bad that nobody wants to marry a **dead** **woman** .
column8: 4) [[nesert](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nesert)] 29-10-2009(31): Romeo held the **delusion** that Juliet was a _deceased woman_.
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 13-3-2011(28): He cared for her so much that he had **delusion** s that the _deceased_ _woman_ , who was 6 feet under, was still with him.

column3: The _flowers_ that _perish_ in the _flood_ are taken here as symbols of an area that has been **laid waste**.
column5: 1) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 13-4-2008(214): After Godzilla **laid waste** to the city, the survivors put some _flowers_ on the bodies of the _deceased_ and floated their bodies down the _stream_.
column6: 2) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 28-8-2006(90): **Laying waste** is just a euphamism for flushing poop down the toilet. It smells nothing like _flowers_ , more like _deceased flowers_ , and it's flushed down into a _stream_ of sewage. Use "waste" to avoid [destroy](../v4/365.html) (#365 滅) [demolition](../v4/400.html) (#400 壊).
column7: 3) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 29-10-2007(26): Hurricane Katrina **laid waste** to New Orleans….as a result, a _stream_ of _dead flowers_ floated into the sea.
column8: 4) [[nicjsb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nicjsb)] 8-9-2008(15): I **laid** my **waste** in the toilet, sprayed some _flower_ -scented air freshener, then _perished_ the **waste** I **laid** with the toilet's _stream_.
column9: 5) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 11-10-2010(6): The army that **laid waste** the entire region left nothing but _flowers_ marking where thousands _perish_ ed and blood flowed in _streams_. 荒い あらい rough, rude, wild, 荒っぽい (あらっぽい) : rough, rude, 荒廃 (こうはい) : ruin, 荒らす (あらす) : to lay waste, to devastate, to damage, to invade, to break into, 荒れる (あれる) : be stormy, lose one's temper.

column3: The story of **ambition** talks of a _king_ walking under the _perishing_  (or "waning") _moon_ dreaming great dreams about his kingdom. (The roots of **ambition** are from the same word as  "ambulate," meaning to walk about.)
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 4-2-2008(238): You're _dead meat_ , buddy, my **ambition** is to be _king_.
column6: 2) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 28-4-2008(140): The **ambitions** of _kings_ often result in _dead_ _bodies_.
column7: 3) [[watanuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/watanuki)] 2-11-2007(39): The _king_ had great **ambition** to have a son, but after certain _part of his body_ _perished_ he lost all hope.
column8: 4) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 15-4-2008(24): The _king_ 's one **ambition** , before he _perishes_ , is to go to the _moon_.
column9: 5) [[matstc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matstc)] 31-12-2008(22): He who has **ambition** must be prepared to walk over the _dead_ _body_ of the previous _king_.

column3: Spinning a _dagger_ about on its hilt on the top of a _top hat_  \- waiting to see in which **direction** it points when it comes to rest - one leaves to fate where one is going next. Take care in writing this character.
column4: * As a primitive, this character will take the sense of a _compass_ , the instrument used to determine _direction_.
column5: 1) [[Deonnn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Deonnn)] 9-12-2007(147): Note: The primitives are _top hat_ and _bound up_. Compare [ten thousand](../v4/64.html) (#64 万). Story: A rich man wearing a _top hat_ and _bound up_ from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for **directions** to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.
column6: 2) [[CSBarnes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CSBarnes)] 15-12-2008(49): I always keep my **directions** _bound_ to the bottom of my _top hat_ so I won't lose them.
column7: 3) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 5-1-2007(15): To find the **direction** , the magician waved his _top hat_ over his _dagger_ to make it function as a makeshift magical compass.
column8: 4) [[ernest](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ernest)] 18-9-2007(11): Is that a DAGGER under your HAT, of are you just happy to see me? Give me some **DIRECTION** here.
column9: 5) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 6-8-2009(9): I always have a _compass_ _bound_ underneath my _top hat_ , so I know I'm always headed in the right _direction_.

column3: Imagine a _compass_ that is **disturbed** every time a _woman_ passes by, sending the needle spinning madly round and round.
column5: 1) [[gpetroce](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gpetroce)] 10-6-2007(162): Capt. Jack Sparrow's compass gets **disturb** ed every time a beautiful woman walks by him (just picture Keira Knightley in her sexy asian outfit as Elizabeth and the image will be fixed forever).
column6: 2) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 12-10-2007(151): One way to **Disturb** a woman is to give her directions while she is in the middle of driving – she just can't take that kind of stress.
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 18-3-2008(43): In college, whenever I had a _woman_ in my room, I'd hang a _compass_ on the doorknob as a do not **disturb** sign. The compass let my roomie know that he needed to "take a hike".
column8: 4) [[fruitangel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fruitangel)] 7-12-2008(33): It's **DISTURB** ING how bad women are with directions.
column9: 5) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 17-6-2006(21): If an attractive _woman_ passes by, it can **disturb** your moral _compass_.

column3: The character for a **boy** shows us a **Boy** Scout cleaning the _dirt_ out of his _compass_  \- the more _dirt_ , the better.
column5: 1) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 14-8-2007(250): Little **boy** s always head in the direction of mud and dirt.
column6: 2) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 16-12-2008(52): **Boy** s thoughts often head in dirty directions.
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 11-6-2008(30): It's a _dirty_ **BOY** scout, lost in the woods by himself with only his compass for _directions_. Can't you just see the lost little **boy** , all alone?
column8: 4) [[skellyfish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skellyfish)] 11-2-2009(16): A **Boy** Scout lost in the woods, all DIRTY and holding a COMPASS, trying to find his way home. Imagine him crying because he's such a young **boy** , covered with DIRT streaked with tears, and banging his COMPASS against trees, etc. in an attempt to get it to work.
column9: 5) [[tgray88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tgray88)] 4-10-2008(13): A **boy** scout will generally use the _ground_ to determine _directions_.

column3: Here we see a special _compass_ used to pick out those _flowers_ most suited for making good **perfumes**.
column5: 1) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 26-12-2007(183): She used a **perfume** so strong, that you can track her by following the _direction_ of the smell of _flowers_.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 31-8-2007(69): People always seem to overdo it with their **perfume**. It seems that whenever I am at school, somebody walks by with their cheap _flowery_ **perfume**. If I close my eyes, I can actually use that _flower_ iness as a compass - it tells me which direction they're in.
column7: 3) [[tgray88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tgray88)] 4-10-2008(47): A _flowery_ scent spreading in all _directions_ is **perfume**.
column8: 4) [[Fluhk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Fluhk)] 2-2-2006(13): Bees - with their "built-in" compass - always pick out the best-perfumed flowers - and so does the human nose, which always turns in the direction of the best-scented flower!
column9: 5) [[krungthep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/krungthep)] 17-7-2009(6): _Flowers_ use their **perfume** to attract insects in their _direction_.

column3: If you eat too much, you may need a _compass_ to find your way around the **obese** mass of _flesh_ that piles up in the midsection. Compare this with your stories for _round_ (Frame 44) and _fat_ (Frame 494), similar in meaning but distinct in imagery.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 11-12-2007(286): " _Flesh_ in all _directions_ " = **obese**.
column6: 2) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 6-9-2007(149): Yo momma so **obese** , she changed the direction of the moon.
column7: 3) [[sfekas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sfekas)] 28-6-2008(51): Yo momma so **obese** , she made the moon change direction. (I like DrWarrior12's story, but switched the words to match the kanji.).
column8: 4) [[Chadokoro_K](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Chadokoro_K)] 11-9-2007(16): **animal fat / +fat** —– BODY PART [FLESH], DIRECTION [COMPASS] ** Hint: Animal FLESH can contain a lot of **ANIMAL FAT** , so you point a special " **fat** -measuring COMPASS" at it to measure how much **FAT** it contains. … Note: this does not mean "obese," nor is it used in compound words meaning **obese**. It is always used together with "shi" in "shibou" for various types of "fats." [D2060].
column9: 5) [[elanlan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elanlan)] 30-3-2011(15): In response to DrWarrior12: Yo' mama's so **obese** , I needed a _compass_ to navigate her round _flesh_ last night. :P.

column3: When making a courtesy **call on** a dignitary, one has to gauge one's _words_ with great care. Hence the need for a _compass_.
column5: 1) [[GenPDP7](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GenPDP7)] 20-12-2007(234): When you **call on** someone, you point your words in their direction.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 22-3-2007(71): Japanese streets usually don't have names, so finding places can be difficult. So if you plan to **call on** someone you need two things, 1) _words_ (for asking the way) and 2) a _compass_ (in case you get really lost).
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 18-12-2006(52): When **calling on** a girl, you'd better what what sweet _words_ will turn her fancy in your _direction_. (Image: last century teenagers on a frilly couch in the sitting room, she with her back to him, and he fumbling for the right words to turn her around).
column8: 4) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 26-1-2008(25): For this key word ' **CALL ON** ' and the more useful meaning of ' **visit** ', think of: a booty call! Haven't you ever got a late night call from someone (on their _mobile_ ), asking for _words_ of _direction_ to your place? Quick, get out your Marvin Gaye record…
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 21-7-2008(23): Note: this kanzi means more like "visit" 訪ねる 【たずねる】 (v1,vt) to visit, (P). Thus, you VISIT another country that uses different WORDS than yours (language) and you have to find your way around with a COMPASS since you can't ask anyone for directions or read any signs.

column3: The _taskmaster_ **sets** an unruly servant **free** , giving him no more than a quick glance at the _compass_ and a boot from behind.
column5: 1) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 2-3-2008(179): Go in any _direction_ away from your _taskmaster_ when you are **set free**.
column6: 2) [[gothats](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gothats)] 27-7-2010(28): Remember what the Genie from Aladdin wanted, to "to be free: be my own master, choose my own direction".
column7: 3) [[Buronzu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Buronzu)] 7-9-2009(25): The 'Saw' movies: If you follow the _directions_ of the _taskmaster_ , you'll be **set free**.
column8: 4) [[imojyochu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/imojyochu)] 3-8-2008(14): When one is **set free** , you no longer have to take direction from your task master.
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 9-4-2008(9): (to help with element placement): Want to be **set free**? Follow me in this _direction_ towards the _left_ …no, not towards the _right_ , your evil _taskmaster_ lies this way…in the _direction_ of the _left_.

column3: Some cosmic _taskmaster_ hovering overhead whips up the waves to make them dash **violently** against the shore. In the _white_ foam that covers the _water_ we see a broken _compass_ floating, all that remains of a shipwreck.
column5: 1) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 31-5-2007(194): When the _taskmaster_ found his favorite _white compas_ damaged by _water_ , he became the most **violent** _taskmaster_ there ever was.
column6: 2) [[alex12345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alex12345)] 25-7-2008(89): Overnight the slave got **Violent** and was Set Free. Overnight….Set Free.
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 27-1-2008(42): In the last frame we saw the slaves set free ( 放 ), yet emancipation didn't end segregation and conflict… remember the **VIOLENT** clashes on the street, whereby _white taskmasters_ turned fire hoses in the _direction_ of the black protesters, spraying them with _water_. (Thanks to KANJI for the (true) story about Bull Connor and the protests).
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 31-8-2007(31): There's a theory as to why _Hitler_ became so **violent** \- basically all he lived on for weeks at a time in prison was _drops of water_ \- literally, just _drops_ at a time, supplemented by copious amounts of _cocaine_ (see [white](../v4/37.html) (#37 白)) , which he snorted off the top of a _compass_ blade. True story, saw it on the _Hitle_ – I mean History Channel. Try this article for a jump-start. <http://www.spiegel.de/international/0>,1518,354606,00.html.
column9: 5) [[MnNoKuma2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MnNoKuma2)] 24-2-2009(20): Water is white in every direction, even the tasmaster is afraid of the **violent** sea.

column3: To **undress** is to expose the _flesh_ and tempt the _devil_ in the eyes of one's onlookers. Ignore the moral if you want, but not the _devil_.
column5: 1) [[wazato](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wazato)] 1-10-2007(209): HORNY TEENAGERS love to **UNDRESS** FLESH.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 6-7-2008(94): Before you **undress** I should warn you – the sight of _flesh_ brings out the _devil_ in me.
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 11-6-2008(21): If you look at pictures of **undressed** women, you are submitting your _flesh_ to the _devil_.
column8: 4) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 5-6-2009(10): If you **undress** the _flesh_ of _horny teenagers,_ you will go to jail. Unless they're over 18. Or unless you live in Alabama. Then it's alllllll good.
column9: 5) [[j0k0m0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/j0k0m0)] 31-12-2010(6): **Undress** your flesh for success, you horny little devil.

column3: Not inappropriately, this character likens an  **explanation** to the _devil's_ own _words_.
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 5-2-2008(133): The _words_ of a _horny teenager_ typically fall into one of two categories: either **rumors** or **explanation** s.
column6: 2) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 11-6-2008(97): The _words_ of the _devil_ incite **rumours** and false **explanations**.
column7: 3) [[wazato](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wazato)] 1-10-2007(34): HORNY TEENAGERS always come up with wild **EXPLANATION** S and THEORIES to SAY to their parents when they come home late after curfew.
column8: 4) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 22-3-2009(26): I'm an atheist and I was arguing with a Catholic, trying my best to explain why I don't think God exists. It was just an **explanation** , but he thought my _words_ were the work of the _devil_!
column9: 5) [[nesert](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nesert)] 29-10-2009(13): When asked for an **explanation** , I _said_ , "The _devil_ made me do it.".

column3: _Metal_ that has been **pointed** (as an awl, a pick, a nail, or a knife) tends to serve the _devil's_ purposes as well as civilization's: our tools are also our weapons.
column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 6-3-2006(162): **Pointed** is the metal devil's pitchfork.
column6: 2) [[lee101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lee101)] 28-8-2011(77): 500 kanji…Come on guys we're about 1/4 of the way there.
