column7: 3) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 2-11-2007(44): The _Horny teenager_ who worked part time at a _gold_ smelting plant always had uncontrollable errections that **pointed** out all the time, this is not a good thing to have when you work in a _gold_ smelting plant, surely he will one day end up with a _Gold_ member!
column8: 4) [[vileru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vileru)] 12-9-2009(34): The _metal_ of the _devil_ , his pitchfork, is **pointed**.
column9: 5) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 17-7-2008(15): **Pointed** metal objects are used by horny teens for devil's play.

column3: This primitive (named for its associations with the kanji of the following frame) is composed of a pair of _horns_ growing out of a _brain_ with a _tongue wagging in the mouth_ beneath. Think of  " **former** " in connection with administrators or heads of state who have just left office but continue to make a nuisance of themselves by advertising their opinions on public policy.
column4: * The primitive meaning, _increase_ , comes from the next frame. Always think of something multiplying wildly as you watch.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 15-2-2007(255): The Artist **formerly** Known as Prince has the _horniest_ _brain_ around, and I think you can imagine what his _wagging tongue_ is doing…
column6: 2) [[allanh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/allanh)] 1-3-2009(236): **Formerly** , _horned_ animals were used to plough the _ricefield_ , and it took all _day_. Nowadays it's done by machine.
column7: 3) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 20-3-2008(70): The horns found in the ricefields were **formerly** used in rituals celebrating the sun goddess, amaterasu.
column8: 4) [[Hyreia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hyreia)] 4-2-2009(62): I can't help but see this as the former president of the United Sates, George W. Bush. The horns growing out of his brain with an evil thought, his tongue wagging in his mouth, saying something stupid. (It helps later on. Increase = him increasing the national deficit until we have nothing but dirt left, Hate = Bush's mind). Fun stuff.
column9: 5) [[cricket](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cricket)] 2-4-2008(21): This was **formerly** a human, but it has turned into a demon, with only jagged _horns_ sticking out of its _brain_ and a disgusting _wagging tongue_ at the bottom.

column3: This kanji depicts an **increase** of _soil_ , multiplying so fast that it literally buries everything in its path.
column5: 1) [[sannomiya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sannomiya)] 20-5-2007(268): Prices always **INCREASE** for LAND that was FORMERLY cheaper.
column6: 2) [[submacrolize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/submacrolize)] 16-4-2008(32): Farmers work the **land** so they can **INCREASE** their **formerly** puny crop supply.
column7: 3) [[atylmo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/atylmo)] 3-10-2008(23): Lately, the artist formerly known as "Formerly Known As Prince", if you can believe it, has become increasingly _dirt_ ier in his songs.
column8: 4) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 22-11-2007(18): This land on which "The Artist _Formerly_ Known as Prince*" built his house has **increase** d in value.
column9: 5) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 4-4-2008(11): Formerly there was lots of land for everyone. But as the world population **increase** s, your own piece of dirt is becoming more and more difficult to secure.

column3: The **presents** offered here are _money_ that _increases_ each time you give it away. Do not confuse with the temporal word  "present" (Frame 275).
column5: 1) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 3-6-2008(54): Imagine if the number of **presents** you get _increases_ with each birthday. So on your first birthday, you receive just one _shell_ as a **present** , but the next year it _increases_ to two _shells_ as **presents** , and so on, _increasing_ and _increasing_ so by the time you're elderly, the number of _shells_ you'll get as **presents** will have _increased_ to an awful lot of **presents**. GOT IT YET? **PRESENTS** = SHELLS + INCREASE.
column6: 2) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 24-5-2009(29): The artist formerly known as Prince gave **presents** to all his fans. Picture him throwing live oysters into the audience as he performs. People are horrified and start gagging from the smell.
column7: 3) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 28-12-2009(27): SEA SHELLS were FORMALLY great **PRESENTS**. Nowadays kids wants playstation and DS!
column8: 4) [[Seiska](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Seiska)] 17-2-2011(16): The money spent on **presents** increases every Christmas :/.
column9: 5) [[neilhalligan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/neilhalligan)] 12-1-2012(10): FORMERLY at Christmas I got **PRESENTS** , but now I just get MONEY.

column3: As a "Western" language, English identifies the **east** with the rising _sun_. In more fanciful terms, we see the _sun_ piercing through a _tree_ as it rises in the **east**.
column4: * Both the direction _east_ and the part of the world called  "the _East_ " are primitive meanings of this character.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 8-1-2006(182): Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.
column6: 2) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 7-12-2008(15): Through the _tree_ s, I watch the _sun_ rising from the **east**.
column7: 3) [[g33kette](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/g33kette)] 6-3-2008(11): To the **east** , you'll notice a rather large _tree_ growing in the middle of that _ricefield_.
column8: 4) [[saleem](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saleem)] 27-3-2008(6): Imagine that hugely symbolic Japanese SUN piercing through a TREE as it sets on Tokyo ( 東京 ), the **EAST** ern capital . (with thanks to AndamanIslander, just found it easier to remember this version).
column9: 5) [[hornlo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hornlo)] 28-5-2011(4): [ **east** = _tree_ overlay _sun_ ] - look **east** and you can see the _sun_ rising through the upper branches of the _tree_ s : ( _east_ [dir], the _East_ [region]).

column3: If the piece of _wood_ in the roof known as the **ridgepole** points _east_ , the sunrise will be visible from the front door.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 2-2-2007(235): Feng Shui states that the **ridgepole** of a house should be made of _wood_ and face _east_.
column6: 2) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 23-7-2008(61): Ok just a note to the 'ridgepole facing east story' im making up a story to JUSTIFY why that is the case. Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a 'sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is', back in those days when people used **ridgepole** s they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning).
column7: 3) [[shank](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shank)] 10-4-2009(24): Way back when, all Japanese houses were made of _wood_ and built with the **ridgepole** facing _east_. The reason for this is that since there were no alarm clocks yet, everyone needed the rising sun to wake them up every morning.
column8: 4) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 14-1-2008(13): I need a **ridgepole** for the house I'm building. It's a very important part of the structure, so I need the best **ridgepole** money can buy. That means I need to special order one. The best **ridgepole** is made from a _tree_ grown in the _east_. When the shipment arrives, I verify that the **ridgepole** is best quality by looking at the _tree_ and seeing the _east_ symbol stamped on it.
column9: 5) [[alphador](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alphador)] 7-1-2010(4): Secondo il feng shui la TRAVE PORTANTE di un edificio deve essere fatta di LEGNO e puntare ad EST.

column3: The whole secret to breaking the _ice_ with the _East_ is to peek behind those mysteriously  " **frozen** smiles. "
column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 7-7-2006(240): _Eastern_ Siberia is often **frozen** by _ice_. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself…it made it stick for me!
column6: 2) [[Wizard](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wizard)] 13-6-2008(97): The _ice_ will stay **frozen** until the _sun_ is visible through the _trees_.
column7: 3) [[tuuli](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tuuli)] 9-12-2007(18): It is always the _east_ side of anything, mountain, yard, forest, that stays **frozen** with _ice_.
column8: 4) [[crayonmaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crayonmaster)] 4-2-2009(7): ICE will stay **FROZEN** during the night, until the SUN rises over the EAST TREES.
column9: 5) [[dat5h](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dat5h)] 11-7-2009(6): Imagine your freezer ( 冷凍庫 れいとうこ) breaking down in the middle of the winter. The temperatures are just around freezing (it'll have to do). So you decide to bury all of your food in the _ice_ outside to keep it fresh. As the sun rises in the _east_ you must quickly move all of your perishables to the other side because of melting (of course remembering to move it back as the sun moves over the trees to the other side). It's tiresome but it'll have to do until you can fix the freezer.

column3: A _woman_ who is in her **pregnancy** is a bit like a _porter_ , bearing her new companion wherever she goes.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 1-12-2006(170): A pregnant woman is a porter of her child.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 22-6-2008(79): A _woman_ becomes **pregnant** when _a drop of gentleman_ gets inside her.
column7: 3) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 5-11-2007(53): The _gentleman_ gave the _woman_ a _bit_ of sperm…BAM **PREGNANCY**!
column8: 4) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 13-3-2008(19): In **PREGNANCY** , a _woman_ needs a _porter_ to carry her bags to her room.
column9: 5) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-2-2007(11): (Image: **pregnant** _woman_ in traditional Japanese home yelling at her cowering _saumari_ husband for pickles and ice cream. He dutifully obliges with great bowls of them on his head).

column3: Those who rule the **courts** , the _porters_ of justice and order, are often found to _stretch_ the law to suit their own purposes. Recall the kanji for _prolong_ from frame 419 and keep it distinct.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-11-2006(163): A _porter_ has run away from his master. His punishment is to be _stretched out_ on the rack. So say the **courts** in this barbaric time.
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 22-12-2007(83): The _gentleman_ _stretched_ the truth a _bit_ in **court**.
column7: 3) [[Angrybeez](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Angrybeez)] 27-5-2008(50): Stretching the truth in court caused a drop of sweat on the gentleman's brow.
column8: 4) [[gopineapples](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gopineapples)] 29-5-2009(22): In court they STRETCHED the PORTER on the rack until he confessed. Torture!!!
column9: 5) [[hornlo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hornlo)] 28-5-2011(9): [ **courts** = _stretch_ ( _porter_ ) ] - the **courts** , _porters_ of justice, sometimes _stretch_ the letter of the law for their own ends.

column3: _Water_ . . . _nine_ . . . _tree_. From those elements you must compose a plot for the key word, **dye**. Here, as elsewhere, any of the alternate meanings of the primitives may be used, provided they do not require a position other than that of the kanji in question.
column5: 1) [[munia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munia)] 21-8-2008(210): To make this **dye** , I used _water_ and the barks of _nine_ different _tree_ s.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 8-8-2007(108): The _baseball_ team hangs their freshly **dye** d _dripping_ jerseys at the top of a _tree_ to dry.
column7: 3) [[penot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/penot)] 23-9-2008(58): **Dye** is a _liquid_ that has to be applied _nine_ times to stain the _wood_ below.
column8: 4) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 18-9-2006(52): [dye, color, paint, stain, print] The most common **dye** s are _liquids_ that come in _nine_ colors (the 7 of the rainbow, plus white and black), and are extracted from _trees_.
column9: 5) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 17-1-2008(16): **Dye** a _tree_ with the _liquid_ in a lengthy _9_ -step process. I always remember the _9_ because so far it's the number I've seen most used as a third primitive in kanji, especially with _tree_. For placement, just remember it's the _liquid_ poured _9_ times over the _tree_.

column3: _Hearth_ . . . _sort of thing_. Beware of letting the simple reading off of the primitive elements do your work for you. Unless you make a vivid image of something **burning** and relate it just as vividly to those primitive meanings, you can count on forgetting this character very quickly.
column5: 1) [[saruwatari](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saruwatari)] 5-1-2008(202): Any sort of thing can **burn** in the fire.
column6: 2) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 5-2-2009(59): The Japanese are very particular about what SORT OF THINGs are considered **BURN** able trash and what's not.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 31-8-2007(41): Somebody from PETA is really angry that they sell dog meat in China, so they've gone to **burn** down the whole cart (my mnemonic for "sort of thing" was seeing strips of dog flesh roasting, and saying "well, that's just the _sort of thing_ they do here in China).
column8: 4) [[squeaky_lill_mk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/squeaky_lill_mk)] 3-6-2009(28): _Fire_ **burn** s any _sort of thing_.
column9: 5) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 13-3-2008(22): The "hot diggety dog" _sort of thing_ caught on _fire_ and exploded in the kitchen, causing me to sustain third-degree **BURN** S all over.

column3: The **V.I.P.** indicated here is an important guest making a visit. The elements are: _house_ . . . _ceiling_ . . . _few_ . . . _shells_.
column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 19-7-2007(385): This _house_ is reserved to **V.I.P.** only. If you are not _one of the few_ with enough _money_ to call you that way, keep out!
column6: 2) [[bendyarm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bendyarm)] 4-10-2007(51): The **V.I.P.** visits your _house_ , but your _ceiling_ is too low for his inflated head, which he bumps and hurts. You have to give him your _few_ _shells_ as compensation.
column7: 3) [[vicnet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vicnet)] 25-3-2010(31): HONEY! We've got a V.I.P visiting tonight!! Let's decorate the _house_ a little why don't we? That _ceiling_ is boring, let's hang a _few_ fancy _shells_ up there, that'll impress them!
column8: 4) [[GenPDP7](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GenPDP7)] 20-12-2007(13): There's only _one_ **V.I.P.** in the _house_ , and all I can do is _focus_ on her _animal legs_.
column9: 5) [[matstc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matstc)] 16-7-2008(8): If you are a **VIP** , you are the only _one_ who can enter the _house_ without paying the cover charge (a _few_ _shells_ ).

column3: _Stop_ . . . _march_ . . . _little_. Be sure not to forget that final dot in the element for _march_.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-1-2007(290): Santa had to put his _foot_ down to stop a _march_ of _little_ guys, namely elves. They were protesting the harsh treatment they get every **year-end** when Santa asks them to step up toy production for the holiday season.
column6: 2) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 10-2-2007(100): At the **year-end** , everything seems to come to a _stop_. However, there's still enough time for a _little march_ to celebrate.
column7: 3) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 3-1-2008(45): At **year-end** , we _stop_ for a _small_ celebration before _marching_ ahead into the new year.
column8: 4) [[cezpeleta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cezpeleta)] 6-11-2009(22): At **year-end** , STOP and celebrate with a LITTLE MARCH.
column9: 5) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 11-6-2009(14): Every **YEAR-END** , its important to STOP and have ONE LITTLE PARADE to celebrate.

column3: Above, an _eye_ and a _fishhook_ , and below the primitive for _little_. Although apparently the simplest of these first six kanji, when you begin to work on its plot and story you will soon find out that the number of strokes and visual complexity of a kanji does not make it easier or harder to remember. It is the primitives you have to work that are the critical factor, as in this case where the meaning of the key word is so seemingly distant from the elements. Remember, you can always break larger elements down ( _eye of a needle_ into _eye_ and _fishhook_ ) if you think it helps.
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 6-4-2008(206): In Japanese this is KEN, as in Barbie's boyfriend. He has lovely blue _eyes,_ a girlfriend who is as thin as a _straightened out fish hook_. But, down where it counts, he has very _little_ to show…
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-1-2007(177): After sticking a _fishhook_ in your _eye_ , the yakuza boss probably has _little_ more to do to convince you to move to a different **prefecture**.
column7: 3) [[kresobilan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kresobilan)] 5-3-2008(81): _Smaller_ administrative units, _hooked_ together by a (Sauron's) central _eye_.
column8: 4) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 25-4-2006(53): Contradictory to what Heisig says, there is no eye of a needle in this picture, because that would be the top part of 直 . Instead, there is the eye of a fishhook. I will not hazard a guess as to what lives in such a place, but in fact the eye of a fishhook - as it has well-defined borders - makes a small **prefecture** of its own.
column9: 5) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 22-6-2008(48): _Eye_ (I) live in a _small_ **prefecture** full of _hook_ ers.

column5: 1) [[onsen_monkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/onsen_monkey)] 6-9-2006(276): There are a bunch of **HORSE CHESTNUT** TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. Chestnuts keep rolling off the cliff and falling on people's heads. So far TEN THOUSAND people have been killed by falling chestnuts, and the Japanese government still ain't did shit about it.
column6: 2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 26-1-2008(72): There is a **horse chestnut** _tree_ that has grown by a _cliff_ for so long, it has deposited _10,000_ **horse chesnut** s that lie at the bottom. Don't worry over this one too much, you'll spend so much time trying to figure out the right story for it, you probably won't forget it.
column7: 3) [[Lizzie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lizzie)] 9-7-2008(38): **Horse chestnut** trees grows in tens of thousands under the cliff.
column8: 4) [[stupiddog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stupiddog)] 29-3-2010(28): Strokes 5 and 6 are in reverse order, so it's not an ordinary cliff, but a _drag_ (primitive at the beginning of lesson 50!) Story: When we were kids, we loved collecting the fruits of the **horse chestnut** _tree_. But because there were so many to collect, we sometimes _dragged_ more than _ten thousand_ of them behind us!
column9: 5) [[MeisterLlama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MeisterLlama)] 7-12-2008(28): This is NOT a cliff. the first stroke is right to left and slanted a bit. in fact, it's more like the axe blade of the axe character. story: you didn't want to try to chop down the **horse chestnut** tree with an axe because the chestnut kept falling on you. so instead you just stacked up _10,000_ _axe-blades_ next to the tree, and eventually they the stack fell on the tree and sliced it to pieces.

column3: _Soil_ and a _scorpion_ (an  "earth animal"). This is, of course, the full character from which the primitive for **ground** derives.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(161): Picture the **ground** as an extent of _soil_ where _scorpions_ are buried like land mines. Imagine a sign post saying 'no trespassing, _scorpion_ mines' if that helps, and how it is dangerous to walk there.
column6: 2) [[bigspenderJ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bigspenderJ)] 7-2-2007(77): The soil is littered with scorpions everywhere and no ones dares put their foot on the **ground**.
column7: 3) [[harhol](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harhol)] 10-5-2009(46): The DIRT SCORPION is a **ground** -type pokémon.
column8: 4) [[Thora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thora)] 31-1-2008(22): You can't escape the _scorpions_ on the **ground** by jumping into the pond 池 - scorpions like both _soil_ and water!
column9: 5) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 19-2-2008(18): **Ground** Zero, after the bombings, only scorpions could live there.

column3: _Water_ . . . _scorpion_. It would be easy to slip into a  "lazy image" in cases like this one, picturing, let us say, a _scorpion_ near the _water_. But if you picture rather a _scorpion_ letting its venom out _drop by drop_ until it has made a whole **pond** of the stuff, the image is more likely to remain fixed.
column5: 1) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 13-7-2008(110): Remember the story of the _scorpion_ that begged the turtle for a ride across the **pond**? Halfway across the _water_ , the _scorpion_ stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.
column6: 2) [[yvanc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yvanc)] 14-6-2007(62): Water scorpions loves to live in the **pond**.
column7: 3) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 13-7-2008(40): The **POND** was infested with WATER SCORPIONS.
column8: 4) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 11-6-2008(13): You thought water snakes were bad…this **pond** has WATER SCORPIONS. One sting and you're dead.
column9: 5) [[lena1849](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lena1849)] 28-6-2010(10): Take out the 1st layer of _soil_ in "ground" 地 , and add _water_. You've got a **pond**.

column3: Work with the pictograph as you wish.
column4: * As a primitive, this insect will refer to the whole _insect_ kingdom, it can be further specified for each kanji that contains it.
column5: 1) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 19-3-2008(164): I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an **insect** biting _into_ the arm, sucking some blood.
column6: 2) [[alexmat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alexmat)] 6-7-2008(60): **Insect** in one drop of amber. Think Jurassic Park.
column7: 3) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 17-4-2008(34): An **insect** stuck its sharp, needle-like mouth _in_ my arm and sucked out _one_ _drop_ of blood.
column8: 4) [[lee101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lee101)] 9-8-2010(30): Just Remember it.
column9: 5) [[alpuri](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alpuri)] 14-3-2010(14): The top part is IN as for **INSECT**. the bottom part is the arm in which the **insect** stings. (thanks Shibo).

column5: 1) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 6-9-2007(241): Bugs have to go to school to learn how to become **lightning bugs**. Only the brightest bugs graduate to become **lightning bugs**.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 15-2-2007(106): Q: Who's the smartest _insect_ in _school_? A: The **lightning-bug**. Because he's so bright! (Image: lightning bug in school with glasses, pocket protector, etc. Maybe even have some cool kids teasing him).
column7: 3) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 30-9-2008(29): In the _schoolhouse_ for _insects_ , the brightest are obviously the **lightning- bug** s.
column8: 4) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 12-8-2008(16): Think of a small Japanese _Schoolhouse_ in the country. The young children have caught some **lightning-bug** s in a jar and placed it next to window. Long after the children go home and the sun sets, the jar continues to illuminate the room. For me, this Kanji isn't about keywords, but a strong visual.
column9: 5) [[Davve](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Davve)] 14-6-2006(14): Poor _schoolhouse_ s can't afford electricity. As you can't teach in the dark the only solution is **lightning-bug** s! It's easy. Catch a thousand or so of them, bunch them together in a box and attach your wires to the box. Electricity flows through the wires as soon as the lightning starts flashing inside the box. Each bug has begun attacking it's neighbour with it's special weapon - the stinging rod of Lightning!

column5: 1) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 22-8-2007(181): A **snake** eats _insects_ and he does that outside, while we eat in the _house_ and preferably with a _spoon_.
column6: 2) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 29-10-2007(101): I use a _spoon_ to feed my pet-snake _insects_ in the house.
column7: 3) [[potempkin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/potempkin)] 12-9-2008(63): The Far Side cartoon: Picture a **snake** with glasses and a tie inside of his _house_ in the morning. He's staring at the _spoon_ next to his bowl full of _insects_. "Dang!" he mutters. (thanks to Cheesemaster64).
column8: 4) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 12-12-2008(28): My **snake** secretly eats _insects_ outside the house, but in the _house_ , he uses a _spoon_ and follow etiquette! (adapted from nilfisq).
column9: 5) [[cingold](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cingold)] 13-8-2009(16): Solid **Snake** gets into his _insect_ camouflage ready to infiltrate the _house_ \- the insect suit doesn't allow weapons to be carried so he pilfers a _spoon_ and takes out the Patriots within, getting out aliv…Snake? **Snake**? **SNAAAAAAKEEEEE**!

column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 4-7-2007(257): Little is it known that a **rainbow** is actually created by _insects_ of different colours flying in formation, a _craft_ they have perfected to create the **rainbow** s we see today.
column6: 2) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 7-7-2008(103): **Rainbow** is of course created by billions of colored _insects_ (what? you really thought it was an optical illusion?). However I had problems remembering that the _insect_ primitive goes on the left. If you have similar difficulties, try this: **rainbow** is an _Insect-Craft_. Mnemonic: **I.C. **Rainbow**** (I see **rainbow** ).
column7: 3) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 1-4-2008(36): For my arts and CRAFTs project at school, I made a **rainbow** out of dead BUGs spray painted different colors and glued to some paper. The teacher was not amused.
column8: 4) [[Autolycus91982](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Autolycus91982)] 21-7-2009(16): I see **rainbow**. I.C. **rainbow**. Insect Craft **Rainbow**.
column9: 5) [[mcaruso](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcaruso)] 2-6-2013(14): You know Skittles, "Taste the **RAINBOW** "? The colorant that gives red Skittles their deep crimson color comes from crushing a type of _insect_ called cochineal. So the next time you taste the **RAINBOW** , remember that you're really tasting _insects_ _crafted_ into sweets. (See: <http://snopes.com/food/ingredient/bugjuice.asp>).

column5: 1) [[zwarte_kat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zwarte_kat)] 15-4-2007(360): A **butterfly** is an insect that appears after spending a generation on a tree as a cocoon.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-2-2008(44): Tip: New primitive: Let _Tarzan_ = _generation_ \+ _tree_ – because _Tarzan_ lives with several _generation_ s of his family at the top of a _tree_. (This combination appears five times: [leaf](../v4/228.html) (#228 葉), **butterfly** , (FRAME 521), [chatter](../v4/2158.html) (#2158 喋), [secret agent](../v4/2726.html) (#2726 諜), [label](../v4/2926.html) (#2926 牒)). Story: You see _Tarzan_ swinging from tree to tree chasing an _insect_. Later he shows it to you neatly pinned into his **butterfly** collection.
column7: 3) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 15-6-2007(36): Butterflies are insects that like to eat just the flowers but leave the leaves behind. (helps me to think of the kanji for leaves, minus the flower bit).
column8: 4) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 4-1-2008(17): If an ugly _insect_ can spend many _generations_ in a _tree_ , it will emerge as a beautiful **butterfly**.
column9: 5) [[wilsoncb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wilsoncb)] 4-2-2009(12): Imagine a tree which is weighed down, so much that its bending over, perhaps, by GENERATIONS of accumulated cocoons (this also helps place generation over tree). You know which INSECT is responsible: the **butterfly**.

column3: Think of this key word in connection with bachelorhood. The elements: _wild dogs_ . . . _insect_.
column5: 1) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 19-6-2007(278): The bachelor's apartment looked like it had been attacked by a _pack of wild dogs_. There were even _insects_ in the kitchen. No wonder he's **single**!
column6: 2) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 14-10-2009(123): A **SINGLE** guy is a WILD DOG who BUGS many women.
column7: 3) [[TunS77](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TunS77)] 12-9-2008(31): I'm telling you, _A pack of wild dogs_ were taken down by a **SINGLE** _insect_!!! Shocking, I know.
column8: 4) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 5-11-2007(15): Dawg, you're **single** cuz you got fleas in your hair!
column9: 5) [[killerducky](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/killerducky)] 31-5-2008(11): The bachelor is **single** because he has a _pack of wild dogs_ with _insects_ (flees) instead of a nice dog.

column3: _Heavens_ . . . _insect_. Be sure to do something about the position of the two elements.
column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 31-8-2007(211): There are no _insects_ in _heaven_ \- well, that is, except for **silkworm** s. What, do you expect Jesus to import his fancy robes from China?
column6: 2) [[kokeshidoll17](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kokeshidoll17)] 16-9-2008(164): In China it was believed that the **silkworm** s were _insects_ sent from _heaven_ because of the beautiful material they produced.
column7: 3) [[yawfosu88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yawfosu88)] 5-8-2007(40): Imagine an _insect_ , the **silkworm** descending from a _heavenly_ , golden, cloud- filled sky on a single string of silk.
column8: 4) [[g33kette](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/g33kette)] 4-3-2008(17): Heavenly bug.
column9: 5) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(12): The poor **silkworm** _insect_ goes up to _heaven_ after we boil its coccoon to take its silk.

column3: _Windy_ . . . _drops of_ . . . _insects_. Hint: think of the last two primitives as representing a swarm of _gnats_ , those tiny _drops of_ pesky _insects_.
column5: 1) [[Ceryn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ceryn)] 16-4-2008(137): They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of **WIND** that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 29-1-2008(82): The **WIND** usually carries things around in it - _drops_ of rain or snow, and lots of _insects_.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 31-8-2007(38): Most people don't know that **wind** is actually created by a bunch of insects at the end of the earth. They wake up in the morning, twist their fitted blue baseball caps backwards (see it on top of their head?), and get to work flapping their wings as hard as they can, causing the **wind** shockwave to spread in all directions.
column8: 4) [[burritokun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burritokun)] 28-8-2008(32): Ever heard of the butterfly effect? All it takes is _one_ flap of an insect's wings to alter the _wind_ patterns around the world. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butterfly_effect>.
column9: 5) [[Rujiel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rujiel)] 15-8-2009(22): _Mediocre insects_ get caught in the **wind**.

column3: The kanji carries the abstract sense of the **self** , the deep-down inner structure of the human person that mythology has often depicted as a _snake_ \- which is what the kanji shows pictographically. Be sure to keep it distinct from the similar keywords, _oneself_ (frame 36) and _I_ (frame 17).
column4: * As a primitive element, this kanji can be used for the _snake_  \- of which it is a pictograph - or any of the various concrete symbolic meanings the _snake_ has in myth and fable.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 25-10-2005(255): This kanji looks like the "s" of "self", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his "self".
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 18-8-2007(90): When Superman looks at him **self** in the mirror, this is what he sees on his chest.
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 2-4-2008(46): I is **self** educated! I drawed this "S" all by myself!
column8: 4) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 3-10-2009(40): I can't believe I didn't think of this as a primitive before. What word starts with the letter 's' and ends up producing someone like your 'self' later on? Sperm. Sperm are wiggly, like a snake, Contain 記 written dna records of yourself into them like words on a page, 起 rise up and run out of the penis once they ejaculate. require wrapping to prevent having babies, 包 . The task master of the sperm, 改 , make up ya own story. 紀 an era is like a thread line of different sperm that conquered the days.
column9: 5) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 20-11-2007(25): _SSSSSSSSelf!_.

column5: 1) [[onsen_monkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/onsen_monkey)] 26-9-2006(181): Be careful when you're RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and **ROUSE** a sleeping SNAKE. Then you'll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!
column6: 2) [[mfistik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mfistik)] 16-10-2007(97): Nothing will **rouse** you quite as much as finding a snake in your bed. You will run away like you've never run before!
column7: 3) [[smujohnson](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smujohnson)] 16-7-2008(47): Yelling " _Run!!!_ _Snake!!!_ " is more than enough to **rouse** anyone nearby.
column8: 4) [[ngoli1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ngoli1)] 5-10-2007(41): I was having a nightmare that I was running from a snake when my mum **rouse** d me from my sleep. "Wakey, wakey, run from snakey!".
column9: 5) [[dizzwave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dizzwave)] 12-5-2008(16): Whenever I **rouse** myself from bed, I find that all the blood has mysteriously _run_ to my _snake_. (The same can be said for being a-roused!).

column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 17-2-2007(233): Cleopatra.
column6: 2) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 6-9-2007(145): Be careful you don't pick up a drag **queen** at a club - they might look like women, but they have a snake down there!
column7: 3) [[rizzo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rizzo)] 20-10-2005(68): **Queen** Cleopatra ends her reign (and life) with the help of a _snake_.
column8: 4) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 9-10-2005(36): Medusa, the snake **queen**. She's the penultimate "snake woman".
column9: 5) [[Daffydus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Daffydus)] 17-7-2009(24): A **queen** is a woman who only thinks about her [self](../v4/525.html) (#525 己).

column3: Pluralizing the _snake_ and focusing on a single _taskmaster_ may help recommend the image of Ireland's most famous **reformer** , St. Patrick, who, legend has it, drove away the _snakes_ from the land.
column5: 1) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 8-1-2008(167): The _taskmaster_ of Slytherin ( wizardry house symbolized by a _snake_ ) plans a **reformation** of Hogwarts, disallowing the study of magic to all muggle- born. こわいですね！.
column6: 2) [[krungthep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/krungthep)] 4-6-2008(110): If you want to achieve the **reformation** of your _inner self_ you have to control your desires and correct your flaws, in sum, be your own _self taskmaster_.
column7: 3) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(98): This is a Meiji **reformation** _taskmaster_ , trying to force usage of the Roman alphabet in Japan in place of Kanji. He holds a _snake_ in the shape of the letter S and tries to explain how much simpler this is (j/k).
column8: 4) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 7-1-2011(37): The **Reformation** was led by Martin Luther, regarded as a _serpent_ -in-the- grass by the Catholic Church, but as a noble _taskmaster_ by his followers. 改革 かいかく reform, **reformation** , innovation, 改札 かいさつ ticket gate, 改める あらためる to change, alter, reform, revise.
column9: 5) [[munia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munia)] 2-9-2008(23): _Snake_ s are so twisted that only the most skilled _taskmaster_ can achieve their **reformation**.

column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 4-7-2007(165): A **scribe** writes down the _words_ spoken by a _snake_ (i.e. a lawyer).
column6: 2) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 29-12-2007(109): **Snakes** have no hands. So, when a **snake** needs to write down something, it has to call in a **SCRIBE** , who will write down all the **say** ings of the **snake**.
column7: 3) [[samesong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samesong)] 25-8-2008(26): This **scribe** was truely badass - to jot down _words_ , he would grab the nearest _snake_ and squeeze it's venom out of it's fangs and use it as ink.. no pen for this guy.
column8: 4) [[elhnad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elhnad)] 12-1-2008(26): A **scribe** writes down the _words_ using the _snakes_ venom.
column9: 5) [[rizzo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rizzo)] 20-10-2005(24): The **scribe** s of yore had no pens or paper. To transcribe _words_ they had to train _snakes_ to twist their bodies into letters as they were spoken to.

column4: * The primitive meaning of _wrap_ should always be used with the _snake_ in mind to avoid confusion with similar terms. Just let  " _wrap_ " mean "with a snake coiled about it."
column5: 1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 7-6-2006(216): The _snake_ _bound up_ its prey by **wrapping** his body around it.
column6: 2) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 4-8-2007(37): Imagine Jessie sending in her _Ekans_ (snake pokemon), and telling it to use _bind_ attack to **wrap** up pikachu.
column7: 3) [[burritokun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burritokun)] 28-8-2008(22): **Wrap** it before you tap it (wrap what? your _snake_ , of course…).
column8: 4) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 19-6-2009(14): Picture a _snake_ all _bound up_ in **wrap** ping paper (to keep from confusing it with other kanji).
column9: 5) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 27-2-2009(8): When you **WRAP** a Christmas gift, you BIND it UP by your - SELF.

column5: 1) [[wzafran](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wzafran)] 16-7-2007(157): Imagine a newborn baby, fresh out of the womb, being entirely _wrapped_ by the long piece of _flesh_ , called a **placenta** , that once fed him.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(81): **Placenta** is _flesh/part of the body_ _wrapped_ around the foetus.
column7: 3) [[Phil2Musashi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Phil2Musashi)] 2-4-2009(32): **Placenta** is the flesh that wrapped around us when we were in the womb.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 8-11-2010(17): 胞子 , 共産党細胞 , 細胞核 , 同胞 ,[placenta](../v4/531.html) (#531 胞)ホウ( 包 ) … Parts: 月 , 包 … Note: Not **Placenta** , that's 胎盤 [womb](../v4/748.html) (#748 胎). 胞 is any body sac, of any living thing, including cells ( 細胞 ). … Story: A _Part of the body_ that completely _wraps_ something up: a cell, a **placenta** , a spore. Include the umbilical cord as part of the **placenta** _wrapped around the fetus like a snake_ After the Fetus is born he swings the snake around like a lasso. YeeeHa!
column9: 5) [[Hujis](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hujis)] 28-2-2009(11): The **placenta** is the part of the body which feeds the baby. However this unlucky baby didnt make it because the **placenta** wrapped around its neck and choked it to death. Not a nice story, but a memorable one. (And I know it's the umbilical cord that feeds the baby, but that doesnt affect the story).

column5: 1) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 22-9-2007(162): Primitive **cannons** fired _stones_ _wrapped_ with poisonous snakes.
column6: 2) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 23-4-2008(131): **Cannon** = _stone_ projectile _wrapped_ by a barrel.
column7: 3) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 25-10-2007(23): A _stone_ _wrap_ ped in smoke blazes from the mouth of a **cannon**.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(20): Picture a very powerful **cannon** (such as on pirate ships), only this one's on an island, and pointed at the sea. It's recoil had to be dealt with somehow, so it is placed in a tight-fitting alcove of _stone_. Hence " _stone- wrapped_ **cannon** ".
column9: 5) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 3-1-2011(16): Rather than a **cannon** , think of a catapult or trebuchet. Both these siege engines fire a large _stone_ that is initially _wrapped_ up or cradled in some fashion. 鉄砲 (てっぽう) : gun.

column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 4-7-2007(236): When _water_ forms a bubble, it _wraps_ a pocket of air.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 18-8-2007(81): To prevent people from popping bubble wrap for fun, the post office has started filling the **bubbles** with water.
column7: 3) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 28-5-2008(30): **Bubbles** are just air wrapped up in a layer of water.
column8: 4) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 29-12-2009(15): **Bubbles** are WATER WRAPPED around air.
column9: 5) [[pjhoover](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pjhoover)] 29-2-2008(9): Anyone remember the disney version of robin hood? the snake falls into the ale (water) then goes about spying on robin hood as a helicopter with a bubble wrapped around his head.

column3: This is not a _turtle_ (See frame 250) but a **tortoise** , however you wish to picture the difference. Let the " _bound up_ " at the to prefer to the head, and the two _suns_ , with a long tail running through it, to the shell.
column4: * As a primitive, this kanji is abbreviated to its bottom half, ⻲, and comes to mean _eel_. (If it is any help, this kanji in its full form can also be remembered through its abbreviation's primitive meaning.)
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 27-10-2007(219): It seems bizarre, but **tortoise** s are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. Where the shell comes from, no one knows.
column6: 2) [[skylarth](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skylarth)] 15-6-2008(118): A **tortoise** is _prosperity_ _bound up_ with a _tail_. They are very lucky creatures.
column7: 3) [[elanlan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elanlan)] 18-4-2009(30): **Tortoise** s are known to live relatively long lives (it is not uncommon for them to exceed 100 years of age). Thus, a **tortoise** is a creature that is _bound_ by its shell to see _many days_ , with its little tail peeking out.
column8: 4) [[Yuta73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yuta73)] 20-11-2010(26): **Tortoise**. DBZ. This is goku's symbol in his back. How can I forget it!
column9: 5) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 26-5-2010(9): [addition to dwhitman's] It seems bizarre, but **tortoise** s are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. They are the symbol of prosperity (stroke order).

column5: 1) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 15-2-2011(170): Think of a two natural sources of **electricity** : electrical storms (a form of _weather_ ) and electrical _eel_ s. 電話 でんわ phone, call, 電気 (でんき) : **electricity** , (electric) light.
column6: 2) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(45): This kanji was invented by the first Chinaman to discover **electricity**. He was so unfortunate, he stepped on an electric _eel_ and got struck by _lighting_ at the same time.
column7: 3) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 4-10-2008(30): When it RAINS , if you put an electric EEL in the swimming pool , you can generate **ELECTRICITY**.
column8: 4) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 22-6-2008(16): It's unwise to stand in the _rain_ while holding an _electric_ **eel**. Picture getting struck by lightning because of this.
column9: 5) [[Norman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Norman)] 23-1-2013(14): If it _rains_ on an electric _eel_ , expect **electricity**.

column3: _Vase_ . . . _eel_. In order not to confuse this kanji with the zodiacal _sign of the dragon_ , which we will meet later (Frame 2164) and use as a primitive, you might think here of a paper parade **dragon**.
column5: 1) [[niktok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/niktok)] 6-9-2007(223): Have you ever seen an asian **DRAGON**? it looks like an eel, but can stand up because it has legs.
column6: 2) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 23-4-2008(79): A **dragon** is like a _standing_ _eel_.
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-1-2007(61): If the poor villagers don't provide him with a _vase_ full of _eels_ each day, the **dragon** will lay waste to the village.
column8: 4) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 30-1-2008(26): **Dragon** s actually evolved from _eels_ a long time ago - they learned to _stand up_ and became much bigger (and the ability to produce electricity evolved into fire-breathing).
column9: 5) [[deadsexylady](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/deadsexylady)] 22-4-2008(17): Think Mushu from Mulan. Mushu was far from the most impressive **dragon**. He looked nothing more than a _eel_ _standing up_. Mulan was very disappointed.

column3: _Water_ . . . _vase_ . . . _eels_. To avoid the confusion mentioned in the previous frame, the character learned there for _dragon_ should not be used as a primitive.
column5: 1) [[mhaellix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhaellix)] 19-9-2007(164): The Water Dragon dwells in the **waterfall**.
column6: 2) [[smujohnson](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smujohnson)] 16-7-2008(82): Ever went under a **waterfall** , _vase_ in hand, trying to catch _eels_ from the _water_ as it pours down?
column7: 3) [[migge](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/migge)] 22-1-2009(54): A **WATERFALL** makes the WATER roar like a DRAGON.
column8: 4) [[snozle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snozle)] 2-2-2009(38): I imagine an incredibly high **waterfall** spilling into a small _vase_. Several _eel_ are swimming over the edge and having a diving competition to see whether they can make it into the _vase_. Just imagine a few missing and you're set.
column9: 5) [[Xzbeat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Xzbeat)] 3-10-2009(21): In Saint Seiya, the _**Dragon**_ knight was always training under a **Waterfall**.

column5: 1) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 26-4-2006(203): **Pork** comes from the flesh of a sow.
column6: 2) [[Kieron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kieron)] 16-5-2007(72): One possible pictograph for " **sow** " primitive: the top line is a feeding trough, the stroke touching it is the head, the long curved stroke is the body (with a little hook at the end for the curly tail), and the four remaining strokes are the sow's legs.
column7: 3) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 15-3-2008(21): When a mother pig nurses its piglets, we call it a SOW. When that same mother pig's _body parts_ are on our plates, we call them **PORK**.
column8: 4) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 4-1-2008(14): **Pork** is the name we give to the _flesh_ of a _sow_.
column9: 5) [[FuDaWei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FuDaWei)] 13-6-2010(7): When Kermit was caught eating barbecued **PORK** rinds at the bar with Fozzie, he spent an entire _month_ apologizing to _Miss Piggy_.

column5: 1) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(155): In association with [consummate](../v4/540.html) (#540 遂), our _sow_ is on the road **pursuing** a mate.
column6: 2) [[samueruht](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samueruht)] 19-1-2008(42): The _pig_ is on the _road_ in the **pursue** of the turtle who is trying to [escape](../v4/283.html) (#283 逃). (See story on [escape](../v4/283.html) (#283 逃) & [consummate](../v4/540.html) (#540 遂)).
column7: 3) [[genbaku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/genbaku)] 7-1-2008(40): In order to hunt for food one must **pursue** the fat sow on the road.
column8: 4) [[dizzwave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dizzwave)] 15-5-2008(36): Miss Piggy, everybody's favorite _sow_ , is hitting the _road_ to **pursue** her long lost Kermit the frog.
column9: 5) [[laner36](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laner36)] 11-7-2007(24): Think of cops (P.I.G.s) pursuing someone down the road. (e.g. a Ron Ronnie Run clip).

column3: The _horns_ atop the _sow_ suggest a boar at work in the background. Add the element for a _road_. Now create a story whose meaning is: **consummate**.
column5: 1) [[rizzo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rizzo)] 20-10-2005(173): This is still Miss Piggy only she's gotten _horny_ (as she often does) and now she's _pursuing_ Kermit to help her **consummate** her desires.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 30-6-2008(74): I don't often complain about Heisig's keywords - but 'consummate' is a little misleading. Think about this kanji in terms of **ACCOMPLISH** or "realize" rather than a sexual encounter. Or, combine the two: the policemen thought they had **accomplished** the task of _driving out_ (see **pursue** , last frame) all the _sows_ , but they received a phone call reporting two _horny_ pigs **CONSUMMATING** on a _road_. When they got there, they found a male and female police officer, not pigs!
column7: 3) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(73): In association with [pursue](../v4/539.html) (#539 逐), our _sow_ has tracked down a suitable mate, they've **consummate** d their relationship, and now the _little sow_ is all grown up into a _boar_ with horns.
column8: 4) [[noushina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/noushina)] 19-1-2007(33): The Horny Pig **Consummate** s in the middle of the Road.
column9: 5) [[samueruht](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samueruht)] 19-1-2008(16): The turtle promised to marry the pig, but after some second thoughts the turtle is on the road trying to [escape](../v4/283.html) (#283 逃) and the pig is on the [pursue](../v4/539.html) (#539 逐). We end up with a _horn_ y _pursue_ r trying to **consummate** the matrimony.

column3: This is the full character whose primitive form we learned already. To help a little, this kanji recalls the times when the "domestic" animals were, as the word itself suggests, really kept in the **house**. Hence: _house_ . . . _sow_.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 1-11-2006(245): Think of "The Three Little Pigs". There was a _house_ made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a _pig_. So, naturally, _housetop_ over _pig_ means **house** , the central element of that story.
column6: 2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 10-2-2008(41): Man, ever hear of cleaning? This **house** is a _pig_ sty.
column7: 3) [[mattoc_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattoc_g)] 12-4-2006(21): Miss piggy in the hooooooooooooooooouse.
column8: 4) [[chucklol](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chucklol)] 24-2-2010(14): ALL YOUR _HOUSE_ ARE BELONG TO _PIG_.
column9: 5) [[ew8049](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ew8049)] 5-8-2008(7): ANIMAL FARM - The PIGS took to taking charge of the barn **HOUSE**.

column3: The kanji in this frame demonstrates the traditional Japanese approach to marriage: it is the _woman_ who leaves her family for another _house_ hold, thus **marrying into** a man's family.
column5: 1) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(188): Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the _woman_ feels more like she's married into the _house_ than into a relationship.
column6: 2) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 16-5-2008(102): Traditionally, it was the _women_ who would **marry into** the _households_ of their husband's families.
column7: 3) [[yawfosu88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yawfosu88)] 21-8-2007(20): Imagine a beautiful _woman_ , say Rihanna, being married inside your _house to a pig_ , an actual pig. Your house is filled with her pig family dressed up like humans. 'I can't believe it, this beautiful woman is about to **marry into** a pig family right in my house!'.
column8: 4) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 4-5-2011(15): 婿嫁婚姻 : Four kanji related to marriage, all with the _woman_ primitive. **Bridegroom** : for the honeymoon, he takes her to the _zoo_ for a _month_. **Marry into** : since the J-husband is never home, she feels more like she's married into the _house_ than into a relationship. **Marriage** : is when she gets a new _family name_ on one particular _day_. **Matrimony** : is the state after the marriage, where she has the husband _pent in_ like a _dog_ … 嫁 [よめ].
column9: 5) [[mattoc_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattoc_g)] 25-10-2006(8): A poor woman marrying into the house of a real pig.

column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 22-11-2007(300): In Orwell's 'Animal Farm' the pigs **overpowered** every other animals. They _crownded_ themselves as ruler of the farm and walked _tall_ on their rear legs, a crime strictly forbidden in the animal republic.
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 6-4-2008(121): Ganon, the _tall crowned pig_ , has been **overpowering** ther land of Hyrule for decades.
column7: 3) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 24-8-2007(36): The tall, crowned "king-porker" from Orwell's Animal Farm was an **overpowering** pig named Napoleon.
column8: 4) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 28-12-2008(33): This kanji is also used for **Australia**. Think about it from Japan's point of view. On average Australians are taller than the Japanese. Australia is nominally a monarchy, indicated by the crown. As far as manners go, compared to the Japanese, typical ockers are pigs.
column9: 5) [[bigspenderJ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bigspenderJ)] 8-2-2007(24): Imagine a tall crown wearing Ms. Piggy beating the $#it out of Kermit…

column5: 1) [[Twentytw0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Twentytw0)] 21-7-2007(220): **Intestines** are the part of the body that is taken out of piglets to make piggy banks. Just imagine factory workers scraping out the **intestines** of real piglets and packaging them up for little children.
column6: 2) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(144): Taking things too literally, you used a real _piglet_ as a _piggy bank_. Now when you smash it open to get your coins out, you have to dig out your coins from its **intestines**. ew.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 18-12-2006(61): Imagine a child's horror if upon smashing open his _piggy bank_ , instead of coins, **instestines** ( _flesh_ ) pours out.
column8: 4) [[nagisa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nagisa)] 6-7-2006(54): The **intestines** are like the _piggy bank_ of your _flesh_ , everyday you deposit a little more into them…
column9: 5) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 26-4-2009(22): The **INTESTINES** are the part of our BODY that acts like our PIGGY BANKS. We store our food in it!

column5: 1) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(259): You're looking for a good **location** to bury your _piggy bank_ savings. It has to be in some soft _soil_ that's easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to rememger like this kanji.
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 27-1-2008(86): Don't confuse with [place](../v4/1127.html) (#1127 所). Think of **location** not as a single fixed spot, but as the act of locating. You've buried your _piggy bank_ in the _dirt_ in your backyard, but you can't remember where. You frantically dig everywhere in a process of **location** to find your piggy bank.
column7: 3) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 6-4-2008(42): **Location** , **location** , **location** , they say in the real estate business, cuz they know if you find the right bit of _soil,_ you can pretty much take that to the _(piggy) bank_.
column8: 4) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 23-2-2009(35): A pile of **soil** marks the **location** of where I burried my **piggy-bank**.
column9: 5) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 16-10-2006(18): A pirate finally finds the **location** of a legendary buried treasure, where X marked the spot. But after long hours of digging, he discovers it was just some kid's piggy bank. ARRRRR!!!!

column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 31-8-2007(305): Imagine a **hot water** kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!
column6: 2) [[Clint](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Clint)] 13-7-2008(33): **Hot water** is a phrase that can mean "getting into trouble." This kanji pictures just one of the many meanings of that phrase: it's _water_ that you get into (with creditors and the like) when your _piggy bank_ is empty!
column7: 3) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 4-2-2008(32): My **HOT WATER** cut off because I forgot to pay the bill. So I break open my _piggy bank_ and run to the local 銭湯 (sentou, public bath).
column8: 4) [[sethg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethg)] 26-2-2009(17): **Hot water** is the kind of _water_ you don't have when your _piggy bank_ is empty.
column9: 5) [[Savara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Savara)] 13-4-2008(13): If you put your _piggy bank_ in **hot _water_** you will make sure no one can get to it… … including yourself.

column3: This pictograph shows the animal _horns_ at the top attached to the head (3rd stroke), the front and back legs (strokes 4 and 5) and body (final stroke).
column4: * The primitive meaning of _sheep_ can add the further connotations given in the following frame. As we saw with the _cow_ , the "tail" is cut off when it is set immediately over another element: ⺷. Note the change in stroke order, as exemplified in the following frame.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 23-10-2007(127): Picture of a **sheep** run over by a steam roller. Must have been a ram, note the horns.
column6: 2) [[dtstutz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dtstutz)] 11-1-2008(26): Our **Lord and King** put on **ears** and a **tail** to become a lowly **sheep** for the slaughter.
column7: 3) [[BooBooQ88](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BooBooQ88)] 15-5-2009(25): The horny king of the **SHEEP** had a huge erection.
column8: 4) [[cbogart](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cbogart)] 26-12-2006(17): (you might consider using something with a religious connotation when used as a primitive, like "lamb of god" or something, because **sheep** seems to appear in a lot of religious kanji).
column9: 5) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 16-2-2008(9): DO NOT CONFUSE these **SHEEP** S with the SHIPS in the OCEAN ( frame 549). The only difference is the water. 羊 洋 .

column3: Try to think of what the Chinese were on to when they associated the idea of **beauty** with a _large sheep_.
column5: 1) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 4-1-2008(163): I guess this kanji proves it's not just the Welsh whose idea of **beauty** is a _large_ _sheep_.
column6: 2) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 25-7-2007(75): A _Sheep_ on top of a _dog_ is NOT a **beautiful** thing.
column7: 3) [[axelb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/axelb)] 15-6-2008(55): Who is more beautiful, a _sheep_ or a _st. Bernhard dog_? Imagine a big contest with many judges, then let the sheep win, since it is on top in the kanji (perhaps even let the _sheep_ ride on the _st. Bernhard dog_ because it won).
column8: 4) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 23-8-2007(42): Sheep dogs are **beautiful** animals.
column9: 5) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 15-2-2007(23): (Image: a bunch of _big sheep_ in a **beauty** pageant, bikinis and evening dresses and all).

column3: _Water_ . . . _sheep_. Be sure to keep the stories and key word of this kanji distinct from those for _sea_. (Frame 500).
column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 1-3-2008(411): This kanji refers to the _water_ s of the Pa _sheep_ hic **ocean**.
column6: 2) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 31-8-2007(88): Remember the story of Jason and the Argonauts from Greek myth? Jason travelled across _oceans_ of _water_ in order to recover the fleece of a certain _sheep_.
column7: 3) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 22-9-2007(73): If you drop a _sheep_ into an **ocean** , it will soak up all the _water_ with its thick coat of wool.
column8: 4) [[KathyinSB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/KathyinSB)] 16-5-2008(29): When you look at the **ocean** , those little whitecaps look like _sheep_ in the _water_.
column9: 5) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 13-11-2005(16): _Sheep_ are pretty absorbent. If you had a few billion _sheep_ handy, you could drop them all into the **ocean** and soak up all of the _water_ , thereby creating a big white fluffy _sheep_ **ocean**.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 13-12-2007(296): Trembling from head to hoof from such a traumatic experience, the _sheep_ gives a very **detailed** worded account to the detective about his wolf attack. "We need more details Mr. Sheep. Tell us exactly where the baaad man touched you".
column6: 2) [[graham6565](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/graham6565)] 12-11-2006(56): _Say_! **detailed** _sheep_ , not like that! DE-TAILED _sheep_. Got it?
column7: 3) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 31-5-2007(50): Babe had to remember the **detailed** _words_ of the _sheep_ in order to get through to them. Anything less **detailed** and they will just act like crazy _sheep_.
column8: 4) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 1-8-2008(48): The next time you can't sleep, instead of counting _sheep_ , think of _word_ y _sheep_ , boring you with **details** of their mundane lives (baa, baa, baa, ………zzzzz). 詳しい (くわしい): knowledgeable, **detailed** 詳細 (しょうさい): details, particulars.
column9: 5) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 22-9-2007(31): **Detailed** _words_ must not be said _sheepishly_.

column5: 1) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 10-4-2007(268): The **fresh** est _fish_ is caught in the middle of the night while most people are "counting _sheep_." (If you've ever been to Tsukiji fish market, you know what I mean).
column6: 2) [[Bullfrog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Bullfrog)] 27-6-2009(222): This one's easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased **fresh**. To remember which foods, take the first letter of **fresh** , "F", to stand for fish and the final sound of **fresh** , "SH", to stand for sheep: **FreSH**. It even puts the primitives in the right order.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(31): There was a fisherman living near the coast, who was also raising _sheep_. One of his _sheep_ once died after eating not-so-fresh _fish_ , and since then, the fisherman's been feeding his _sheep_ with **fresh** _fish_. – "fresh fish for the _sheep_ ".
column8: 4) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 14-10-2009(29): I like my FISH 'n' SHEEPS (chips) **FRESH**.
column9: 5) [[sheetz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sheetz)] 11-7-2007(16): To keep your fish **fresh** , wrap them up in sheepskins.

column3: The key word is meant to connote someone "skilled" at something. On the _road_ we find _soil_ OVER _a sheep_. You may have to work with this one a while longer.
column5: 1) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 30-12-2007(202): Dolly (the first cloned **sheep** ever) grow tired of being a celebrity and escaped from the labs by digging a tunnel. She turned out to be an **ACCOMPLISHED** escapist, as she managed to dig a **road** under the **soil**. **/** Imagine Dolly performing a escape, like those movies where the main character has to escape from jail.
column6: 2) [[erlog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erlog)] 20-3-2007(87): The dirty sheep had come far down this road and had **accomplished** many things.
column7: 3) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 16-7-2008(64): I see this character used most often as the "-dachi" in _tomodachi._ And so, as we travel the _roads_ of the _earth_ , we gather a flock of _sheep_ (friends). And only then we can say we have **accomplished** much.
column8: 4) [[tuuli](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tuuli)] 11-12-2007(41): Only the most **accomplished** grave digger can cover a _sheep_ with _dirt_ in the middle of the _road_ and have no one find the grave.
column9: 5) [[Sabien](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sabien)] 14-4-2009(30): Cover the _road_ kill _sheep_ with _soil_ before the farmer sees, we drive off, mission **accomplished** …

column3: _Sheep_ . . . _water_ . . . _yawn/lack_. Although this character looks rather simple, special care should be taken in learning it because of the proximity of the final two elements to the character for _next_ , which we learned in frame 510. Note, too, that the _water_ comes UNDER the _sheep_ , rather than on its own to the left.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(289): A very thirsty sheep, who always _lacked_ _water_ , spends his days watching his fellow _sheep_ (in the farm next door or in another pen) and being very **envious** of their _water_.
column6: 2) [[dtstutz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dtstutz)] 11-1-2008(153): **Envious** of the greener grass on the other side of the fence, the **sheep** looks down in disgust at his own dry grass **lacking water**.
column7: 3) [[the_marshal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/the_marshal)] 27-9-2007(42): Some ppl have to try things like counting SHEEP or DRINKING a glass of water before they can sleep. Some other can just YAWN and fall asleep… you can be **ENVIOUS** of those one.
column8: 4) [[squeaky_lill_mk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/squeaky_lill_mk)] 5-5-2009(37): A _sheep_ that _lacks_ _water_ is **envious** of those who have it.
column9: 5) [[natemb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/natemb)] 6-6-2008(21): Unlike cotton, wool is warm even when wet, because it wicks water away from the skin. Many animals have cool adaptations and abilities that I wish I had, but I am most **envious** of _sheep_ , because even if they get wet on the outside, the _water_ is _lacking_ UNDERNEATH. (helps to remember the water-lack part goes on the bottom).

column5: 1) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 3-6-2007(224): This New-Zealand pro-gamer has won many **distinctions** playing _WoolCraft_ (a massively multi-user game in which the goal is to shear sheep).
column6: 2) [[samueruht](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samueruht)] 26-1-2008(164): The **distinction** between fine and common wool, is the _craft_ smanship of the _wool_.
column7: 3) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 5-8-2007(141): Noob players make no **distinction** between what games they play, whether it's the geniune thing or a bootleg fake copy. The biggest example of course, would be the legit World of Warcraft and the biggest ripoff there is: World of _Wool_ - _craft_!
column8: 4) [[tuuli](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tuuli)] 11-12-2007(40): Since all sheep look alike, it is hard to make a **distinction** between them. You have to learn the _craft_ of telling them apart by their _wool_.
column9: 5) [[saxman_52](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saxman_52)] 12-6-2009(18): A **distinction** must be made between "World of Warcraft" and " _Wool_ over _Craft_.".

column3: I cannot resist doing this one for you, since it clearly describes **donning** (putting on) one's clothes as  "pulling the _wool_ over one's _eyes_. "
column5: 1) [[mocm12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mocm12)] 20-3-2006(167): A pullover is **don** ned by pulling wool over your eyes.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-6-2006(65): Someone who is **don** ning a disguise does that in order to pull the _wool_ over your _eyes_.
column7: 3) [[Cheesemaster64](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cheesemaster64)] 12-8-2008(22): **Don** Juan caught a disease called Wool-eye. Now women **Don** Juan anything to do with him. (ROFL).
column8: 4) [[tcjeff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tcjeff)] 7-6-2008(11): I imagine a very tight _wool_ sweater, maybe a gift from uncle **Don**. This _wool_ sweater is so tight that it makes your _eyes_ bug out when you pull it over your head, but you have to **don** it every time uncle **Don** comes to visit and pretend you love it.
column9: 5) [[aerdeyn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aerdeyn)] 17-11-2011(7): The wolf **donned** his disguise by pulling the _wool_ over his _eyes_.

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 4-12-2006(270): The _mouth_ of a _turkey_ is used **solely** for saying, "Gobble." Likewise, your _mouth_ , full of _turkey_ , is **solely** used to gobble it up.
column6: 2) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 7-1-2008(113): Sadly my _mouth_ gets to taste _turkey_ **solely** on Christmas Day.
column7: 3) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 13-2-2008(64): "We can't prosecutre the murderer based **solely** on what comes from the mouth of this turkey!" Imagine a turkey who witnessed a murder of his fellow kind (to be eaten) and trying to report it to the cops.
column8: 4) [[diracbracket](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/diracbracket)] 9-1-2011(50): To be remembered in conjunction with its virtual synonym "only". All we need to remember is this: "only" gets the _turkey_ 's legs, and **solely** gets the rest of the _turkey_.
column9: 5) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 25-6-2008(31): Remember the episode of Friends, when no one except Joey wanted turkey for thanksgiving? Joey insisted, "what kind of thanksgiving would it be without a turkey?" so Monica agreed to make one, if he could eat it all by himself. A whole _turkey_ **solely** for the _mouth_ of Joey Tribbiani! Just picture him sitting there, with a huge _turkey_ on the table in front of him, stuffing it in his _mouth_. If I recall correctly, he still had some space left for the desert!

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 15-6-2007(71): After our pre-Thanksgiving massacre, we **piled high** all the _turkey_ corpses atop the _soil_ of the farmyard.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 30-6-2008(36): During the _Turkey_ Holocaust (this is what the animal kingdom calls Thanksgiving - they have really short memories and thus don't recall that it actually happens every single year), _turkeys_ are killed en masse, and their bodies are **piled high**. To keep them from tumbling down, a pile of _dirt_ is **piled high** right next to them to keep them standing upright so that they will be fresh when it is time to eat them.
column7: 3) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 29-8-2010(15): The farmer awakes Thanksgiving morning to find huge mounds of dirt **piled high** in front all of his doors and windows. He can't get out. Clever turkeys.
column8: 4) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 25-1-2009(7): _Soil_ **piled high** on top of a _turkey_ with only it's gobbler sticking out.
column9: 5) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 16-9-2010(4): The turkey is making a pile of soil (piled high) trying to hide its doo doo.

column5: 1) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 17-11-2009(59): This is the kanji for the shii _tree_ , on which shiitake ( 椎茸 ) mushrooms grow. It's easy to picture a _turkey_ dropping by the shii _tree_ to gobble down some of those **sweet oaky** (shiitake) mushrooms.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 13-6-2007(31): Why is the **sweet oak** so sweet? Not sure, but to me it tastes just like _turkey_ (with gravy and cranberry sauce!) Now that is sweet.
column7: 3) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 22-12-2011(15): I always use **SWEET OAK** WOOD to add flavor to roasted TURKEY.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 8-11-2010(4): 無脊椎動物 , 脊椎動物 , 脊椎 , 椎骨 , 椎骨 , 椎茸 , [sweet oak](../v4/2505.html) (#2505 椎) ツイ,しい … Tree now written ツイ. Used for **Spine** 脊椎, and Shiitake 椎茸 . Replacing the key word to **Spine** ( お風呂 [spine](../v4/24.html) (#24 呂) is a phonetic only character), remember the 仙台 hermits we 催す [sponsor](../v4/987.html) (#987 催) 'd? Well we got them out of the _mountains_ and then we got the _Mountains_ out of them by telling them to get a **Spine** and got a job. (mnemonic 2: Oak is Sweeter than Shiit~ake).
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 22-3-2007(4): The _turkey_ liked to search for food under the **sweet oak** _tree_ , believing that sweet grains would grow there.

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 28-11-2008(87): Do you remember that song where they _say_ " **Who** let the _turkeys_ out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble"?
column6: 2) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 5-2-2007(40): [who, someone, somebody] You're alone when, suddenly, you think you hear someone _speak_ ing. " **Who** 's there?", you _say_ , but there is no answer. Then you find out it was only a _turkey_ gobbling. You feel relieved (and ashamed to tell this story). (Based on raulir).
column7: 3) [[Wally](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wally)] 10-4-2009(23): **Who** talks turkey? (I'm surprised this common American phrase 'talk turkey' hasn't made it in here. It is North American centric, however – and how the _heck_ is this _not_ in RTK 1? I mean, primary school kids have to know this kanji.).
column8: 4) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 29-4-2006(16): " **Who** 's there?" he says, but it was only a turkey.
column9: 5) [[hknamida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hknamida)] 21-1-2008(11): _Socrates_ spins around, startled. " **Who** 's there?" It turns out that it is only a _turkey_ , and the philosopher is safe… for now. （だれ）.

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 15-11-2006(208): When I put the _turkey_ over the _oven fire_ , it always ends up being **charred** beyond recognition. I'm not a very good cook.
column6: 2) [[tcjeff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tcjeff)] 7-6-2008(67): **Char** could be any meat over _oven fire_. So why is it a _turkey_ in this kanji? Because **char** red _turkey_ is what sticks out most in your mind as the thing that ruined Thanksgiving dinner.
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 22-12-2007(26): We see here the _roadrunner_ , running so fast that it **chars** the ground beneath it, leaving a trace of _fire_.
column8: 4) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 21-8-2008(19): Turkey is not very common in Japan. (found only in Subway sandwiches!) So when Japanese try to barbecue turkey on the grill, they always **char** the meat. _masaka!_.
column9: 5) [[Apple_Head](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Apple_Head)] 2-10-2009(10): Unfortunately, Ash Ketchum's **char** mander sucked so bad it devolved into a **char** turkey. **Char** mander has flames on its tail, **char** turkey has flames on its butt.

column5: 1) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 9-3-2006(206): **Reef** s are often formed from volcanic rock, or "rock that has been charred".
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 12-10-2006(173): Coral **reef** s are now dying off due to our abuse of the environment and now look like _charred stone_. For a picture illustrating this, see <http://www.nacri.org/images/Hof-dredgingfig8.jpg>.
column7: 3) [[ruukukun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruukukun)] 26-7-2010(28): You may be familiar with this unfortunate natural phenomenon. The Coral **Reef** s are some of the most beautiful habitats in the world, full of color and life. However, recently due to overfishing, the **reef** s have been undergoing something called Coral Bleaching. The algae dies off, and the sun _chars_ the coral, leaving nothing but a barren wasteland that looks like _charred rock_. The color is gone and all you have left is bone-dry, white _rocky charred_ stuff.
column8: 4) [[libsrone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/libsrone)] 6-5-2008(25): A turkey gets stoned on **reef** ers to prepare itself for the oblivion of the oven.
column9: 5) [[Clint](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Clint)] 16-7-2008(14): This character illustrates ancient ideas about the origin of coral **reefs**. Although we now know that coral are in fact marine organisms, the ancients thought that **reefs** looked like a gigantic pile of _stones_ that had been _charred_.

column5: 1) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 30-8-2007(198): Hunter-gathers, searching all along the ground for food. They never look up and see the Turkeys that have **gather** ed on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!
column6: 2) [[dsamari](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dsamari)] 14-10-2007(110): **Gather** the turkeys for Thanksgiving. **Gather** the trees for Christmas. In that order…
column7: 3) [[henroski](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/henroski)] 2-2-2008(26): A **GATHER** of turkeys up a tree, K-I-S-S-I-N-G.
