column8: 4) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 6-4-2007(22): The TURKEYS **GATHER** ED in the top of the TREE……..who knew they could fly up there??
column9: 5) [[yukkuri_kame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yukkuri_kame)] 18-6-2009(17): American families **gather** around a TURKEY at Thanksgiving and around a TREE at Christmas. I prefer the Turkey over the Tree. [集まる＝集まる＝](midori://search?text=集まる＝集まる＝) to **gather** [集める＝集める](midori://search?text=集める＝集める) =to collect. Examples: [皆が集まる＝](midori://search?text=皆が集まる＝) Everybody **gather** ed together. [私は皆を集める＝](midori://search?text=私は皆を集める＝) I **gather** ed everybody together.

column5: 1) [[mattoc_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattoc_g)] 18-7-2006(323): **Quasi-** modo, the famous hunchback of Notre-Dame wasn't actually a hunchback at all!! He used a frozen turkey to make a hunch!
column6: 2) [[bigspenderJ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bigspenderJ)] 12-3-2007(110): An iced turkey is only **quasi-** as-good-as fresh turkey.
column7: 3) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 6-4-2008(56): You're having a _frozen turkey_ for dinner? Come on, that's not a real meal…that's a **quasi-** meal at best!
column8: 4) [[GenPDP7](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GenPDP7)] 21-12-2007(21): An ice-turkey is a **quasi-** turkey.
column9: 5) [[isharabash](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/isharabash)] 17-10-2009(11): That **turkey's** **frozen**! It's not even **quasi-** cooked!

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 13-5-2007(318): Why did the _turkey_ cross the _road_? To **advance** to the other side, of course.
column6: 2) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 19-11-2006(101): [re: raulir] Animals on the _road_ : Turtles [escape](../v4/283.html) (#283 逃) and Pigs [pursue](../v4/539.html) (#539 逐), while the Turkeys **advance** (looking very formidable indeed).
column7: 3) [[danflynn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/danflynn)] 13-6-2009(75): The **turkey** leader led his brave troops across the plumage-covered **road** : "ADVANCE, **turkey** s! I know none of you are chicken!".
column8: 4) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 6-8-2007(23): The first game out on gameboy **advance**? A little known Japanese game called " _Turkey Road_ " – it was like Mario Kart but everyone had deformed turkey heads!
column9: 5) [[paddy71](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paddy71)] 17-1-2008(15): I asked my boss to give me an **advance** … He said "Hit the Road, Turkey"….

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 13-2-2007(297): Newscast: "Among today's **miscellaneous** stories, we have a report on a _baseball_ team that was chased up a _tree_ by a _turkey_. Stay tuned for this and more!".
column6: 2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 25-4-2006(69): On the left we have baseball and wood, which obviously means a baseball bat. Instead of balls, there are **miscellaneous** other objects you may hit with it. While beating people may be one favorite use, in this case we see it used for making turkey mash.
column7: 3) [[tcjeff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tcjeff)] 7-6-2008(57): " _Nine_ _wood_ en _turkeys_?" asked the official directing people at the antiques roadshow, "I suppose you should head over to the **miscellaneous** department to get them appraised.".
column8: 4) [[xxinde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xxinde)] 21-4-2009(51): Among the **miscellaneous** birds sitting on a tree ( _nine_ in total), the biggest one is a _turkey_.
column9: 5) [[cingold](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cingold)] 14-8-2009(36): Trying to Ebay the _Nine Wooden Turkeys_ I found in the loft I couldn't find a category, so I had to stick with **Miscellaneous**.

column3: This character for **female** forms a pair with that for _male_ , which we will learn later (Frame 804). The elements: _footprint_ . . . _spoon_ . . . _turkey_.
column5: 2) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 25-2-2007(124): To become feminine you must stop using a spoon to eat turkey and use a knife and fork like a proper lady.
column6: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-2-2008(50): Tip: _stop/footprint_ \+ _spoon_ : This combination of primitives appears seven times in Heisig, including as a separate character, which he names [this here](../v4/2043.html) (#2043 此). REF: feminine/female (FRAME 563), [purple](../v4/1375.html) (#1375 紫), [brushwood](../v4/2044.html) (#2044 柴), [fort](../v4/2045.html) (#2045 砦), [whit](../v4/2046.html) (#2046 些), [beard](../v4/2047.html) (#2047 髭).
column7: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(43): Oh I love this one, it's so silly but fun to picture. Imagine a turkey walking in the snow (in the North pole for example) wearing spoons for snowshoes. Turkeys have small feet so they can use spoons as snowshoes, right ? Now you're looking down at the footprints left by the spoon-wearing turkey who is walking off in the distance, and you think to yourself that those footprints look feminine : curvy and slender.
column8: 5) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 13-3-2008(21): Mother to daughter - 'You are not a 雌 （めす） **female** animal! Now _stop_ _sitting on the ground_ with those _turkeys_ , its not **feminine**!'———–Building from Katsuo's tip about how ( _stop spoon_ ) is used often and later becomes (FRAME 2043)= _This here_ ； used for the words ここ、これ＆この maybe we should imagine the daughter｀s name is [ここ＝此](midori://search?text=ここ＝此) .

column3: Think of this in terms of the **semi** finals of some sports competition. _Water_ . . . _turkeys_ . . . _needle_.
column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 4-7-2007(195): At the _turkey_ fighting **semi-** final, turkeys are injected with drugs via _needles_ and splashed with _water_ to help them last the match.
column6: 2) [[metacall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/metacall)] 13-1-2008(136): The anhinga, or _water_ _turkey_ , has a _needle_ -like nose, so really it's only a **semi-** turkey <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anhinga>.
column7: 3) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 26-10-2007(60): The _Turkey_ s made it to the _water_ polo **semi-** finals against the Ducks before the refs discovered the _needle_ s in their lockers.
column8: 4) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 2-10-2007(55): And the _"Water Turkeys"_ are now _UP 10_ points in this exciting **semi-** final!
column9: 5) [[zanzibar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zanzibar)] 26-5-2009(23): The TURKEY is only **semi-** done if WATER comes out when you poke it it with a NEEDLE.

column3: St. Bernard dog . . . turkey . . . rice field/brains.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-1-2007(241): The _St. Bernard dog_ pounces on a _turkey_ in a _rice field_ and **stirs up** all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?
column6: 2) [[elitentity](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elitentity)] 5-2-2006(91): Gruesome, but it makes it easy to remember. Here goes: The _St. Bernard_ **stirred up** a crowd of _turkeys_ and caught one. It bit the head, _brains_ spilling onto the _rice field_.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 23-6-2008(47): Calling my brother/sister " _big turkey brains_ " gets her real **stirred up**.
column8: 4) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 12-1-2008(28): St. Bernard/Turkey/Field = **Stirred up**. The St. Bernard **stirred up** all the animals on the farm as he chased the turkey through the field. (He also **stirred up** a lot of dust).
column9: 5) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 29-11-2008(22): BIG + TURKEY = 'Chocobo' (For those final fantasy fans). **Stirred up** and excited are chocobos when you let them run around on a rice field in hope of finding gyshal greens.

column3: Whereas _burglary_ (Frame 381) implies clandestine appropriation of another's property, **robbery** refers to taking by force. The primitive elements: _St. Bernard dog_ . . . _turkey_ . . . _glue_.
column5: 1) [[pupul07](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pupul07)] 20-11-2007(210): Don't let the neighbor's _St.Bernard_ **rob** tonight's _turkey_ …. _glue_ it to the table if you must.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 25-8-2007(145): Remember the scene in **A Christmas Story** where the _big dogs_ **robbed** the family of their Christmas _turkey_? Well, the following year Ralphie's mom glued the holiday bird to the kitchen table, just as a precaution.
column7: 3) [[phate1313](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phate1313)] 5-3-2008(52): The turkey and a St.Bernard dog are going to **rob** a bank. The turkey first, the dog behind him. When they approach the bank the turkey pulls out a tube of glue and says, "Remember Dawg, it's a **rob** bery, whatever happens we gotta stick together.
column8: 4) [[smujohnson](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smujohnson)] 17-7-2008(43): The poor _turkey_ was **rob** bed of its virginity when the smart _St. Bernard Dog_ _glued_ its feet to the ground and then pounced on top of it! Disgusting? Yes… easy to forget the story and its primitive order? You decide.
column9: 5) [[mattimus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattimus)] 15-9-2009(30): A giant turkey just **rob** bed me- with a glue gun!

column3: On the left you see the _rock_ , which is familiar enough. But pay attention to the right. Taking careful note of the unusual stroke order that has the "chimney" on the _house_ doubled up with the first stroke of the _turkey_ , we may see the right side as a _turkey house_ (or  " _coop_ "). We shall see this pattern only on one other occasion (Frame 2093), but even for these two characters it is well worth the trouble to single it out as a primitive.
column5: 1) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 30-8-2007(260): To assure that no one will get into the Turkey coop, put a huge rock in the entrance!
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 5-12-2008(129): You've heard the expression "killing two birds with one stone." ( 一石二鳥 _is-seki-ni- chou_ ). We'll, there's another one that roughly translates as "killing an entire coop with a giant boulder. " That's the method that hunters use when they want absolute **assurance** of taking home a bird.
column7: 3) [[protput](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/protput)] 20-3-2009(42): I **assure** you, the _rock_ is big enough to keep the _turkey_ inside the _house_. And if that's not enuff, I'll tie the tail of the _turkey_ to the chimney.
column8: 4) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 29-8-2008(22): I assure you, I promise a thousand times over–this rock will be strong enough to keep the killer turkeys inside their turkey house. Stop worrying, I assure you this will work!
column9: 5) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 16-5-2008(12): If you use _stone_ to build your _turkey house_ , you will have a much better **assurance** that it will last longer.

column3: With a bit of stretching, you might see a horse's head pointing leftwards in this character. That gives the primary meaning of the Chinese zodiacal sign of the horse, which corresponds to the hour of **noon**. Note how this kanji primitive differs from that for _cow_ (Frame 260).
column4: * As a primitive, this character gets the meaning of a _horse_. Any _horse_ image will do, except that of a _team of horses_ , which will come later (Frame 2132) and get its own primitive.
column5: 1) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 28-2-2008(231): **Noon** is a good time for a _ten_ minute _nap_ (using lie down as nap).
column6: 2) [[Qroxxy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Qroxxy)] 17-11-2008(67): **Noon** is a good time to _lie down_ for _ten_ minutes or so.
column7: 3) [[osaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/osaki)] 5-3-2007(60): **Noon** is the hour of the horse.
column8: 4) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 26-3-2008(28): At **noon** , the cow's head got chopped off. He had to be replaced by the horse.
column9: 5) [[Osaka_John](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Osaka_John)] 16-11-2009(19): **Noon** is a good time to _lie down_ for a _ten_ minute nap. (Especially after eating like a _horse_ for lunch.) 午後 【ごご】 (afternoon, p.m), 午前 【ごぜん】 (morning, a.m.).

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(209): If horses could speak, you might have to ask their permission before mounting them.
column6: 2) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 26-10-2007(117): Mr Ed ( a famous talking _horse_ ) was finally at a loss for _words_ when told he would need a **permit** for public speaking.
column7: 3) [[tcjeff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tcjeff)] 8-6-2008(60): Everyone knows that a driver's license has some _words_ on the left and your picture on the right. A _horse_ -riding **permit** looks just like a driver's license, except to the right of the _words_ there's a picture of the _horse_ instead of a picture of you.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 3-7-2009(44): To _speak_ to me at _noon_ you need a **permit** because I'm eating lunch.
column9: 5) [[krungthep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/krungthep)] 31-5-2008(31): You have to whisper sweet _words_ to the _horse_ before she **permit** s you to ride her.

column3: Again I cannot resist sharing my own associations. If you've ever seen Disney's animated interpretation of classical music, "Fantasia," you will recall what was done there with Beethoven's "Pastoral Symphony" (the 6th), and the _flying horses_ that figured in it. The mares are bathing in the stream and the stallions begin to gather. As dusk sets in, the _flying horses_ all start _yawning_ and pair off for the night: a perfectly **delightful** portrait of **delight**.
column5: 1) [[mattoc_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattoc_g)] 20-4-2006(234): Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her **delight** when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday… and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly… hence the yawn.
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 2-11-2007(175): I would be **delight** ed if Japanese lacked the Pegasus kanji.
column7: 3) [[rich_f](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rich_f)] 16-7-2007(67): A _lack_ of _flying horses_ is a **delight** to those on the ground who get hit with the _flying horse_ poop.
column8: 4) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 27-3-2011(31): I would be **delight** ed to see an actual _pegasus_. The world _lack_ s their kind, and is the poorer for it. 歓声 (かんせい) : cheer, shout of joy, 歓迎 (かんげい) : welcome, reception..
column9: 5) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 4-8-2007(19): Malfoy **delight** s in the lack of hippogriffs (pegasus).

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(228): I have Eric Cartman of the “South Park” animated series, wearing a cop uniform, riding a wooden Pegasus (such as on a funfair), and yelling “RESPECT MY AUTHORITAH!!!”.
column6: 2) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 10-6-2007(146): No one has the **authority** to tie up a _pegasus_ to a _tree_!
column7: 3) [[libsrone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/libsrone)] 25-4-2008(31): The park authorities are here, making sure everyone's dog is on a leash and everyone's pegasus is tied to a tree.
column8: 4) [[blair79](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blair79)] 15-3-2007(24): "Respect my **AUTHORITY** ," said Cartman as he whacked PEGASUS with his TREE.
column9: 5) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 13-2-2009(21): **Pegasus** has **authority** over the **tree** s, because she can fly.

column5: 1) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 8-9-2007(409): Microsoft **Outlook** works about as well as a pegasus that can't see: they both crash all the time.
column6: 2) [[tummai](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tummai)] 23-4-2008(100): I used to hate birds.They're loud, stupid and worst of all they shit on your head. Used to think birds were the most vile creatures on earth. Then I encountered a _pegasus_. I was just walking down the road, minding my own business when I happened to _look_ up. I _saw_ it there, braying noisily, ivory wings outstretched like an angel, back leg raised ever so slightly. It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my **outlook** completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth.
column7: 3) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 14-10-2009(64): This kanji actually means **view**. While on a pegasus you will see a great **view**.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(64): You see a Pegasus flying far above, and wonder what your **outlook** on life would be if you could see what the Pegasus sees.
column9: 5) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 8-3-2008(34): You can see an amazing **outlook** when riding a pegasus.

column3: From the pictograph of two bird-wings, we get **feathers**.
column4: * The related image of _wings_ can be added as a primitive meaning. It can also take the form  ョョ when used as a primitive, as we shall see in frames 618 and 619.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(94): Pictograph. Easy enough.
column6: 2) [[Ceryn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ceryn)] 23-4-2008(63): These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their **FEATHERS**.
column7: 3) [[konakona50](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/konakona50)] 21-9-2008(41): Two wings full of **feathers**.
column8: 4) [[FoxintheStars](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FoxintheStars)] 5-8-2010(10): Just noting how I use this as a primitive. When it's in this full form, containing the "ice" element, I try to think of it as _penguins_ or flightless wings. When it's the variant with straight lines, then it's _feathers_ or flying wings.
column9: 5) [[Easytarget](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Easytarget)] 7-1-2011(7): This is a picture of two exact **feathers** of the ice bird.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(198): Imagine a white bird loosing a _couple feathers_ as it is **learn** ing to fly. You **learn** a lesson as you watch it doing so, maybe you **learn** that “nothing comes for free” or that “one has to be prepared to loose in order to gain”…
column6: 2) [[avparker](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/avparker)] 18-12-2007(76): By the time you're old and all your _feather_ s have turned _white_ , you should have **learn** ed a thing or two.
column7: 3) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 12-1-2008(63): **Learn** ing is all about adding more _feathers_ to your cap and the most prestigious of all is the beautiful pure _white_ feather you'll receive when you have **learn** ed the kanji!
column8: 4) [[LordGolem](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LordGolem)] 21-4-2008(25): Little birds with _white feathers_ still have a lot to **learn**. When their plumage will be mature enough they'll be ready to fly away. To help not confusing it with [study](../v4/324.html) (#324 学), think birds don't need to study in order to **learn**.
column9: 5) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 28-6-2007(23): I'm **learn** ing to fly…but I ain't got wings…..I just got two feathers….on top of some white thing….

column3: _Feathers_ . . . _vase_. Be sure to contrast the connotation of this keyword with that for _next_ (Frame 510).
column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 19-5-2008(200): Your _feathers_ would also _stand up_ if you were a hen in a slaughter house and you heard: " **The following**!".
column6: 2) [[tuuli](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tuuli)] 11-12-2007(185): " **The following** segment is sponsored by…Swiffer - who make excellent _feather_ dusters for cleaning your _vases_ ".
column7: 3) [[jackhuddleston](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jackhuddleston)] 24-4-2008(96): The first thing a bird must do is learn how to _stand_. **The following** thing it must learn is how to use it's _wings_ to fly.
column8: 4) [[MikeNeko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MikeNeko)] 16-9-2008(56): Help, a flying vase is following me! Every time I turn around it is still following, flapping its two feathered wings and hovering menacingly at head height like something from a horror movie called **the following**.
column9: 5) [[tenken3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tenken3)] 27-2-2008(29): **The following** exhibit are 2 feathers sticking out of a vase.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 28-2-2008(327): Tip: _feathers_ \+ _turkey_ : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest " _futon_ " (your _futon_ is made from _turkey feathers_ ). REF: _weekday_ (FRAME 576) , [laundry](../v4/577.html) (#577 濯), [leap](../v4/1285.html) (#1285 躍), [outstanding](../v4/2272.html) (#2272 擢), [twinkle](../v4/2534.html) (#2534 燿), [shimmering](../v4/2880.html) (#2880 耀). Story: On **weekday** s you hang your _futon_ out in the _sun_.
column6: 2) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 12-1-2008(77): The poor farmer spends every **weekday** while the _sun_ shines, plucking _turkey_ _feathers_.
column7: 3) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 30-8-2007(30): On the **weekday** s, turkeys have to go to work. What do they do at work? Well, just strut their feathers. (It's an easy gig.).
column8: 4) [[kathodos](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kathodos)] 19-2-2009(19): I have a terrible job, on **weekday** s all I do all _day_ is to pluck the _feathers_ from _turkeys_. Its especially busy around christmas.
column9: 5) [[Asayoru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Asayoru)] 30-9-2010(10): Every **day of the week** , I let the _sun_ shine on on my _futon_ so it will be warm by bedtime.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 1-3-2008(245): At the **laundry** you stuff your large _futon_ (made from _turkey feathers_ ) in the machine, thereby causing it to break – as shown by the _water_ spurting out the side.
column6: 2) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 30-8-2007(130): When turkeys do the **laundry** , they put their feathers in water (they don't have clothes).
column7: 3) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 23-5-2008(64): Wednesday is **laundry** day. Or in kanji arithmetics: 水 + 曜 = 濯 + 日 .
column8: 4) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 24-6-2008(25): My _futon_ (thanks Katsuo) is in the **laundry** because I _wet_ the bed.
column9: 5) [[TunS77](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TunS77)] 14-9-2008(8): To do the **LAUNDRY** I just stick my _futon_ in the water.. It never really gets that dirty anyway.. (Thanks Katsuo :-) I like the 'futon' idea).

column3: _Pent in_ . . . _one_. The key word refers to famous sayings of famous people, and is the origin for the primitive meaning of _a tongue wagging in the mouth_ that we learned in frame 12. The size of this kanji, a relatively rare one, is what distinguishes it from _day_.
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 17-2-2008(148): "Sayeth"?! Who the hell says "sayeth"? Doesn't seem quite right…just like this kanji, which is just like "day" but doesn't seem "quite right.".
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 10-4-2008(87): When _pent up_ alone, _one_ **sayeth** little.
column7: 3) [[iheckman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/iheckman)] 2-6-2008(45): So I don't mix with [speaketh](../v4/1117.html) (#1117 申). **Sayeth** rhymes with dayeth.
column8: 4) [[niktok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/niktok)] 5-9-2007(22): So **SAYETH** we all. They are pent in on galactica, as one family.
column9: 5) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 27-3-2008(16): One pent up tongue **sayeth** little.

column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 17-10-2007(291): I'm supposed to make an enclosure for my _tree_ , but if I use its _wood_ for the enclosure, there won't be anything left to be _pent-in_. What a **quandary**!
column6: 2) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 22-7-2008(64): Trees need space to grow. If you _pent in_ a _tree_ , it will be in quite a **quandary**!
column7: 3) [[fagie37](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fagie37)] 20-1-2008(58): You are pent in the garden of eden with one tree, but outside is the whole world to explore! What a **quandary** – should you stay in paradise with the tree of knowledge or should you go out into the world?
column8: 4) [[tuuli](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tuuli)] 12-12-2007(20): To solve a **quandary** , you have to think outside the _box._ For example, how do I get this huge Christmas _tree_ into through the door?
column9: 5) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 7-5-2008(17): A **quandary** is a situation where you are _boxed in_ without knowing what you _"wood"_ do.

column3: _Old_ . . . _pent in_. Leave the people out of your story to avoid complications later when we add the element for person to form a new kanji (Frame 1047).
column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 10-5-2007(252): Fossils are _old_ things _pent in_ that have **harden** ed.
column6: 2) [[Cheesemaster64](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cheesemaster64)] 15-8-2009(113): Remember Metapod from Pokemon? All it used was **harden** , which kept it _pent in_ until it grew _old_ enough to evolve into Butterfree..
column7: 3) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 11-9-2007(63): An old **harden** ed criminal who is dying pent up in a prison cell.
column8: 4) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 5-11-2007(41): If you're _old_ and in a _box_ then you've probably **harden** ed from rigor mortis.
column9: 5) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 8-11-2006(28): If you keep it _pent in_ the breadbox, _old_ bread will surely **harden**.

column5: 1) [[Dakoina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dakoina)] 2-9-2010(42): RTK supplement: **weld** (metal, harden) - **weld** ing the metal bars of a cage together, to _harden_ the cage even more… nothing shall escape now!
column6: 2) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 25-1-2011(11): You **weld** _metal_ in the knowledge that it will _harden_ again.
column7: 3) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 5-7-2010(10): **imprison** : _Metal hardening_ describes the method of **imprisoning** people in Star Wars by freezing them in carbonite. (The carbonite as used in Star Wars is a fictional substance and may or may not be metal, but I'll imagine it is.).
column8: 4) [[FooSoft](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FooSoft)] 1-1-2010(5): The **imprisoned** criminal grew _hardened_ due to the many years he spent behind the _metal_ bars in the prison.
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 23-9-2012(3): By **weld** ing _metal_ and then subjecting it to refrigeration, it will become very _hard_ by the process known as annealing.

column5: 1) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 12-1-2008(127): In my **country** (England) the crown _jewels_ are kept _pent-in_ in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also _pent- in_ (probably for trying to steal those _jewels_ ).
column6: 2) [[genbaku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/genbaku)] 11-1-2008(95): Just think of Japan, a **country** which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 21-10-2005(30): Think of a **country** that has “ _pent in_ ” all of its _jewels_ so they wouldn't go away. Maybe it was China and its great wall.
column8: 4) [[ajikanji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ajikanji)] 17-4-2008(24): Japan was once a **COUNTRY** that went through a period of isolationism, it's JEWELS were PENT-IN and could not be traded.
column9: 5) [[skellyfish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skellyfish)] 13-2-2009(12): Picture a map of the world showing all the different **countries** PENT IN with thick borders, each one with an image of a pile of JEWELS proportional to its wealth (like those cute little geography maps from elementary school).

column5: 1) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 27-9-2007(241): When you are admitted into a **group** like the Yakuza, you're well and truly done (だん) for. You must stick to the **group** like _glue_ , and you will be _pent-in_ for life, never being able to leave.
column6: 2) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 23-9-2007(54): A _pent-in_ **group** will naturally be more cohesive, or " _glued_ together.".
column7: 3) [[rizzo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rizzo)] 21-10-2005(43): Living in Japan, this image is too true for comfort. Every **group** I've ever encoutered sticks together like _glue_ , but it seems thats not enough so they create little barriers to keep outsiders out and insiders in, once someone finds their **group** they are pretty much _pent in_ for life. (that felt good).
column8: 4) [[Henduluin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Henduluin)] 15-1-2008(25): For the Haruhism people: SOS-dan!
column9: 5) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 9-9-2007(24): Picture a bunch of **group** ies on a tour bus with some big rock band. The band members are getting tired of these **group** ies, so the band leaves the tour bus, superglues the door and the windows shut, and leave them all pent up in the bus.

column5: 1) [[rizzo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rizzo)] 21-10-2005(190): We once had a _dog_ with big paws // and oh what great trouble he'd **cause** // we built a huge pen // to keep him _pent in_ // and stop him from breaking more laws //.
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 5-7-2006(128): Why is there poop on the kitchen floor? Oh, the **cause** is that you kept the _dog_ _pent in_ the house all day. Next time remember to walk him.
column7: 3) [[narazumono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narazumono)] 16-11-2008(113): The **cause** of the big bang (the ultimate **cause** ) was a very _large_ amount of matter _pent in_ to a point in space.
column8: 4) [[Alunalun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Alunalun)] 3-7-2009(43): **Cause** is a difficult key word, hard to associate with a concrete image. So let 'cause' be associated with 'first **cause** '. Let this be the big bang (not worry about what **cause** d _that_ , since people can't decide what it is so it's no use for an image). The first **cause** , the big bang, is represented by having something _large_ (the universe) _pent in_ inside a tiny space. It's about to explode and **cause** EVERYTHING.
column9: 5) [[osaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/osaki)] 5-3-2007(16): Our **cause** is to rescue the pent in St. Bernard.

column3: _Woman_ . . . _cause_. Think here of the  "state of **matrimony** " and you will not confuse it with other characters involving marriage, one of which we have already met (Frame 581).
column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 7-6-2010(425): **Matrimony** is the state in which the _woman_ has got you _pent_ _in_ like a _dog_ so that you cannot go after other bitches.
column6: 2) [[eightyd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eightyd)] 9-6-2010(74): Forget the heisig stuff for this one. To me it looks like a fat girl looking in a mirror and her reflection is skinny, this is how every fat girl should feel on her day of **matrimony**.
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-4-2007(60): When the _woman_ gets angry, she treats her man like a _pent in dog_ (i.e., puts him in the doghouse). It's a perfect metaphor for the state of **matrimony**.
column8: 4) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 23-12-2007(50): **Matrimony** is a _cause_ of _women's_ suffering.
column9: 5) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 7-9-2009(44): 婿嫁婚姻 : Four kanji related to marriage, all with the _woman_ primitive. **Bridegroom** : for the honeymoon, he takes her to the _zoo_ for a _month_. **Marry into** : since the J-husband is never home, she feels more like she's married into the _house_ than into a relationship. **Marriage** : is when she gets a new _family name_ on one particular _day_. **Matrimony** : is the state after the marriage, where she has the husband _pent in_ like a _big_ St. Bernard.

column5: 1) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 14-12-2008(90): You can't breathe very well, so the doc looks inside your _mouth_ to find the _cause_. "Oh, I see the _cause_ of your **windpipe** blockage. There's a St Bernard penned up in there!".
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-2-2007(30): Imagine a group of **windpipes** chatting: “That _mouth_ is the _cause_ of all my problems, you know, always breathing in germs, etc.”.
column7: 3) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 14-6-2010(15): The **windpipe** in your _mouth_ is what _causes_ you to breath.
column8: 4) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 30-1-2009(10): Let's break this kanji down further into a _mouth_ and a _mouth with a dog in it_. Picture a T-Rex sitting in the waiting room of an Ear, Eye, and Throat Hospital. The TV on the wall has some educational content running: "Here's a picture of a healthy **windpipe** ," the T-Rex doctor says while pointing to an X-ray of a clear **windpipe** , which looks just like a _mouth_. "And here's an X-ray of a _windpipe with a dog stuck_ in it. Don't let this happen to you!".
column9: 5) [[fvenegas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fvenegas)] 14-1-2012(4): The sounds which come out of your mouth, are caused by your **windpipe**.

column5: 1) [[amthomas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amthomas)] 10-1-2007(147): A nice picnic _pent up_ in the **park** , with your _crock pot_ and _scarf_ (picnic blanket).
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 17-6-2006(48): You're walking in the **park** and a little ways off the path there is a “pent in” lidded crock on a scarf. Just picture it and it should work. You may also imagine the lidded crock family is having a picnic in the **park** , and 'baby lidded crock' was left alone in its pen/playpen, wearing a scarf (or sleeping on a scarf).
column7: 3) [[zodiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zodiac)] 5-11-2008(41): In the **park** , I discovered a _lidded crock wrapped with a scarf_. The police promptly _pent_ it up. (lidded crock wrapped in scarf = fake bomb, look at first story in [distant](../v4/402.html) (#402 遠)).
column8: 4) [[sethg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethg)] 3-3-2009(21): This is just like the _lidded crock_ wrapped in a _scarf_ you had to stay [distant](../v4/402.html) (#402 遠) from. This time it's even more dangerous, because it's _pent in_ the sandbox in the **park** , where children play. Who knows what could be inside! Hopefully it's something as harmless as a [monkey](../v4/403.html) (#403 猿) this time. Who would put something so potentially dangerous in a **park** , anyway?
column9: 5) [[koiulpoi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koiulpoi)] 28-6-2009(12): When wearing a nice _long kimono_ , the best thing to do is to go visit the **park** (which is obviously hedged in), and show off your stuff.

column3: The suffix " **-times** " refers to a number of repetitions. Its elements: _a mouth_  . . . _pent in_. Hint: you may find it more helpful to forget the primitives and think of one circle revovling inside of another.
column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 16-2-2008(167): Write _mouth_ two **-times**.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 21-10-2005(73): Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around).
column7: 3) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 29-4-2007(26): A _pent in mouth_ will curse many **times**.
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 20-6-2009(14): Recursive _enclosure_ of an _enclosure_ of … how many times?
column9: 5) [[lanval](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lanval)] 9-2-2009(11): I've told you x **times** not to eat so many bagles (i love this kanji).

column3: _Soil/ground_ . . . _top hat_ . . . _-times_ . . . _nightbreak_. With kanji as difficult as this one, it generally pays to toy with the various connotations of its primitives before settling on one image. Aim for as much simplicity as you can.
column5: 1) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 23-11-2005(414): A man on the **podium** announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a _top hat with dirt as many times_ as you can by _nightbreak_.
column6: 2) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 27-3-2007(111): Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of _soil_ for a **podium** , when he wore his _top hat_ and gave the speech he had practiced many _times_ until _nightbreak_. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed.
column7: 3) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 7-5-2008(52): A **podium** is a bit of raised _ground_ where _top-hatted_ "important people" go _around and around_ making speeches until _nightbreak_.
column8: 4) [[skinnyneo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skinnyneo)] 11-10-2007(16): Think of the movie _Ground_ hogs day. The mayor in his _top hat_ takes the **podium** and tries many _times_ to get the ground hog to come out before _night break._.
column9: 5) [[jinkouchinou](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jinkouchinou)] 12-6-2009(12): It's the oldest trick in the books. A filibuster! He's not going to give any _ground_ no matter how many _times_ you ask. He is just going to wear his _top hat_ and speak until _nightbreak_.

column5: 1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 15-10-2007(326): Try to remember all those **store** s from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.
column6: 2) [[kiisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kiisu)] 7-3-2008(72): The fortuneteller has a **store** in a cave.
column7: 3) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 26-11-2006(25): The _cavemen_ ask their _fortune-teller_ about what the future will look like. He goes into a trance, and in it sees a convenience **store** \- row after shiny row of completely incomprehensible products…
column8: 4) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 10-12-2008(13): The first **store** was simply a _cave_ used by a _fortune teller_.
column9: 5) [[fiddle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fiddle)] 10-7-2006(10): The **STORE** is in a CAVE run by a really annoying FORTUNE TELLER who just wants to predict your future, preventing you from actually being able to buy anything.

column5: 1) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 3-11-2005(372): I think of the Batcave. It's a big cave that Batman uses as a **warehouse** to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys.
column6: 2) [[dizzwave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dizzwave)] 17-6-2008(28): Have you ever worked in a **warehouse**? It's like a giant metal _cave_. Watch out for that _forklift_!
column7: 3) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 8-4-2009(17): With rents high and auto businesses failing, GM chose to use a _cave_ as a **warehouse** for their unsold _cars_.
column8: 4) [[damichan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/damichan)] 8-3-2009(9): I have a secret **warehouse** , set in a cliff cave, with a beautiful view of a turquoise ocean. That's where I keep my Lambhorginis, Ferraris, etc.
column9: 5) [[xxinde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xxinde)] 30-3-2010(7): This _cave_ was meant to house a _car_ , but is used as a **warehouse** for varios things… and stuff. If there were a car ( 車庫 ), it would make it a garage.

column5: 1) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 21-12-2006(220): When the courthouse caved in, trials had to be held in the **courtyard**.
column6: 2) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 7-9-2008(89): Back in caveman days, _courts_ were held in _caves_. When too many people showed up to watch, they spilled out into the **courtyard** (the yard outside the _cave_ _court_ ) . 庭 (にわ): garden, yard, compound 庭園 (ていえん): garden, park 校庭 (こうてい): schoolyard.
column7: 3) [[Clint](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Clint)] 10-5-2008(39): A **courtyard** (as the name suggests) is a yard where _court_ is held. However, due to frequent inclement weather, the _courts_ were moved to a _cave_. Old habits die hard, however, and the name " _court cave_ " never caught on, people still refer to it as a **courtyard**.
column8: 4) [[Floatingweed5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Floatingweed5)] 7-6-2007(36): [Thanks to dingomick] The poor porter samurai, being stretched on the rack by order of the court, is being tortured in an ornate ceremonial **courtyard** featuring a large echoing cave, so that his screams are amplified as a warning to potential wrongdoers.
column9: 5) [[killtheclock](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/killtheclock)] 3-2-2009(10): Als die _Höhle_ unter dem _Gerichtshof_ einbrach mußte man stattdessen im **Garten** recht sprechen.

column5: 1) [[miknon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/miknon)] 14-8-2006(143): Some bureaucrats at a **government office** decided that the tunnels of _caves_ need to get _street_ signs, which are then _nail_ ed to the walls of the _cave_.
column6: 2) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 1-11-2007(123): In some of the scarier countries, when someone is invited to visit a "government office", it's actually a dungeon where they're dragged into a cave and nailed to the wall.
column7: 3) [[gringozolano](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gringozolano)] 16-6-2008(98): Because of his **cave** man instincts, Clinton tried to **nail** Monica L. in his _gov't office_.
column8: 4) [[thegeelonghellswan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeelonghellswan)] 8-9-2008(56): The **government office** is on cave street.
column9: 5) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 26-5-2009(24): Kafka portrayed a **government office** as a cavernous space with faceless bureaucrats **nail** ed to their desks.

column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 21-6-2006(216): The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a _tree_ and in a _cave_. So these can be considered as **bed** s.
column6: 2) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 11-2-2008(102): (based on mspertus:) The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a _tree_ and in a _cave_. So to be on the safe side it is best to put a tree in a cave and use it as a **bed**.
column7: 3) [[Tornadic_Indignation](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tornadic_Indignation)] 2-5-2009(89): When you take a girl to **bed** , your _tree_ goes in her _cave_.
column8: 4) [[amontice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amontice)] 25-10-2007(19): The only good way to sleep in a **bed** in the wilderness is to chop down a _tree_ , drag it into a _cave_ and carve it up so you can have some shelter from the elements.
column9: 5) [[kathodos](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kathodos)] 23-2-2009(17): Draculas **bed** is a _wood_ en coffin in a _cave_.

column3: _Cave_ . . . _grove_. If it helps, this is the **hemp** marijuana comes from.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 15-2-2007(135): (Image: while Batman is out, Robin is smokin' a huge doob in a secret corner of the Bat _cave_ where he nurtures his **hemp** _grove_ ).
column6: 2) [[madheavy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/madheavy)] 30-1-2008(110): Where is the best place to hid your _grove_ of **hemp** trees? In a cave, you _dope_!
column7: 3) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 23-9-2007(45): The world's most prolific drug dealer maintains a massive _grove_ of **hemp** in a _cave_ to avoid law enforcement.
column8: 4) [[harusame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harusame)] 19-5-2009(35): **Hemp** is an extremely useful material and can be used to make produce healthy oils (such as omega-3 and 6), fibers for clothing, biomass for fuel and even sturdy industrial matierals. (All of this is true.) Unfortunately, because the USDEA is run by a bunch of morons that refuse to distinguish between it and marijuana, you can't get a permit to grow it and thus have to grow your **hemp** groves in a cave to avoid fines and prosecution.
column9: 5) [[osaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/osaki)] 8-5-2007(13): The **hemp** grove is in the cave.

column5: 1) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 15-4-2008(283): If you **grind** the _hemp_ you are bound to get _stoned_ quicker.
column6: 2) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-8-2007(46): You must **GRIND** the HEMP collected in the grove by your cave on solid STONE to make the best ropes.
column7: 3) [[CSBarnes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CSBarnes)] 20-12-2008(30): " **Grind** , **grind** , **grind** the _hemp_ , slowly with the _stone_ ".
column8: 4) [[BStoobs](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BStoobs)] 24-11-2007(22): Ma (マ) used to **grind** hemp with a stone and then brush her teeth with it to relieve the pain when she got toothache.
column9: 5) [[mcmike2099](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcmike2099)] 10-5-2009(15): **Grind** your HEMP on a STONE to prepare the marijuana that will get you stoned.

column3: This character, a pictographic representation of the **heart** , is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet.
column4: * As a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings. In its kanji-form, it appears BENEATH or to the RIGHT of its relative primitive and means th physical organ of the _heart_.   To the LEFT, it is abbreviated to three strokes, ⺖, and means a wildly emotional _state of mind_. And finally, at the very BOTTOM, it can take the form ⺗, in which case we give it the meaning of a _valentine_.
column5: 1) [[munia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munia)] 25-12-2008(60): (mature content: violence) I hung the **heart** of my victim with a _hook_ and three _drops_ of blood spattered me.
column6: 2) [[oRis1024](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oRis1024)] 15-8-2008(30): **Heart** needs three drops of blood to work.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(15): Pictograph, see book.
column8: 4) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 24-7-2007(12): こころ！.
column9: 5) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 7-6-2006(9): When this primitive is on the left as _state of mind_ , I had a hard time visualizing it. Thus I have created the following story. All the smartest people in the country were fed up with their state governments. These great _minds_ joined together and created their own official _state_ : the _state of Mind_. I visualize it as a small, sectioned off area with brains floating around. A scientific utopia.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-3-2007(331): You only truly **forget** her when she has _perish_ ed in your _heart_.
column6: 2) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 1-11-2007(47): To **forget** means that something perishes from your heart.
column7: 3) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 15-10-2007(31): _Perish_ my _heart_ if I **forget** this kanji.
column8: 4) [[penot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/penot)] 12-9-2008(23): A _dead heart_ is the only way to **forget** your love.
column9: 5) [[zer0range](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zer0range)] 28-3-2009(18): We keep the deceased in our hearts so as not to **forget**.

column5: 1) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 15-10-2010(64): **Selfish** lover breaks your _heart_ and moves on to the _next_ lover. (And _yawns_ with a _heart_ of _ice_ at your suffering).
column6: 2) [[terozen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/terozen)] 8-4-2012(13): A **selfish** person doesn't care about the _next_ person's _heart_ , only their own.
column7: 3) [[Hinode](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hinode)] 3-10-2011(4): I'm born with two hearts? How lucky! Well I could donate one and save the life of someone else, but I'm one **selfish** bastard…. If my first one fails, I'll just move on to my _next heart_!
column8: 4) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 2-6-2010(4): His son is a spoiled, **SELF-INDULGENT** prima-donna, going from one venture to the _NEXT_ (at daddy's expense, of course), whatever takes over his _HEART_ at the moment. (Cf. [wish](../v4/1590.html) (#1590 念)).
column9: 5) [[FooSoft](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FooSoft)] 1-1-2010(3): When I have trouble concentrating, it's like my _heart_ runs off to some _next_ **arbitrary** activity, rather than staying focused on what I'm working on!

column3: Blade . . . heart. **Endure** here means long-suffering patience.
column5: 1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 22-10-2006(280): A ninja must be able to **endure** the pain of clinging to a ceiling, motionless, for hours at a time, waiting for just the right moment to drop down and thrust the _blade_ of his sword into the _hearts_ of his enemies. By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 ( _ninja_ ) which is why I choose to use _ninja_ as its primitive meaning.
column6: 2) [[Kurisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kurisu)] 17-3-2008(60): 忍び （しのび）Shinobi the 忍者 （にんじゃ）Ninja was able to **endure** the massacre of his family  & horrors of his training by placing the way of the _blade_ above the way of the _heart_.
column7: 3) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 7-4-2009(54): To **endure** unrequited love is like living with a _blade_ in your _heart_.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(39): Someone with a _razor blade_ stuck in their _heart_ has to **endure** the pain wherever they go and can tell no one about it.
column9: 5) [[WeTsTICK](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/WeTsTICK)] 15-6-2009(17): I doubt you can **endure** a blade in your heart for very long.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(183): You are given a _speech_ about some serious mistakes of yours, and you have to _endure_ the whole thing, because all you can do is **acknowledge**.
column6: 2) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 11-6-2006(142): I never read the "acknowledgements" section of books or theses, because they are mostly just boring _words_ that i must _endure_ reading, before i can get to the interesting part. :).
column7: 3) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 16-11-2005(82): You would think that most _ninjas_ (see previous frame) would **acknowledge** each other's presence with something like a silent nod. Imagine the consequences if, while raiding an enemy castle, one stupid _ninja_ chose to **acknowledge** another by _saying_ , "HELLO!!".
column8: 4) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 9-12-2008(33): In Japan, people who make efforts to _endure_ (gaman) can expect to receive _words_ of **acknowledge** ment at some point. The ability to _endure_ is so valued and respected in Japan that **acknowlegement** of some sort is virtually inevitable.
column9: 5) [[Medeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Medeo)] 19-6-2009(25): Some Oscar winners go on far too long with their acceptance speech. But we are expected to politely ENDURE their endless stream of WORDS as they **acknowledge** their colleagues and loved ones.

column5: 1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-8-2007(269): Remember the tale of Cleopatra? She was **MOURNING** the loss of her Marc Antony, so she placed the asp SNAKE to her HEART.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(148): You are **mourning** the death of a relative, and it feels as if a snake had bitten into your heart. – "mourning feels like _snake_ -bitten _heart_ ".
column7: 3) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 9-12-2008(49): **Mourning** is really self-pity. When someone mourns, it seems on the surface that they are feeling sadness for a lost loved one. In reality, they are feeling heavy-hearted because they themselves have permanently lost something very precious.
column8: 4) [[Yozora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yozora)] 24-5-2009(38): **Mourning** can feel like a constrictor SNAKE is squeezing your HEART to death.
column9: 5) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 13-1-2008(20): When _Snake_ finally killed Sniper Wolf, his _heart_ was filled with **mourning**.

column5: 1) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 25-7-2007(293): A _samurai'_ s **intentions** always come from the _heart_.
column6: 2) [[amthomas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amthomas)] 17-1-2007(107): _Gentleman_ always have _hearts_ full of good **intention** s.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 1-9-2007(42): _Tom Cruise_ no doubt had good **intention** s when he made the Last _Samurai_ \- his heart in the right place (right there, down to earth). Too bad the concept of a white dude as the last samurai is ridiculous, if not offensive. Picture Tom Cruise in a press conference being asked about this, at which point he jumps on a heart-shaped, grabs somebody's hands, and screams BUT MY **INTENTION** S WERE FROM THE HEART! SCIENTOLOGY HELPS PEOPLE.
column8: 4) [[wazato](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wazato)] 3-10-2007(29): A samurai shows up at the door to pick up his date. Her father asks, "What are your **intention** s with my daughter?" He responds that his **intention** s come from the heart.
column9: 5) [[nekoyaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nekoyaki)] 9-4-2009(19): Father: "What are your **intention** s to my daughter?". _Samurai_ : "I intend to give her my _heart_! (slices out his own heart and hands it over).

column5: 1) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 15-2-2008(190): This is quite simple: a **document** is a set of _words_ describing your _intentions_.
column6: 2) [[Johan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johan)] 24-4-2006(144): A will is an important **document** that contains your final _word_ on how you _intend_ to distribute your assets.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 30-10-2007(94): A policeman stops you (in Japan) saying, " **Document** s, please". You: "Er, I _intended_ to bring them, but . . .". Policeman: " _Words_ of _intention_ are not good enough, I need to see your **document** s!".
column8: 4) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 17-10-2006(19): When you **document** your source code, you use English _words_ to describe the _intention_ of the highly technical program code.
column9: 5) [[amthomas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amthomas)] 27-1-2007(15): _Words_ can **document** your _intentions_.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(68): Giving a girl _flowers_ is like lighting the **wick** to her _heart_.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 27-5-2007(64): My favorite are heart shaped candles that smell like sweet flowers. The trick is to find one with a thick **wick** , they give off the most flower scent (but burn the quickest).
column7: 3) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 16-12-2008(13): My girlfriend jabbed a long-stemmed _flower_ into my _heart_ , then lit it like a **wick**. She had a funny way of saying "I love you".
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 11-10-2010(5): 替芯 , 鉛筆の芯 , 芯を切る , 芯が腐っている [wick](../v4/2368.html) (#2368 芯) シン … Parts:艹, 心 … Story:If you want to "Dip You **Wick** ", then give Roses and pretend to open your _Heart_ … 熟語 : … cf:.
column9: 5) [[Proxx](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Proxx)] 25-7-2010(4): Imagine a beautiful flower with a strange **wick** sticking out at the top. You ignite it - the flower turns into a heart!

column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 1-6-2007(155): Their true _loyalty_ exists **in the middle** of their **hearts**.
column6: 2) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 26-10-2007(123): Your **loyalty** is to what's _in_ your _heart_.
column7: 3) [[zardoz73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zardoz73)] 25-8-2008(64): Hachiko, the most **loyal** dog of all, has a statue in his honor in the **middle** of the **heart** of Shibuya.
column8: 4) [[frozach](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/frozach)] 1-8-2007(32): After the British soldiers executed the French archers, they dissected their bodies, only to find French flags INSIDE them, wrapping around their HEARTS. Now that shows true **LOYALTY**.
column9: 5) [[adhmm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adhmm)] 22-4-2008(26): The evil genius guaranteed himself the **loyalty** of his minions by placing explosives _in_ the _middle_ of their hearts.

column3: This pictograph of two pieces of meat on a skewer, a **shish kebab** , will help us in the next frame.
column5: 1) [[Texie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Texie)] 30-7-2008(119): This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.
column6: 2) [[poopdeedoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/poopdeedoo)] 20-3-2008(101): Naka naka , "who's there?" **shish kebab** …. "shish kebab who?".
column7: 3) [[shadolite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shadolite)] 27-3-2008(30): The actual definition of this kanji is " **a skewer** ," which I believe is much more helpful as a primitive. Just think, two _mouths_ **skewer** ed on same _stick_.
column8: 4) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 30-5-2007(15): The **skewer** that runs through the two junks of **shish kebab**.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(9): Pictograph, see book.

column5: 1) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 5-12-2007(247): A person who is **afflicted** with the vampire disease can only be killed with a _sheesh-kebab_ through the _heart_.
column6: 2) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 14-1-2008(104): If you eat too many _shish kebabs_ , your _heart_ will be **afflicted** with cholesterol.
column7: 3) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 16-11-2005(55): If you are **afflicted** with severe _heart_ burn, eating a spicy _shish kebab_ will feel only slightly less painful than having it jammed straight into your _heart_.
column8: 4) [[nagisa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nagisa)] 18-9-2007(24): A person who has been truly **afflicted** with the pain of love feels as if a giant _shish kebab_ has been shoved through their _heart_.
column9: 5) [[CSBarnes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CSBarnes)] 20-12-2008(21): A _skewered heart_ is **afflicted** with pain.

column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 8-7-2006(237): **Think** with your _brain_ NOT your _heart_.
column6: 2) [[PacifistGod](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PacifistGod)] 8-4-2007(153): To **think** is to use your brain over your heart.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(53): **Think** ing too much with our brains, and not enough with our hearts, leads to many of our life's pains and sorrows. This kanji reminds us that **think** ing, while an activity of the brain, should always have the support of the heart.
column8: 4) [[dizzwave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dizzwave)] 10-7-2008(18): **Think** ing requires the _brain_ and the _heart_.
column9: 5) [[Norman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Norman)] 30-1-2013(12): **Think** with both your brain and your heart.

column3: Take **grace** in its sense of a favor freely bestowed, not in its meaning of charming manners or fluid movement. The primitives: _cause_ . . . _heart_.
column5: 1) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 14-12-2007(221): **Grace** here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a _big dog pent up in a small cage_ and adopt him. That will _cause_ a warm feeling in your _heart_!
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(111): This kanji tells us that wherever heart is the cause, **grace** is the consequence. Think of “grace” as a **grace** ful act: something benevolent that comes from the heart.
column7: 3) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 10-12-2008(74): **Grace** is when you give from your _heart_ to serve a higher _cause_.
column8: 4) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 27-5-2008(38): A **grace** is a gift whose only _cause_ for being given comes from the _heart_. WARNING: Do not confuse with [graceful](../v4/721.html) (#721 淑) - this kanji and it's meaning have nothing to do with being **grace** ful.
column9: 5) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 5-1-2007(30): **Grace** Kelly died be _cause_ of her _heart_ condition. I.e., her _heart_ was the _cause_. It was because of all that dancing… that's how the story goes. But really, what happened is that she accidentally locked in her St. Bernard for 5 days without food, and when she came back home he ripped out and swallowed her heart.

column3: _Cave_ . . . _heart_. The sense of the key word here is of something appropriate that fills a particular need, and hence  " **applies**. "
column5: 1) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 12-12-2006(182): [bravo, scottamus!] To **apply** for the job as a (replacement) Batman, you have to make it to the _heart of the cave_ past all the traps he set up to test you. There, you see a table with the application form on it. Now that you think about it, the ad in the paper did say "Those who don't make it to the _heart of the cave_ need not **apply**.".
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 17-10-2006(152): In the videogame Zelda, Link enters a CAVE to visit a fairy that will **APPLY** magic to fill his HEART containers.
column7: 3) [[yukkuri_kame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yukkuri_kame)] 12-2-2009(95): Heisig's keyword doesn't **apply** this kanji directly. 応用する （おうようする）means "to **apply** " as in [彼らは新しい科学技術をその産業に応用した。](midori://search?text=彼らは新しい科学技術をその産業に応用した。) "They applied new technology to the industry." The most common translation of 応 (on it's own without 用 ) might be "respond". As in responding to a question or responding to a situation. Story: Men are _CAVE_ men at _HEART_. When confronted by emergency situations they RESPOND by **APPLY** ING their primitive power.
column8: 4) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 20-12-2007(35): Said the doctor: Usual rules **apply**. If you **apply** too much force the _heart_ will _cave_ in.
column9: 5) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 9-11-2005(35): Batman applied himself to catwoman deep in the _heart_ of bat _cave_.

column5: 1) [[onsen_monkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/onsen_monkey)] 4-10-2006(325): When you get a good **IDEA** you get excited and you can hear the SOUND of your HEART, it's pounding so hard.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(58): Picture someone who's just had a great **idea** , but in place of a blinking light bulb over their head, you see a _heart_ thumping with great _noise_. Imagine the greater the **idea** , the louder the _sound_ of the beating _heart_.
column7: 3) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 26-8-2007(38): The best **idea** s are _sound_ **idea** s that come right from the _heart_!
column8: 4) [[Atomik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Atomik)] 14-2-2010(32): The Frenchman René-Théophile-Hyacinthe Laennec is best known for a great **idea** he had in 1816, when he invented a device to listen to the _sound_ of a patient's _heart_ : the stethoscope. Until then, doctors simply put their ears against people's chests, which was ineffective for overweight patients and embarrassing for female patients. Laennec's **idea** was so great that doctors still rely on it today.
column9: 5) [[aelirri](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aelirri)] 14-5-2009(15): A good **idea** will always _sound_ right in your heart.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 7-5-2007(84): **Cowardice** is the situation where you get the thought that maybe running away and saving your _flesh_ is a good _idea_.
column6: 2) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 28-12-2008(64): **Cowardice** is when you are not willing to sacrifice your _flesh_ for your _ideas_.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 2-8-2008(6): A real brave person would never put their _flesh_ before their _ideas_. That's why so many people have been killed - for example, in China, where people showed **cowardice** in the face of capitalism. They weren't willing to put their _flesh_ behind their _ideas_. Note that _flesh_ is the "strong" or "main" radical in this kanji, which lets you know that this person is emphasizing _flesh_ , and thus, exhibiting _cowardice_.
column8: 4) [[manubear](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/manubear)] 10-8-2012(4): "Er, I've got a good _idea_ , let's hide on the _moon_ " says the **cowardly** Shaggy in Scooby Doo ( 臆病な ).
column9: 5) [[Aeryon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aeryon)] 24-1-2012(3): Man 1: "Hey, enough with the dumb ideas!" Man 2:"Dumb ideas?! I am just trying to save our flesh!" Man 1: "You coward!".

column3: To distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame, focus on the sense of the "con-" in the word " **concept**. " Its elements are: _inter-_ . . . _heart_.
column5: 1) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 29-11-2007(364): The **concept** of love is basically two _hearts_ _inter_ -acting as one.
column6: 2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 16-4-2008(61): _''Inter-heart''_ is a new therapy _CONCEPT_ that helps macho guys share their feelings with each other.
column7: 3) [[Wizard](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wizard)] 13-8-2008(49): Newton realised the **concept** when he was sitting under a _tree_ , and an apple smacked him in the head. He stood up, _eyes_ wide, _heart_ racing, for he had discovered gravity!
column8: 4) [[Clint](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Clint)] 23-7-2008(39): When you find a **concept** that really moves you, such as the **concepts** of mercy, forgiveness and compassion, the reason they do so is the fact that the mental component of these **concepts** _inter-_ act with your _heart_ (to avoid mixing up the keywords for idea and **concept** , remember: _sound_ idea, _inter-_ esting **concept** ).
column9: 5) [[zodiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zodiac)] 6-11-2008(29): When you finally manage to explain a difficult **concept** to someone, it feels as if your _hearts_ are _inter-_ connected.

column5: 1) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 14-1-2008(316): Your **breath** brings oxygen in through your _nose_ which is then pumped around your body by your _heart_.
column6: 2) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 31-3-2008(102): I think I've met my dream girl, but there's a problem. her **breath** is horrible! So, do I listen to my _nose_ or my _heart_?
column7: 3) [[wynterp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wynterp)] 3-9-2007(48): From Genesis 2:7 (NKJV): Creating man. God "breathed into his _nostrils_ the **breath** of life and the man became a living being." (can't you see his _heart_ start pumping?).
column8: 4) [[Izumo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Izumo)] 4-3-2010(16): **BREATH** brings oxygen from your _nose_ to your _heart_.
column9: 5) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 26-11-2007(15): Someone has almost drowned. We plug their NOSE as we **breath** into them, then listen to see if the HEART starts beating.

column3: _Tongue_ . . . _nose_ . . . _heart_. The sense of _breath_ from the last frame should not be used, it could lead you to put only the _nose_ over the _heart_ and leave the _tongue_ off to one side.
column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 1-3-2007(274): **Recess** to me is a school break. At **recess** some kiddies are comparing their latest body piercings. _Tongues_ and _noses_ are nothing special. The new cool is to have your _heart_ done!
column6: 2) [[strugglebunny](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/strugglebunny)] 17-11-2008(104): At **recess** , little boys stick their _tongues_ out and pick their _noses_ while little girls draw _hearts_ on the ground with chalk. It's winter now, so any _tongues_ –left– out for too long will freeze.
column7: 3) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 13-4-2008(96): Ah **recess** , _tongues_ slandering, _noses_ being turned up, and beneath it all, young _hearts_ being broken. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of _tongues_ , which helps me remember that in this kanji _tongue_ comes first.
column8: 4) [[Johan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johan)] 13-4-2006(52): The **recess** is a remote place for meditation. You sit meditating with other monks, breathing though your nose, holding your tongue (keeping quiet), and finding peace in your heart.
column9: 5) [[j0k0m0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/j0k0m0)] 2-6-2011(17): At **recess** …tongues flapping , noses running, hearts racing. wheeee! 休憩 きゅうけい Imagine the skinny teacher from The Simpsons saying "we're gonna have **recess** now children, nnnkay". けい.

column5: 1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 13-8-2007(763): Too easy. Imagine the Wizard of OZ. There, the three heroes asked the Wizard for three **FAVOR** S: the lion wanted courage of TEN men, the scarecrow wanted a BRAIN, and the tin man wanted a HEART. Ok, the lion bit is stretching but you have it memorized now, so who cares?
column6: 2) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 15-3-2007(38): If you would give someone 10 fields as a **favor** then you truly have a big heart. Or, people who do lots of **favor** s for others have a heart as big as 10 fields, a "10-field-heart".
column7: 3) [[joxn_costello](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joxn_costello)] 7-12-2008(33): "Igor, do me a **favor** : go down to the morgue and pick me up _ten_ _brains_ – oh, and a _heart_ , if they have any fresh!".
column8: 4) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 6-7-2008(19): -Do me a **FAVOR** , give me TEN FIELDS (I am talking to someone who owns a lot of fields), and I will thank you from my HEART !
column9: 5) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 13-2-2008(12): "Ten fields and my heart for my lady's **favor**!" cried Lord Fancypants.

column5: 1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 27-4-2006(343): If your heart surgeon is mediocre in his craft, you have plenty of reason to **fear**. ("Oops, I think I left my scissors in there").
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 9-4-2007(125): My deep dark **fear** at the bottom of my _heart_ is that I am _mediocre_ at my _craft_.
column7: 3) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 10-7-2006(41): Some have called the US the culture of **fear**. **Fear** is a craft that mediocre leaders use to control the hearts of the populace.
column8: 4) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 10-4-2009(29): I have an unusual **fear** \- when I'm sleeping, the _mediocre I-beam_ above my bed will fall and crush my _heart_. The builder was certainly mediocre, the I-beam is not even quite straight! Could fall any time…
column9: 5) [[delenir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/delenir)] 7-12-2009(16): **Fear** will _craft_ a _mediocre_ _heart_.

column3: The first three elements, _fiesta_ . . . _mouth_ . . . _floor_ , appeared together once already in frame 380. Beneath them, once again, the _heart_.
column5: 1) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 25-9-2007(372): She was **beguiled** / **mislead** by his charm: at the party he kissed her on the _mouth_ , they did it on the _floor_ and thus he stole her _heart_. Poor girl!
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 16-1-2006(92): The same cowboy from frame # 356 (elements mouth, floor and fiesta), kisses the floor with his mouth, once again, before going to the fiesta. There, he uses his good looks to **beguile** women (gets them to buy him drinks or such), by playing with their hearts.
column7: 3) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 30-4-2009(37): I like to think of this character as Guile from Street Fighter 2, **beguiling** Chun Li at the _fiesta_. He kisses her on the _mouth_ , they do it on the _floor_. Then, remembering his job, he rips out her _heart_ , Mortal Kombat style. "which character are you gonna be?" "I'm gonna **be Guile** " (Partly inspired by nilfisq's).
column8: 4) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 23-7-2008(31): This kanji actually means **BEWILDERED**. At the fiesta, he was kissing the floor with all his heart. Everyone was **bewildered**.
column9: 5) [[NickCooper](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NickCooper)] 5-9-2008(12): At the fiesta I decided to **beguile** the crowd by performing a trick where I pull out my heart and throw it on the ground. It worked, their mouths hit the floor!

column5: 1) [[szreter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/szreter)] 15-2-2008(283): **Emotion** is a _march of mouths_ inside your _heart_ telling you what to feel.
column6: 2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 17-7-2008(130): Strong **EMOTION** S don't stay hidden. They march right out of one's _heart_ (below) and out _one_ 's _mouth_ (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of **emotion** it is!).
column7: 3) [[harusame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harusame)] 19-5-2009(24): When you get **emotion** al, words come marching out of your mouth from your heart, and it's impossible to stop them.
column8: 4) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 10-9-2007(17): Picture a site that consists solely of emoticons (represented by the mouth) marching across the screen - you know, hundreds of them. Imagine how much this website would slow down your computer. At this point you might consider stabbing the site's creator in the heart. (inspired by taijuando).
column9: 5) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 24-3-2008(9): Emoticons held a _march_ to protest against their low status in communication. Along went all those _little mouths_ , shouting as _one_ , riding not on horses but big squidgy _hearts_ , bouncing one pace with each beat. Sadly, many were 'tired and **EMOTION** al' ( _euphemism for 'drunk' in the British Press_ ) and they all started squabbling, at which point the march fell apart.

column3: _Head_ . . . _crown_ . . . _heart_ . . . _walking legs_. Two things merit mention here. First, the doubling-up of the last stroke of _head_ with the top of the _crown_ serves to make the whole more aesthetically beautiful. It happens so rarely that the exceptions are easily learned. Second, try to make a single image out of the four elements. (Religious statuary of **melancholy** figures should offer plenty of suggestions.)
column5: 1) [[rizzo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rizzo)] 7-2-2006(244): **Melancholy** makes me think of Hamlet cause he was so 'emo'. In order to play up his feelings he bares his _head_ and holds his _crown_ over his _heart_ then walks (on _walking legs_ ) around the palace making everyone see how **melancholy** he is. What a wuss.
column6: 2) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 24-3-2008(155): This is an image of the crucifixion. Jesus is on the cross. His _crown_ of thorns has slipped down and is around his neck, right between his _head_ and his _heart_. His _walking legs_ can be seen dangling from the cross as well. How **MELANCHOLY**!
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 12-11-2007(114): In the middle of _summer_ you lose both your _crown_ and your _heart_. No wonder you feel **melancholy**.
column8: 4) [[FutureBlues](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FutureBlues)] 16-7-2008(43): In the **Melancholy** of Suzumiya Haruhi, reality was all in her _head_ , leading to situations where her melancholic feelings in her _heart_ would be released into bubble-like _crowns_ of negative space where they'd _walk around on their legs_ and wreck havoc.
column9: 5) [[skinnyneo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skinnyneo)] 24-9-2007(26): The most **melancholy** places of all is a funeral. This is a funeral for the Burger King guy, where everybody takes the paper _crowns_ that they were given off of their _head_ and covers their _heart_ with it. _Each_ person then uses their _walking legs_ to come up to the casket and throw in a whopper.

column3: _House_ . . . _head_ . . . _dagger_. Immediately we get another instance of a very odd exception. Notice how the final stroke of the head is lengthened, giving the final two strokes a chance to stretch out and make room for the _dagger_ that fits in beneath.
column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 26-5-2007(295): The new **widow** sits in the _house_ , her _head_ in her lap (the extended stroke), her _dagger_ in her husband.
column6: 2) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 28-7-2007(49): The _house_ 's _head_ , her husband, was murdered with a _dagger_. You can still see the drops of blood above the dagger. She is now a **widow**.
column7: 3) [[wazato](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wazato)] 3-10-2007(44): Extending Megaqwerty's story, the **widow** sits in the house with her head leaned forward in her lap so that her long pig-tails are stretched out to the floor. In between her pig-tails lies the dagger used to kill her husband.
column8: 4) [[mikemorr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mikemorr)] 22-8-2009(36): The **widow** is _head of the house_ now that she's been _part_ ed from her husband. [part](../v4/781.html) (#781 分).
column9: 5) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 15-4-2008(15): After I found my husband in the _house_ with his _head_ chopped off by a _dagger_ , I realised I'd become a **widow**.

column5: 1) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 29-6-2006(224): **Busy** (as in "occupied") means a _state of mind_ where all other thoughts are _perished_.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 28-5-2010(104): ^^^Make the "state of mind" primitive _Data (from Star Trek)_ instead right now and save yourself the headache, 'state of mind' is too vague! ( _Data_ can stay so **busy** as not to sleep without _dying_. He's a robot).
