column8: 4) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 22-6-2008(17): The most common _trees_ found in _public parks_ ( 公園 ) are **pine trees**.
column9: 5) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-4-2006(15): You can't show **pine tree** s in public, because their lower parts are bare.

The higher in rank you get in this tribe, the more _feathers_ decorate you. Imagine this old man covered in beautiful feathers.

But, alas, there is no toilet paper! So, he's caught a pigeon and is using it to wipe his bottom. (note the feathers on the bottom of the kanji, this helps remember placement). Can you see the _feathers_ flying everywhere?
column7: 3) [[martinnz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/martinnz)] 5-8-2009(37): The **venerable old man** is in the _public_ park feeding the _pigeons_.

column3: _Go in_ . . . _an umbrella_ . . . _a mouth_. Because of space restrictions, the element for _go in_ is shortened in this character. If you stand on your head and look at this kanji, the image of a **valley** stands out more clearly: the _mouth_ of the river whose water flows down at the intersection of the two mountains, with the final two strokes adding the element of perspective. Now get back on your feet again and see if the image still remains clear. If not, then return to the primitives and make a story in the usual way.
column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 21-2-2007(207): This could be seen as a very accurate pictograph of another type of **valley** : a **valley** _mouth_ open under the _umbrella_ of inner labia, with the outer labia _parted_ above. There are even more connections to be made among the primitive keywords and the visuals, but i will _enter_ no further…
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 3-7-2006(81): Think of the classic anime 風の **谷** のナウシカ (Nausicaa of the _Valley_ of the Wind). We see Nausicaa _entering_ the _valley_ _mouth_ gliding on an _umbrella_.
column7: 3) [[Clint](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Clint)] 18-9-2008(68): Yea, though I _enter_ the **valley** of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for I have brought my _umbrella_ and if anything scares me, I will open my _mouth_ and scream for help!
column8: 4) [[alatown](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alatown)] 11-2-2010(35): Pictograph - a little house with mountains behind.
column9: 5) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 13-12-2007(26): _Enter_ the **valley** with an _umbrella_ and your _mouth_ closed the mist is quite throat irritating.

column5: 1) [[nakome](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nakome)] 7-3-2008(258): This story is quite lascivious, sorry… Now, imagine you are at a 混浴 （こんよく） [two kanjis we now know] Onsen ( 温泉 ), and you are watching a woman **bathe**. Just picture the _water_ dripping down her cleavage (that _valley_ in between her breasts). Note: cleavage in Japanese is 谷間 .
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 13-5-2007(117): The mountain man uses the _water_ from the _valley_ to **bathe**.
column7: 3) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 7-1-2008(64): Cleavage in Japanese is called the _valley_ of the chest, and **bathing** sends _water drops_ into that valley. Memorable image, I think you'll agree.
column8: 4) [[axelb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/axelb)] 24-5-2008(20): In a _valley_ full of _water_ you may **bathe**.

column3: This character depicts a _house_ so large that it can **contain** an entire _valley_.
column5: 1) [[eieneverafter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eieneverafter)] 25-3-2008(215): Imagine a house big enough to **contain** an entire valley. might want to live there. And now imagine cleaning it. . . . Maybe not . . .

column7: 3) [[frychiko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/frychiko)] 25-6-2008(52): To **CONTAIN** the virus, everyone in the VALLEY had to stay in their HOUSES.

Being a genteel creature (and a vegetarian – phew), he invites you for dinner at his _house_. Not only is it large enough for him, but it **contains** a whole _valley_ inside. It's quite pretty. Imagine walking in and seeing a beautiful _valley_ **contained** within the _house_.
column9: 5) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 16-6-2009(18): The sorority _house_ **contain** s _valley_ girls.

column7: 3) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 15-4-2008(45): An inconvenient truth: when the polar ice caps **melt** , there's going to be no way to _contain_ the rising _water_ level…
column8: 4) [[Lucien](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lucien)] 12-9-2008(42): Imagine "WARNING: MAY CONTAIN WATER. DO NOT **MELT**." engraved in a bunch of ice cubes you just bought.
column9: 5) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 6-8-2008(13): WATER CONTAINED in ice, **MELTS**.

column3: _Valley_ . . . _yawn_. Be sure to keep the key word distinct from _pining_ (Frame 683).
column5: 1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 22-6-2008(283): Guess what? Japanese has dirty words too! (In fact, a lot of them) A sexual story is NOT inappropriate here, as this kanji is very sexual, such as in 性欲 , lust. As for a story: the _lack_ of contact with a woman's _valley_ will leave a man **LONGING** for love.
column6: 2) [[mattoc_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattoc_g)] 20-7-2006(139): The valley has something my life is lacking…. something I've been **longing** for.. peace and quiet.
column7: 3) [[konayuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/konayuki)] 23-9-2008(33): Imagine a young girl who has lived in this _valley_ her whole life. She's looking out _yawning_. When confronted about it, she simply replies "This is such a _valley of lack_! There's nothing to do here but _yawn_! I'm **longing** to get out of here. I'm **longing** for something more than just this _valley of lack_ , this _valley of yawns_ ".
column8: 4) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 24-7-2006(14): Nausicaa is **longing** to get back to the _valley_ because she is homesick. She _lacks_ her home.
column9: 5) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 26-4-2008(13): When I lived in the valley I spent all my time yawning - now I find myself **longing** to return.

column3: This character shows the typical _cloak_ of _valley_ folk, which, unlike the tailor-made, high-fashion overcoats of city folk, is loose-fitting and free- form. Hence the key word's meaning of **abundant**.
column5: 1) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 7-1-2008(325): Again using the fact that cleavage in Japanese is called " _valley_ of the chest": a woman with **abundant** cleavage tightly wraps up her bosom in a form-fitting _cloak_ , but leaving her _valley_ exposed. Another unforgettable image (thank you, thank you, I'll be here all week).
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(115): Welcome to cloak-valley, the valley where everyone wears cloaks and every shop sells cloaks. Mnemonic : “cloaks are **abundant** in the valley”.
column7: 3) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 16-3-2007(63): Elven _cloaks_ are **abundant** in the _valley_ of Rivendell.
column8: 4) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 27-7-2008(39): She used a _cloak_ to hide her **abundant** _valley_ from prying eyes.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 10-5-2008(13): [+rtkrtk] It's said that cleavage actually looks like the cleavage of the rear end - in other words, it looks like a bun dent, or **abundant**. Imagine a magazine called **abundant** a-bun-dents, and the winter issue features pretty woman wearing nothing but a heavy trench coat, exposing her **abundant** a-bun-dents, featuring _Hidden Valley Ranch_ seductively poured all over them. Gross, sure, but hey. Whatever works, right? I was having hella trouble with this one.

That is exactly the literal meaning of the two parts of this Kanji. To get the keyword out of this Kanji just think of all the GOLDEN GULLY's the boys in Led Zeppelin used to fill in thier hayday. Of all the rock bands in history, LE(A)D zeppelin is famous for how much sex they used to have - read "Hammer of the God's", if you don't believe me.
column9: 5) [[Onikagii](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Onikagii)] 13-7-2009(33): This is an odd story. IF you have ever broken a pencil right in two the long way you can see the pencil **lead** lying in the little gully formed by the wood. Helps me remember that **lead** is used in the word 鉛筆 えんぴつ for pencil.

column3: _Water_ . . . _gully_. The key word is meant to refer to things like rivers and railway tracks that **run alongside** something else.

In fact, if you see a gaijin **running alongside** the _water gullies_ that **run alongside** the road, you may want to see if they need a hand.

column7: 3) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-4-2006(33): This also means a palm. So you're in the outhouse, **manipulating** something with your hand(palm).
column8: 4) [[Biene](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Biene)] 8-1-2008(19): In islamic countries try to avoid to **manipulate** food with your left _hand_ after you went to the _outhouse_. (Since that hand is used to clean oneself with water after going to the toilet, instead of using toilettpaper. It's concidered unclean no matter how much you washed it afterwards. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_toilet_etiquette>).
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(13): Think of students who **manipulate** a pen in their hands to pass the time during classes. Here you **manipulate** something in your hands to pass time while you are in the outhouse. Maybe you're making little balls out of toilet paper, or playing with a Rubik's cube (“Outhouse hands **manipulate** ”).

column3: The simplest way to remember this character is to see it as built up from that for _branch_. The first stroke can then stand for something  "hanging" down from the _branch_ , namely its bark or **pelt**. The barb at the end of the second stroke is the only other change. Merely by concentrating on this as you write the following small cluster of characters should be enough to fix the form in your mind. By way of exception, you might doodle around with the kanji's form to see what you can come up with.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(150): A **pelt** is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a **pelt** and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging **pelt** ) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning “skin”.
column6: 2) [[myglagata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/myglagata)] 14-5-2008(54): To be honest, this is one of those cases where I have found it easier to "just remember it" as a radical, as it occurs so frequently: 彼 （かれ him） 波 （なみ wave）and so on.
column7: 3) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 18-4-2008(24): Davy Crocket used to hang his coon-skin **PELT** on a _branch_ that had grown out over the edge of a _cliff_.
column8: 4) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 17-2-2009(16): The head from the tiger **pelt** is hooked over the branch ([tiger](../v4/1990.html) (#1990 虎) also has this hook on it), and the tiger's tail hangs down on the left. This is Hobbes **pretending** to be a **pelt** , which makes the image not so sad. See <http://ezoons.com/images/wallpapers/calvin-tree.jpg>.
column9: 5) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 13-2-2008(10): The **pelt** Jason travelled so far for was found _hanging_ from the _crooked_ _branch_ of a tree, standing alone on a _cliff_.

column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 30-4-2007(241): **Waves** are the ocean's pelt (skin).
column6: 2) [[alanj](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alanj)] 8-3-2008(88): The Inuit used _water_ -proof seal _pelts_ for their kayaks, to travel the **waves**.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(24): If you can see **waves** appearing in fields of high grass when a strong wind blows, you will easily imagine **waves** appearing in the fur (pelt) of the water (“waves are water's pelt”).
column8: 4) [[Yozora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yozora)] 28-5-2009(17): **Waves** blanket the ocean like a WATERY PELT.
column9: 5) [[sethg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethg)] 28-3-2009(16): **Waves** are _water_ that is _pelt_ ing the shore.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(325): An **old woman** is seen here as a woman with waves (i.e. wrinkles, creases).
column6: 2) [[walexander5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/walexander5)] 20-7-2008(58): Picture an **old woman** on her balcony, watching the _waves_ , wondering if her husband will ever return from the sea.
column7: 3) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 20-2-2008(36): You know "The Old Man and the Sea." Well, this is the sequel, "The **Old Woman** and the Sea Waves.".
column8: 4) [[jotun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jotun)] 21-4-2008(28): The Queen. She's an **old woman** who _waves_.
column9: 5) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 6-12-2008(13): Come one guys.. this one is staring at you right in the face… water + skin + woman. Ok, no matter what you used int he previous frame thsi will help anyway. When your skin is in water for a long time it turns all wavey and old looking. Woman are always sensitive about looking old. wala.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 21-10-2005(226): You **expose** holes in a _pelt_ by passing your _fingers_ through them and wiggling them on the other side. The sense of the kanji here is to reveal something that was hidden, to make known, to open your heart (thus revealing it, exposing it to others), express your opinion, etc.
column6: 2) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 17-5-2008(79): Think of it in this vulgar way. You really want her to **expose** her “beaver” _pelt_ , so you have to encourage her with your _fingers_ to **expose** it.
column7: 3) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 29-11-2007(50): Fred Flintstone gets arrested for **exposing** himself to young cave-ladies. He does this by lifting his pelt with his fingers.
column8: 4) [[j0k0m0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/j0k0m0)] 13-4-2009(28): Eskimos don't want to **expose** their fingers from their pelted mitts.
column9: 5) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 23-5-2007(24): Some girls these days wear their clothes so tight that it's like a second skin, a _pelt_ , if you will, and they **expose** themselves by ripping them off with their _fingers_ , or, at least, I hope.

column5: 1) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 13-6-2006(294): Before the invention of scissors or knives, sharp STONES were used to **REND** PELTs, so that caveman designers could complete new styles for the upcoming year.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 21-2-2007(80): **Rend** is a violent, primitive kind of word. (Image: cavemen **rend** ing _pelts_ right off live animals with _stone_ tools).
column7: 3) [[Sunnan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sunnan)] 24-8-2008(39): Me Ugg. Me have rock. Me **rend** pelt with rock.
column8: 4) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 28-11-2008(9): Hobbes is stalking with his belly low to the ground when a sharp stone **rend** s his pelt (he is, after all, a stuffed animal).
column9: 5) [[brainrobert1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brainrobert1)] 26-12-2010(7): Rock + pelt = **rend**. He then took a sharpened STONE to the PELT and **rend** ed it from the flesh.. 破る yaburu to tear or rip.

column5: 1) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 13-6-2006(424): If you wear a coat of fur (pelt) you are sure to **incur** the wrath of animal rights extremists.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 24-4-2007(120): A **cloak** of fur ( **pelt** ) will _**incur**_ the wrath of animal lovers.
column7: 3) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 31-3-2007(47): A fashionable lady decided to put on her cloak of pelt, and thus **incurred** the wrath of animal rights extremists. But don't worry, they weren't brutal or violent: they just shouted " **ink her!** " as they stained her valuable cloak.
column8: 4) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 26-6-2008(26): Also means "cover". Having **incurred** God's wrath, God made Adam and Eve _clothing_ made from animal _skins_ to **cover** their private parts.
column9: 5) [[rowdyphantom](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rowdyphantom)] 16-1-2010(10): **Incur** someone's rage by replacing his fine _cloak_ with a smelly old _pelt_.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(146): The **remainder** of the bones have been thrown from the float (for the dogs maybe, at the end of the parade).
column6: 2) [[Pauline](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pauline)] 18-6-2006(111): Throwing all those coins (see [coin](../v4/368.html) (#368 銭)) was a really bad idea, people got mad with greed. The only **remainder** s left were the _bones_ of those that was on the _float_.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 13-9-2008(85): After the cannibal _float_ had passed the crowd, all that **remained** were _bones_.
column8: 4) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 13-2-2008(30): At the halloween parade, there was a _float_ made entirely from _bones_. Once the parade was over the **remainder** of the bones were left in the streets for the dogs to chew on.
column9: 5) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 11-4-2010(23): Maths problem - it takes 6 _bones_ to make a _float_. If I have 37 _bones_ and make as many _floats_ as possible, what's the **remainder**?

column5: 1) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 14-8-2006(224): Think of the early Christian martyrs who suffered **martyrdom** because of their faith. See them held in cells for 10 days (a decameron) before being fed to the lions. They appear before the chanting Roman crowds as _bones_ to be devoured. Think of what was leftover after the lions finished them off….nothing, not even a pile of _bones_ to bury.
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 14-11-2007(86): The _boney_ man martyred himself during his 10 day hunger-strike.
column7: 3) [[imojyochu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/imojyochu)] 23-8-2008(72): To commerate the saint's **martyrdom** his BONES will be displayed for a 10-DAY- PERIOD (decameron).
column8: 4) [[yukkuri_kame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yukkuri_kame)] 21-6-2009(46): After being bound up for a day (see [decameron](../v4/67.html) (#67 旬)) there was nothing left of Heisig but BONES. He had attained **MARTYRDOM** for the sake of an obscure keyword…
column9: 5) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 19-2-2007(19): Nice. If you know about the Canterbury Tales, you know they were pilgrims going to see a martyrs tomb. Just imagine that they're going to see the _relics(bones)_ of that **martyr** on their _decameron_!

column5: 1) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 14-3-2006(177): A t-bone steak is vermilion - **particularly** if served rare.
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 23-10-2006(146): Castlevania – The _vermillion_ skeletons ( _bones_ ) are **particularly** hard because they just keep regenerating.
column7: 3) [[Thora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thora)] 29-7-2008(143): [Too abstract, so: **particularly** - > particles as recall hint. ] The _bones_ had enough _vermillion_ particles on them to identify the victim. DNA is **particularly** accurate.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(33): The vermilion bone is **particularly** (especially) different from the others (it's a dog toy made of rubber).
column9: 5) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 18-4-2008(31): "Not **PARTICULARLY** ," I said when asked if I was interested in buying a _vermillion_ _bone_.

column5: 1) [[howdycowdy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howdycowdy)] 22-4-2008(388): Advertisement for Breast Implants – Tired of nights all alone? Want to get _boned straightaway_? **AUGMENT** your breasts and all your troubles will be solved!
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(90): In the movie “Gattaca”, Vincent Freeman (played by Ethan Hawke) **augment** s his size by straightening his bones (his legs), in order to match up with the genetically “perfect” population, and reach his goal of travelling in space. The stretching of his lower leg bones involved multiplying the bone cells, another sense of this key word.
column7: 3) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 26-3-2009(35): He wanted to **augment** his height so had some _bone_ added to his legs _straightaway_.
column8: 4) [[elmaestrokgb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elmaestrokgb)] 7-6-2009(24): Wolverine has had his body specially **augment** ed. He has special super- _bones_ and the ability to heal _straightaway_ after any injury.
column9: 5) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 7-10-2012(16): This kanji actually means **multiply/reproduce**. God said, "Be fruitful and multiply." When Adam saw his partner, he _straight away_ said, "this is _bone_ of my bone" (since she was made from his rib).

column3: _Bones_ . . . _saber_. The sense of the key word is of people or things lined up in a row.
column5: 1) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 27-7-2006(208): A line of skeletal warriors, all armed with sabers.
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 26-7-2006(108): Skeleton army rank and **file**. Dudes made of _bones_ carrying _sabres_.
column7: 3) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 2-5-2006(45): Common scene in (old) computer rpgs. Skeletons with sabers coming at you neatly in a **file**. (see [skeleton](../v4/1288.html) (#1288 骨)).
column8: 4) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 17-4-2008(32): Really this means things/persons lined up in a **row** (as opposed to 'columns'). So just picture a **row** of neatly lined up _bones_ **file** d next to a **row** of nicely lined up _swords._ Must be some sort of Khmer Rouge memorial. Now picture the people **lining up** outside the museum to **file** past those **rows** of _bones_ and _swords._ Now you remember this kanji is good for both things and people.
column9: 5) [[mothralad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mothralad)] 5-3-2007(11): Imagine dead soldiers standing in **file** to get into afterlife: bones of severed limbs in one hand, saber in the other.

column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 12-3-2007(220): They tried issuing the _skeleton warriors_ with proper _garments_ to wear, but they kept getting **split** by the sharp bones or by their _sabres_. In the end, it was decided they look scarier naked anyway.
column6: 2) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 3-11-2005(107): Someone takes a sword made of bone to **split** the garment right down the middle. Very effective.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 13-9-2008(81): My _boner_ **split** a hole in my _pants_ like a _saber_.
column8: 4) [[Angrybeez](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Angrybeez)] 28-8-2008(50): We should walk in single _file_ so no one sees I **split** my _undergarments_! (Undergarments should help with position).
column9: 5) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 30-4-2007(24): Think about what happens when you **split** your pants….the tear makes a _line_ in your _garment_.

column5: 1) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 13-6-2006(252): The nazis were **ardent** believers in the master arian race, see them marching everyone else into the _oven fires_ , single _file_.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 19-5-2007(108): The undead, marching single _file_ , prove how **ardent** they are be walking across a field of _flame_. Fun fact, **ardent** used to mean to _burn_.
column7: 3) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 24-7-2006(40): **Ardent** followers (skeleton army), [file](../v4/812.html) (#812 列), would _file_ over _hot coals_ for their master.
column8: 4) [[philiphoward123](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/philiphoward123)] 19-10-2009(26): My Japanese students have such an **ardent** desire to speak native English that you will never find any of them confusing _file_ with _fire_.
column9: 5) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 15-9-2008(18): People can get really extreme and **ardent** in the _line of fire_.

column3: _Bones_ . . . _spoon_. Note how the first stroke is extended to the right, forming a sort of  "roof" overhead.
column5: 1) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 3-11-2005(252): Ok, this is where knowing some Eastern culture comes in handy! In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they're out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead.
column6: 2) [[pacersfan218](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pacersfan218)] 1-9-2007(108): Imagine the grim reaper (the bringer of **death** ), carrying a _spoon_ made of human _bones_ instead of a scythe.
column7: 3) [[blackstockc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blackstockc)] 3-2-2008(68): The Grim Reaper eats bones for breakfast (with a spoon).
column8: 4) [[Biene](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Biene)] 28-4-2008(25): Remeber **DEATH** from Terry Pratchett's Discworld books? Now picture _bony_ **DEATH** as he sits down (in the book "Mort") in the restaurant together with his new apprentice to eat a bowl of hot curry with a _spoon_.
column9: 5) [[peepiceek](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peepiceek)] 20-7-2008(17): _One evening_ I choked to **death** on a _spoon_. (Don't ask how I wrote this…).

column5: 1) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 3-11-2005(284): I imagine an **interment** as a funeral. At this funeral it's an open casket, and the dead body (death) is holding flowers with both of its hands.
column6: 2) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 2-10-2007(74): During the **interment** ceremony, the grandchildren placed _flowers_ over the _dead_ body while the widow sat praying with _two hands_.
column7: 3) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 9-10-2010(36): During **interment** , flowers are placed above _death_ , while _two hands_ from the netherworld are pulling from below.
column8: 4) [[humpolec](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/humpolec)] 11-11-2008(20): We see _Death_ himself standing at a funeral. This time he's not holding his scythe, but he has _flowers_ in both hands.
column9: 5) [[vertigo959](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vertigo959)] 6-10-2008(13): I used to confuse 亡 and 死 in this kanji, so I use the image of 死神 (shinigami, or death god) to help remember the right element.— At this **interment** funeral, underneath the _flowers_ on top of the grave, the _death god_ ( 死神 ）, is descending towards the underworld, lowering the coffin with _both hands_. ソウ [葬式。葬る](midori://search?text=葬式。葬る) .

column5: 1) [[SpaceCakeGirl](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SpaceCakeGirl)] 1-1-2008(162): What a dilemna, you wore SUNGLASSES over your EYES when you went to the BIRDHOUSE so you wouldn't be recognized - but now you can't **WINK** at the girl you want!
column6: 2) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 26-4-2006(158): Imagine Snoopy **wink** ing with his big _eyes_ (and a happy smile) standing next to Woodstocks _Birdhouse_ , woodstock being so cool that he wears little _sunglasses_.
column7: 3) [[mattimus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattimus)] 3-2-2010(69): At the _whorehouse_ a girl pulled down her _sunglasses_ and **wink** ed at me with a _single massive eye_ OMG SHE'S A CYCLOPS. Didn't stop me though.
column8: 4) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 18-1-2007(27): Out of the corner of your eye, you thought some cute girl was **wink** ing at you, but it turns out it was just a birdhouse with sunglasses. Isn't that always the way it turns out.
column9: 5) [[mattoc_g](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattoc_g)] 20-4-2009(21): I prefer to use the 舛 to mean "dancing legs". Makes a lot more sense to me that way. Just think of it as in the evening, you want to watch dancing legs, (you can see the two legs wrapped around a pole… right? ,) ) You go to a certain kind of "BIRD" HOUSE, to watch the DANCING LEGS. Your EYE is drawn to one particular set of dancing legs in the birdhouse, she has a twinkle in her eye and you blink as she **WINK** S at you. (This kanji also means blink and twinkle).

column3: The pictograph for the **ear** looks much like that for _eye_ , but note how the stroke order gives it a different look.
column5: 1) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 14-11-2007(87): Your **ear** is like the eye on the side of your head for seeing things, but there is hair around it that creates jagged lines.
column6: 2) [[delbertmon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/delbertmon)] 30-11-2009(39): Just remember it.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(36): Pictograph, see book. * The primitive meaning can easily be extended to **ear** plugs.
column8: 4) [[andresito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/andresito)] 9-5-2009(20): Deaf people use their **ear** s as _eyes_. An **ear** is just a modified _eye_.
column9: 5) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 29-12-2009(12): Correct stroke order: Begin with capital T, add two horizontals from capital F. Then add the "scissors" from 斗 [Big Dipper](../v4/1177.html) (#1177 斗)… Remember: the horizontals overextend at all 4 corners, but the verticals overextend ONLY at the bottom right corner… 耳 [みみ].

column5: 1) [[Rakushun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rakushun)] 17-5-2007(257): You put your ear next to a womans crotch…and somehow, from it, you hear the words "Take me….".
column6: 2) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 1-5-2009(136): Fuaburisu's with a twist: You know that classic trick where someone pretends to **take** something out of an someone else's _ear_ (such as a coin). Instead of a cigarette or a pen he pulls the person’s _crotch_ out of their ear. Very painful!
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 16-1-2006(46): Someone does the classic magic trick of pretending to **take** something out of their ear (such as a coin). Or maybe it is a cigarette or a pen that you **take** from behind the ear (the crotch of the ear).
column8: 4) [[skays](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skays)] 3-6-2008(42): You know that episode of Family Guy where Meg was gonna **take** it in the _ear_ instead of the _crotch_?
column9: 5) [[Seiska](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Seiska)] 7-11-2010(18): "Its too dangerous to go alone **take** these." and so Link **take** s _earplugs_ and _crotch_ protection and goes to face the furious Zelda. Ganondorf was not the final boss..

column5: 1) [[jwy2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jwy2k2)] 12-4-2007(284): The **gist** of it is this: We take the money and run!
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 21-2-2007(82): Pickpocket advice: It's simple, FIRST _run_ , then _take_. Yeah, that's the **gist** of it!
column7: 3) [[Dragg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dragg)] 18-11-2007(37): I gotta RUN soon so I will just TAKE the **GIST** of your otherwise long-winded story.
column8: 4) [[nadiatims](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nadiatims)] 1-2-2008(21): Advice for learning japanese: Just take the words you know, and run with them. You'll soon get the **gist** of it.
column9: 5) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 11-5-2006(17): Fagin is telling Oliver Twist: " This is the **GIST** : RUN and TAKE, RUN and TAKE. Now do you get the **GIST**?".

column5: 1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 28-8-2007(274): TAKE the **UTMOST** care when you SUN bath all DAY, or you'll get burned from your EARS to your CROTCH.
column6: 2) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 30-9-2006(148): Do your **utmost** \- seize(take) the day.
column7: 3) [[mikedough2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mikedough2)] 14-11-2007(60): The renewable energy that man can _take_ from the _sun_ is of **utmost** importance to the world's future.
column8: 4) [[theBryan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theBryan)] 24-7-2008(33): To take the **utmost** out of life, you must live fully each day. You must Carpe Diem, Seize or Take the day.
column9: 5) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 11-4-2010(28): Its of the **UTMOST** importance this doesn't TAKE all DAY.

column3: _Finger_ . . . _utmost_. This character _is_ used for taking photographs. Note how, conveniently, the element for  " _take_ " is included in it.
column5: 1) [[volfy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/volfy)] 27-3-2006(308): Take the _utmost_ care that you don't have your _finger_ in the way when you take a **snapshot**.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 19-6-2006(69): When I learned photography from my dad as a little girl, he explained the basics to me: "when you _take_ a **snapshot** , be careful not to put your _fingers_ before the lens, and don't look towards the _sun_ (this was in the days that photographs would be spoiled by direct sunlight).
column7: 3) [[Hujis](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hujis)] 26-12-2008(63): As a Japanese girl, when having your **snapshot** taken it is of the _utmost_ importance to make the peace sign with your _fingers_.
column8: 4) [[cangy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cangy)] 18-1-2008(22): Pictograph of a large SLR, finger grip on the side, flash on top, and the bit that takes the **snapshot** underneath.
column9: 5) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 24-6-2008(20): When taking a **snapshot** , 1. Don't put FINGER on lens 2. Don't look into SUN 3. TAKE it!

column3: _Ear_ . . . _heart_. It is most rare to have the _heart_ at the right, rather than at the bottom. Take advantage of this fact when you compose your story.
column5: 1) [[rhclaghorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rhclaghorn)] 21-2-2008(200): Vincent Van Gogh's greatest **shame** was cutting off his _ear_ to win the _heart_ of a woman.
column6: 2) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 4-12-2005(161): Amelia Ear-Heart (sic) brought **shame** to those who said women couldn't fly.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 22-1-2006(107): This chinese character explains how **shame** stands between social expectations (the _ear_ listening to the outside world) and one's own expectations (one's _heart_ ).
column8: 4) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 6-9-2007(75): I am a **shame** d that I don't know who Amelia _Ear-heart_ is…
column9: 5) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 2-11-2007(51): Star Trek crew gossiping about Mr. Spock: " **Shame** about his _ears_ , but at least his _heart_ 's in the right place".

column3: The key word refers to one's occupation, or position of employment. Its elements: _ear_ . . . _kazoo_.
column5: 1) [[mothralad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mothralad)] 5-4-2007(258): Worst **post** in history: quality checker at the kazoo factory. Imagine the toll on your ears!
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-4-2007(146): Buckingham Palace guards are famous for staying at their **post** no matter what, even if you blow a _kazoo_ in their _ear_!
column7: 3) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-4-2006(90): You want to leave your **post** when you hear the sound of the fiesta.
column8: 4) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 19-11-2006(26): A guard stands at his **post** , listening for approaching intruders. If he hears anyone coming, he must sound out the warning signal – which is (due to budget cuts) just a kazoo.
column9: 5) [[spoonsman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/spoonsman)] 28-1-2009(16): From Star Wars: Episode IV. "TK-421, why aren't you at your **post**? TK-421, why aren't you at your **post**?" Han, in the Stormtrooper uniform, points to his _ear_ , indicating he can't hear. The commander turns to a guard. "We probably just sound like a _kazoo buzzing_ in his _ear_. Go check him out." Han then busts through the door and kills everyone on the Death Star.

column5: 1) [[tcjeff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tcjeff)] 11-6-2008(182): A **holy** man hears with his _ears_ before he speaks with his _mouth_ , which places him higher than a _king_ in people's esteem.
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 3-7-2007(175): The trick for me is to remember that the 耳 is to the left of the 口 . However, this is easy because a true **holy** man uses his _ear_ to listen (i.e., to God or his supplicant) before he opens his _mouth_ to speak, unlike a charlatan who just makes something up. Of course, _king_ s are often true **holy** men and prophets (e.g., King David in the bible).
column7: 3) [[lb4269](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lb4269)] 19-3-2006(57): **Holy** Hand Grenade: Monty Python: Quest for the **Holy** Grail. The rabbit just tore the ear off of a knight with it's fierce mouth. The knight is running back, screaming, and the King is watching. He decides to call out for the **Holy** Hand Grenade to fix the situation.
column8: 4) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 17-7-2006(49): Since God will only speak to the people through the king (or so he says, anyway), his ears and mouth are therefore **holy**.
column9: 5) [[jimsublimeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jimsublimeman)] 22-6-2007(22): **Holy** men always seem to have their _mouths_ in the _ears_ of _kings_ and other important leaders. Think Rasputin…

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 9-8-2007(264): Only a truly **daring** Japanese student would wear a _spike_ in his _ear_ under the gaze of the Japanese teacher _taskmasters_!
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(112): See that ear nailed over there ? It's the ear of the last person who was too **daring** with the taskmistress.
column7: 3) [[strugglebunny](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/strugglebunny)] 29-11-2008(27): English (punk) teenagers in the 70s were **daring** when they pierced _nails_ through their _ears_. Many of them got in a lot of trouble with their _taskmasters_ (parents, teachers, etc.).
column8: 4) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 12-3-2009(14): The **daring** schoolgirl whispers, "Come _NAIL_ me," in the _EAR_ of the _TASKMASTER_ …
column9: 5) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 7-2-2007(14): You must be **DARING** to use a SPIKE to tickle the top of the EAR of the TASKMASTER, very **DARING** indeed!

column3: _Ear_ . . . _needle_ . . . _eye_ . . . _heart_. Compare frame 427 for this and the following kanji, and then once again when you get to frame 950.
column5: 1) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 26-2-2008(250): I promise to use my _ear_ to do nothing but **listen** … stick a _needle_ in my _eye_ , cross my _heart_ and hope to die! (Intentionally said backwards to get the order of the primitives correct).
column6: 2) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 14-8-2006(115): **Listen** ing to others is different from hearing [1626] with the _ear_. One must allow the words to pierce through the _eyes_ (the window of the soul) and reach deep into the _heart_ …a symbol of thinking about and contemplating on what was said, not just the sounds of words spoken. A married man while reading his newspaper, his wife going on about something suddenly, says, "You're not **listen** ing to me, are you?" He replies, "I heard every word you said. You said…" “Yes, but you're not **listen** ing.".
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 25-1-2006(48): A doctor is **listen** ing as best as he can to someone's heart, but even with the stethoscope the doctor can not hear anything, because the patient's heart is "so small it could pass through the eye of a needle" (see frame 400). Contrast with passive "hear" of frame 1626.
column8: 4) [[jwy2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jwy2k2)] 10-4-2007(44): When you really **listen** to another person and not just hear them, you use your ears like ten eyes and see their heartfelt meaning.
column9: 5) [[vertigo959](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vertigo959)] 24-9-2008(24): To detect lies, _Darth Vader_ turns up his _ear_ piece loud enough so that he can hear someone's _heart_ beat, and closely **listen** s. チョウ [聴覚、聴講、聴診器。](midori://search?text=聴覚、聴講、聴診器。) .

column3: State of mind . . . needle . . . eyes . . . garment.
column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 11-2-2008(260): (re: taijuando) When you are in New York City you have to be alert, i.e. in the "New York _State of Mind_ ": you need _ten_ _eyes_ to make sure no one will go through your _garments_ and pick your **pocket** s.
column6: 2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 26-3-2007(44): She had me in her **pocket**. It was a _state of mind_ that would eventually _demolish_ me… —I use this story with a kind of unrequited love theme not only because it jives with my romantic soul, but also because this kanji also has connotations of attachment and sentiments/feelings.
column7: 3) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 15-1-2008(39): _Data_ is a good security officer because his _piercing eyes_ can even scan _garments_ for hidden **pocket** s.
column8: 4) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 23-6-2007(36): Imagine Darth Vader's state of mind when he discovers his garment has not **pocket** s. " D O NOT WANT!".
column9: 5) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 25-2-2008(23): The tailor's state of mind when he eyed the needle and the simple garment: **Pocket** s! We must add **pocket** s!

column5: 1) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 16-12-2007(233): I'll focus on the **mandala** primitive here. I guess Heisig chose this keyword for phonetic reasons and as a character it's the "man" in mandara/mandala ( 曼荼羅 ). A mandala is a graphic representation of the universe, here split in 3 planes of existance, the _sun_ representing the cosmos, the _eye_ represents the human observer, the _crotch_ represents the animal instincts.
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 8-11-2007(119): He' s often **ridicule** d for having his _eye_ on _crotches_ all _day_.
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 5-4-2007(81): Heisig really dropped the ball on this one, introducing the obscure primitive _mandala_ without a word of explanation. I choose to read it as _Nelson Mandela_ instead. Picture him under the hot _sun_ , being tormented by _cyclopes_ who constantly kick him in the _crotch_ in his South African prison. Therefore, this kanji: The _state of mind_ of _Nelson Mandela_ was to constantly **ridicule** the Apartheid system.
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 17-12-2007(68): The whole crew **ridicules** _Data_ as he's on a big hippy phase wearing _mandalas_ and such trying to explore human behavior. (It depicts the order of sacred cosmic symbols: sun, eye, crotch).
column9: 5) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 15-4-2007(35): In my diccionary this kanji appears to have nothing to do with "ridicule" and a lot more with "pride" and "conceit": You may **ridicule** others because you are so **conceited** that in your _state of mind_ you are at the center of the _mandala_.

column5: 1) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 30-11-2007(161): One obscure Tibetan sect– the Otaku cult– has an unusually **loose** interpretation of mandala drawing practice. Instead of traditional mandalas they draw mangas ( 漫画 ). They then pour water on the image to wash it away, and begin anew.
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 14-11-2007(132): Staring at _mandalas_ is a tool in meditation to **loosen-up** the mind and body, allowing the energy to flow like _water_.
column7: 3) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 30-6-2008(82): Even NELSON MANDALA dreams of drops of WATER glistening on comic book/ anime girls with **LOOSE** morals. (This story has been edited in response reports).
column8: 4) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 15-3-2009(71): The **loose** girl became wet the day her eyes looked at my crotch.
column9: 5) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 10-11-2007(20): A girl in a manga wearing a tantric sex mandala, feels its effects and gets wet and **loose**.

column5: 1) [[bigspenderJ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bigspenderJ)] 21-3-2007(194): When something catches my eye, I take out a few clams and **buy** before anybody else does.
column6: 2) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 28-8-2008(86): Rules to **Buying** : 1. You've had your _eye_ on it for a while. 2. You have enough _shells_ to afford it.
column7: 3) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 6-7-2006(20): If I have my _eye_ on something, I'll _shell_ out the _shells_ to **buy** it.
column8: 4) [[shibuyashoeya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shibuyashoeya)] 26-1-2011(15): Keep an _eye_ on your _money_. Watch what you **buy**!
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(11): Our freakish shellfish with a single, gigantic eye (see FRAME 54) **buy** s himself another smaller eye that he places above his big eye. Now he looks even more freakish.

column5: 1) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 11-8-2008(287): Working in retail you learn the **placement** of any item should be at _eye_ level so it's seen _straightaway_.
column6: 2) [[jimsublimeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jimsublimeman)] 30-10-2007(188): On the JET Programme, many people have their _eye_ on a **placement** in Tokyo, Osaka or another big city, and write it on their application form. They are usually sent to the countryside _straightaway_.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 6-3-2007(53): To ensure the correct **placement** of anything, your turn your _eye_ sideways and look _straightaway_ to line it up. (Image: something specific your fixing correct **placement** for. Maybe trying to fit a fishhook through the eye of a neele…).
column8: 4) [[strugglebunny](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/strugglebunny)] 4-1-2009(15): The **placement** of a cyclopes' _eye_ allows him to only look _straightaway_.
column9: 5) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 14-3-2011(10): At the job **placement** centre, you have to keep your _eye_ ON the listings and apply _straightaway_ , or you'll miss out on the chance of a lifetime. 置く おく put, keep, leave, 位置 (いち) : location, position.

column5: 1) [[takoman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/takoman)] 10-3-2008(226): For Japanese, when the mind's eye (the sideways eye) feels guilty for something bad that the body has done, there are two **penalty** s to choose from. One, you can say I'm sorry. Two, you can commit suicide by sabre. Why, oh why, do so many Japanese executives commit suicide at the first sign of scandal when all the have to do is say I'm sorry to get off the hook. (on yomi: バチ, バツ).
column6: 2) [[Proxx](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Proxx)] 13-9-2007(108): There is a 3-way masterplan for every goalkeeper to prevent a goal at **penalty** shootout: 1. Look directly into the _eyes_ of the player — 2. Confuse him by screaming senseless _words_ — 3. Pull out you your _saber_ and … (that's up to you).
column7: 3) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 27-12-2007(56): This keyword must be kept separate from "penal" and "punishment". I use the game- specific meaning of "penalty". Imagine a game of scrabble with a mechanical, computerized surveillance camera (the all-seeing EYE) as the game master, monitoring what the players do. If a scrabble player tries to form a WORD that is not in the robot's dictionary, that player is immediately hit with a **PENALTY** , and the robot uses his robotic arm to automatically injure the offending player with a SABER.
column8: 4) [[kaminix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kaminix)] 10-8-2008(48): This kanji is a timeline. First we have the _eye_ wittness observing the crime, then we have the prosectuor _talking_ about the crime in court, finally we have the guilty being **penalised** for his crimes. Eye to words to action.
column9: 5) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 17-2-2010(38): (Seppuku) The greatest **PENALTY** in Japan: You close your EYEs, say your last WORDS, put the SABER in…

column5: 1) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 31-10-2007(236): A pretty tough kanji. Think of elegant old housewives with English accents dining together at a HOUSE party. The hostess brings out a dish of hors d'oeuvres: a SPIKE of metal with an EYEBALL and a HEART skewered on it. Upon being offered this treat, one of the housewives says in her English accent, "I'd **RATHER** not.".
column6: 2) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 25-3-2006(235): **Rather** a house with a heart than an eye with a spike.
column7: 3) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 8-11-2008(63): Did your parents ever tell you that _home_ is where the _heart_ is? Maybe that's because they want to keep an _eye_ on you. They'd **rather** you were inside, than on the _streets_. Sadly, crack doesn't sell itself.
column8: 4) [[Samsara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Samsara)] 3-9-2008(43): I'd **rather** die peacefully in my _house_ from a _heart_ attack than from a _spike_ in my _eye_.
column9: 5) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 9-3-2006(42): Picture a racist railroad foreman from the days when the wild west was being tamed. "I'd **rather** be at my house eatin' and drinkin' my way to a heart attack than watching these slanty eyed Chinese immigrants hammering railroad spikes".

column3: The key word for this kanji connotes the "muddying" effect on a soft consonant brought about by vibrating the vocal chords. For example, in English a "j" is **voiced** while a  "sh" is unvoiced. In Japanese, the し is changed to じ when it is **voiced**. The primitives are: _water_ . . . _eye_ . . . _bound up_ . . . _insect_.
column5: 1) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 28-6-2007(228): The fly is wrapped in a spiderweb voicing "Help me, Help Me" under the watchful eye of the spider who's venom is dripping like water from her fangs.
column6: 2) [[rhclaghorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rhclaghorn)] 29-12-2007(153): Pour _water_ over the _eyes_ of a _bound up_ _insect_ if you want to hear a pitiful buzz that is very similar to a **VOICED** consanant.
column7: 3) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 6-9-2007(52): This is how to produce **voiced** consonants, like Z: [1] use lots of saliva ( _water_ ), [2] you can _see_ the vibrating of the vocal chords in a mirror, [3] the sound is that of a zzzzooming _insect_ , as if _bound up_ in your throat.
column8: 4) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 17-6-2006(41): **Voiced** here refers to the "muddying" effect on a soft consonant brought about by vibrating the vocal chords. For the image of muddy, we have an _insect_ that is _bound up_ and lowered into the _water_ as bait. As it struggles for its life, it stirs up the sediment at the bottom, muddying the _water_ such that your _eyes_ cannot see through it.
column9: 5) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 11-4-2010(28): My EYES WATERED when I got an INSECT BOUND UP in my throat, and all my consanants became **VOICED**. ブッキング インシェクト。。。.

column3: _Jewel_ . . . _eye_ . . . _ceiling_ . . . _mouth_ . . . _scarf_. The number of elements is large here, so take extra care. Learn it in conjunction with the next frame, since these are the only two cases in this book where the combination of elements to the right appears.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 27-11-2008(253): Together with the next kanji, the keywords spell “send back the **ring** ”. First we have a _jewel_. Next we have the _great eye_ of Sauron searching for the fellowship hiding under the many _ceilings_ during their journey. The fourth and fifth primitives are the _mouth_ of Gollum always mumbling “My preciousss”, and Pippin's _scarf_! Placement: the eye appears at the top similarly to how the Great Eye of Sauron is perched atop the Dark Tower.
column6: 2) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 15-12-2007(137): In conjunction with [send back](../v4/837.html) (#837 還)……. When I tried to give her the _jewel_ **ring** , she _eyed_ me, threw it to the _floor_ , opened her _mouth_ and tried to speak, she said nothing. She grabbed her _scarf_ and left.
column7: 3) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 19-11-2006(83): The Saudi woman accepted the marriage **ring** , though it meant lowering her eyes to the floor and covering her mouth with a scarf.
column8: 4) [[Es2Kay](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Es2Kay)] 20-2-2011(38): There's no "jewel" in this kanji!! It's a "king" you idiots!
column9: 5) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 15-1-2008(26): The one **ring** is the _jewel_ that the _eye_ of Sauron, above the _ceiling_ of his tower, is searching for. To get it back, Sauron sends his nazguls, whose insubstantial _mouths_ are hidden behind a _scarf_.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 20-1-2006(234): You've probably guessed it by now, this is the _road_ that Sam and Frodo take to **send back** the _ring_ to Mount Doom! (see previous frame, the _jewel_ is replaced by the _road_ ).
column6: 2) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 15-12-2007(110): Continued from [ring](../v4/836.html) (#836 環)……. So I'm on the _road_ going to **send back** the _ring_ minus the _jewel_ , the hit to the floor knocked it out.
column7: 3) [[Thora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thora)] 3-2-2008(36): A [ring](../v4/836.html) (#836 環) with no _jewel_?! she screamed and told her fiance to hit the _road_ \- she'd **send back** the ring.
column8: 4) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 19-11-2006(30): The Saudi woman was tired of looking at the floor and covering her mouth with a scarf, so she asked her husband to send her back on the road to home, though she didn't **send back** the ring.
column9: 5) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 4-5-2008(6): This shows the _road_ travelled by Frodo in the Lord of the Rings to **send back** the _One_ ring to the _mouth_ of Mordor…wrapped delicately in a _silk scarf_ , of course. All the while, the _eye_ of Sauron looks on.

column3: The kanji for _a_ **husband** or  "head of the family" is based on the kanji for _large_ and an extra line near the top for the  "head." Recall the kanji for _heavens_  already learned back in frame 457, and be sure to keep your story for this kanji different.
column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 15-10-2006(233): Even though it is argued size is not important, I'm sure most women would like their **husband** to have a _big one_.
column6: 2) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 25-2-2007(72): Homer Simpson, as a primitive.
column7: 3) [[Clint](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Clint)] 22-10-2008(21): After marriage, most men let themselves go a bit, and the result is predictable: _one large_ **husband**.
column8: 4) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 9-6-2006(18): My _husband_ is sent from **heaven** , and his head still pokes out a little.
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 10-12-2009(7): The bride of Frankenstein owns this kanji. It represents her **husband** : _large_ with a long _bolt_ through his neck.

column5: 1) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 23-3-2008(98): In Homer Simpsons' house, the first **aid** kit is usually used for when he smashes his fingers trying to build something (there are countless Simpsons episodes you can draw from for this).
column6: 2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-4-2006(77): A husband doesn't lift a finger to **aid** his partner.
column7: 3) [[ambassadog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ambassadog)] 2-11-2009(62): Band-Aids were invented by a _husband_ for his wife, who would regularly injure her _fingers_ while cooking. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Band-Aid>.
column8: 4) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 20-2-2008(56): When a woman can't open a jar, her _husband_ comes to her **aid** with his strong _fingers_.
column9: 5) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 10-11-2007(31): To fulfill his _husband_ ly duties, sometimes the " _big one_ " requires a little **aid** from his partner's _fingers_. This kanji is a very graphic representation of this act, and should probably be censored.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 9-8-2007(189): The Simpsons are on vacation. _Homer_ stops to take a leak in a **mountain stream** but gets snatched by an _eagle_. Hear his scream?
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 8-4-2006(92): A husband who went fishing at the **mountain stream** to feed his family, fell in the rapids (we'll assume this is a large **mountain stream** ). He is saved from the waters by a great eagle. He comes back home with nothing to feed the family, his clothes still dripping wet as he tells his wife of how he was saved by a great eagle, and of course she does not believe him. The story continues in [chicken](../v4/1947.html) (#1947 鶏).
column7: 3) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 3-3-2008(46): The water from the **mountain stream** saved my husband from thirst, dehydration and the vultures.
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 22-5-2012(23): The _water_ from the **mountain stream** saved the _husband_ from _vultures_ (see [chicken](../v4/1947.html) (#1947 鶏) for another example of vulture over husband).
column9: 5) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 31-12-2006(19): Did you ever wonder where the _water_ in **mountain stream** s came from? It comes from _vultures_ peeing. Anyone knowing the anatomical and temperamental differences between the sexes will also realize that the _water_ comes from the _vulture_ _husbands_.

column5: 1) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 17-7-2006(331): In the male-dominated world of yesterday, the husband's way of seeing things was considered the **standard** point of view. Women who dared to disagree were frowned upon.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 26-10-2007(58): Unfortunately, Homer Simpson is the **standard** model of a husband in American society. (Placement: You have to _look_ in the RIGHT places to find one that doesn't fit that mold.).
column7: 3) [[rodders](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rodders)] 15-10-2009(41): _Husbands_ that still _look_ (at beautiful women, at porn) are the **standard**. Those that don't are either saints and martyrs, asexual or blind.
column8: 4) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 1-12-2007(29): Ugh. You can tell what her **standard** s are just by _seeing_ her _husband_.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 7-4-2009(16): The **standard** _husband_ does a lot of _watching_ , when the wife is NOT _watching_ that is!

column5: 1) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 18-3-2007(291): A show like "Trading Spouses" called "exchanging husbands" where 2 husbands are **exchange** d for a day (thanks dingomick).
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 9-8-2007(79): Marge's dream: to **exchange** _Homer_ for another _husband_ for just _one day_.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-9-2008(57): There will come a _day_ when _two husbands_ can **exchange** vows.
column8: 4) [[Asgard](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Asgard)] 3-9-2006(22): This kanji depicts the reality TV show where two families **exchange** the _two husbands_ for a _day_ to see how they manage in another family.
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 17-4-2008(15): Think Brokeback Mountain. The _two husbands_ wish they could **exchange** their dreary, closeted existence for just _one day_ together.

column5: 1) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 6-9-2007(319): Out of two potential _husbands_ , which would you **approve** of? Well, the one with _shells_ (money) of course!!!
column6: 2) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 29-3-2007(56): Bush's campaign- "John Kerry **approve** s using taxpayers' _money_ to support _gay marriage._ I don't." "I **approve** this message".
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 15-10-2007(42): A _pair of husbands_ who are married to the same rich woman, **approve** of each other's spendings of the wife's money ( _shells_ ). Husband nr.1 - “That DVD player and wide-screen HDTV you bought last week, they're awesome!”. Husband nr.2 - “My pleasure. By the way I totally **approve** of that BMW you bought the other day!”.
column8: 4) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 18-5-2008(38): Out of two potential _husbands_ , which would mom and dad **approve** of? Well, the one with _shells_ (money) of course!!! (big thanks to zazen here but I keep getting this one confused with [choose](../v4/1074.html) (#1074 択) later.. So I figure mom and dad would be the ones whose approval we'd like).
column9: 5) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 9-8-2007(28): If a married couple were _two Homers_ , they would always **approve** on what to spend their _money_. (Image: shopping together: New golfclubs? I **approve**! Donuts? I **approve**!).

column5: 1) [[mayurp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mayurp)] 20-3-2006(223): When a submarine or similar vessel **SUBMERGE** S an EXCHANGE of air for WATER takes place in special compartments.
column6: 2) [[Asgard](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Asgard)] 3-9-2006(116): The _two husbands_ _exchange_ for a _day_ on the reality TV show (see [exchange](../v4/842.html) (#842 替)) finally goes underway. One of the _two husband's_ first job is to fix the _water_ faucet in his new family's apartment. Unfortunately, he isn't very good at fixing things and after a few failed attempts the entire apartment is **submerged** in _water_.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-9-2008(39): When you _exchange_ places with _water_ you become **submerge** d.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 4-9-2007(18): After their lovely _exchange_ of vows, the two gay _Homer_ _husbands_ **submerge** themselves in the hot tub.
column9: 5) [[samueruht](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samueruht)] 20-1-2008(15): Fact: To **submerge** , a submarine exchange the content of ballast tanks with either water or air. To **submerge** the air is _exchange_ with _water_. (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Submarine#Submersion_and_navigation>).

column3: To **lose**  here takes the sense of "misplace," not the sense of _defeat_ , whose kanji we learned in frame 67. It pictures a _husband_ with something falling from his side as he is walking along, something he **loses**.
column4: * As a primitive, this character can also mean to drop.
column5: 1) [[rich_f](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rich_f)] 19-7-2007(222): The _drop_ falling here is the _husband's_ toupee… he's already **lost** his hair once, now he's **losing** it again. Such is life, I suppose.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 10-8-2007(64): Note: Heisig's stroke order is wrong. It's the same as vermilion, drop first. _Homer_ **loses/drops** his wedding ring.
column7: 3) [[marydj](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/marydj)] 21-10-2007(43): My husband is going to **lose** his hair, one drop at a time.
column8: 4) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 14-2-2008(22): Homer's head drops in disappointment when he realizes he lost one of his 2 remaining hairs on his head.
column9: 5) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 22-6-2008(11): The _husband_ has **lost** his job ( 失業する ), yet on his way out of the office he bows respectfully one last time (the drop signifying his deep bow), saying "shitsurei shimasu" ( 失礼しあす ).

column5: 1) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 17-6-2006(282): **Iron** is a _metal_ that gradually becomes _lost_ due to oxidation and rust.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 20-10-2008(105): Compare with [pig-iron](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/270) (#270 銑). In moving from **pig-iron** to **iron** , some of the _metal's_ maleability is _LOST_. (The only difference between the two kanji is that **IRON** has knee- less, unbending legs, while PIG-IRON (270) has very supple, bendable legs.).
column7: 3) [[thermal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thermal)] 10-6-2008(52): **Iron** man will never lose.
column8: 4) [[tcjeff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tcjeff)] 13-6-2008(37): I accidentally _dropped_ a bucket of molten **iron** on my husband one day at the factory. He died instantly, but I didn't know what to do with his remains. Somehow an art collector heard about my plight and offered me three million in _gold_ for my "masterpiece". He called it **Iron** Man. So all because of a bucket of molten **iron** , I gained some _gold_ and _lost_ a husband.
column9: 5) [[kanjisensei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjisensei)] 25-10-2009(15): **Iron** weights a lot. It's a metal that's easy to drop.

column5: 1) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 3-11-2005(243): When you get lost, you just take an **alternate** road to get back on track.
column6: 2) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 27-2-2006(133): When you _lose_ your way, you can always try to tell the wife that you merely took an **alternate** _road_. To save time you know. I'm not LOST, I'm just taking an **alternate** road. Ahem.
column7: 3) [[zodiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zodiac)] 16-11-2008(41): If you take the **alternate** _road_ , trust me you'll get _lost_.
column8: 4) [[Buronzu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Buronzu)] 13-9-2009(17): When your GPS _loses_ the _road_ , it **transfers** to an **alternate** route.
column9: 5) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 16-8-2008(11): Trying to take an **alternate** road as a shortcut is the best way to… _lose_ you _way_.

column3: This kanji is actually a pictograph for an eye, distorted to make it appear that the pupil is protruding towards the right. This may not be an easy form to remember, but try this: Draw it once rather large, and notice how moving the two vertical lines on the right as far right as possible gives you the pictograph of the eye in its natural form. The "pop-eye" image belongs to an Emperor's **retainer** standing in awe before his ruler.
column4: * As a primitive, the meaning of the key word becomes _slave_.
column5: 1) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 17-12-2008(112): **Retainer** : _a servant, especially one who has worked for a person or familly for a long time._ Now, if you imagine looking at a **retainer** (e.g. Igor) from top, you see how he is bending his head (middle rectange) between his two shoulders as he offers something with his two hands (upper and lower lines) to his master.
column6: 2) [[yvanc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yvanc)] 12-6-2007(71): Its a pictograph of a teeth with a **retainer** in the middle.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 14-11-2007(68): **Retainer** = A slave (for the purposes of this kanji.) This is a pictograph of a slave collar with two handcuffs dangling from it.
column8: 4) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 16-4-2007(23): It may be useful to know that 大臣 （だいじん） means Minister.
column9: 5) [[gavin.schultz-ohkubo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavin.schultz- ohkubo)] 17-5-2010(13): It's clearly an X-Wing. Piloted as usual by everyone's favourite slave / **retainer** , R2-D2. I'll attempt to use him as a primitive in the following kanji. (He's much easier to use as a primitive because a) he's more loveable than an X-Wing and b) he's always where the action is).

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(223): **Princess** Leia becomes Jabba's slave (“princess Leia is a woman slave”).
column6: 2) [[mhaellix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhaellix)] 28-9-2007(106): Cinderella: A woman who was a slave who became a **princess**.
column7: 3) [[akotkav](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akotkav)] 4-4-2006(38): Ancient **princesses** were simply _women_ with loyal _slaves_ standing by them.
column8: 4) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 2-4-2008(10): A **princess** is a women who is a slave to manners.
column9: 5) [[Cygnus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cygnus)] 15-3-2008(6): Ever seen _Revolutionary Girl Utena_? In the story, a girl named Himemiya Anshī ( 姫宮 アンシー) is a coveted **princess** bride by title, but she is little more than a woman-slave, who is passed around from master to master as the prize of a dueling game. And look at her name: this character for "princess" is the first of the kanji in it.

column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 31-3-2008(241): The **storehouse** is _overgrown_ with _slaves_. The _slaves_ are to be sold in the store, to differentiate from a warehouse, which doesn't have the word "store" in it.
column6: 2) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 21-4-2008(96): Slaves moved flowers from the **storehouse** in preparation for the parade.
column7: 3) [[hknamida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hknamida)] 2-9-2007(44): For this story, I have chosen to use _overgrown_ as an enclosure. The _slaves_ , who are treated as objects rather than human beings, are denied the luxury of living in a proper house. Rather, they are stuffed in the _overgrown_ **storehouse** with their owner's other possessions.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(23): Slaves are being paraded, decorated with flowers in a rather ironic attempt of making them look happy in order to attract buyers. After the parade they are put back into the **storehouse**. - **STOREHOUSE** (for temporary preservation), storeroom.
column9: 5) [[imojyochu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/imojyochu)] 24-8-2008(11): The Romans wearing _flower_ garlands had a victory _parade_ in which the captured Slaves were moved to a **STOREHOUSE**.

column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 1-5-2007(229): You signed your organ donor card, right? So, when you die, your **entrails** and other body parts will be placed in a storehouse.
column6: 2) [[axelb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/axelb)] 9-8-2008(107): Your _body_ is like _a storehouse_ for your **entrails**.
column7: 3) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 24-11-2006(67): Again with the Pyramids, each Pharaoh had their **entrails** taken out and put into little jars that were shaped in the forms of their Gods and entombed along with the preserved body. So, the **entrails** are the _parts of the body_ that are placed in the _storehouse_ along with the Pharaoh! Damnit, why can't they always be this easy? :(.
column8: 4) [[ablindmouse](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ablindmouse)] 12-3-2008(30): Your **entrails** are the storehouse for your body's waste.
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 18-4-2008(13): Most people don't really like to eat **entrails** …so those _pieces of meat_ just build up in the _storehouses_ over time. (Picture a storehouse bursting at the seams with tripe…).

column5: 1) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 19-11-2006(342): An **intelligent** man is neither slave to his crotch nor to money. But an **intelligent** slave will know how to use his/her crotch to make money.
column6: 2) [[Shizuru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shizuru)] 12-8-2007(93): Every **intelligent** man is a _slave_ to two things, his: 1) _crotch_ , and 2) _money_.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(32): An **intelligent** slave hides shells (money) in his crotch (in the crotch of his buttocks, say) so that one day maybe he can buy his freedom. Note: do not confuse with FRAME 459 “cleverness” (in which Heisig suggested the image of a fox associated with the idea of “alert, quick”). This key word here refers in fact to “wise” but Heisig probably chose **intelligent** to avoid confusion later with “wisdom” (so try to think of **intelligent** in the sense of someone wise).
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 2-7-2008(27): Tip: The _slave + crotch_ combination appears five times in Heisig. It may be worth making a new primitive. I suggest _loincloth_ , which the _slaves_ wear to cover their _crotch_. Ref: [intelligent](../v4/852.html) (#852 賢), [strict](../v4/853.html) (#853 堅), [tense](../v4/1374.html) (#1374 緊), [kidney](../v4/2453.html) (#2453 腎), [longness](../v4/2618.html) (#2618 竪).
column9: 5) [[mikemorr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mikemorr)] 9-4-2009(26): "Slave" plus "crotch" is the character 臤, which apparently means "hard" or "wise". I like Katsuo's idea of calling it "loincloth" (something a slave might wear to cover his crotch). The **intelligent** slave used his _loincloth_ to hide some of the master's _shells_.

column5: 1) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 9-12-2009(47): If you have a weak **KIDNEY** , you'll become a SLAVE to your CROTCH's need to pee. Oh well, it's just a weakness of the FLESH.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 16-11-2008(36): When the _sex slave_ misbehaves, threaten to sell his _body parts_ starting with his **kidney**.
column7: 3) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 11-1-2009(9): If you become a _slave_ to your _crotch_ and play with your _flesh_ every night, that _part of your body_ will think it no longer needs to be used for peeing, and that is how you get **kidney** failure.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(6): Needing more money, the _slave_ sold this _body part_ in addition to her _crotch_.
column9: 5) [[BladeWalker](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BladeWalker)] 16-7-2012(4): The **kidney** s are a filtering system for blood that removes waste and diverts it to the urinary system. In other words, **kidney** s are a _part of the body_ that acts like a _retainer_ for your _crotch_.

column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 15-11-2006(267): The **strict** parent thinks adolescent kids are " _slaves_ to their _crotch_ " (= can't control their hormones), so he _grounds_ them. Permanently!
column6: 2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-4-2006(40): **Strict** masters treat even [intelligent](../v4/852.html) (#852 賢) slaves like dirt, and they get no shells.
column7: 3) [[takoman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/takoman)] 11-3-2008(39): I'm very **strict** about not just sleeping with anyone. People who are _slaves_ to their _crotches_ often end up with _dirt_ y genitalia and I don't want to get their VD. (on yomi=ケン).
column8: 4) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 27-5-2006(33): It's a **strict** place…any _slave_ caught violating rules will be buried up to his _crotch_ in the _soil_.
column9: 5) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 12-3-2008(16): The **strict** est of masters took advantage of their _slaves' crotches_ , right there on the _soil_ … the degradation of _slave_ ry at its worst, and most **strict**.

column3: _Slave_ . . . _reclining_ . . . _goods_. The key word suggests both **looking** ahead **to** something and  "seeing to" what is at hand. Consistent with everything we have learned about the role of the key word, this means that you must choose ONE meaning and stick to it.
column5: 1) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 13-6-2006(269): The _slave_ is **look to** the future, "One day" he thinks "I will be able to _recline_ with all my _goods_ , a tv, stereo and washing machine, and when that day comes I shall be truly happy" he sighs.
column6: 2) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 1-5-2007(126): Imagine a slave(or in this case, a female porn star) looking to her new gangbang film where she reclines and gets all 3 holes filled at the same………..OK. Very vulgar, but I was inspired by raulir's clever use of "3 holes"………
column7: 3) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 22-11-2007(48): Roman master to _slave_ \- "I want you to **look to** the _goods_ while I _recline_ on this couch.".
column8: 4) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 8-5-2009(38): You better **look to** your _slave_ , he was last seen _reclin_ ing on the _goods_ he's supposed to be loading.
column9: 5) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 1-5-2006(11): The [intelligent](../v4/852.html) (#852 賢) slave is **looking** ahead **to** yet another day of reclining and using all three holes.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(172): The slave reclines on the floor at night to watch the stars. Since that's the only thing the slave is allowed to “read”, he does so very thoroughly and diligently, hence **perusal**.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 5-9-2007(104): [+scottamus] "Please, come in and **peruse** this fine selection of slaves, all reclining here on the floor for your **perusal**. Have a look here": <http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Slave_ship_diagram.png/440px- Slave_ship_diagram.png>.
column7: 3) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 6-12-2005(90): "Please come in and make a **perusal** of all my finest _slaves_ _laying_ on the _floor_. Tell me if you _see_ anyone you like. For you, I make the best deal.".
column8: 4) [[bexinkyushu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bexinkyushu)] 25-7-2011(60): In Japan while out shopping, you will often hear the shop assistant use the phrase ' ご覧ください ' (goran kudasai) which are words to the effect of 'please feel free to browse/take a look'. It is a politer way of asking someone to look than ' 見て ' (mite).
