column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 23-8-2007(30): If you're super poor, you can _substitute_ a potato **sack** for normal _garments_.
column8: 4) [[unicornpuddlefoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/unicornpuddlefoot)] 7-12-2008(11): When my clothes went missing I found a quick substitute - a **sack**!
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 8-8-2009(10): A **sack** can be used as a _substitute_ _garment_.

column5: 1) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 21-1-2007(266): In order for the bank to **lend** you _money_ , you need to put up some sort of collateral as a _substitute_ for the _money_.
column6: 2) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 3-10-2007(65): The poor _substitute_ teacher asks the class to **lend** him some _money_ for the bus fare home.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 7-9-2007(21): Flash back a second… _Mr T_ is still your _substitute_ teacher. You realize you didn't bring any shells for lunch, and you ask your friend to **lend** you some _shells_ for lunch money. He refuses, and you feel a bit embarrassed. _Mr T_ quietly reaches into a sack (which they will cart him away on later) and discreetly hands it to you. "I'm just **lend** ing it to ya, foo! Stop that thanking jibba jabba." [trigger: **lend** me some lunch money].
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 28-10-2005(17): I pictured the " _substitute shells_ " as semi-transparent, or ghostly money, symbolising how they only stand for money that you didn't have in the first place. – "lended _shells_ are _substitute shells_ ".
column9: 5) [[robertmyers](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/robertmyers)] 23-11-2011(13): When you **lend** money to someone, you are in essence substituting their money (or lack there of) with yours.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 30-12-2005(117): Referring to a scene in the movie "The Matrix" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine _Mister T_ who **change** s a _spoon_ into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of "spare **change** ", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as "shape" or "turn into".
column6: 2) [[ezmoreldo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ezmoreldo)] 3-4-2008(95): I just see this one as a pictograph of a person changing position and sitting down.
column7: 3) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 17-6-2007(64): _Mr. T_ reaches into his wallet for some spare **change** but it has all **change** d into _spoons_.
column8: 4) [[Valkyrie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Valkyrie)] 3-11-2008(32): MR. T can **change** a SPOON into a spork using only his teeth.
column9: 5) [[partyrash](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/partyrash)] 22-1-2008(16): You'd be a **change** d man if Chuck Norris spooned you!

column5: 1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 24-6-2006(210): The **flower** s _change_ with the seasons.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 15-6-2006(61): The _flower_ is the essence of transience. So, the conceptual _flower_ involves both the concept of **flower** plus **change**.
column7: 3) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 31-12-2007(46): "Hana" turned me down so I gave her a **flower** to _change_ her mind.
column8: 4) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 14-4-2009(26): When do you buy **flower** s? Right, when your girlfriend is mad at you. You hope that it _changes_ everything, especially her mood. - I know, it's a bit naive… ,-).
column9: 5) [[MeisterLlama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MeisterLlama)] 23-1-2009(17): Man, **flower** s aren't really **flower** s unless they change. If you just have a **flower** that looks the same all the time, it's just one of those fake plastic ones. Real **flower** s change with the seasons.

column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 14-2-2008(185): **Freight** is the _shells_ (money) paid to _change_ the location of something big. Don't confuse with the similar 賃 [fare](../v4/1004.html) (#1004 賃).
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 7-9-2007(97): This is a **freight** train that runs on _spare change_. Imagine getting on the **freight** train with a bunch of _spare change_. You put in some _change_ and it starts up…goes for a few minutes, then starts to slow down. You look at the slot..there's actually a slot for _spare change_ and one for regular _shells_. Your call, but it seems to prefer _spare change_ over _shells_.
column7: 3) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 17-11-2007(46): Countries like to _change_ _money_ by trading **freight**.
column8: 4) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 20-3-2009(36): This is also commonly used to mean currency, which is easier to remember given the kanji I think. When you travel abroad you change your clams into the local currency. Easy breezy.
column9: 5) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 13-12-2008(13): You catch the **freight** train, but suddenly realise you did not bring enough _money_. You turn out your pockets to show the inspector that you have nothing but spare _change_.

column3: _Change_ . . . _head_. The key word has the sense of **leaning** on or toward someone or something.
column5: 1) [[adhmm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adhmm)] 13-5-2008(206): _Mr. T_ gave a girl some _change_ to **lean** over and give him _head_.
column6: 2) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 12-5-2008(89): I didn't study for the test at all! So what else could I do? When the guy beside me wasn't looking, I **lean** ed over, and _changed_ his _page_ with mine!
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 30-12-2005(64): Referring to the movie "The Elephant Man" by director David Lynch, here we see Elephant Man **lean** ing on his bed, wishing he could _change his head_. He knew very well he could not lie down, for he would die unable to breathe, and thus he always slept **lean** ing on a few cushions.
column8: 4) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 22-10-2008(56): Your _head_ **leans** around the corner to watch the girl _changing_ her underwear.
column9: 5) [[Seiska](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Seiska)] 6-6-2010(18): **Lean** over so I can change your head, said man to his robot.

column5: 1) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 22-1-2008(157): **What** can Mr T do? 'You mean: **what** can't MR T do, you fool'.
column6: 2) [[msukovich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/msukovich)] 6-5-2008(44): " **What** country you from?" " **W-what**?" "' **What** ' ain't no country I ever heard of, they speak English in ' **What** '?" " **W-w-what**?" "ENGLISH, MOTHERFUCKER, _CAN_ YOU SPEAK IT?" "Yes!" "Now describe **what** this _person_ Marsellus Wallace looks like!" " **W-w-w-what**?" "Say ' **what** ' again! SAY ' **WHAT** ' AGAIN! I dare you! I double-dare you, motherfucker! Say ' **what** ' one more god-damn time!".
column7: 3) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 25-5-2007(31): **What** _can_ 't _Mr. T_ not do?
column8: 4) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 8-12-2005(26): If _Mr. T_ can't do it, **what** _person_ _can_?
column9: 5) [[Tatiana](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tatiana)] 22-10-2006(16): Personman. Personman. Doing **what** only _person_ _can_.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 22-2-2007(262): TSA guard: _What's_ in the **baggage**?! It's just _flowers_ , I swear!
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 1-11-2007(85): Your girlfriend arrives at the airport. You give her _flowers_ , but she brushes you off and says "here, carry my **BAGGAGE**." Dumbfounded at her rudeness, you say, " _what_?".
column7: 3) [[msukovich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/msukovich)] 7-5-2008(51): Customs agent: " _What_ kind of _flowers_ are these in your **baggage** , sir? Poppies, huh? Please come with us, sir…".
column8: 4) [[rptb1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rptb1)] 11-11-2005(26): A man walks through airport security with a big piece of **baggage**. The sniffer dogs go bezerk! "What's in the bag?" yell the guards. But when they open the bag they just find it's full of flowers.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 31-3-2006(12): My story is similar to rptb1, only that the **baggage** is extremely heavy, and when the guards open it they see flowers and say " _What_ kind of _flowers_ is that !?" (you would never imagine flowers would make **baggage** this heavy).

column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 7-9-2007(242): The entire town wants to get rid of _legal prostitutes_ , but the **sagacious** _Mr T_ realizes that they are a benefit to the economy and society. So he lets the sa-geishas stay.
column6: 2) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 9-10-2006(101): (re: sweetneet) Since he is not very **sagacious** , _Mr. T_ failed his driver's _license_ and now needs to resort to his _walking legs_ to get around.
column7: 3) [[sobani](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sobani)] 17-2-2009(29): This is the first time I heard of the word **sagacious** , so I looked it up at dictionary.com and found [http://dictionary.reference.com/search?db=dictionary&q=sagacious](http://dictionary.reference.com/search?db=dictionary&q=sagacious). For the definition they give the example of "a **sagacious** lawyer". And let a lawyer be a _person_ that has a _license_ to practice law and who _walks_ frantically through the courtroom as he tries to sway the jury. To add some drama: he's defending Osama bin Laden (can be used as the _person_ element).
column8: 4) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 31-12-2009(20): People who just get their drivers _license_ think they are better than anyone else. But, in reality, the _people_ who are **sagacious** are the ones who used their _walking legs_ as much as possible (since it's better for their health).
column9: 5) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 1-5-2009(18): A _person_ who is has been a _streetwalker_ is probably very **sagacious** about human nature. see [tempt](../v4/766.html) (#766 唆).

column5: 1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 30-4-2008(205): In Japan, the emperor is a **bystander** \- he _stands on his crown_ but can't really affect the _direction_ of the country. (thx shimouma).
column6: 2) [[the_marshal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/the_marshal)] 6-3-2006(132): Mr. T is in the street, standing up, wearing an golden crown and a compass in his hand… he's asking the **bystander** if they know how to get to buckingham palace (!).
column7: 3) [[Joyo1945](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Joyo1945)] 6-1-2009(57): _Mr. T_ is tired of being a **bystander** , he _stands up_ and takes the king's _crown_ for himself to change the _direction_ of the country.
column8: 4) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 1-5-2009(49): Side Note: The right side of this kanji is itself a kanji (but not a kanji given in Heisig) meaning "The right hand side of a kanji" (旁【つくり】). It can also mean "at the same time." Not sure if this is useful, but it seemed interesting…
column9: 5) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 28-5-2007(21): Many cultures have some traditional story about the _sovereign_ who disguises himself as a peasant or traveler, a **bystander** if you will, to judge the moral _compass_ of his _people_.

column3: The key word refers to a very familiar way of referring to oneself, typically used by men. Its component elements: _person_ . . . _St. Bernard_ . . . _eel_.
column5: 1) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 11-12-2009(73): **Myself** as used by men – a _person_ who prides himself on how _big_ his “ _eel_ ” is.
column6: 2) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 16-9-2007(30): "I did it all by **myself**!" _Mr T_ stands there proud as holding a _moray eel_ in his hand. He's brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish… what a guy.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-2-2007(24): As astridtops mentions, this is "Ore". In Japanese r = l, so could write it "Ole". So picture a bullfight with _person_ as the matador and a _dachshund_ replacing the bull. The crowd keep shouting "Ole! (Ore)".
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-8-2006(15): (note: this is the kanji for 'ore'). "I, **myself** , am the _person_ who will kill the _Midgard Snake_ ", the god Thor bellows. Since he's not known for his politeness, you can see him using 'ore' to refer to himself…
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 25-6-2008(6): _Mr T_ is unfortunately bragging a bit here - "Myself? I have got a pretty big mini- **myself**. It's actually right around the size of a _moray eel_ , sucka." And as opposed to the Japanese, who point to their noses to refer to their own **myself** , or cultures that point to their body, when _Mr T_ wants to refer to his **myself** , he points to his _moray eel_.

column3: This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for _bound up_ and a _person_. Think of a mummy, and the key word will not be far behind.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-2-2007(225): Note: this is the ひさ in ひさしぶり . **Long time** no see _mummy_! (A bound up person).
column6: 2) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 2-3-2006(33): This is a picture of a person bowing "long time no see!".
column7: 3) [[Delina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Delina)] 13-5-2008(22): Be careful if you're using alternate primitives for this kanji! There are only three strokes, and the stroke order is similar to _bound up_ with an extra 'leg' like the last stroke of _person_. Using _recline_ and _person_ would give you four strokes. Using _drop_ and _enter_ would give the wrong stroke order and the wrong shape in handwritten kanji, even though they all look kind of the same in print. See <http://www.mahou.org/Kanji/3557/> (bottom of page) for the handwritten style.
column8: 4) [[Artemisk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Artemisk)] 19-3-2009(21): That _bound up_ _person_ is a _mummy_ , he's been that way for a **long time**.
column9: 5) [[kansaigaijin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kansaigaijin)] 28-7-2009(13): A mummy is a _person_ who has been _bound up_ for a **long time**.

column3: Think of the three kinds of **furrows** shown here in this character - a _top hat's_ rim, a _rice field's_ ridges, and the wrinkles that show you've been around a _long time_.
column5: 1) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 19-3-2007(209): Using a TOP HAT to make **FURROW** S in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME!
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 7-9-2007(107): A _mummy_ tries to **furrow** his brow but realizes that he's got no head - just a _brain_ with a _top-hat_ on it. So he **furrow** s his _brain_. [trigger: **furrow** your _brain_ ].
column7: 3) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 27-12-2007(48): A man from the city, thus wearing a _top hat_ , working in a _field_ , takes a very _long time_ to dig a simple **furrow**.
column8: 4) [[MeisterLlama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MeisterLlama)] 29-4-2009(20): Correct keyword: **ridge** ( 畔 - >waterside). ( 畝 is used in 畝間 , meaning **furrow** , but that's because the interval between ridges is a **furrow** ). Words: 畝 (ridge/rib), 畝織り (ridged fabric). Story: A _rice field_ is actually a secret burial ground for _mummies_. Each **ridge** is actually a sarcophagus. The _mummies_ are buried under the **ridges** , and each _mummy_ has a _top hat_ which takes up the remaining length of the **ridge** , filled with his riches.
column9: 5) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 14-6-2008(17): The farmer uses a _mummy_ to plow **furrow** s in the _field_ , but he disguises him with a _tophat_ so he doesn't scare the neighbors.

column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 2-2-2006(165): A person _pent in_ is obviously **captured**. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money.
column6: 2) [[adhmm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adhmm)] 13-5-2008(122): Mr. T can't be **captured**. This kanji is lying.
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 6-2-2007(27): They've finally _pent in_ _Mr. T_. But don't worry, no one can keep T **captured** , foo!
column8: 4) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 14-10-2009(23): There is a butt **captured** within this picture. Lol!
column9: 5) [[miyadamuraman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/miyadamuraman)] 25-8-2011(15): This is a very easy kanji. A PERSON who is PENT IN is obviously **captured**. DO NOT USE MR. T! Why people are using this as a primitive element is beyond me. MR. T is the variant of person when it appears on the left side of a kanji. Do not confuse your PERSON and MR. T or you'll never know which one to use when you have a MR. T story. Keep each version of a primitive distinct in your naming. (Think of the difference between using "heart" and "valentine").

column3: _Person_ . . . _belt_. Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of _hood_ here because the _person_ runs THROUGH the element, not under it.
column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 11-7-2008(135): _Mr. T_ 's new _belt_ is huge! When he's **inside** it, his feet no longer touch the ground!
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-9-2008(118): A seat _belt_ keeps a _person_ **inside** the vehicle.
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 22-5-2008(91): How is a _person_ ever supposed to get **inside** that girl when she's wearing such a huge chastity _belt_? I guess that's kinda the point, eh?
column8: 4) [[fightswumbrellas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fightswumbrellas)] 16-6-2009(27): A person who fell through the roof of their house, now their legs are **inside**.
column9: 5) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 16-2-2007(12): In Washington DC someone who is an **inside** r is someone who knows everything within the _belt_ way.

column3: Those no-frills flights the airlines offer to attract customers should help create an image from _ceiling_ . . . _person_ . . . _belt_. The kanji meaning " _inside_ " should not be used because of its proximity to the element for " _in_. "
column5: 1) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 15-9-2007(385): In this **third class** flight, the seat _belts_ are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the _persons_ hit the ceiling. (it's almost pictographic here!).
column6: 2) [[somukeru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/somukeru)] 11-2-2008(26): Travelling by ship **third class** the cabins are all _inside_ (no windows) and the _ceilings_ are so low you hit your head.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 17-4-2007(23): But **third class** is so small Mr. T's head hits the celing.
column8: 4) [[Penguin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Penguin)] 1-10-2007(12): Mr T. hates flying **third class**. His head hits the ceiling, and the buckle on the seatbelts scratch his new belt.
column9: 5) [[nesert](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nesert)] 27-6-2010(10): The _ceiling_ _inside_ **third class** is exceptionally low.

column5: 1) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 27-4-2008(497): Half Way!!!!
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 19-6-2006(223): This is a " _design_ " as in a "pattern", not a verb as in "to _design_ ". The **tree** grain _design_ was too expensive for the **third class** airline to use for the panelling. They just painted it.
column7: 3) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 29-4-2008(200): Makes me think of Ikea. Everything is _wooden_ and the **design** is really nice but the quality really is _third rate._.
column8: 4) [[rptb1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rptb1)] 11-11-2005(58): The third class seats on the train are very simply **design** ed. In fact, they're not **design** ed at all. They're just wooden stumps of trees.
column9: 5) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 12-4-2008(23): **DESIGN** makes me think of 'intelligent **design** ', the _third class_ alternative to evolution for the hard-of-thinking. You'd have to have solid _wood_ between your ears to believe it!

column3: Let this doubling of one of the elements for " _inside_ " yield the sense of " _insides_ " to approach the key word, **meat**. The abbreviated form of this character gave us the primitive meaning of _flesh_ or _part of the body_ for the kanji 月.
column5: 1) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 13-1-2008(176): Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.
column6: 2) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 19-9-2007(61): A _person's_ _inside_ \- fleshy, raw, pink, **meat**.
column7: 3) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 24-12-2007(24): To avoid confusion with the _flesh_ primitive from [month](../v4/13.html) (#13 月), I'm nicknaming this one: _soylent green_. It's easy to remember since "Soylent green is people!".
column8: 4) [[dontpokebadgers](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dontpokebadgers)] 21-7-2010(14): Inside a person is **meat**.
column9: 5) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 28-11-2007(10): I like narafan's story that captures the primitives nicely, but I'm with Rakushun and fuaburisu - this is just a pictograph of a slab of **meat** (I picture a t-bone steak), and it gets reinforced since you constantly see it on menus.

column5: 1) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 19-9-2007(213): The **rotting** _meat_ _adheres_ to the _cave_ walls.
column6: 2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 8-5-2007(65): Smaller _municipalities_ are well known for filling their budgets with _pork (meat)_. Thats why they are also well known for being **rot** ten.
column7: 3) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 7-12-2005(38): The _municipality_ workers in their _cave_ are too busy with bueraucracy and _adhering_ to rules so they cannot regulate and measure the huge delivery of _meat_ that was made days ago. So it just lies in the back of the cave to **rot** as more work piles up.
column8: 4) [[FarisB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FarisB)] 9-6-2009(30): Resident Evil reference: The MUNICIPALITY of Raccoon City has been overrun by **ROT** TEN MEAT (zombies).
column9: 5) [[chillyrobotito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chillyrobotito)] 8-10-2008(21): There's something **rot** ten in the municipality of Denmark.

column5: 1) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 16-2-2006(268): Coal mine ( _cave_ ), tea break time, the _assembly line_ stops and everyone **sit** or squat on the _dirt_ floor, in a long line, to rest.
column6: 2) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 28-8-2009(267): CONGRATULATIONS YOU'RE HALFWAY THERE!!!! =).
column7: 3) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 2-6-2006(72): Nice one Gorgon. I thought I would mention that the stroke order is non-standard here. With _soil_ the vertical stroke comes first.
column8: 4) [[calittle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/calittle)] 15-10-2007(37): While working on an _assembly line_ in a _cave_ , there no benches on which to **sit** , so everyone just **sits** on the _ground_.
column9: 5) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 26-5-2010(12): Tea break on the coal assembly line — Time to all **sit** in the dirt. (Coal mine is a cave of course :) You **sit** DOWN so the vertical downstroke of soil comes first! [—Thanks gorgon  & wrightak!].

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-2-2007(58): I **sprained** my _fingers_ when I _sat in meditation_ (by sitting in a strange position).
column6: 2) [[algarich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/algarich)] 10-12-2010(23): (Using the primitives in the RTK1 addendum) The workers at the _assembly line_ in the coal cave ([squat/sit](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1024) (#1024 座)) frequently claim to " **sprain** " their _fingers_ because working within all the _dirt_ around them is hard and they'd much rather stay at home.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 30-7-2009(11): I **sprain** ed in my _finger_ doing a complicated mudra while _sitting in meditation_.
column8: 4) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 16-1-2010(5): You might **SPRAIN** your FINGERS while SITTING IN MEDITATION if you suddenly put your hand out to catch yourself after falling asleep.
column9: 5) [[Puchatek](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Puchatek)] 5-8-2011(3): With your _fingers_ you try to repair an _assembly_ line that got broken after some _soil/dirt_ got into it. But then the _assembly line_ suddenly starts working. It spurts _soil_ everywhere, and its movement also **sprain** s your poor _fingers_.

column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 31-12-2009(183): Ph.D graduation for assembly line of doctors( _needles_ ) with the cap and tassel( _top hat_ ). It took them _10 years_ (Bachelor's, Masters, PhD) to get there…. :-p.
column6: 2) [[fagie37](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fagie37)] 2-4-2008(95): When you **graduate** , you wear a hat and **graduate** in an assembly line while your parents sit on pins and needles because it will take ten years to pay off those loans.
column7: 3) [[xxinde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xxinde)] 12-1-2010(69): In the distant future, universities will produce **graduate** s on _assembly lines_. As the kids move along on a conveyor belt they are injected with knowledge via a _needle_ from below while overhead robotic arms place _square caps with tassels_ on their heads. This way it only takes a few minutes to **graduate**.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-9-2008(37): The _couple_ counted to _ten_ before tossing their _top hats_ at **graduation**.
column9: 5) [[eightyd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eightyd)] 13-6-2010(17): Forget the heisig stuff for this one. To me it looks like a little stick figure in a graduation cap with happy eyes. Hes happy, I mean he is graduating after all.

column5: 1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 29-10-2006(289): There are two _assembly lines_ at the **umbrella** factory. One is responsible for making the top of the **umbrella** , and the other for making the handle. The two lines _cross_ at the end, where one man tries frantically to jam the sets of parts together.
column6: 2) [[kumakuma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kumakuma)] 17-6-2008(154): FOUR PERSONS can fit under this **UMBRELLA** if they are thin as a NEEDLE.
column7: 3) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 15-9-2007(40): A pictograph: 4 people sheltering under one big **umbrella**.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-9-2008(14): _Two couples_ on a double date pool together _ten_ dollars for a huge **umbrella** they can all stand under.
column9: 5) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 15-7-2008(12): _Four people_ under an **umbrella** is better than _ten_!

column3: This character obliges us once again to make use of a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent. It refers to an old unit of weight, equal to about 3.75 grams. The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English. Its primitives, if you look closely, are: _bound up_ . . . _arm_.
column5: 1) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 2-9-2006(270): "Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!" "Yeah man, it's a bummer… with my arm like this I can only lift one **monme**!".
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 3-12-2007(57): "Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!" "Yeah man, it's a bummer… with my arm like this I can only lift one **monme**!" "You'll never be able to use your dagger now!" (adapted from ergerg).
column7: 3) [[Ikeda_kat2007](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ikeda_kat2007)] 31-12-2007(52): In Jamaica: Hey **mon, may** I have some (3.75 grams to be exact) uh dat leaf? I need it fo medical reasons. Look at my bound up arm!
column8: 4) [[sindhikara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sindhikara)] 2-12-2008(37): Either Heisig or the person who put this on the list is an asshole. Most JP people have never seen it. Heisig admits is useless. I hope his arms get bound up by the police for carrying a **monme** of crack.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 24-9-2007(34): Very difficult to picture, however, a **MONME** is very light, only 3.75 grams. So, imagine your BOUND UP sore ARM. Now imagine the weight of the cloth that BOUND UP your ARM. Yep, you guessed it. It weighs one **MONME**.

column3: Picture a _person_ dragging a _plow_ behind, and the _drop of_ sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Think of him (or her, for that matter) making a living  " **by means of** the sweat of their brows. "
column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 3-11-2005(188): A man earns his living **by means of** the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age "ard" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox.
column6: 2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 23-1-2008(42): Mr T now makes a living **by means of** a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it.
column7: 3) [[shinyclef](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shinyclef)] 12-5-2009(31): **By means of** a _plow_ and a sweat _drop_ on his brow, a _person_ earns his living.
column8: 4) [[Euphemism](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Euphemism)] 12-4-2012(9): **By means of** the plow, with sweat on his brow, a man earns his chow.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 11-9-2011(7): 以上 , 以前 , 以外 , 以降 , 以下 , 以て =以って=もって, 以心伝心 , [by means of](../v4/1028.html) (#1028 以) イ, (もって) … Parts: レ, ソ, 丶 (cf: 似ている [becoming/similar](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1029) (#1029 似) … Note: ’Plow’ is only used in 2 character 以 , 瓦 … Story: If you use "Person" in this Story, you might end up wanting to put 亻in it, more importantly the shape will be wrong. Learn your レ ソ n : This is written almost like those two Katakana characters then the drop last. Memorize it **By Means of** the Katakana plus a drop.

column3: Be sure to keep this key word distinct from _likeness_ (Frame 104). Its elements: _person_ . . . _by means of_.
column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 18-10-2006(200): **Mr. T** finds that living **by means of** dragging a **plow** is _similar_ to slavery.
column6: 2) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 16-2-2006(36): A _Mr T_ impersonator is **becoming** **similar** er (more like) _by means of_ plastic surgery. The process is painful and his face is all bound up in bandages as the surgery heals.
column7: 3) [[Wally](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wally)] 16-5-2009(33): A PERSON can become quite **SIMILAR** to someone else BY MEANS OF plastic surgery.
column8: 4) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 14-8-2008(14): People / PERSONS when young , BY MEANS OF anything, try to be as **SIMILAR** to their peers as possible.
column9: 5) [[krungthep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/krungthep)] 22-12-2009(10): You can **become **similar**** to _Mr. T by means of_ a sweaty _plough_ (your skin will get darker and your body will get more muscular).

column3: The sense of the key word is one of **joining** things together that were previously separate. Its elements: _person_ . . . _puzzle_.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-4-2007(158): _Mr. T_ furiously works a _puzzle_ in an attempt to **join** Mensa, the high-IQ society.
column6: 2) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 30-11-2006(75): "Why do I gotta **join** these two _puzzle_ pieces? I ain't got time for **joining** no jigsaw-jabba!" _Mr. T_ apparently gets a severe case of crankypants when doing puzzles.
column7: 3) [[cornrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cornrow)] 26-11-2008(31): **Join** _people_ together like a _puzzle_. How do they fit?
column8: 4) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 29-7-2008(31): _Mr. T_ is doing a _puzzle_. "Just **join** the pieces , foo!".
column9: 5) [[phauna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phauna)] 12-2-2008(19): (Adapted from Smithsonian's and vosmiura's) _Mr. T_ furiously **join** s the _puzzle_ pieces together in an attempt to **join** Mensa, the high-IQ society. Just **join** the pieces , foo!

column3: Ceiling . . . plow . . . fishhook . . . a drop of.
column5: 1) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-10-2007(238): Horror scene: Hanging from the _ceiling_ , a _plough_ and _fishhook_ _dripping_ with blood down onto the **tile** d bathroom floor.
column6: 2) [[penot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/penot)] 28-11-2008(176): [ **true stroke order** ] First draw _**T**_ for **Tile** , which then becomes _**I**_. Then draw an _' **L** ' fish hook_ with a _dash_ in the middle to make a mediocre ' **e** ' that few can see.//ガ wa3 와 (wa).
column7: 3) [[Biene](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Biene)] 5-5-2008(96): Note: This **tile** means roof- **tile** (e.g. 屋根瓦 ), not the ones you put on the floor. Hanging from the _ceiling_ of an old shed are a rusty _plow_ and some tangled up _fishhooks_. Since the **tiles** on the roof are old and broken some rainwater is leeking through and you can see _drops_ glistening between the _plow_ and the _fishhooks_.
column8: 4) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 24-5-2006(18): As said in errata, this is ceiling+plow+fishhook+a drop of (and stroke order goes accordingly). A plow is fixed on the ceiling and a fishhook is hanging on the plow, drawing a drop of blood from it (if animals can talk, why can't plows bleed? :-).
column9: 5) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 4-7-2009(11): Simple ~ spell out the word. First draw a T, then add a line on the bottom to change it to an I. Draw an L (the fishhook shape) then go back and add a dash beside the I, like adding the center dash of an E.

column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 3-12-2005(304): A **flower pot** that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together.
column6: 2) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 8-9-2007(110): To solve this _puzzle_ all you need is to put the **flower pot** on top of the proper _tile_. (cue secrets tune from Zelda).
column7: 3) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 19-8-2008(28): Imagine a mosaic like **flower pot** made from _puzzle_ -like pieces of _tile_.
column8: 4) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 1-12-2008(14): Puzzle + Tile: A **flower pot** was revealed when I solved the _puzzle_ made out of sliding _tiles_.
column9: 5) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(11): You knock the **flower pot** over and it breaks into pieces all over the floor _tiles_. You work furiously with your two hands to rearrange the pieces. It's almost like a _puzzle_. Hurry, your mom is almost home.

column3: Way back in lesson 2 we learned the character for _spine_. The two other characters in which it is used we can now learn together in this and the following frame. Here a **Shinto shrine** is composed of _house_ and _spine_.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 27-6-2006(242): A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: "house with a spine, **Shinto shrine** "!
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 8-1-2006(163): This **Shinto shrine** is built with human _spines_. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for "sedlec ossuary", it's quite a sight.
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 18-2-2007(101): The _house_ that serves as the _backbone_ of Japanese religion is the **Shinto shrine**.
column8: 4) [[samueruht](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samueruht)] 22-1-2008(24): Fact: Most of the traditional japanese Shinto families have a small **Shinto shrine** (kamidana) in their homes. Is very important for them, The **Shinto shrine** is really the _spine of the house_. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamidana>.
column9: 5) [[MisterM2402](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MisterM2402)] 4-2-2011(11): A friend of mine made up this rhyme: " _house with a spine_ , **Shinto shrine** "! (Now Raichu's whole story rhymes :D).

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 18-3-2007(247): The _schoolhouse_ is the _backbone_ of a foundation that will allow you to find a good **occupation**.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 13-11-2006(87): During the German **occupation** , this Nazi officer's **occupation** was to manage _schools_ that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect _spine_ (mnemonic : "the **occupation** 's _spine schools_ "). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also "barracks, camp, encapment". This story should help avoid confusion with [post](../v4/824.html) (#824 職) and [employ](../v4/1083.html) (#1083 雇). The military **occupation** theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 "detention barracks".
column7: 3) [[walexander5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/walexander5)] 14-7-2008(56): Stay in _school_ so you can get an **occupation** that doesnt require breaking your _backbone_ all day.
column8: 4) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 10-12-2007(23): I get this confused with [business/profession](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1792) (#1792 業). An **occupation** is something you can get after you leave the _schoolhouse_ with a _backbone_ of knowledge, but to get a profession you need to move on to higher education.
column9: 5) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 19-5-2008(20): ATCHUNG!!! This keyword stands for **Military **occupation**** , and not profession, as it could be (incorrectly) assumed from the primitives. Meanings: **Management** , **Military Camp**.

column3: _Sheep_ . . . _horns_ . . . _mouth_. Pay special attention to the writing of this character.
column5: 1) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 16-12-2007(297): Imagine a priest's teaching: "To achieve **virtue** one must first submit himself as a _sheep_ to God's flock, rejecting the _horns_ of Satan and resisting the _mouth_ of Hell.
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 9-1-2007(95): To be **virtuous** , a good rule to follow is to put your _sheepishness_ (discretion) over your _horns_ (anger) before using your _mouth_. In other words, "discretion is the better part of virtue".
column7: 3) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 2-10-2007(48): Sheep proves to be **virtuous** by bringing food to its hungry baby, the two little _horns_ and open _mouth_ that are waiting under it for food.
column8: 4) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(31): There once was a beautiful girl. So **virtuous** and chaste. One day, however, she got really _horny_. Unfortunately, the only living creature was a _sheep_. Unable to resist her desire, she opened her _mouth_ …
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 16-12-2009(17): The **virtuous** _sheep_ with the _horny_ _mouth_.

column5: 1) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 29-10-2009(73): The _virtuous_ vegan will not touch this **dining tray** because it has had a piece of _meat_ on it.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 16-5-2007(26): Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the **dining tray** s are especially _virtuous_ and never let any man touch their _flesh_.
column7: 3) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 17-12-2011(11): As VIRTUOUS cannibals, we serve FLESH on **DINING TRAY** S.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 2-8-2009(9): I don't want a _virtuou_ s girl - I want one who will let me use her naked _flesh_ as a **dining tray** for sushi!
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 29-9-2010(5): Vegetarians are _virtuous_ because they never let any _meat_ touch their **dining tray**. Note: also the counter for bowls (of rice) or pairs (of chopsticks), ーぜん.

column3: In an odd fashion, the kanji for **year** joins together the element for _horse_ , on the top, and the right half of the element for _sunglasses_. Think of it as a _horse_ wearing _sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out_. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later.
column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 21-3-2007(149): A _horse_ wears a pair of _sunglasses with one lens popped out_ after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New **Year**.
column6: 2) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 15-4-2008(63): A **horse** wears a **monocle** for New **Year** s to appear dignified for the **year** of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like [descend](../v4/1308.html) (#1308 降).
column7: 3) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 28-1-2008(25): Hint: A pirate horse?
column8: 4) [[delbertmon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/delbertmon)] 13-12-2009(15): The **year** of the _pirate horse_!!! Picture it on the zodiac calendar. A horse with an eye patch.
column9: 5) [[dat5h](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dat5h)] 3-6-2009(10): NOTE: 舛 is actually a radical meaning dancing legs. Can't you see the legs twisted about a pole perhaps? I am uncertain why Heisig chose sunglasses. Consider the last _dance_ that a _horse_ performs in a **year** for some festival. What do you mean, "horses don't dance"? <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zKQgTiqhPbw>.

column3: First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of **night** with those of _evening_ (Frame 114) and _nightbreak_ (Frame 30). Its elements: _top hat_ . . . _person_ . . . _walking legs_ . . . _drop_.
column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 25-4-2007(216): Actually, the lower-right primitive isn't quite "walking legs." It's a little more like "evening" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for **night** as: _evening_ plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the _top hat_ which my special _person_ is wearing out on the town…
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 18-10-2005(86): Here we have _Mister T_ sleepwalking, wearing a _top hat_ as if he was the ambassador of the **night** , walking, and walking and walking on his tired _walking legs_ , until he _drops_ (back into his bed).
column7: 3) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 9-1-2008(46): An elegant vampire. Going out in his **night** suit with a top hat, the creature looks like a person with long walking legs. The drop is the blood that the vampire seeks.
column8: 4) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 8-1-2008(14): See this as an example of when the oldest profession in the world – prostitution – prefers to work. Even the wealthiest of gentleman in their _top hats_ are ordinary _people_ , and will not decline to deposit their _drops_ between the _walking legs_ of the streetwalkers out in the **night**.
column9: 5) [[harkren](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harkren)] 15-8-2009(10): Mr T was taking a stroll during the evening with his brand new top hat, and without even noticing, it turned from evening to **night** in a dash.

column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 28-5-2007(285): A wet dream……..water **fluid** that comes out at night….
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 19-1-2006(54): I imagined some kind of liquid ( _water_ ) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes **fluid** only at _night_ , in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?
column7: 3) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 8-6-2009(37): _water_ at _night_ = > sexual **fluid**! エキ； 精液 せいえき semen； 液晶 えきしょう liquid crystal ( 画面 ).
column8: 4) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 30-1-2009(24): Try not to drink too many **FLUID** S like WATER at NIGHT or you'll have to get up to pee.
column9: 5) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 16-9-2007(11): Ninja's are **fluid** like _water_ and they come out at _night_.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 23-8-2007(218): There's already King of the Hill. This is Queen of the **Hillock**. It's _Ms. Piggy_ sitting on top of a mound of _soil_ in her _crown_.
column6: 2) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 20-2-2006(79): The _crowned sow_ (we met her in _overpowering_ ) is standing atop her little mound of _earth_ - **hillock** \- the undisputed champeen of all the pigsty.
column7: 3) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 4-5-2008(56): _Napoleon the Pig_ (from Orwell's Animal Farm) crowns himself king of the farm standing on a little mound (hillock) of _earth_.
column8: 4) [[cheesy_dave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheesy_dave)] 4-12-2008(15): These _pigs_ are searching for truffles in the **hillock** s. Their noses track the _dirt_ , and the one who finds the biggest truffles are _crown_ ed, never to be eaten.
column9: 5) [[sumomi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sumomi)] 9-3-2009(12): Auf der _Erde_ vor mir liegt der **Haufen** der _gekrönten Sau_ und was soll ich sagen, er sieht genauso aus, wie der **Haufen** jedes anderen gewöhnlichen Schweins.

column5: 1) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 1-5-2009(177): A counterfeiter is using a _shredder_ to shred a _towel_ in order to print up some **cash** (he needs some rag paper) .
column6: 2) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 19-4-2009(105): In order to create some **cash** , first you feed a _towel_ through a _shredder_ to get the raw materials. ("Paper" money isn't plain paper, it's mostly linen.).
column7: 3) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 9-3-2006(58): (The _shredder_ isn't a mechanical shredder but a little animal kept in servitude by the taskmaster. The _little_ critter has a _little belt_ around its neck which the _taskmaster_ yanks when he has a document to shred).
column8: 4) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 14-5-2008(39): _Shredder_ from TMNT is the _taskmaster_ who rules over the foot clan. He wears a _belt_ and has _little_ spikes both above it (on his head/arms) and below it (on his legs). Here, a hotel demands that _Shredder_ pay them some **cash** after they found out that he shredded all of their _towels_!
column9: 5) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 24-8-2010(30): The Shredder(from Teenage mutant Ninja Turtles) uses his towel as a whip and grabs your **cash** and disappears like all ninjas do…. (story for SHREDDER primitive: the droplets are the pieces of shredder paper flying around. The vertical line is the paper feeder. The belt is to squeeze and pack the shredded paper. The taskmaster is the person shredding illegal documents for fear of a lawsuit.).

column5: 1) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 30-4-2008(74): You **cover over** the _shredder_ with _flowers_ when the FBI comes a-knockin'.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-7-2008(21): _Shredder_ is writing a anonymous ransom note to the police. "Bring me one billion dollars or I'll destroy your city with my Foot Soldiers! Signed, _Shredder_." …oops! This was supposed to be anonymous, but he signed his own name! He can't re-write it now, he spent all that time doing the letter in beautiful calligraphy. What to do? …Thinking fast, _Shredder_ grabs a large _daisy_ and some tape, and **covers over** his name, leaving only the "-er." Good thinking, _Shredder_!
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(14): The _taskmaster_ arranges _flowers_ to **cover over** the _rags_ she makes us clean with.
column8: 4) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 27-8-2009(10): See why the FLOWERS keep on falling into the SHREDDER? You keep on forgetting to put the **COVER OVER** it. After you finished with it dont forget to put the **COVER over** it so that the FLOWERS wont fall into it again.
column9: 5) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 26-11-2011(6): SHREDDER COVERED OVER himself with FLOWERS so that the TMNT would not find him.

column5: 1) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 19-6-2006(97): You’ve heard of Edward Scissor hands? Well this is Medward Shredder Hands. Instead of nicely trimming your shrubs, he uses his TWO SHREDDER equipped HANDS to **ABUSE** your plants by shredding them into wood chips.
column6: 2) [[inuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/inuki)] 31-12-2006(58): Mafioso abusing someone to get information. They use a shredder on both of his hands.
column7: 3) [[potempkin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/potempkin)] 13-10-2008(50): _Shredder_ is **abusing** Bebop and Rocksteady by bitch-slapping them with _both his hands_.
column8: 4) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 18-3-2008(46): Shoving someone's _hands_ into a _shredder_ surely counts as **abuse**.
column9: 5) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 24-11-2008(21): This really refers to **abuse** in terms of bad habits. The taskmaster puts your two hands in the shredder when he catches you picking your nose again. That'll fix your bad habits!

column3: The _mouth_ on the left is obvious. The rest is harder. Try this: _four St. Bernard dogs bound up_ in a bunch. Together they should supply a clear enough portrait of a **yell** , provided you are careful to see all _four_ of them. Note how the final stroke of the _four_ is supplied by the long horizontal stroke of the _St .Bernard_.
column5: 1) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 10-11-2005(223): Think yelp when you hear **yell** to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I'm imagining lots of yelping.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 7-9-2007(50): **Yell**? You mean, Old **Yell** er. Here, we see four _St Bernard dogs_ all **yell** ing for a chance to play a part in Old **Yell** er. They're so loud that you have to _bound_ them, and their _mouths_ , up.
column7: 3) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 14-12-2007(43): The musher **yell** s at the 4 dogs bound up to the dog sled to get them to run faster and cross the finish line first. (4 St Bernards bound up together makes a dog sled).
column8: 4) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 26-1-2009(31): **Note:** 奐 means "clear, bright." The keyword [bright](../v4/20.html) (#20 明) is already used. However, among all the 3000 Kanjis presented by Heisig, the keyword _clear_ alone is not used, so you might want to use it to refer to this radical. **Story:** Although I could not hear them, seeing their _mouth_ es, it was _clear_ to me that they are **yell** ing.
column9: 5) [[nac_est](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nac_est)] 21-7-2007(18): You have to **yell** really hard if you want the _four St. Bernard dogs_ to pull the sled: they don't like being _bound up_.

column3: Fingers . . . four St. Bernard dogs bound up.
column5: 1) [[nac_est](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nac_est)] 21-7-2007(324): After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled- pulling _four bound up St. Bernard dogs_ : one snap of your _fingers_ and they **interchange** their positions.
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 18-6-2007(62): On the snap of your _fingers_ , the _four St. Bernard dogs bound up_ **interchange** places.
column7: 3) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 2-3-2009(40): **Note:** 奐 means "clear, bright." The keyword [bright](../v4/20.html) (#20 明) is already used. However, among all the 3000 Kanjis presented by Heisig, the keyword _clear_ alone is not used, so you might want to use it to refer to this radical. **Story:** With their fast _finger_ movement, it was not _clear_ that any **interchange** was taking place.
column8: 4) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 30-4-2007(10): Musher is going to **interchange** dogs in his _harness of four sled dogs_ with four spare ones. Dogs can't reharness themselves, so he has to do it with his own human _fingers_.
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 4-5-2008(8): Those _four st. bernards_ all yelping to be Old Yeller? Truth is, they're pretty much **interchange** able…just pick one out with your _finger_ …eeeny meeny miney moe…

column3: _Ceiling_ . . . _mouth_ . . . _hood_ . . . _human legs_ . . . _spike_ . . . _insect_. This is the maximum number of elements _to appear in_ any story in the book.
column5: 1) [[zenkun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zenkun)] 13-3-2006(653): I have created the element "old camera" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject's point of view, the light is captured by _one_ _mouth_ (the lens). The photographer is under a big _hood_ , we only see his _legs_ , and he is holding a _spike_ in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little _insect_ is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and **dissolve** s in the air.
column6: 2) [[amthomas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/amthomas)] 21-3-2007(97): I've seen this crazy thing with only _one mouth_ that can **dissolve** up to _4 nails_ and an _insect_ at the same time. Sweet! (It's a venus flytrap, btw).
column7: 3) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 27-11-2008(42): Just one single mouthful of cola has enough acidic power to **dissolve** 4 nails and one large live insect! Gross! (Not actually true, but meh…).
column8: 4) [[xiaoma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xiaoma)] 29-9-2009(28): 鬲 is a "reki" [http://images.google.com/images?oe=utf-8&q=%E9%AC%B2](http://images.google.com/images?oe=utf-8&q=%E9%AC%B2) Its _mouth_ faces the _ceiling_ , it's hooded, and it's got three legs. My magical _reki_ has 2 _animal legs_ in front and a _spike_ in the back. It can _dissolve_ any _insect_ that dares pass between its mouth and the ceiling. My reki can also **dissolve** website designers who _bug_ it by not allowing HTML links.
column9: 5) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 24-10-2005(24): **Dissolve** (fuse, liquefied by heat) a man is welding a large hole in the _ceiling_. He sees his wife's _mouth_ yelling at him from the floor above, but he can't hear her from inside the welding _helmet_. He steps back with his tiny _legs_ onto a _nail_ (ouch), all while a huge nasty stinging _insect_ gets into his helmet. This guy is just having one of those days. :) _(This one is an abridged version of Fuaburisu, but I posted it because this kanji is so damn hard to remember by a story)_.

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 8-9-2007(220): Under their _banner_ , volunteers are requesting **alms** for _scorpion_ sting victims.
column6: 2) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 29-3-2008(126): " **ALMS** for the poor" cries the beggar under his tattered BANNER. An evil bastard instead drops a SCORPION into his begging bowl.
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 3-1-2008(62): (Note: This kanji also has the meanings "apply bandages/administer first-aid"). With that sense, you see some poor man who has been stung by a _scorpion_ , so you extract the blood and **make bandages** out of your _banner_ to **administer first-aid** to him. The you take the man to an hospital and give him **alms** to pay for the cure.
column8: 4) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 6-12-2007(17): The notorious Kane of the Brotherhood of Nod introduces a new policy to gain followers. Instead of making war, they now provide charity under their _Scorpion_ _banners_. This 'switching from arms to **alms** ' is widely criticized among his military officers.
column9: 5) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 18-4-2011(13): "Alms! **Alms** for the poor!" A filthy old man sits under a ratty old _banner_ , trying to get help from passers-by. Instead, he gets stung by a _scorpion_. Now he needs **first aid**. 施す (ほどこす) : to donate, to give, to conduct, to apply, to perform, 実施 (じっし) : enforcement, enact, put into practice, carry out, operation, 施行 しこう enforcement, 布施 ふせ **alms**.

column3: _A banner_ . . . _a zoo_. Hint: think of a merry-go-round.
column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 13-2-2006(248): A merry-go-round with a big _banner_ on top and below a veritable zoo of bakelite animals on poles in perpertual **rotation** accompanied by silly music. Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos…
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 25-10-2007(135): Don't confuse with revolve or axis! Think of **rotation** as a **rotation** of animals in the _zoo_ \- some are on display (in **rotation** ), some are in cages in the back (out of **rotation** ). The ones currently in **rotation** (on display) are advertised with a large _banner_.
column7: 3) [[bennyb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bennyb)] 3-6-2009(38): I had trouble remember this with previous zoo-banner-rotation stories, so here is something a bit more vivid: The future of ZOO technology: There is a giant Ferris Wheel-type contraption with individual plastic cages, each with an animal that ROTATES every 10 minutes. It's built half-way into the ground, can you envision it? The lazy people who watch wouldn't know what animal was what without the colorful BANNERS that accompany each cage.
column8: 4) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 17-12-2008(17): The zoo is now open and the electric BANNER that says "ZOO" is in full **rotation**.
column9: 5) [[CarolinaCG](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CarolinaCG)] 7-8-2009(6): The zoo banner rotates.

column5: 1) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 7-4-2007(283): The BANNER warns that CHILDREN **PLAY** on the ROAD.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 19-2-2007(50): There is always a stupid **banner** talking about **children** at _play_ near the **road**. They mean "drive slowly", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) **children** that are at _play_.
column7: 3) [[FarisB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FarisB)] 9-6-2009(38): No matter how many times we told them these CHILDREN keep **PLAY** ing in the middle of the road, so we put up a new BANNER: "RUN EM DOWN", that scared the hell out of them… what? why are you looking at me like that?
column8: 4) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 8-11-2005(20): A _banner_ hangs over the _road_ saying "watch out for _children_ at **play** ".
column9: 5) [[xxinde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xxinde)] 30-3-2010(8): Seeing how drivers ignore the _road_ signs that warn about **play** ng children, the parents took matters in their own hands by making the kids wear bright _banners_ on their backs, much like Japanese medieval soldiers (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sashimono>).

column3: Let the last 4 strokes, which are also the concluding strokes to the character for _garment_ , represent a _rag_ as its primitive meaning. We shall meet this only on one other occasion. This gives us as our elements: _banner_ . . . _rag_.
column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 4-12-2006(237): The boat starts to leave on it's **trip** across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge _banner_ that spans the width of the ship and says "Bon Voyage", the people wave their _rags_ signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic.
column6: 2) [[partyrash](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/partyrash)] 22-1-2008(112): After a long long **trip** , what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.
column7: 3) [[shinyclef](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shinyclef)] 12-5-2009(25): When taking a **trip** , people wave goodbye with _banner_ s and _rag_ s.
column8: 4) [[iheckman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/iheckman)] 12-5-2008(22): So Mr. T is walking down the street when he falls over this Banner. Someone yells "Hey Mr. T, did you have a nice **Trip**?". Mr. T gets so angry he rips the banner into Rags.
column9: 5) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 27-10-2010(11): When leaving on a short **trip** , some people wave "Bon Voyage" _banner_ s, others wave their snot _rag_ s. Don't confuse this with [journey](../v4/880.html) (#880 往). 旅行 (りょこう) : travel, **trip** , 旅 (たび) : travel, **trip** , journey.

column3: First take the primitive meaning of this character: _knot_. Think of it as the _piglet_ minus its body (the horizontal stroke), that is, the curly tail that looks like a _knot_. As an exception, we will use the homonym to remember the abstract key word, **not**.
column5: 1) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 19-3-2007(219): This kanji is **NOT** a piglett.
column6: 2) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 14-2-2008(69): The butcher is standing over the piglet. "This is a piglet…(cuts of head)… **NOT**!".
column7: 3) [[samesong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samesong)] 28-9-2008(25): Three strings walk into a bar. The bartender throws them out, yelling "Can't you read the sign?! I don't serve strings." The strings try again, and again the bartender kicks them out. Finally, one of the strings gets the idea to mess himself up a little. He walks into the bar. The bartender scowls, "What's wrong with you? Can't you read? I don't serve strings!" The string replies, "I'm a frayed knot!".
column8: 4) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 8-10-2007(25): Ceci **NOT** pas une piglette.
column9: 5) [[penot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/penot)] 29-9-2008(13): [argument](../v4/1820.html) (#1820 論)=( 論 )=RON argued, "( **勿** 論) ' **MOCHI** 'RON, this kanji is **NOT** a piglett…. ".

column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 18-6-2007(190): The _cow_ 's " **thing** " is tied in a _knot_! ouch.
column6: 2) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 3-12-2005(160): A _cow_ is _not_ a **thing**. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and **thing** s are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.
column7: 3) [[netsplitter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/netsplitter)] 28-8-2011(45): A _cow_ does _not_ have a "thing"! (Cows are female).
column8: 4) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 17-6-2008(18): It's _not_ a _cow_ , it's _not_ a _piglet_ (no head - it's _not_ even close), it's just some strange - **thing** -.
column9: 5) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 4-5-2008(15): For Hindus, a _cow_ is _not_ a **thing** , it's a god!

column5: 1) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 21-11-2007(210): The _sun_ is _not_ an **easy** place to get to.
column6: 2) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 31-3-2006(128): Under the sun, it is **easy** to untie a knot. Under a pitch-dark sky, it is knot so **easy**.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 12-7-2006(78): If you take the _ceiling off_ your _piggy bank_ , you'll have **easy** money!
column8: 4) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 18-6-2007(29): It is _not_ **easy** to tie your _tongue wagging in mouth_ in a _knot_.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(12): On a sailing ship, the old sailor challenges a new young recruit to a task and teases him : "See the _sun_ over there ? When it settles down way over there on the other side of the boat, you have to have untied that _knot_. You've got all _day_ to untie that _knot_ , **easy** ! ".

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 29-12-2006(284): A **grant** is _easy money_.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 21-2-2007(57): Do you want free _shells_ from the government? It's _easy_ with my new book, "How to Get a Free **Grant** from the Government!" Call today!
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 18-10-2005(28): This **grant** is _shells_ (money) that were awarded to you, or that someone "deigned to give" to you (another kanji meaning). Regardless, they are " _easy shells_ " because you won't have to return them, and you didn't have to work for them! – "grant is _easy shells_ ".
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 10-6-2010(16): A **grant** may seem like easy money, but then the kanji would be out of order. So you must justify the **grant** _money_ first, then it will be _easy_.
column9: 5) [[crystalcastlecreature](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crystalcastlecreature)] 17-12-2008(8): MONEY that's EASY is a **GRANT**.

column5: 1) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 5-1-2008(237): Animals use their **urine** to mark their territory. So for them, their body _water_ works as a _flag_ denoting their "country" ( _why bother? we all know which story you are going to pick_ ).
column6: 2) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 15-9-2006(128): Someone is pissing on the American flag, but since the **urine** is clear it looks like water.
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 23-5-2008(80): The flag primitive looks like a big "P". And, let's face it, **urine** is just pee water. So, "Urine = _P Water_ ". Yes, it's stupid, but I don't think I'm gonna forget it now, haha. (I renamed the flag primitive "pee", it makes for unforgettable stories).
column8: 4) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 27-7-2007(30): Animals use **urine** as a "watery flag".
column9: 5) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 20-8-2008(22): **Urine** is _water_ that _flags_ your territory.

column5: 1) [[PacifistGod](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PacifistGod)] 12-4-2007(258): Red cross **nun** s sit in a tent under the red cross flag, spooning out food to the hungry.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 23-8-2007(66): A **nun** _sits_ in protests under an _American flag_.
column7: 3) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 23-1-2008(34): **Nun** in protest under the US flag. she has a megaphone and a big spoon. 'stop shooting, start feeding'. an anti war protest.
column8: 4) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 13-5-2008(27): The **nun** does not believe in the miracles of modern medicine. She had a dream that her _pee_ would cure all diseases, so she's feeding _spoon_ fuls of it to sick people. (I use "pee" for the "flag" primitive).
column9: 5) [[tenken3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tenken3)] 5-8-2007(15): Super combat **nun**! Dual wielding a flag and a spoon, fighting off whole armies of non-believers with these unconventional weapons.

column5: 1) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 15-12-2007(77): The _baseball_ team stick _flags_ in their **buttocks** and wave them at the opposing team to put them off.
column6: 2) [[Rooboy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rooboy)] 24-4-2009(74): I wonder if this story will be _flagged_ for saying i give her **buttocks** a score of _9_.
column7: 3) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 18-11-2008(13): In the locker room, the BASEBALL PLAYERS snap each other in the **buttocks** with FLAGS.
column8: 4) [[jotakami](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jotakami)] 3-4-2010(10): Simple image: a streaker running across a _baseball_ field, bare-ass naked, holding a _flag_ with two hands above his head. See him get tackled by the security guards…
column9: 5) [[Mushi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Mushi)] 9-10-2010(5): When a _baseball_ team wins the _pennant_ , they slap each other on the **buttocks** , as they can get to the World **しり** ーs .

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 23-6-2006(249): TV gets weirder and weirder… Now they're doing **mud** wrestling shows with _nuns_ splashing around in the _water_. What will they think of next?
column6: 2) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 2-7-2007(57): Water monks live in a den, but _water nuns_ live in the **MUD**.
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 13-5-2008(56): My catholic church was suffering from serious attendance problems and was in danger of closing down. Then they replaced the homily with _nuns_ **mud** wrestling in **mud** made from holy _water_. Now mass costs $20 admission and it's sold out every night. Praise the lord!!!
column8: 4) [[chrislewisca](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chrislewisca)] 21-10-2008(27): How much **mud** do I like in my _water?_ _Nun!_.
column9: 5) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 13-2-2009(13): Jesus can turn _water_ into wine. When _nuns_ try, all they can make is **mud**.

column5: 1) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 27-10-2006(235): [fence, wall, (kokuji)] A **fence** separates one _soil_ from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of _soil_ s in the world have a virtual **fence** called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their _soil_ with one color, their national _flag_ as the legend and a **fence** on the borders… don't you think it looks like a giant _puzzle_?
column6: 2) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 27-7-2007(96): Why the Earth has to be **fence** d off and flags used to represent each "country" is a puzzle to me - we're all just monkeys on a big rock spinning round the Sun!
column7: 3) [[adhmm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adhmm)] 19-5-2008(34): An Ikea **fence** : you want to seperate your soil from your neighbor's, so you go buy an Ikea **fence**. You start putting it together and it's like a puzzle, with little flags on top of each post.
column8: 4) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 3-10-2007(28): What is the best way to **fence** this _soil_? If we mark possible locations with _flags_ it may be easier to solve this _puzzle_.
column9: 5) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 11-10-2009(26): The _Earth_ is **fence** d off with _flags_ indicating different countries, forming a complex _puzzle_ of lands. (thanks samuize).

column5: 1) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 10-4-2009(206): NOTE: The most common use is in はく, meaning to put on **footgear** , rather than actual **footgear** itself. STORY: You are asleep in camp when you are woken up with news that the FLAG has fallen to the enemy. You quickly PUT ON YOUR **FOOTGEAR** and run off to RESTORE the FLAG.
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 21-9-2006(105): You should never use a _flag_ as a shoeshine cloth to _restore_ your **footgear**.
column7: 3) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 2-2-2006(76): The flag has fallen! To win the flag must be restored. Whomever has to run up on the hill to restore the flag needs good **footgear**.
column8: 4) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 4-1-2010(16): After being embarassed at the olympics, the national track team wants to restore honor to their flag. So they hire Nike to create ultra futuristic **footgear** (think Michael Johnson's gold running shoes).
column9: 5) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 13-5-2008(13): My friend's **footgear** had lost its shine after constant wear. He was drunk and all of a suddent got a "brilliant" idea to _restore_ that "wet look" to his **footgear**. Yup, he _peed_ all over them. Gotta love drunken ideas. ( I use "pee" for the "flag" primitive).

column3: _Flag_ . . . _climax_. Note that this kanji has no relation to the drawing of a  "roof" used in the primitive for _house_.
column5: 1) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 27-7-2007(219): Flag at the climax (highest point) of a castle **roof**.
column6: 2) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 10-4-2007(113): A couple climaxing on the **roof** , draped in the American flag. The neighbors are mortified and call the landlady…
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 13-5-2008(41): My girlfriend is crazy. First she drags me up onto the **roof** of her apartment building to have sex, then she wants me to _pee_ all over her after I _climax_. She's crazy, but I love her! (Note: I use "pee" for the "flag" primitive).
column8: 4) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 4-3-2007(40): See [room](../v4/754.html) (#754 室). Room is _roof_ \+ _walls_ \+ _soil_ (floor). Here **roof** is marked by _flag_ to indicate what is being singled out in this kanji.
column9: 5) [[elmaestrokgb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elmaestrokgb)] 10-6-2009(14): In the _climax_ of Rush Hour, Jackie Chan slides down a giant _flag_ (a kanji flag, no less) from the **roof**.

column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 2-10-2007(246): Fingers **grip** ping the roof as your about to fall to your death. Think of an action scene in some movie.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 23-8-2007(69): (This is the にぎ of sushi). A sushi chef _climaxes_ into a rice ball, wraps it in an _American flag_ , and **grips** is firm with his _fingers_ to form the "Fuck You America Onigiri.".
column7: 3) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 7-8-2007(47): During a game of 'Capture the Flag': at the climax of the game the red team moves forward, **grip** ping the flag tighly in their fingers.
column8: 4) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 3-12-2007(18): [Image: tires **grip** ping the road] I get this confused with [grasp](../v4/1752.html) (#1752 把). To avoid confusion, I imagine a person sliding down a roof. They try to hold on but their _fingers_ keep slipping because they have no **grip** (friction).
column9: 5) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 31-7-2008(15): Remember the kinky couple from [roof](../v4/1058.html) (#1058 屋)? They better have a good **grip** on their _fingers_ , lest fall off the _roof_.

column5: 1) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 29-4-2007(284): When **yield** ing, soldiers raise the white _flag_ before _exiting_ from the trenches.
column6: 2) [[broderickjeff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/broderickjeff)] 5-1-2007(71): If you live in Japan, you are only too familiar with the helpful little man who assists you in getting out of every parking lot or parking garage, standing at the exit, waving his flag to make traffic **yield** to you.
column7: 3) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 4-4-2008(26): The yellow flag at the exit indicates one should **yield** to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
column8: 4) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 30-12-2008(17): When you **YIELD** in a battle, you raise the FLAG of surrender then EXIT the battlefield.
column9: 5) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 13-5-2008(10): Nobody ever **yield** s to oncoming traffic like they're supposed to, so they're trying to make a new law. If you don't **yield** , a cop will pull you over, make you _exit_ your car, and _pee_ all over you. (Note: I use "pee" for the "flag" primitive).

column5: 1) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 4-3-2007(210): If you **dig** with your _fingers_ hard enough, soil eventually _yields_.
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 10-12-2005(52): When you **dig** , you'd better hope that whatever you're **dig** ging into _yields_ to your _fingers_. If not, you're bound to lose some nails.
column7: 3) [[b0ng0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/b0ng0)] 28-1-2009(47): When you _yield_ in battle, the enemy will often take you prisoner to execute you. While you are waiting, try to use your _fingers_ to **dig** a tunnel out of their prison!
column8: 4) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 1-7-2008(25): In contrast to the soldiers who _yield_ ed, exiting with the white flag in the previous frame, these soldiers refused to _yield_. In fact, they gave the enemy the _finger_. They **dug** a tunnel under enemy lines and took them by surprise from behind. From tritonxg: 掘り井戸 【ほりいど】well 掘進 【くっしん】tunnel 発掘 【はっくつ】discover 採掘 【さいくつ】 mining 掘り出し物 【ほりだしもの】good bargain, rare find 掘り返す 【ほりかえす】rake up, dredge up.
column9: 5) [[stupiddog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stupiddog)] 5-9-2009(12): Not obeying the Geneva convention, the millitary junta did not leave the soldiers who _yield_ ed alive - they forced them to **dig** their own graves with the _fingers_ before getting executed.

column5: 1) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 6-3-2007(219): (See [dig](../v4/1061.html) (#1061 掘)). When _soil_ finally _yielded_ thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a **ditch**.
column6: 2) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 30-12-2006(49): **Ditch** / trench. The _yielding_ army abandons it's patch of _soil_ , leaving behind a landscape of **ditchs** and trenches. Trench warfare.
column7: 3) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 27-1-2007(26): Trench warfare in WWI: both sides dug **ditch** es in the soil, and refused to yield to the other side.
column8: 4) [[nakome](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nakome)] 30-3-2008(14): When you **ditch** someone you are treating them like _dirt_ because you refuse to _yield_ to their shit.
column9: 5) [[tritonxg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tritonxg)] 20-4-2010(5): [FR]fossé japlt:N1 **hori** kanji &kana:1804 _monticule+se courber(fesses+sortir)_ un FOSSé en coupe transversale c'est deux MONTICULES qui SE COURBENT en creux au milieu 堀 【ほり】moat,canal 堀割 【ほりわり】canal,ditch 堀江 【ほりえ】canal 堀川 【ほりかわ】canal 堀端 【ほりばた】side of a moat 外堀 【そとぼり】outer moat (castle) 内堀 【うちぼり】inner moat 釣り堀 【つりぼり】) fish pond.
