column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 23-8-2007(178): A humongous _American flag_ in Florida marks the place where all the _old_ people **reside**.
column6: 2) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 16-9-2007(131): It is an _old_ tradition that people plant a _flag_ on places where decide to **reside** , this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. [set](../v4/1064.html) (#1064 据).
column7: 3) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 27-6-2006(63): Protocol dictates that when the the Queen of England **reside** s at Buckingham Palace they fly the the Union Jack. So, when the _flag_ is flying over the palace you know the _old_ bitch is in.
column8: 4) [[Haych](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Haych)] 25-10-2008(27): The old war veteran **reside** s here. You can tell because hes always proudly flying the flag which he fought for.

column7: 3) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 5-5-2008(93): _Formerly_ , in Japan, each social **stratum** had to wear specific types of clothes to _flag_ their social class and caste. Of course, these days Japanese society isn't so regimented anymore.

column3: The key word **shaku** has actually come into English in the word _**shaku** hachi_, the ancient Japanese flute that measured "one **shaku** and eight _sun_ " (the "sun" being about an inch in length). Since the **shaku** is about one foot in length, this makes about 20 inches. Let the final sweeping stroke be like a tape measure added to the _flag_.
column4: * As a primitive, this will mean the _shakuhachi_ flute.
column5: 1) [[jwy2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jwy2k2)] 6-5-2007(194): Slang for blowjob and that's priceless for stories…but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length.

column5: 1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 10-12-2005(272): Traditional Japanese storefront **door** s have several _flags_ , known as "noren," hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 30-12-2006(37): A Japanese **door** has a noren, a _flag_ hanging from a _rod_. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered **door** ).

column3: The key word signals a "coming back" or return to some place or activity. Its elements: _door_ . . . _St. Bernard dog_.
column5: 1) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 11-7-2006(222): The _St. Bernard dog_ whining at the _door_ of his master’s house in order to **re-** enter / **re-** turn inside.
column6: 2) [[thermal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thermal)] 16-6-2008(140): This is common with cats, but also happens with dogs. They go out the door. 5 minutes later they change their minds and come back in. They **re-** go out the door. They **re-** come back in. They **re-** go out the door. They **re-** come back in. They **re-** go out the door. They **re-** come back in. They **re-** go out the door. They **re-** come back in. They **re-** go out the door. They **re-** come back in. They **re-** go out the door. They **re-** come back in. They **re-** go out the door. AAAAAARRRRRGGGHHHH!!!
column7: 3) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 16-11-2007(78): Think about hachiko, the _dog_ waiting at the _door_ of the station, waiting for his master to _re-_ turn.
column8: 4) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 16-9-2008(25): This story can help you remember this Kanji as well as the next frame [tears](../v4/1082.html) (#1082 涙). When the _lost dog_ **re-** turned to his master's _doorstep_ , the two **re-** joiced at their happy **re-** union.
column9: 5) [[unauthorized](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/unauthorized)] 12-11-2009(17): Hint: This is the kanji used in the verb 戻る [もどる] which means "to return, to turn back". I suggest using "turn back" as keyword, which is far easier to remember compared to the abstract "re-". Do not confuse with [return](../v4/725.html) (#725 返) which has the meaning of the verb かえる - to return, to come back.

column5: 1) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 27-7-2007(228): I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 28-3-2007(147): **Tears** are watery ( _water_ \+ _re_ ).
column7: 3) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 4-6-2006(35): When my dog (who was about as big as a _St. Bernard_ ) got quite old, he had to be put down. The last thing that I saw was him lying on the table staring at me before the vet shut the _door_. The way he looked at me, I swear he knew that his time was over. Dogs don't shed **tears** but if he could have I think he would have at that time.
column8: 4) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 16-9-2008(31): The master shed **tears** of joy when his lost dog returned to his doorstep. (See [re-](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1081) (#1081 戻)).
column9: 5) [[kalin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kalin)] 16-9-2008(25): Futurama: Fry's dog, Seymour, waiting for him outside the pizza shop. T_T.

column3: _Door_ . . . _turkey_. Be sure to keep distinct from both _employee_ (Frame 59) and _use_ (Frame 1065).
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 31-8-2007(402): Our company has no standards. We'll **employ** any _turkey_ who walks in the _door_.
column6: 2) [[kazelee](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kazelee)] 4-8-2008(35): Comedy. An executive is having an argument with a cocky, but skilled, **employ** ee: "Damn it, you might be good. But that don't account for your behavior. You keep this up and I'll fire your ass." "No, you won't." "What damn it, I'll fire you your ass so fast you won't…know…"-. "And what will you do after you fire me, **employ** the next turkey that walks through that door?" A turkey then walks through the door and hands the Exec his resume. –"The Exec **employ** s the turkey that walked through the door".
column7: 3) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 1-12-2008(29): "Sorry," says a store manager, "We don't **employ** Turkeys here." He then points to the door. The disappointed turkey hangs his head low and walks out.
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 26-5-2007(8): It is the last straw…we shall _employ_ the ultimate weapon! Open the hangar _doors_ and unleash the _turkeys_!
column9: 5) [[tritonxg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tritonxg)] 17-2-2010(5): [FR] **employer** N2 **KO yato(u)** k &k1553 _porte+dinde_ **employée secretasse :** on EMPLOIE pour l'accueil près de la PORTE d'entrée, de jeunes DINDES 雇い主 【やといぬし】employeur 雇い人 【やといにん】employee 雇用創出 【こようそうしゅつ】job creation 臨時雇い 【りんじやとい】temporary **employ** ment 終身雇用制 【しゅうしんこようせい】emploi à vie 常雇い 【じょうやとい】regular **employ** ee 日雇い 【ひやとい】daily **employ** ment.

column5: 1) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 19-7-2007(279): I was EMPLOYED to give HEAD…when I **look back** , maybe that was not a wise career move.
column6: 2) [[PacifistGod](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PacifistGod)] 13-4-2007(138): The people we employ are always turning their heads to **look back**. They don't want to be caught playing solitare on company time.
column7: 3) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 20-12-2007(70): It's sad to see the _turkeys_ **look back** one last time before entering the _door_ of the slaughterhouse and losing their _heads_.
column8: 4) [[myglagata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/myglagata)] 15-1-2009(33): Think "Spirited Away". Chihiro is told not to **LOOK BACK** at the magical bathhouse, else she will revert to the EMPLOY of the witch with an enormous HEAD.
column9: 5) [[Lutzos](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lutzos)] 2-11-2009(19): Looking back, employing that turkey was our smartest move in ages. It became head of the company in no time!

column5: 1) [[bluestocking](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bluestocking)] 18-9-2007(335): Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and **DISCLOSE** information.
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 19-6-2007(62): You signed a non- **disclosure** agreement with the _taskmaster_ but you opened your mouth as soon as you got out the _door_!
column7: 3) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 29-12-2007(31): It's best not to **disclose** what you were forced to do with your _mouth_ behind closed _doors_ for your _taskmaster_.
column8: 4) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 3-4-2010(15): Before they go out of the _door_ , the _taskmaster_ makes everyone sign non- **disclosure** forms to keep on top of the possibility that they might open their _mouths_.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 18-10-2005(11): A closed _door_ refuses to **disclose** (dis-close) whatever is happening behind, so someone asked the _taskmistress_ to whip the _door_ , and force it to reveal/disclose what is going on behind. The _door_ gives up (who can resist the _taskmistress_ , hehe) and **disclose** s the information by way of a _mouth_ that appears, just like that (even in imaginary world, doors need a _mouth_ to talk).

column3: Although the elements _two_ and _little_ are available for the using, it may be easier to remember this character as a picture of an altar. Something placed atop the altar is put on **show** for all to see.
column4: * As a primitive, this kanji means _altar_. At the left, the abbreviated form that this element takes is made by chopping the _altar_ in half and leaving only one dot behind to represent the right side. The new appearance of this primitive form, ネ, should be kept distinct from that for _cloak_ , identical except for the one final short stroke.
column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 26-5-2007(203): A boy made an _altar_ , but he's afraid to **show** it to God because he thinks it's _two little_.
column6: 2) [[BigAmish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BigAmish)] 15-8-2008(86): "I'll **SHOW** you mine if you **show** me yours!", she said. I did  & she scoffed because it was _TWO LITTLE_.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 8-3-2007(44): I give this form a primitive of _EVIL ALTAR_. Imagine a black stone altar used for satanic rituals. I give the left radical form a primitive of _CHURCH ALTAR_. Imagine a beautiful cathedral altar.
column8: 4) [[Hyreia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hyreia)] 23-3-2009(35): Unrelated: Frankly, I found Chapter 30 BORING. (I guess I was spoiled with Mr. T.) To jazz up the excitement, this ENTIRE chapter is all about one very crazy religion that exists today (in your imagination). What are the specifics? That's for you to find out. The clues? The next 39 kanji. Just look at some of the keywords: Altar, oil, sleeve, collar, speakth, naked!!! Be sure to give altar it's own meaning inside the cult you're creating.
column9: 5) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 20-5-2009(7): A picture of an altar. _Two small things_ are placed on it to **show** them off (I imagine two watches covered in diamonds).

column3: This key word refers to the polite bows and ceremonious forms of **salutation** so important in Japanese culture. Its elements: _altar_ . . . _fishhook_.
column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 24-8-2006(213): "Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the **altar** and do not give the proper _salutation_ a large **fishhook** will rip you away".
column6: 2) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 15-9-2007(103): You should _fish hook_ (bend/bow) your body before an _altar_ as a form of **salutation** to God/gods.
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-10-2007(54): **SALUTATION** (a hand salute in this case) was given to the ALTAR by a veteran with a HOOK for his hand. Just keep that mental picture and you own this kanji.
column8: 4) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 21-7-2008(20): This cult has a really dumb **salutation**. They form sort of a _'fishhook'_ on their foreheads with their thumb and index finger. They do it whenever they come near the _altar_. They say it's 'L' for 'Luck', I say it's 'L' for 'Losers'.
column9: 5) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 19-6-2007(11): Salute the church _altar_ with a bow (bend yourself like a _fishhook_ ).

column5: 1) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 13-9-2006(189): Bringing a _sheep_ to sacrifice on the _altar_ was a sign of an **auspicious** life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more **auspicious** an expensive _sheep_ for an offering.
column6: 2) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 24-5-2007(73): On this **ewe-spicious** occasion, you sacrifice a _sheep_ at the _altar_. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. Sometimes an egregious pun is the only way.
column7: 3) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 16-3-2007(57): Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. If the gods are pleased, they send down a _sheep_ to the _altar_. The people see this as an **auspicious** gift, the wool and milk from this sheep is considered holy. But the gods think of it as a witty joke, since it's just a metaphor for the people following ancient rituals like blind sheep. Continued in [calamity](../v4/1291.html) (#1291 禍).
column8: 4) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 13-2-2008(29): It's an **auspicious** sign when you go to the _altar_ and the _sheep_ is already beside it, ready to go.
column9: 5) [[cbogart](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cbogart)] 18-1-2007(23): **Auspicious** (adj): contraction of "Australia" and "delicious", a sheep is placed on an "australian altar", or "barbie", on an **auspicious** occasion to celebrate.

column5: 1) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 2-8-2008(218): When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the _altar_ at their local shrine and **celebrate** no longer being a _teenager_.
column6: 2) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 19-11-2006(134): It's a Bar Mitzvah. At the _altar_ , the _teenager_ is singing in his awful, mid-puberty voice. We'll all **celebrate** when that part is over!
column7: 3) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 19-6-2007(22): _Teenagers_ **celebrating** at the church _altar_. (Maybe they just finished RTK).
column8: 4) [[joxn_costello](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joxn_costello)] 3-1-2009(15): This _teenager_ is at the _altar_ , about to **celebrate** the sacrament of Confirmation.
column9: 5) [[sir_sanuk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sir_sanuk)] 9-1-2011(13): Coming of Age Day ( 成人の日 , seijin no hi) is a Japanese holiday held annually on the second Monday of January to **celebrate** those who have turned 20 years old. In this kanji we see someone going to the _altar_ to **celebrate** no longer being a _teenager_.

column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 15-1-2007(224): This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave _wealth_ to the _altar_ (i.e. priest) and received a _blessing_. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation ( _wealth_ ) that is expected when you're called to the ark ( _altar_ in the kanji) to give a **blessing** over the torah.
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 19-6-2007(78): Put all your _wealth_ on the church _altar_ and receive one **blessing**. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.).
column7: 3) [[akaiYaMa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akaiYaMa)] 10-3-2009(52): Wow, this is Scientology put into a kanji. In the Scientology faith the _wealthiest_ members have the highest status in the Church. So basically, the _wealthiest_ person that puts the most money on the _alter_ receives the most **blessing** s….(not really, from what I've heard, the more money you give the better parking spot you get….).
column8: 4) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 8-9-2008(16): When you pray at the _altar_ be sure to count your _wealth_ as a **blessing**.
column9: 5) [[kadano](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kadano)] 20-4-2009(11): This illustrates the idea of tithing… thankful for God's **blessing** s, you give back a tenth of the _wealth_ He has given you at the _altar_.

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 11-9-2007(184): And in front of every _altar_ , she _stopped_ to pray for the **welfare** of the others.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 7-3-2007(161): Religious Republicans regularly go to the _altar_ to pray for a _stop_ to **welfare**.
column7: 3) [[jimsublimeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jimsublimeman)] 6-5-2008(74): I pray at the _altar_ everyday that they don't _stop_ my **welfare** checks. (A quick mnemonic is better for this one).
column8: 4) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 2-7-2008(37): Marxist belief: To improve general **welfare** , the influence of the _altar_ must be _stop_ ped. Maybe the Marxists had a point…. (Mnemonic: **Welfare** = _Stop_ the _altar_ ) 福祉 (ふくし): **welfare**.
column9: 5) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 29-12-2007(19): I remember this one with a political idea … don't read if you're easily offended. Ironically, many of the people on **Welfare** in the USA are the super-religious type (the sort that regularly visit their respective _altars_ ) in the American South, and tend to all have that infamous _"Footprints"_ poem (where God carries you across the beach) hanging in their living rooms. These people tend to vote conservatively (politicians that oppose federal **welfare** ), and thus … against their own best interests.

column3: _Altar_ . . . _soil_. The **company** referred to here is that of the modern business world.
column5: 1) [[mfistik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mfistik)] 6-8-2007(304): When you enter a Japanese **company** it's like you join a cult… your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.
column6: 2) [[Delina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Delina)] 13-6-2008(54): Some Japanese **companies** , including Toyota, have a Shinto _shrine_ on their _grounds_ to bring luck and prosperity to the **company** and its employees.
column7: 3) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 17-6-2006(39): If a **company** is built on _land_ near the _altar_ , it is believed that it will become successful.
column8: 4) [[endote](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/endote)] 30-11-2010(33): The Japanese treat their **company** like a shrine and the **company** treat them like dirt.
column9: 5) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 15-11-2008(14): An _altar_ was bulldozed and filled with _soil_ as the foundation for a new **company** building.

column5: 1) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 27-2-2006(168): The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be **inspection** approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the _altar_ a "visual once over" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?).
column6: 2) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 2-9-2006(105): [inspection, regard as, see, look at] **Inspection** : you 示 [show](../v4/1086.html) (#1086 示) and someone else 見 [see](../v4/57.html) (#57 見).
column7: 3) [[phauna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phauna)] 13-2-2008(71): (Thanks to Ricardo) There's an **inspection** in the church. You _show_ the altar, and the inspector _sees_ if it's okay or not.
column8: 4) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 19-11-2008(23): At the _altar_ , god _looks_ at you, in an **inspection** of your soul.
column9: 5) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 27-2-2006(14): The stone cutter inspects the altars with his keen eyesight for details. The surface must be smooth as ice, not a blemish must be seen. Very well, let me see the next stone altar.

column3: We choose the city of **Nara** as the key word in this case because this kanji, frequently used in proper names, appears in **Nara** , and also because of **Nara's** famed religious monuments, which help us with the primitives: _St. Bernard dog_ . . . _altar_.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-2-2007(219): It's beautiful place, but the dark side of **Nara** is that they sacrifice _St. Bernards_ on _evil altars_ every night after the tourists leave!
column6: 2) [[ezmoreldo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ezmoreldo)] 3-4-2008(129): **Nara** is just a _big_ _show_ for tourists.
column7: 3) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 17-5-2006(65): There is a BIG ALTAR in **NARA**. (really! :-) ).
column8: 4) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 8-8-2007(25): **Nara** is famous for its deers running freely everywhere. To avoid any accidents, Shepperd dogs are put on to the temple's altars to stop the deer from entering the temples.
column9: 5) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 13-5-2008(15): Toudaiji Temple in **Nara** is one heck of a _big altar_.

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 11-9-2007(189): Of course it had to be the **military officer** 's idea to _glue_ a _national flag_ to the _altar_ he's stationed at.
column6: 2) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 21-2-2006(81): Perhaps you have heard about Koizumis controversial visits at the Yasukuni war memorial shrine. It is the japanese flag waving above a small stone altar. A **military officer** keeps watch here night and day, to honor the dead war heroes, as if he is glued to the ground.
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 7-10-2007(27): Only way I remember this is think of a **MILITARY OFFICER** standing next to a FLAG draped ALTAR (well, the coffin is by the altar) as if GLUED to it. Might hurt if you think that GLUED primitive looks like the **MILITARY OFFICER** is saluting the FLAG draped ALTAR, with a slight tear coming from the eye.
column8: 4) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 6-3-2008(22): **Military officer** s glue their flags to the altars of the countries they've conquered.
column9: 5) [[KristinHolly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/KristinHolly)] 5-9-2008(17): The **military officer** is even patriotic when he watches tv. Whenever there's a _flag_ on the _show_ , he's just _glue_ d to the set.

column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 27-5-2007(287): A _military officer_ must offer **consolation** to the _hearts_ of the families of his fallen men.
column6: 2) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 8-9-2008(107): This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II "comfort women" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing **consolation** to battle-weary, _heartsick military officers and soldiers_ , the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.).
column7: 3) [[shakkun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shakkun)] 14-6-2008(39): The MILITARY OFFICER is given a Purple HEART by the army as **consolation** for the wounds he received in the line of duty.
column8: 4) [[hunchbag](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hunchbag)] 19-11-2009(33): The _military officer_ consoles the parents: "Well, your son did not win the war. He died. But, as a **consolation** prize, you get his _heart_!" TA-DAAA!! "Thanks for playing, folks!" (cue screaming).
column9: 5) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 17-12-2007(12): "My time in the army was complete misery." - "Well if it's any **consolation** that bastard _military officer_ had a _heart_ attack.".

column5: 1) [[ovioprime](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ovioprime)] 29-5-2007(226): Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about **goodwill**. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight!
column6: 2) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 21-8-2008(96): A _samurai_ 's _show_ of **goodwill** is never _lacking_.
column7: 3) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 27-2-2006(75): For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The _samurai_ kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his _goodwill_ benefits everyone. No beheadings.
column8: 4) [[subhuman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/subhuman)] 11-1-2008(24): **Goodwill** is something that _samurais_ _show_ and other warriors just _lack_.
column9: 5) [[Deborah](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Deborah)] 14-1-2008(21): **Goodwill** Hunting, the Japanese version. Will is played by Toshio Mifune, a former _SAMURAI_ who dreams of attending MIT. However he _LACKS_ confidence and instead works polishing _ALTARS_ at a nearby temple.

column5: 1) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 26-9-2007(224): Similar to radical tyro's story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably "no smoking" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a **prohibition** of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will).
column6: 2) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 7-8-2007(37): Hidden in a _grove_ was a church with a secret _altar_ that was stocked full of **prohibited** alcohol during the American **prohibition** period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this _altar_ so he could stock **prohibited** alcohol "for sacremental purposes" and share it with his _kin_ (きん).
column7: 3) [[genbaku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/genbaku)] 13-1-2008(25): Placing trees on this alter is prohibited.
column8: 4) [[Antunes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Antunes)] 21-12-2006(21): When Chirstianity was prohibited and the christians were being chased in Japan they had to hide their altars under the groves.
column9: 5) [[harusame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harusame)] 29-5-2009(12): During **prohibition** , people drank hidden in _groves_ so that they wouldn't be _shown_ drinking in public.

column5: 1) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 22-8-2006(170): A **collar** is the part of your _cloak_ that, if tightened too tight, will _prohibit_ breathing.
column6: 2) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 16-9-2007(115): **Collar** s are _prohibited_ from wizarding _cloaks_. Blood purists say they're too muggle.
column7: 3) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 24-11-2007(67): Dress code: all _cloaks_ without **collar** s are _prohibited_.
column8: 4) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 15-8-2008(40): In some future anti-Catholic dystopia, a _prohibition_ against **collars** has been enacted, so Catholic priests often conceal them (or _cloak_ them) underneath their _cloaks_. Imagine a cloaked Catholic priest walking down the street when he sees a police officer approaching him, and the priest nervously tightens his _cloak_ to ensure his **collar** isn't seen.
column9: 5) [[nebusoku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nebusoku)] 18-8-2009(23): Popping the **collar** on any _cloak_ is strictly _prohibited_ because doing so will make you look like an enormous douchebag. _Fun fact_ : the phrase "pop [one's] **collar** " is [「襟を立てる」](midori://search?text=「襟を立てる」) in Japanese.

column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 9-9-2007(173): I never really did figure out what **religion** my host family was - all I knew was that they kept an _altar_ in their _home_.
column6: 2) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 30-1-2008(108): All the **RELIGION** S have their own temples, which are **houses** where they place their **altars**.
column7: 3) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 15-1-2007(33): You can discover a japanese family **religion** by observing their _house altar_.
column8: 4) [[zanzibar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zanzibar)] 12-8-2009(26): We have an altar in our HOUSE to SHOW our **religion**.
column9: 5) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 21-1-2009(16): A _house_ with an _altar_? Perhaps they practice a **religion**.

column5: 1) [[Rakushun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rakushun)] 4-9-2007(236): In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to **adore** the gods who live on Mount Olympus.
column6: 2) [[Shizuru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shizuru)] 21-8-2007(143): I would **adore** the religious people if they just went and threw themselves off a mountain top.
column7: 3) [[Hawkeye123](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hawkeye123)] 6-2-2009(99): Several kanji become their 'greater' version when you add 山 on top ( 風 becomes 嵐 , 石 becomes 岩 ). Thus, _religion_ becomes **adoration**.
column8: 4) [[desmidus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/desmidus)] 16-2-2008(82): The annoying woman from Los Angeles says "oh I absolutely **adore** those cute little mountain religions, like tibetan buddhism, they shave their cute little heads and wear those bright pretty robes, so adorable.".
column9: 5) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 26-8-2008(20): I **adore** _mountains_ over _religion_.

column3: _Flesh_ . . . _crotch_ . . . _altar_. Note how the second element is cut short, giving a tent-like effect to the character.
column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 8-8-2007(404): A **ritual** such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 17-4-2007(41): There are many famous penis **matsuri** s(festivals) in Japan. The **ritual** s of these festivals involve placing the _flesh_ of the _crotch_ on an _altar_.
column7: 3) [[TheSlakey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TheSlakey)] 11-12-2008(12): まつり（ 祭り ）Ritual nude dances (nothing but flesh) involving lots of pelvic thrusts before the altars of ancient Japan. Now they're nothing but festivals, but back in the day they were **ritual** s. Most Japanese festivals have a circle dance, just imagine all the old people doing the except same dance but in the buff, wrinkly flesh flapping in the wind and all. Remembered. Unfortunately, perhaps forever.
column8: 4) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-1-2008(12): This kanji is used for **festivals**. [Flesh from one leg … show] I think of those sexy high slit skirts, the ones that let you see the leg of its wearer.
column9: 5) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 30-9-2007(6): The top part of this kanji I memorize as _circumcision_. - - - - - - - – - - - - - - - - - In an ancient **ritual** , people are _shown_ how to _circumsize_ their newborns.

column3: **Guess**  here has the sense of a measured conjecture. Its elements: _house_ . . . _ritual_.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 12-9-2007(130): I have an informed **guess** about whose _house_ the dark _rituals_ are performet at.
column6: 2) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 28-7-2007(72): Police ( 警察 ）drive around a street at night trying to **guess** whose house is having a matsuri indoors after complaints from the neighbours.
column7: 3) [[MethodGT](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MethodGT)] 14-4-2008(51): For our child's circumcision (the _ritual_ ) we invited a rabbi to our _house_. We didn't know it at the time, but he was blind, and he had to **guess** which little squishy thing was the baby's penis.
column8: 4) [[pandawhipped](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pandawhipped)] 10-3-2008(21): The POLICE had enough evidence, so they were able to make an informed **GUESS** as to which HOUSE the dark RITUALS were being performed in.
column9: 5) [[Alunalun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Alunalun)] 20-7-2009(14): In our _house_ we have a _ritual_. When something happens someone says "Guess what happened." We ask for some sort of vague hint, but get "no, go on, **guess**!" Asking what sort of thing it's about, news, music, catastrophe, just gets "no, you have to **guess** ". It takes quite a long time to find out what's happened. It's a very annoying ritual.

column5: 1) [[guidedog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/guidedog)] 14-7-2007(171): If you mis-guess the cheese you'll **grate** your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 8-3-2008(72): Ouch! _Guess_ how many _fingers_ I just **grate** d in the **grate** r? (Edit: OR: Ouch! _Guess_ what I just **grate** d in the **grate** r? – my _finger_!).
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 9-1-2006(52): When you **grate** something you have to _guess_ where your _fingers_ are so you don't hurt yourself.
column8: 4) [[desmidus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/desmidus)] 16-2-2008(50): It was a cruel form of torture. He would **grate** cheese and by the smell make me guess what sort of cheese it was. If my guess was wrong, he would **grate** one of my fingers. Which is how I know how pretty much every cheese smells now, although I don't have many working fingers left.
column9: 5) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 26-2-2009(35): The meaning of this kanji is more like "rub, scour, scratch, or scrape." Story: Frustratedly trying to solve a math equation on the classroom chalkboard, the student made a sound that would really **GRATE** on everyone's nerves. She would **GRATE** her FINGERnails on the chalkboard as she GUESSED at the next step in solving the equation.

column3: The " **wherefore** " of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a _rice field_ sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and **wherefore** of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the _flower_ appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full _seedling_.)
column4: * As a primitive, in conformity to the explanation above, this kanji will be taken to mean _shoot_ or _sprout_.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-11-2007(155): " **Wherefore** art thou, _Sprouteo_?" (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet's dinner plate and rolled off).
column6: 2) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 16-1-2008(152): "Cogito **ergo** sum." **Wherefore** is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it's often mistranslated as "where" when in fact it's an urge to know a cause or reason, and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought _sprouts_ from my _brain_. I think, **therefore** I am.].
column7: 3) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 4-7-2007(37): Errata: Stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. The vertical stroke is #3. (story: dingomick).
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-4-2007(30): " **Wherefore** art thou Romeo?" says Juliet on her balcony as she plucks brussel sprouts instead of rose petals. (This takes on the primitive of the much more memorable _BRUSSEL SPROUT_ ).
column9: 5) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 16-2-2010(18): **Wherefore** art thou, Romeo. He's in the _rice field_. You can see his hair sticking up above the rice. New Primitive: Romeo.

column5: 1) [[Thora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thora)] 8-9-2007(223): [When I see the word **pluck** , I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with [pick](../v4/733.html) (#733 採):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to _sprout_ out of my chin again, I **pluck** it with my _fingers_.
column6: 2) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 25-12-2007(59): If you **pluck** your _fingers_ , new ones will _sprout_ in their place. (try it ,).
column7: 3) [[phauna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phauna)] 14-2-2008(24): If you **pluck** hair from your eyebrows with your _fingers_ , more hair will _sprout_ in it's place.
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 29-12-2012(19): _fingers_ **pluck** a single _sprout_.
column9: 5) [[Samsara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Samsara)] 26-9-2008(13): Every time I see this kanji I think of the snapple commerical: "White tea is a baby tea leaf, and while it still has a naturally light flavor…. we **pluck** it." <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=znAoCGATk8w>.

column5: 1) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 16-1-2007(196): The _liquid_ **oil** that _sprouts_ from an **oil** field.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(65): In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified _Brussel sprouts_ (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the _water_ to suck up **oil** spills.
column7: 3) [[kansaigaijin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kansaigaijin)] 30-7-2009(37): **oil** is the most valuable _liquid_ to _sprout_ from the earth.
column8: 4) [[genbaku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/genbaku)] 14-1-2008(19): When cooking sprouts in water add **oil**.
column9: 5) [[b0ng0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/b0ng0)] 30-1-2009(13): If you squeeze certain _sprouting_ plants, such as rapeseed, _drops_ of liquid will come out. This is the **oil** you use for cooking.

column5: 1) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 16-5-2008(166): The bad magician says, "As you can see, there's nothing up my **sleeve** s!" Then he trips over his _cloak_ and brussel _sprouts_ fall everywhere.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 28-10-2005(111): Imagine some magic _cloak_ , that when worn, has little green _sprouts_ appearing on the sides that grow into **sleeve** s.
column7: 3) [[Asriel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Asriel)] 30-3-2009(71): **Sleeve** s are just what _sprouts_ out of the sides of _garments._ Duh.
column8: 4) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 19-7-2007(23): If it had **sleeve** s, it wouldn't be a _cloak_ , now would it? But if you insist, I suppose I could use my majic to have some **sleeve** s just _sprout_ out from the shoulders. . .
column9: 5) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 23-4-2008(14): What do garments sprout? **Sleeve** s, of course!

column5: 1) [[laxxy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laxxy)] 28-10-2006(329): Jack's beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in **mid-air** suspended on the SPROUT.
column6: 2) [[tcjeff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tcjeff)] 23-6-2008(59): Hahaha, the image of walking into a _house_ and finding a sea of _brussel sprouts_ floating **mid-air** is enough for me to remember. Maybe there's a magician in the kitchen shouting a reassuring "Don't mind the _sprouts_!".
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 9-1-2006(29): This one doesn't help me very much but some of my mates found it helpful: Jack's beanstalk _sprouted_ up, he climbed up it and found a _house_ floating in **mid-air**.
column8: 4) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-4-2007(19): With new _houses_ _sprouting_ up everwhere, **mid-air** collisions are becoming more common as airplanes have to avoid the new structures.
column9: 5) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 10-10-2006(13): A jet fighter has a **mid-air** collision with Jack's house: the _house_ at the top of the bean- _sprout_.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 14-4-2007(341): In the US, when the mail is **deliver** ed, a _flag_ _sprouts_ up on your mailbox. (We don't have that in Australia.).
column6: 2) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 3-4-2010(97): **__Warning: Don't use a mailbox in this story, there's a primitive for that coming soon…__**.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 27-1-2006(70): A Japanese man ordered some Brussel _sprouts_ from Belgium. They are **deliver** ed with a little Belgian _flag_ (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat).
column8: 4) [[burritokun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burritokun)] 15-10-2008(30): Just a note on Raichu's story, it's actually when you have mail _to_ **deliver** that the flag "sprouts" up (i.e. outgoing mail), it's not for incoming mail. The story still works, though..
column9: 5) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 16-5-2008(18): I tried to **deliver** a clear message to my girlfriend that said "I don't like brussel _sprouts_ " by _peeing_ on the bowl of them that she'd just made. (Note: I use "pee" for the "flag" primitive).

column5: 1) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 7-4-2007(186): **Flute** is made of _bamboo_ _sprout_.
column6: 2) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 25-12-2008(126): You pick up your _bamboo_ **flute** , and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a _Brussels sprout_! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A _bamboo_ **flute** that plays _sprouts_! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place.
column7: 3) [[tummai](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tummai)] 21-5-2008(77): Bamboo shoots… make good **flute** s.
column8: 4) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 19-2-2006(18): Our japanese Pied Piper plays his magic **flute** to make the _bamboo sprouts_ grow quicker up, so that he can cut them and craft himself a proper shakuhachi **flute**.
column9: 5) [[desmidus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/desmidus)] 27-2-2008(14): The troublesome boy used his bamboo **flute** in music class as a projectile weapon, firing brussel sprouts at various unsuspecting girls as well as the teacher.

column5: 1) [[kyldyyr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kyldyyr)] 25-11-2005(176): An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a _car_ going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single _sprout_ (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car's wheels, causing the car to fly around its **axis**.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 4-3-2007(130): The Germans manufactured so many _cars_ during World War II that it was almost as if they were _sprouting_ from the factories of the **Axis**.
column7: 3) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 13-12-2007(51): Left side is the car, right side is a zoomed in picture of the car showing the detail of the axle/axis.
column8: 4) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 30-12-2007(27): George W. Bush placed a great deal of Middle Eastern countries in his " **Axis** of Evil" … perhaps because that region is the _sprouting origin_ of what we have to put into our _cars_ (let's bring back the electric car, eh?).
column9: 5) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 23-11-2008(25): James Bond has guns that _sprout_ from the wheel **axes** of his _car_.

column3: This kanji reverses the element for _sprout_ , giving the image of roots being sent down into the earth by a seed planted in the _rice field_. From there you must invent a connection to the keyword, **armor**.
column4: * The primitive meaning is _roots_. Important to that word is the image of  "pushing downwards," as _roots_ do.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 20-1-2006(200): Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai's **armor**. Then I looked up images of the samurai **armor** and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai **armor** because of the "turtle samurai" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess.
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 21-11-2007(156): It looks like a bird's eye view of a tank (modern **armor** ).
column7: 3) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 22-8-2006(60): Pictograph. Kendo visor with chin guard.
column8: 4) [[Wile_e42](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wile_e42)] 17-4-2008(36): Armour weighs you down like you’re rooted to the ground.
column9: 5) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(14): Looks like an **armor** ed helmet. You have the part that protects the _brain_ and a little line beneath that acts as a nose guard.

column5: 1) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 2-10-2007(154): **Push** the _roots_ down, instead of plucking the seedling.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 4-3-2007(100): Use your _fingers_ to make sure the _roots_ of your plant are deep underground by **pushing** them down, down, down.
column7: 3) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 26-12-2007(67): **Push** the button with your _finger_ and get _root_ beer!
column8: 4) [[claxton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/claxton)] 25-7-2008(17): For those who liked the "bird's eye view of the tank" imagine a tank that has its tracks stuck in the sand. The big green machine is extremely hot from the desert sun as well as the heat its engine has created. With that picture in mind, this Kanji depicts what happens next when the soldiers get around the back of the tank and have to **push** it with their fingers because the surface is too hot for them to put their hands on.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 10-5-2008(16): You are wearing your cool new _Ninja Turtles Shell Armour_ and you realize that there's a little button with a _finger_ symbol on it, inviting you to **push** it. You **push** it, and the front wall of the shell **push** es out violently. You've learned a new attack - this isn't just a defense tool anymore, you can now run around and **push** people around for no reason! Cool!

column3: Like the _cape_ (Frame 164) and the _promontory_ (Frame 840), the **headland** refers to a jut of land. Its elements: _mountain_ . . . _roots_.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 10-3-2007(206): A **headland** is a _mountain_ that is firmly _rooted_ despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a **headland**!).
column6: 2) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 21-4-2008(125): **Headland** s are natural forts, in fact, once men build castles on them, they become _armoured mountains_. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an _armoured mountain_ ).
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 10-11-2008(26): A _mountain_ that has been _pushed_ into the sea.
column8: 4) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 7-1-2011(22): The **headland** is _mountain_ ous terrain that provides a natural fortification (or _armour_ ) against sea-borne invasion. 岬 (みさき) : cape (on coast).
column9: 5) [[dilandau23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau23)] 9-1-2007(19): Forget confusing the meanings ( **headland** , [promontory](../v4/778.html) (#778 崎), [cape](../v4/153.html) (#153 埼)) they are synonyms, no way around that. Luckily, all three seem to be used in names most. I used: The **headland** or **head** of the **land** is obviously the part of the land that is placed highest, in the same way our head is highest on the body. _Mountains_ are the **head** s of the **land** s they have planted their _roots_ into.

column3: _Fingers_ . . . _thousand_ . . . _roots_. Observe how the writing order does not follow the elements in order, because the final stroke is used for two different elements.
column5: 1) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 25-9-2006(245): A rice farmer's delicate _fingers_ have **insert** ed _1,000 rooted_ seedlings into his field.
column6: 2) [[Ramchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ramchip)] 28-5-2008(156): Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and _thousand_ of _root_ -like tentacles are **insert** ing themselves in… well, I think you can fill the rest.
column7: 3) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 24-11-2007(47): Before you _push_ the button for the _ginseng root_ tea, you must **insert** _1000_ yen.
column8: 4) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 19-7-2007(20): _Fingers_ , the thief, is trying to get money using my ATM card. After **insert** ing it in the ATM, he tried _1000 times_ to _push_ the right buttons. And got my pin right number on the last try! Notice the long vertical stroke done last!
column9: 5) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 2-8-2008(13): Weird arcade machine this one. Instead of reading "insert coin", it reads " **insert** _1,000 roots_ ". I hope you can play until your _fingers_ get sore, for that price!

column3: The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb "to speak." It is written by a _tongue wagging in the mouth_ with a _walking stick_ rammed through it and coming out at both ends.
column4: * While this kanji has obvious affinities to the "seed" group, it also happens to be the zodiacal sign of the _monkey_ (the one who _speaketh_ no evil, among other things). We shall therefore take _monkey_ as its primitive meaning.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 15-8-2006(181): I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the "s" and **speaketh** like thith becauth they have a _cane_ in their _mouth_.
column6: 2) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 14-2-2008(90): I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 [sayeth](../v4/578.html) (#578 曰). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in "moshi moshi" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say "hello, this is X **speaking**.".
column7: 3) [[mistamark](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mistamark)] 26-10-2008(61): The _cross_ in the _mouth_ of the _Monkey_ ensured it **speaketh** no evil.
column8: 4) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 26-5-2007(21): A MONKEY can't **SPEAKETH** of anything if he has a WALKING STICK driven through his TOUNGE WAGGING IN HIS MOUTH.
column9: 5) [[furrykef](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/furrykef)] 2-7-2008(14): Distinguished from [sayeth](../v4/578.html) (#578 曰) in that we're surprised that the _monkey_ can speak at all: "The monkey **speaketh**!".

column5: 1) [[Akuji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Akuji)] 18-2-2006(146): Here we see Mr. T. **expand** ing his gang with some trained fighter monkeys.
column6: 2) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 17-7-2007(95): Mr. T wants to show you the incredible **expand** ing monkey trick. He grabs a monkey by the tail and neck, stretches him out a few times, then blows him up like a balloon. The monkey **EXPAND** s until it pops. Haha, sucka monkey, I pity you foo.
column7: 3) [[uberstuber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberstuber)] 26-5-2007(53): A _person_ _speaketh_ and **expand** s my knowledge.
column8: 4) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 3-5-2007(38): A _person_ is really just a _monkey_ that has been **expand** ed and stretched out a bit to stand up straight and use speech.
column9: 5) [[BigAmish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BigAmish)] 15-8-2008(20): _Mr. T_ 's waistline is **EXPAND** ing because he has been eating too much "Chunky _MONKEY_ " ice cream!. "I pity the foo that doesn't like Ben & Jerry's ice cream!".

column5: 1) [[Floatingweed5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Floatingweed5)] 10-9-2007(108): The **Gods** are gathered around debating Zeus' latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant "speak no evil" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again .
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 30-12-2006(107): Hinduism has many **gods** , not just one God. One of the most famous of these **gods** is Hanuman the _monkey_. Many _altars_ are dedicated to him.
column7: 3) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 20-6-2007(55): **Gods** are _monkeys_ who sit behind church _altars_.
column8: 4) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 5-1-2009(50): At the alter, you speaketh to the **gods**.
column9: 5) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 28-7-2007(24): God speaketh from behind the altar.

column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 20-6-2007(204): The _monkey_ **search** es around with his _fingers_ for his _crotch_.
column6: 2) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 21-3-2008(80): With its fingers, a monkey **search** es its crotch for bugs to eat.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 21-9-2009(38): If you are familiar with the Monkey legends ( 西遊記 Journey to the West) there is a good image for this character: While **search** ing for the end of the universe, _monkey_ reaches to his _crotch_ and urinates on Buddha's _fingers_. (Update: new link <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RYXFppaKLL4>).
column8: 4) [[ambassadog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ambassadog)] 26-10-2009(23): Heard about the fourth wise _monkey_? Often overlooked after Hear, See and Speak no Evil, he's **Seek** no Evil. Picture the four famous monkeys at Nikko, the fourth covering his _crotch_ with his _fingers_ , showing he won't be **searching** for any evil deeds in that evil place.
column9: 5) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 28-3-2009(18): Watch this VIDEO and you will definitely never forget this kanji. Just ask yourself what the monkey was **search** ing for: [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1ICaFDq8_Ik&feature=related](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1ICaFDq8_Ik&feature=related) (or youtube **search** : "monkey ass").

column3: The final stage of the seed is reached when the plant has reached its full growth (the _tree_ ) and comes to fruition, producing **fruit** full of new seeds that can return to the earth and start the process all over again. The main thing to notice here is the element for _brains_ at the top, which might prove more helpful than _rice field_ for creating an image. The writing, however, follows the order of a _sun_ with a _tree_ whose trunk runs through the _sun_.
column5: 1) [[vionnacrowe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vionnacrowe)] 11-3-2007(259): If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden **fruit** from the tree.
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 24-7-2006(55): There really are _brain_ **fruit** _trees_. See <http://www.dpchallenge.com/image.php?IMAGE_ID=108312>. Enough said.
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 14-1-2006(36): Just a pictogram of a cluster of **fruit** on a tree.
column8: 4) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 17-1-2009(9): **Fruit** is like a productive _rice field_ that grows on top of a _tree_. 悪因悪果 (sewing  & reaping evil). 悪果 (bad results). 無花果果 (fig). 因果 (cause & effect). 規模効果 (economies of scale).
column9: 5) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 20-8-2006(9): Instead of _brains_ use _rice field_ and we see a bunch of _fruit_ trees growing about the perimeter of a _rice field_.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 13-8-2007(218): This candy is made in the shape of a _flower_ , each petal with the taste of a different _fruit_.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 14-1-2006(107): Candy is coloured like flowers and flavoured like fruit.
column7: 3) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 5-2-2008(39): I think of Willy Wonka's factory where the flowers all bear **candy** fruits.
column8: 4) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 18-12-2010(25): Willy Wonka, the **confectionary** wizard, is probably the only man with the _brains_ to develop a _tree_ whose _flowers_ are all **candy**. 菓子 かし pastry, 菓子 みずがし fruit.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 3-9-2008(16): In Japan, **candy** can be flavored like _fruit_ or _flowers_ (e.g. rose-flavored gum).

column5: 1) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 16-5-2008(229): After I finish each **chapter** of RTK, I eat a piece of _fruit_ to celebrate all the new _words_ I've learned. (Thanks Misha!).
column6: 2) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 26-9-2007(135): _Words_ signify the written words in a book. The _fruit_ represents something whole, complete. A **chapter** in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It's good to disambiguate the keyword from [paragraph](../v4/82.html) (#82 項). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each **chapter** of Tolstoy's "War and Peace" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you'd very quickly run out of fruit).
column7: 3) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 12-9-2007(49): The _words_ of each **chapter** bear a different _fruit_.
column8: 4) [[TheSlakey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TheSlakey)] 12-12-2008(38): The first **chapter** of the Bible are _words_ telling the story of _Adam and Eve_ and how they ate the forbidden _fruit_.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 5-10-2007(17): Here we think of the **CHAPTER** of the bible, namely **CHAPTER** three where you hear the lord SAY "Who has eaten of the forbidden FRUIT?" Goes well with the Naked frame that talks of the other forbidden FRUIT.

column5: 1) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 26-4-2007(299): Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were **naked** , and so clothing themselves in a cloak.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 10-3-2007(120): Hey honey, I'm **naked** underneath this _cloak_. I've got some nice _melons_ and a fresh _peach_ waiting for you. Don't you want to taste my forbidden _fruits_ …?
column7: 3) [[jmadsen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jmadsen)] 13-2-2006(29): Eve was **naked** until she ate of the _fruit_ and put a _cloak_ on.
column8: 4) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 14-1-2006(20): A cloak hides the fruit-bearing parts of one's **naked** body.
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 26-10-2012(18): The _cloak_ slipped to her side to reveal her **naked** _fruit_ (don't confuse with [undress](../v4/498.html) (#498 脱)).

column3: This character represents a picture of an **ax** , the two vertical lines being the handle and the horizontal strokes of the blade. Note the writing order carefully.
column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 4-7-2007(178): Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first.
column6: 2) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 16-5-2008(104): The **axe** -wielding maniac _nails_ a poor victim, right under a _cliff_. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!).
column7: 3) [[Ramchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ramchip)] 28-5-2008(41): Warning: unlike the nail primitive, notice that the **axe** does not have a hook on the last stroke.
column8: 4) [[bokuzukuri](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bokuzukuri)] 14-1-2006(21): Pictograph, see book.
column9: 5) [[jinkouchinou](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jinkouchinou)] 9-8-2009(18): The **axe** -wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!). [Shibo] Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first. [radical_tyro] Warning: unlike the nail primitive, notice that the **axe** does not have a hook on the last stroke. [Ramchip] I just wanted to combine these as they were all very helpful. I take no credit for any of them.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 30-12-2006(221): We **chop** down _trees_ with _axes_ to **analyze** their rings.
column6: 2) [[adhmm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adhmm)] 13-11-2007(78): Wood + axe = **chop**? how much more simple can it get?
column7: 3) [[Pauline](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pauline)] 28-6-2006(31): How much _wood_ would a _wood_ chopper **chop** if a _woodchopper_ would **chop** _wood_? (Don't forget to imagine the _ax_ ).
column8: 4) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 7-12-2006(26): This more accurately means "take apart" or "analyse", so I guess, once you **chop** down the tree with an axe, you can analyse its structure.
column9: 5) [[johngwk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johngwk)] 17-7-2011(6): To **chop** the TREE– use an AXE.

column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 11-9-2007(149): You outsiders better learn your **place**! An _axe_ stuck in the _door_ when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best **place** for you.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 23-7-2007(94): A **place** for everything and everything in its **place**. To the right of the _door_ is the standard **place** for the _axe_.
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 5-10-2008(57): When you come over to my **place** , you leave your _axe_ at the _door_!
column8: 4) [[HerrPetersen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/HerrPetersen)] 9-5-2007(41): Platz - The "Shining" (Jack Nicholson hacks the _door_ with an _ax_ ) is not a nice **place** to be.
column9: 5) [[saxman_52](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saxman_52)] 10-6-2009(23): Heeeeeeere's Johnny! Jack Nicholson breaks down a _door_ with his _ax_ in order to get to his wife's hiding **place**.

column5: 1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 14-12-2006(188): Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the _altars_ at the local missions, and if anybody refused to **pray** , they would get the _axe_.
column6: 2) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 23-5-2008(129): A warrior **pray** s for victory before the battle. He kneels at the _altar_ , his battle _axe_ at the ready.
column7: 3) [[fiminor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fiminor)] 30-9-2006(34): When you come to the _altar_ to **pray** , you need to leave your _axe_ to one side. Biblical quote, settle your differences with someone before coming before your god.
column8: 4) [[jwy2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jwy2k2)] 14-5-2007(27): At the altar ax da Lord and **pray** to help ya! Hallelujah!
column9: 5) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 11-4-2007(15): D&D: the religious dwarf **pray** at the _altar_ , with his trusty _axe_ at his side.

column3: _Ax_ . . . _road_. Be careful not to confuse with _draw near_ (Frame 204) or _bystander_ (Frame 1090).
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 30-12-2006(261): The end is **near**. The _axe_ -murderer is waiting for you on the _road_ …
column6: 2) [[zenkun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zenkun)] 13-3-2006(98): An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long _road_. To make A and B **near** , take an _ax_ , cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.
column7: 3) [[javiergakusei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/javiergakusei)] 21-11-2007(60): Hint: Short- cut.
column8: 4) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 14-9-2007(28): An _axe_ left in the middle of the _road_! Dwarves must be **near**!
column9: 5) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 7-6-2008(15): When I think of " **near** ", I always think of that absurd muppet sketch with Grover running back and forth to demonstrate " **near** " and "far". So, I see grover on the _road_ somewhere and I shout to him and ask him if he can show me " **near** ". He runs up to me and shouts " **Near** !"Then I kill him with my _axe_ and sling him over my shoulder. We're having muppet for dinner tonight!Now that you all think I'm insane, you should probably watch this, haha. <http://video.aol.com/video-detail/eating-muppets/3865632416>.

column3: _Fingers_ . . . _ax_. Hint: make an image out of the Japanese art of "origami" (paper- **folding** ).
column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 14-1-2007(243): It's the latest Japanese game show: **Forudo**! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to **fold** it into a complex origami shape. If they're not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in **fold** ing, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off.
column6: 2) [[Piitaa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Piitaa)] 22-6-2006(89): **Fold** some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It's even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!
column7: 3) [[jotun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jotun)] 24-5-2008(45): To hold an _axe_ , you need to **fold** your _fingers_ around the handle.
column8: 4) [[tstuhldreher](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tstuhldreher)] 12-10-2008(31): Japanese **fold** with their _fingers,_ but the creases they make are as sharp as an _axe_.
column9: 5) [[lanval](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lanval)] 9-3-2009(9): I' m so strong, I can **fold** the axe with my fingers (works well for me, just imagine it clearly).

column5: 1) [[ithil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ithil)] 2-11-2006(229): A two-hour lesson of **philosophy** in high school. All the students, bored to death, are _folding_ sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the _mouth_ of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers.
column6: 2) [[jwy2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jwy2k2)] 19-5-2007(88): I fold my mouth, therefore I am.
column7: 3) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 17-11-2007(50): All the **philosophy** that comes out of my _mouth_ I learned from those Chinese fortune cookies with the _folded_ paper inside. 'Confucius say…', et cetera. Come to think of it, the cookie itself looks like a weirdly _folded mouth_.
column8: 4) [[xxinde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xxinde)] 7-5-2010(41): This friend of mine once unknowingly popped the whole fortune cookie into his _mouth_. Then using his _fingers_ he retrieved a _folded_ piece of paper. And it was the only time some **philosophy** came out of his _mouth_.
column9: 5) [[sindhikara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sindhikara)] 3-12-2008(27): Here's a philosophical question: Can you _fold_ a _hole_?

column3: The connotation is of a "dearly **departed** " who has passed away. The elements: _fold_ . . . _road_.
column5: 1) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 11-4-2007(383): One of the dearest of Japan's dearly **departed** is Sasaki Sadako, who developed Leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, and became famous for _folding_ more than a thousand paper cranes, never giving up hope. To this day, people in Hiroshima still _fold_ origami cranes in her memory. For this character, let us imagine a parade in her honor, the entire _road_ lined with _folded_ cranes.
column6: 2) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 20-1-2008(46): The BIG ONE hits Tokyo. You see a news report of the recently **departed** victims who died when the _roads_ _folded_ (from the earthquake).
column7: 3) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 14-9-2007(26): The **departed** are those who have crossed that _fold_ you cannot see past in the _road_ we all walk.
column8: 4) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 14-3-2008(23): In the film The **Departed** a guy falls out of the window and ends up _folded_ double on the _road_ below.
column9: 5) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 21-8-2006(16): Picture the funeral procession of a great head of state (i.e. JFK) a dearly **departed** loved one to a nation. See his coffin drapped with the _folded_ American flag as it is moved through the _roads_ and streets of our nation's Capitol.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 21-10-2005(240): This Japanese couple wrote the **vow** s that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then _folded it into an origami_ , and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an _origami_ , but to them it is also a symbol of their **vow** s. – "the _folded words_ are **vow** s". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an _origami_ for the primitive " _fold_ ".
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 19-12-2007(81): A Japanese wedding tradition is to present each other with _origami cranes_ with their **vows** _written_ on the BOTTOM.
column7: 3) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 11-2-2009(50): Sadako Sasaki **vow** ed to _fold_ 1000 paper cranes and kept her _word_. (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sadako_Sasaki>).
column8: 4) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 18-2-2008(15): If you're a sci-fi/fantasy reader –> The Aes Sedai of Robert Jordan's "The Wheel of Time" series were famously forced to take three **vow** s, one of which was to never lie. This was next to pointless, however, as the old broads easily got around it by being so skilled at _folding_ their _words_ that while they never TECHNICALLY lied … the absolute truth that they spoke was still highly deceptive.
column9: 5) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 21-6-2007(13): After cutting himself badly, _Socrates_ **vow** ed never to _fold_ origami again.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 12-10-2008(114): I wanted a convertible so I **chopped off** the top of my _car_ with an _axe_.
column6: 2) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 30-9-2007(43): A "chop shop" is a place where stolen _cars_ are taken, and parts **chopped off** with an _axe_ , to be sold.
column7: 3) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 24-11-2008(23): Picture a death-mobile car with rotating axes on the hood that drives by and chops off people's heads. [beheading is another common meaning].
column8: 4) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 23-5-2008(4): Seen before in "Steadily" and "Temporarily". Both stories talked about taking an AXE to a CAR. Here, either take the horror movie approach where a driver in a CAR had his head CHOPPED OFF by a maniac with an AXE, or take the **CHOP OFF** shop approach where a guy is cutting up a CAR with an AXE.
column9: 5) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 17-2-2007(3): In movies _cars_ often have their tops **chopped off** as if with an _axe_.

column5: 1) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 30-1-2006(219): Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are **temporarily** without car.
column6: 2) [[jotun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jotun)] 24-5-2008(107): Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can **temporarily** (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.
column7: 3) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 1-5-2009(27): The top kanji is [chop off](../v4/2092.html) (#2092 斬).
column8: 4) [[tenken3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tenken3)] 17-5-2007(21): Axe murderer hiding in a car **temporarily** for a few days after killing someone.
column9: 5) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-1-2008(15): [[chop off](../v4/2092.html) (#2092 斬) … day] During daylight saving time, we **temporarily** _chop off_ the _day_ by taking an hour out of it, which we will return back in six months.

column5: 1) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 29-12-2006(229): I imagine firemen working **steadily** to rescue a man from a crashed _car_. First, they spray it with _water_ , then, they use an _axe_ to break through the window.
column6: 2) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 7-8-2008(111): Water + Car + Axe: The **steadily** rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out.
column7: 3) [[Kieron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kieron)] 1-2-2008(53): _Dripping water_ on your _car_ **steadily** builds up rust. Over time, it's just as damaging as taking an _ax_ to it.
column8: 4) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 10-7-2007(15): Driving **steadily** down the road in the _wet_ in a [chop off](../v4/2092.html) (#2092 斬) convertible. Singing in the rain.
column9: 5) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 1-1-2008(12): The attempt to fix the _car_ 's radiator with an _axe_ did not go well. There was a steady drip drip drip of _water_.

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 14-9-2007(244): [Based on fuaburisu's] A man puts some _rice_ on a _fishhook_ as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his _axe_ and **sever** the line lest he be dragged into the depths.
column6: 2) [[marydj](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/marydj)] 25-10-2007(117): When you get the ax at work, use your **severance** pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 17-5-2006(59): The _axe man_ is fishing at a nearby river, using a _rice-ball on a hook_ as bait. He catches some real big fish, which is pulling so hard on the line that _axe man_ has to **sever** the line or let go of his pricey fishing rod. And at the same time there is the idea of **severance** in _axe man_ having to let go of his big catch.
column8: 4) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 28-3-2012(53): Your manager brings you into his office and offers you three **severance** packages. You can take the _hook_ (become a fisherman), take the _rice_ (become a farmer), or take the _axe_ (become a lumberjack). Picture the items laid out on his desk like the shopkeepers in Zelda.
column9: 5) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 6-10-2008(23): After he got _hooked_ on _rice_ wine the Japanese salaryman got the _axe_ at work. Now all he has to live on is serverance pay.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-2-2007(243): What is this **substance** on this _clam_? I've already broken 2 _axes_ on it! (Good **question** … 質問 ).
column6: 2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 5-1-2008(85): Another keyword that I do not like by Heisig. 質 【しつ】 (n,n-suf) quality. Story: Your at a local ax dealer and you have TWO AXES which you are testing for QUALITY by trying to split CLAMS right down the opening. Picture yourself succeeding with one AX and then some weird **SUBSTANCE** comes out of the shell…eww (I don't like clams).
column7: 3) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 1-10-2007(48): [seems to mean "substance" in the sense of essential nature or core quality, most common usage might be 質問 , shitsumon (inquiry)] a pair of scientists are smashing away at a mysterious **shell** with **axes** , pounding it into powder so they can feed it into their analysis machine and discover exactly what **substance** it's made up of.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 20-3-2008(26): This guy dealing in illegal **substance** s makes a lot of _shells_ (money), but he's always equipped with his _dual-axe_ … it's a dangerous job.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 11-9-2007(14): The newest illegal **substance** on the streets is Shellinium. It's made of _shells_ hacked to bits with _axes_. Imagine going to your local dealer to get it - you've got to get past a huge _shell_ mafia goon who is holding two _axes_ …

column5: 1) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 17-5-2008(246): The kids at school used to **reject** me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my _axe_ to school. See the _drop_ of blood on it?
column6: 2) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 3-9-2007(114): The quality expectations are very high in our _axe_ manufacturing facility. If there's one _drop_ of rust on any axe, it gets **reject** ed.
column7: 3) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 11-4-2007(64): Gimli **REJECT** S an AX because it has a DROP of blood on it. Obviously the "soul" of the ax is not pure so he must **REJECT** IT.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 4-1-2009(35): This _axe_ is a **reject** from the _axe_ factory : a _drop_ of red paint got onto the handle, which looks like a drop of blood. It freaks out customers, so it doesn't make it to the shops.
column9: 5) [[nadiatims](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nadiatims)] 5-2-2008(19): My pawn shop **reject** s any axe with even a drop of blood.

column5: 1) [[joesan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joesan)] 23-10-2007(180): I strongly _reject_ the **accusation** implicit in your _words_.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 10-11-2008(81): _Words_ that make you feel _rejected_.
column7: 3) [[szreter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/szreter)] 14-6-2008(58): After murdering those who _reject_ ed me with my blood-stained axe, I received a letter containing _words_ of **accusation** from their families and the police.
column8: 4) [[tristanthorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tristanthorn)] 18-3-2009(42): _Words_ of **accusation** are usually _rejected_ , rarely accepted.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 25-10-2005(15): A mnemonic to put in image : "The **accusation** _rejects_ the _words_ of the defendant" .

column5: 1) [[kyldyyr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kyldyyr)] 15-11-2005(185): One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the _day_ that I _saw_ before today was **yesterday**.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 15-11-2006(127): Yester- DAY, all my troubles seemed SAW far away…
column7: 3) [[libsrone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/libsrone)] 22-5-2008(78): Today I see. **Yesterday** I saw.
column8: 4) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 14-1-2007(52): My coworker has an excessive way of updating his daily calendar. Instead of throwing **yesterday** 's page into the trash, he'll pulverize it with a chainsaw he keeps under his desk.
column9: 5) [[Apple_Head](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Apple_Head)] 13-1-2011(38): **Yesterday** : a _day_ that has been _sawed_ off from time and can never be lived again.
