column3: The **lie** in this character refers to falsehoods and fibs. Its elements: _words_ . . . _saw_.
column5: 1) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 6-6-2006(518): Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a _word_ of a **lie** , his nose grows and he has to get the _saw_ out again.
column6: 2) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 23-4-2008(44): Her **lie** s are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw.
column7: 3) [[Piitaa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Piitaa)] 3-7-2006(23): Hint: I think of **lie** s as _serrated words_ for some reason.
column8: 4) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 24-11-2008(12): This really has the connotation of fraud rather than **lie** but the Pinnochio story works too well.
column9: 5) [[nicjsb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nicjsb)] 3-10-2008(8): His words were false, I saw right through his **lie**.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-2-2007(152): _Mr T._ 's favorite magazine is **Make**. He loves to **make** things. But he's a purist: he only uses _saws_ , no power tools.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-4-2007(70): When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, _Mr. T_ salvages a _saw_ from the wreckage and says, "I don't know about y'all foos, but I'm gonna **make** a raft.".
column7: 3) [[thelooseteeth](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thelooseteeth)] 8-3-2009(36): _Mr. T_ can **make** anything with his trusty _saw_.
column8: 4) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 27-11-2008(29): _Chuck Norris_ can **make** a _saw_ just by biting into a piece of iron !
column9: 5) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 18-1-2010(15): Police ask a witness about what they _saw_ and the _person_ **make** s up a story instead of telling the truth.

column3: _Rain_ that undergoes a change so that it can be swept aside with a _broom_ is **snow**.
column5: 1) [[BigAmish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BigAmish)] 15-8-2008(183): **SNOW** isn't all that different from _RAIN_ , except it can be removed with a _BROOM_ because it only forms in freezing temperatures.
column6: 2) [[nesert](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nesert)] 28-6-2010(53): Unlike _rain_ , **snow** can be swept away with a _broom_.
column7: 3) [[gibler](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gibler)] 7-10-2011(8): PRIMITIVE: I like to relate the particle for BROOM also as HARRY POTTER on his BROOM. (stories become really easy for the next 11 kanji especially)… . STORY: During the summer Harry Potter on his broom shows off by turning the rain to **snow**. RTK2: セツ 積雪 せきせつ(pilled up **snow** ). [＃＊雪崩](midori://search?text=＃＊雪崩) なだれ Avalanche.
column8: 4) [[netsplitter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/netsplitter)] 26-9-2009(7): It's going to rain tomorrow with a 3% chance of **snow**!
column9: 5) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 15-6-2008(6): When it **snow** s, you need a broom to clear your porch.

column3: _Metal_ . . . _broom_ . . . _rice_. Note how the final stroke of the _broom_ is extended slightly when an element below is attached directly to it.
column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 28-5-2007(191): A monk won a _gold metal_ for breaking the current **record** for most _swept rice_ in one minute.
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 6-8-2006(144): This character is about a **record** ing for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a _metal_ _broom_ and the little pins on the cylinder are like _metal_ _grains of rice_.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 4-2-2007(83): Historians have discovered an ancient **record** about Buddhist monastic life **record** ed in _gold_ plates. Sadly, the only thing the monks did was use their _brooms_ to sweep up _rice_.
column8: 4) [[shakkun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shakkun)] 14-6-2008(38): For the combination of broom+rice I'll use Curling <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curling> where the stone has been replaced with an onigiri rice ball (thanks Katsuo). So here, the Canadian team is recieving a GOLD medal for breaking the world **record** for points scored in CURLING.
column9: 5) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 16-9-2009(30): The **right part** should be a new **primitive** since it will appear several times (see [green](../v4/1371.html) (#1371 緑), [peel off](../v4/2145.html) (#2145 剥) and [salarium](../v4/2602.html) (#2602 禄)) and can easily confused with similar stroke combinations. I suggest **videotape** , deduced from its Chinese meaning (thx shinclef).

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 14-2-2007(87): **Peel off** the outside of the _broom_ that sweeps up _rice grains_ to reveal a _saber_.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 13-6-2007(36): A multi-purpose _broom_! It cleans, it sweeps ( _rice_!), it hits! In fact, **peel off** the mahogany exterior to uncover a _sabre_! It slices, it dices, it kills!
column7: 3) [[shinyclef](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shinyclef)] 22-3-2013(11): This may be of interest to some. [录 [lù] verb - record, write down, copy, videotape] (<http://goo.gl/3jHhU>) The web address shows the 录 part of the kanji with meanings and examples.
column8: 4) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 31-5-2009(8): Horror movie (on a _videotape_ , see my comment for [record](../v4/1144.html) (#1144 録), thx shinycled): A murderer **peels off** his victims with his _sabre_.
column9: 5) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 1-2-2009(5): For those of you using the "curling" primitive ( _broom_ plus grainy _(r)ice_ \- see [record](../v4/1144.html) (#1144 録) for more info): Picture a zamboni, driving about a _curling_ rink like a big ride-on lawnmower, resurfacing the ice by using its _saber_ -like blades to **peel off** the top layer.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 3-9-2006(349): The policed **inquire** d into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ _ero_ in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.).
column6: 2) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 20-1-2008(85): As a verb this means, this means "to ask, to enquire, to search, to look for, to look into, to investigate,". Imagine the police inquiring in an in-depth investigation. They are interrogating a suspect. But the suspect has a _crafty mouth_ and is very sly. He/she also knows when to keep their mouth shut( _glued_ ) at the right moments to avoid self-incrimination. As a final measure, the police torture the suspect by tickling him/her with a broom while they **inquire**.
column7: 3) [[netsplitter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/netsplitter)] 15-12-2008(68): You are new in Japan and you **inquire** about a new job. Lucky for you, there is one. You're now the guy with the _broom_ who sweeps the _エロ (ero)_ "studio" after they're done. "Eww, what's this _gluing_ the _broom_ to the ground…". Time to **inquire** about a new job :).
column8: 4) [[melchan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/melchan)] 14-6-2009(34): The cleaning lady found some _エロ ero_ pictures _glued_ together while sweeping the floor and started to **inquire** everyone around about it.
column9: 5) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 22-5-2006(21): I tried to **inquire** about _broom_ _craft_ but every one's _mouth_ was _glued_ under an **inquire** spell.

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 16-9-2007(196): She was always _bound_ to a _broom_ , her _heart_ pounding in a **hurry** to finish before she was punished for being slow.
column6: 2) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 1-10-2007(111): In a **hurry** to tidy up before guests arrive, you're feverishly sweeping with a bunch of **brooms** **bound** together, your **heart** pounding.
column7: 3) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 18-10-2007(89): Fantasia: _Bound up brooms_ out of control send Mickey's _heart_ racing–he has to **hurry** and figure out how to stop them before the magician returns!
column8: 4) [[mcbainpc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcbainpc)] 31-3-2008(37): Cinderella was always _bound_ to a _broom_ , her _heart_ pounding in a **hurry** to finish before she was punished for being slow.
column9: 5) [[yo6shi9](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/yo6shi9)] 18-4-2009(30): **Hurry** potter (terribly sorry for the pun…) here we see him flying by in a **hurry** , bound to his broom not to fall, in a heart pounding race to get the Quidditch World Cup RTK2: キュウ 急行 きゅうこう(express train).

column5: 1) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 28-2-2007(175): This whole kanji is a picture of **calm** ness. The _wheat_ has been harvested and even the _vultures_ sit **calm** ly watching the humans _sweep_ and clean- up after the harvest is over. _Hearts_ are peaceful and **calm** at this time of the year. Even the days are **calm** without storm.
column6: 2) [[joesan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joesan)] 29-10-2007(142): The farmer is **calm** knowing that his _wheat_ fields are protected from _vultures_ by his _strawman_ with a _heart_ (all the better to do the job properly).
column7: 3) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 14-4-2007(80): A **Calm** day: the _vulture_ is flying above the _wheat_ fields, where there's a a scarecrow made with a _broom_ with an _heart_ painted on the shirt (like oz scarecrow).
column8: 4) [[kusterdu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kusterdu)] 25-3-2008(42): The farmer lying in the middle of the wheat field is so **calm** the vultures think he is dead and keep trying to get at his heart. He just lightly brushes them away with a broom, barely noticing their presence.
column9: 5) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 6-8-2008(35): Creepy but **calm** bucolic scene: In a field of wheat, a vulture sits atop a scarecrow's broom, **calm** ly eating a heart (a mouse heart?).

column3: _Person_ . . . _broom_ . . . _crown_ . . . _crotch_. Gather the elements on the right into a composite image that can serve you in the next two frames.
column5: 1) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 21-4-2008(187): The _parson_ **ENCROACH** ES on the _French maid_ , driven wild by her little _broom_ , dainty _tiara_ and sinfully short skirt showing her knickers ( _crotch_ )!
column6: 2) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 23-7-2007(62): Mr T. hits a _condom salesman (broom + crown + crotch)_ over the head with a _broom_ because the dude **ENCROACH** ed Mr. T's privates area during the sale.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 8-3-2009(49): "I pity da fool who **encroach** es on me". _Mr T._ is dressed as a _French maid_ (= _broom + crown + crotch_ ), working undercover at a hotel that has a problem with guests misbehaving towards female staff.
column8: 4) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 18-3-2007(41): Right side is similar to [accept](../v4/735.html) (#735 受), except that instead of birdhouse here we have a _broomhouse_. I assign _broomhouse_ meaning to whole primitive. – _Mr. T_ locks in a _broomhouse_ anyone who **encroaches** upon his position of leadership.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 14-11-2007(22): Here we see the sex starved Marine SENTRY about to **ENCROACH** upon the French MAID (broom, crown, and a nice crotch?). Makes for an easy mental picture.

column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 5-12-2007(182): The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting **immersed**. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!).
column6: 2) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 10-1-2009(68): **__YOU MUST BE 18 YEARS AND OVER TO SEE THIS__** You load SEXY.FRENCH.MAIDS.XViD.avi and you see a French maid, **immersed** in sperm. Shit close the porno someone is coming!!
column7: 3) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 23-7-2007(51): After being hit in the head with the _broom_ , the _condom salesman_ **IMMERSED** his head in some _water_.
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 3-3-2009(21): _French maid_ at the hotel is demonstrating how to use the bath: “ …then fill with _water_ until you are completely **immersed** , like this…” ( **immerses** herself).
column9: 5) [[findus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/findus)] 1-5-2008(16): Often in a _broomhouse_ you also have _water_ so that your broom can be **immersed** before the cleaning.

column3: Do not confuse this key word with either the element for _reclining_ or the character for _prostrated_ (Frame 1035). Its primitive elements are: _house_ . . . _turtle_ . . . _broom_ . . . _crown_ . . . _crotch_.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 5-12-2007(209): After work, the _French maid_ goes _home_ and lies down with a _turtle_. Turtle? Well, he's sloooow and always hard… (thanks to Nukemarine and Wakela!).
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 11-9-2007(59): After being hit on the head [encroach](../v4/1148.html) (#1148 侵), the _condom salesman_ goes back to his _house_ to **lie down**. He hasn't made a single sale today, so he doesn't have enough money to buy a pillow. He lies down on his pet _turtle_ and cries himself to sleep.
column7: 3) [[Koos83](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Koos83)] 21-12-2009(51): The _French maid_ I hired cleans my _house_ as slowly as a _turtle_ , but I keep her on, because I love to 'lie down' with her…
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 7-7-2009(30): While the _maid_ in our _house_ was **lying down** , I touched her _crotch_ , but there was half a _turtle shell_ covering it. Nice foresight girl!
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-10-2007(18): For this kanji, **LIE DOWN** in your HOUSE and imagine a MAID (broom, crown and crotch should make an easy picture). In her HOUSE, she gets lax and **LIE DOWN** , with her feet propped on a TURTLE table. Maid works great in the previous two kanji's, did it not?

column5: 1) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 7-2-2008(252): In high society, a **lady** is a _woman_ who never touches a _broom_ or an _apron_.
column6: 2) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-10-2007(114): The **LADY** of the house is nothing more than a WOMAN who's a HOUSEWIFE (BROOM and APRON anyone?).
column7: 3) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 29-6-2007(29): Im a laaaaidy! (little britain) - heres the old fashioned woman with her apron on beating a man up with a broom because he made an ungentleman like advancement on her.
column8: 4) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 9-9-2007(18): The French maid is the ideal **lady** – here's a _woman_ that comes to your house dressed in an _apron_ and carrying a _broom_. To enforce the position of the primitives, make this a particularly kinky maid that is wearing just the _apron_ below her waist, and using the _broom_ to cover her breasts.
column9: 5) [[KeroHazel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/KeroHazel)] 18-6-2009(11): The _French maid_ modestly covers her crotch with a _towel_ when she enters the _women_ s' bath. As dirty as she may be in her private life, in public she is a perfect **lady**.

column5: 1) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 3-5-2007(138): Whether I **SWEEP** something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON.
column6: 2) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 5-10-2007(70): FINGERS of the HOUSEWIFE (in itself, holding a BROOM, with an APRON) busily **SWEEP** the floor.
column7: 3) [[mcbainpc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcbainpc)] 29-6-2008(68): **Sweep** \- Learn to **sweep** properly! Grip the _broom_ with your _fingers_ and be sure to wear your _apron_.
column8: 4) [[vitor569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vitor569)] 30-9-2008(31): While she was **sweep** ing the floor I took down her apron and fingered her.
column9: 5) [[walexander5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/walexander5)] 11-5-2009(11): Our [lady](../v4/1151.html) (#1151 婦) is now afraid she'll break a nail on one of her _fingers_ since had never had to **sweep** with a _broom_ in her life. It's not easy trading in your _crown_ for an _apron_.

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-4-2007(249): Some mothers use a _small broom_ to **hit** their children when they misbehave.
column6: 2) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 25-2-2007(53): [hit, right, appropriate, himself] If you're old enough, this is a pictograph of an Atari joystick (which, BTW, got its name from this word/kanji). You can also think of how an Atari joystick is like a _small_ _broom_ with which you can **hit** and sweep off the enemies from the screen…
column7: 3) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 17-12-2005(52): Here is a weird carnival game where you hold a _broom_ like a javelin and throw it, trying to **hit** the center of a very _small_ target. The target is so _small_ , in fact, that if someone does manage to **hit** it, the operator turns in surprise and says, "Whoa, really?! ( 本当 ?!)".
column8: 4) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 6-11-2007(22): **Hit** the Atari ( 当たり ) joystick, it's a _small_ hand-held _broom_ \- like device which you can use to **hit** and sweep off the enemies with. Tootal (とう) destruction! (Readings: あ(たり), とう).
column9: 5) [[sabretou](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sabretou)] 14-2-2011(11): RPG: Your first weapon in the game is a _Small Broomstick_. Use  >> Attack Enemy >> You **Hit** the Enemy for 40 Damage! (Imagine the two little sparks emerging from the broom as it **hit** s your enemy).

column3: The top primitive of this character is actually an old form of _broom_. The remaining elements are: _crown_ . . . _fruit_.
column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 3-12-2008(42): I was having _mutual difficulties_ in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the _crown_ and I was the one picking the _fruit_. In order to fix the problem I checked the **glossary** for " _mutual difficulties_ " but found nothing. I guess we're going to have to _mutually end_ our relationship.
column6: 2) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 12-3-2010(27): When I went to _Headless Mutual_ , the bank for tough London gangsters, I was given a pamphlet that said "If you try'a rip us off, we'll give you the rough end of a pineapple." I didn't quite understand this phrase, but it was important that I knew my legal obligations, so I consulted my **Glossary** of British Thieves' Argot. The result: "'give one the rough end of a pineapple': lit. insert the _crown_ of the _fruit_ into the recipient's anus. Metaphorically used to mean 'to exact vengeance'. Oh, I see now.
column7: 3) [[brose](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brose)] 2-4-2007(22): People who read the **glossary** are _mutually exclusive_ (exclude the top line of [mutually](../v4/757.html) (#757 互) ) from those who eat _crowned fruit_ イ はりねずみ same kind 語彙 .
column8: 4) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 26-1-2009(9): I was reading a recipe book but had trouble figuring out what a "pineapple" was. Thanks to the _one-way assisting_ **glossary** at the end, I learnt that a pineapple was a _crowned fruit_.
column9: 5) [[BladeWalker](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BladeWalker)] 27-7-2012(8): We had no idea what a _crowned fruit_ was so we _mutually_ checked the **glossary**. Well, I say mutually, but really I did all the work.

column5: 1) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-1-2008(174): This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to _bound up_ his opponents, and with a _trident_ , which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific **contenders** , so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 21-6-2007(93): A boxing ring is _bound up_ by the ropes. The **contend** er is cheating and using a _rake_.
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 24-12-2008(82): In an episode of the Simpsons, Sideshow Bob is trying to kill Bart, but on the way has to **contend** with a pile of _rakes_ which keep him _bound up_ for some time.
column8: 4) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 4-5-2007(47): The peasants revolt: if you do weird things to them in your castle, you may have to **contend** with a mob ready to _bind you up_ and beat you to death with _rakes_.
column9: 5) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 13-11-2006(23): One of the **contend** ers in Street Fighter 2 is _Vega_ who has _rakes bound_ to his hands.

column5: 1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 22-5-2006(162): Bottled water marketers contend to make their version of tap water sound the **clean** est.
column6: 2) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 16-9-2007(126): The _water_ _contends_ against the dirt in the ultimate battle for **cleaninless**.
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 11-8-2008(78): Separate the primitives. **Cleaning** the garden involves _watering_ the lawn and _binding_ up all the leaves with a _rake_.
column8: 4) [[narazumono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narazumono)] 23-12-2008(62): I wanna see a **clean** fight. Pour _water_ on the _contenders_ to make them **clean**. (silly I know).
column9: 5) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-1-2008(34): _Gladiators_ (see my story for [contend](../v4/1154.html) (#1154 争)) often bathed in _water_ or _oil_ before a battle, so that their opponents would have a hard time trying to grab them. As a result, they looked very **clean** and shiny!

column3: This key word here refers to abstract **matters**. The elements are: _one_ . . . _mouth_ . . . _rake_. Note how the _rake_ handle reaches out the top and bottom of the character.
column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 16-9-2007(216): Just _one_ word about this **matter** from your _mouth_ and you will find this _rake_ across it.
column6: 2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 18-11-2007(109): I had to take _one_ day off from work due to 'personal **matter** s' after stepping on a _rake_ and having the handle snap up and smack me across the _mouth_. I certainly wasn't going to tell anyone about it.
column7: 3) [[blackstockc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blackstockc)] 31-1-2008(51): This is a pictograph of someone stepping on a rake, and the handle coming up to hit them in the face…no laughing **matter**.
column8: 4) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 23-2-2009(49): This IS a laughing **matter** : _One mouth_ getting smacked after someone steps on a _rake_ \- classic slapstick comedy!
column9: 5) [[Kewickviper](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kewickviper)] 5-9-2009(14): Just one word from your mouth about this **matter** and I'll stab you with a fucking trident.

column3: The key word here refers of course to the **T'ang** Dynasty in China (and not to the name of the drink astronauts take with them into outer space, though this could be useful for the next frame). Its elements: _cave_ . . . _rake_ . . . _mouth_.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 2-4-2007(244): Two archeologists are in a _cave_ looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a _rake_ and says, "What about this – T'ang, do you think?" The second puts the _rake_ in his _mouth_ and answers, "Yes, it does **tang** a bit".
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 17-12-2005(133): Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical _caves_ , where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden _rakes_ to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their _mouths_ to see if it's tasty or not.
column7: 3) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 21-3-2008(94): (Based on matticus) The **Tang** juice was created in China in the **T'ANG** dinasty. The T'ANG emperor discovered that certain **cave** s walls had a very sweet smell, so he **raked** the walls of one of them and put the **rake** into his **mouth**. This way he discovered that tasty powder that nowadays is known as TANG juice.
column8: 4) [[zanzibar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zanzibar)] 31-5-2009(44): Archaeologists found an ancient RAKE from the T'ang dynasty at the MOUTH of the CAVE.
column9: 5) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 19-1-2008(14): I imagine that people from the T'ang dinasty looked a bit like cartoony asians, with teeth so prominent that looked like _rakes_ on their _mouth_. They felt ridiculous about that, so they usually hid on _caves_ , wishing for a dinasty with better depictions.

column5: 1) [[guidedog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/guidedog)] 19-7-2007(139): **Sugar** made from rice has a tangy flavour.
column6: 2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 18-11-2007(125): The _T'ang_ are the ones who began using **sugar** in China–of course, the first thing they tried it on was _rice_.
column7: 3) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(56): The ultimate **sugar** y breakfast is a _rice krispy treat_ and a big glass of _Tang_.
column8: 4) [[Hinode](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hinode)] 11-3-2009(37): This is what my research yielded on the origin of the kanji: The traditional form of **sugar** in China was maltose, which is a form a **sugar** made from malt (= dried _grains_ ). It was still used in the late Han and throughout the Tang period, though during the Tang **sugar** cane substituted _grains_ as the primary source of **sugar**.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 11-9-2007(24): _Condi Rice_ wakes up every morning and spoons about three cups of **sugar** into her _Tang_. Why? Well, she's got to have something to hype her up about facing the American public day after day. Picture her waking up and shaking until she gets her daily **sugar** ration…then things go overboard and she starts to pipe **sugar** -loaded _Tang_ straight into her veins..

column5: 1) [[laxxy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laxxy)] 25-8-2006(285): A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are **sane** and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the **sane** ones take out the plug and get the water out with **ease** ).
column6: 2) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 16-9-2007(95): People on the _cave_ age became more **sane** after they started using _sieves_ to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康 , health).
column7: 3) [[matt_jenkins](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matt_jenkins)] 16-4-2008(50): Ever since I meditated in the _cave_ and realised that wearing a _sieve_ on my head would stop the C.I.A controlling my thoughts, I've been completely **SANE**.
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 30-12-2006(26): Japanese doctors recommend you retreat to a _cave_ every week to _sieve_ rice through a _rake_. It will keep you **sane** , sound, healthy, and wholesome.
column9: 5) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 23-9-2008(10): A **sane** person in a polluted CAVE will use a SIEVE to breath.

column3: Think of **apprehending** criminals. The elements are: _sieve_ . . . _road_.
column5: 1) [[bokuzukuri](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bokuzukuri)] 14-1-2006(423): Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but **apprehend** ing criminals.
column6: 2) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 6-7-2007(25): In Space Balls, they were combing the desert in order to **apprehend** Lone Star. Picture Dark Helmet saying "Combing the desert failed, we must now sieve the road!".
column7: 3) [[Koos83](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Koos83)] 21-12-2009(11): The police have a new way of **apprehend** ing criminals, a big _sieve_ in the _road_. Innocent people pass over, but people with a guilty conscience fall through.
column8: 4) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 27-5-2007(11): Corrupt cops **"apprehend"** a suspect by shooting him in the middle of the _road_ , shooting him until he's so full of holes he's leaking like a _sieve_. No wonder the general population is so **apprehensive** when the police roam the streets: they don't want to be shot up like a _sieve_ on the _road_. —— Avoid confusing [arrest](../v4/654.html) (#654 拘) and [apprehend](../v4/1160.html) (#1160 逮).
column9: 5) [[scarby+dancer](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scarby+dancer)] 29-5-2013(5): When they were finally **APPREHEND** ED, Bonnie & Clyde were shot so many times they were leaking like a SIEVE on that desolate Louisiana ROAD… _["So numerous were the bullet holes that undertaker C. F. 'Boots' Bailey would have difficulty embalming the bodies because they wouldn't contain the embalming fluid." WIKI]_ … [ 逮捕 【たいほ】 arrest, APPREHENSION, capture _versus_ 勾引 , 拘引 【こういん】 arrest, custody, seduction, abduction].

column3: Used chiefly in proper names, and given the sound "i," this kanji can be remembered as an abbreviation of **Italy** , for which it is still used today in Japan. Its primitives: _person_ . . . _mop_.
column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 11-9-2007(150): The "boot" of **Italy** has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but _Mr T_?
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 25-10-2005(69): Here I have _Mister T_ cleaning up with a _mop_ , a real mess of spaghetti, in front of the Piza (in **Italy** ).
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 18-1-2008(47): The radical on the right looks to me like a _fork_ holding a _spaghetti_. In **Italia** is pretty common to see _people_ eating spaghetti.
column8: 4) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 17-5-2008(40): Mr. T is so excited to be **Italy**! Wow!! He gets off the plane and sees what must be an Italian delicacy! Spaghetti on a stick! look at those huuuuuge noodles! T is chowing down. Meanwhile, the airport janitor is wondering why _Mr. T_ is eating his _mop_ …
column9: 5) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 26-11-2008(13): _Luke Skywalker_ in **Italy** , _mop_ -in-hand working as a cleaner for a pizza restaurant. Sometimes, when nobody is around, he pretends the _mop_ is a lightsaber, reliving his glory days.

column3: The somewhat highbrow British term of address is chosen hereto represent the kanji for a form of address used towards one's juniors. It is composed of: _mop_ . . . _mouth_.
column5: 1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 9-3-2011(224): There's a tendency in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. "Well **old boy** ," a senpai might say, "If you did as much work with the _mop_ as you do with your _mouth,_ you would have been done an hour ago".
column6: 2) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 22-1-2007(69): The Beatles, english **old boy** s, had hairs like _mop_ and a good singing _mouth_.
column7: 3) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 6-4-2008(46): 君 [kimi] is said by the **old boy** to the younger boy, never the other way around as it would be an insult.
column8: 4) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 11-1-2008(32): For this character I think of the Korean movie " **oldboy** ", in which the protagonist has hair like a _mop_ and a _mouth_ that screams in agony. If you have not seen it you really should it's great, I won't spoil the ending…you won't see it coming :).
column9: 5) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 18-4-2009(22): 君 [kimi] is said by the **old boy** to the younger boy, otherwise it would be an insult and someone would end up with a _mop_ to the _mouth_. (Thank you Raseru).

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 14-5-2007(262): _Good ol' boys_ are like _sheep_ , they tend to **flock** together.
column6: 2) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 16-9-2007(55): A little girl herder calls out, " [羊君、きて！](midori://search?text=羊君、きて！) " to the sheeps and they **flock** to her at once.
column7: 3) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 7-2-2008(27): (Thanks Stefanot) Fans **flock** ed like sheep at Beatles - old boys concerts.
column8: 4) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 3-3-2008(18): Quentin Tarantino fans are like **flock** s of sheep. He gives the thumbs up for "Old Boy" and everyone **flock** s to the theatre to watch.
column9: 5) [[Dantheman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dantheman)] 19-2-2011(8): Kimi! Get back in the **flock** , like a good sheep.

column3: The key word is a suffix used to indicate "safe from" or "protected against," as in the words rust **proof** , water **proof** , and fire **proof**. It is composed of: _comb_ . . . _glue_.
column5: 1) [[laner36](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laner36)] 3-10-2007(314): [akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof–and I glued it to myself.
column6: 2) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 3-2-2007(91): I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.
column7: 3) [[harusame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harusame)] 30-5-2009(51): _Glue_ your hair together and it will be _comb_ **-proof**.
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 17-4-2007(16): Urushi is one of the hardest lacquers(and glues) known to man. It's **-proof** ed against everything: acid, oil, water, heat, etc. They found a 6,000yo urushi comb in Japan! <http://www.urushi-kobo.com/history.html>.
column9: 5) [[thelooseteeth](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thelooseteeth)] 10-3-2009(12): My _comb_ is _glue_ - **proof**!

column3: The sense of **demand** is best captured by thinking of the economic principle of  "supply and **demand**. " The primitives: _rain_ . . . _comb_.
column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 22-6-2007(270): Supply and **demand** is a simple concept: when it _rains_ , the **demand** for _combs_ goes up to deal with wet hair.
column6: 2) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 22-3-2007(108): If it's raining combs, then the **demand** for them sure does drop.
column7: 3) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 12-8-2008(92): If it _rains_ , the **demand** for _combs_ will rise. However, if it _rains combs_ , the **demand** for _combs_ will fall. It's all about supply and **demand**. (A combination of radical tyro's and FuduMyo's stories).
column8: 4) [[paramausi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paramausi)] 2-7-2009(38): It's _raining_ _combs_?? I **demand** an explanation for this shit.
column9: 5) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 3-10-2007(5): A smart salesman will know which kind of _weather_ will cause frizzy hair, with the subsequent increase in the **demand** for _combs_.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 24-8-2007(161): No more **Confucian** jibba-jabba! I _demand_ you tell me why it's _raining_ _combs_!".
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 29-10-2006(95): One day, _Mr. T_ started reading the little proverbs he found in fortune cookies, and with this newfound wisdom he became a **Confucian** scholar. He was suddenly in _high demand_ as people came from all over to ask for his sage advice, immensely satisfied with suggestions such as, "You will find happiness with a new love".
column7: 3) [[mcbainpc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcbainpc)] 29-6-2008(61): _Mr. T_ _demand_ s to know what **Confucian** means!
column8: 4) [[finethankyou](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/finethankyou)] 8-4-2009(43): Confucius Say: when it rain comb, man have brush with death.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 31-7-2006(24): Confucius is a _person_ who _demanded_ that people make an effort to live up to high moral **Confucian** standards and improve society that way.

column5: 1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 12-2-2006(248): Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is _standing_ at the _edge_ of a sheer _mountain_ face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn't seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully _combing_ his hair so it would fall perfectly.
column6: 2) [[eltjopoort](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eltjopoort)] 12-7-2008(112): When you _stand_ a _comb_ on its **edge** , it looks like the [mountain](../v4/768.html) (#768 山) kanji.
column7: 3) [[inuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/inuki)] 25-9-2006(68): Jimi Hendrix: Well I stand up next to a mountain, chop it down with the **edge** of my ……… comb?
column8: 4) [[desmidus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/desmidus)] 2-3-2008(37): Standing on the **edge** of a mountain, you throw your comb into the abyss. Head shaved, no need for it anymore. Goodbye comb, goodbye. You're on the **edge** yourself, you look below. The abyss beckons. You watch the comb fall…
column9: 5) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 17-9-2007(16): He valianty _stood_ at the _mountain_ 's **edge** … and proceed to _comb_ his hair for the photographs.

column3: _Ceiling_ . . . _belt_ . . . _mountain_. Note that the writing order follows the order in which the primitives are given here.
column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 26-8-2006(276): Primatives _celing, belt, mountain_ as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link. **Both** effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the _celing_ with your _belt_ or jump off a _mountain_.
column6: 2) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 19-2-2008(37): Under one _ceiling_ **both** took off their _belts_ in Brokeback _Mountain_.
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 14-5-2007(36): Be careful with this one. The correct primitive order is _ceiling_ . . . _belt_ . . . _mountain_. That said, in the Mario video games, there are some levels where spikes hang from the _ceiling_ and there are large conveyor _belts_. One example is Koopa _Mountain_. Imagine **both** Mario and Luigi trying to get through the level unscathed.
column8: 4) [[volfy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/volfy)] 2-4-2006(26): Matticus, the errata at www.nanzan-u.ac.jp/ SHUBUNKEN/publications/miscPublications/ Remembering_the_Kanji_1.htm reflects your view of how the character should be written. Everyone should take a look and correct all the listed errors in the book.
column9: 5) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 12-3-2008(16): **Both** the ceiling of heaven and the mountains are belted to the Earth.

column3: _Water_ . . . _flowers_ . . . _both_. Given the abstract nature of this last primitive, you may want to borrow the image from the previous frame.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 24-8-2007(244): Add _water_ THEN the _flowers_. With _both_ the vase will be **full**.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 22-5-2007(128): I was thirsty so I gulped down the _water_. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the _flowers_. Yes, I am responsible for _both_ the missing _water_ and the missing _flowers_. Yes, I'm afraid _both_. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite **full** now.
column7: 3) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 20-11-2007(67): I hate going on dates where a girl says "I'll have a _salad_ and a _water_ " and then insists that they _both_ make her **full**!
column8: 4) [[Machine_Gun_Cat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Machine_Gun_Cat)] 10-3-2009(45): Just imagine you and your closest Japanese class rival having a contest to see who can get **full** marks ( 満点 ）in a test, the winner is given _Flowers_ , the looser is drenched with ice cold _water_ , now imagine you _both_ get **full** marks and so _both_ of you get drenched and flowered.
column9: 5) [[fiminor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fiminor)] 16-7-2006(20): In spring, the _water_ of Kyoto's waterways is **full** of cherry blossom _flowers_ , right up to the banks on _both_ sides.

column3: In forming an image for the key word, it is helpful to know that this kanji is used for artistic representations (like a completed painting), and as a counter for the number of **brush-strokes** in a character (as, for instance, in Indexes II and III at the end of this book). Its elements are: _ceiling_ . . . _sprout_ . . . _shovel_.
column5: 1) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 20-6-2006(180): You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.
column6: 2) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 17-9-2007(77): To paint a kanji in your _ceiling_ with only natural materials, you use a _sprout_ as a **brush** and _shovel_ some dirt to use as paint for your **strokes**. [modified from johnskb's].
column7: 3) [[chully](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chully)] 7-4-2009(46): Start with just _one_ stroke. Soon more will _sprout_ , and then you end up with a whole _shovel_ full!
column8: 4) [[cingold](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cingold)] 9-10-2009(37): The first kanji I learnt was just _one_ **brush stroke** , but then my knowledge _sprouted_ and I knew a _shovel_ ful.
column9: 5) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 12-1-2008(28): New age artist. The canvas is on the _ceiling_. The floor is covered with bean _sprouts_. The artist takes a _shovel_ and makes a sweeping motion on the ground, sending a stream of sprouts flying up to the ceiling and sticking to the canvas in strange patterns. "This is radical calligraphy," he says, panting for breath, "and the act of shoveling is my new-age equivalent of the classical **brush stroke**.".

column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 22-6-2007(302): _Stop_ _shoveling_ _rice_ into your mouth, you'll hurt a **tooth**! Use chopsticks instead.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 24-8-2007(90): My dentist used his _foot_ and a _shovel_ to dislodge the _rice_ stuck between my **teeth**.
column7: 3) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 16-8-2007(33): My female dentist: " _Stop_ using a _shovel_ to pick the _rice_ grains from out of your **teeth**! You'll wreck them!" she (し) said.
column8: 4) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 21-1-2009(18): A Japanese wife _stopped_ cooking _rice_ one night because she was tired. Her husband complained so she took a _shovel_ to his face and broke all his **teeth**.
column9: 5) [[Nick65765](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nick65765)] 7-6-2012(14): I cant believe i didnt see this before …………………………………………………….. ITS A PICTOGRAPH OF A **TOOTH**!!! …a front **tooth** thats _white as rice_ , wedged into the _upper gum to stop it_ moving and the _shovel primitive is the shape of the **tooth**_. …you dont need much imagination to picture this!!……..UPDATE: the stop primitive can even mean _foot_ of the **tooth** (like opposite to head) thus root of the **tooth**.

column3: Picture yourself grabbing hold of the two strokes poking out the top of the kanji and wrenching them apart, thus giving the sense of **bend**. If you think of them as deriving from the element for _brains_ beneath (of course, the middle stroke has been reduplicated and pulled out to where it can be grabbed hold of), you can associate the key word with **bending** someone's mind to your own point of view.
column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 28-10-2005(250): It looks like the mouth of _Bender the robot_ , from Matt Groening's animated series "Futurama". Thus, I use the character _Bender the robot_ as a primitive.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 5-9-2006(120): Also means "melody". Think of it as a pictogram of a guitar where you have to **bend** the strings to make a **melody**.
column7: 3) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 24-4-2009(87): When _two sprouts sprout_ at the same place they don't have enough space and have to **bend** in different directions to grow…
column8: 4) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 27-2-2007(15): Hannibal Lecter exposes his victim's _brains_ and inserts two _walking sticks_ , using them to **bend** the victim to his will. Note: Heisig implies this, but doesn't show the actual stroke order. Write this in the same order as [rice field](../v4/14.html) (#14 田) but with two extended vertical strokes in the center instead of one short stroke.
column9: 5) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 24-12-2008(13): This is a guitar fretboard. You have to **bend** the strings to produce a _melody_.

column3: This character is written in the order of its elements: _one_ . . . _bend_ . . . _sun_.
column5: 1) [[mikemikepw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mikemikepw)] 19-9-2007(166): A space **cadet** eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver).
column6: 2) [[diracbracket](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/diracbracket)] 23-12-2008(134): _Bender_ lasted just _one day_ in the space **cadet** s.
column7: 3) [[elmaestrokgb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elmaestrokgb)] 19-6-2009(49): Japanese **cadet** s have to constantly do _one_ thing– _bend_ OVER all _day_ , bowing to their superiors.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 25-10-2005(41): Hint : As a primitive I use the image of Bender the robot from the animated series "Futurama" (by the same creator as "The Simpsons"). Here Bender is a **cadet** at the army, and the sergeant who is blinded by the sun reflected on Bender's metallic body, keeps saying "this **cadet** is _one_ -insert random expletive- _bend_ er of the _sun_!" (meaning Bender bends the sun's rays).
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 12-9-2007(22): This is from back in _Bender_ 's early days, when he was a promising young space **cadet** at the evil empire academy. He had one task - blow up _one_ _sun_. _One_. _Sun_. That they had set up for him beforehand. Well, he ended up blowing up the entire solar system his outfit was stationed in. When he got called in for a meeting, the commander said: "Cadet _Bender_ , you were asked to blow up _one_ _sun_. At this rate, you'll never be more than a **cadet** ". _Bender_ : "Screw this, I'm outta here".

column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 22-6-2007(198): Close **encounter** s of the third kind. The space _cadet_ **encounter** s aliens on the _road_.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 4-12-2005(54): _Bender the cadet_ (see frame 1172) has an "encounter of the third kind" on the _road_. Reference to Steven Spielberg's 1977 movie "Close **Encounter** s of the Third Kind". Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO's while driving on the road.
column7: 3) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 8-1-2008(30): Close **encounter** s of the third kind. You **encounter** a space _cadet_ on the _road_. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. Having "alien" in the story made me want to use 玄 in place of 曹 ).
column8: 4) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 26-11-2008(20): You **encounter** cadets on the road as they march "hut 2-3-4" (frame 1173).
column9: 5) [[thelooseteeth](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thelooseteeth)] 10-3-2009(11): While traveling the Milky _road-way_ , _Bender the space cadet_ had an alien _encounter_. However, he's used to them by now, so it wasn't really a big deal.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 4-12-2005(149): _Bender the cadet_ (see frame 1172) is **rowing** , during some army exercise, and he's very afraid of _water_ (Bender is a robot).
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 22-6-2007(67): The space _cadet_ is in training, **rowing** in the _water_ (see it splash).
column7: 3) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 8-2-2008(38): A space _cadet_ has crashed on an unknown planet. Fortunately he crashed in _water_ so he's unharmed, but now he has to do some **rowing** to get out of the _water_.
column8: 4) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 9-9-2008(18): When the _cadets_ are ordered into the _water_ , it can only mean one thing - **rowing**. (Make sure to picture this as the verb **rowING** , so as to not confuse with [row](../v4/1785.html) (#1785 並), which means 'a row of something').
column9: 5) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 18-12-2006(8): **Water** **cadet** s (a freshwater branch of the sea scouts), love to go _rowing_. Stroke! Stroke!

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 4-12-2005(146): Also as part of some army survival exercise, the _cadets_ (including _Bender_ see frame 1172) are sent into the _woods_ to build a **vat** (for collecting water for example).
column6: 2) [[jimsublimeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jimsublimeman)] 27-11-2007(63): _Bender the Cadet_ (kudos to Fuaburisu) is found on an army training exercise, hiding behind a _tree_ , getting drunk on the famous scotch whiskey **Vat** 69.
column7: 3) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 23-3-2008(58): A true (?) story about Captain Cook and sauerkraut. Cook was convinced that sauerkraut would prevent the disease scurvy among his sailors, but his problem was getting his sailors to eat the stuff. He tricked the low-ranking _cadets_ into eating sauerkraut by storing it in _wood_ **vat** s labeled "for officers' use only". The _cadets_ thus believed that they were being unfairly denied access to the officers-only **vat** s, so they secretly stole and ate the sauerkraut - which was exactly what Cook wanted them to do.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 7-7-2009(29): Space _cadets_ are decompressed in _wooden_ **vat** s when they return to Earth.
column9: 5) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 21-11-2006(22): Cadets have to bathe in wooden **vat** s.

column3: The **Big Dipper** here is of course the constellation of Ursa Major, of which this kanji is a sort of pictographic representation.
column4: * Since we already have a primitive element for a "dipper" \- namely, the _ladle_ \- we shall let this one stand for a _measuring cup_. By the way, it would make a rather large one, since the kanji is also used for a measure of about 18 liters!
column5: 1) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 7-10-2007(162): Since the meaning of "big dipper" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of **measuring cup**. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 10-10-2008(98): Is it just me, or do all of these traditional kanji pictographs look like they were drawn by a retarded bunny rabbit?
column7: 3) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(30): I looked out my window frame and saw two shooting stars slashing through the **big dipper**. Primitive: Big Gulp cup from 7-11.
column8: 4) [[igordesu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/igordesu)] 13-1-2009(22): This does not look like the **big dipper** or 18 liters of anything in any way, shape, or form.
column9: 5) [[meiko452](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meiko452)] 11-11-2010(11): The **Big Dipper** is a celestial measuring cup.

column5: 1) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 29-9-2006(259): When buying _rice_ , the **fee** is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don't just use any cup, it has to be a proper _measuring cup_.
column6: 2) [[wzafran](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wzafran)] 24-10-2007(62): Samurai(s) once received their **fee** in the form of _rice_ that had been carefully weighed in a _measuring cup_ beforehand.
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 23-5-2008(39): Ancient Japan mobile promises no monthly **fee** s for long distance but I hate the fact that they don't take credit cards. I'm tired of mailing them a _measuring cup_ full of _rice_ every month.
column8: 4) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 26-11-2008(13): Hidden **fees** are everywhere nowadays. Just the other day, I bought some rice, and they charged me for using the _measuring cup_!
column9: 5) [[Hawkeye123](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hawkeye123)] 15-2-2009(10): This kanji is used in 料理 (cooking). Imagine a **cooking** recipe: Telling you how many _cups of rice_ (measuring cups, of course) you need, and what the **fee** at the supermarket is.

column3: Think here of the faculty or **department** you entered in university, using the elements: _measuring cup_ . . . _wheat_.
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 4-8-2010(235): University **department** s study things like _wheat_ (agriculture) and the _big dipper_ (physics/astronomy), and exact _measuring cups_ (engineering).
column6: 2) [[cornrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cornrow)] 9-12-2008(160): The national **DEPARTMENT** of _WHEATS_ and _MEASURES_. Get it? This one was hard until I came up with this.
column7: 3) [[ezmoreldo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ezmoreldo)] 3-4-2008(22): The science **department** s at universities are trying to grow one wheat plant that can fill a whole measuring cup. (genetic engineering).
column8: 4) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 11-7-2009(15): An alphabetical list of the university's **department** s reads "Agriculture ( _wheat_ ), Astronomy ( _Big Dipper_ )…." and so on.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 12-9-2007(9): The **Department** of _Wheat_ Measurement has heard some strange things about _Cap 'n Crunch Cereal_ recently - namely, that the amount of _wheat_ in _Cap 'n Crunch Cereal_ may not be as high as is claimed on the box. So here they are at the factory with a huge _garbage pail-sized measuring cup_ , putting the appropriate amount of _wheat_ into each box.

column3: _Pent in_ . . . _Big Dipper_. Hint: among the songs dating from the days of slavery that have become part of American folklore is one called  "Follow the Drinking Gourd." It referred to the nighttime travel of runaway slaves (those _pent in_ ) who had no **maps** other than the stars to guide them, among them the bright and predominant _Big Dipper_ , the "Drinking Gourd."
column5: 1) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 16-4-2007(217): Can't see direct relation to [Big Dipper](../v4/1177.html) (#1177 斗) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it's written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure **map**. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.
column6: 2) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 27-3-2011(56): A pictograph of a treasure **map**. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive, 地図 ちず **map** , 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do, 図々しい ずうずうしい impudent, shameless, 図書館 としょかん library.
column7: 3) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 20-6-2006(23): When I arrived in Hollywood, I bought what they call a "star **map**." Much to my dismay, it didn't even show the location of the _big dipper_!
column8: 4) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 2-5-2007(14): A PENT IN BIG DIPPER is an astronomy **MAP**.
column9: 5) [[cingold](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cingold)] 12-10-2009(11): Ahem, it looks like a Trea- _tsu me_ p, er a treasure **map** …

column3: _Meat_ . . . _walking stick_. Be sure to keep this key word distinct from that for _use_ (Frame 1065). The stroke order is exactly as you would expect it from the order of the primitive elements as given.
column4: * As a primitive element, we shall substitute the image of a _screwdriver_ , perhaps the most _utilized_ of all tools around the house.
column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 7-5-2007(141): To tenderize _meat_ in an emergency wilderness situation, just **utilize** your _walking stick_!
column6: 2) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 20-12-2007(115): I'll confuse this with [use](../v4/990.html) (#990 使), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, "utilize" has an artificial, business-speak connotation, you only **utilize** "utilize" when you're trying to puff up what you're saying and sound important. So: "BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, **utilizing** the our latest _Flesh_ Grip(tm) technology!" I'm seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of _flesh_ , a short _shaft_ , and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it.
column7: 3) [[nmkohi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nmkohi)] 4-4-2006(74): When your flesh is weak you must **utilize** a walking stick.
column8: 4) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 18-5-2008(35): We have to **utilize** different tools for different jobs. If some object in your kitchen needs to be be screwed, you would **utilize** a **screwdriver**. If your woman needs to be screwed, you would **utilize** your _meat stick_.
column9: 5) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 10-10-2008(27): NASA **utilize** s a giant laser to cut the moon in half. Very shortly, the Earth will have two _companion_ moons.

column5: 1) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 15-1-2008(246): To live a **comfortable** life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.
column6: 2) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 3-8-2006(68): When I first moved in to my new _cave_ , all I had was a bed (see [bed](../v4/592.html) (#592 床)). But now I've settled in, got myself a few handy things like a _rake_ and a _screwdriver_ , and made myself more **comfortable**.
column7: 3) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 27-4-2008(49): To make your cave more **comfortable** , you'll need to do some work with a rake and screwdriver. Clean it up. Fix a few things.
column8: 4) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 24-11-2008(21): Commonplace seems like a better keyword for this, though it's easier to confuse with others like "usual" and "mediocre". In this case, commonplace refers to something ordinary and non-exceptional. I picture a commonplace caveman's cave, with very ordinary, non-fancy, cave drawings he did with a screwdriver because he couldn't afford a writing brush. You have to visualize him etching the drawings with the screwdriver.
column9: 5) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 8-2-2008(18): (Thanks rtkrtk) To live a **comfortable** life, the Flintstones need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.

column3: _Person_ . . . _flowers_ . . . _cliff_ . . . _screwdriver_. In cases like this you can jumble up the primitive into any order that seems best for the composition of a story, provided you feel confident about the relative position that those primitives take to one another in the completed character.
column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 14-2-2006(282): Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He **equip** s himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 12-9-2007(45): An RPG where you're using _Mr T_ as a character. Before you enter a battle, you **equip** the _flower cliff screwdriver_. This is a small _screwdriver_ obtained at the bottom of a _cliff_ that, when used in battle, shoots out pink _flowers_. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and **EQUIP** ping this item just before facing a tough boss.
column7: 3) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 20-6-2006(29): A _person_ **equip** ping themselves with _flowers_ they will _utilize_ to beautify the barren _cliff_.
column8: 4) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 20-12-2006(20): _Mr. T_ falls from the edge of a _cliff_ but grabs hold of a _flower_ to save his life. He then shoves a _screwdriver_ into the dirt and lifts himself up to safety. "I pity the fool who doesn't come **equip** ed," he quips.
column9: 5) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 26-11-2010(12): _Jedi_ Anakin wanted to present Padme with some rare _flowers_ which only grow at the top of a high _cliff_ on Naboo. To **equip** himself for the climb, he only carried a sonic _screwdriver_ , since he was able to _utilise_ his Jedi powers. 準備 じゅんび preparation, 備える (そなえる) : to furnish, to provide for, to **equip** , to install, to have ready, to prepare for, to possess, to have, to be endowed with, to be armed with, 守備 (しゅび) : defense.

column3: _Salad_ . . . _days_. This is the character with which Japanese fairytales commonly begin.
column5: 1) [[the_marshal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/the_marshal)] 30-4-2006(209): **Once upon a time** , the children were forced to eat their salad every day.
column6: 2) [[andye](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/andye)] 11-1-2007(147): For those who don't know the expression, "salad days" means the time of one's youth. (originally from Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra - see <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days>). I suspect Heisig chose "salad" as the name for the radical just for this phrase…
column7: 3) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 20-10-2007(107): **Once upon a time** there was a McDonald's _salad_ and it was left out in the sun for a whole _day_. But … nothing happened because it was a McDonald's salad, chock full of preservatives and other garbage. The salad lived happily ever after (and so did the person who didn't eat it). The end. [I didn't write this… the original author deleted it… but it's my favourite story on the whole site.].
column8: 4) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 31-1-2010(19): This is the kanji for "mukashi". Often used for "once upon a time" or "long time ago". I will take this kanji to mean "really fucking long time ago"……A really fucking long time ago, I use to eat _salad_ every _day_ and was very slim…..those days are long gone and I'm now fat as a pig…
column9: 5) [[Hujis](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hujis)] 2-3-2009(8): **Once upon a time** there was a ruler called _ceaser_ (shiza sarada). He ruled everything under the _sun_ , even the _sun_ worshiping egyptians, until one _day_ he was killed and then his _sun_ Augustous took over. I think Ceaser will be an easier primitive than **once upon a time**. N.B. It's worked really well for me over the next couple of kanji.

column5: 1) [[javiergakusei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/javiergakusei)] 14-9-2007(181): A long time ago, people of the world got **confused** because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro.
column6: 2) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 3-8-2006(157): _Once upon a time_ , it was thought that the ancient "art" of alchemy could transform anything into _gold_. At that time, people were obviously **confused** about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as **confused** as ever, just about different things now.).
column7: 3) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 1-5-2007(49): _Once upon a time_ there were some very **confused** alchemists. They couldn't understand why they couldn't turn other metals (i.e. lead) into gold. (adapted from Raichu).
column8: 4) [[tummai](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tummai)] 22-5-2008(39): _Once upon a time_ Metallica used to be a great _metal_ band. Somewhere around 1990 they got **confused** and now they write shitty pop rock songs.
column9: 5) [[epangelia2k2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/epangelia2k2)] 11-5-2008(30): Ahhh senility, when you are **confused** by the everything in the world . . . your _golden_ years are not at all like your _salad days_.

column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 9-12-2007(173): _Once upon a time_ I let _Mr T_ **borrow** my _salad_ bowl, but he won't give it back. "This be mine now, foo!".
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 12-9-2007(32): _Mr. T_ **borrow** ed a copy of _Cinderella_ and won't give it back. He keeps watching it over and over again, trying to figure out how the _Fairy Godmother_ does her magic.
column7: 3) [[phauna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phauna)] 17-2-2008(21): _A really long time ago_ , I **borrow** ed some gold chains and a vest from _Mr. T_ , I hope he doesn't notice that I haven't given them back yet.
column8: 4) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 13-7-2008(15): _Once upon a time_ , _Chuck Norris_ **borrow** ed something from me. Do you think I'm going to ask for it back? No way!
column9: 5) [[ambassadog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ambassadog)] 26-10-2009(13): _Back in the day_ , you'd **borrow** from a _person_. These days you go to a bank.

column3: _State of mind_ . . . _once upon a time_. The sense of the key word is that of a lost opportunity or bad turn of affairs, as in the phrase  "What a **pity**! "
column5: 1) [[jmadsen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jmadsen)] 13-2-2006(189): What a **pity**! My _state of mind_ when i think of the opportunities I missed from _once upon a time_.
column6: 2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 10-11-2008(85): "I **pity** da foo who **borrowed** my place in this kanji! (Watch out _Data_!).
column7: 3) [[zz_alex_zz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zz_alex_zz)] 30-1-2008(60): _Data_ says "What a **pity** " when he hears that _once upon a time_ there were no robots.
column8: 4) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 10-11-2008(38): A state of mind when you regret things done once upon a time.
column9: 5) [[nac_est](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nac_est)] 28-7-2007(18): "Pity? It was **pity** that stayed Bilbo's hand! _Once upon a time_ he would not have felt it, but his _state of mind_ changed, and he spared Gollum's life".

column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 26-12-2006(142): _Long ago_ our ancestors **set aside** the use of fingers and began to use cutlery. (Raichu,11-7-2006) The way I remember it's 昔 [once upon a time](../v4/1184.html) (#1184 昔) rather than 旧 [olden times](../v4/35.html) (#35 旧) is that they began to use cutlery to eat _salad_. (I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in _Once upon a time_ , their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.).
column6: 2) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 8-2-2008(119): " _Once upon a time_ …" Oh hell, you're just too old for this. You close your fairy tale book and set it aside, pushing it away with your _fingers_.
column7: 3) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 13-8-2007(53): To **set aside** in the sense of giving it up. We **set aside** childish things, namely, those ONCE UPON A TIME stories we grew up with– though those stories' faeries and Disney tinkerbells come up to us, we brush them away with our FINGERS, once after another, but they keep coming, not wanting to be **set aside** – so we flick them away!
column8: 4) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 27-4-2008(26): Once upon a time, I **set aside** my fingers and began using chopsticks. The rest is history…..no more sticky fingers.
column9: 5) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 11-7-2006(14): _Long ago_ our ancestors **set aside** the use of fingers and began to use cutlery.

column5: 1) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 8-10-2007(266): The **taskmaster** is dissatisfied with the meal she's served, and **scatter** s the **salad** & **meat** across the floor for the servants to clean up.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-5-2007(83): When his _salad_ had _meat_ in it, the vegetarian _taskmaster_ blew his top and **scattered** it all over the restaurant floor.
column7: 3) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 13-1-2008(55): Perhaps you've heard of Nyotaimori or Nantaimori (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyotaimori>) in which sushi is ate from the flesh of a naked person, the story comes easily. **Scatter** _salad_ over the _flesh_ of the _taskmaster_ in preperation for some nantaimori :).
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 12-9-2007(16): As we all know, _Hitler_ was a vegetarian. So when he was enjoying his _salad_ and found a bit of _flesh_ **scatter** ed in it, he flipped out and **scatter** ed it all over the floor. After hearing it was the chef's special creation, a " _Flesh_ **Scatter** _Salad_ ", he goes on a rampage and startskilling people. Imagine him walking into a room, with people screaming, "Oh no! It's _Hitler_! **Scatter**! **Scatter**!!".
column9: 5) [[Rivvie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rivvie)] 28-5-2008(13): So… what's in the salad? Just some lettuce, the taskmaster answers, oh, and some human flesh. Everybody **scatter** s from the dinner table.

column3: The two _tens_ joined at the bottom by a short line is actually the old character for **twenty** , which we might as well learn since we need its primitive form. It is written the same as _salad_ , except for the shorter final stroke.
column5: 1) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 24-3-2007(160): A _generation_ is 30, one stroke less is **twenty**.
column6: 2) [[Pauline](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pauline)] 29-6-2006(62): _Ten_ plus _ten_ is **twenty** (see [generation](../v4/28.html) (#28 世)).
column7: 3) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 15-3-2009(42): 十 [ten](../v4/10.html) (#10 十)、廿 [twenty](../v4/1190.html) (#1190 廿)、世 [generation](../v4/28.html) (#28 世).
column8: 4) [[mattias](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattias)] 31-5-2010(14): [十、廿、丗](midori://search?text=十、廿、丗) … Ten, **Twenty** , Thirty… Japanese is logical as usual.
column9: 5) [[fagie37](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fagie37)] 27-5-2008(9): I'll give you this **twenty** if you'll give me two tens. I just really got to break this **twenty**.

column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 31-1-2010(209): **Commoner** s have to huddle in _caverns around a campfire_ , while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel.
column6: 2) [[fagie37](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fagie37)] 28-5-2008(71): If you are so poor that you are a **commoner** , you will have to live twenty **commoner** s to a cavern, with only one fire for everyone to share.
column7: 3) [[epsilondelta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/epsilondelta)] 14-12-2009(58): PRIMITIVE: _Cave_ \+ _twenty_ = **Finnish sauna** (instead of Heisig's "caverns", which I'd confuse with "cave"). This primitive meaning works well for all kanji it occurs in, I've posted stories for all of them. STORY: Wealthy people have a _sauna_ in their house, but **commoner** s have to use their _oven fire_ to warm themselves.
column8: 4) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 7-2-2006(25): I draw upon The Two Towers again. Imagine the scene where the people of rohan seeks refuge in the cavernous fortress of Helms Cleft. The nobility and warriors stand ground at the bulwark, where as the **commoner** stay behind in the huge caverns of 20 little fireplaces.
column9: 5) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 18-11-2007(12): Tamaki is fantasizing about Haruhi again (Ouran Host Club), thinking of her **commoner** lifestyle, eating **commoner** food–in this particular fantasy, she's in a _cave_ with _twenty_ raggedy **commoner** family members (must have borrowed some siblings from Yamada Taro Monogatari) trying to huddle around a _fire_ , cooking some sort of **commoner** food.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-8-2007(287): The _commoners_ are revolting! We must **intercept** them on the _road_ before they reach the castle!
column6: 2) [[tuuli](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tuuli)] 17-2-2008(78): If don't want your secret message to be **intercept** ed, make sure your deliveryman is dressed as a _commoner_ while traveling on the _road_.
column7: 3) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 19-2-2007(23): Robin Hood was a **commoner** , but he still would routinely _intercept_ the Sherriff of Nottingham on the road.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 9-4-2009(20): This keyword is dangerously similar to [apprehend](../v4/1160.html) (#1160 逮). The idea of a "road-block **intercept** ing" people can't be used twice, so here's an alternative: The children from the local village (merely _commoners_ ) walked up to the overpass of the nearby _highway_ and **intercepted** the communications of passing truckers using their little CB radio.
column9: 5) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 16-4-2010(8): In Lord of the Rings, the COMMONERS are **INTERCEPT** ED on the ROAD to Helms Deep. Think of the scene where they attacked by the goblins.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 18-4-2007(192): Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a **seat** was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches).
column6: 2) [[epsilondelta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/epsilondelta)] 14-12-2009(62): PRIMITIVE: _Cave_ \+ _twenty_ = **Finnish sauna** (instead of Heisig's "caverns", which I'd confuse with "cave"). STORY: You don't directly sit on the wooden **seat** in the _sauna_ – rather, you put a _towel_ underneath.
column7: 3) [[mikedough2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mikedough2)] 3-1-2008(49): You're tired from walking the tour at this _cavern_ and there's no benches to sit down on, so you take a _towel_ and sling it up into a hammock-like **seat** using the stalagmites. (Big no-no).
column8: 4) [[Ramchip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ramchip)] 17-7-2008(36): You're in an onsen _cavern_ , peeping at the pretty young girls wearing only a _towel_ … when suddenly Chris Hansen appears. "Please take a **seat** ".
column9: 5) [[b0ng0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/b0ng0)] 2-2-2009(13): If you want to take a **seat** in the _caverns_ , they're often pretty damp - best to lay down a _towel_ first before getting a wet ass.

column3: This key word refers to a gradation of measurement, not to academic diplomas. Its primitives: _caverns_ . . . _crotch_.
column5: 1) [[jimsublimeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jimsublimeman)] 4-12-2007(225): The _cavern refugees_ are so poor that they can't afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their _crotches_ inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in **degrees** from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs…
column6: 2) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 3-5-2008(64): The cave is twenty **degrees** cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.
column7: 3) [[epsilondelta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/epsilondelta)] 14-12-2009(62): PRIMITIVE: _Cave_ \+ _twenty_ = **Finnish sauna** (instead of Heisig's "caverns", which I'd confuse with "cave"). STORY: When it gets 95 **degrees** Celsius (or 200 **degrees** Fahrenheit) in the _sauna_ , you start feeling the heat in your _crotch_.
column8: 4) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 20-12-2005(32): You might want to pick a seat in the _cavern_ a little closer to the cooking fire, though. Otherwise, the second you sit down on the cold rocks, the temperature of your _crotch_ will drop about fifty **degrees**!
column9: 5) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 8-2-2008(15): (Continuing story from previous kanji - thanks matticus) One of the commoners has no towel. As soon as he sits down on the cold rocks of the _caverns_ , the temperature of his _crotch_ drops about fifty **degrees**!

column5: 1) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 3-8-2006(294): This particular form of **transit** is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the _water_ if it's not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 _degrees_.
column6: 2) [[Istvan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Istvan)] 15-7-2007(29): The **transit** system in Tokyo is one of the best in the wrold, but why is it that when it is 35 degrees outside, it is about 2 degrees on the train? Or when it is 2 degrees outside, it is 35 degrees inside the train. This degree of difference means I am always sweating then getting the chills! I think I caught a fever!
column7: 3) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 16-3-2009(25): Hint: This is most commonly used in わたる, meaning to cross (a river etc) - most of the other readings are fairly obscure. I guess Heisig didn't use that because of the earlier 'crossing' kanji, but there we go. Story: the Dwarves who live in the Arctic caverns develop a **transit** system (perhaps of husky drawn carts) on the frozen _water_ when its -20 _degrees_ so they can cross to the other caverns.
column8: 4) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 20-12-2007(22): This kanji becomes a snap when you think of a surveyor's instrument called a **transit**! The **transit** has a small, curved _liquid_ tube (with an air bubble) and a scale marked in _degrees_ so you can tell if something is level or not.
