column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 16-10-2008(11): _Water_ may change several _degrees_ during **transit**.

column3: The hustle and **bustle** of this character is depicted by a _St. Bernard dog_ and a _haystack_.
column5: 1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 11-12-2007(170): Hustle and **bustle** = a big _St. Bernard dog_ frisking about in a _haystack_ , knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up.
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 30-10-2006(90): A **bustle** is also the name for the big wire-framed skirts that women used to wear. Here's a _St. Bernard dog_ jammed ass-first into the top of a _haystack_ , looking like some kind of proper Victorian-era lady as he struggles to get out.
column7: 3) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 13-3-2008(73): (note: easier way to remember haystack - it's just as difficult to find a needle in a haystack, even if you use two hands) Farmers hustling and bustling to move big haystacks.
column8: 4) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 9-3-2008(41): In the hustle and **bustle** of NYC, you suddenly find this humongous _haystack_ and a giant _St. Bernard_ sitting on top of it, howling Christmas songs. Nobody even stops to look….only in NYC.
column9: 5) [[imagia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/imagia)] 27-8-2008(12): - I had trouble using the haystack primitive without "money" as in the following frames, so I've separated the elements out to make sure I don't put "money" into this kanji. Whenever you come across any **BUSTLE** , there's a simple solution for getting through. Get your St Bernard and prick him with a needle - he'll cut right through the **BUSTLE**. You just have to hold onto him with two hands!

column5: 1) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 6-5-2007(232): History of Pompei: An unexpect **erupt** ion and from the _mouths_ of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting _haystacks_ in the fields and the fisherman catching _shells_ on the coast.
column6: 2) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 20-12-2007(66): A bit nasty (but makes the whole thing much easier to remember) is to take the right side and call it a _bearded clam._ For **erupt** , you can make your own story about the _mouth/opening_ on the left.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 17-6-2006(37): Well, the local farmers stuffed the _mouth_ of the dangerous volcano with _haystacks_ , thinking that would prevent **erupt** ions. Even more stupid was one tourist who threw some sea food ( _shellfish_ ) into the _mouth_ of the volcano. This caused an instant **erupt** ion of unprecedented magnitude!
column8: 4) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 3-10-2007(24): After eating some particularly bad _clams_ at a dodgy seafood restaurant, you **erupt** and release them back out through your _mouth_. You cover up the mess with a _haystack_.
column9: 5) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 1-2-2010(21): For _30 clams_ , a prostitute will let you **erupt** in her _mouth_ …..LOL…

column3: _Soil_ . . . _haystack_ . . . _clams_. In order not to confuse this kanji with that for a _grave_ (Frame 246), something like the image of an Egyptian **tomb** should be adopted, with all its special connotations.
column5: 1) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 10-2-2007(201): After the eruption all is a **tomb**. The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering _haystacks_ and of the fisherman collecting _shells_.
column6: 2) [[Soseki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Soseki)] 21-4-2008(97): Using _soil_ and _hay_ to make bricks, the Egyptians built the pyramids to **entomb** the Pharaohs along with all of their _money_.
column7: 3) [[libsrone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/libsrone)] 30-5-2008(37): Depending on how much money you have, you can be buried in the hay, in the dirt, or in a **tomb**.
column8: 4) [[ezmoreldo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ezmoreldo)] 3-4-2008(26): An Egyptian **tomb** is soil molded in the shape of a giant haystack, with all the money of the pharoah burried underneith.
column9: 5) [[Cheesemaster64](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cheesemaster64)] 26-1-2009(19): I think I'm gonna puke. That _bearded clam_ has so much dirt in it that it looks like a **tomb** rather than a womb.

column5: 1) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 18-9-2006(250): Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of "indignant". So **aroused** here refers to being **aroused** because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn't seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry _state of mind_ **aroused** at finding all your _clams_ buried under your _haystack_ stolen, gone!
column6: 2) [[joesan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joesan)] 25-10-2007(68): _Data_ was **aroused/indignant** when he saw what the volcano had done to the farmers building their _haystacks_ and the fishermen collecting their _shells_ . The tragedy of it all **aroused** him so much he didn't even notice he was feeling emotion.
column7: 3) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 24-9-2007(31): **Aroused** : the state of mind men are in _before_ their eruption…
column8: 4) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 20-12-2007(24): Oh boy, does _bearded clam_ ever work for this kanji! I get into an **aroused** state just thinking about it.
column9: 5) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 20-11-2008(10): After _Data_ got his emotion chip, his anger was **aroused** when he realized he wasn't getting any of that _bearded clam_.

column3: _Hearth_ . . . _straw man_. Take care to distinguish this kanji from _cook_ (Frame 507) and _burn_ (Frame 549) when you compose your story.
column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 17-4-2007(125): Ah, there's no better way to **bake** a pizza than an oven fueled by a _burning strawman_. And if you listen carefully, there are stifled strawman screams coming from the kitchen. Think of this image: <http://users.mtrx.net/funnypics/content/-rdm1-ABCD1234-rdm1-/2005/2005-08-23-0002/Doughboy.jpg>.
column6: 2) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 4-10-2007(39): To the _fire_ goes the _straw man_ , thinking to **bake** a cake on it, but…
column7: 3) [[cangy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cangy)] 2-3-2008(25): The best yakisoba / yakiimo / yakizakana / yakitori / yakiniku / takoyaki / taiyaki / shogayaki / sukiyaki / okonomiyaki / dorayaki / teriyaki / teppanyaki is made by burning a strawman.
column8: 4) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 30-8-2006(20): I see the _strawman_ as _The Wicker Man_ (which incidentally I would recommend to all!). Without wanting to spoil the film for those who haven't seen it, let's just say that if you have seen the movie, this one is easy!
column9: 5) [[partyrash](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/partyrash)] 28-1-2008(18): The straw man burning festival. Burning man music festival. I suppose a lot of people have lighters and matches there so they can get **bake** d, eh?

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-5-2007(262): The _sun_ rising beside a _straw man_ in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of **daybreak**.
column6: 2) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 14-6-2008(73): The first person to see the _sun_ at **daybreak** is of course the _straw man_ who stands outside all _day_.
column7: 3) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 4-10-2007(38): **Daybreak** comes and at the touch of the _sun_ all the vampires instantly become _straw men_!
column8: 4) [[xingji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/xingji)] 1-10-2009(31): [nightbreak](../v4/30.html) (#30 旦) was yoake 夜明け = or when the night brights up - **daybreak** is a akatsuki (the kun reading of this character), coming from akatoki =明時 which is the exact moment at which the SUN can give life to the STRAWMAN (it used to mean the period of time when it's still dark - before dawn) [dawn](../v4/2448.html) (#2448 曙) is usually reserved for the figurative sense of beginning of a new era. to keep them separated i'm sorting them chronologically as : 暁 (4 a.m)/曙(5:12:04)/旦(6 a.m).
column9: 5) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 13-12-2006(12): I'd like to see a **daybreak** more often but I'm never up that early. So instead, I get my _Voodoo Doll_ and leave it outside facing east. So it sees the _sun_ rise up for me, whilst I'm still sound asleep. (Hey, if it can transfer pain to me, it can transfer beautiful sights like this!).

column3: Although the writing order is different, one can remember the appearance of this character by seeing it as a _little needle_ \- the kind used for splitting hairs in **half**. (Again, according to rule, _little_ takes a stroke beneath it in order to be placed over an element that has no horizontal line at the top.)
column5: 1) [[bspeaks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bspeaks)] 26-1-2008(361): Imagine karate chopping the number three in **half** with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first "board" breaks.
column6: 2) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 15-3-2009(38): I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in **half** and there are still two more to go.
column7: 3) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 26-5-2006(13): What is 1 divided by 2? ONE (vertical stroke) divided by TWO (horizontal strokes) equals one- **HALF**. The ANIMAL-HORNS are your prize for solving this complex math problem.
column8: 5) [[inuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/inuki)] 14-8-2006(8): I karate chopped the first one in **half** but for the next two I needed a walking stick.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 27-2-2006(217): The _person_ who is your **consort** is most commonly "your other _half_ ".
column6: 2) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 26-7-2007(131): _Mr. T_ wants to splits himself in _half_ so he can be his own **CONSORT**.
column7: 3) [[myglagata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/myglagata)] 12-3-2009(44): MR T's **CONSORT** is only HALF the size that he is (she's Japanese after all).
column8: 4) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 28-7-2007(14): _Mr. T_ will never take a **consort**. Marriage or nothing! No _half_ -way measures for _Mr. T_!
column9: 5) [[Jaunty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jaunty)] 2-7-2009(7): The Asari **consort** from Mass Effect looked _half human_.

column3: _Rice field_ . . . _half_. The key word here refers to the **ridges** that rise up between the sections of a rice **paddy**.
column5: 1) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 1-6-2007(299): A **PADDY-RIDGE** divides the RICE FIELD in HALF.
column6: 2) [[MeisterLlama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MeisterLlama)] 20-1-2009(65): Better keyword: waterside (as in lakeside, etc.) words: 河畔 (riverside) 湖畔 (lakeside), 池畔 (by a pond), etc. New keyword captures most common meaning, and avoids confusion with 畦 , which means ONLY **paddy- ridge**. story: A rice field is divided in half, half is field half is water. If you stand at the halfway mark, you are at the waterside.
column7: 3) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 13-12-2006(35): Think about a large _rice field_ as a big square. Then you draw a line down the middle, _halving_ it into two. Then you draw a line across the middle, _halving_ it again into four… These halvings are **paddy-ridges** that separate the rice field into separate sections. I dunno the reason why, but that's how it's done.
column8: 4) [[protput](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/protput)] 12-8-2009(4): <Http://www.fotosearch.com/bigcomp.asp?path=UPC/UPC004/pss32184.jpg> a paddy ridge divides the rice fileds in halves.
column9: 5) [[Garland](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Garland)] 25-7-2010(3): If you keep dividing the _rice paddy_ in _half_ , and in _half_ again, and again, you'll get more and more **paddy-ridges**.

column3: _Half_ . . . _saber_. You might recall the famous **judgment** of King Solomon, who offered to slice a baby in two with a _saber_ to give _half_ to each of the mothers who claimed it as her own.
column5: 1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 26-6-2008(252): In the bible, King Solomon's **JUDGMENT** was admired not by saying to cut the baby in HALF with the SWORD, but that it revealed who the true mother was.
column6: 2) [[jotun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jotun)] 1-6-2008(72): It takes good judgement to cut things in exactly half with a saber.
column7: 3) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 25-4-2008(22): See book. Solomon made his **judgment** and decided to cut a baby in half with his saber. Good thing he found the real mom before that happened!
column8: 4) [[errtu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/errtu)] 3-2-2010(12): Heisig's story is perfect.
column9: 5) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 16-7-2008(8): Judge Judy: " You cut the couch in _half_ with your _saber_. It doesn't matter if you did it by accident because you tripped with a _saber_ in your hand. What were you doing carrying a _saber_ anyway! **Judgment** for the plaintiff in the amount of 1000 dollars".

column3: _Quarter_ . . . _hand_. Be careful to keep this key word distinct from the primitive element of the same meaning we met back in Frame 741.
column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 31-7-2009(54): 1) I hold a roll of _quarters_ in my _hand_ when I make a **fist**. 2) I hold a _quarter_ in my _hand_ as I prepare to play the Iron **Fist** Tournament: 鉄拳 （てっけん） at the arcade.
column6: 2) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 15-6-2008(37): Quarter, hand: If you have a roll of _quarters_ in your _hand_ , your **fist** will deliver a much more effective punch.
column7: 3) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 12-8-2009(14): 及 **fist** * His **fist** is a QUARTER the size of his open HAND.
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 8-11-2007(7): A **fist** is a _hand_ that offers no _quarter_.
column9: 5) [[einahpets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/einahpets)] 27-2-2012(6): Your _hand_ may only be a _quarter_ of its usual size with the fingers spread out when you make a **fist** but it looks a lot tougher.

column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 28-7-2007(386): Entering the movie, the dude asks for your **ticket** , so he can tear it in half. He looks at you funny when you hand him a **ticket** already torn in half. He quietly tears the stub into _quarter_ s after you show him your _dagger_ with a smile.
column6: 2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 7-5-2007(28): In Japan, the JR railway ju-hachi-kippu seasonal discount **ticket** can be cut into _quarters_ with a _dagger_ and shared with your friends. (its actually sort-of true).
column7: 3) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 7-6-2009(24): Typically, about one _quarter_ of a **ticket** with be separated by a perforated edge which the **ticket** guy will tear off when you are at the gate. However, this kanji was made waaay before perforated edges were invented. It used to be that the guy would cut off a _quarter_ of your **ticket** with a _dagger_.
column8: 4) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 1-6-2007(17): Fact #1: A QUARTER of all **TICKET** S are obtained with DAGGERS.
column9: 5) [[sdrobertm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sdrobertm)] 7-2-2011(14): While a quarter may not buy you a **ticket** , a dagger will, if you know what I mean.

column3: _Quarter_ . . . _snake_. The key word refers to a manuscript rolled up into a **scroll** , not to a _hanging scroll_ (Frame 435).
column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 5-3-2007(165): At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled- up **scroll** for only _25¢_. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous _snake_. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap…
column6: 2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 7-5-2007(110): How to make snake **maki** : Take a _snake_. Roll it up in rice and nori (seaweed paper) like a **scroll**. Cut into _quarters_ and serve on a wooden geta with ginger and wasabi.
column7: 3) [[nadiatims](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nadiatims)] 7-2-2008(48): This **scroll** isn't long enough to show more than a quarter of a snake.
column8: 4) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-4-2007(31): The _quartered_ _snake_ was the illustration on the famous **scroll** by Ben Franklin that read, "United we stand, divided we fall.".
column9: 5) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 25-4-2008(22): Orichimaru (Naruto) uses a **scroll** to summon a SNAKE. To his surprise, the snake demands a QUARTER. Orichimaru forgot his quarters, so back into the **scroll** goes the snake…

column3: This key word refers to a realm or orbit, not to a ball. Its elements: _pent in_ . . . _scroll_.
column5: 1) [[ivoSF](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ivoSF)] 9-9-2006(156): I assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the efect of this spell is pent in a certain **sphere** of influence, outside it no damage is done.
column6: 2) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 10-2-2008(115): [RPG] You're fighting a powerful enemy. Your mage uses a _scroll/quartersnake_ of protection, and he's _pent in_ a **sphere** of protection.
column7: 3) [[ezmoreldo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ezmoreldo)] 14-4-2008(63): The entire **sphere** of human knowledge used to be pent into the library of alexandria on scrolls. (oops, but then it all burned).
column8: 4) [[henroski](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/henroski)] 10-4-2007(40): If the area of the page is outside the **SPHERE** of your screen size, you have to SCROLL vertically or horizontally so that the display on your screen display is not PENT IN by physical dimensions.
column9: 5) [[tritonxg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tritonxg)] 7-1-2010(9): [FR]sphere japlt:N1 **KEN** kanji &kana:508 _enclos+s'enrouler_ **quadrature du cercle :** ce problème mathématique consiste dans un ENCLOS carré à faire s'ENROULER une **SPHERE** 圏外【けんがい】outside range 英語圏 【えいごけん】English-speaking world 気圏 【きけん】atmosphere 旧ソ連圏 【きゅうソれんけん】former URSS 南極圏 【なんきょくけん】Antarctic Circle 商圏 【しょうけん】business region 首都圏 【しゅとけん】Tokyo area.

column5: 1) [[happychair](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/happychair)] 6-3-2006(230): After your **VICTORY** cut your enemy's FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER.
column6: 2) [[msukovich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/msukovich)] 12-5-2008(100): After England's **victory** over Scottish rebel William Wallace, they had his _flesh_ drawn and _quartered_ and then sent around Britain to demonstrate their _power_.
column7: 3) [[wio_dude](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wio_dude)] 29-3-2009(36): On the _moon_ it only takes a quarter of your _power_ to accomplish the same **victory** (because of the low gravity).
column8: 4) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 23-12-2005(23): Victor Belmont, one of the lesser-known Belmonts, derives his strength not from the full moon like most mythical characters, but from the _quarter_ _moon_. When there is a _quarter_ _moon_ in the sky, his _muscles_ become suddenly huge, and his **victory** over Dracula is assured.
column9: 5) [[Haych](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Haych)] 30-11-2008(15): You are sure to achieve **victory** in an arm wrestle if your opponent's flesh has a quarter the power.

column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 7-5-2007(205): According to legend, the great Ogaki **wisteria** tree grew and _flowered_ from magical _rice grains_ that were planted under the _quarter_ _moon_.
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 23-12-2005(88): The **wisteria** is a type of hanging vine covered with _flowers_. By the light of the _quarter_ _moon_ , the _flowers_ look like clusters of _rice grains_.
column7: 3) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 29-3-2007(56): This is easy if you've seen Desperate Housewives. Here on **Wisteria** Lane, under the immaculate _flowers_ , you wouldn't believe the things going on at night under the light of the _quarter moon_ , and we're not talking about fancy recipes for cooking _grains of rice_.
column8: 4) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 13-6-2010(24): **Wisteria** is a plant that is the color of the moon and only blooms one quarter of the year (spring). It's best planted in a hole full of rice grains.
column9: 5) [[pgp27](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pgp27)] 17-7-2009(19): The **wisteria** is a FLOWER you can cook with MEAT and a QUARTER of a pound of RICE to make a delicious dish.

column5: 1) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 5-5-2008(311): Sending a **facsimile** to the _moon_ can be problematic only a _quarter_ of the _words_ actually get there.
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 15-1-2008(92): As a prank, a guy sits with his butt _flesh_ on the **facsimile** machine, inserts a _quarter_ , and tries to fax it to his boss. However the **facsimile** machine has pattern recognition technology and instead of an image of his _flesh_ , it just transmits the _word_ "asshole". Don't forget it's flesh, not words, on the left side, the flesh image gets transformed into words.
column7: 3) [[narazumono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narazumono)] 7-12-2008(38): When you send a **facsimile** to the _moon_ it costs a _quarter_ per _word_.
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 4-12-2011(13): What used to take a _month_ to re-scribe only a _quarter_ of the _words_ , the modern technology of a **Xerox** or even **mimeograph** or **facsimile** reproduces them them in moments.
column9: 5) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 28-7-2007(12): It really is a quite acceptable **fax**. It's just in the _moon_ light, you can only read a _quarter_ of the _words_.

column3: This kanji is based on the pictograph of a tree with some branches going upwards and others hanging down, split right down the middle. When that picture's right side is isolated, it becomes the kanji for **one-sided** , in the sense of only one part of a whole.
column5: 1) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 11-12-2006(282): Fuaburisu's pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a **one-sided** version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 5-2-2006(121): Taking the keyword in the sense of only one part of a whole, I see this as a pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife (I couldn't see any trees or branches in there).
column7: 3) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 21-7-2009(45): A **one-sided** romance–he proposes and she says no. (Thanks to fuaburisu).
column8: 4) [[Odieone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Odieone)] 15-12-2008(15): If you look at this image from **one side** , it looks like the **top hat** is floating over a **chair**.
column9: 5) [[LazyNomad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LazyNomad)] 5-1-2010(8): There is also other side (left-side) of the tree, which is the kanji - 爿(radical no. 90, which has the meaning of "piece of wood" and was earlier used in [status quo](../v4/239.html) (#239 状), [robust](../v4/321.html) (#321 壮), [leader](../v4/731.html) (#731 将), but then was simplified to "half-turtle" element). Now put them together - 爿片 - and you can see a tree.

column3: Although this character also carries the sense of an "edition" of a publication, the elements, _one-sided_ and _anti-_ , more readily suggest its other meaning of a **printing block**.
column5: 1) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 3-9-2006(297): Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn't be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small **printing block** s had to be used instead. _One side_ of the **printing block** would have a mirrored ( _anti_ ) image of the kanji. This is true.
column6: 2) [[matsuyamakiwi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matsuyamakiwi)] 7-6-2008(71): Nazi propaganda. Picture the **printing blocks** producing very _one-sided_ (Aryan), _anti_ -Jewish propaganda spreading posters to hang around town.
column7: 3) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 3-4-2011(59): **Printing block** has a _one-sided_ _anti-image_ of what's being printed.
column8: 4) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 31-5-2006(22): **Printing block** s are one-sided and have "anti-image" of the page carved into them (the background-colored areas are engraved, not the text).
column9: 5) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 8-10-2007(12): Picture teams of monks copying scriptures… before the advent of **printing block** s, documents were copied by hand. The copyists were able to get away with making slight omissions & changes when they didn't agree with the source documents, resulting in **one-sided** versions of the original text. The invention of the **printing block** ensured all copies would be identical to the original, thus it is **anti-one-sided**.

column3: This character is now used chiefly in proper names, and is best learned as the character closest to the hiragana え, though in fact it has no relation to it.
column4: * In order to give this kanji a more concrete meaning when it is used as a primitive element, think of it as referring to _building blocks_ with the hiragana written on them, much the same as the A-B-C blocks you played with as a child.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 4-11-2007(292): **Of** all the kanji, this is the only one 之 orro can write.
column6: 2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 31-1-2008(110): The Z **of** Zorro (and yes he has a hat).
column7: 3) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 7-2-2007(49): "Hey Zorro, would you sign my chest?" "Why **of** course!" Long story short: he didn't use a pen…
column8: 4) [[Groot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Groot)] 13-4-2010(16): The mark **of** 之 orro!
column9: 5) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 31-1-2008(10): My kanji dictionaries state that this is an alternate kanji for これ ( **this one** ) ( 此れ being the other form). It looks like a very small _person_ 人 who lifts a _hat_ with his _arm_. I like to think **of** him as a _gardener_ with a Panama Hat, but it could also be the almighty Zorro!

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 15-2-2008(167): Just one _drop_ (of alcohol) and he starts walking in _zig-zags_ – no wonder _Zorro_ 's living in **destitution**. (Note: As a primitive let 之 be _Zorro_ or _Zig-Zag_ : it's pictographic).
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 22-2-2006(132): Children in complete **destitution** have no hope of ever getting toys to play with, so when they find even a tiny _drop_ of a _building block_ they are overjoyed.
column7: 3) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 31-1-2008(54): The people living in **destitution** POOR. Zorro gives them every drop he has: drops of sweat while fighting, drops of blood when he is cut down,… even the senorita gets some drops.
column8: 4) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 20-5-2008(24): _Zorro_ helps prostitutes living in **destitution**. He gives them money, in return they allow him to cover them in _drops of Zorro_. What a philanthropist! (thanks filip!).
column9: 5) [[digicult](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/digicult)] 15-6-2009(12): This is bad story, but whatever, it works, I was having real trouble with this kanji: On those Sunday morning World Vision shows you see African children living in total **destitution** , often wearing some wacky T-shirt that was popular in the West back in the 80's or something. Now see one little **destitute** child wearing a T-shirt that reads "A Drop of Zorro." A _Drop of Zorro_? What the hell? I don't remember that movie!

column5: 1) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 13-3-2008(227): Zorro, with a flower between his teeth for the ladies, defends his **turf** against evildoers. "This is my **turf**! And this…is for the lady.".
column6: 2) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 5-10-2007(104): Artificial **turf** made easy: _flowers_ stuck on top of _building blocks_ that you can place anywhere.
column7: 3) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 27-7-2007(27): ZORRO tried to plant FLOWERS but found his lawn was made of astro-TURF.
column8: 4) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 8-6-2009(24): You know that when you see a flower bed in the shape of a Z that you're on Zorro's **turf**.
column9: 5) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 13-12-2006(18): Ever seen **turf** rolled out like carpet on a new block? Here a roll of **turf** is unfurled and inside of it was _Zorro_ with a _flower_ in his mouth. Some people are just that smooth…

column3: You may play with the primitives of this kanji as you wish ( _ceiling_ . . . _person_ . . . _a drop of_ ), _but_ you will probably find that its simplicity, and its frequency, make it easy to remember just as it is.
column5: 1) [[laner36](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laner36)] 24-9-2007(194): [Smithsonian] Scene: _Mr. T_ hanging from the _ceiling_ being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a _drop_ of saliva) in the torturer's face, he says "Negative".
column6: 2) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 20-8-2007(45): _One below_ zero is a **negative** number.
column7: 3) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 4-6-2006(29): If just ONE PERSON has a DROP of NEGATIVITY it can make everyone **NEGATIVE**.
column8: 4) [[FoxintheStars](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FoxintheStars)] 22-1-2011(13): A minus sign with an arrow pointing up at it, indicating that this is the symbol that means **negative**.
column9: 5) [[owenjd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/owenjd)] 9-11-2008(12): Anything smaller than 1 is **negative**.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 4-11-2007(201): To distinguish between 否 **negate** , and 不 [negative](../v4/1217.html) (#1217 不): Note that ne _gate_ contains 口 , which is a kind of gate.
column6: 2) [[mairov](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mairov)] 2-1-2008(143): Negative mouths **negate** everything.
column7: 3) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 10-9-2007(48): I get this mixed up with [negative](../v4/1217.html) (#1217 不). The difference here is that someone **ate** the _negative_ to **negate** it.
column8: 4) [[brose](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brose)] 5-1-2007(31): Tip: this is much better learned as "SAY NO", negation coming out of a mouth, easy to remember if you have kids.
column9: 5) [[unauthorized](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/unauthorized)] 27-12-2009(24): Hint: This is the old kanji writing of the word " **いいえ** " (no), which is a negative word coming out of your mouth. Using the Japanese meaning as keyword helps avoid confusion with [negative](../v4/1217.html) (#1217 不).

column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 17-12-2006(249): The maple **tree** is very **negative** about it, but the farmer still collects _cupfuls_ of maple syrup from it.
column6: 2) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 29-11-2007(61): Ｗｈｅｎ ｙｏｕ ｓａｙ ［いっぱい」 Ｔｈｅ ｋａｎｊｉ ｉｓ [一杯．](midori://search?text=一杯．) Just think of Wooden cups being used for drinking, but drinking **CUPFULS** is Negative as you might get sick.
column7: 3) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 6-3-2009(30): The kanji for いっぱい is [一杯．](midori://search?text=一杯．) One cup is great, two cups still good, but if you have so many **cupfuls** that you pass out under a _tree_ , the situation has turned _negative_.
column8: 4) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 7-5-2007(20): A wooden cup is a piece of _wood_ with _negative_ space waiting to be filled by the _cupfuls_.
column9: 5) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 6-3-2007(17): If you want the _tree_ to show _negative_ growth, you should use a few **cupsful** of poison every day.

column3: When shot high into the _heavens_ , the **dart** gets so small it looks like a mere _drop_. Although this character could as well mean  "arrow," it has no connection with the primitive of that meaning. Hence the new key word.
column5: 1) [[libsrone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/libsrone)] 18-6-2008(180): Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop **dart** s from the heavens.
column6: 2) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 16-6-2008(80): Do not mistake with LOSE 失 .
column7: 3) [[j0k0m0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/j0k0m0)] 24-7-2009(35): I lost 845 失 the tip to my **dart** 矢 .
column8: 4) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 3-7-2007(31): **Dart** s are like _drops_ falling from _heaven_. I see massive falling **dart** s from a scene in Babylon 5. I think they were either Shadow weapons or weapons used to attack the Shadows…
column9: 5) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 16-3-2008(20): The 11th and not so well-known plague of Egypt: **Dart** s falling like _drops_ from _heaven_. Imagine a **dart** board over the map of Egypt, with Cairo in the centre, and the angels of heaven playing a round of **dart**. But be sure to also see it from the Egyptians perspective: the drops.

column5: 1) [[Fluhk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Fluhk)] 19-5-2006(209): _Angels_ have now been given a powerful tool to **rectify** human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop _darts_ on those who misbehave… spare the _dart_ and spoil the man…
column6: 2) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 6-8-2006(67): The _darts_ of the _angel_ Cupid are supposed to bring people joy, but usually just make things a lot worse. Here we see another _angel_ flying around shooting people with the anti- _darts_ (antidote), to **rectify** the situation.
column7: 3) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 20-5-2007(63): The _Angel_ cupid uses _darts_ to **rectify** people's love life.
column8: 4) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(26): While trying to make you fall in love, Cupid accidentally threw a dart up your **rectum**. Now another angel is coming to **rectify** the problem.
column9: 5) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 5-10-2007(7): Oh Cupid (angel with the darts): "You can **rectify** my love, **rectify** my love…".

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 12-3-2007(284): With a _banner_ declaring "Keep Out!" and blow _darts_ to back it up, the Amazon **tribe** is not that friendly.
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 20-12-2006(45): Once **tribe** s shot _darts_ under their war _banners_ , now they are putting _banner_ ads on the internet for betting on _dart_ -games at their casinos :(.
column7: 3) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 5-6-2006(40): **TRIBE** S in Japan either have BANNERS (samurai) or poisoned DARTS (ninja).
column8: 4) [[epsilondelta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/epsilondelta)] 18-12-2009(29): Hint: This most commonly occurs in 家族 (かぞく, **family** ), and **family** is not taken, so I'm renaming this kanji to **family**. Story (thanks Hawkeye123): When I'm playing _darts_ at home, I put a _banner_ on the door so my **family** doesn't enter my room and get stung by a _dart_.
column9: 5) [[lecz0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lecz0r)] 7-2-2011(7): An Amamzonian **TRIBE** puts a BANNER outside their village that reads: we have DARTS!!

column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 10-7-2006(287): I should _know_. After all, I did graduate from **Dart** **mouth**!
column6: 2) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 21-9-2006(133): [know, wisdom] [An arrow 矢 like mouth 口 ] If you **know** the answers, they will fly like _dart_ s from your _mouth_.
column7: 3) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 3-12-2007(37): A **know** -it-all can't help themselves, like Hermione, the answer to every question just _darts_ from their _mouth_. [slight reframing from Ricardo's].
column8: 4) [[chully](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chully)] 24-3-2009(29): See <http://i44.tinypic.com/2ljg5yh.jpg> – I find this image helpful.
column9: 5) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 1-3-2006(16): _Dartmouth_ is a place in England, do you **know** it?

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 22-11-2006(236): **Wisdom** is knowing everything OVER the sun (fools assume everything UNDER).
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 1-12-2007(200): _Knowing_ more each _day_ , brings **wisdom**.
column7: 3) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 28-6-2008(55): **Wisdom** is the _knowledge_ gained by the passing of _days_.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 22-1-2006(28): **Wisdom** is a kind of _knowledge_ that "enlightens" and brings warmth to others, just like the _sun_ does.
column9: 5) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 16-9-2009(15): The wise old man says his **wisdom** is all thanks to his _Dartmouth days_.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-5-2007(53): In the busy pub, one of the _dart_ players **shove** d his dart into my _elbow_ by accident when it nearly slipped out of his _fingers_.
column6: 2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 3-1-2009(26): Your _fingers_ slip when someone's _elbow_ **shove** s you, causing you to drop the _dart_ you were about to throw. But as you can see, their elbow is very small, so you decide they're too weak to **shove** back.
column7: 3) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 12-9-2008(22): You're scared to do your introduction ( 挨拶 ）, so a giant FINGER appears to **shove** you in front of the class. You land on your ELBOW, and the class shoots DARTS at you for falling.
column8: 4) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 16-6-2010(15): (+astridtops) In the crowded bar, someone **shove** s an _elbow_ into you just as you are about to throw your _dart_. The _dart_ slips from your _fingers_. You are just about to curse at the person when you realize that she is your Japanese teacher. You bow and greet [ 挨拶 (あいさつ): greeting, salutation] her instead. 挨拶回り (あいさつまわり): New Year courtesy calls 挨拶状 (あいさつじょう): greeting card.
column9: 5) [[Kaame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kaame)] 13-9-2012(7): I **shoved** him with my _fingers_. Then he **shoved** me with his _elbow_. Then I threw _darts_ at him. Then he killed me :-(.

column3: The **halberd's** battle-ax head and long shaft are depicted here. Take care with the number and order of the strokes.
column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 8-7-2009(210): マオ Zedong always carried a **halberd**.
column6: 2) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 1-2-2006(38): Make the **halberd** a heroic warrior (perhaps of scandinavian origin) who weilds this polearm - the most effective, brutal and vicious one - with great skill. He can use it to hook, pierce and chop (the three strokes).
column7: 3) [[adrenaline](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrenaline)] 28-5-2009(34): Mao (マオ) gets his head chopped off by a **halberd**.
column8: 4) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 16-3-2009(19): **Halberd** : A weapon of the 15th and 16th centuries having an axlike _blade_ and a steel _spike_ mounted on the end of a long _shaft_. **Pictograph:** Take a moment to see its different parts. The upper マ is the _blade_ , the horizontal line belongs to the _shaft_ , and finally the lower vertical line is the _spike_.
column9: 5) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(12): It looks a lot like child. Picture a powerful warrior cutting a child's head off with a **halberd**. You can see the head removed from the body and the slashing **halberd**.

column5: 1) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 21-9-2006(226): [tender, weakness, gentleness, softness] Love me **tender** , Love me perfect, Never cheat on me. Or I'll impale you on my _Halberd_ , And hang ya atop a _tree_ …
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 1-6-2007(72): Use a _halberd_ to **tender** ize a _tree_ : _halberds_ can chop, poke, and slash, so it's all good!
column7: 3) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(55): I like my steak **tender**. That's why I impale it with a _halberd_ and smash it against a tree to **tender** ize it.
column8: 4) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 6-2-2008(32): The poor warrior wanted to eat a **tender** steak but all he could find was a slab of _wood_. He chops at and beats at the _wood_ with his _halberd_ until it becomes **tender** so that he can imagine eating a **tender** steak. Primitive placement: remember the halberd is on top pounding down on the wood below. Careful: [tenderness](../v4/993.html) (#993 優).
column9: 5) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 30-3-2009(19): Seeing all the children he orphaned, the now **tender** knight hung his _halberd_ up on a _tree_ , permanently.

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 5-10-2007(206): It is with the _halberd_ he holds that the _taskmaster_ exerts his _power_ over those actually performing the **task**.
column6: 2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 12-5-2007(122): So many video games have a "boss" stage you must pass in order to advance to the next level. Here, your **task** is to use your _halberd_ to beat the _taskmaster_ with the huge, bulging _muscles_.
column7: 3) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 20-12-2007(31): The most _powerful **task** master_ knows how to multi- **task**. Here he's given himself the impossible **task** of _halberd_ sparring with one arm, and _muscle_ building with the other - and he's succeeding!
column8: 4) [[elmaestrokgb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elmaestrokgb)] 28-6-2009(21): A first RPG **task** –not even a full quest, just a **task** some random dude gives you (you always have to start off with some stupid weapon and go kill some other random dude, for no reason). Here, take this _halberd_ I happen to have lying around. Now go kill the _taskmaster_ and his hired- _muscle_ UNDERling.
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 27-8-2010(14): Your **task** is: take the _halberd_ from the huge _taskmaster_ with all the bulging _muscles_.

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 5-10-2007(270): This **fog** is the perfect _weather_ for us to perform our _task_ undetected.
column6: 2) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 9-10-2007(68): **FOG** is easy to associate with the RAIN primitive. So think of **FOG** as a type of RAIN that is slow at the TASK of getting the place wet.
column7: 3) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 4-4-2007(57): _Rain_ 's _task_ is to get rid of the **fog**.
column8: 4) [[rganymede](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rganymede)] 3-2-2009(15): In Persona 4, your _task_ is to rescue people before _rain_ falls and the **fog** sets in.
column9: 5) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 20-8-2008(11): Rain + Task: **Fog** makes driving in the _rain_ a hazardous _task_.

column5: 1) [[Nuriko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nuriko)] 1-3-2008(311): Am I the only one who took this as penis and balls? In order to be in the man-squad, naturally you need to have two balls with your "spear" in the middle there.
column6: 2) [[shirahime](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shirahime)] 29-8-2007(74): Here we have two kings trying out for the cheer-leading **squad**. A spear on the floor separates their dancing areas.
column7: 3) [[skinnyneo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skinnyneo)] 31-10-2007(41): King Leonidas from the movie 300 throws his spear at Xerxes (the Persian king) trying to kill him as his **squad** of spartins make their last stand.
column8: 4) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 30-5-2009(26): If you have a SPEAR and TWO BALLS you have no business being on a cheerleading **SQUAD**.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 9-10-2007(24): A long **SQUAD** of men carrying SPEARS keep the two rival KINGS separated, so that they won't fight.

column3: _Spear_ . . . _broom_ . . . _apron_. The character for _lady_ (Frame 1234) shares the same right side as this character, which does not bode for a very happy **homecoming**.
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 12-10-2007(227): A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her _spear_ to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a _broom_ and an _apron_. “Boy, this is some kind of **HOMECOMING** ,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb).
column6: 2) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(48): Our high school theme was tradition. They gave the **homecoming** king a _spear_ and the **homecoming** queen a _broom_ and _apron_.
column7: 3) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 20-4-2007(27): Well, the boss man warrior upon his **homecoming** has set aside his spear. Remember the [lady](../v4/1151.html) (#1151 婦) (who put aside her broom and apron)? I wonder what they're doing now?
column8: 4) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 15-3-2006(20): A veteran returns home from battle. The village chief takes away his SPEAR to symbolize the end of fighting and gives him a BROOM and an APRON to begin his new career as a hotel maid. “Boy, this is some kind of **HOMECOMING** ,” thinks the veteran.
column9: 5) [[endote](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/endote)] 20-9-2010(13): At the **homecoming** , the man drops his spear, while the women drops her broom and removes her apron. Cherishing the moment that they are reunited.

column3: This character pictures the bent wooden **bow**. Later we will learn how to make the _bowstring_ that goes with it (Frame 1490). If you stretch this character out and see the indentation on the left as its handle, the pictography should be clearer.
column5: 1) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 13-11-2005(98): My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the **bow**. I suppose robin hood etc would work too.
column6: 2) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 20-8-2008(55): I have a **BOW** made from a SNAKE that I BOUND UP. He sure wasn't happy!
column7: 3) [[Earthlark](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Earthlark)] 16-8-2010(40): <Http://cn1.kaboodle.com/hi/img/2/0/0/127/7/AAAAAiIf76sAAAAAASd0rQ.jpg>.
column8: 4) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 20-8-2007(15): Picto: COMPOUND **bow** , because of the shape.
column9: 5) [[bokuzukuri](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bokuzukuri)] 16-1-2006(6): Pictograph, see book.

column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 24-6-2007(188): Put a _walking stick_ in the _bow_ and **pull** it back, ready to fire at the geezer.
column6: 2) [[eugs51](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eugs51)] 2-11-2007(175): This is actually a bow and an arrow. (Real origin of this kanji). **Pull** and release to fire!
column7: 3) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 13-11-2005(20): Legolas catches Frodo **pull** ing on his _walking stick_. I'll let you decide what that means exactly.
column8: 4) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 5-4-2007(19): If you **pull** at the ends of a _bow_ long enough, you'll deform it to make a decent _walking stick_. This was a tactic used by injured archers to escape battle.
column9: 5) [[dilandau23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau23)] 11-2-2007(10): This is the story of Odysseus’ great _bow_ , here we see it as the _bow_ both strung(as _bow_ ) and unstrung(as _walking stick_ ). The challenge was given by Odysseus' wife (Penelope) to see who had strength enough to **pull** the bow and string it.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 19-9-2006(255): Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier's weapons–his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their **condolences**.
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 24-6-2007(80): Send your **condolences** to the old geezer whom you shot the _walking stick_ into with your _bow_. (see [pull](../v4/1232.html) (#1232 引)).
column7: 3) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 12-1-2008(50): Don't confuse with [reparation](../v4/985.html) (#985 償), [compensation](../v4/476.html) (#476 賠). **Condolences** aren't monetary or physical, it's just a letter. "Dear wife, your bungling soldier husband tried to string his _bow_ with his _walking stick_ , which of course failed. He was promptly killed by enemy fire. Our **condolences**.".
column8: 4) [[Thora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thora)] 30-4-2008(22): A dead soldier's _bow_ and _walking staff_ unceremoniously delivered to his widow with a note: "Our **condolences** ". That's it. Heartless. At least "consolation" has some "heart". [In case you used a soldier's death in both stories].
column9: 5) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 17-6-2009(14): The enemy archer kills your friend. Then, seeing how upset you are, he mocks you by offering his **condolences** by using his _bow_ and _walking stick_ like a violin to play a sad song.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 21-9-2006(242): If you pull the bow back with your elbow, you can shoot a **vast** distance.
column6: 2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 1-12-2007(139): The valley was so **vast** that if you yelled _elbow!_ you could hear it echo _bow, bow, bow_.
column7: 3) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 23-9-2007(28): This land is so **vast** , I have plenty of elbow room to pull on and shoot my bow.
column8: 4) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 5-9-2006(24): _Legolas_ pulls back his _elbow_ so he can fire a **vast** distance. I think of the part of 'The Two Towers' when they are chasing the orcs who have captured Merry and Pippen. They were covering a **vast** area.
column9: 5) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 6-3-2007(11): In ancient times, feudal lords agreed on a method to fairly distribute land. Each lord would stand on the top of a different hill and shoot an arrow by pulling back on the _bow_ at exactly the length from hand to _elbow_. The arrow's distance would serve as the radius of his new **vast** territory.

column3: _Vast_ . . . _insect_. Note how the _elbow_ of _vast_ is shrunken and elevated to make room for the _insect_ beneath.
column5: 1) [[jaresty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jaresty)] 10-11-2007(176): An insect who can fly vast distances is **strong**.
column6: 2) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 19-7-2006(106): The _vast_ majority of _insect_ s are pretty **strong** , ants can carry 10x their weight!
column7: 3) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 16-5-2008(49): There was once a legendary archer, who was known for being incredibly **strong**. In reality he was very weak but had a powerful _insect friend_ who tugged on his _elbow_ while pulling on his _bow_ and arrow.
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 14-2-2007(49): Legolas is so **strong** that he can even shoot down _vast_ numbers of tiny _insects_ at _vast_ distances with ease.
column9: 5) [[tristanthorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tristanthorn)] 18-3-2009(21): When using a _bow_ , you need a **strong** arm, and a steady _elbow_ to hit an _insect_.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 23-7-2009(56): If I _recline_ back, I can pull my _bow_ open a _little_ **more and more**.
column6: 2) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 13-8-2009(17): **More and more** _bows_ were made to kill people, until they were _laid down_ for better _small_ er guns.
column7: 3) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 30-10-2007(15): The _bow_ dug **more and more** into the _small_ of his back as he _reclined_ on it. Will someone please tell the idiot to get up?
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 24-4-2007(9): _Little_ Clark Kent, who was found _reclining_ in his spaceship as a baby, grew **more and more** stronger over the years, and found he could fly as fast as an arrow shot by a _bow_.
column9: 5) [[Corodon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Corodon)] 10-12-2011(7): **More and more** archers shoot their _bow_ s while _reclining_ a _little_. It's a very popular stance.

column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 6-3-2007(186): Two **weak** archers agree on a duel to the death. They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it's wintertime and their _bows_ are coated in _ice_.
column6: 2) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 8-4-2008(124): BOWS with ICE on them are brittle and **WEAK**.
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-11-2007(92): I'm missing this Kanji too much, so here's another take: Look at the two BOWS and you'll see it looks like FEATHERS at the base of the BOWS. So, imagine two indian children who are still too **WEAK** to pull a real bow, so their parents make two BOWS from two long FEATHERS. Now the **WEAK** children can pretend they have real BOWS. Two FEATHER BOWS.
column8: 4) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 12-3-2007(22): _Two bows_ with _ice_ on them are still **weak** er than one bow without.
column9: 5) [[Fangio](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Fangio)] 13-2-2012(11): These two archers are so **weak** it's just as if their _bows_ were shooting _feathers_.

column3: _Water_ . . . _weak_. Do not confuse the meaning of this key word with "Drown" (Frame 763), which is closer to "founder."
column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 8-5-2007(90): Weak people placed in the water start **drowning**. Get some strength in those arms and learn how to swim!
column6: 2) [[nadiatims](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nadiatims)] 24-6-2009(7): Weak people who can't hang onto the deck(DEKI) during a storm end up **drowning**.
column7: 3) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 5-5-2013(6): Darwin awards: The weakest of the _weak_ will start **drowning** if put in several drops of _water_. (Do not confuse with [drown](../v4/707.html) (#707 没)).
column8: 4) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 28-11-2009(3): After the Titanic went down in the WATER those who were WEAK soon found themselves **DROWNING**.
column9: 5) [[kiwiburner](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kiwiburner)] 7-11-2012(2): You will begin **drowning** if you are put in the _water_ when you are _weak_.

column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 6-3-2007(167): Re CharleyGarrett: This liquid looks like ordinary _water_ , but it will instantly **seethe** when it comes in contact with counterfeit _dollar bills_. The inventor must be rich (and probably has dollar signs in his eyes).
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 12-3-2007(115): When his daughter used a lot of _water_ for her shower, the father could practically see the _dollar signs_ , so he was **seething** with anger.
column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 3-3-2009(52): This kanji is more closely related to water and emotions boiling. Story: When his daughter used a lot of WATER for her shower, the unemployed father could practically see the DOLLAR SIGNS going down the drain. He began SEETHing with anger… (Thanks smithsonian).
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 11-5-2008(29): Hint: This _dollar sign_ is clearly one of those iced out dollar pendants. <http://newworldtreasures.100megs2.com/Test/HHCP221.jpg> And just imagine **seething** after someone gets water all over your brand new _dollar bling pendant_.
column9: 5) [[ivoSF](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ivoSF)] 21-1-2008(24): I **seethe** (and not only from the heat)when i found out how many dollars one water bottle costs in this desert!

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 6-10-2007(212): An **expense** is an **expense** , whether you put it in _dollars_ or in local _money_.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-5-2007(98): A _dollar sign_ next to an amount of _money_ denotes an **expense**.
column7: 3) [[Fluhk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Fluhk)] 20-5-2006(35): _Shell_ , one of the largest oil multinationals in the world, makes a lot of _dollars_ in Nigeria, often at the **expense** of the local population.
column8: 4) [[zanzibar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zanzibar)] 14-2-2009(26): There's always an extra **expense** involved when you try to convert DOLLARS into other MONEY (clams).
column9: 5) [[adhmm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adhmm)] 20-5-2008(25): I drew up a monthly **expense** list, and the largest **expense** was me buying shells with dollar signs painted on top of them… what's wrong with me?

column3: The key word **No.** is the abbreviation for  "number." Its elements: _bamboo_ . . . _dollar sign_.
column5: 1) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 5-3-2007(214): The **No.** 1 currency in the world is the _dollar_. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the _bamboo_ represent the **No.** 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order ( _bamboo_ on top and the _dollar_ on the bottom) is really a look at the future.
column6: 2) [[WithLoveFromExIA](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/WithLoveFromExIA)] 10-1-2009(101): The **No.** 1 currency may at one time have been the dollar, but since the economic slowdown the _weak dollar_ has been overtaken by currencies from _bamboo_ growing countries. (Thanks to Johnnyltn for the idea.) Using the alternate writing of the dollar primitive as weak dollar.
column7: 3) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 30-4-2008(63): _Bamboo_ _bling_ is the newest Asian Rapper, **No.** 1 on the charts right now.
column8: 4) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 24-6-2007(19): The pole vaulter wants to be **No.** 1, so designs a _bamboo_ pole with _dollar signs_ painted on it. (The shape of a pole signifies this is the 1-stroke $).
column9: 5) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 21-5-2007(15): Even in the _bamboo_ forests of Southeast Asia, the _US Dollar_ is the **No.** 1 currency in demand. (well, it is true of Cambodia at least).

column5: 1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 6-10-2007(216): **Younger brothers** are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little _horns_ on him and the _dollar signs_ on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme.
column6: 2) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 29-1-2007(67): The **younger brother** was a _horny_ _dollar_ -chasing bastard.
column7: 3) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 6-3-2007(35): This is a picture of my stupid **younger brother** 's tattoo. I can't believe he thinks a red _dollar sign_ with devil's _horns_ is cool.
column8: 4) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 12-10-2008(21): My _horny_ **younger brother** is always pinching _dollars_ from me for porn.
column9: 5) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 5-7-2006(18): _Condolences_ for the freakish **younger brother** who was born with _horns_ and a _tail_ (the long diagonal stroke at the bottom).

column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 22-2-2007(210): **Adroit** : dextrous, deft, skillful. Snare is a little generic so I'll use BEAR TRAP, with huge teeth cartoon style that snares you around the ankle. In the _crafting_ of a _bear trap_ , one must be particularly **adroit**. Otherwise they will become the victim of their down device.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 1-1-2007(77): To be _adroit_ one must have mastered the **crafting** of **snares**.
column7: 3) [[joesan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joesan)] 30-10-2007(37): To be **adroit** is to have mastered the _craft_ of avoiding _snares_.
column8: 4) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 12-1-2008(15): It's a spy movie and a trap has been set for our hero in an industrial factory. Our hero trips on a _snare_ which sends a heavy _metal I-beam_ swinging towards his head. He **adroit** ly does a roll to safety.
column9: 5) [[Rakushun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rakushun)] 21-6-2007(13): The **adroit** McGuyver _crafts_ a _snare_ out of…um…nothing. I kinda wish this kanji had more primitives…

column5: 1) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 22-5-2008(242): My **nickname** is "No Lips". Yep, I shouldn't have put my _mouth_ on that _bear trap_ …
column6: 2) [[tony563](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tony563)] 7-5-2006(68): When certain **nickname** snares to people's mouths, they will call you that way forever.
column7: 3) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 8-5-2007(44): Also used in code, signal, password, etc. A **password** is the **code** you must _mouthe_ to release the _snare_ so you may enter safely. Most people just use their **nickname** (which is not recommended by security experts).
column8: 4) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 9-4-2009(40): Her _mouth_ was a _snare_ for cocks, so we gave her the **nickname** BJ Maxx.
column9: 5) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 17-6-2009(27): This guy talks too damn much! We **nicknamed** him _snare-mouth_. Once you get into a conversation with him, you're like a small animal who wants to escape but can't!

column5: 1) [[volfy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/volfy)] 4-4-2006(159): This _snare_ isn't terribly effective, because it's swinging from a **decay** ing _tree_. Imagine the tree as being so **decay** ed that when an animal gets caught in the snare, its struggles cause the tree to collapse into a putrid mess.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 14-9-2007(74): [+air,charley] Trigger: **decaying** remains. You walk by a tree and see the **decaying** remains of what looks like a dead human (? hard to tell, it's been years), still trapped in a _bear trap_. Turns out that the tree itself set them out. All of its comrades were getting chopped down, so it puts out _bear traps_ to en _snare_ would-be choppers and lets them simply **decay** , and uses their remains as nutrients.
column7: 3) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 3-7-2009(56): 枯 wither The **decay** of an animal in the TREE was from something caught in a SNARE.
column8: 4) [[Floatingweed5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Floatingweed5)] 8-10-2007(30): Don't use wooden snares because, as the woodsman says, "They're prone to **decay** , and the catch gets away".
column9: 5) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 10-7-2006(24): **Tree** doesn't like getting chopped. To protect himself, he's set up a **snare** beside him. If anybody comes to chop him down, they'll get en **snare** d, and he'll just let them _decay_ into nutrients that **Tree** will consume.

column3: Words . . . St. Bernard dog . . . ceiling . . . snare.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 19-12-2007(401): The hunter's **boast** : I _say_ , it was a " _big_ _one_ ", but the _snare_ broke and it got away. (credit to many others before).
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 15-1-2008(65): A dog owner **boast** s about how obedient, not how smart, his _Saint Bernard_ dog is. "Why, my dog will even walk right into a trap if I tell him to. Watch!" With a single _word_ , "go!", his dog obediently runs into a _snare_ trap hanging from the _ceiling_. In a flash, the dog is netted tightly and swinging from the _ceiling_. Don't forget the _ceiling_!
column7: 3) [[ezmoreldo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ezmoreldo)] 14-4-2008(16): When you **boast** too much, your words cause your head to become so _big_ it gets _snared_ on the _ceiling_.
column8: 4) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 10-9-2008(10): His **large** **boast** ful **words** **snare** d no **one**.
column9: 5) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 26-11-2008(8): I'm usually **boast** ing when I _say_ , "Yep, my _big one_ usually _snares_ the ladies." If only it were true…

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 29-7-2009(72): Your **chin** is the part of your _head_ under your _nostrils_ that forms the _double snare_ that is your jaw.
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 31-8-2007(21): Left side is _crocodile_ primative. _crocodile's head's_ most prominent feature is his **jaw**.
column7: 3) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 17-7-2007(14): _Both_ my friend's and my _mouths_ dropped open when we saw a person's _head snared_ up to the _ceiling_ by his **chin**.
column8: 4) [[cb4960](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cb4960)] 7-2-2009(6): _Two mouths_ are attached to the _ceiling_ with a long tongue hanging down ready to _snare_ someone's _head_. This is why you should always have a positive attitude and keep your **chin** up (so you can avoid these kinds of things).
column9: 5) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 29-11-2008(5): After I got my _head_ caught in _double snares_ , it looked like my **chin** had _two mouths_.

column3: _Water_ . . . _two_ . . . _snare_. Note that the first two strokes for _snare_ doubles up with the first stroke for _two_.
column5: 1) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 18-11-2007(175): A hunter Washes, with WATER, his TWO SNAREs, because they are **dirty**.
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 12-1-2008(133): Washing your **dirty** snare in water, the extra line represents the water level as you submerge the snare.
column7: 3) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 28-1-2008(45): きtanai. Backwards き with drops of dirt coming off it.
column8: 4) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 8-5-2007(39): You should always keep _two_ _snares_ so that you can wash one with _water_ when it gets **dirty** without interrupting your trapping.
column9: 5) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 3-5-2006(37): Something **dirty** needs to be immersed in _water_. In fact it's so filthy you hold it by a _hook_. Note the water level marked across the hook.

column3: _Slingshot_ . . . _one_. Later we shall learn the character for _give_ (Frame 2046), but even so, it is a good idea already at this point to distinguish this key word from _impart_ (Frame 795) and _grant_ (Frame 1131).
column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 26-5-2007(229): David went to battle with a **slingshot** and it only took him **one** shot to slay Goliath. Partly because of this, the prophet Nathan was later instructed to _bestow_ upon David the throne of all Israel.
column6: 2) [[eieneverafter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eieneverafter)] 22-4-2008(156): In The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time, _one_ of the first weapons **bestow** ed on Link was the _slingshot_.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 8-7-2009(44): High _5_! And **bestow** me _one_ low!
column8: 4) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-4-2007(24): A _slingshot_ was but _one_ of the items **bestowed** to the Dennis the Menace museum.
column9: 5) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 13-11-2008(14): I shall **bestow** you with "the **one** " **slingshot**.

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-5-2007(259): A _crown_ was _bestowed_ to the British royalty museum, but it was only a **copy**.
column6: 2) [[pm215](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pm215)] 16-4-2008(84): True fact: in the UK the right to print a **copy** of the KJV Bible is _bestowed_ by the _crown_ – there are only a few authorised bible printers. (see <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Bible#Copyright_status>).
column7: 3) [[narazumono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narazumono)] 8-12-2008(57): A _crown_ is _bestowed_ upon each Burger King patron, why not? It's just a cardboard **copy**.
column8: 4) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 10-12-2007(22): I actually knew this one, until Heisig's keyword threw me off. Heheh. It's the very part of the very familiar kanji for **photograph** : 写真 （しゃーしん）, which is what I will let this kanji represent.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 13-10-2007(20): I think of the **COPY** of the CROWN that was BESTOWED upon David after he slew Goliath with ONE SLING.

column3: The key word **somebody** was chosen to convey the double meaning of this kanji: body and person. Its composition is based on the _nose_ (which, you will recall, is also the kanji for _oneself_ ). The extension of the bottom and far right strokes of that element, together with the unusual diagonal stroke, forms the pictograph of **somebody** with a prominent paunch.
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 8-12-2006(230): **Somebody** was just looking for you. He had a long _nose_ that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is some _body_ rather than [someone](../v4/1256.html) (#1256 者) is that the story is full of _body_ descriptions.
column6: 2) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 16-3-2006(56): **Somebody** was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face.
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 17-4-2007(28): Gang members sometimes mark themselves to show belonging, like by cutting their _nose_ with a large _slash mark_. Why do they do it? To show that they are **somebody**. As a primitive, this character will mean _gang member_.
column8: 4) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 17-5-2008(15): **Somebody** with a stick pierced through their nose just came in here. I think they were from the Brazilian rainforest.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 16-6-2010(10): 身体 [somebody](../v4/1248.html) (#1248 身) シン, み … Note: horrible keyword. Synonym for 体 … Parts: 自 , 丿 … Story:Though 体 has mostly the same meanings this one has more to do with the human body rather than the general idea of body. 車体 is a car body for instance. So **Some one's Body** might be a better keyword, so : 自分ノ body. … 熟語 : 独身 , 身長 , 身に着ける , 全身 , 変身 … cf: 発射 ,.

column3: I **shot** an arrow into the air, And it landed I know not where  goes the poem. (The poor poet obviously loses a lot of arrows.) This kanji, however, tells us where it did land. Its elements: _somebody_ . . . _glued to_.
column5: 1) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 13-4-2008(190): You **SHOOT** SOMEBODY with a GLUE-gun.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 13-3-2006(63): The aim of **shoot** ing is to end up with a bullet stuck in someone's body.
column7: 3) [[henroski](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/henroski)] 26-2-2008(48): Like paintball, GLUEball is another hunting game. You walk around looking for SOMEBODY to **SHOOT** a big blob of GLUE at, you know you have got him, because he gets stuck to the spot unable to escape.
column8: 4) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 6-10-2008(19): **Skeet! Skeet! Skeet!**.
column9: 5) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 29-12-2007(18): SOMEBODY put GLUE on my toilette seat, so I SHOT him!

column5: 1) [[erikkusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erikkusan)] 1-3-2006(184): Dick Cheney…
column6: 2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 21-1-2008(133): The famous _speech_ by the man that Dick Cheney _shot_ in the face: "I'm sorry for the trouble I have caused the Vice President".
column7: 3) [[wasurenaide](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wasurenaide)] 17-7-2007(63): _socrates_ says, " _shoot_ first, **apologize** later".
column8: 4) [[jonjimbo2000](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonjimbo2000)] 16-6-2008(54): Say the _words_ or I'll _shoot_. **Apologize** or I'll _shoot_. Say your sorry.
column9: 5) [[alanj](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alanj)] 2-12-2008(50): In the Wild West it's _shoot_ first, **apologize** later, but in Japan the _words_ come first - so polite!

column3: First, do not confuse this character with _venerable old man_ (Frame 849), which is far more rarely used. The character for an **old man** begins with an abbreviation of the character for _somebody_ , the _nose_ having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines. But there is another, simpler way to remember it all: the _soil_ drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when  "dust to dust" begins to take on a personal meaning, the diagonal _walking stick_ for getting around, and the _spoon_ for being spoon- fed.
column4: * As a primitive, the meaning is the same, but the final two strokes are omitted so that they can be replaced with other elements.
column5: 1) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 18-12-2006(200): An **old man** , wondering what it's like in a grave, _sits_ in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with _soil_ , the **old man** saves himself by flailing his _walking stick_ in the air.
column6: 2) [[aphasiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aphasiac)] 14-8-2009(71): The _dirty_ **old man** had a _stroke_ so now he must be _spoon_ fed.
column7: 3) [[libsrone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/libsrone)] 30-5-2008(37): **Old man** sits in the dirt, having a stroke.
column8: 4) [[myglagata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/myglagata)] 18-3-2009(18): An **OLD MAN** in a Japanese nursing home must follow the rules: _no_ _spoon_ ing the nurses or _soil_ ing pants. (The slash is like a katakana "no" : ノ).
column9: 5) [[nicjsb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nicjsb)] 4-10-2008(16): Old men soil themselves, have diagonal walking sticks, and must be spoon fed.

column3: _Old man_ . . . _slingshot_. Remember: you already have kanji for _discriminating_ (Frame 521), _deliberation_ (Frame 692), and _think_ (Frame 651).
column5: 1) [[kyldyyr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kyldyyr)] 17-11-2005(224): Before shooting an _old man_ with a _slingshot_ , one shold carefully **consider** the possible consequences.
column6: 2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 14-3-2007(82): Even though he had the _old man_ Mr. Wilson within the sights of his _slingshot_ , Dennis the Menace **considered** what he was doing and stopped.
column7: 3) [[Fluhk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Fluhk)] 20-5-2006(31): As a last resort, we actually might **consider** sending our _old men_ into the battle, armed with _slingshots_ only…
column8: 4) [[dilandau23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau23)] 14-2-2007(27): Think Rod Serling: **Consider** this. An _old man_ picks up his childhood _slingshot_ and **consider** s his past. Yet, this seemingly innocent act will set in motion his final trip into, The Twilight Zone.
column9: 5) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 16-10-2008(21): **Consider** what would happen if we took the _spoon_ away from the [old man](../v4/1251.html) (#1251 老) and gave him a slingshot instead. (Creamed spinach all over the nursing home walls?).

column5: 1) [[dilandau23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau23)] 14-2-2007(317): This _child_ has taken **filial piety** to the next level. He is actually carrying the _old man_ on his shoulders.
column6: 2) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 9-11-2007(76): +dilandau23: This _child_ has taken **filial piety** to the next level. He is actually carrying the _old man_ on his shoulders. There is a picture of a statue depicting this here <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filial_piety>.
column7: 3) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 6-5-2009(11): In **filial piety** , the _child_ looks up to the _old man_.
column8: 4) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 1-6-2006(6): **Filial piety** requires a _child_ to look after their _old man_ when he becomes a really _old man_.
column9: 5) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 16-3-2009(5): **Hint:** A picture depicting this Kanji at <http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/index.html?curid=3957309>.

column5: 1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-5-2007(280): In early Japan, _filial piety_ was the cornerstone of education, and harsh _taskmasters_ were employed to **teach** it.
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 24-12-2005(74): You could say that the _taskmistress_ is **teach** ing you _filial piety_ when she whips you and asks, "Who's your daddy?!".
column7: 3) [[Christoph](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christoph)] 11-10-2006(24): Can you please **teach** me what filial piety means, taskmaster?
column8: 4) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 12-12-2008(9): Under the 3rd Reich, _Hitler's schoolmasters_ used to **teach** children that _filial piety_ is less important than the fatherland. Kids ended up denouncing their parents to the regime.
column9: 5) [[aphasiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aphasiac)] 24-8-2009(6): In Nazi Germany, _hitler_ made every school **teach** the concept of _filial piety_ , as it was important to his dreams of an Arian race.

column5: 1) [[javiergakusei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/javiergakusei)] 6-9-2007(183): In **Torture** 101 class they teach you to Consider the Fingers as the first part to inflict pain to. Then you can move on to other parts (like feet, groin, head, etc. etc. , ) ).
