column9: 5) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 18-10-2007(7): **Mortar** is that goop, prepared on a board (which this pictographically resembles) that works like DOUBLE-STAPLES to hold bricks together.

column5: 1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 26-5-2008(79): Wow, that baker must really be mad! He's trying to **BREAK** his MORTAR by throwing it to the SOIL. Whoa! Now he's aiming a MISSILE at it!
column6: 2) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 17-9-2007(40): To " **break** the _soil_ " is to make a symbolic gesture that indicates the beginning of construction. Like when a politician in a hardhat gets a shovel and lifts a piece of dirt. This particular project is behind schedule, so to speed things up, they blow it up with _mortar_ and an air-to-ground _missile_.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 7-2-2010(23): Drawing inspiration from [beat](../v4/709.html) (#709 撃) by kinkypete, this kanji shows the rules for a bizarre form of janken (paper, stone, scissors). A mortar can **break** soil (grinding it to dust). Soil can **break** a missile (burying it - causing it to eventually rust away). And a missile can **break** a mortar.
column8: 4) [[eatyoda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eatyoda)] 9-12-2008(6): You'll **break** everything down to _dirt_ if you use both _mortars_ and _missiles_.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 11-10-2008(6): Someone tried to **break** into _Staples_ using a _missile_ , but it ended up **break** ing the whole store, turning it to _dirt_.

column3: _Mortar_ . . . _same_ . . . _tool_. Be careful to make an image that keeps _same_ in the middle.
column5: 1) [[laner36](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laner36)] 21-11-2007(202): To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be **entertain** ed. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the _same: staples_. What _tools_! [ayoung24].
column6: 2) [[Shizuru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shizuru)] 27-8-2007(90): Photographically, this kanji simply looks like a set of two speakers (the staples primitives) between the sub-woofer (primitive for same) – all this as a tool to **entertain** a group of drunks at a club.
column7: 3) [[aphasiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aphasiac)] 9-9-2010(39): Wacky Japanese TV **entertain** -ment show: a _monk_ is _stapled_ to the wall on both sides with huge _staples_ , whilst contestants throw _tools_ at his face.
column8: 4) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 12-12-2008(34): This is a pictograph an **entertainment** system (two speakers left and right of the main unit, which has a CD slot and a tape deck) on a table-top.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 23-9-2008(24): Whenever I go to _Staples_ I end up looking at the _same tools_ every time (PDAs, printers, etc.) but it manages to **entertain** me.

column3: Though we shall later encounter the kanji for _bird_ , we introduce this one for the tenth sign of the zodiac mainly because of its use as a primitive, where it has a different meaning.
column4: * As a primitive, it means _whiskey bottle_. In its pictograph, you can see the loosely corked lid, the bottle and the contents (about one-third full). You might also think of the Spanish  "porrón," a decanter shaped like a long-necked bird.
column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 15-7-2006(181): The **sign of the bird** on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 3-4-2007(124): Normally birds fly south, but _one_ bird flew _west_. People were worried about it and kept asking "Is there any **sign of the bird** – you know, the _one_ that flew _west_?".
column7: 3) [[fagie37](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fagie37)] 19-7-2008(12): It's time for a drinking game everyone! If you see the **sign of the bird** , take a drink from your whiskey bottle.
column8: 4) [[TheSlakey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TheSlakey)] 24-12-2008(11): The **Sign of the Bird** on Greygoose Vodka. It's got such a fancy bottle, but I think Absolut tastes smoother.
column9: 5) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 14-11-2009(10): The driver had drunk too much _whiskey_ and was driving too fast, giving all the slow drivers the **sign of the bird**.

column5: 1) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 27-8-2006(176): **Sake** is just watered down whisky.
column6: 2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 13-6-2007(86): **Sake** is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is _whiskey_ and _water_.
column7: 3) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 15-3-2010(19): **Sake**. Looks like _water_ , tastes like _whiskey_. (thanks Bodhisamaya).
column8: 4) [[vengeorgeb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vengeorgeb)] 23-4-2009(7): If you forget this Kanji and you watch a lot of Anime then don't study Japanese.
column9: 5) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 6-11-2007(7): **Sake** is the _liquid_ that comes out of the _sake bottle_ \- and when ever there's a **sake** drinking competition, all the delicate women shoo (しゅ) away. (Readings: しゅ、さけ、さか、ざか).

column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 16-1-2007(266): At the local pub, their **bartending** practises are unusual. They serve the _whiskey_ by pouring it from a _ladle_ , like one would from the punch bowl.
column6: 2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 29-1-2008(23): Ever seen the anime Bartender? **Bartending** isn't just about _bottles of whiskey_ , it's about _ladling_ out advice.
column7: 3) [[mithrila](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mithrila)] 6-7-2009(15): Old fashioned **bartending** had the server ladle out the alcohol from a giant whiskey bottle.
column8: 4) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 30-5-2009(7): Coyote Ugly! The girls **"bartending"** in the bar don't use _whiskey bottles_ \- they use _ladles_ and pour everything over their bodies. What a show! Where was the bar exactly?
column9: 5) [[elmaestrokgb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elmaestrokgb)] 25-7-2009(6): **Bartending** consists mainly of giving the customer the proper amount. That's why they dispense from a _whiskey bottle_ into a special _ladle_ to measure the RIGHT amount.

column3: This kanji is used for thick, low-grade saké made from various kinds of grains. Its primitives are: _whisky bottle_ . . . _glue_.
column5: 1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 22-12-2006(48): While the keyword is "hooch", this usually means 焼酎 . It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated.
column6: 2) [[endote](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/endote)] 7-3-2011(21): Tastes like whiskey, smells like glue? Then it must be しょうちゅうの「ちゅう」 ( **hooch** ). - There you go, reading meaning and a catchy ad jingle, all in one. Possibly the best story I've written. ^^.
column7: 3) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 11-6-2010(19): I combined WHISKEY and GLUE to make **HOOCH**.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 29-11-2010(7): 焼酎 , 酎ハイ , 芋焼酎 [hooch](../v4/2748.html) (#2748 酎) チュウ … Parts: 酉 , 寸 … Cultural Note: Shochu ( 焼酎 ) now outsells Sake ( 日本酒 ) in Japan, so even though Heisig Calls it **hooch** , and Spahn calls it low-grade liquor, Shochu is more popular than Sake. So don't be comparing it to sniffing glue dammit.
column9: 5) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 10-8-2009(5): This thick, illicitly-made beverage is actually just _whiskey_ mixed with _glue_!

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 12-7-2006(208): The secrets of **fermentation** are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 14-6-2006(131): Since _filial piety_ is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a _whiskey bottle_ is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing **fermentation** ) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn't, sink back some whiskey and it will.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-7-2008(104): Add a phrase to Raichu's story: The secrets of **fermentation** are written on a _whiskey bottle_ and passed to the child who displays the most _filial piety_.
column8: 4) [[jonny_wonny](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonny_wonny)] 23-3-2009(29): In a family of alcoholics, _filial piety_ is saving the more **fermented** _whiskey_ for the elders.
column9: 5) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 21-2-2008(15): The boy throws the body of the old man in the whiskey barrel. There he lets **fermentation** do his work. The best whiskey ever.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 12-7-2006(230): It's **cruel** to pour alcohol down a cow's mouth.
column6: 2) [[genbaku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/genbaku)] 17-1-2008(108): Offering whiskey to people to encourage them to make revelations is **cruel**.
column7: 3) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 27-9-2007(64): There is a saying that a drunk man's words are a sober man's thoughts. Be careful about giving someone a _bottle of whiskey_ , you may get some _revelations_ about their **cruel** ty. Of course, they'll just say that it's the whiskey speaking.
column8: 4) [[Gingerninja](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Gingerninja)] 2-1-2009(23): Some people when they drink too much alcohol start to tell the truth about everything. Unfortuantly some of these revelations can be rather **cruel** , at least you find out exactly what they think of you.
column9: 5) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 29-11-2008(16): This one seems too obvious. Drinking too much whiskey makes for some **cruel** revelations as you stop watching what you say to your friends. Hey, your girlfriend is a good kisser!

column5: 1) [[Talka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Talka)] 10-9-2007(204): Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state **repay** s you with whiskey.
column6: 2) [[Thora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thora)] 25-8-2007(128): Hint: bottle deposit refund - the state will **repay** the recycling deposit for each alcohol bottle returned.
column7: 3) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 24-10-2007(35): If you take your _whiskey_ across a _state line_ , you'll have to **repay** the liquor tax in the new state.
column8: 4) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 15-10-2007(30): True story, the former communist _state_ of Russia was once so poor it **repay** ed it's teachers with _vodka_ <http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/177421.stm>.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 23-9-2008(19): _States_ like Michigan **repay** you for returning your _whiskey bottles_.

column5: 1) [[Shizuru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shizuru)] 27-8-2007(163): To stay healthy, Dr. Phil told me to have some **dairy products** with each bottle of whiskey I drink…
column6: 2) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 29-11-2006(139): In an attempt to increase sales of **dairy products** , the grocery store is giving away a free miniature _whiskey bottle_ with _each_ dairy product you buy.
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 31-5-2008(32): The makers of Bailey's Irish Creme _add_ **dairy products** to _each_ of their _bottles of whiskey_ , creating one of the most delicious alcoholic beverages known to mankind.
column8: 4) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 31-8-2007(19): **Dairy products** go bad so often, you can get sick if you eat or drink them, unless EACH one is accompanied afterwards by a shot from a WHISKEY BOTTLE. The alcohol kills the bacteria and warms your innards.
column9: 5) [[myglagata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/myglagata)] 22-4-2009(14): Put a little _whisky_ in baby's **dairy products** at _each_ feeding time to ensure sound sleep.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 18-4-2007(284): Drinking alcohol that's turned to **vinegar** feels like a saw going down your throat.
column6: 2) [[szreter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/szreter)] 24-6-2008(85): I spent ages _saw_ ing that _whiskey bottle_ open, but when I got in, it had all turned to **vinegar**!
column7: 3) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 24-5-2009(12): _Yesterday_ 's _alcohol_ turns into today's **vinegar**. (Yesterday = day + _saw_.).
column8: 4) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 1-7-2007(12): To determine wether the bottle contains **vinegar** or _whiskey_ , you have to _saw_ it open.
column9: 5) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 26-9-2009(8): When the _whiskey_ turns to **vinegar** , the taste is sharp like a _saw_.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 2-9-2007(267): God you're **drunk**! How many _whiskeys_ did you have? _9_? _10_?
column6: 2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 7-2-2008(91): Whiskey with 90 percent alcohol will get you **drunk**. I don't care who you are.
column7: 3) [[echeng25](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/echeng25)] 3-12-2008(29): As Ernest Hemingway said, it only takes one drink to get me **drunk**. But I'm not sure if it is the ninth or tenth drink that does it. [from dingomick].
column8: 4) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 25-10-2007(13): 99 bottles of beer on the wall, 99 bottles of beer, take one down, pass it around 98 bottles of beer on the wall, etc, getting **drunk** , just remembering the '90' part.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-10-2007(9): You will get **DRUNK** if you drink WHISKEY that is 90 proof (NINE and TEN).

column5: 1) [[happychair](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/happychair)] 14-3-2006(217): To **DISTRIBUTE** _WHISKY_ during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a _SNAKE_.
column6: 2) [[Tommy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tommy)] 13-5-2008(140): In Japan, it's rude to **distribute** the _sake_ to your _self_ before anybody else.
column7: 3) [[diracbracket](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/diracbracket)] 26-4-2011(37): Those who have studied physics may find this useful. The two parts of the kanji represent the two statistical **distribution** s for bosons and fermions. The Bose-Einstein **distribution** is represented by the _sign of the bird_ because birds, like bosons, are social creatures who like to flock together. The Fermi-Dirac **distribution** is represented by a _snake_ , since _snake_ s, like fermions, are solitary creatures who like to keep to themselves.
column8: 4) [[the_marshal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/the_marshal)] 23-5-2006(31): Do a google search for "Laotian Snake Whisky"… yes snake whisky does exist !. Now you only have to found their distributor to get yourself a botle !
column9: 5) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 31-5-2008(14): Sir, you're under arrest for **distributing** _alcohol_ to _snakes_. "WHAT?? They told me they were worms!!".

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 2-9-2007(209): The _prostitute_ carries an old _whiskey bottle_ filled with **acid** to throw at any difficult Johns.
column6: 2) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 29-1-2008(113): Dealing _alcohol_ requires a _license_ , dealing **acid** requires fast _legs_ (to run from the police).
column7: 3) [[Corodon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Corodon)] 22-1-2009(71): I stopped doing **acid** , and am living the clean life. Well, aside from all the _whiskey_ and _prostitutes_.
column8: 4) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 8-4-2009(10): The punishment for people who sell _whiskey_ without a _license_ is harsh: **acid** is poured onto their _walking legs_.
column9: 5) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 30-8-2006(9): Sometimes ppl put **acid** into their _alcohol_ to make it taste bad (so you won't want to drink it anymore). this guy uses this technique to give up drinking _alcohol_ , since due to the number of his DUIs he had gotten his driver's _license_ suspended and thus must make use of his _walking legs_ (an inconvenience!).

column3: Wild dogs . . . animal horns . . . whiskey bottle.
column5: 1) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 28-8-2006(151): The **waver** for this kanji means to hesitate. I **waver** ed before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle.
column6: 2) [[shakkun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shakkun)] 17-6-2008(83): For the right primitive: Red Bull (the energy drink). Can be mixed with alcohol and gives you wi- uh, horns. Coincidentally, also the name of the Indian CHIEFTAN in frame 2906. (Thanks Katsuo).
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 26-8-2008(81): Tip: _horns_ \+ _whiskey bottle_ : This combination of primitives appears five times in Heisig, including as a separate kanji 酋 [chieftain](../v4/2906.html) (#2906 酋). REF: [revered](../v4/1439.html) (#1439 尊), [courtesy](../v4/2425.html) (#2425 鄭), [Japanese oak](../v4/2493.html) (#2493 楢). Edit: Note that in some fonts _horns_ are replaced by _eight_ 八 .
column8: 4) [[Wakela](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wakela)] 11-9-2007(80): . Have you ever had Wild Dog brand whiskey? That stuff is downright evil. So evil, the bottle has horns, and you need to sign a **waver** before you drink it. Because of this warning you will surely **waver** as you bring the shot glass to your lips.
column9: 5) [[bladethecoder](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bladethecoder)] 2-6-2010(34): I **waver** ed when the _pack of wild dogs_ was blocking the way, but then I drank some _Red Bull_ and charged through. (thanks shakkun).

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 2-9-2007(204): I drank the _Devil Whiskey_ and was **revered** by all. Too bad I had to have my anus _glued_ shut from the damage it did to my digestive system…
column6: 2) [[Hinode](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hinode)] 13-2-2009(83): _Red Bull_ , the [chieftain](../v4/2906.html) (#2906 酋) is so **revered** in his clan that everyone sticks to him like _glue_.
column7: 3) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 29-1-2008(52): Have you seen people who save their empty alcohol bottles? Some of them take the reverence too far, and _glue_ the **revered** _bottle of whisky_ to the wall, mounted like a rack of _animal horns_.
column8: 4) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 28-6-2006(29): A _whiskey bottle_ collector discovers a bottle where the glass has been shaped into _horns_. He likes it so much, he _glues_ it to his mantelpiece. The most **revered** item in his collection.
column9: 5) [[imojyochu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/imojyochu)] 15-9-2008(24): The **revered** TV evangelist turned out to be nothing but a HORNy, ALCOHOLic degenerate who also sniffed GLUE.

column3: This kanji depicts a pot of **beans** , although it looks more like a table on which the pot is resting.
column4: * As a primitive, this kanji will mean _table_.
column5: 1) [[happychair](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/happychair)] 14-3-2006(241): If I eat **BEANS** , after _ONE_ _MOUTHful_ I fart like some kind of _HORNED ANIMAL_.
column6: 2) [[sindhikara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sindhikara)] 4-1-2009(91): I hate using primitives that are completely unrelated. Let's call this one Mr. Bean! He's an easy character to build stories with.
column7: 3) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 14-12-2007(32): Looks like a pot of refried **beans** on top of a stove to me with a top over the pot.
column8: 4) [[Pangolin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pangolin)] 3-3-2009(23): _One_ _mouth_ ful and you spit them on the _floor_ ( _two drops_ of spit out **beans** ). I'm talking about 納豆 (natto) of course.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-10-2007(13): **BEANS** are served on the TABLE. It's a simple pictograph, so force the issue here.

column3: Here we meet at last the full kanji on which the primitive for **head** is based. The elements: _table_ . . . _head_.
column5: 1) [[blackstockc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blackstockc)] 17-2-2008(215): The **head** of the family sits at the **head** of the _table_.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 25-10-2008(87): _Mr. Bean_ has a funny **_head_**.
column7: 3) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 3-3-2008(51): Mr _Bean_ 's _head_.
column8: 4) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 20-12-2006(21): Which one is the **head** _table_? Well, it's the _table_ with the **_head_** sitting beside it, isn't it?
column9: 5) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 14-6-2007(11): Sometimes old men refer to your **head** as your noggin, your noodle, or your _bean_.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(144): He's so **short** , he can't even throw over a _table_ while playing _darts_.
column6: 2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 25-11-2008(79): Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw _darts_ over a _table_ at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be **short**.———— This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height.
column7: 3) [[sindhikara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sindhikara)] 4-1-2009(78): _Mr. Bean_ somehow finds himself in an archery contest. He has no arrow's so he uses _darts_ , (even though they are quite too **short**!). All of his shots land extremely **short**! (Picture Mr. Bean trying to shoot a dart and it landing **short** ).
column8: 4) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 30-6-2009(37): A **short** man can DART under the TABLE.
column9: 5) [[Angrybeez](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Angrybeez)] 13-9-2008(22): My **short** friend plays darts, but when he goes to pick them out, he has to climb up on the table we put next to the board.

column3: Bend . . . table. Think of a **bountiful** harvest, and you will not be far from the meaning of this character.
column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(256): The **bountiful** feast was so **bountiful** that it _bent_ the _table_ below it under its weight! いただきま〜す！.
column6: 2) [[WithLoveFromExIA](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/WithLoveFromExIA)] 26-1-2013(64): Her bust and bum was so **bountiful** I couldn't resist the urge to _bend_ her over a nearby _table_ and…
column7: 3) [[sindhikara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sindhikara)] 4-1-2009(45): _Bender_ stands on top of _Mr. Bean_ to be able to reach the **bountiful** feast on the giant's table. ( _Mr. Bean_ didnt know how he even ended up there).
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 10-10-2008(19): Be careful when people _bend_ over around here: the _bean_ harvest was **bountiful**.
column9: 5) [[phauna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phauna)] 19-2-2008(14): Bender stands over the table, **bountiful** ly covered in loot.

column3: The full kanji for the _drum_ adds a _branch_ , apparently to serve as a **drum** stick, to the primitive for _drum_.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 2-9-2007(165): Japanese festivals have **drums** so big, a _samurai_ has to SIT (not stand) on a _table_ to beat one with a tree _branch_! <http://www.d2.dion.ne.jp/>~hidafyh/furukawayh/gyouji/image/maturi03.jpg.
column6: 2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 20-2-2008(41): I really hate the primitive meaning of "table" for "bean." I just use "bean." Anyways, for the **DRUM** primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a **DRUM** with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: "DRUMing on a **DRUM** with a huge BRANCH".
column7: 3) [[sindhikara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sindhikara)] 4-1-2009(29): _Mr. Bean_ tries to play **drum** s with _10_ different _branches_ he found on the ground.
column8: 4) [[TheSleeve](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TheSleeve)] 6-11-2007(22): These SAMURAI, sitting at the TABLE and waiting for their food, grab some BRANCHES to begin **DRUM** MING a rhythm while they wait. (In fact, they stand on the table, removing the top stroke!).
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 7-12-2009(15): A _drum_ cannot **drum** without a stick. No stick? Use a _branch_ instead. HINT: For **drum** primitive - Our samurai has eaten loads of beans and now his LOWER HALF (tummy full of beans) is bloated and stretched taut like a **drum**. We can see him tapping contentedly on his "drum". In Japanese folklore, tanuki are believed to play music by **drum** ming "ponpoko pon no pon" on their tummies.

column5: 1) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 31-1-2008(189): The _samurai_ sitting on the _drum_ is on a stage, and the people below him are **rejoicing** with their _mouths_ in unison. It helps me to imagine the placement this way.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 13-3-2007(59): **Rejoice** with the sound of _drums_ and _voice_!
column7: 3) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 5-9-2006(42): In the taiko ([drum](../v4/1444.html) (#1444 鼓)) song of rejoicing, the drummers shout with open mouths.
column8: 4) [[tummai](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tummai)] 30-5-2008(30): _Ten_ _beans_ in my _mouth_! I was starving so this small meal is enough for me to **rejoice**!
column9: 5) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 3-8-2008(23): Think Monty Python and the Holy Grail. Sir Robin's ministrals, following the group with their _drums_ : "One winter they had to eat (therefore the mouth) Robin's ministrals… and there was much **rejoicing**.

column5: 1) [[Wakela](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wakela)] 14-1-2007(317): The hippies object to trees being cut down for timber. They have glued themselves to the **timber-trees** and are beating their drums.
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 17-1-2008(49): To the cutting down of **timber-trees** and the destruction of the forest, the hippies have staged a protest demonstration using a _drum_ in the _middle of the town_ (see [town](../v4/208.html) (#208 村)).
column7: 3) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 20-1-2008(28): Everyone likes to see big trees fall down. For this kanji imagine hundreds of spectators _glue_ d to their chairs, then a _drum_ roll and then a cry of "timber!!!" as the huge _tree_ crashes to the ground.
column8: 4) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 6-9-2008(19): _Drums_ are made from **timber-trees** cut down and _glued_ together. (they really are).
column9: 5) [[LazyNomad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LazyNomad)] 25-5-2009(9): Trivia: 尌 (drum+glue) is a rare kanji wih a meaning _standing (something) up_. Story: Trees that were set to stand up (and grow) at certain places are **timber-trees**. 樹立 【じゅりつ】 (n,vs) establish, create,.

column3: The kanji for a **dish** is, clearly, the pictograph of a painted or carved bowl, seen from the side.
column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 30-9-2006(223): Three **dish** es stacked side-by-side in a **dish** washer.
column6: 2) [[narazumono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narazumono)] 21-12-2008(53): Pictograph of a **dish** with a three-layer cake slice on it.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 7-12-2009(28): 3 **dish** es in a **dish** rack. HINT: To avoid making 4 **dish** es, remember that '4' is an unlucky number in Japan so things are rarely in sets of 4.
column8: 4) [[dilandau23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau23)] 14-3-2007(8): The Holy Grail.
column9: 5) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 30-1-2008(4): I eat fast, so all my **dish** es have racing stripes like this one.

column3: The _drop_ in the _dish_ is **blood**. It is similar to the _drop_ we saw earlier on the _dagger_ in the character for _blade_ (Frame 88).
column5: 1) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 6-6-2007(184): Vampire orders **blood** in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of **blood** in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of **blood** spraying everywhere.
column6: 2) [[genbaku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/genbaku)] 17-1-2008(49): You cut yourself washing the dishes, drop of **blood**.
column7: 3) [[dilandau23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau23)] 14-3-2007(32): Image: _Holy Grail_ with a _drop_ of Jesus **blood** on it.
column8: 4) [[ceginis](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceginis)] 22-9-2007(23): People used to think that **blood** letting was an effective treatment for many illnesses. The doctor would cut the patient's arm open and let the _drops_ of **blood** fall into a _dish_.
column9: 5) [[Dustin_Calgary](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dustin_Calgary)] 9-1-2009(18): **BLOOD**?! IS that a SPOT of **BLOOD** on my PLATE!?! asks the infuriated vegetarian when he ordered a salad at a restaurant.

column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(254): The _part_ of the kitchen sink in which you wash _dishes_ in is the **basin**.
column6: 2) [[crayonmaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crayonmaster)] 5-4-2009(53): Your mom yells at you to stop throwing dishes in the **basin**. She lifts up (to show primitive order) the broken parts to show you the damage you've done.
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 22-2-2008(18): If you break a coconut in two _parts_ , you can improvise a kachi-kachi (a kind of castanet that is played at **bon festivals** ). After the festival is done you can use them as a curved _dish_ , a **basin** (synonym of bowl).
column8: 4) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 1-5-2006(15): When the god parted his soup dish in two it created a huge **basin**.
column9: 5) [[mairov](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mairov)] 13-3-2008(14): It will take just a minute to wash the **basin** 's dishes.

column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 26-1-2010(183): (re: Raichu) An undercover **alliance** between Japan (the _sun_ on its flag) and Turkey (the _moon_ on its flag) detected by a surveillance satellite _dish_. <http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100126a3.html>.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 13-5-2006(86): A new **alliance** is proclaimed at the end of a meal between officials. As a symbol of their **alliance** they clean up together one _dish_ , and present it to the photographers. The clean dish under the flash lights appears very _bright_ , and it's pretty much all you can see on the photo that appears on the next morning's newspapers, with the title "New **alliance** , one _bright dish_!".
column7: 3) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 2-6-2008(52): The _bright dishes_ in the cupboard form an **alliance** against the others.
column8: 4) [[LazyNomad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LazyNomad)] 18-1-2010(44): In medieval Japan (during Sengoku Jidai) there was an interesting ritual to form an **alliance** between different samurai clans. The warlord, who wanted to propose to form an **alliance** to another warlord, would send him a big ceremonial _dish_ with the _sun_ drawn in the center. If the proposal were accepted, the second warlord would draw an image of the _moon_ next to the _sun_ on the same _dish_ , and then return the _dish_ to the first warlord. (not true story, but helped me to create vivid image).
column9: 5) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(20): The **alliance** has built _bright_ satellite _dish_ es to defeat the rebels.

column5: 1) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 30-5-2006(273): You are so poor you dont know where your _next dish_ will come from all you know is that you will have to **steal** it.
column6: 2) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 24-10-2007(62): The first thing to **steal** is the silverware, _next_ , the _dishes_.
column7: 3) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 9-7-2006(34): You're at a revolving sushi restaurant with a famous thief, who's so slick he says he can **steal** anything without anyone noticing. OK, you say, the NEXT DISH that comes by, **steal** it…
column8: 4) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 2-8-2010(25): This is pretty easy: While he's not looking, imagine **steal** ing food from the dish next to you!
column9: 5) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 24-1-2011(8): The _next_ thing on his list of things to **steal** after the _dishes_ was the kitchen sink. Watch out for [burglar](../v4/357.html) (#357 賊) and [rob](../v4/566.html) (#566 奪) and [crime](../v4/1414.html) (#1414 犯). To differentiate it, think that **steal** ing is arbitrary (hence the kitchen sink), [rob](../v4/566.html) (#566 奪) is more deliberate (and hence the protection of the attack turkey) and [burglar](../v4/357.html) (#357 賊) is the most professional of them all (it is his full time job), so he knows when to hit (when everyone is at the fiesta).

column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 17-1-2007(299): If you leave **water** out in the **sun** in a **dish** , naturally it will get _warm_.
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 16-4-2007(30): I'm mixing this up with [warmth](../v4/1949.html) (#1949 暖) far too much. Trying to use mnemonic "Warm Water" - 温泉 （おんせん） obviously relates to _water_ that is **warm** , from the _sun_ and when you think about it, is kind of like a big _dish_.
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 24-2-2008(25): I ate the _sun_ on a _plate_ , and I now feel **warm** inside. I had to drink _water_ to stop this burning.
column8: 4) [[cingold](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cingold)] 8-11-2009(13): To **warm** _water_ , leave it in a _dish_ in the afternoon _sun_.
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 14-3-2011(8): The **warm** water, **warm** sun, and **warm** dish: the three best things to keep you **warm**.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 21-10-2006(78): The **lid** of this _dish_ is _gone_! Now the whole room smells of the _flowers_ that were used in the cooking.
column6: 2) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 15-11-2008(40): The magic **lid** trick: you put flowers in the dish and cover them up with the **lid**. Then you lift and the flowers are gone!
column7: 3) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 18-5-2009(12): The waiter of a fancy restaurant takes the **lid** away and what you see is - nothing! The food is _gone_ \- somebody has stolen it. All what has been left from the _dish_ is the decoration, a single _flower_ …
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-2-2009(9): You're tunelessly singing, "Where have all the _flowers gone_? Gone to _dishes_ every one…", and someone shouts, "Put a **lid** on it!".
column9: 5) [[Altaira](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Altaira)] 27-4-2012(5): When the magician lifted the **LID** , the _flowers_ were _gone_ from the _dish_.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(203): The slavetrader **oversees** the slaves washing _dishes_ int he kitchen. No _reclining_ on the _floor_!
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 1-11-2007(79): The _slaves_ are _reclining_ on the _floor_ when the **oversee** r comes in. They tell him "We're not goofing off, a _dish_ fell and broke and we're cleaning it off the _floor_ ".
column7: 3) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 20-3-2008(35): While the slave-buyer is perusing ([perusal](../v4/855.html) (#855 覧)) the stack of **slaves reclining on the floor** , the slaves' **oversee** r supplies them with **dishes** of gruel – don't want the slaves starving to death before they can be sold!
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 28-10-2005(18): Mnemonic : "The **oversee** r **oversee** s that the _slaves_ are washing the _dishes_ instead of _reclining_ on the _floor_ (having a siesta)".
column9: 5) [[blackstockc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blackstockc)] 6-2-2008(10): The plantation master **oversee** s his slaves crawling on the floor and eating from the same plate.

column5: 1) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 24-5-2006(186): Who's job is it to oversee the water level on the dam? It'ts **overflow** ing!
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(112): The _overseer_ isn't doing his job and he lets the slaves **overflow** the sink!
column7: 3) [[dilandau23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau23)] 14-3-2007(30): When _water_ **overflow** s it is usually because someone was not properly _overseeing_ the task. Image: A mother talking on the phone, _overseeing_ the drawing her kid's bath, boiling something on the stove, and breaking up a fight between two of the kids. Something is bound to **overflow**.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 22-3-2009(17): This is the _overseer_ from the previous kanji, who was watching the slave wash the dishes. Unfortunately, the reclining _overseer_ fell asleep and didn't notice when the _water_ starting **overflow** ing from the sink. ……………………………………………………………………. An alternate version of this story would be the famous scene from Fantasia where Mickey falls asleep and stops _overseeing_ the brooms bringing in _water_ , so the room **overflow** s.
column9: 5) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 23-6-2009(14): Water will **overflow** … if you do not oversee.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(173): The _overseer_ tags his slaves with _gold_ earrings, just like **specimens**.
column6: 2) [[markjohnquinn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/markjohnquinn)] 3-9-2008(98): (Thanks bodhisamaya) The authorities are suspicious about the athlete that won GOLD at the olympics. They are now OVERSEEING a thorough drug test, taking all sorts of **SPECIMEN** S.
column7: 3) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 6-7-2008(38): Professor Hojo OVERSEEs his **SPECIMEN** S in their METAL tanks.
column8: 4) [[Moses](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Moses)] 15-2-2010(37): The _overseer_ tags his favorite slave with _gold_ earrings. "Ah, what a fine **specimen**!".
column9: 5) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 9-6-2006(21): The overseer demands a golden shower into the **specimen** jar.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(65): **Indigo** _flowers_ have to be _overseen_ because they are often picked for their beauty.
column6: 2) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 5-1-2010(45): Traditionally, 青 [blue](../v4/1534.html) (#1534 青) could be used to describe blue OR green. However, two kanji that describe the hues specifically are 藍 and 緑 . This kanji is the "blue" counterpart of [green](../v4/1371.html) (#1371 緑). Story: The _overseer_ , master of the slaves, wore a cloak dyed with **indigo** , and _flowers_ in his hair.
column7: 3) [[Drack](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Drack)] 26-8-2011(16): <Http://gaijinsmashnet.wordpress.com/2007/06/28/1-kyuu/> Reading this rant by a non-RTKer mentioning this particular kanji made me remember it very well.
column8: 4) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 10-1-2009(9): **Indigo** _flowers_ have to be closely _overseen_ during the growing process, otherwise they'll be useless for making **indigo** dye.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 8-4-2007(5): The princess who likes to _oversee_ the making of her dishes, often wears **indigo** coloured clothes. **Indigo** is made from _flowers_.

column5: 1) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 28-6-2009(291): The **fierce** WILD DOG attacked the CHILD who came near his feeding DISH.
column6: 2) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 16-1-2009(44): I picture a **fierce** little fat kid, defending his dish of food from a pack of dogs.
column7: 3) [[teiohx2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/teiohx2)] 31-7-2007(31): If you want to make your wild dogs **fierce** , feed them a child. Children are the holy grail of dogfood you know…
column8: 4) [[jaresty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jaresty)] 16-11-2007(28): If you want to make your wild dogs **fierce** , put a child in their dish.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-10-2007(13): Ok, I'll bring in a 300 reference. A **FIERCE** pack of WILD DOGS fight an even **FIERCE** R spartan CHILD over the food left on the PLATE. The CHILD won and was declared king.

column3: Here **boom** refers to something that is popular and prospering. Its elements: _turn into_ . . . _dish_.
column5: 1) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 28-4-2006(301): Japan's economic **boom** turned their empty plates into full ones.
column6: 2) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 16-1-2006(65): The **boom** of satellite TV has made antennas _turn into_ _dishes_.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 4-10-2006(30): The Chinese kitchen is famous for knowing how to _turn_ anything slightly edible _into_ a good _dish_. That's one of the reasons why their cuisine **boom** ed all over the world.
column8: 4) [[cangy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cangy)] 16-3-2008(24): Yoshinoya is enjoying a popularity **boom** because of the promotion where all their _dish_ es are _turned into_ 大 **盛** り sized _dish_ es at no extra charge. [おおもり, "a large serving"].
column9: 5) [[nakome](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nakome)] 14-6-2008(20): The Japanese have a phrase, マイブーム (my **boom** ), which refers to something that a person is currently obsessed with or fascinated by. This kanji depicts the **boom** as a certain _dish_ that has just _turned into_ a national trend.

column5: 1) [[bigloui](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bigloui)] 29-3-2006(228): In the old days, **salt** was a worth alot, so it is not surprising to find someone _reclining_ on the _ground_ , _mouth_ to _plate_ , getting every last grain of that delicious **salt**.
column6: 2) [[Weber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Weber)] 21-2-2007(78): Remember the mock sushi documentary that circulated a while ago: "Because some feel that the shoyu was not **salt** y enough, complementary **salt** dishes are provided on the ground outside the sushiya, you can recline and put as much as you desire in your mouth".
column7: 3) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 12-11-2006(53): It is bad luck to spill **salt** on the _ground_ , so you better _recline_ and lick it into your _mouth_ or put it back on the _dish_.
column8: 4) [[joxn_costello](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joxn_costello)] 12-1-2009(25): This is a picture of an artificial **salt** lick on the _grounds_ of a nature preserve: animals can go there, _recline_ , and use their _mouths_ to lick the **salt** from a _dish_.
column9: 5) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 21-8-2010(10): In a **SALT** pan, all the **soil** is actually **SALT**. You can **recline** , taste it with your **mouth** , and put it in your **dish**. <http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Salar_Uyuni_Bolivie.JPG/300px- Salar_Uyuni_Bolivie.JPG> <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salt_pan_%28geology%29>.

column5: 1) [[Pauline](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Pauline)] 3-7-2007(165): Like _gold_ , _silver_ is a _metal_.
column6: 2) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 23-1-2008(52): Not sure why Heisig find the right side so troublesome. My grandma's _hairpin_ (just before [long](../v4/1920.html) (#1920 長)) is made of **silver** , the metal that best reflects _sun_ light. I'm sure you can see the flash from her hair as she walks by on a sunny day. Note that the two elements ( _sun_ and _hairpin_ ) share not only a horizontal stroke, but also the left vertical one. Therefore a bit odd stroke order.
column7: 3) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 21-1-2009(26): _Metal_ that is **silver** is **silver**!
column8: 4) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 28-2-2009(20): **Silver** is almost as [good](../v4/1468.html) (#1468 良) as gold, but not quite (one stroke missing).
column9: 5) [[Nijuro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nijuro)] 21-7-2010(10): In order of value, it goes: _gold_ , then _**silver**_.

column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(347): The athlete's _state of mind_ is nothing but **resentment** after getting the _silver_ medal.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 2-9-2007(73): _Data_ 's greatest **resentment** is getting a _silver_ medal in Science Olympiad. (Image: _Data_ fuming on the podium muttering about being half robot).
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 2-5-2007(18): What is your state of mind when you win silver? You resent that you didn't win gold!
column8: 4) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 28-2-2009(8): **Regret** at missing the gold means a silver medalist's state of mind = **resentment** [True phenomenon: bronze medalists are happier than silver because they are just glad that they medalled at all.].
column9: 5) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 31-3-2008(5): Data felt **resentment** toward the Silver Surfer for being able to fly through space freely while he was always trapped on the Enterprise with Picard and Riker doing dumb missions.

column5: 1) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 28-10-2007(227): Since trees eat through their **root** s, one could imagine **root** s as _tree silver_ ware.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(109): The **root** s of the magical _tree_ are _silver_.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 18-6-2006(42): In the kanji for **root** (not the primitive), I imagine a _tree_ whose **root** s end up in _silverware_ , which the _tree_ uses somehow to eat whatever is underground.
column8: 4) [[Weber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Weber)] 21-2-2007(22): Think of how if you look at the **root** s of many trees, they are not brown like the rest of the trunk, they sometimes are a whitish, silver color, because they are full of water and nutrients, rather than course cellulose like what is needed up top to protect from the elements.
column9: 5) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 22-7-2009(18): The _tree_ with _silver_ on it (the Christmas tree) has NO **root** s.

column5: 1) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 28-6-2006(307): He scratches off the _silver_ _stamp_ and discovers that he is an **instant** winner.
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(137): For **instant** postal delivery, buy a _silver_ _stamp_!
column7: 3) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 26-2-2007(35): Hint: **Instant** cameras. In photography it only takes an **instant** for the light to reach the _silver_ nitrate on the film and _stamp_ an image on it.
column8: 4) [[tristanthorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tristanthorn)] 18-3-2009(28): **Instant** ramen always has _silver_ foil _stamp_ ed on the top of the cup, as a lid.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 25-1-2010(17): Forewarned is forearmed: careful 忽 [instantaneously](../v4/2431.html) (#2431 忽) & 頓 [immediate](../v4/2788.html) (#2788 頓).

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 20-12-2007(259): An _eagle_ stole the **baron** 's _eye_ in the war, but now he has a _silver_ coin _glued_ in the socket instead.
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(66): Here we see an evil **baron** \- a _vulture_ perched on his shoulder, and a _siver_ _eye_ -patch _glued_ to his _eye_.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-9-2008(42): A _vulture_ took the **baron** 's _eye_ , so he _glued_ a _silver_ one in its place.
column8: 4) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 22-2-2006(27): During the first world war there was a german fighter pilot knicknamed the red **baron** (von Richthofen). He was like a _vulture_ , coming from above you see a huge red _eye_ painted on the plane's wings, you see the glint of his many silver medals as he glues himself to your tail, he sights and shoots… pow pow pow the bullets wizz by, soon it will all be over. (it it helps von Richthofen had _silver_ cups engraved for every 'kill' he made).
column9: 5) [[janse112](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/janse112)] 9-5-2013(6): Yes, it is I, the venerable **Baron** _Vultureye_ von _Silverglue_!

column5: 1) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 28-6-2006(268): Counting the **node** s on _bamboo_ is an _instant_ way to tell its age.
column6: 2) [[rhclaghorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rhclaghorn)] 14-3-2008(71): A certain species of _bamboo_ is considered the fastest growing plant in the world. A new _node_ can be formed in an _instant_.
column7: 3) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 12-11-2007(40): Is it just me, or do the **node** s on a _bamboo_ tree look like a stack of Cup Noodle _instant_ soup cups?
column8: 4) [[I_pity_the_fool](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/I_pity_the_fool)] 28-12-2008(25): See the legend here - <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bamboo>. When you see a bamboo tree with a many **node** s, don't be a fool and touch it - you may be joined to it in an instant.
column9: 5) [[Praxix](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Praxix)] 29-1-2010(15): Forget the quicksort algorithm and tree structures, use a bamboo structure and your **node** s will be sorted instantly.

column5: 1) [[DurablePants](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DurablePants)] 23-6-2006(217): You see a huge army of people in silver armour on the road so you **retreat**.
column6: 2) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 25-8-2007(72): In the land of Oz, you advance by following the golden road, but you reatreat by following the _Silver Road_.
column7: 3) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 25-6-2006(48): In Spanish there is a saying which is useful to remember this kanji. It says: "A enemigo que huye, puente de plata," which translates literally as "To enemy that **retreat** s, silver bridge," meaning one should not stay in the way of a **retreat** ing enemy. In the kanji we just replace the silver bridge by a _silver_ _road_.
column8: 4) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 1-11-2007(41): Vampires **retreat** down the _road_ when they see villagers arming themselves with _silverware_.
column9: 5) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 21-12-2006(13): Orders in from HQ: _Retreat_! Grab the **silver** and hit the **road**.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-4-2007(162): The speed **limit** at _The Pinnacle_ is posted on _silver_ signs.
column6: 2) [[pazustep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pazustep)] 10-8-2008(64): At _The Pinnacle_ , they **limit** how much _silver_ you can have. Too much silver will lead to wrongfulness.
column7: 3) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 9-4-2008(50): Not just anyone can gain membership into The Pinnacle, it **limit** s its membership to those with the appropriate amount of silver, both to be used as cash and weaponry in their war against the werewolves. (Mnemonic: Pinnacle **limit** s membership to those with enough silver.).
column8: 4) [[Nuriko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nuriko)] 16-3-2008(18): I'll elaborate on dingomick's story to highlight the importance of "silver" in this story so as not to forget. The speed **limit** at The Pinnacle is posted on silver signs… why do you think they are silver? If you remember the top story from [silver](../v4/1459.html) (#1459 銀), you know that silver is the metal that reflects the most light and therefore draws a lot of attention to it. These people up in the Pinnacle really want you knowin' them **limit** s.
column9: 5) [[Christoph](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christoph)] 14-12-2006(15): I don't think that my _limit_ is **silver**! I know I can reach the **pinnacle**! gold!!

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(156): T-1000. <http://clicknothing.typepad.com/Images_Posts_2006/T1000.jpg>.
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 17-9-2006(102): **_Eye_ balls** made of _silver_. That's what they use to play pachinko with, isn't it?
column7: 3) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 21-4-2008(73): The baron's silver eye was not actually an **eyeball**.
column8: 4) [[SexyMexicanMaid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SexyMexicanMaid)] 19-2-2010(25): Picture an EYE all dressed up in SILVER, on its way to the **EYEBALL**. It's a joke you see.
column9: 5) [[iheckman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/iheckman)] 20-5-2008(18): _"Silver salts have antiseptic properties. AgNO3 is often dropped into newborn babies' eyes at birth to prevent contraction of gonorrhoea or chlamydia from the mother."_ <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_nitrate>.

column4: * As a primitive, use the image of a saint's _halo_. As with _silver_ , when this element is drawn on the left, the penultimate stroke is omitted.
column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 14-6-2007(176): With a _drop_ of _silver_ , the forces of **good** can vanquish the werewolves.
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(88): A _drop_ of _silver_ is **good** , but a whole bar of it is better!
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(38): I'm a _good_ person. See my _drop of silver HALO_?
column8: 4) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 4-10-2009(13): A _drop_ of _silver_ is **good**.
column9: 5) [[cornrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cornrow)] 11-12-2008(11): A _DROP_ of _SILVER_ is really **GOOD** for you. (It's true… people dilute it and take shots).

column5: 1) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 16-11-2007(180): [Image: 'Moonlight sonata'] The _moon_ has inspired many _good_ composers (like Ludwig van Beethoven) to write something **melodious**.
column6: 2) [[naniwa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/naniwa)] 4-3-2007(90): A glowing _halo_ surrounds a magnificent full _moon_. A perfect image of the mythic and **melodious** music of the spheres.
column7: 3) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 25-8-2007(42): 'Au clair de la lune' (in the halo of the moon) is a **melodious** french lullaby ( <http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Au_clair_de_la_lune> ).
column8: 4) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 1-8-2007(29): "GOOD MOON Rising" has a nice **melody** ….what? It's called "Bad Moon Rising"? my mistake.
column9: 5) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 4-7-2009(20): [Image: 'Moonlight sonata'] many _good_ composers (like Ludwig van Beethoven) have been inspired by the _moon_ to write something **melodious**. (This is misha's story, with the order changed around).

column5: 1) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 7-9-2008(183): _Water_ is a _good_ thing to have when you're out **wandering**.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 20-12-2007(91): John the Baptist with a _halo_ sprinkling _water_ on people as he's **wandering** the wilderness.
column7: 3) [[wingedge](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wingedge)] 23-12-2007(63): _Jesus_ (the halo) **wanders** idly over the _water_.
column8: 4) [[skinnyneo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skinnyneo)] 18-11-2007(18): You end up **wandering** through lots of _water_ in _Halo the video game._.
column9: 5) [[kodorakun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kodorakun)] 5-5-2010(16): Note this is the kanji used in "rounin", the **wandering** samurai (usually a badass vagrant dude): 浪人 (water-good).Water is a good thing to have when you're out **wandering**.

column5: 1) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 30-11-2008(180): Your **daughter** is a good girl……well, let's hope so… :-).
column6: 2) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 25-7-2008(80): Be careful **not** to think woman + angel here, which has already been seen for [attractive](../v4/430.html) (#430 嬌). Suggest using _woman_ with a _halo_ , as in an innocent girl, something that everyone sees their **daughters** as being.
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 12-7-2006(33): Parents wish that their **daughter** grows up to be a good woman.
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(9): Daddy's little _girl_ ( **daughter** ) is an _angel_!
column9: 5) [[terozen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/terozen)] 25-3-2012(7): A _woman_ with a _halo_ , that's what your **daughter** seems like while she's growing up. But you have no idea ,).

column3: If _halo_ and _umbrella_ aren't enough, break the _halo_ down into _drop_ and _silver_ \- or  "silverware," an additional primitive.
column4: * As a primitive, this kanji can mean either _eating_ or _food_. As with _silver_ , on the left the final two strokes of this element are combined into one.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 4-4-2007(173): That _umbrella_ looks _good_ enough to **eat**!
column6: 2) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 30-9-2008(51): Umbrella + Good: Let's go **eat** at that restaurant - the table with the _umbrella_ looks _good_.
column7: 3) [[lee101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lee101)] 15-9-2012(23): I've been waiting for this kanji for so long…
column8: 4) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 23-1-2008(17): Imagine the _halo_ when you pray before the meal. The people queuing up outside the restaurant in the rain with an _umbrella_ couldn't care less about your sanctimoniousness.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 8-1-2006(12): Note : as a primitive I use the image of a hamburger, or "fast food".

column5: 1) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 4-6-2008(245): I'm _anti_ -fast _food_. Sit down and eat a real **meal**!
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(53): I'm _Anti-_ McDonald's. _Anti-_ Happy **Meal**. _Anti-hamburger_.
column7: 3) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 8-9-2008(30): Part of every traditional Italian **meal** is when they _eat_ the _anti-_ pasto first. (Antipasto is not a food, it's the first course, see Wikipedia.).
column8: 5) [[hunchbag](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hunchbag)] 14-11-2009(16): Before a good **meal** , _eat_ _anti_ pasto!

column5: 1) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 28-10-2007(152): When you _lack food_ , just **drink** something to fill you up.
column6: 2) [[dilandau23](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau23)] 27-2-2007(117): In Japan, the one thing I always seem to be _lacking_ with my _food_ is a properer sized **drink**. Instead I have to **drink** that shot glass of water.
column7: 3) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 3-7-2008(72): Always the same in those restaurants. You've already received your **drink** and you're waiting so long for your _food_ that you begin to _yawn_.
column8: 4) [[Georgi87](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Georgi87)] 9-4-2008(31): VERY easy! Food alone is never enough - without a **drink** , our meal would be lacking! After all, food lacks the water that we get from **drink** ing.
column9: 5) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(6): After _eating_ I like to have a big _yawn_ and a cool _drink_.

column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 21-1-2007(297): The smell of cooked _food_ wafts past you in the _wind_ , making your stomach rumble and feeling **hungry**.
column6: 2) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 24-10-2007(67): The _wind_ blew away my _food_ , so now I'm **hungry**.
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 19-1-2006(36): When you feel the _wind_ (or even hear it) in your stomach, that means you're **hungry** and you need to _eat_. Imagine your stomach like an empty, barren desert, and the _wind_ blowing through it.
column8: 4) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 9-4-2008(14): If all you had to eat was wind, you'd be **hungry** too.
column9: 5) [[Tornadic_Indignation](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tornadic_Indignation)] 7-7-2009(11): I was so **hungry** that I _ate_ my _fart_ s.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 13-12-2006(278): All those starving models in Hollywood - they want to _eat_ , but their _ego_ (about their appearance and trim look) makes sure they grin and bear it!
column6: 2) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 8-10-2008(106): He **starve** s for FOOD but his EGO won't let him beg.
column7: 3) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 17-7-2006(31): He was **starving** for _food_ , but he had too much _ego_ and was too proud to ask for _food_.
column8: 4) [[crayonmaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/crayonmaster)] 5-4-2009(18): A group of high class chefs were trapped in a fast food restaurant. They had such a big ego, they refused to eat any hamburgers, and they all **starve** d to death.
column9: 5) [[zanzibar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zanzibar)] 10-6-2009(9): People use the phrase "I'm starving" too casually. They just want some FOOD, and their EGO causes them to magnify their terminology for effect. If they were really to **starve** , they'd lose their EGOs, and absolutely anything would become FOOD.

column5: 1) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 27-4-2007(200): [decorate, ornament, adorn, embellish] We **decorate** a table before _eating_ , _reclining_ a _towel_ over it.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-5-2007(162): Naked sushi: a lady _reclining_ on a _towel_ as **decoration** for the _food_ laid out on her.
column7: 3) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 22-1-2007(72): In Japanese bukkake movies, an "actress" _reclining_ on a _towel_ is **decorate** d in cum, then has the pleasure of _eating_ it!
column8: 4) [[nite_run](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nite_run)] 20-11-2007(29): You **decorate** your house with pictures of you reclining in a towel surrounded by food.
column9: 5) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 23-2-2006(16): Hint: a fancy picnic.

column3: _Food_ . . . _ear_. The sense of the key word here is that of bait or **feed** for animals.
column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-3-2007(71): _Food_ made of _ears_ is animal **feed**.
column6: 2) [[mairov](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mairov)] 22-3-2008(30): Do you know Mike Tayson favorite **feed**? Ears! He eats ears!
column7: 3) [[tanaquil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tanaquil)] 27-3-2010(28): When I bring out the can opener to open the _food_ , my cat's _ears_ prick right up. **Feed** ing time!
column8: 4) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 14-1-2010(9): Pavlov's dog knew that **FEED** had been set out for him to EAT whenever his EARS heard the bell.
column9: 5) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 27-7-2009(8): **Feed** him until the FOOD comes out of his EARS.

column3: The abbreviation of **Building** suggests that this kanji is used in proper names, as indeed it often is. Keep your connotation distinct from _Inst._ (Frame 1401) when working with the elements: _food_ . . . _bureaucrat_.
column5: 1) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 24-2-2008(211): A **building** that _eats_ _bureaucrats_!!!!!!!!
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(163): This **Bldg.** is like all the other government buildings - they house _bureaucrats_ who sit around sipping wine and _eating_ expensive meals at the taxpayers expense.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 25-9-2008(40): The _bureaucrat_ never goes out for lunch, always choosing to _eat_ in the **Bldg.**
column8: 4) [[jamestaverner](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jamestaverner)] 21-2-2008(15): Empire State **Building** (to avoid confusing with [government office](../v4/591.html) (#591 庁) and [Inst.](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1304) (#1304 院)). _McDonalds_ lobbies the _bureaucrats_ by treating them to a lavish feast at the top of the Empire State **Building**.
column9: 5) [[BlackMarsh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BlackMarsh)] 8-1-2006(11): As this is a type of abbreviation you can assume that the building type is that of a government organisation. And we all know the type of people found in these "bldgs" - fat bureaucrats who have eaten too much food.

column3: _Mochi_ is the glutinous rice the Japanese pound into cakes. Its primitives are: _food_ . . . _puzzle_.
column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 12-9-2007(62): Call your friend and he answers the phone "Mochi, **mochi**!" whatever he is _eating_ sure is making it hard to understand. I will _puzzle_ over the content of our conversation for some time to come.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 30-7-2009(18): **Mochi** is like a _puzzle_ you _eat_ and solve in your mouth lest you choke.
column7: 3) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 14-12-2008(15): **Mochi** ice cream is a puzzling food, I still have no idea how they get that ice cream in there, but it sure tastes good.
column8: 4) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 15-1-2010(13): **MOCHI** is so difficult to EAT, it's a PUZZLE to me why people eat it.
column9: 5) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 21-6-2010(9): As a promotion, a **MOCHI** manufacturer starts making them as pieces of a jigsaw. Now kids want to buy them not to eat them, but to solve the week's _FOOD PUZZLE_!

column3: _Sheep_ . . . _food_. The key word has the sense of promoting the development of something, especially in a psychological or spiritual sense.
column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 25-8-2007(162): A sheep became the **foster** parent for a wolf pup, feeding it with milk. This story cannot end well…
column6: 2) [[akotkav](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akotkav)] 9-5-2006(117): You **foster** ("promote the growth of") your sheep well when they have food right at their feet.
column7: 3) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 21-4-2008(103): Judy **Foster** in "The Silence of the _Lamb_ s" is what Dr. Hannibal-the cannibal- Lecter would like to _eat_.
column8: 4) [[uberstuber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberstuber)] 6-6-2007(44): **Foster** a _sheep_ today! Rule 1: don't _eat_ your new _sheep_.
column9: 5) [[delbertmon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/delbertmon)] 6-1-2010(34): You **foster** a sheep so you can eat it later.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(213): My gluttony was only **sated** after I ate the _hamburger_ AND the _wrapper_!
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 19-1-2006(87): This guy is **sated** only after _eating_ the _hamburger_ AND its _wrapping_!
column7: 3) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 29-1-2008(72): 飽きる (P), 厭きる , 倦きる , 倦る 【あきる】 (v1,vi) to get tired of, to lose interest in, to have enough, (P) STORY: This one is easy. You go to a all you can eat steak house and eat FOOD until you are TIRED of it / **Sated**. Then you ask for them to WRAP up the left-overs so you can take them home.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 25-9-2008(55): I was **sated** , so I _wrapped_ up the rest of my _food_ in a doggy bag to take home.
column9: 5) [[Alucard](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Alucard)] 4-1-2007(43): I wonder why my book has a 金 instead of a 食 there.. strange.

column3: _Silver_ . . . _waitress_. Do not confuse this kanji's key word with _before_ (Frame 263).
column5: 1) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 20-1-2008(222): Distinguish from [formerly](../v4/501.html) (#501 曽). Think of **previously** as "the previous customer" in a restaurant. At a cheap sleazy diner, the _waitress_ gives you unwashed _silver_ ware that was **previously** used by the previous customer. Yuck.
column6: 2) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 8-1-2008(78): For the waitress primitive, I don't really see the receipt. So instead, I imagine a waitress holding a plate above her head, using those legs to weave through the tables.
column7: 3) [[jotun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jotun)] 2-6-2008(31): **Previously** on The Silver Surfer. The Silver Surfer took the _Silver Waitress_ back to his place. Now we get to see what happens next.
column8: 4) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 14-1-2007(28): **Previously** - > **previews** at the movies. Almost all the actresses on the _silver_ screen **previously** were _waitresses_. Story by mspertus.
column9: 5) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 20-6-2007(24): **Previously** , we left some _silver_ on the table for the _waitress_.

column3: _Roots_ . . . _waitress_. Note that the kanji meaning of the two primitives to the right is not used here because we shall later meet a primitive meaning _beforehand_ and want to preempt any confusion. The same holds true in the following frame.
column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 1-9-2007(221): A murder has been commited. A corpse was found under a _tree_. The police chalks the **outline** of the victim, an old _silvered_ -haired _waitress_ working at a restaurant nearby.
column6: 2) [[RobMow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RobMow)] 16-9-2009(60): If you attempted to **outline** the biography of most famous actresses, you'd find that they have _roots_ working as _waitresses_ before getting their big break.
column7: 3) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 17-6-2006(31): If you look at the **outline** (resume/CV) of any professional woman, you'll probably find that while a student she was a _waitress_ part-time so that she could pay the bills, so you could say that most professional women have their "roots" in being a _waitress_.
column8: 4) [[Dustin_Calgary](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dustin_Calgary)] 10-1-2009(15): The chalk **OUTLINE** of a murdered TREE. It was hit by a car and crashed to the ground. All that remains now is a chalk **OUTLINE** where the TREE was PREVIOUSLY laying dead, before being thrown into the chipper.
column9: 5) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 20-6-2007(14): Some restaurants use _wooden_ signs to **outline** the amount of _silver_ one should leave for the _waitress_.

column5: 1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 20-6-2007(200): If you don't leave some _silver_ as a tip, you will **rue** the day you earned the _resentment_ of your _waitress_.
column6: 2) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 30-6-2006(41): The _resentment_ of a _waitress_ who gave up going to college to help her boyfriend (with his tuition). She **rue** s that decision ever since she got dumped by him (just after he graduated).
column7: 3) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 7-9-2008(32): _Data_ is angry…he gave all his _silver_ to the lady who was supposedly his _waitress_. She ran out the door and left him with no money to pay the bill! He shouts, 'You will **rue** the day you stole my silver!'.
column8: 4) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 6-10-2008(18): State of mind + Previously: To **rue** something is to let your _state of mind_ be ruled by whatever _previously_ happened.
column9: 5) [[jamestaverner](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jamestaverner)] 21-2-2008(12): I'm English so when I go to Paris, they really _resent_ me. Sitting in a cafe on any **rue** , I can see the _resentment_ in the _waitresses'_ faces. After what they do to my food, I **rue** eating there! [after gorgon].

column3: This character is easiest remembered as a pictograph of a water lily floating on the surface of the water, which gives it its meaning of **even**. The fourth stroke represents the calm, smooth surface of a pond, and the final stroke the long stem of the plant reaching underwater.
column4: * As a primitive, this kanji can keep its pictographic meaning of a _water lily_.
column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 15-10-2006(106): There's an **even** covering of _water lilies_ on the pond at 金閣寺 （きんかくじ） the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto.
column6: 2) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 7-9-2008(50): **Even** if Heisig showed me in person, I still wouldn't believe that this is a _water lily_. I don't get it.
column7: 3) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 9-4-2008(28): The graph of an **even** function [f(x)] will be symmetrical over the y-axis, as this kanji appears to be.
column8: 4) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 28-2-2008(23): If you take scissors and cut off the upper part of its primitive and then close your scissors, you get an **even** kanji.
column9: 5) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 22-7-2009(19): This is **even** as in flat, level, smooth, calm (not like "even if" or "even though").

column3: _Mouth_ . . . _water lily_. Note: this is the one time that the  "stem" has a barb at the end. Work this fact into your story.
column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 9-5-2007(270): I'm a lazy fisher, so I genetically engineered a _lily pad_ with a _fishing hook at the stem_ and a _mouth_ to **call** me whenever it catches something.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 2-9-2007(69): I just follow the **calls** from the frogs _mouths_ on the _lily pads_ to _hook_ them.
column7: 3) [[woodwojr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woodwojr)] 15-7-2008(62): The right portion of this character isn't a water lily at all, we will take it to be a _broken hand_ (see how if you rotate the second and third strokes, you approach the appearance of the character for hand?). In this character, we see someone who is trapped with a _broken hand_ opening their _mouth_ to **call** for help.
column8: 4) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 25-7-2008(29): Inspired by dingomick: 'Budd' - 'weis' - 'er' **call** the frogs _mouths_ from the _liliy pads_ , working to get you _hooked_ on beer. <http://youtube.com/watch?v=f3mXaATLeRM>.
column9: 5) [[cangy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cangy)] 17-3-2008(17): Not really _even_ and first and last strokes are a different stroke type. Frog with open _mouth_ **call** ing out as he slips off the _water-lily, bending it out of shape_.

column3: This kanji belongs to an old Japanese system of measurement and indicates an area of about 36 square feet, or the **area** taken up by **two** tatami **mats**. Its elements: _ground_ . . . _water lily_.
column5: 1) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 28-6-2006(205): A **two-mat area** is just about as much _ground_ as you will need for a _lily_ pond.
column6: 2) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 21-1-2008(114): A **two-mat area** is plenty of space for sleeping in a tent but you won't be comfortable unless the _ground_ is _even_.
column7: 3) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 5-3-2006(30): A **two-mat area** is exactly how much ground a giant lilypad will cover.
column8: 4) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 27-2-2008(21): Place the two mats on the _ground_ _even_ ly to get a **two-mat area**.
column9: 5) [[Weber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Weber)] 21-2-2007(15): Since one full tatami mat's length is twice as long as its width, a two mat area would create an even, square floorspace: a somewhat more convenient unit of measuring the ground.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(203): Good **evaluation** should always be _words_ of _even_ fairness.
column6: 2) [[pm215](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pm215)] 1-1-2009(118): You get an **evaluation** copy of MS _Word_ because you want to **evaluate** whether it's worth buying the full version. At the end of the **evaluation** period the CD turns into a _lily_ pad so you can't use it any more (an innovative new copy- protection trick).
column7: 3) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 4-7-2006(46): Gardeners have developed many _words_ to **evaluate** the health of _lilies_.
column8: 4) [[javiergakusei](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/javiergakusei)] 22-9-2007(34): The first time I delivered a speech in japanese it was a mess! The juries (it was contest) **Evaluate** d me and gave me a bad score because the Words were not said in an Even tone. I guess I was too nervous (true story).
column9: 5) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 24-9-2007(22): _Words_ have to come out in an _even_ tone during a Japanese speaking test, otherwise your **evalutation** will have bad **comments** written all over it, resulting in **criticism** from your teacher. He your (ひょう) teacher though, so it's his fault! NOTE: This kanji also means 'comment'  & 'criticism'.

column5: 1) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 12-6-2006(180): Sheaf? No. This is the sign of the X-Men. I'm going with Wolverine on this one.. Wolverine **reap** s the bad guys with his saber-like claws.
column6: 2) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 18-4-2006(79): A SABRE is used to cut the stalks of plants being **REAP** ED at harvest. They are then combined into a SHEAF.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-9-2008(28): You **reap** what you sow, so sow plenty and **reap** a lot to have a メリ Christmas!
