column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-9-2007(19): The _Scotsman goalkeeper_ took a **dose** of medicine injected by _saber_ , like a real man.
column8: 4) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 23-2-2008(15): See my story for 1729. STORY: If you have one pill and you need to take an even **DOSE** of it twice a day, just cut it as SYMMETRICALLY as possible with your SABER.
column9: 5) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 11-9-2007(15): The _Scotsman_ in huge pain from a hangover demands his doctor adjust his pain killer **dosage** up and threatens him with a _saber_.

column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 12-7-2007(136): When the _goalkeeper_ **finish** es the game, he drinks a lot of _water_ and adjusts himself.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 6-6-2007(98): **Finish** him! Subzero _adjusts_ the _water_ in your body and crushes you into a few million pieces.
column7: 3) [[aniseed](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aniseed)] 6-2-2009(37): After i've **finish** ed having a pee i adjust my trousers.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 5-4-2009(26): After you **finish** exercising, be sure to drink some water and adjust your pace (cool down and stretch).
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 19-12-2007(19): After the _Scotsman goalkeeper_ gave someone a dose of poison [1730], someone from the opposing team engaged him in a match of Mortal Kombat. Uh oh, looks like the _Scotsman_ lost - "Finish Him!!!" and as the **finish** ing punch is delivered, drops of _water_ (ala SNES) come out, not blood…pretty disappointing.

column3: _Plaid_ . . . _fenceposts_ . . . _altar_. This is a  "religious" **purification** , which distinguishes it from the simple kanji for _pure_ (Frame 1659).
column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 20-9-2006(90): A scottish priest in a _tartan_ kilt has put his altar between a couple of _fence posts_ and is now playing the bagpipes in a very Scottish **purification** rite.
column6: 2) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 16-2-2009(62): An exorcism, or "purification" of the soul. The possessed girl is tied to two **posts** next to the **altar** , her head spinning around and around. Then the priest says the required **sentence** : "The power of Christ compels you!".
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 3-12-2007(52): Kind of vulgar, but here the SCOTSMAN got tired of adjusting himself so decided try **PURIFICATION**. Sadly, he did it by straddling the ALTAR with his skinny LEGS.
column8: 4) [[jaresty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jaresty)] 30-11-2007(43): The scottish priest in a _tartan_ kilt is purifying his genitals. He's standing delicately atop two _fence posts_ , and gingerly dipping himself atop the _altar_.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 19-12-2007(27): [+fudo] The _Scotsman goalkeeper_ is going all out to stop balls from crossing the goal line. Here he is in a **purification** ritual with a little mini _altar_ on the goal line, throwing salt about and burning incense in order to **purify** the line. He prays: "Oh dear Lord, let no balls pass this **purified** line of salt and chalk…". He then **purifies** himself by rubbing the mini _altar_ all over under his _kilt_. A shower would do, really…

column3: _Rake_ . . . _rice_ . . . _fenceposts_. Take special care to draw this character in the same order as the primitive. Note too, that the fourth stroke for _rice_ is already taken care of by the fourth stroke of _rake_.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-9-2007(261): Even though it's a maddening task, the monks stay **solemn** as they rake _rice_ between the _fenceposts_.
column6: 2) [[cangy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cangy)] 7-4-2008(169): **Note:** This is not _sieve_ as it has a full _rice_ and not _rice grains_ and the hook is missing from _rake_. Also the given stroke order is incorrect ( _fenceposts_ should come last).
column7: 3) [[LazyNomad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LazyNomad)] 27-6-2009(42): This is a zen rice garden. It is different from rock garden in only one aspect. Here you see _raked_ white _rice_ between the _fenceposts_. In **solemn** silence the monks rake rice every morning.
column8: 4) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 10-8-2007(33): I tie CONDI RICE in between two FENCEPOSTS and prepare for the **SOLEMN** task ahead….beating her over the head with a RAKE.
column9: 5) [[plumage](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/plumage)] 7-4-2009(22): The RICE thrown at the wedding must be RAKED up before the **SOLEMN** funeral procession enters between the FENCE POSTS.

column3: The kanji of this frame refers to the four **bases** that are placed at the corners of a baseball infield. The elements: _field_ . . . _sparkler_ . . . _ground_.
column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 10-5-2007(246): Playing baseball in a _rice field_ with _sparklers_ stuck into the _ground_ to act as **bases**.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-9-2007(72): The traditional New Year's baseball game in Japan is held at midnight in a _rice field_. They stick _sparklers_ in the _ground_ for the **bases** so they can be seen, and to be more festive.
column7: 3) [[Angrybeez](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Angrybeez)] 20-5-2008(47): _Warning! warning! Base compromised initiating Computer on self destruct mode_.
column8: 4) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 28-9-2006(21): The surprise attack came from left- _field_! Somebody set us up the _sparkler_! How are we gentelmen? All your **base** are belong to us! But no, they stood their _ground_ and sent out the ZIG! For great justice!
column9: 5) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 29-3-2007(19): This means **bases** as in baseball, otherwise a fort. The original form of this kanji is 壘, a pictogram of four **bases** , the home base marked specially.

column5: 1) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 18-1-2008(145): Zelda: Ocarina of Time - The _white sparkly_ thing is Navi. She's hovering/dancing around a _tree_ to the legendary Lost _Woods_ **music**.
column6: 2) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 24-4-2008(84): The most amazing new bird has been found: it's white and produces the most beautiful **music**. It sits in trees all day and shoots out sparks as it sings.
column7: 3) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 8-10-2007(60): There we were at the concert…her voice was like a _dove_ …her dress _sparkled_ …then suddenly, a _tree_ fell on her…..
column8: 4) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 13-6-2008(42): I learned this as enjoyable (which is 楽しい - たのしい） **Music** is - 音楽 - おんがく as in sounds that are enjoyable.
column9: 5) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 9-4-2007(18): The most **enjoyable** kind of **music** is when the conductor conducts with a _white sparkler_ while standing in a _tree_.

column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 28-9-2006(232): New- age **medicine** involves using things like _music_ and _flowers_ (aromatherapy) as treatment.
column6: 2) [[shakkun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shakkun)] 28-6-2008(40): Oh man, this **medicinal** marijuana is making me hear MUSIC and see FLOWERS everywhere…
column7: 3) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 7-10-2011(33): _Flowers_ and _music_ are the best **medicine** to make you happy.
column8: 4) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 13-7-2007(16): You go to the 薬屋 to fill the prescription for your **medicine** , and upon opening the jar, a _flower_ pops up and _music_ starts playing.
column9: 5) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 26-11-2006(14): **Medicine** commercials these days don't even tell you what the **medicine** does! They just play some uplifting _music_ and show people frolicking through fields of _flowers_.

column5: 1) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 5-2-2008(152): Keep separate from proportion. _Gandalf_ is trying to adjust the aspect **ratio** of his monitor from 4:3 to 16:9 so that he can watch Lord of the Rings in widescreen format. He's poking around the inside of his monitor with a magnesium _needle_ when he causes a short circuit which sets his needle on fire making the needle look just like a _sparkler_.
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 28-9-2006(137): It's quite _mysterious_ how each _sparkler_ gives of sparkles at a precise **ratio** of _ten_ to one. Physicists have been studying this effect for decades, known as the Sparkler Effect, and using it to explain why stars look like sparklers in the night sky.
column7: 3) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 2-8-2008(58): A witches spell requires the proper **RATIO** of ingredients: "TEN SPARKLERS and TEN COCOONS into the HAT ye load, wait TEN minutes and watch it explooooode! hehehehehe".
column8: 4) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 14-6-2008(40): When I first started downloading torrents, I thought that **ratio** s were very mysterious. Now I keep a _sparkling ten_ to one **ratio**!
column9: 5) [[uberclimber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberclimber)] 19-3-2011(22): When the world's **ratio** of women to men _mysteriously_ changed to _ten_ to one overnight, the men all lit _sparklers_ in celebration: "Hey fellas! We're all gonna get laid!". 率 りつ rate, 軽率 けいそつ rash, thoughtless, careless, hasty, 率いる ひきいる to lead, to spearhead (a group), to command (troops).

column5: 1) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 20-2-2008(184): If you eat something **astringent** _water_ will _stop_ the _sparkly_ sensation in your mouth.
column6: 2) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 6-7-2006(144): I think that Heisig meant this as the "slightly bitter but fresh" meaning that it can have to describe foods like lemons (しぶい). So imagine a guy trying a cocktail ( _water_ ), feeling like he's been kicked in the face ( _footprint_ ) and _sparks_ are flying from his tongue. 'How did it taste?'. 'Hmm, yes, slightly bitter, but fresh".
column7: 3) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 23-10-2007(51): An **astringent** is also a medical term for something that causes puckering of the flesh or can stop bleeding. An **astringent** is the _liquid_ you'd need if you _step_ on a _sparkler_.
column8: 4) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-9-2007(21): Only **astringent** _water_ is strong enough to _stop_ a _sparkler_.
column9: 5) [[Mary_K](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Mary_K)] 24-9-2009(16): You ate something **astringent**? Quickly drink this _water_ here to _stop_ the _sparkly_ sensation. (+meolox).

column5: 1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 13-7-2007(146): Now that I'm a responsible adult, I have to get my **vicarious** thrills from watching stupid people put _sparklers_ up to their _ears_ and burn their _fingers_.
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 1-5-2007(128): I put my _fingers_ in my _ears_ to avoid going deaf while getting a **vicarious** thrill from watching kids light off _sparklers_ and fireworks on Chinese New Year.
column7: 3) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 24-2-2008(28): 摂る 【とる】 (v5r) to take something into the body, to absorb nourishment. 摂取 【せっしゅ】 (n,vs) (1) intake, absorption, adoption, (2) assimilation, (P) STORY: One way to TAKE IN SOME NOURISHMENT INTO THE BODY is to take your FINGER, dig around in your EAR, then eat whatever SPARKLY matter you may find.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 19-12-2007(23): [+mspertus] My friend is too afraid of loud noises, so while we go out to enjoy the _sparklers_ and _fireworks_ on New Years, he stays at home and watches everything on TV so he can have a **vicarious** experience. Just the sight of them freaks him out though, so he watches with the volume low and his _fingers_ firmly planted in his _ears_.
column9: 5) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 3-12-2007(10): Old southern joke. It was a **VICARIOUS** situation, the man lights a firecracker (SPARKLES), then stuck his FINGER in his EARS to prepare for the boom. Sadly, he was still holding the firecracker.

column3: The elements depict a _St. Bernard_ with its head and paws keeping their stick-like form, but with the middle or **center** of its body filled out in a box-like shape.
column5: 1) [[pjhoover](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pjhoover)] 6-11-2008(143): A person with a big mouth wants to be the **center** of attention.
column6: 2) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 30-8-2007(122): Youve got the st bernard dead centre in your sights (the box).
column7: 3) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 7-12-2006(13): You must get the explosive into the **center**. The armor will protect him otherwise. The key is to wait for the _mouth_ of the _St. Bernard_ to be open, and then fling the dynamite into the **center** of it.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 19-12-2007(11): For the primitive, I'll try a _big_ boxy _target_ \- like the kind you use to line up your enemy in a videogame before you blow it up. Here, though - you're given the opportunity to finally kill that _St Bernard_ from _Duck Hunt_ \- just make sure to line it up in the _center_ of your _target_ …
column9: 5) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 20-7-2010(9): I see this as a modern-day pictogram for someone walking in carrying a big birthday cake, with one fat candle at its **CENTRE** (to remind me that the **CENTRE** vertical juts up from the "cake"), and to be placed at the **CENTRE** of a table, in honor of the person who's the day's **CENTRE** of attention. (I use the **CENTRE** instead of **CENTER** to promote the connection with [England](../v4/1741.html) (#1741 英), 英 .).

column3: _Flowers_ . . . _center_. This is another abbreviation used to identify a country by the pronunciation of the kanji.
column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 11-8-2006(124): The original great seal of the king of **England** had a very ornate _flower_ in the _center_.
column6: 2) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 14-9-2010(83): **England** was once the _flowering_ _center_ of civilization.
column7: 3) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 29-12-2006(48): **England** is a country where people think they're the flower at the center of the world. (a description that would fit China much better.. 中華 ).
column8: 4) [[guidedog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/guidedog)] 25-2-2007(35): **England** , country of flower shows and big, fat dogs (I live in **England** , it's true).
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 16-10-2005(20): In a rare display of class, the **England** supporters throw _flowers_ at the _center_ of the football stadium.

column5: 1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 29-12-2006(360): In the solar system, the Sun is the central source of all light, everything else just **reflect** s it.
column6: 2) [[sacmaliyorsun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sacmaliyorsun)] 3-3-2008(58): A _solar_ power plant consists of thousands of mirrors **reflect** ing the _sun_ 's rays, concentrating the energy on a focal point at the _centre_. See here: <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_Two>.
column7: 3) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 1-1-2007(13): You can build a very powerful camp stove just by using metalic mirrors to **reflect** the _sun_ onto a cooking surface at the _center_.
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 16-10-2005(9): Imagine the _sun_ , at the _center_ of our solar system, like a huge disco- ball (a ball made with hundreds of tiny mirrors), **reflect** ing the light from the planets and stars around (instead of emitting light on its own). The kanji refers to images which are **reflect** ed, mirrored and also projected, as in the kanji compound 映画 (eiga) : a movie, film. A projected image is like a **reflect** ion of the original material.
column9: 5) [[andresito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/andresito)] 19-5-2009(4): [「えい」画](midori://search?text=「えい」画) A movie **reflects** the _central days_ of the person filmed.

column3: _Ground_ . . . _dagger_ . . . _little_. The two strokes of the _dagger_ take the place of the middle stroke of _little_.
column4: * As a primitive on the left, this kanji keeps the same form. Elsewhere, the first two strokes are abbreviated to a single dot. This latter form will take the meaning of an _apple_.
column5: 1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 30-6-2006(204): He was stabbed with a _dagger_ , and _little_ drops of **red** blood dropped onto the _ground_.
column6: 2) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 30-9-2007(55): There was **red** all over the _soil_ after Little **Red** Riding Hood plunged a _dagger_ into the wolf. Those two dots we see are wolfies _animal legs_ we see, by the way (a la smithsonian).
column7: 3) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 25-1-2007(24): (I prefer to use _animal legs_ instead of _little_ so as not to resort to combining it with _dagger_ :) The cow refused to leave the temple _grounds_ , even when it was threatened with a _dagger_. Its _animal legs_ just stayed planted firmly there so it could show its devotion to Buddha. This is the story of ''akabeko'', the **red** cow, a popular myth in the Aizu region of Japan.
column8: 4) [[jmcanally](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jmcanally)] 10-2-2010(13): This is a mass grave for _animal and human legs_. The serial killer is a Japanese guy with short legs and long-leg envy, so he cuts off legs that are longer than his and buries them here. Notice that since the legs have been cut off one-by-one and tossed in the grave randomly so the animal legs look a bit far apart and the human legs look a bit different than usual (direction of the curve of the right leg is opposite the usual). The _ground_ is still **RED** with from all the blood spilled.
column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 15-10-2009(12): The _soil_ was **red** after the hunter used his _dagger_ to cut off the _animal's legs_.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 3-4-2007(158): The student blushed until his face was red, so the schoolmaster decided to **pardon** him.
column6: 2) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 8-11-2006(46): Blushing _red_ while asking for a **pardon** from the _taskmaster_.
column7: 3) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 18-8-2009(16): **Pardon** the fart of the RED faced TASKMASTER.
column8: 4) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 5-10-2009(14): "Um… **pardon** me," says a very _red taskmaster_ , after he lets one go.
column9: 5) [[kanjihito](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kanjihito)] 11-11-2012(12): Turning _red_ with embarrassment, he appealed to the _taskmaster_ for a **pardon** (compare with [salvation](../v4/936.html) (#936 救)).

column5: 1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 13-2-2008(266): It's quite **unusual** and **abnormal** to see an _apple_ with _walking legs_ running away from the person who wants to eat it!
column6: 2) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 3-12-2007(67): Imagine an _apple_ on _walking legs_ on stage singing "It's not **unusual** to be loved by anyone" (Tom Jones). Keyword can be confused with [uncommon](../v4/1797.html) (#1797 異).
column7: 3) [[guidedog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/guidedog)] 25-2-2007(61): It is **unusual** in the obese US to eat _apples_ or to _walk_.
column8: 4) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 7-7-2006(42): In Japan, it's very **unusual** for people to eat whilst _walking_ down the street. When Japanese people visit western countries and see someone eating an _apple_ or a banana on the street, they find it very strange. This is true.
column9: 5) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 1-10-2007(11): Sexual pervert 変態 （へんたい） **Unusual** behaviour?

column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 22-4-2007(317): Pirate pokes the tip of his _wooden leg_ into an _apple_ to disguise his **tracks**.
column6: 2) [[erikkusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erikkusan)] 23-3-2006(37): To hide his distinctive wood-leg **tracks** , this pirate is throwing apples after his **tracks** in order for animals to come and confuse his **tracks**.
column7: 3) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 26-11-2008(33): Leg + Red: The **tracks** made by his bleeding _leg_ were _red_.
column8: 4) [[fiminor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fiminor)] 9-3-2007(17): Hint: the pirate is Captain Barbosa from Pirates of the Caribbean. Remember his fixation with apples?
column9: 5) [[elmaestrokgb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elmaestrokgb)] 1-8-2009(9): Sir, these are definitely fake **tracks**. How do you know? One foot is a _wooden leg_ , and the other is an _apple_.

column5: 1) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 3-5-2008(278): The **barbarian** picks an _apple_ from above and eats it even though there is a worm ( _insect_ ) in it.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 3-4-2007(39): **Barbarian** s eat apples with worms still in them.
column7: 3) [[Aikou](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aikou)] 16-9-2006(28): **Barbarian** is derived from "barba rossa" which means _red_ beard (true!). In this red beard live lots of disgusting _insects_.
column8: 4) [[zaydana](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zaydana)] 27-5-2009(17): Imagine a **barbarian** choosing between two apples - one full of insects, and one without. The **barbarian** of course decides to eat the one with insects - "I need my meat for the day!".
column9: 5) [[mistamark](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mistamark)] 8-1-2009(4): The **barbarian** eats the _red apple_ , _insect_ and all!!

column5: 1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 12-9-2007(192): The **romance** between Snow White and Prince Charming started when Snow White took a bite of poison _apple_ and her _heart_ stopped.
column6: 2) [[kodama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kodama)] 1-11-2007(94): A childhood **romance** : a boy takes a _red apple_ to school to try to win the _heart_ of his beloved.
column7: 3) [[blackstockc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blackstockc)] 21-1-2008(57): You're the _apple_ of my _heart_!
column8: 4) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 10-8-2008(18): This kanji does not mean "romance" such as romantic love. Here is a common saying:" [恋は追いかけるもの、愛は受け入れるもの](midori://search?text=恋は追いかけるもの、愛は受け入れるもの) ." 恋 means a love that you chase passionately. You are not necessarily loved back, or who you love does not know, in a sense. 愛 however does mean a mutual love, or "romance" between two people. (if you disagree E-mail me) STORY: You fell in LOVE with someone but they told you they don't love you. Now you wish you had that poison APPLE to stop your HEART.
column9: 5) [[fruitangel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fruitangel)] 27-3-2009(12): **Romance** is a big _red heart_.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 13-3-2007(240): In his most daring feat, William tell used his _bow_ to shoot an _apple_ off the head of his son across the _water_ of the **gulf**.
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 5-2-2008(92): An army of archers must cross a **gulf** of _water_. Fortunately there are millions of _apple_ trees growing in the cliffs above the **gulf**. The archers use their _bows_ to shoot down _apple_ after _apple_ , which all fall into the _water_ and slowly fill up the the **gulf** until the archer soliders can cross on foot.
column7: 3) [[Angrybeez](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Angrybeez)] 17-8-2008(38): In the **Gulf** war Iraq troops fight back with _water_ guns, rotten _apples_ and _bow_ 'n' arrows - so much for the 'weapons of mass destruction' !
column8: 4) [[blurp76](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blurp76)] 8-5-2009(32): This is one beauty of a kanji! Looks like a painting of a sunset. You can see the sea (water), the coast shaped like a bow and the red sun (or some red apples trees planted nearby).
column9: 5) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 1-3-2008(11): Legolas shoots over the waters of the **gulf** into the apple on the other side.

column5: 1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 30-6-2006(301): The _salad_ did not look very appetizing… The _sprouts_ were **yellow** and there were _animal legs_ sticking out of it.
column6: 2) [[Thora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thora)] 22-8-2007(48): I order a _salad_ with _sprouts_. I'm asked if I'd like to add chicken. Yes please. My salad then arrives . . . . topped with these horribly gnarled **yellow** things. Chicken feet! ( _animal legs_ ) ugh.
column7: 3) [[TheSlakey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TheSlakey)] 31-12-2008(36): My face turned **yellow** when I watched my salad sprout animal legs and start scurrying across the table. Check please!
column8: 4) [[Angrybeez](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Angrybeez)] 24-6-2008(16): The salad goes **yellow** sprouts legs and runs off.
column9: 5) [[GKKLJapan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GKKLJapan)] 18-7-2011(11): Anyone who's played Final Fantasy knows what a Chocobo is. Chocobos have **YELLOW** plumage and strong ANIMAL LEGS. They are also fond of eating SPROUTS, which has led to the promotion of various Chocobo SALADS.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 3-4-2007(232): A tree went all yellow. It died and fell down, ending up **sideways**.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(75): In a horrible accident, a _yellow_ schoolbus gets wrapped **sideways** around a _tree_.
column7: 3) [[mr_hans_moleman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mr_hans_moleman)] 23-11-2008(28): Imagine a TREE that grows BANANAS that is so heavy that it made the TREE fall **SIDEWAYS**.
column8: 4) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 13-12-2008(11): Guys only _pee_ **sideways** on _trees_ , never up and down.
column9: 5) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 3-10-2009(8): The _tree_ fell **sideways** and _yellow_ fungis grew on it.

column5: 1) [[msukovich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/msukovich)] 3-6-2008(225): Japanese censorship laws require pornos to use a _mosaic_ screen, so you can't see what the porno chick is **grasping** with her _fingers_ (but you can assume, neetch).
column6: 2) [[tristanthorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tristanthorn)] 18-3-2009(139): Your _fingers_ **grasp** the _Rubic's cube_ … if only your brain could too.
column7: 3) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 17-5-2007(43): _Mosaic_ primative = _rubic's cube_. Here _Shrek_ **grasp** s his _Rubic's cube_ trying to get a **grasp** on how it's done.
column8: 4) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 2-3-2007(25): The _Rubik's Cube_ keeps slipping out of my _finger's_ **grasp** every time I try to turn it. One of the children must have been playing with it earlier…
column9: 5) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 2-8-2009(22): To me, the 'mosaic' primitive looks just like a _computer mouse_. ( **Grasp** ing your _fingers_ around the _computer mouse_.).

column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 17-11-2006(213): _Bound up_ in the _Rubik's cube_ are the 6 different **colours**.
column6: 2) [[Haych](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Haych)] 22-11-2008(54): Ever look closely at _mosaic_ s? They contain a bunch of images _bound up_ into a larger one. It seems amazing until you realize that the only quality of the smaller images that really matters is their **colour**.
column7: 3) [[Dragg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dragg)] 13-6-2008(39): A man and woman are BOUND UP in a **color** ful sex act. She bends over, legs tucked underneath, exposing her FULL MOON buttocks in order to be penetrated. *Heisigian liberties aside, this is what the kanji literally means. By reporting this story, you are reporting Japanese to be a naughty language in general.
column8: 4) [[cangy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cangy)] 23-2-2009(28): This kanji has a secondary meaning relating to sex (so stop reading now if you have issues) and originally showed a bending person ( _bound up_ ) over another bending person ( _mosaic_ ). This might help as an alternative to the _mosaic_ primitive. (Say, _doggy-style_? Works ok for [grasp](../v4/1752.html) (#1752 把) " **grasp** the love handles with your _fingers_ during _doggy-style_ ", but I'm not sure about [fertilizer](../v4/1756.html) (#1756 肥)…Oh, wait, how about "be careful with your _flesh_ during _doggy-style_ of you might **fertilize her** "? No? Oh well…).
column9: 5) [[Radii](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Radii)] 2-4-2010(9): If you look into a kaleidoscope it's like a _bound up mosaic_ of **color**.

column6: 2) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 20-2-2008(107): _Spiderman_ has decided to **discontinue** his red _color_ suit in favor of the black one, it looks way cooler.
column7: 3) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 30-6-2006(41): As times move on and fashion tastes inevitably change, _threads_ of certain _colors_ often get **discontinue** d.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 10-7-2009(20): _Spider-Man_ changed the _color_ of his costume fearing if he didn't spice things up they'd **discontinue** his comic.
column9: 5) [[jamiemw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jamiemw)] 4-10-2007(14): _Spiderman_ comics are only available in _colour_ as black and white ones have been **discontinue** d.

column8: 4) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 14-4-2007(20): This means **manure** , comma-shaped ( 巴 2096) output from a certain body part.
column9: 5) [[unauthorized](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/unauthorized)] 8-1-2010(18): Natural **fertilizer** comes from a part of the body that cannot be shown on TV and therefore needs to be covered by mosaic.

column3: This kanji is a pictograph of a small wicker basket. (The extra short stroke in the middle helps keep it distinct from the character for _twenty_.) All one needs to add is some image of **sweet** cakes or breads carried in the basket, and the union of picture and meaning is complete. Take care not to confuse with _confectionary_ (Frame 1203).
column4: * As a primitive, the pictograph's meaning of a _wicker basket_ is used, a small one like the kind used for picnics.
column5: 1) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 10-5-2006(119): Little red riding hood is carrying around a wicker basket filled with **sweet** baked cookies for granny.
column6: 2) [[kumakuma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kumakuma)] 7-7-2008(62): Girls are kinda **sweet** and sexy until they reach their twenties. So 20 minus ONE.
column7: 3) [[Mary_K](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Mary_K)] 12-5-2009(42): **Sweet** _twenty-one_. The next **sweet** number after **sweet** sixteen.
column8: 4) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 17-4-2007(41): I let this be a **honey pot**. Wicker basket just doesn't do it for me.
column9: 5) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 30-9-2007(20): As a primitive, **sweet** manufacturer extraordinaire, _Willy Wonka_.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 15-2-2007(166): Thanks raulir - As many Japanese perverts know, **navy blue** threads conceal school girl sweetness underneath.
column6: 2) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 30-9-2007(94): Much like Violet Beauregarde from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, _Spiderman_ failed to heed _Willy Wonka_ 's warnings, and upon chewing on the 3 course meal chewing gum turned a very navy shade of **navy blue**.
column7: 3) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 17-9-2007(39): The sailor in the **navy blue** uniform grabbed the _lollipop_ from the little girl, but luckily _Spiderman_ swung in and saved it for her.
column8: 4) [[thermal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thermal)] 3-7-2008(27): _Spiderman_ bought his _sweet_ a **navy blue** dress. Imagine Mary Jane walking down some stairs looking dazzling in it.
column9: 5) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-12-2006(14): Girl in a school uniform made of **navy blue** threads carrying a wicker basket.

column3: The key word here refers to the adjective for an unspecified person or thing. Its elements: _wicker basket_ . . . _tree_.
column5: 1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-12-2006(141): I had the same idea as fuabrisu. A generic person is described here as having body sort of like a tree trunk and head sort of like a wicker basket.
column6: 2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 2-3-2008(73): Two girls with a lollipop in a tree gossiping' so-and so did this.' 'really? so-and what did she do' ' o she is sooo wrong..'.
column7: 3) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 3-7-2009(43): Lately I've been seeing a lot of **so-and-so** girls on the street. They have _sweet_ faces, but their bodies look like _tree_ trunks. It's like, damn bitch, if I had your potential, I'd lay off the donuts and hit the gym more often.
column8: 4) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 30-9-2007(41): When _Willy Wonka_ went into the jungle to search for the Oompaloompas, they at first believed him to be a malicious **so-and-so** , and so they chased him up a _tree_.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 22-11-2005(31): Tip : you can make **so-and-so** a person, which will help with the following kanji. Mr **so-and-so** has no defining features, i.e. no mouth, no eyes, just a grey blob.

column5: 1) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 7-9-2006(240): I imagine a clique of catty girls **conspiring** against a another girl…they are exchanging lots of _words_ , chatting about how _so-and-so_ girl is now up to such-and-such (gasp!), and how they will spread the word about it.
column6: 2) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 2-8-2008(37): _Talking_ about _so and so_ behind their back.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 10-7-2009(29): When you **conspire** against someone, you use the _word_ " _so-and-so_ " in case they or one of their friends are listening.
column8: 4) [[erikkusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erikkusan)] 23-3-2006(15): You might hear the words of someone conspiring… "If you do so-and-so…".
column9: 5) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 30-9-2007(10): Yes, it was indeed _Socrates_ who **conspire** d with the Oompaloompas to send _Willy Wonka_ up that _tree_.

column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 4-6-2007(214): In a divorce, the _woman_ needs a **mediator** because she won't talk to that _so- and-so_. Imagine the woman on the ground and the so-and-so up in the tree, and the poor **mediator** climbing up and down, trying to mediate their fight.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 25-4-2007(72): In a divorce, the woman needs a **mediator** because she won't talk to that so-and- so.
column7: 3) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 2-3-2008(36): The two little gossiping girls with their lollipops are having a fight. Now an adult woman (mom or teacher) has to come between them an serve as a **mediator**.
column8: 4) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 7-9-2006(12): Well the " _so-and-so_ "girl that was picked on in the previous frame tattled on the catty girls, and a catfight breaks out…at which point yet another _woman_ was brought forth to be the **mediator** between their squabble. not like that would help things, but whatever…
column9: 5) [[Renaissance](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Renaissance)] 18-11-2009(9): (inspired by akrodha, with basketman integrated in the story) Basketman is going through a divorce. The _woman_ needs a **mediator** because she won't talk to Basketman. Imagine the **mediator** walking back and forth between the woman and Basketman, trying to understand the stuff Basketman is saying from under his basket.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(197): Kasparov practices **deceit** by grabbing your _rook_ while pretending to _yawn_.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 13-3-2007(128): Every day, a smuggler takes _bushel baskets_ on donkeys across the border. But the border patrols can never arrest him for _lack_ of evidence no matter how much they search the _bushel baskets_ : they can't find whatever he is smuggling. What was his **deceit**? He was smuggling donkeys!
column7: 3) [[guidedog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/guidedog)] 28-2-2007(82): Bushel-basket = pictograph of chess rook (running over the board). Trying to deceive the opponent with a yawn while positioning a rook on the board.
column8: 4) [[mattimus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattimus)] 14-11-2009(59): Note - everyone uses this primitive to symbolize chess/rook in the following frames (don't bother with "bushel basket").
column9: 5) [[uberstuber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberstuber)] 21-6-2007(31): **Deceit**! Someone must have moved one of my _chess pieces_ while I waws _yawning_!

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(210): **Chess piece** = _wooden rook_.
column6: 2) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 17-9-2007(34): The machine at the **chess piece** factor takes in whole trees and spits out thousands of **chess piece** s into the _barrel_.
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 25-4-2007(28): Ever seen those huge chess games in parks? The large wooden **chess piece** s need to be carted in a shopping trolley.
column8: 4) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 2-6-2008(13): A _bushel basket_ full of _wooden_ **chess pieces** in the house of a pro shogi player.
column9: 5) [[Renaissance](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Renaissance)] 14-3-2010(8): **Pokute** play **chess** high up in the trees, and that's where they store the **chess piece** s too. (primitive explanation <http://img71.imageshack.us/img71/6628/pokute3vp.gif> ).

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(201): The United Republic of Chess' **national flag** is actually a _banner_ with a _rook_ , that way they can hang it at every tournament.
column6: 2) [[misha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/misha)] 30-11-2007(61): The **national flag** of Croatia. It's a _banner_ with the Croatian coat of arms, commonly referred to as the _Chess_ board (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Croatia>).
column7: 3) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 4-6-2007(30): After 9-11, people sold **national flag** s by the bushel-basket. And for every _bushel-basket_ you buy, you get a _free banner_ with some cheesy patriotic quote.
column8: 4) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 11-5-2006(9): A poor, agrarian nation features on its **NATIONAL FLAG** a BUSHEL BASKET. The country is so poor, however, that the **NATIONAL FLAG** look more like a BANNER than a proper **NATIONAL FLAG**.
column9: 5) [[Renaissance](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Renaissance)] 14-3-2010(6): The **national flag** of the land in Hale Nochi Guu, is actually a banner with **Pokute** on it. (primitive explanation <http://img71.imageshack.us/img71/6628/pokute3vp.gif> ).

column3: _Bushel basket_ . . . _month_. As the _month_ indicates, this has to do with **periods** of time.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 13-3-2007(195): The slowest remote chess game ever: a one _month_ **period** between every move.
column6: 2) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 5-4-2009(88): The slowest chess game ever: It took him a one _month_ **period** to move the _rook_! (Edited from dingomick).
column7: 3) [[Piitaa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Piitaa)] 4-9-2006(70): The girl's panties are all in the bushel basket as it's that time of the month again… her **period**.
column8: 4) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 11-5-2006(20): One BUSHEL BASKET full of rice is enough to sustain a small family for a **PERIOD** of one MONTH.
column9: 5) [[Nuriko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nuriko)] 2-4-2008(8): A woman who doesn't want to throw harmful materials into the landfills might be found using a rook instead of a tampon when it's her time of the month. In other words, her **period**.

column3: _Bushel basket_ . . . _stones_. The key word refers to the Japanese game played with black and white colored _stones_ on a lined board.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 9-4-2007(208): **Go** is _chess_ played with _stones_.
column6: 2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 7-2-2008(83): The ignorant gaijin put a _rook_ on top of his opponent's _stone_ when playing **Go** , much to the consternation of the Japanese players.
column7: 3) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 17-9-2007(19): The two **Go** masters, playing on a gigantic _stone_ **Go** board, take their _stone_ playing chips from huge _barrels_.
column8: 4) [[mistamark](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mistamark)] 12-1-2009(17): **Go** needs a _bushel basket_ full of _stone_ s to play it.
column9: 5) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 13-12-2006(8): I wanted to play **Go** , so I wanted to set up the board. I went for my _bushel basket_ , where I keep all of the _stones_ , but they fall out of the bottom! This is the same _bushel basket_ that Charlie used in his escape! Now, I have nowhere to keep my **Go** stones. raulir 30-4-2006.

column5: 1) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 11-12-2007(218): **Fundamentals** of _chess_ : use the _rooks_ to protect your _ground_.
column6: 2) [[bigloui](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bigloui)] 9-4-2006(28): A _Bushel-basket_ full of _earth_ contains the fundementals of farming. i.e. earth.
column7: 3) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 13-7-2007(27): Before playing chess, you must learn the **fundamentals** : begin by placing a _rook_ on the _ground_.
column8: 4) [[Hyland1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hyland1)] 22-5-2013(20): I took a course on the **fundamentals** of bushel basket-weaving. They teach you everything from the ground up. (sweetneet variation).
column9: 5) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 18-1-2008(16): One doesn't become a grand master over night. Before he could graduate to using a real chess board, _Garry Kasparov_ had to master the **fundamentals** of the game by drawing chess boards in a pile _dirt_. (a pile of _dirt_ that he was for some reason straddling, I might add).

column3: _Bushel basket_ . . . _equal_. Note how the first stroke of _equal_ doubles up with the sixth stroke of the _bushel basket_ , and how the _animal legs_ of the _bushel basket_ are dropped to make room for the _human legs_ of _equal_.
column5: 1) [[Zareon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zareon)] 3-4-2007(203): It's a tremendous match between the two chess-players. They are clearly eachother's equal.
column6: 2) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 4-8-2007(49): These two _bushel baskets_ are **tremendously** huge. But not only they are huge, they are also perfectly _equal_ in size.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(44): Losing both your _rooks_ is **tremendous**. It's almost _equal_ to having your queen's _legs_ chopped from under her.
column8: 4) [[baylin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/baylin)] 8-7-2009(22): This kanji is **tremendously** difficult to remember because it is not _equal_ to the other bushel baskets in this lesson. Their _bushel baskets_ all have animal legs.
column9: 5) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 15-6-2008(14): Equal I remember as the counter for small animals. Remember Battle Chess? I just picture a tremendous **rook** from Battle Chess wandering around stomping on **little animals**. Those guys were sweet.

column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 6-7-2006(247): **Intuition** is a _tremendously_ _power_ ful resource of the mind.
column6: 2) [[Nuriko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nuriko)] 2-4-2008(63): Using Zareon's story for the previous frame "tremendously"… The two chessplayers who are eachother's equals are so good at chess that they don't have to even move a muscle. Their brain power does it for them. Furthermore, they don't even have to think, really. Their **intuition** takes control. This is: extreme chess.
column7: 3) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 5-9-2008(24): A woman's **intuition** is TREMENDOUSLY POWERful.
column8: 4) [[jackhuddleston](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jackhuddleston)] 31-5-2008(14): I had an **intuition** of who would win this fight by judging the size of my opponents _tremendously_ large _muscles_.
column9: 5) [[Mary_K](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Mary_K)] 24-9-2009(6): **Intuition** – _tremendously powerful_.

column5: 1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 17-9-2007(211): Because I hid myself behind a huge _dirt_ barrier I dug, I was able to **withstand** the _tremendous_ nuclear blast.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-4-2007(64): Plain old _soil_ can **withstand** _tremendous_ amounts of pressure.
column7: 3) [[Nuriko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nuriko)] 2-4-2008(37): The two equal chessplayers from the last two frames are duking it out still. Part of this extreme chess match is when the judges dump a huge mound of soil onto them. Watch as they **withstand** the weight of the dirt and how their brainpower keeps all the chess pieces, rooks and all, on the board. Simply astounding.
column8: 4) [[BigAmish](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BigAmish)] 15-8-2008(33): The Japanese high-rise was built to **WITHSTAND** _GROUND_ tremors of _TREMENDOUS_ force!
column9: 5) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 7-2-2008(6): Though I had lost both rooks in chess, a _tremendous_ loss, I was able to hold my _ground_ on the chessboard and **withstand** my opponent's attacks.

column3: This kanji takes away the _maestro_ 's baton and replaces it with a _purse_. The _road_ represents his being **dispatched** on his way a san obvious misfit. You will remember that when he did have his baton, he was being _chased_ down the road by his fans. All of which shows what a difference a single stroke can make!
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(208): **Dispatch** all cars and _chase_ the _maestro_! He's gone crazy and stolen a ladies _purse_!
column6: 2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 27-2-2008(55): Apart from meaning **DISPATCH** , this kanji can mean "to give (to someone lower than you)," "to do," and to even "have intercourse." STORY: The MAESTRO is on the ROAD waiting for a pimp to **DISPATCH** some new ladies (lower than him) so that he can GIVE THEM money from his PURSE and then DO IT with them. Where is the MAESTRO'S baton? You don't wanna know…
column7: 3) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 7-9-2008(35): Small additions to dingomick's story: **Dispatch** all cars and chase the _maestro_! He's gone crazy. He's thrown away his baton and stolen the _purse_ of some lady on the _road_! 派遣 (はけん): **dispatch** , send 人材派遣会社 (じんざいはけんがいしゃ): temporary staff service (temp agency) 遣わす (つかわす): to send, **dispatch** 小遣い (こづかい): allowance, pocket money 気遣う (きづかう): be concerned about, care about, worry about.
column8: 4) [[tomtosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomtosh)] 27-4-2008(23): To remember this one, I combine the _purse_ with the key part of _bureaucrat_ to come up with _diplomatic pouch_ , the thing that is used to hold a **dispatch** whenever an emissary is **dispatch** ed on the _road._.
column9: 5) [[harusame](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/harusame)] 16-6-2009(13): _Bond_ has stolen a lady spy's _purse_ while she was asleep after their evening together. When she discovers it's gone, she **dispatch** es some henchmen on the _road_ after him to **dispatch** him, but _Bond_ evades them and escapes with the _purse_.

column5: 1) [[Steinway](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Steinway)] 1-5-2008(55): …Faramir and Frodo watched the tiny creature far below. "Shall we shoot him?" Faramir asked. "This Gollum has **defiled** the _waters_ of the Forbidden pond, looking for his _Precious_ , and for that the penalty is death"…
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(51): Don't **defile** _precious water_.
column7: 3) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 14-1-2009(25): So much for [undefiled](../v4/1548.html) (#1548 潔). Not only did the poor girl get **defile** d, she also had her _precious purse with money_ stolen from her. She ended up drowning herself in the _water_.
column8: 4) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 14-4-2008(18): The moment _Precious_ was taken out of the _water_ , it started to **defile** the soul of the new owner, turning him into Gollem.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 17-8-2008(13): This kanji means "smash" or "break" such as to smash or break something, or [”顔をつぶす”](midori://search?text=”顔をつぶす”) which means "loose face" or "break face" in the literal sense. STORY: Use PRECIOUS WATER (i.e. holy water) to BREAK/SMASH the face of the undead. STORY 2: If you SMASH something in heaven, you can just pour some PRECIOUS WATER (holy water) on it to fix it.

column3: The top two strokes show someone _reclining_ , and the next six are a pictograph of an oaken _tub_ ribbed with metal strips, like the kind once used for bathing. At the bottom, the _sunglasses_ round off the character.
column5: 1) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 16-6-2007(228): The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his shades while his personal harem **dance** s nakes for him.
column6: 2) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 15-6-2008(120): I learned [nothingness](../v4/1775.html) (#1775 無) first because it is a very common kanji. Probably easier to think of this kanji in that context. Attractive **dance** rs should **dance** wearing **nothing** but **sunglasses**.
column7: 3) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 3-6-2007(18): I imagine this _big oaken tub_ as being full of grapes being squashed by the feet of the vinyard owners. Each wearing _sunglasses_ and doing that Russian arms crossed _dance_ and squishing all the grapes.
column8: 4) [[spleenlol](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/spleenlol)] 8-6-2010(14): See [jump](../v4/1409.html) (#1409 踊). Renamed this kanji **interpretive **dance****. (readapated thegeezer3) The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his タキ(tacky) _sunglasses_ while his personal harem does an **interpretive **dance**** for him.
column9: 5) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 12-5-2012(13): Heisig, let's get this straight: NEW keywords: 曜 JUMP ex-[leap](../v4/1285.html) (#1285 躍), 踊 **DANCE** =ODORI ex-[jump](../v4/1409.html) (#1409 踊), 舞 KABUKI ex-[dance](../v4/1774.html) (#1774 舞) (used in concepts related to **dance** , like stages, fluttering, etc.). So, KABUKI 歌舞伎 【かぶき】is the keyword here. STORY: We learn [nothingness](../v4/1775.html) (#1775 無) first because it is a very common kanji. Then we go to see KABUKI en the EVENING wearing SUNGLASSES.

column3: This character is the Japanese character for the supreme philosophical principle of much Oriental thought: **nothingness**. Make use of the oaken _tub_ from the previous frame, and add to that the _oven fire_ at the bottom.
column5: 1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 17-9-2007(278): When I enter the _wooden tub_ heated by _flames_ in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into **nothingness**.
column6: 2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-12-2006(40): In a hot tub you can relax and have your stress vanish into **nothingness**.
column7: 3) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 17-11-2007(19): As the _heat/flames_ rises up through the _oaken tub_ for a long period of time, all the water evaporates and what's left is **nothingness**.
column8: 4) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 11-8-2006(11): In the ancient days of Buddhism, philosphers were common. Each of them would deeply ponder the meaning of **nothingness** while _reclining_ in their _oaken tubs_ of hot water. Underneath, there were _flames_ to keep the water from cooling, tended by the non-philosophers. Immacolata 8-5-2006. Nothing too good for pondering the meaning of **nothingness**!
column9: 5) [[Yuta73](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yuta73)] 17-5-2012(5): Note: This is the actual kanji for -nai endings.

column5: 1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 18-9-2007(241): The leader of the _Spiderman_ **association** has tons of _Spiderman_ figurines lined up on his _shelf_.
column6: 2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 2-3-2008(60): Watch this: <http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r249/sith_lord10/updated%20showroom%20july/s29.jpg> The leader of the Spiderman **association** has tons of Spiderman figurines lined up on his shelf.(Zactacular).
column7: 3) [[Zareon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zareon)] 5-4-2007(27): **Association** means linking things together. This can be made literal by using a _thread_ to bind (associate) stuff which belong on your _shelf_.
column8: 4) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 14-12-2007(23): Spiderman is part of an **association** which meets behind the secret revolving _shelves_ (bookcase).
column9: 5) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 14-3-2009(15): Cat in the Hat for the new primitive. Spiderman forms an **association** with Cat in the Hat to promote literacy while fighting crime.

column5: 1) [[felicitygreen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/felicitygreen)] 27-4-2006(185): Refined rice [1535] can only be found in exclusive grocery shops. **Coarse** _rice_ by contrast fills the supermarket _shelves_ \- don't go looking for anything else there.
column6: 2) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 22-3-2009(140): Ugh, why does this _shelf_ feel so **coarse**? Because it's made of _rice_ , of **coarse**! Get it? Of **coarse**?? Hahahahahahahahahah god i hate my life.
column7: 3) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-12-2006(37): In America they sell **coarse** rice on the shelves. The Japanese are much more discriminating, as they eat rice all the time, so they want finer rice.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 22-2-2009(20): Japanese carpenters don't use sandpaper, they use rice-paper(rice glued on to some paper). Here the carpenter is using the **coarse** paper to smooth out the shelf he's making.
column9: 5) [[firion1234](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/firion1234)] 18-3-2010(10): " _RICE_ is not nice," said the _CAT IN THE HAT_ , "it is much to **COARSE** , like food for a horse.".

column5: 1) [[felicitygreen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/felicitygreen)] 27-4-2006(206): The EU and US impose such high **tariff** s on food imports that third world _wheat_ (the most basic of staples) never reaches first world supermarket _shelves_.
column6: 2) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 6-8-2006(134): According to Henshall, this kanji originally represented the harvested rice (the wheat primitive) that farmers paid as a tithe. Its meaning today would seem to be very similar. Imagine the farmer putting aside some of his harvested _wheat_ on a _shelf_ in order to pay the **tariff** to his lord.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(29): All the _wheat_ imports sit on a _shelf_ until the **tariff** is paid and it can be distributed.
column8: 4) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 2-3-2008(24): Tax. (Heisig is trying to hard to come up with different words) The devil who has collected wheat taxes before, stores these taxes in shelves.
column9: 5) [[firion1234](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/firion1234)] 18-3-2010(5): "If _WHEAT_ you'd like to eat," said the _CAT IN THE HAT_ , "then you'll have to pay the sheriff a **TARIFF**.".

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-5-2007(83): When her home was invaded by a _pack of dogs_ , the little girl climbed on the _shelf_ and **aimed** various items **at** the dogs below.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 17-6-2007(21): I think the _dogs_ purposely **aim at** your _shelves_ to deal the most damage.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(14): Like a _pack of wild dogs_ , my children **aim at** the top of my _bookshelf_ where I hide my porn.
column8: 4) [[dancingblade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dancingblade)] 14-7-2010(9): There's this game at the carnival where you **aim at** prizes on a _shelf_. In this particular variant, you **aim at** pictures of _wild dogs_ on a _shelf_. The more you knock down, the better the prize!
column9: 5) [[kodorakun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kodorakun)] 27-5-2010(6): Out hunting with my wild dogs, i took **aim at** the beast and fired. now the beast sits on my shelf, taxidermed.

column5: 1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 8-5-2006(184): The **ancestor** worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member.
column6: 2) [[kodama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kodama)] 5-11-2007(99): The urns of **ancestors** are kept on _shelves_ next to the _altar_.
column7: 3) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 2-3-2008(32): At the partents of my wife's house (she is Japanese) they have a shelf with pictures of their **ancestor** s. Its like a little shrine and they often pray to it.
column8: 4) [[coverup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/coverup)] 16-2-2009(13): An altar on the shelf to remember your **ancestor** s.
column9: 5) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 24-2-2009(10): **Ancestor** s are revered in Japan. Some homes have large family _altar_ s ( 仏壇 (ぶつだん)) with several _shelves_ to accommodate the name plaques (and these days photographs) of all the **ancestor** s. 祖母 (そぼ): grandmother 祖父 (そふ): grandfather 祖国 (そこく): motherland, fatherland, native country 先祖 (せんぞ): **ancestor** 祖先 (そせん): **ancestor** [also used in a broader sense, such as apes were the **ancestor** s of humans].

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 25-12-2007(201): In a last ditch effort to **thwart** the invaders of _The Pinnacle_ , they push glass _shelves_ over the edge onto their heads below.
column6: 2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-12-2006(69): The shortness of the Japanese **thwart** s their attempts to reach the topmost (pinnacle) shelf without grabbing a chair.
column7: 3) [[tristanthorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tristanthorn)] 18-3-2009(26): _The Pinnacle_ keeps its pantry _shelves_ locked at nighttime, to **thwart** midnight snackers. No fatties allowed here!
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 10-7-2009(16): Keeping porn on the _pinnacle_ of a _bookshelf_ can **thwart** snooping kids (thanks bodhisamaya).
column9: 5) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 1-5-2008(12): To **thwart** attacks on the Pinnacle, their shelves are always full of various magical weapons.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(286): A whole team of cops is sent to **investigate** how a _tree_ could grow on top of a _shelf_ with no soil or water.
column6: 2) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 9-10-2007(86): The result of the inverstigation of the missing _Trees_? Why, most of them had become _shelfs_!
column7: 3) [[Hujis](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hujis)] 2-5-2009(43): Police suspected that some _wooden shelves_ had come from illigaly lumbered timber in the Amazon. They launched an investigation in to the matter. "Trees are more important than shelves and therefore should be placed on top" A spokesman for the police said in an interview.
column8: 4) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 18-3-2009(20): Why the hell would a _tree_ be growing on a _shelf_? Time to **investigate**. Also time to think up a story that makes more damn sense.
column9: 5) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 19-8-2009(5): I have a little potted _tree_ sitting on my _shelf_ , and I found a note in it that said "You will die in 3 days." So, naturally I try to figure out who put it there! Dave Chappelle did a comedy special way back (1997) where he does an impression of a white guy in a horror movie with just one line, 'I'd better **investigate**!' That would be me in this situation.

column3: _Shelf_ . . . _power_. The reason why the _shelf_ appears on the left here is that the right side is the normal position for power, the stronger primitive. Indeed, the only exception in all the kanji is the character for _add_ (Frame 932).
column5: 1) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 2-5-2007(228): **HELP**! Someone's pinned under this bookshelf and it's gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-4-2007(84): Can you **help** me move this _shelf_? I don't have the _muscle_ to do it alone.
column7: 3) [[stupiddog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stupiddog)] 26-12-2009(10): To assemble an _IKEA shelf_ , logic is sometimes not enough. You need **help** from someone with brute _muscle_ strength!
column8: 4) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 9-10-2007(8): Anna doesn't have the _power_ to reach the merchandise on the top _shelf_ , so she asks a passerby - any old _Jo_ (じょ) - to **help** her.
column9: 5) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 26-5-2010(6): While it's always the heroine that discovers the _hidden passageway behind the shelves_ , they never have enough _muscle_ power to open it on their own and they have to call for " **Help**!"…

column3: This kanji, a polite way of expressing one's **best regards** to another. Its elements: _house_ . . . _shelf_.
column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 5-6-2007(256): It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their **best regards** , they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I've gotten so many that I had to buy a _second house_ which contains nothing but _several fancy shelves_. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents.
column6: 2) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 16-6-2007(40): Noone in japan will admit to this but every house has a secret "best regards shelf" hidden away somewhere. Its a shelf full of the tat they are constantly giving each other on return from holidays etc. Heres the house wife looking over her shoulder for the all clear to put another useless present on the **best regards** shelf. Happy Circumcision and **best regards**. Shelved.
column7: 3) [[Odieone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Odieone)] 18-1-2009(28): The _shelf_ your dad made for my _house_ was fantastic. Give my **best regards** to him.
column8: 4) [[stupiddog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stupiddog)] 26-12-2009(11): When I brought my new _IKEA shelf_ Billy into my _house_ , the assembly instructions read: "This will be the nightmare of your life. **Best regards** \- IKEA.".
column9: 5) [[Machine_Gun_Cat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Machine_Gun_Cat)] 22-3-2009(6): You are stepping over the threshold of you're new Japanese homestay _house_ You're half way through delivering your **best regards** in REALLY crap Japanese " d d d [どうぞう宜しく”](midori://search?text=どうぞう宜しく”) When you accidentally knock over their shelf where they keep their valuable ornaments with a terrible CRASH, not the best first impression.

column5: 1) [[DurablePants](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DurablePants)] 22-6-2006(322): The king is peacefully sleeping on his new **tatami mat** when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 20-6-2007(74): Making **tatami mats** from _rice field_ waste was Japan's _crowning_ achievement, but for some reason other countries just _shelved_ the idea.
column7: 3) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 8-3-2009(72): Rice Field + Crown + Shelf: **Tatami mat** s were used by everyone - from the workers in the _Rice fields_ to the _crown_ \- and when they were not in used, they were put on the _shelf_.
column8: 4) [[kumakuma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kumakuma)] 16-7-2008(21): To rest on the **tatami mat** , he puts his BRAIN and CROWN on the SHELF. Dont forget to put it on again, when you leave!
column9: 5) [[tristanthorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tristanthorn)] 18-3-2009(14): After a hard days work in the _rice field_ , the humble king hung his _crown_ upon his _shelf_ , curled up on his **tatami mat** , and slept.

column3: This character represents a slightly stylized duplication of the kanji for _stand up_. By lengthening the sixth and seventh strokes, you will see how this is done.
column4: * The primitive meaning remains the same as that of the kanji, but special attention has to be given to the varieties of shape this element can undergo. It is the most difficult one you will meet in this book. When it appears BENEATH its relative primitive, the top three strokes are omitted, though the third horizontal stroke may be doubled up with the bottom horizontal stroke of the element above it. ATOP its relative primitive, it can keep its kanji shape. When it does not, the top three strokes are removed and all of them are replaced BELOW the primitive's bottom line. We shall acknowledge this latter transformation by changing its meaning to _upside down in a row_.
column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 8-6-2007(290): This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of _two_ people _standing_ in a **row**.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 12-1-2006(53): Hint : as a primitive I use the image of a **row** ing boat. In a **row** ing boat people sit in **row** s, but also side-by-side (another meaning of the kanji), working together (yet another meaning of this kanji). Note : there will also be a kanji for "rowboat" coming at frame 1876. The **row** ing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for "rowboat" has a generic meaning of "a small boat". In any case, the kanji for "rowboat" will not appear as a primitive in the book.
column7: 3) [[bkvogel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bkvogel)] 17-9-2008(37): Roman numeral II with 2 **row** s of animal horns.
column8: 4) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 18-7-2009(22): **Full form:** The image of a _viking longboat_ has the advantage of being both a pictograph and lending to the idea of _rowing_. **Flattened form:** Here, we simply take the action of _rowing_ , already reinforced by the previous image. **Upside-down-in-a-row form:** The horns on the top of this form follows the other forms as an image of a _Viking Berserker_ with his horned helmet.
column9: 5) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 14-7-2007(15): Pictograph of the standing **row** in a theatre. // Primitive: a **row** of standing penguins (since they can't sit). If it's in the top position, the penguins are in a **row** in a balcony above the stage. If it's in the bottom position, the penguins are in the front **row** , lower than the stage. If the top 3 strokes are moved to the bottom ("upside down in a **row** "), then the penguins are in a **row** doing headstands.

column5: 1) [[Reikon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Reikon)] 4-8-2007(223): People at **Universal** Studios wait in rows so long that the sun goes down.
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 9-12-2006(57): To me, _row_ is way too close to [file](../v4/812.html) (#812 列), so I'm adopting Fab's meaning of _rowboat_ from the previous frame. **Universal** Studios went through a number of logo animations before settling on the one they are most famous for: the letters **UNIVERSAL** orbiting the Earth. One of the most ridiculous of these involved a man _rowing_ himself in a boat around the _sun_.
column7: 3) [[redskatz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/redskatz)] 6-4-2009(35): It is a **universal** human desire to sit in _rows_ to watch the _sun_ go down.
column8: 4) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 1-7-2009(22): If every planet lined up in a row with the sun there would be a **universal** solar eclipse.
column9: 5) [[ivantolearnkanji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ivantolearnkanji)] 19-4-2008(14): A song **universal** ly known among the kinder, at least in the English-speaking world, is " _Row, Row, Row_ Your Boat" - sung by a row of schoolchildren, _tongues wagging in the mouth_ as in [chant](../v4/21.html) (#21 唱).

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 20-6-2007(202): **Musical score** s are in a universal language.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(87): A **musical score** can be read, but not like _ordinary words_. Music is a _universal language_.
column7: 3) [[bizarrojosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bizarrojosh)] 16-1-2010(43): **MUSICAL SCORE** S are not written in WORDS, but in a UNIVERSAL language called notes.
column8: 4) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 7-9-2008(22): Small addition to Raichu's story: **Musical score** s are in a _universal_ language. No _words_ are required. 楽譜 (がくふ): **musical score** 音譜 (おんぷ): musical note, notation (e.g. ♪) 暗譜 (あんぷ): memorizing **musical score** s 棋譜 (きふ): record of a game of shogi/go/chess.
column9: 5) [[happychair](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/happychair)] 20-5-2006(10): For a **MUSICAL SCORE** to be successful, the WORDS must have UNIVERSAL appeal.

column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 13-10-2006(199): You first wash you clothes with _water_ and wring them until they are just **damp** before hanging them in a _row_ under the _sun_ to dry. If you don't wring them **damp** first they will take days to dry!
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 20-6-2007(53): When your things are **damp** , you line them up in a row under the sun.
column7: 3) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 9-12-2006(28): An image: a shirt hangs on the oars of an old _rowboat_. Though it is slowly being dried by the _sun_ high above, the occasional _drops of water_ from it indicate that it is still **damp**.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 16-9-2009(11): I'll bet most of us have had this experience at a water park… You are gazing at the _water_ hungrily while standing under the hot _sun_ , waiting in a long _row_ to get on the water slide. By the time it's your turn, you've been under the sun so long that you're not even all that wet anymore - just a little bit **damp**.
column9: 5) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 14-7-2007(9): The _row_ of penguins find themselves in the front row, right under the _sun_. It's very hot, so they spray themselves with cool _water_. This of course makes the entire theatre very **damp**!

column5: 1) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 20-1-2008(191): One day a _row_ of _Suns_ **appear** ed in the sky, turning everyone's _heads_ upwards.
column6: 2) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 13-8-2007(57): Clouds were covering the sky for months now. _Rows_ upon _rows_ of people spent whole days with their _heads_ turned upwards, waiting for _sun_ to **appear**.
column7: 3) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 27-4-2010(29): When the _sun_ comes up, a _row_ of severed _heads_ **appear** s on the castle wall. Think medieval times, they put the heads of dead enemies on show at each sunrise to intimidate.
column8: 4) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-12-2006(20): When a row of suns **appear** s in your head, you are enlightened. (Note: this can also mean "to become apparent", i.e. something hidden coming to light. E.g. 顕在 /潜在 are opposites, and 露顕 is "to get found out").
column9: 5) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 19-3-2010(17): Get up early and watch the _sun_ **appear** through a _row_ of _head_ s at Easter Island. (See photo at <http://i266.photobucket.com/albums/ii258/KatsuoB/EasterIsland.jpg>).

column5: 1) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 15-6-2008(221): _Spiderman_ has to stay **slender** , so during _thanksgiving_ , he keeps away from the long _row_ of food.
column6: 2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-12-2006(50): At the time of Thanksgiving, there's a row of all sorts of food on the table, which you mustn't eat if you want to stay as **slender** as a thread.
column7: 3) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 18-9-2007(24): _Spiderman_ is watching his weight and trying to become **slender** , so instead of eating a whole turkey for _Thanksgiving_ , he decides to only eat a _penguin_.
column8: 4) [[zodiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zodiac)] 22-12-2008(19): _Spiderman_ has to stay **slender** , so during _thanksgiving_ , he keeps away and _rows a rowboat_. (Zarxrax).
column9: 5) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 17-2-2010(7): During _Thanksgiving_ dinner, Spiderman is exercising on the _rowing machine_. He says he has to **slender** up so that he looks better in his Spidey-suit for Mary Jane.

column3: _Rain_ . . . _two_ . . . _row_. This character will refer only to the inhabitants of the  " **spirit** world, " and not to moods or temperaments, for which we will learn another character in frame 2030.
column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 10-5-2007(211): After _raining_ for _two_ days in a _row_ , you plead with the **SPIRITS** for some relief. (Adapted from johnskb,21-5-2006).
column6: 2) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 9-8-2007(56): When it _rains_ , _two_ worlds come together and **spirits** can be seen in the forest, dancing in a _row_.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-3-2007(41): When it _rains_ , the **spirits** have to cross between the _two_ worlds in a _rowboat_.
column8: 4) [[Angrybeez](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Angrybeez)] 24-6-2008(21): Under a rainy sky Two _rows_ of **spirits** wait one for heaven and one for hell.
column9: 5) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 11-1-2009(8): After praying to the **spirits** for _two_ days _in a row_ , it finally _rained_. See! The _rain_ **spirits** really do exist!

column3: In a row upside down . . . not yet.
column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 9-2-2007(211): A truly gruesome **profession** : an abattoir worker. Where the carcasses are _upside down in a row_ that have _not yet_ been cut up into sausages and steaks.
column6: 2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 9-12-2006(54): My **profession** is taking unfinished rowboats and waterproofing them. Customers come in all the time asking if I've finished, and I point to their _upside- down rowboat_ , still wet with sealant, and say, " _not yet_ ".
column7: 3) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 18-3-2009(29): The oldest **profession** : prostitution. I was once in a brothel in Amsterdam where the working girls had a group of businessmen blindfolded and hanging _upside down in a row_ , _not yet_ spanked and whipped, but waiting eagerly.
column8: 4) [[testoman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/testoman)] 4-9-2008(20): My life is ruined. All my **business** es went _upside down in a row_. I'm _not yet_ ready to change **profession** s though.
column9: 5) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 28-10-2006(17): Taking this _upside down in a row_ world and placing it upright is a **profession** that this world is _not yet_ ready for.

column3: Fingers . . . upside down in a row . . . husbands.
column5: 1) [[guidedog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/guidedog)] 3-3-2007(160): After a row husbands take their wives upsides down over the knee and **slap** them with their fingers on the bottom (if that doesn't get me banned…).
column6: 2) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 21-5-2006(140): Here we have badly behaving HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. Each wife approaches her HUSBAND, berates him, gives him a sharp **SLAP** in the face and, Three-Stooges style, pokes him in the eyes with her FINGERS.
column7: 3) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 9-12-2006(46): A couple in a rowboat. The wife **slap** s the _husband_ so hard with her _fingers_ that the entire _boat_ flips _upside-down_.
column8: 4) [[blaked569](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blaked569)] 12-3-2009(11): I'm the _husband_. I told my wife to lay _upside down_ so I could have an easier time _fingering_ her. Needless to say, I got a **slap** in the face.
column9: 5) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 11-1-2009(9): The wife immediately regretted giving her _Berserker husband_ the _finger_ after he **slapped** her half way across the room. See [row](../v4/1785.html) (#1785 並).

column3: This key word is yet another synonym for "I," somewhat more familiar in tone. As a rule, it is a word that boys and men use to refer to themselves. Its elements: _person_ . . . _husbands_ . . . _in a row upside down_.
column5: 1) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 13-5-2008(145): Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig **me** thod, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it's the kanji for "boku." Males usually use either "boku" or "ore" (instead of "watashi") to refer themselves. "Boku" is slightly boyish and soft, "ore" is rough & tough.
