Mr. T would definitely use "ore" – but when he's one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to "boku" when he pleads "come on baby, it's **ME**!".
column6: 2) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 21-5-2006(112): Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s **ME** , Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.
column7: 3) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 28-5-2008(16): **Me** awaken to discover **me** self upside down over Mr. T's knee getting slapped. Does this make Mr. T **me** husband??
column8: 4) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 26-12-2006(11): _Row of upside down husbands_ all begging _Mr T_ to set them free…" **ME**! **ME** **ME**!".
column9: 5) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 9-12-2006(5): _Mr T._ watches the _rowboat-overturning_ [slap](../v4/1793.html) (#1793 撲) from the shore and says, "I'm sure glad that ain't **me** ".

column4: * The primitive retains the meaning of _together_. Imagine things _strung together_ like fish on a line, beads on a thread, or whatever. The main thing is to avoid putting them in a straight row, which would confound this element with the previous one. As we saw with _bushel basket_ , this primitive can join its legs to the final horizontal stroke and stretch them to form an enclosure.
column5: 1) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 1-10-2007(256): The character for [deluge](../v4/1799.html) (#1799 洪) gave me the idea to use **together** as a primitive for _Noah's Ark_. Noah kept plenty of _salad_ on board to entice the animals with their _animal legs_ to scurry on board **together** , two by two.
column6: 2) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 18-9-2007(64): The conjoined twins, who are always **together** , have trouble eating **together** because one is a vegetarian, eating _salad_ and the other is a avid meat eater, eating _chicken legs_.[Thanks fuaburisu!].
column7: 3) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 13-10-2006(28): Imagine yakitori with _animal legs_ and _salad_ skewered on **together**.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 30-9-2008(22): _Salad_ and _animal legs_ just go **together**. This primitive means _chicken caesar salad_. <http://www.kfc.com/menu/salads.asp>.
column9: 5) [[kusterdu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kusterdu)] 15-4-2008(18): After I put animal legs in my vegetarian girlfriend's salad as a joke, she said, "We can't be **together** anymore.".

column3: **Submit** here is a transitive verb, meaning to offer or present. Its elements: _person_ . . . _strung together_.
column5: 1) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 1-10-2007(178): It took over 600 frames for _Mr T_ to [make](../v4/1142.html) (#1142 作), the _Ark_ , but when he was finally done, he cast his saw aside and **submit** ted the _Ark_ to Noah for his approval. "I pity the foo who doesn't climb aboard this ark," said Noah to his friend.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 11-12-2006(69): _Mr. T_ **submits** a resume _together_ with his application. "I pity da foo don't got no resume!" he says.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 31-3-2007(27): When _people_ are _together_ and form a group, they suddenly **submit** their personal responsibility to the mob mentality.
column8: 4) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 9-2-2006(17): Mr. T ( _person_ ) **submit** s to the police all _strung together_ the criminals that he has captured.
column9: 5) [[karmatheif](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/karmatheif)] 11-12-2009(14): _Person_ \+ _Together_ : You have to be _together_ with another _person_ when you **submit** a request to get into the ark. (Two of each creature, one male, one female) 供 (P), 伴 【とも】 (n,vs) (See お供 , おとも) accompanying, attendant, companion, retinue, (P) 供える 【そなえる】 (v1,vt) to offer, to sacrifice, to dedicate,.

column5: 1) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 8-5-2008(156): Noah's Ark is so **uncommon** ly large, he can even fit a rice field on top to feed the animals.
column6: 2) [[TalkTalk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TalkTalk)] 13-8-2009(102): _potentially offensive (sorry): It's **uncommon** to find someone with _brains_ who also believes in the story of Noah's _Ark_.
column7: 3) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 29-8-2006(79): _Brains_ _together_ with beauty is an **uncommon** combination.
column8: 4) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 18-2-2007(72): It's **uncommon** to find a pair of _together twins_ who are connected at the brain! When such a set does turn up, they are inevitably showcased on TV.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 30-9-2008(21): Finding _brains_ in a _chicken caesar salad_ is **uncommon** , unless you eat at McDonald's.

column5: 1) [[fiminor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fiminor)] 20-3-2007(182): The thing about feathers is that they usually cover the entire bird. A creature with _feathers_ only on its **wings** would be very _uncommon_.
column6: 2) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 7-12-2007(56): **WING** S without any FEATHERS would be an UNCOMMON site. Well, unless you like to eat chicken **WING** S alot.
column7: 3) [[LazyNomad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LazyNomad)] 9-7-2009(41): This is つばさ. To make a distinct image you can think about aircraft **wing** for which this kanji is also used. _Feathers_ would be extremely _uncommon_ to use in design of an aircraft **wing** s.
column8: 4) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 16-6-2008(24): When we talk about **wing** s and **feathers** we usually talk about 羽 , but the more **uncommon** form is つばさ for larger **wing** s- like angels - quite **uncommon** beings.
column9: 5) [[rich_f](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rich_f)] 10-3-2008(21): Reki's **wing** _feathers_ were an _uncommon_ color among haibane–they were black instead of white.

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 29-6-2007(82): At _Thanksgiving_ , it’s _uncommon_ for people to **accept humbly** the food: most people just dig in.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 14-8-2008(31): You're invited to a _Thanksgiving_ party in Japan! Awesome! You're so happy that your Japanese friends are trying to make you feel at home (you've been homesick recently). You sit down to the table, and they bring out some..uh… _uncommon_ food. Really _uncommon_. Like just imagine the most _uncommon_ _Thanksgiving_ food ever, and that's what you're given (i don't know, a frisbee or something?). Of course, you have to be Japanese and **accept humbly** their food.
column7: 3) [[Yozora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yozora)] 9-9-2009(11): As THANKSGIVING is an American holiday, it is UNCOMMON to say いただきます! before eating.
column8: 4) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 30-4-2010(9): " **ACCEPT HUMBLY** " is a translation for 頂戴する (chōdai-suru), a Japanese expression of _THANKS-GIVING_ that shows an _UNCOMMON_ degree of respect and formality, and is reserved for the most _UNCOMMONl_ y solemn occasions. Ironically, 戴 also appears in 戴きます (いただきます), which is also a form of _THANKS-GIVING_ , but is _anything but UNCOMMON_. In fact, it is so commonplace to that it borders on formulaic and meaningless. (NB: いただきます is also written 頂きます ).
column9: 5) [[Puchatek](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Puchatek)] 11-8-2011(2): During _Thanksgiving_ it is _uncommon_ to see Americans **accept humbly** their meal. Usually they're more like "Turkeyyy!!! Give me my turkeeeey, bitch!".

column5: 1) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 1-10-2007(198): _Water_ plus _Noah's Ark_ equals **deluge**.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 14-4-2007(121): Lots of water coming together is called a **deluge**.
column7: 3) [[elmaestrokgb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elmaestrokgb)] 29-7-2009(11): Even as the _water_ was rising, somehow Noah got _together_ all the right animals before the **deluge** began in earnest.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 9-10-2008(6): I downed my _chicken caesar salad_ with a **deluge** of _water_ , and it was delugious!
column9: 5) [[jonusbalonus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonusbalonus)] 7-5-2013(2): The **deluge** of _water_ was expected, and all were safe _together_ aboard _Noah's Ark_.

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 20-6-2007(187): During a _deluge_ , all the poor _snakes_ get washed into the **harbour**.
column6: 2) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 1-10-2007(120): All throughout the _deluge_ Noah had been kicking himself for forgetting to bring any _snakes_ onto the _Ark_. It wasn't until the _deluge_ had finished, and Noah had brought the _Ark_ safely back to the **harbour** that he realised that the _snakes_ had been under the _Ark_ all along.
column7: 3) [[cangy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cangy)] 10-4-2008(72): **The Office of Film and Literature Classification advises that this story is rated M due to moderate horror violence, moderate coarse language, sex scene and incidental drug use.** "Enough is enough! I have had it with these motherfucking _snakes_ on this motherfucking _Ark_! Get it to the **harbour** now!" (thanks rgravina and uragi).
column8: 4) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 3-4-2010(31): **While edited for consistency and more family oriented viewing, the Office of Film and Literature Classification still advises that this story is rated M due to moderate horror violence, moderate coarse language, sex scene and incidental drug use.** After weeks of _water_ getting in and _snakes_ sliding under his feet, Noah proclaimed "Enough is enough! I have had it with these motherf•••ing _snakes_ on this motherf•••ing _Ark_! Get it to the **harbour** now!" (thanks cangy rgravina and uragi).
column9: 5) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 18-9-2007(6): When the cargo ship from Africa unloaded it's cargo onto the **harbor** , a _deluge_ of _snakes_ came pouring out of the cargo hold.

column5: 1) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 31-8-2007(164): Having spent all _day_ _stringing together_ _grains of rice_ he suddenly had an **outburst** , "I can take it any longer!".
column6: 2) [[laner36](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laner36)] 2-11-2007(140): Noah was having an **outburst** after being at sea for 40 days and 40 nights and running out of rice grains to eat. Then the _sun_ suddenly burst out in an **outburst** over the _Ark_ and there was an **outburst** of cheering.
column7: 3) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 21-3-2008(49): Hint: Popcorn.
column8: 4) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 26-5-2010(27): Another freakin' _day_ on this freakin' _Ark_ , all there is to eat is freakin' _rice_! Aaaaaaaaaaarrrrrrrrrggh! …………His time on the Ark seemed to be getting to Noah (the hot sun overhead didn't help).
column9: 5) [[TheSlakey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TheSlakey)] 1-1-2009(17): One day on Noah's Ark, Noah's eldest son throws down his chopsticks and has this **outburst** : "That's it! I've had it! The sun is out, why are we still out on this damn Ark together eating the same damn rice??" That was the day Noah sent the dove out. (Thanks bodhisamaya).

column5: 1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 20-6-2007(184): Actually means explosion, like an outburst of fire.
column6: 2) [[Piitaa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Piitaa)] 11-7-2006(96): **Bomb** s make fiery outbursts. It's almost too logical, this one.
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 17-6-2008(83): An _outburst_ of _fire_ explodes outside Noah's Ark. "What happen!?", Noah shouted. "Somebody set up us the **bomb**!", came the Lord's reply.
column8: 4) [[spleenlol](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/spleenlol)] 9-11-2009(22): I laughed out loud so hard at Shibo's comment. Amazing. If you don't know what he's talking about go here: <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FVsijmCFs50>.
column9: 5) [[jabberwockychortles](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jabberwockychortles)] 6-10-2009(4): **Bomb** s=a _fire_ _outburst_.

column5: 1) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 1-5-2008(149): Noah feels like he gets no **respect** from the other passengers on the Ark, but they all make him Valentine's Day cards to show how much they **respect** what he's done for them.
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 20-12-2006(109): If you wanna stay _together_ you have to show your _valentine_ **respect**.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 6-10-2007(60): As I like Aretha Franklin's song "R-E-S-P-E-C-T", I cut out each of the letters from pieces of card, then _string_ them all _together_ and send it to her as a _valentine_.
column8: 4) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 7-8-2008(28): If you **respect** your girlfriend you will definitely spend Valentine's day together.
column9: 5) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 1-10-2007(14): As a sign of **respect** for all those who did not make it onto the _Ark_ , Noah hung _valentines_ on the underside of the _Ark_.

column5: 1) [[joesan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joesan)] 17-12-2007(162): There were so many _snakes_ on the _road_ to _Noah's ark_ so they had to **elect** which two would represent the _snake_ species.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 20-6-2007(121): You're driving on the road and you see two snakes together. You can't avoid both, so you have to **elect** which one gets run over.
column7: 3) [[nakome](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nakome)] 27-6-2008(89): Isn't this how the US presedential **elect** ion works? You are given a choice between _two snakes_. Their politics are actually _strung together_ but you get to feel as though you chose which one you want to lead you down the political _road_ for the next four years. So which _snake_ are you going to **elect**?
column8: 4) [[Hujis](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hujis)] 8-6-2009(45): There isn't quite enough room on _Noah's Ark_ for all the animals. So they decide to **elect** which two animals to kick out on to the _road_. Suprise, Suprise, they chose to get rid of the _two snakes_.
column9: 5) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 24-2-2008(13): Who am I going to **elect** , both the candidates are _two snakes_ who _together_ both promise a _road_ to better government, you know what I think I'll stay home on **elect** ion day.

column5: 1) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 9-8-2007(170): **Mr.** President! We all stand here _together_ under a national _flag_. One thing is certain: we'll never give in. We are launching nuclear _missiles_ now to implement mutually assured destruction protocol.
column6: 2) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 2-10-2007(83): (+synewave) Noah looks on in disbelief as **Mr.** and Mrs. Smith board the _Ark_ , start waving their _flag_ everywhere and blasting everything in sight with a _missile launcher_.
column7: 3) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 30-11-2009(37): **Mr.** Bush is has sullied the reputation of the US _flag_ , this tragedy _together_ with the countless _missiles_ that have killed innocent people have sent the worlds opinion of America the lowest it has ever been.
column8: 4) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 4-12-2007(32): Only in Hollywood. The new NOAH's ARK movie had the FLAG raised over the ARK signifying it's about to leave. Crowds come to board but Noah aims MISSILES at them to hold them away. His catch phrase "They Call me MISTER Noah!!!" Well, better than Evan Almighty I guess.
column9: 5) [[fergal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fergal)] 29-9-2009(26): This is the **Mr.** (との) used when addressing someone at the start of a letter. How letters were delivered to the _ark_ was intersting. Noah would wave a big _flag_ and the post man would fire a _flag_ -seeking _missile_ full of letters for **Mr** Rhino and **Mr** Giraffe etc.

column3: Recalling that there are no circular strokes, and that the shape of the square and the square within a square (Frame 630) have already been used, it should be relatively easy to see how this character can be consider a pictograph of a **well**.
column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 8-10-2006(182): I nearly died by falling in a **well**. Actually, on _two_ separate occasions. I'm glad to see they've added these _fence posts_. Now the **well** will be much safer.
column6: 2) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 13-7-2008(108): Have you ever seen an old fashioned japanese **well**? == <http://cruises.about.com/od/southeastasiacruise1/ig/Osaka-Japan/Ancient-Well- at-Osaka-Castle.htm>.
column7: 3) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 6-8-2007(33): This is a picto of the grate over top of the **well** at 大阪城 , so no one falls in.
column8: 4) [[Tornadic_Indignation](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tornadic_Indignation)] 25-7-2009(13): _Two_ people _j_ ammed _i_ n the **well**.
column9: 5) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 23-12-2008(9): _Tic Tac Toe_ is the only game I can play **well**.

column3: _Donburi_ is a bowl of rice with eel or meat on it. The character is a pictograph, perhaps designed by someone who felt that the portion of meat he was served with his bowl of rice looked to be no more than a tiny _drop_ in the _well_.
column5: 1) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 2-11-2007(65): A little one is eating a **domburi** while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down  & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 31-7-2009(24): I _drop_ a **domburi** down into the _well_ for the goblin living there.
column7: 3) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 4-9-2009(13): (thx mantixen) I DROP **Domburi** into the WELL to feed Sadako (Ring).
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 5-11-2009(4): A **donburi** is rice bowl, with _drops_ of food (other than rice) and garnish on top. The steep-sided shape of the typical **donburi** bowl is depicted in the kanji as a _well_ , which is not a bad comparison. Picture: <http://www.sushigallery.net/Arts/chicken%20donburi.jpg>.
column9: 5) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 25-3-2010(3): Pictograph of a Yoshinoya beef bowl with a drop of raw egg in the center (thanks Chadoro_K).

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(226): The village **surround** ed the _well_ with a _wall_ so kids wouldn't fall in.
column6: 2) [[nite_run](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nite_run)] 28-11-2007(45): You get good **surround** sound when your pent-up in well.
column7: 3) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 14-12-2008(35): Tweaking dingomick's story: The village _well_ is _pent in_ by a **surround** ing wall so that kids don't fall in. 囲む (かこむ): to **surround** , encircle 範囲 (はんい): range, extent, scope 周囲 (しゅうい): **surround** ings, environs, periphery, perimeter, circumference 囲う (かこう): to enclose, fence in 囲い (かこい): enclosure, fenced in area (such as a corral or a pen) Careful: [enclosure](../v4/1842.html) (#1842 郭).
column8: 4) [[thairob](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thairob)] 15-1-2008(23): The best **SURROUND** sound I ever heard was when I was PENT IN a WELL and they lowered a microphone and speaker so we could communicate. (thanks nite_run).
column9: 5) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 2-7-2009(11): Pent in by the enemy they were **surround** ed and then pushed down a well.

column5: 1) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 26-10-2006(227): If you just grow your christmas tree in a well, there will be no need to **till** the soil.
column6: 2) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 17-11-2007(78): A man was **till** ing a new plot to plant _xmas trees_ but his tractor hit an old covered-up _well_ and fell halfway in, he's asking for a new tractor for xmas..
column7: 3) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 19-12-2007(51): Note: **till** in the sense of plow or cultivate, not until. (story: ergerg).
column8: 4) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 21-12-2007(31): Plant a _Christmas tree_ to mark the location of the _well_ , so that those who are **till** ing the soil won't fall in.
column9: 5) [[Zarxrax](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zarxrax)] 7-7-2008(15): I kept drawing a complete blank every time this Kanji would come up, so I started thinking of the phrase "don't open **till** Xmas" that you often see on Christmas presents in cartoons and things. This brought the image of the Christmas tree to my mind, and from there I could use one of the other stories.

column3: In this kanji, the abbreviation for **Asia** , you should be able to see the character for _mouth_ behind the Roman numeral II.
column5: 1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 26-9-2007(279): In **Asia** n countries, people use _II_ chopsticks to get things into their _mouths_. Just imagine someone shoving a piece of sushi into their mouths with chopsticks.
column6: 2) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 25-6-2007(86): A mouth barred up and not aloud to speak freely is the sign of **asia** (korea, China, pakistan etc).
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-4-2007(24): In the Roman Empire there were signs marking where you were about to enter **Asia**. This was a dangerous place for Romans, so the sign consisted of a picture of _two Romans_ (= _Roman two_ ) being eaten by a _mouth_.
column8: 4) [[sabretou](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sabretou)] 17-3-2011(9): _China_ ( 中 ) taken two times should be about the total landmass of **Asia**.
column9: 5) [[onsen_monkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/onsen_monkey)] 6-9-2006(7): There are 'II' things I love about **ASIA** : I) I can use my MOUTH to communicate in exotic languages, and II) I can use my MOUTH to suck on some nice **ASIA** N women's bodies!! Yeah!!

column5: 1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 26-9-2007(283): Because _Asian_ people started to eat Western food, their _hearts_ became **bad** and they started having _heart_ attacks.
column6: 2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 3-3-2008(121): Asian hearts are **bad** and **evil**. They invented so much martial arts: karate, judo, kungfu, muay thai, silat, etc… just to hurt each other. They torture their own people (China, North Korea). They torture other people (Japan in China and Korea). And they are able to hide all this behind their nice facade of kindness. **Bad** , **bad** Asians. (did i shatter some people's ideas on Asia? my **bad** ).
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 19-3-2006(24): In the chinese version of the music video for Michael Jackson's "BAD", the performers are dancing in sync in eighties music video fashion, wearing leather jackets, chains, **bad** jeans, dark glasses etc. Each time Michael Jackson sings "I'm **bad** , I'm **bad** … you know it!" they open their jackets and on their bare chests you can see a black tattoo of a heart. Which brings us to the mnemonic… _asian_ _hearts_ are **BAD** ! You know it !
column8: 4) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 31-8-2010(16): Sanosuke sagara ( るろうに剣心 ) is not evil, he is just a **BAD** ass. <http://images.quizilla.com/A/AN/ANG/angelprincess062393/1160854681_cssanosuke.jpg> <http://images.absoluteanime.com/rurouni_kenshin/sanosuke-shirt.jpg>.
column9: 5) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 17-8-2009(13): (Counter Filips Argument) All human beings (Asians, Whites etc) are capable of doing **bad** or good its in the heart of human nature, whites are hated for invading peoples counties and stealing their lands, spreading their diseases, massacring their people almost to the point of genocide stealing the land for themselves on Australia, America, Pacific Islands, India, China etc. The crime against humanity for dropping a nuclear bomb.. unforgivable. (did i shatter some people's ideas on Whites? my **bad** ).

column3: This kanji, also used for Yen, is one you are not likely to need to study formally, since you can hardly get around in Japan without it. The connection is that the yennies, like pennies, are **circular** in shape. In any case, the elements are: _glass canopy_ . . . _walking stick_ . . . _one_.
column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 10-2-2007(154): The shape of a Yen coin.
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 28-1-2006(40): A poor old man is almost killing himself trying to lift a huge _glass hood_ with his _cane_ (using it as a lever), to get to just _one_ yen coin. Note : the kanji refers to a circular, round object, but also to the Japanese currency (pronounced "en").
column7: 3) [[Matthew](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Matthew)] 27-5-2007(27): A pictograph of a bank teller's window. The **circle** s are the coins which are passed back and forth for deposits and withdrawls.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 30-9-2008(15): Sometimes I wear my _top hat_ under my _hood_ and it makes my head look like a **circle**.
column9: 5) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 24-2-2008(14): You may wonder why this character is pronounced 'en' yet is said 'yen' in the west, well this is because when it was first romanized the obsolete ゑ character was used and as such became yen in the west.

column3: _Bound up_ . . . _glass canopy_ . . . _walking stick_ . . . _two_. If you write the character once, you will see why we avoided using the element for _soil_ , which would prompt you to write it in improper order.
column4: * As a primitive, imagine the tool used by draftsmen and carpenters to draw right- _angles_.
column5: 1) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 4-5-2007(203): A museum display of two walking sticks bound together under a glass canopy, showing the first device used to measure an **angle**.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-12-2007(36): [+nuke] As a primitive, a boomerang. This boomerang is used to grab a bunch of meat, or _flesh_ , lying around on the ground at a farm. First, you throw it straight at a _walking stick_ , then it makes a right **angle** and goes to _walking stick_ number _two_ , and wraps around that. A quick tug, and you've got all the _flesh_ flying toward you contained in that tri **angle**. Hooray for free (stolen) food!
column7: 3) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 30-6-2007(27): [angle, corner, square, horn, antlers] I needed to measure an **angle** , so I improvised a rudimentary protractor by _bounding up_ a _walking stick_ to some _body part_ of mine.
column8: 4) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-12-2007(16): The **ANGLE** of a Boomerang? BOUND UP, thrown by the BODY, but is not a WALKING STICK thanks to that 90 degree **ANGLE** in each one. So as a primitive, use Boomerang.
column9: 5) [[ezmoreldo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ezmoreldo)] 30-6-2008(8): If you bind up a circle with a rope, tied tightly it will have **angle** s.

column5: 1) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 7-5-2007(254): For _insects_ to get in **contact** with each other, they need to place their antennae at just the right _angle_.
column6: 2) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-12-2007(70): Wow, he threw that BOOMERANG with such skill, it made **CONTACT** with that INSECT in mid flight.
column7: 3) [[wrightak](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wrightak)] 9-7-2006(31): This is commonly read as 触る （さわる）, meaning to touch or feel something. An _insect_ 's version of _horns_ are its antennae (see [contact](../v4/1813.html) (#1813 触)). They are it's prime source of **contact** with the world and it uses them to touch and feel its way around.
column8: 4) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 26-9-2007(28): Th e physics professor explains that, depending on the **contact** _angle_ , the _bugs_ hitting your windshield may splatter really good!
column9: 5) [[thairob](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thairob)] 15-1-2008(14): In the movie **CONTACT** , Jodie Foster has to turn the radio telescope at just the right ANGLE in order to pick up the alien signal. Unfortunately, just as she's found the perfect ANGLE, a huge INSECT lands on the receiver and scrambles the signal. Jodie has to bust ass and call her friend in Australia to pick up the signal.

column5: 1) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 25-11-2006(221): Did you know that you can **unravel** a cow? If you stick the dagger in at exactly the correct angle, the whole cow will just **unravel**.
column6: 2) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 20-7-2009(77): **Unravel** the mystery by determining at what ANGLE the SWORD went into the COW.
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 8-12-2007(38): I tossed the BOOMERANG, which stuck like a DAGGER into a COW that I targeted. Now I watched the COW's insides begin to **UNRAVEL** from the cut.
column8: 4) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 29-4-2007(19): To **unravel** this mystery, you have to consider it from the right _angle_. Remember the most important clue: The _dagger_ was found lodged in the stable above the _cow_ 's head! Once you see that _angle_ , who would be able to place the _dagger_ over the _cow_ 's head, the whole puzzle will **unravel**.
column9: 5) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 25-7-2008(17): Think: Piñata. Specifically, one in the shape of a _cow_ that will completely **unravel** if _stabbed_ at just the right _angle_.

column3: _Jewel_ . . . with a _belt_ hung on it. Note how the _belt_ is drawn right after the first stroke of _jewel_.
column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(240): The _king_ has eaten too much and has to get a new _belt_ **again**. See his fat rolls hanging over?
column6: 2) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 14-9-2006(93): This is a _belt_ with a non-adjustable _jeweled_ buckle. Everytime you go back to the leathersmith telling him to move the buckle because you've packed on a few pounds (but that this is the last time!), he says "Again?!? Weren't you just here last month?".
column7: 3) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 1-5-2008(65): (I thought this was easier to remember as king with a belt) As the king gets fatter, his belt needs to be adjusted **again** and **again**.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 12-7-2009(19): I _craft_ _yen_ to buy things **again** and **again**.
column9: 5) [[fiminor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fiminor)] 22-3-2007(10): Have _jewelled belts_ come back into fashion **again**? I just can't keep up with the times!

column5: 1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 7-6-2007(157): I have a _funnel_ attached to my laptop that takes my prof's **lecture** and puts the _words_ into a text file. The bigger the funnel, the more accurate the conversion, so picture a bunch of laptops with large, unwieldy funnels attached to the USB port.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(101): Image: a professor walking around with a _funnel_ and simply pouring his _words_ into each students head instead of a **lecture**. (Primitive: _FUNNEL_ , who got the _celery_ stuck in the funnel _again_?! You know it's not supposed to be used for that!).
column7: 3) [[tenricefieldsglue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tenricefieldsglue)] 7-7-2009(63): FUNNEL primitive: " _Celery–again_?!" "You'll eat your _celery_ or else I'll make you eat it with a FUNNEL!".
column8: 4) [[dshill99](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dshill99)] 14-5-2010(39): At a **lecture** _words_ are _funneled_ into students.
column9: 5) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 15-7-2007(15): _Socrates_ is giving a **lecture**. He's using a _funnel_ as a megaphone but also pours some celery in there between words. // Primitive: _funnel_ = who got the _celery_ stuck in the funnel _again_?!

column3: _Shells_ . . . _funnel_. The key word is meant to suggest magazine **subscriptions** and the like.
column5: 1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 1-1-2007(205): **Subscription** is like a money funnel, because the receiving end is small (just one company) and the other end is wide (the whole country).
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 9-4-2007(56): My **subscription** to _Money_ magazine came with a free coin _funnel_.
column7: 3) [[SKlepJr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SKlepJr)] 22-12-2006(25): My **subscription** to Money magazine came with a free funnel.
column8: 4) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 15-2-2007(19): You put your _shells_ into a _funnel_ at the newsagent to buy your **subscription** to Better Kanji Writing magazine. It spins around the funnel many times before finally falling down the hole.
column9: 5) [[Rooboy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rooboy)] 3-4-2009(10): I had to cancel my **subscription** to that "special" magazine when my wife found out where i was _funneling_ all our _money_.

column5: 1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 12-10-2006(157): _Trees_ with good **posture** look like _funnels_. For example, <http://static.flickr.com/53/118084202_8896e54a14_m.jpg>.
column6: 2) [[kodama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kodama)] 6-11-2007(132): A farm girl uses a _wooden funnel_ as a corset to improve her **posture**.
column7: 3) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 29-9-2007(41): The old maple syrup farmer developed horrible **posture** because she had been bending over for years to tap the maple _trees_ and _funnel_ out the maple syrup and carrying the syrup back to the shed .
column8: 4) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 16-12-2008(36): I fell out of a _tree_ and broke my neck. So they put one of those white _funnels_ around my neck to correct my **posture**.
column9: 5) [[Schwingy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Schwingy)] 20-5-2009(15): In Aikido, you must have good **posture** (or 構え ）. Be as a strong as a tree and funnel that energy into controlling your opponent's attacks.

column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 15-10-2006(243): A **gutter** _funnels_ _water_.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 23-4-2007(65): A **gutter** takes the _water_ that falls as rain and _funnels_ it off to where it can be dealt with appropriately.
column7: 3) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 25-7-2008(27): _Water_ \+ _funnel_ == **gutter**. But really, if you need help with this one, how did you make it this far? :).
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-12-2007(14): Instead of a normal **gutter** , the city is cutting costs by just putting a huge _celery funnel_ on the side of the road every few hundred yards. While this is actually a bit more efficient than standard **gutter** s and quite cheap, it'sa bit dangerous (as there's a rather nasty juicing mechanism attached to the bottom of each one). Imagine telling some kids to stay out of the **gutter** on a rainy day, and one of them not heeding you (kids love splashing in them!) and falling to her doom.
column9: 5) [[jeebus101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jeebus101)] 23-2-2013(3): [using 'diet' as right hand primitive] Alcoholics will land in the **gutter** if they keep up their _liquid diet_ consisting of only alcohol.

column3: _Words_ . . . _meeting_ . . . _scrapbook_. The **argument** here is a process of academic reasoning, not a personal quarrel or spat.
column5: 1) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 14-8-2007(191): Right part: _academic conference_ (a _meeting_ , some of the attendees making notes in _scrapbooks_ during presentation). **Argument** at _academic conferences_ is naturally carried out using _words_.
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 15-10-2006(67): It's very difficult to present a good **argument** if you don't bring along a _scrapbook_ with some key _words_ jotted down to the _meeting_.
column7: 3) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 22-1-2010(35): _Words_ must he chosen _methodically_ to make a good **argument**. Note: 侖 [Unicode-0x4f96](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/20374) (#20374 侖) is an extremely rare kanji meaning "methodical", I remember this with: "A meeting of scrapbookers who are very methodical.".
column8: 4) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 17-6-2008(24): For _scrapbook_ I used the image of a Panini sticker album, and thus the _meeting of scrapbooks_ becomes a "Panini sticker album convention" (like a comics-con, only with collectors of Panini sticker albums). Pretty much all the _words_ you can hear at the _scrapbook meeting_ are **argument** s between geeks about which album is better.
column9: 5) [[igordesu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/igordesu)] 6-3-2009(22): Picture a bunch of ladies at a scrapbook convention engaging in a heated debate/argument with their words. "You call that a scrapbook!" "Psh! Puh- lease! You ain't got the first thing about a scrapbook!" "That ain't no scrapbook! That's a crapbook!".

column5: 1) [[scout](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scout)] 20-2-2008(152): _Mr. T_ talks about **ethics** at the _academic conference_. "I pity the fool who gets caught plagarizing someone else's stuff!".
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(82): _Mr. T_ has no **ethics** at the _scrapbooking convention_. He'll do whatever it takes to beat all those ladies.
column7: 3) [[adhmm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adhmm)] 23-11-2007(29): One small change from dingomick to make it memorable to me: _Mr. T_ has no **ethics** at the _scrapbooking convention_. He'll do whatever it takes to bang all those ladies.
column8: 4) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 13-1-2009(20): 侖 = think or be methodical. A _person_ who _thinks or acts methodically_ has **ethics**. 五倫 【ごりん】 (n) the 5 Confucian filial-piety relationships, 社内不倫 【しゃないふりん】 (n) adulterous affair with someone at work, 人倫 【じんりん】 (n) human relations, humanity, 精力絶倫 【せいりょくぜつりん】being of unbounded energy or sexual stamina, 沈倫 【ちんりん】sinking into obscurity, 破倫 【はりん】 (n) immorality, incest, 比倫 【ひりん】.
column9: 5) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 27-11-2005(12): Here _Mister T_ discusses **ethics** at a _Panini sticker album convention_ (see previous frame). See, according to Mister T, there is so much "double" stickers when you buy the pack of stickers, that it creates a lot of waster paper and such, and it contributes to pollution, and a waste of resources. Now most people nowadays would think of embryos and stem cell research when thinking about **ethics** , but hey, this is _Mister T_.

column5: 1) [[adhmm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adhmm)] 23-11-2007(131): Someone stole all the **wheel** s off the ladies' cars at the scrapbook convention.
column6: 2) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 17-9-2007(112): During a talk at the _academic conference_ , speaker shows an introductory slide depicting the structure of _car_ , and then moves on to the more narrow topic of **wheels**.
column7: 3) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 19-8-2009(45): At an _academic conference_ many thousands of years ago, the uses of the **wheel** were discussed–eventually leading to the invention of the _car_. I sort of imagine a TED conference with cavemen discussing the **wheel** with a 2001 Space Oddesy-esc transition to Henry Ford also at a TED conference. (www.ted.com A seriously good website).
column8: 4) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 5-3-2007(16): You have to be _methodical_. Before you invent the _car_ , you'll need to invent the **wheel**.
column9: 5) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 15-7-2007(15): It's a strange _scrapbook_ _meeting_ with albums full of _cars_ and **wheel** s.

column3: _Person_ . . . _door_ . . . _scrapbook_. The sense of the key-word is that of having a bias or preference for someone or something.
column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 19-2-2007(117): Mr. T is very **partial** to hentai comic books. I know because he dropped a pile of them when I accidentally bumped into him at the door to kinokuniya!
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 25-12-2007(88): _Mr. T_ is **partial** to _konbini hentai_. He reads them for hours every day after work at his local konbini. (Primitive: _KONBINI HENTAI_ , all the magazines(scrapbooks) by every konbini door in Japan).
column7: 3) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 1-1-2007(45): Comic book is a nice idea. It's a sort of scrapbook that is like a door to a different kind of reality. Person is always **partial** (unfair) on the subject of comic books, because (s)he doesn't like them.
column8: 4) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 16-12-2008(38): Right side: scrapbook on your door = _Heisig kanji poster_. Story: A _person_ with a _Heisig kanji poster_ is **partial** to the Heisig method.
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 3-3-2008(29): This reminds me of those **PARTIAL** /BIASED religious PEOPLE who come to your DOOR trying to shove the biblical SCRAPBOOK down your throat.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 20-2-2007(124): Go down the road in Japan and you will find comics **EVERYWHERE** , newpaper stands, 7-11, Tsutaya, even the supermarket. Comics are **everywhere** here along the road.
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(93): Go down any _road_ in Japan and you'll find _konbini hentai_ **everywhere**.
column7: 3) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 15-7-2006(58): A _scrapbook_ is a _door_ that takes you down the _road_ to **everywhere** you've ever been.
column8: 4) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 16-12-2008(22): You take the _kanji poster_ on the _road_! Damn, you take it **everywhere**!(See [partial](../v4/1823.html) (#1823 偏) for _kanji poster_ ).
column9: 5) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 3-3-2008(11): 遍 【へん】 (ctr) (See 一遍 , 回 ) number of times. 何遍 【なんべん】 (n) how many times, how often, (P) (see my story for 1824) STORY: Those religious missionaries that go DOOR to DOOR handing out their biblical SCRAPBOOK are very persistent. They will come to your house any NUMBER OF TIMES and will even chase you down the ROAD to spread their word of God.

column5: 1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 29-9-2007(98): I took the **compilation** of covers of all my _Spider-Man_ comics that I had saved in a _scrapbook_ and glued them on my door.
column6: 2) [[DeKleft](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DeKleft)] 3-12-2007(70): My _Spiderman comic book_ _**compilation**_ is almost complete…only one left, and I may have to kill for it…
column7: 3) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 31-5-2008(59): Whereas Mr.T was partial to KONBINI HENTAI, SPIDERMAN likes to wait for the **COMPILATION**. He finds it more convenient to have his hentai compiled in one volume to read on the loo.
column8: 4) [[theasianpleaser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theasianpleaser)] 16-12-2008(18): _Spidey_ has the _kanji poster_. A **compilation** of all RTK 1 kanji(See [partial](../v4/1823.html) (#1823 偏) for _kanji poster_ ).
column9: 5) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(11): Did you hear about the new _Black Widow konibini hentai_ **compilation**?! I'm going to 7-11 right now to buy it. She's so hot!

column3: This key word is a counter for books. It differs from _scrapbook_ both in the writing order and in the extension of the second horizontal stroke.
column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 22-11-2006(134): Pictograph. I think of that Harry Potter spell book that had to be bound shut coz it wanted to eat you.
column6: 2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 4-3-2008(63): 冊 さつ 1: counter for books A heavy scrapbook so full that flowers are sticking out. Only if a scrapbook is that full, it can be called a heavy book.
column7: 3) [[rabite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rabite)] 19-7-2008(58): Pictograph of three books tied up for transport.
column8: 4) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 10-1-2010(34): A pictograph of The Lord of the Rings Trilogy viewed end on: All _3_ **tome** s held together with _one ribbon_ \- "one ribbon to bind them all".
column9: 5) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 8-10-2006(14): Hint: **Tome** rhymes with "comb", and it looks a little bit similar to the comb primitive.

column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 17-10-2007(61): A **palisade** is a "fence of stakes especially for defense," usually the stakes are very strong, set closely together, and pointed on top. _Tome_ can be seen as a pictograph of several close-set _wooden_ stakes, braced by one horizontal bar.
column6: 2) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 12-4-2008(25): Before I build him a _wooden_ **palisade** , the mighty leader gives me a mighty _tome_ on the subject.
column7: 3) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 5-10-2010(6): I'll let the tome primitive refer to a spell book, in order to keep it distinct. In that case, this kanji shows me a _wooden_ **palisade** under siege by a few mages, trying to demolish it with their spells from the _spell book_.
column8: 4) [[drwaltoa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/drwaltoa)] 23-9-2011(4): A pallisade is made of wooden tree-trunks laid side by side like the pages of an ancient tome.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(3): _Wooden tomes_ form **palisade** s at the library.

column3: We introduce this character here because of its connection to the book-related kanji treated above. It is based on the character for _bend_ (frame 1256), whose last stroke is lengthened to coincide with the first stroke of the element for _tool_.
column5: 1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 15-10-2006(178): **Coding** is a _tool_ which you can use to _bend_ the computer to your will.
column6: 2) [[vileru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vileru)] 8-1-2010(75): This kanji means a **code** of law, not a secret language or symbolic language (such as programming **code** ) … Story: The **code** of law is a _tool_ used to _bend_ citizens to society's will. You can use the image of a totalitarian state, but be careful not to confuse it with the pinnacle primitive [Heights](../v4/1294.html) (#1294 阪).
column7: 3) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 8-7-2008(60): Think "codex" (mnemonic help) or "code of laws", or even Leonardo Da Vinci's **code**. Here I see a **code** x as a _tool_ used to _bend_ the masses into submission. Picture a huge **code** x book lifted down on crowds to bend them down in submission. Another: if you _bend_ to the **code** without asking questions, you are a _tool_!
column8: 4) [[jotun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jotun)] 8-7-2008(23): Bender can be used as a tool for bending. But only if you know the right **code** (He never does want you want to).
column9: 5) [[tristanthorn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tristanthorn)] 18-3-2009(20): **Code** / **rules** can be _bent_ with the correct _tool_ … (usually money).

column3: Pay close attention to the stroke order of the elements when learning to write this character. The elements: a long _drop_ . . . _fishhook_ . . . a _one_ . . . _fishhook_.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 12-11-2007(239): Looks a bit like Ft => **F** amily **t** itle => **Family name**.
column6: 2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 19-10-2006(75): The **family name** is important to me! _Drop_ me from a building, torture me with a _fishhook_ , I'm keeping my _one_ **family name**. Hook me with a second _fishhook_ , I refuse to change my **family name**.
column7: 3) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 20-8-2007(43): This _box_ is full of _arrows_. _Arrows_ are special: armorer's **family name** is engraved on each arrowhead (hence last _dot_ is left out).
column8: 4) [[dilandau24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dilandau24)] 28-11-2006(27): Note that the stroke order of this is _drop_ , _fishhook_ , _one_ ( **written as normal** , not right to left as Heisig writes) then the second _fishhook_.
column9: 5) [[Hujis](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Hujis)] 11-5-2009(14): Hook, is both Hook's (from Peter Pan) first name and **family name**. So he's called _Hook Hook_. But he thought that was a bit silly so he _droped_ the second hook and only uses _one_.

column5: 1) [[Jasta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jasta)] 8-11-2008(225): _Spiderman_ doesn't have a single **paper** with his _family name_ on it (because he doesn't want to reveal his identity).
column6: 2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 4-12-2005(79): I imagine a ridiculously expensive, and rather pointless, Japanese type of **paper** for writing letters, with one's _family name_ woven in _fine thread_ somewhere in a corner.
column7: 3) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 1-5-2008(39): Spiderman regrets getting drunk last night. Peter Parker hands in his **paper** with the name Peter Spiderman–wrong family name. Oops!
column8: 4) [[torida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/torida)] 26-5-2010(16): _Spiderman_ is very careful not to leave any piece of **paper** lying around with his _family name_ on it (because he doesn't want to reveal his identity) …….[thanks Jasta].
column9: 5) [[randomkrazy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/randomkrazy)] 7-3-2009(9): Peter Parker's original name was Peter **Paper** , but they decided to change it before the comic was released.

column5: 1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 4-12-2005(270): **Marriage** is the _day_ in this _woman_ 's life where she gets a new _family name_.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 20-2-2008(90): Tip: Heisig later introduces the kanji 昏 [dusk](../v4/2451.html) (#2451 昏). Story: Never enter into **marriage** with a _woman_ at _dusk_ (wait until you see them in daylight). Note: This is an ancient proverb . . . (probably).
column7: 3) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 19-6-2008(26): My goodness, between this story and surname and matrimony.. Ouch. I apologize in advance for this one, ladies, but if I don't make this story memorable this kanji will haunt me forever. Ok, here goes: **Marriage** is the day a _woman_ is changed forever. Not only does she get a new _family name_ but she can start using her _mouth with a wagging tongue_ to nag instead of those other unspeakable acts that her husband used to enjoy..
column8: 4) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 29-3-2013(24): 3 Kanji related with **marriage** , all the 3 with the primitive WOMAN. 嫁 [marry into](../v4/542.html) (#542 嫁): Since the man is hardly ever home, the woman feels more like she's married into the HOUSE . 姻 [matrimony](../v4/584.html) (#584 姻): is the state you get after the **marriage** , in which the woman has got you PENT IN like a DOG, so that you cannot go after other bitches. 婚 [marriage](../v4/1830.html) (#1830 婚): is "THE" day in this woman's life where she gets a new FAMILY NAME. Remember that **MARRIAGE** begins one DAY, whereas MATRIMONY is the state you get after the **MARRIAGE**.
column9: 5) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 23-11-2009(13): 婿嫁婚姻 : 4 kanji related to **marriage** , all with the _woman_ primitive. **Bridegroom** : for the honeymoon, he takes her to the _zoo_ for a _month_. **Marry into** : since the J-husband is never home, she feels more like she's married into the _house_ than into a relationship. **Marriage** : is when she gets a new _family name_ on one particular _day_. **Matrimony** : is the state after the **marriage** , where she has the husband _pent in_ like a _dog_ … 婚約 [こんやく] [、結婚](midori://search?text=、結婚) [けっこん] [、離婚](midori://search?text=、離婚) [りこん].

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(208): _Mr. T_ travels to Japan and knows he must bow **lower** when presenting his _business card_.
column6: 2) [[mattimus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mattimus)] 17-11-2009(71): Primitive: The Japanese always _underline_ their _family name_ on their **Calling (Business) Cards**. (Easy to remember, Underlined Family Name = Business Card).
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 26-7-2007(44): A _person_ bows **low** when presenting his _business card_.
column8: 4) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 13-4-2008(17): For **calling card** primitive: The thief always left a **calling card** with his _family name_ on it, lying on the _floor_ of crime scenes. Not too smart. ————– _Dracula_ leaves a _calling card_ on his victims that lets everyone know he considers them **lower** on the food chain, quite beneath him.
column9: 5) [[coverup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/coverup)] 16-2-2009(9): I imagine Mr. T bowing to present his business card, but he doesn't **lower** himself enough… so a limbo chant starts blaring over the speakers, "How much **lower** , can you-go? How much **lower** , can you-go?" Mr. T wincing in pain as he tries to bow even **lower** …

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 20-2-2007(172): Most japanese find it impossible to **resist** pushy businessmen in Japan when they push their damned _business cards_ into your _fingers_.
column6: 2) [[ivantolearnkanji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ivantolearnkanji)] 28-4-2008(135): Japan business etiquette tip: When someone hands you a _business card_ , **resist** the impulse to fiddle around with it with your _fingers_ , and by all means **resist** the urge to use the card to pick gunk from under your _finger_ nails. Just examine it carefully, ask politely about the (few by now) kanji that you don't know, and put it away carefully in a location that shows your counterparts how important they are to you.
column7: 3) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 24-2-2008(48): You have to **resist** using your _fingers_ to present your _business card_ the correct etiquette is to present it with both hands.
column8: 4) [[Cheesemaster64](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cheesemaster64)] 2-6-2009(20): How do **resist** someone giving your their _business card_? Give them the _finger_.
column9: 5) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 8-2-2007(13): _Fingers_ , the thief, wouldn't have been caught. But he was unable to **resist** leaving his _business card_. Now his only choice is whether to **resist** arrest.

column5: 1) [[uberstuber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uberstuber)] 21-6-2007(205): I put all those useless _business cards_ at the **bottom** of a _cave_.
column6: 2) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 8-5-2007(93): At the **bottom** of the _cave_ you find a _meishi_ : "LOST? DIAL 1-800-…".
column7: 3) [[joxn_costello](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joxn_costello)] 31-1-2009(36): In the deepest **bottom** of this _cave_ complex, spelunkers leave their _calling cards_ to prove they made it all the way.
column8: 4) [[Weber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Weber)] 28-2-2007(19): Its unlikely for you to have a card if you're low in society. People living in caves must be at the **bottom** of society, so they sure as hell don't have one.
column9: 5) [[faded](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/faded)] 23-1-2010(13): You know you've hit **rock **bottom**** when you have to operate your business out of a _cave_. All you have left are a few _business cards_ , and you're desperately hoping someone calls and offers you business.

column3: In place of the _drop_ at the start of the character for _family name_ , we have a _mouth_ , which makes you think of the "vox populi."
column5: 1) [[burento5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burento5)] 22-6-2008(150): How many of you know what "vox populi" means?
column6: 2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(139): All the **people** of the world with all their _family names_ shouting with their big _mouths_.
column7: 3) [[Virtua_Leaf](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Virtua_Leaf)] 22-1-2008(49): Once they'd learned to properly utilize their _mouths_ to form a language, the **people** of the world all adopted _family names_ , regardless of their race, culture etc..
column8: 4) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 8-7-2007(35): [people, nation, subjects] Somehow I remember this kanji as the **_P_ eople**'s _R_ epublic of _One_ family name. It resembles an _R_ with _one_ striking it through.
column9: 5) [[narazumono](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narazumono)] 17-1-2009(31): In a government of the **people** , by the **people** , and for the **people** one's _mouth_ is more important than your _family name_. 民主主義 - (みんしゅしゅぎ Democracy).

column5: 1) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 26-9-2006(225): In an Orwellian sense, the _eye_ watching the _people_ never **sleep** s.
column6: 2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 8-7-2007(63): People need to close their eyes and **sleep**.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 16-12-2006(34): The little boy from The Sixth Sense couldn't **sleep** because before his very _eyes_ he saw a dead _crowd of people_ everywhere.
column8: 4) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 13-4-2008(28): I **sleep** with one _eye_ open, because the _people_ are dangerous and may revolt at any time, you can't trust the unwashed masses.
column9: 5) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 25-5-2008(19): (inspired by PepeSeco's) The Orwellian-style government has a mysterious floating **eye** that floats silently through the night, looking in windows, watching the **people** while they **sleep**.

column5: 1) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 1-5-2008(196): I was retreating from the battlefield. In the chaos, my friend threw his dogtags at me to give to his family. I managed to **catch** them with my fingers as the chopper was lifting off.
column6: 2) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 20-8-2007(84): _Dog tag_ : This is a wild animal track device. It has an _arrowhead_ and _screwdriver_ -shaped radio beacon. It's evidently fired in animals to track their movements. When animal has a _dog tag_ , it's easy to **catch** it: just take a _dog tag_ in your _fingers_.
column7: 3) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 16-9-2009(52): "Dog tag" appears later as a kanji on its own: [offspring](../v4/2097.html) (#2097 甫) Offspring are pretty slippery when they come out of the womb, be sure to **catch** the baby with your fingers so it doesn't slide and fall on the floor!
column8: 4) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 9-4-2007(23): In some countries when they **catch** a thief, they cut his fingers and put a sturdy RFID dog tag on him. (I made this all up of course).
column9: 5) [[Joyo1945](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Joyo1945)] 11-6-2009(16): Its easy to **catch** a dog if it has _dog tags_ because you can just use your _fingers_ to take it by the collar.

column5: 1) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 2-6-2010(35): The extremely efficient (military veteran) wet-nurse keeps track of which infant has been **SUCKLE** d already by marking each _MOUTH_ with a _DOG-TAG_. (Cf. [suck](../v4/689.html) (#689 吸)).
column6: 2) [[Henkka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Henkka)] 14-2-2011(17): This mom of a dozen babies put _dog tags_ on the ones whose _mouthes_ she had already allowed to **suckle** her.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 23-3-2010(14): The _mouth_ of an _offspring_ **suckles**. [哺乳・ほにゅう](midori://search?text=哺乳・ほにゅう) lactation, suckling.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 7-11-2011(7): 哺乳類 , 哺乳動物 , 哺乳 =ほ乳, 哺育 =保育 [suckle](../v4/3027.html) (#3027 哺), ホ( 甫 ) … Parts: 口 , 甫 [offspring](../v4/2097.html) (#2097 甫) … Note: Overly clever keyword **Suckle** since it is only used for the word for mammal. ('Nursing' is now written 保育 .) … Story: The only pets you put _dog tags_ on are Mammals, who are called **Mammals** because they use mouth on mammaries.
column9: 5) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 23-3-2011(6): The scaredy-cat soldier puts his _dog tags_ in his _mouth_ and **suckle** s them nervously. It sounds like he's a **suckling** infant.

column5: 1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(189): The _water_ of the **bay** washes all the _dog tags_ up after the battle.
column6: 2) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 6-6-2006(53): Imagine the opening scenes of **bay** watch….beautiful _water_ and the _dog tags_ of the cast jumping up and down as they run along the beach.
column7: 3) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 30-9-2007(51): Otis Redding is sitting on the dock of the **bay** , looking over the _water_ while clutching the _dog tags_ of his fallen friend from Vietnam.
column8: 4) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 10-11-2009(17): Unwanted _offspring_ are often dumped in the _waters_ of a **bay**.
column9: 5) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 21-12-2006(12): My _aibo dog_ [[catch](../v4/1836.html) (#1836 捕)] fell in the _water_ and stopped working, so I sold it on e **Bay**.

column5: 1) [[erikkusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erikkusan)] 1-4-2006(176): **Bulrush** was the flower that you could see near almost all bays in japan before the japanese started putting concrete everywhere. Just check how many percent of Japan's coastline that is concretised… you'll be surprised.
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 6-6-2011(64): The **bulrush** is a _flower_ that grows around _bays_. <http://www.meltonrossnewbarnetby.co.uk/images/bulrush.jpg>.
column7: 3) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 15-7-2007(19): I sell **bulrush** _flowers_ on e- _bay_.
column8: 4) [[dtstutz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dtstutz)] 14-2-2009(18): Pharoah's daughter is walking along the **bay** picking **flowers** among the **bulrushes**. To her surprise, she sees a baby floating in the **water** on a primitive little boat made of **bulrushes**. After her servants swim out and retrieve the boat, they learn the baby's name by looking at his wrist bracelet **dog tag**. "Moses," huh. Sounds Hebrew. We'll just call him **Bulrush** Kid for now.
column9: 5) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 26-7-2007(17): Weeds that grow in a bay.

column3: _Cottage_ . . . _dog tag_. The key word refers to the noun, not the verb.
column5: 1) [[AryllWind](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AryllWind)] 30-3-2008(128): A **shop** in an impoverished country is just a cottage with a dog tag identifying it.
column6: 2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 1-1-2007(97): Normal cottages ( 舎 actually means a building) don't have tags advertising their names, but **shop** s do.
column7: 3) [[bihzad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bihzad)] 1-5-2008(43): Soldiers used to go the "lady-shop" at the edge of town. It was a little cottage stocked with women. All you had to do was show your dogtags to be admitted.
column8: 4) [[Rooboy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rooboy)] 3-4-2009(13): In Vietnam there is a little _cottage_ industry of **shop** s producing and selling fake US _dog tags_. These **shop** s are starting to appear in Iraq and Afghanastan too.
column9: 5) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 15-7-2007(9): This _cottage_ is a **shop** that sells _Aibo dog tags_.

column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 15-2-2007(192): I usually hear **supplement** in "dietry **supplement** ". So you're given a _cloak_ for extra fibre and _dogtags_ for extra iron. Keeps you regular and stops you feeling tired and run-down.
column6: 2) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 27-11-2007(80): The name and number printed on a soldier's _cloak_ is a **supplement** to his main I.D. tag, his _dog-tag_ , in helping identify the soldier.
column7: 3) [[mezbup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mezbup)] 6-7-2009(16): Ah yes, this dog tag perfectly **supplement** s my cloak!
column8: 4) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 5-12-2008(16): Cloak + Dog Tag: **Supplement** s are provided to soldiers, along with _cloaks_ and _dog tags_.
column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 10-11-2009(7): These days, many have to **supplement** their income to _cloak_ their _offspring_.

column5: 1) [[QuackingShoe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/QuackingShoe)] 22-7-2008(151): So fed up am I, I've finally built _city walls_ around my **residence** to keep these Japanese from soliciting me with their _business cards_.
column6: 2) [[Perry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Perry)] 28-4-2010(87): The _business card_ says his **residence** is just to the left of the _city walls_. Can you find it? Yep, got it.
column7: 3) [[scotty28](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scotty28)] 2-8-2009(85): Suggestion- since we have the pinnacle on the left(which had a great potential for imaginative stories as we explored the ultimate society), the right side will be the pinnacle's opposite - the slum. It's so dangerous that a steep menacing city wall has been erected to keep its denizens in(and protect those outside). story: If your calling card said your **residence** was the slum, you'd be too ashamed to show it to anyone.
column8: 4) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 28-8-2007(45): There are so many places of **residence** inside the city walls, I put a calling card outside mine so I can find my way home.
column9: 5) [[Odieone](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Odieone)] 18-1-2009(12): My _business card_ shows that my **residence** is within the _city walls_.

column5: 1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 21-5-2009(180): The city finally _received_ the **enclosure** that it desperately needed, _city walls_ to protect it against attacks from the _tall kids_.
column6: 2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 15-7-2007(79): Even the _tall_ _kids_ can't get out of the **enclosure** that is the _city walls_.
column7: 3) [[zwarte_kat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zwarte_kat)] 18-2-2009(62): As you can see, the tall kid peaks over the **enclosure** of the city walls to see the red light district (one of the meanings of the kanji).
column8: 4) [[scotty28](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scotty28)] 2-8-2009(26): (primitive city walls - slum. See residence 1841) in the slums, the city walls enlose everyone within. Some of the tall kids reckon they can clamber over the enlosing city walls, but even they fail.
column9: 5) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 26-5-2009(15): This Kanji also has the meaning of **red-light district** (probably an abbreviation from [licensed quarters](../v4/2235.html) (#2235 廓)). Only _tall kids_ are allowed to go there and leave the **enclosure** through the _city wall_ to _receive_ what they need so desperately.

column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 23-2-2007(135): **County** cricket. "I say _old boy_ , you've hit that ball clear over the _city walls_. That's six and out!".
column6: 2) [[zazen666](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zazen666)] 10-10-2007(88): You can take the _good old boy_ out of **county** (and into the _city walls_ ), but you can't take the **county** out of the _good old boy_. Is that how the saying goes?
column7: 3) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 11-8-2007(40): A ぐん is smaller than a prefecture so you can see the city walls. It sounds like 君 (くん).
column8: 4) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 21-5-2009(36): The _old boys_ don't venture out into the **county**. They stay cooped up within the safety of the _city walls_.
column9: 5) [[igordesu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/igordesu)] 9-3-2009(18): The old boy had never been outside of his own **county** because he couldn't get over the city walls.

column5: 1) [[blackstockc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blackstockc)] 24-1-2008(129): The country folk and and the city folk mingle at the **outskirts** of town, just past the city walls.
column6: 2) [[cbogart](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cbogart)] 12-3-2007(75): The city walls mark the **outskirts** of the inner city, where it begins to mingle with the suburbs.
column7: 3) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 1-1-2009(52): The city folks don't like to _mingle_ with people from the **outskirts**. That's why they built such big _city walls_.
column8: 4) [[Tzadeck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tzadeck)] 20-8-2009(16): Many of the girls from the _slums_ come to _mingle_ near the **outskirts** of the slums–in the hopes that they can find a more wealthy guy to get them out of the hell hole.
column9: 5) [[violetize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/violetize)] 7-8-2009(8): (primitive city walls - slum. See residence 1841 - scotty28) On the **outskirts** of the community is the _slum_ , where you dare not _mingle_ with the slum dwellers - it's too dangerous.

column5: 1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 28-6-2006(155): Within the _city walls_ , this **section** of town was so noisy that we had to _muzzle_ them up.
column6: 2) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 22-11-2007(34): " **Section** 8 housing" is a way to _muzzle_ the impoverished people who are unable to pay rent but want to live inside the _city walls_.
column7: 3) [[scotty28](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scotty28)] 2-8-2009(21): (primitive city walls - slum. See residence 1841) A riot happens in one **section** of the slum. Rioting about the poor living conditions and treatment by the authorities. That **section** of the slum have muzzels fixed on them. Such demeaning treatment is typical in the slum.
column8: 4) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 13-4-2009(19): The illegal israeli settlement has already muzzled the fuck out of all the land, so in order to further claim their (unwanted) presence. They muzzle the land (200m on both sides) of the Apartheid wall to **section** and part the land.
column9: 5) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 1-12-2006(14): **Sectioning** is a term used in the UK that refers to putting a _muzzle_ on someone and taking them inside the _city walls_ to a mental hospital.

column5: 1) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 1-6-2008(163): A vision of a futuristic **METROPOLIS** : standing at the window of your 400th floor apartment, hand in hand with your LOVE DOLL, gazing out at the gigantic CITY WALLS that you can never escape.
column6: 2) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 15-10-2006(75): In a huge **metropolis** , it's hard not to feel like just _someone_ within the _city walls_.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 31-7-2006(22): In the movie **Metropolis** by Fritz Lang, a robot _puppet_ is used by the evil mayor to manipulate the poor part of the city. Picture the puppet robot on the _city walls_ , giving a speech.
column8: 4) [[captal](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/captal)] 16-6-2008(21): [my primitive for someone is ninja]A **ninja** must be able to scale the **city walls** of the **Metropolis** without being seen.
column9: 5) [[scotty28](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scotty28)] 2-8-2009(12): (primitive city walls - slum. See residence 1841) A futuristic **metropolis** , and within it's city walls it still has the problems of slums and new problems of citizens whose only human connection is to AI love dolls.

column5: 1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 17-12-2006(178): The _drooping_ _citywalls_ was generating a lot of angry **mail** for the city officials.
column6: 2) [[tomusan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomusan)] 27-11-2010(86): The _city walls_ _droop_ down in one spot so that the **mail** man can throw the **mail** over.
column7: 3) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(30): _Droopy Dog_ delivers the **mail** by walking along the _city walls_ and throwing it to the people below.
column8: 4) [[coverup](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/coverup)] 17-2-2009(20): The _drooping_ _citywalls_ was generating a lot of angry **mail** for the city officials. Hint: think "hate **mail** " and you will remember this one. [thx CharleyGarrett].
column9: 5) [[swiftman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/swiftman)] 26-8-2009(10): **Mail** never gets delivered correctly in the _slum_ … the **mail** man is too busy _drooping_ down so he doesn't get shot.

column5: 1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 28-6-2006(178): He reminisced about his **home country** : "Ah, back in my **home country** , the _bushes_ grew so high that they covered the _city walls_!".
column6: 2) [[CountPacula](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CountPacula)] 8-8-2008(91): In -my- **home country** , we'd like to put up _walls_ to keep _Bush_ -OUT-, thank you very much.
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 5-8-2008(38): It's easier if you think of the USA as the **HOME COUNTRY**. To the northern border you have it protected by BUSHES, while to south you have it protected by CITY WALLS (or a 800 mile long fence).
column8: 4) [[QuackingShoe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/QuackingShoe)] 22-7-2008(30): In my **home country** , all we had for _city walls_ was _bushes!_.
column9: 5) [[violetize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/violetize)] 7-8-2009(22): (primitive: city walls = slum. See [residence](../v4/1841.html) (#1841 邸) - thanks scotty28) A nostalgic immigrant to the _slums_ reminisces: "In the **home country** , we were surrounded by pretty _bushes_ , not ugly _slums_ ".

column3: _Sword_ . . . _two_ . . . _city walls_. Used classically to indicate an **interrogative** part of speech, this character is used chiefly now for its sound.
column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-10-2007(106): If you arrive with _two swords_ at the _city walls_ , expect some **interrogative** s before they'll let you in.
column6: 2) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 28-8-2008(9): **Interrogation** at the _city walls_ : "Any weapons, **question mark**." "Just a _blade_." "Why the _two_ scratches on the _blade_ , **question mark**." "To remind me that I cut off my other ear too, _exclamation mark_ ([exclamation](../v4/2680.html) (#2680 耶)).".
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 27-3-2010(8): Phonetic ナ. If a trespasser attempts to cross the _city walls_ , the guards will likely employ the **interrogative** approach of pointing a _double-edged sword_ at them. Sort of shorthand for "Who goes there?". Note: "two" is written before final stroke of 刀 .
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 23-3-2011(5): Mix of Katsuo and Gavmck: If you arrive at the _city walls_ , get some **interrogative** s from the guards, and say that you have _two swords_ , they will probably say: "ナ(Nah), you can't enter." Reading = ナ.
column9: 5) [[mirnkaya](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mirnkaya)] 20-7-2012(1): (thanks Katsuo) If you arrive with _two swords_ at the _city walls_ , expect some **interrogative** s before they'll let you in, unless your the master of the armory that is… (this character is used chiefly now for its sound ナ. only common word using this kanji 旦那 (だんな) – master/patron).

column5: 1) [[inuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/inuki)] 1-11-2006(253): Your hometown is where you broke out of your cocoon (born), and where you left when your hair was silver (died), your whole life was spent inside the city walls.
column6: 2) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 13-10-2007(77): Your **home town** is where you earned enough _silver_ to enable you to break out of your _giant cocoon_ (leave home) and explore outside the _city walls_.
column7: 3) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 5-9-2007(37): He never left his hometown, from the day he crept out of the family _cocoon_ till the day his hair turned _silver-gray_ , he never once crossed the _city walls_.
column8: 4) [[itsumo45](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/itsumo45)] 22-1-2011(17): It's about time I leave my **HOME TOWN** …break out the _cocoon_ , grab all my _silver_ , and say goodbye to these _city walls_.
column9: 5) [[QuackingShoe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/QuackingShoe)] 13-8-2008(9): This always makes me think of Haibane Renmei, and the Home. They come in a cocoon, and can't pass the huge silver city walls.

column5: 1) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 5-10-2006(210): People's voices are like **echo** es of _sounds_ from their _hometowns_ ….you can always tell where they're from by how they talk.
column6: 2) [[Balaam](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Balaam)] 29-1-2008(85): My hometown is a ghost town, any sounds **echo** es and **echo** es.
column7: 3) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 21-5-2008(48): Whenever I call long-distance back to my hometown, the sound on the line has a terrible **echo**!
column8: 4) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 13-10-2007(29): The _sound_ of your _hometown_ always **echo** es in your ear when you travel abroad.
column9: 5) [[nac_est](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nac_est)] 9-9-2007(17): You go back to your _hometown_ after a long time, and you find out that's been destroyed! The only _sound_ you can hear as you walk among the ruins is the **echo** of your footsteps…

column5: 1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 11-2-2007(262): The _daughter_ is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The **son** is a _good_ boy that grows up to defend the _city walls_.
