column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 25-8-2006(44): _Rays_ of sunlight on the _water_ make for a **glistening** effect.
column6: 2) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 10-1-2009(13): The WATER is **glistening** in the RAYS of light.
column7: 3) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 20-1-2009(6): Compare with shimmering (frame 2880), where the rays of sunlight shimmer off the futon. Water is what's **glistening** in those rays. (helps to remember both kanji).
column8: 4) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 13-7-2010(3): _Water_ glistens when lit by the _rays_ from ANY kind of light (fire, candle, lamp) - NOT just sunlight.
column9: 5) [[wilsoncb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wilsoncb)] 23-8-2010(1): When I think of **glistening** (in a way that's distinct from sparkle or shimmering), I think of sweat **glistening** on someone's brow. Imagine seeing the drops of water there, **glistening** in the rays of sun…

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 14-3-2007(48): You know you are deep in the _water_ of a **bounding main** (deep body of water), when you look up and can no longer see the _rays_ of the _sun_ above you.
column6: 2) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 22-3-2008(11): You know you are deep in the _water_ of a **bounding main** (deep body of water), when you look up and realise it's not [limpid](../v4/2446.html) (#2446 晃).
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 16-10-2008(6): The _sun_ shines over the _glistening_ **bounding main** that is the ocean.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 12-11-2009(3): What a fine day for scuba diving into the vast, deep **bounding main**. The _water_ is particularly [limpid](../v4/2446.html) (#2446 晃) today, making it perfect for spotting sea life.
column9: 5) [[HolyKotor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/HolyKotor)] 13-10-2011(1): You are far out on the **bounding main** , sailing peacefully, with the _sun's light rays_ reflecting off the _water_. Serenity.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 16-10-2008(46): To **gargle** , put a _bundle_ of medicine in your mouth with _water_ and throw your head back as if in a _yawn_.
column6: 2) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 8-10-2011(7): 含漱 =含嗽=嗽=うがい, [嗽薬＊](midori://search?text=嗽薬＊) , 夏目漱石 = Natsume Soseki ＝ Summer Eye, **Gargle** Rocks, 漱ぐ =雪ぐ=濯ぐ,[gargle](../v4/2288.html) (#2288 漱)ソウ, すすぐ … Note: うがい(Gargle) is written in kana or 嗽. … Parts:氵, 束 , 欠 OR 瀬 - 頁 , 欠 (cf: 瀬戸内海 [rapids](../v4/1666.html) (#1666 瀬), 濯ぐ [laundry](../v4/577.html) (#577 濯), 雪ぐ [snow](../v4/1143.html) (#1143 雪), 頼む [trust](../v4/1665.html) (#1665 頼), 嗽薬 [Unicode-0x55fd](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/22013) (#22013 嗽)) … Story: Going rafting with **Soseki** , we hit the _rapids_ , fell out the boat, and our _heads fell off_. Now we _lack heads_ and **gargle** river water. Not a good day out with Soseki.
column7: 3) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 10-11-2007(5): **Gargle** by _bundling water_ in your throat that _lacks_ moisture.
column8: 4) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 22-3-2010(3): Sōseki ( 漱石 ) never **gargled** with any liquid except _water_ , because his _trust was lacking_ (hence the missing/replaced primitive from _trust_ ). He died of a stomach ulcer. Coincidence? I think not.
column9: 5) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 29-12-2007(2): Pictogram. Heisig himself suggested _lack_ as referring to a gaping maw. So, the _water_ becomes _bundled_ with a _gaping maw_ and the **gargling** ensues.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 17-2-2007(38): Australia is the only **continent** that is surrounded by _water_ on all sides, yet is still a single _state_.
column6: 2) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 14-2-2008(24): If the borders of a _state_ are all _water_ , then it is more properly called a ' **continent** ' instead. (For 州 [state](../v4/128.html) (#128 州), I think of the small-dash/big-dash alternating pattern that is used for state borders on some maps.).
column7: 3) [[lankydan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lankydan)] 13-9-2007(8): **Continent** s have states with water around it.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 18-8-2011(6): 八重洲線 , 六大洲 =六大州, 座洲 =座州=坐洲, 中洲 =中州, 砂洲 =砂州, 满洲国 =滿洲國=満州国=Manchukuo, 滿洲 =满洲=Manchuria, [continent](../v4/2289.html) (#2289 洲) シュウ( 州 ), す( 州 ) … Parts:氵, 州 [state](../v4/128.html) (#128 州) … Story: Ignore the keyword, this is just an alternate writing of 州 [state](../v4/128.html) (#128 州). More correctly, all of the former uses of this kanji (other than names) have been collapsed into the simplified character 州 .
column9: 5) [[gdaxeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gdaxeman)] 17-1-2011(2): All **continents** are surrounded by large bodies of _water_ and composed of independent _states_.

column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 28-7-2008(33): You have got a really, really plugged up bathtub - so plugged up, as a matter of fact, that when you get out of the bath, it takes an entire _decameron_ for the gently **swirling waters** to go all the way down. You are really annoyed at this (it's gross, besides), so you get a tiny little _sun_ and _bound it up_ with twine, and lower it into the drain. It clears the clog right up, and the _swirling waters_ zip right on down!
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 7-1-2007(23): For _ten days_ , we watched the **swirling waters** , but it didn't seem like the _water_ would rise in another tsunami.
column7: 3) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 1-7-2010(6): Without the **swirling waters** of a toilet, you may have to hold your _water_ for a _decameron_. How's that for bladder training?
column8: 4) [[At0m5k](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/At0m5k)] 9-8-2009(5): Swirling _waters_ are **truly** a wonderful thing to behold. I could watch them for a whole _decameron_ and never get bored. (I haven't been able to find any other reference stating that this kanji means **swirling waters** , so I'm going with **truly** as the main meaning).
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 12-8-2011(3): 洵 , 洵美 , [swirling waters](../v4/2290.html) (#2290 洵)ジュン( 旬 ), まこと … Parts:氵, 旬 [decameron](../v4/67.html) (#67 旬) (cf: 殉 [martyrdom](../v4/809.html) (#809 殉), 詢 [counsel](../v4/2705.html) (#2705 詢), 恂[Unicode-0x6042](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/24642) (#24642 恂) … Note: Keyword just a mnemonic, 洵 , 詢 , 恂, are all male names read まこと or ジュン. Many other kanji share the readings. … Story: You note the **Swirling _Waters_** after you take a bath for the first time in _Ten Days_ in _June_ (reading).

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 15-4-2007(49): We have a prettily _shaped umbrella_ , but when it started to rain, _water_ **seep** ed through and _three of our elbows_ got wet. So much for design over functionality.
column6: 2) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 12-8-2011(4): 滲み易い , 滲む , [seep](../v4/2291.html) (#2291 滲)(シン),(しみる),にじむ … Parts: 氵, 参 /參 (cf. 参 [nonplussed/visit](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1720) (#1720 参), 惨 /慘 [wretched](../v4/1721.html) (#1721 惨)) (Note: Uses 參 (old for 参 [nonplussed/visit](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1720) (#1720 参)) … Similar Keywords :A _stabbed heart_ will _invariably_ 泌尿器 [ooze](../v4/636.html) (#636 泌), an antique Vase will 滴 [drip](../v4/442.html) (#442 滴), a flag pole mount will 漏れる [leak](../v4/1068.html) (#1068 漏) when it rains. Old people 滲む [seep](../v4/2291.html) (#2291 滲) fluids on my couch. … Story: When old people visit ( _Old Visit_ ), they tend to **Seep** bodily _fluids_ onto my damn couch. get some depends, motherfscker.
column7: 3) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 1-2-2009(4): X-men movie scene where the senator **SEEP** S through the bars like WATER. You see all these ELBOWS (three of them) move in trying to grab him, but it's MYSTIQUE the SHAPE changer that catches him in her UMBRELLA.
column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 7-3-2010(3): _Water_ **seep** s through my _parasol_ & wets all _three_ of my _elbows_. (Edward Albee, anyone?).
column9: 5) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 25-8-2009(3): A scene from Harry Potter. A man seemed to **seep** into the wall. He threw some _water_ on it, tapped it _three_ times with his _elbow_ , and once with his _umbrella_ , and it changed its _shape_ into a door.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 2-5-2007(41): In the _wild west_ everything was so dirty! With the limited _water_ people could spare, a simple **rinse** was the best your clothes would get.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 23-7-2009(26): **Rinse** _empty whiskey bottles_ with _water_.
column7: 3) [[sboegema](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sboegema)] 2-10-2008(5): NOT CLEANSE In the wild west, they would **rinse** out your mouth with water any time you said a dirty joke 洒落 [しゃれ] adj-na,n joke,pun,witticism *****.
column8: 4) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 1-2-2011(4): In the _west_ , we don't **rinse** ourselves before getting into the bath _water_.
column9: 5) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 10-6-2010(2): Use WATER to **RINSE** out the STYLISH bottle.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 21-9-2006(44): In the forest fire, they **douse** d the _trees_ with _water_ to prevent more damage.
column6: 2) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 14-5-2009(9): You use _water_ to [irrigate](../v4/2079.html) (#2079 沃) _saplings_. When it has become a _tree_ , you need more. Then you have to **douse** it.
column7: 3) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 23-1-2010(6): We **douse** d the _trees_ with _water_ to prevent a forest fire. To disambiguate **douse** & 渥 [moisten](../v4/2320.html) (#2320 渥) recall that had we **douse** d the trees properly in the first place we might not have had to moisten the roof later.
column8: 4) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 12-10-2007(5): Pun alert: dowsing is the use of a divining rod (usually a _tree_ 's forked branch), to find _water_. Dowse is also a legitimate alternative spelling for "douse" – after you find the _water_ you can **douse** the _tree_ with it.
column9: 5) [[kumakuma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kumakuma)] 19-11-2008(3): **Douse** your WOOD in cold WATER if you are contstantly horny.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 17-10-2008(56): _Water_ drops from your _eye_ are **teardrops**.
column6: 2) [[channi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/channi)] 21-5-2009(10): I get water in my eye to form **TEARDROPS** wishing every kanji was this easy.
column7: 3) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 16-7-2010(7): 泪橋 [teardrops](../v4/2294.html) (#2294 泪) ルイ, なみだ … Parts: 氵, 目 … Note: Tuttle 3a9.21 … 涙 [tears](../v4/1082.html) (#1082 涙), vs. 泪 [teardrops](../v4/2294.html) (#2294 泪) (vs 淚 )? don't worry. They are the exact same word except when used in place names: On and Kun are the same . 涕 has the decency to have a different On-Yomi. But the Kun is the same. …
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 4-9-2006(2): **Teardrops** are _water_ that falls from the _eyes_. Well, technically it isn't pure water, and technically it doesn't fall from the eyes, but from the tear conducts, but let's keep the image simple…
column9: 5) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 29-6-2012(): After seeing this kanji on a bottle of eye drops for contact lenses, I changed the keyword to **eye drops** to distinguish it from 涙 [tears](../v4/1082.html) (#1082 涙).

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 16-6-2007(39): As the Pharaoh's _chariots_ tried to cross the Red Sea, **gushing** _waters_ came and crushed them.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-10-2007(27): Picture yourself driving a _chariot_ wildly down the street and knocking over all the fire hydrants. _Water_ is **gushing** everywhere.
column7: 3) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 12-10-2007(4): My _chariot_ hath runneth into a fire hydrant, and now there art _water_ **gushing** everywhere.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 6-2-2007(2): A **gushing** of _water_ from a local overflowing river is being cleaned up by the _army_.
column9: 5) [[eggcluck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eggcluck)] 20-10-2011(1): Neptunes chariot, picture a great classical image of the god riding **gushing** waves. <http://www.greek-gods-and-goddesses.com/greek-god- poseidon.html> <http://www.flickr.com/photos/28433765>@N07/5680489450/in/photostream/.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 26-4-2007(73): The church is _selling_ holy _water_ for the faithful, but if you dare to say its tap water, they'd tell you you were **blaspheming**.
column6: 2) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 12-11-2009(4): During the Wedding at Cana, the Son of God had some people come up to complain after he performed his miracle. "This wine is terrible! Are you trying to _sell_ me _watered_ -down wine?" He replied, "It's a wedding, for God's sake, the wine is free, so stop complaining." The dissatisfied guest retorted, "Hey, don't **blaspheme**!" Jesus Christ just rolled his eyes and, under his breath, uttered his own name in vain.
column7: 3) [[Harpagornes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harpagornes)] 14-10-2011(2): "Jesus entered the temple area and drove out all who were buying and _selling_ there…" Mathew 21:12. In the Japanese version of this event, Jesus drives out the **blasphemers** by throwing _water_ at them. Cf. 売 [sell](../v4/323.html) (#323 売).
column8: 4) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 7-4-2008(1): Crooks **blaspheme** the free-market system by trying to _sell_ something as readily availabile (in Westernized countries, at least) as _water_. Don't spend $4 bucks for a plastic bottle of what you can get from your tap!
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(1): Long ago people would **blaspheme** you for trying to _sell water_.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 16-10-2008(50): What seemed to be _water_ dripping from the _wooden_ **roofbeam** was actually _drops_ of blood dripping from a _sword_ lodged in it.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 21-4-2007(10): He cut down the _tree_ with a _sword_ to make a new **roofbeam** , but when he saw _two drops_ lying on the tree, he assumed there was too much _water_ in the wood and he left it to dry first.
column7: 3) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 12-7-2009(8): A while back, I was goofing around with my _sword_ when I accidentally lodged it in the **roofbeam**. So that's why there is a _tree_ growing on the floor now. :/.
column8: 4) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 8-12-2008(2): _Water_ is pouring in through the **roofbeam** s. You stick a _blade_ in, and the flow subsides to just a couple of _drops._.
column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 1-7-2010(1): _Water_ is used to clean the 2 _drops_ of sap off the _sword_ that cut the _tree_ for the **roofbeam**. Pretty stupid carpenter if you ask me.

column6: 2) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 13-5-2009(14): After Mr. (and Mrs.) Smith blasted everything in sight with a missile launcher (see [Mr.](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1805) (#1805 殿)), turning the whole world into **sediment** , nothing was left to shot at. The only thing left was _WATER_. So boring…

column8: 4) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 19-1-2009(6): MR. Noah noticed as the WATERS receeded from the flood, lots of **SEDIMENT** was left on the land. Good for growing grapes I guess.
column9: 5) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 27-3-2010(4): I have a lot of **SEDIMENT** , from hard _WATER_ , in my aged _MR COFFEE._.

column5: 1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 5-2-2008(32): **Old Kyoto** was once the capital, but if has _fall_ en from grace and the flowers that used to decorate its houses have all disapeared.

column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 16-6-2007(8): Pfft, young whippersnappers! Back at the **old capital** , they didn't even have _water_ for _each_ and everybody! If you wanted water, you had to go hike for several miles and hope that the well wasn't empty yet!

column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 12-11-2008(11): Australia was designed as a **moat** , surrounded by _water_ , to keep out the _overpowering_ forces of foreign nations.

This kanji refers to things that stop moving such as water, air, speech, etc. "Stagnate" has been used elsewhere, so maybe "go stale," "stall," or "stop moving" would be suitable keywords. column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 14-11-2008(28): The **bush clover** is a special _flower_ which was dedicated to bush when he won the presidency in _Autumn_.

column7: 3) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 14-7-2009(13): From the Japanese Wikipedia page for **bush clover** : ハギ（ 萩 ） [とは、マメ科ハギ属の総称。落葉低木。秋の七草のひとつで、花期は](midori://search?text=とは、マメ科ハギ属の総称。落葉低木。秋の七草のひとつで、花期は) 7 月から 10 [月。](midori://search?text=月。) So the **bush clover** really does _flower_ in _autumn_ , as suggested by its kanji.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 26-10-2010(3): Like past President Bush, **bush clover** is a little slow. It flowers (blossoms) in fall, after most flowers have died and wilted away.

column6: 2) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 14-7-2009(10): A _technique_ that can produce [heat](../v4/1516.html) (#1516 熱) without using a fire? That's an old **technique** that anyone can do!
column7: 3) [[At0m5k](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/At0m5k)] 10-8-2009(8): The **techniques of old** used by martial arts masters had far more _force_ in them than the _technique_ s of today.
column8: 4) [[dtcamero](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dtcamero)] 9-1-2011(4): _MARIO_ uses the OLDEST **TECHNIQUE** S in the book… fireball _FLOWERS_ and running on _CLOUDS_ is so 80's.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(4): The **[old] **technique**** for making a _rising cloud of flowers_ was misused by _round men_ to get a woman's _legs_ caught in _ivy_.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(35): Get a [pheasant](../v4/2584.html) (#2584 雉) to **trim** your _flowers_ for you.
column6: 2) [[hissatsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hissatsu)] 18-11-2010(8): This lawn doesn't need just a **trim**. With _flowers_ and weeds so thick I have _pheasants_ nesting in it, it needs to be **mowed down**.
column7: 3) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 10-3-2010(4): **Trim** _pheasants_ **trim** _flower_ s, flabby ones leave _flower_ s a ruin. Conventional wisdom. But the key word is off: 薙ぐ /なぐ is more radical than 'to **trim** ', more like 'to **slash** down or away', as with a 薙刀 /なぎなた/long- handled sword,  & so, Sod's law, I hired a **trim** _pheasant_ to **trim** my _flowers_ & he took a scythe to them instead!
column8: 4) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 16-1-2009(3): Wtf **trim**? Using "mow down" as keyword. Picture a pheasant massacre where all the pheasants were mowed down and now flowers have been placed there to commemorate the event.
column9: 5) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 28-11-2009(2): When you **TRIM** the FLOWER field with that huge mower you may also get a few PHEASANT - because they nest there.

column5: 1) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 13-5-2008(32): Flower, decline: After your _flowers_ have _declined_ (i.e., lost their bloom), you can always use the remains to weave a **straw raincoat**. It's all about recycling these days…
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 21-5-2007(23): Looking for a job at a florist during bad weather, I was forced to wear my pauper's **straw raincoat**. Predictably, I was _declined_ at every _flower_ shop I found.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(7): _Flowery_ raincoats are on the _decline_ , with **straw raincoat** s now coming into fashion.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 24-4-2007(6): The pathetic guy that was _declined_ at the fancy restaurant, bought a **straw raincoat** while wandering the streets. There were still _flowers_ in the straw.
column9: 5) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 14-6-2009(3): Imagine Aeris in her **straw raincoat** , going from corner to corner trying to sell _flowers_ , but being _declined_ each time.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(43): _Flowers_ can be seen on the _pedestal_ covered with **moss**.
column6: 2) [[fightswumbrellas](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fightswumbrellas)] 20-8-2009(13): Most people throw flowers on pedestals after a great performance, however a strange person in the audience started throwing **moss** instead.
column7: 3) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 15-9-2009(9): **Moss** is a _flower_ that usually grows on " _pedestals_ ", like rocks, trees, and the like.
column8: 4) [[alucardchuu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alucardchuu)] 8-1-2010(5): The flowers you can see on old pedestals when you visit the ruins in Greece are **moss** in fact.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 16-12-2009(3): A statue of a military leader was torn down after he was tried for war crimes and hanged. But each year, on the anniversary of his death, followers visit the _pedestal_ where the statue once stood (now surrounded by tall trees and covered in moist green **moss** ) and leave _flowers_ in his memory. (Bonus - you can see his face in the kanji! Flowers=eyes, elbow=nose, mouth=mouth open, shouting orders. Call him General **Moss**!).

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 23-3-2007(32): When the **prodigal** son returned, he was greeted with _flowers_ and _hot water_ for tea by his mum.
column6: 2) [[Corodon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Corodon)] 1-8-2009(16): The **prodigal** son thought he was going to be in _hot water_ when he went home after wasting his family's money, but instead they greeted him with _flowers_.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(10): It would be **prodigal** to _water flowers_ with _hot water_ : What a waste of energy!
column8: 4) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 14-12-2008(5): When the **prodigal** son returns, he brings unique recipes for making tea by boiling exotic _flowers_ in _hot water_.
column9: 5) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 17-1-2009(3): I'm going to use "enchanting" as keyword. Tub of hot water with flower petals sprinked everywhere can make for an enchanting evening.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 1-11-2006(28): The alien plant from outer space _flowered_ and started drawing _mandala's_ on the ground with its **tendril** s as a way of communication.
column6: 2) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 15-7-2009(10): In a tentacle rape hentai, Sailor Mars uses her Burning _Mandala_ attack to fight away the **tendril** s attempting to de _flower_ her.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(6): If you show a _mandala_ to a _flower_ it will cross its **tendril** s into the lotus position.
column8: 4) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 5-9-2008(5): A Buddhist MANDALA sends out runners, **tendril** s from its already-complex image, each of which sprouts a FLOWER that in turn is a mandala, and sends out its own **tendril** s, forever and ever…
column9: 5) [[BladeWalker](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BladeWalker)] 12-7-2012(2): The evil archaeologist (think Indiana Jones) entered a chamber where the walls were covered with _mandalas_. In the center of the room was single _flower_ of impossible beauty. When he picked the flower, living **tendril** s burst out of the _mandalas_ , ripping him apart, the _flower_ still in his hand.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 6-10-2007(42): A **lotus** can either be a _flower_ , or else something that _take_ s you _along_ (the car make).
column6: 2) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 4-1-2009(18): **Lotus** can be either a flower or a car on the road.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-7-2008(5): Way too easy! **Lotus** , as in the really expensive, fast car. Whenever I want to take someone somewhere ( 連れる ）, I make sure to rent a **Lotus** so that I can arrive to pick them up in style. I'm a great customer of the local car rental shop, so they always make sure to give me a _flower_ when I pick up my **Lotus**.
column8: 4) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 13-4-2010(1): [This is a bit of a follow up to my [baggage](../v4/1013.html) (#1013 荷) story.] There's a superstition that the **LOTUS** brings good luck during trips. Specifically, one must _TAKE ALONG_ as many of these _FLOWER_ s as possible. Thus the **LOTUS** is nicknamed the _"TAKE-ALONG FLOWER"_. (They sure can make your [baggage](../v4/1013.html) (#1013 荷) unwieldy and conspicuous, but that's actually a good omen.).
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 6-1-2007(1): Some people like to _carry along_ **lotus** _flowers_ for good luck.

column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-7-2008(26): [+woelpad] In a certain culture, there is a ritual carried out when a girl is quite young (young enough, in fact, that they do it before they are considered a woman in that culture - for the same reason that some cultures do not name a baby until they are sure it will live) - she must go on a vision quest for a **lotus flower** and look inside it to see the face of her _husband_ \- then report back.. Imagine a poor flower girl's dismay when she looks into the **lotus flower** and sees the face of _Homer Simpson!_.
column6: 2) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 18-4-2008(20): There's a popular myth amongst _flower_ girls that the face of their future _husband_ is hidden inside a **lotus flower**.
column7: 3) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 17-5-2008(4): Flower, husband: ' **Lotus flower** ' is a software package tailored to the needs of those in the _flower_ business. Since the flourist is a no-no on all things digital, her _husband_ operates it for her.
column8: 4) [[brose](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brose)] 5-6-2007(4): A _husband_ wants to buy a **Lotus** so he gives **_flowers_** to his wife every day. フ T1 はす lotus, Mt Fuji.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(3): The only _flower_ a _husband_ likes is the **lotus flower** for spiritual reasons.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 1-5-2007(24): Those little _flower_ buds _contain_ a whole **lotus blossom** when they grow bigger.
column6: 2) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 24-1-2008(9): **Lotus blossom** _flowers_ are highly prized because they _contain_ lots of nectar.
column7: 3) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 17-5-2008(5): Flower, contain: ' **Lotus Blossom** ' is the stripped down version of a software package tailored to the needs of flourists: Lotus _Flower_ ([lotus flower](../v4/2361.html) (#2361 芙)). However, the software still _contains_ the most important functionality of the original version.
column8: 4) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 18-4-2008(3): (Continued) This little _flower_ girl eagerly waits for her **lotus** to **blossom** and reveal its secret. Will it _contain_ what she expects?
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(2): Despite its appearance, the **lotus blossom** _contains_ a beautiful _flower_.

column5: 1) [[sboegema](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sboegema)] 23-9-2008(24): The **orchid** thief tries to steal exotic flowers from the east, only to be stopped customs at the departure gate ***** 蘭 【らん】orchid.
column6: 2) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 15-7-2009(11): Note: I changed the keyword to Dutch because this is also the kanji used in Japanese for the Netherlands. I needed a break from all the flower types. Story: Nagasaki was opened up to **Dutch** traders in Japan, making it the only _gate_ to the _East_ at that time. As a result of the additional trade, both the Dutch and Japanese economies _flower_ ed.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(8): The _Asian lesbians_ are partial to this _flower_ because it reminds them of their favorite classic video game character: B. **Orchid**.
column8: 4) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 26-2-2010(7): When the people of **the Netherlands** brought **orchids** _east_ to _Tokyo_ , the citizens of Tokyo opened up their _gates_ to let the Dutch in. Apparently they've always had a weakness for **orchid** s in the east.
column9: 5) [[nadiatims](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nadiatims)] 25-6-2009(3): The queen of holland( 蘭国 ) grows **orchid** flowers by the west gate of her palace.

column5: 1) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 19-1-2008(34): You must play a tune using a **hollow reed** , to open the secret _door_ hidden beneath the _flowers_.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 18-2-2007(13): Ancient superstition requirs you to adorn your _door_ with **hollow reed** and _flowers_ , but nobody knows the purpose anymore.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-7-2008(7): I was sitting in my house when all of a sudden the SWAT team came through and teargassed my apartment! I couldn't breathe, but no way was I going to go outside and get shot! Thinking quickly, I grabbed one of the **hollow reed** s I'd bought at the garden shop and stuck it under the back _door_ and breathed deeply. The SWAT team was at the front - they'd never suspect a thing. But I forgot I'd just finished planting _flowers_ in the back and sucked one in, clogging the **hollow reed** …oh no…
column8: 4) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 14-11-2008(5): " **Hollow Reed**!" said the _flower_. "Oh, Hollow Flower," said the **hollow reed** , "the _door_ 's open, come on in!".
column9: 5) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 12-7-2010(2): Ant engineers strip a flower and use the **hollow reed** to break the seal of the refrigerator door and get in.

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 18-6-2007(19): The _signature flower_ of Ireland: the **yam**! Speaking of which, how are **yam** s different from potatoes?
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 24-7-2009(13): A **yam** has a _signature_ _flower_ that differentiates it from a sweet potato.
column7: 3) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 19-1-2008(4): Gordon Ramsey's _signature_ dish is **yam** soup with _flowers_ sprinkled on top.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 1-11-2010(3): 甘薯 , 薯童謡 , 薯童説話 , [yam](../v4/2365.html) (#2365 薯) ショ( 署 ), いも … Parts:艹, 署 [signature](../v4/1259.html) (#1259 署) (cf 曙 dawn (#2448 曙), 夢 [dream](../v4/305.html) (#305 夢)) … note: Sweet Potato is written with any of these: 芋 [potato](../v4/1655.html) (#1655 芋), 薯 [yam](../v4/2365.html) (#2365 薯), 藷 [sweet potato](../v4/2402.html) (#2402 藷), 蕷. No reason other than RTK testing to know one from another. … Story:The _Signature Plant_ of Southern Japan is the Sweet Potato, and this is the old Chinese way of writing it.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 5-1-2010(3): The famous 紫薯 (purple sweet potato) farmer guarantees his product by _signing his name_ on every **yam** he sells. Beside his _signature_ , he draws a little _flower_ , because he thinks it's cute. Note: stroke number should be 16 as in the book, not 17.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-11-2006(34): Only _prosperous_ people (picture someone with a lot of bling) can afford to have **iris** _flowers_ in the house regularly. They're too expensive for daily use.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 29-7-2008(16): Most people don't realize this, but there is a very specific biological reason that the **iris** _flower_ has _flowers_ that split into two main petal groups that generally face two completely different directions. The reason is that the **iris** _flower_ was brought over from another solar system many light years away that had two _suns_. Thus, one petal group would face one _sun_ , while the other petal group would face the other _sun_.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 2-4-2009(9): You become so _prosperous_ selling _flowers_ ( **iris** es) you buy Van Gogh's famous painting " **Iris** es" and hang in in your flower shop.
column8: 4) [[BladeWalker](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BladeWalker)] 12-7-2012(1): Need to disambiguate because I don't know about flowers. Story: _Prosperous_ people have invented a new game, poke each other in the **iris** with **iris** _flowers_.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 1-11-2010(1): 菖蒲 [iris](../v4/2366.html) (#2366 菖) ショウ( 昌 ) … Parts: 艹, 昌 (cf. 昌 [prosperous](../v4/25.html) (#25 昌), 合唱 [chant](../v4/21.html) (#21 唱), etc.) … Story: A flower made by pulling one ’I’ from each 目 , turning each 目 into a 日 . **Iris**.

column6: 2) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 18-4-2008(10): _Charred_ **banana** s on a bed of _flowers_ are a delicacy that stir up images of a tropic island.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 7-3-2007(5): **Banana** _flowers_ look often _charred_ , just like **banana** s often grow black very quickly.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 30-10-2010(3): Perfect. This is a Hawaiian Luau. You cook meat by building a fire, putting food wrapped in **banana** leaves in, and then burying the whole thing with sand. The person here has their own original recipe. They use Turkey instead of the traditional pork and put **banana** flowers on top. The fire is underneath the turkey.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 5-11-2010(1): 芭蕉 , 蕉風俳諧 , 甘蕉 , [banana](../v4/2367.html) (#2367 蕉) ショウ( 焦 ) … Parts: 艹, 焦 [char](../v4/557.html) (#557 焦) … Note: For both 芭 [plantain](../v4/2386.html) (#2386 芭) or 蕉 [banana](../v4/2367.html) (#2367 蕉). IRL meaning: the name 芭蕉 , Basho, the famous J Poet 'inventor' of the Haiku. … A Haiku in his memory: … Basho **banana**?- A Charred flower last name- it is such a shame. (it helps me to think of the End of the **Banana** looking charred, and the is the end Kanji of Basho.).

column5: 1) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 27-6-2009(24): I gave the _angel_ a _flower_. In return she gifted me with a year's supply of **buckwheat** to feed my family.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 27-5-2007(22): "Buckwheat's been shot! **Buckwheat** 's been shot!" At his funeral, attended by the rest of Our Gang, **Buckwheat** is placed in his coffin covered by flowers. An angel is also present, and says "Its O-tay **Buckwheat** , you have been invited up to heaven!".
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 8-3-2007(14): Grain from the **buckwheat** _plant_ can be used for some _angelically_ tasting cakes.
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 2-4-2009(6): The buck- toothed _angel_ pulls a _flower_ through her buck teeth thereby removing all the flowers and leaves. The stems that remain are then processed into **buckwheat** noodles.
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 22-2-2010(3): 年越し蕎麦 (としこしそば) is a dish of **buckwheat** noodles eaten on New Year's Eve to promote longevity. In other words, to prevent you meeting those _angels_ (imagine them with _flowers_ in their hair) before your time.

column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 10-12-2009(6): [+mantixen] **Butterbur** _flowers_ line the _path_ but the _path_ has been spread with **butter** & you slip in it & get a **bur** in your ass.
column9: 5) [[wilsoncb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wilsoncb)] 24-8-2010(4): Since **butterbur** means nothing to me, I'll think of Butterbeer, the beverage from the Harry Potter franchise. Eating too many of the flowers that it's made from can lead one onto the path of alcoholism…

column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 18-6-2007(18): **Behind the scenes** , in the _shady_ areas, they trade various _flowers_ : oh, yeah, gather 'round the good stuff!

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 2-10-2006(51): My mother used to joke that if I didn't wash my _ears_ properly, **mushroom** _plants_ would be growing out of them.
column6: 2) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 30-6-2009(10): I took **mushrooms** and saw _flowers_ sprouting from my friend's _ears_.
column7: 3) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 22-12-2011(1): After eating too many **MUSHROOM** S I stuck FLOWERS in my EARS and ran around yelling that I am going to save the planet.
column8: 4) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 18-4-2010(1): The common names of many **MUSHROOM** species attest to how they were often perceived as the _VEGETATION_ 's _EAR_ s: wood _EAR_ , tree _EAR_ , etc. (Following DeRoo, here I'm extending the _FLOWER_ primitive to _VEGETATION/VEGETAL/VEGETABLE_ , this extension is useful for other kanji as well.).
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 25-2-2010(1): It's well known that **mushroom** s are not _flower_ ing plants. Less well known is a **mushroom** known as the "Jew's ear". It really looks like an _ear_. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File>:Auricularia_auricula-judae_a.JPG shows an example.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(45): All it takes is _time_ to get _flowers_ after **sowing** seeds.
column6: 2) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 16-1-2009(6): After **sowing** seeds it will take TIME before FLOWERS grow.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 11-1-2010(2): It's _flower_ **sowing** _time_!
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 17-2-2007(2): If you are **sowing** these seed, in _time_ beautiful _flowers_ will come up in your garden.
column9: 5) [[hissatsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hissatsu)] 19-10-2010(1): **Sowing** _flowers_ is _time_ well spent.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 30-5-2007(18): The _axe_ murderer glares at his _flower_ garden victims "First **Parsley** , Sage, Rosemary, and Thyme!".
column6: 2) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 1-7-2009(14): Cooking for Cannibals: Sprinkling a freshly chopped **parsley** _flower_ onto your _axe_ before cutting up those helpless victims is a great way to add a little zest to your dishes.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 15-11-2008(10): …Next all we need to do is finely chop some **parsley** _plant_ using a sharp _axe_.
column8: 4) [[kadano](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kadano)] 15-9-2009(4): **Parsley** is a pretty tough _plant_ and requires a small _ax_ to chop it up and serve it.
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 6-3-2010(2): **Parsley** is popular for its leaves rather than _flowers_. Imagine a skilled chef finely chopping some with an _axe_.

column5: 1) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 31-10-2007(23): The **thatching** of the old thatched roofs in rural Japan often has FLOWERS growing out of it when it's gotten weathered. So you can pluck them and use them like tea leaves to tell your FORTUNE.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 12-9-2006(13): The _fortuneteller_ wants the **thatching** of his roof done with _flowers_ instead of reeds.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(5): _Flowers_ form the **thatching** over the local _fortune-teller_.
column8: 4) [[kioku3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kioku3)] 1-8-2009(3): A smart door-to-door roofing salesman always gave his customers _flowers_ and brought a _fortune teller_ along who predicted a bright future if they got new **thatching**.
column9: 5) [[kumakuma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kumakuma)] 17-12-2008(2): I need someone who would be able **thatching** my roof. Who shall I employ, the HIPPIE or MERLIN? Obivious choice.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 5-5-2007(43): The _godown_ was filled with **pale blue** _flowers_ , probably some drug…
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 15-11-2008(13): If you give her **pale blue** _flowers_ , she'll _godown_ on you every time.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(5): **Pale blue** _flowers_ cover the _godown_ from sight.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 5-11-2010(3): 蒼天 , 蒼生 , 暮色蒼然 , 蒼白 , 蒼い =青い, 蒼惶として = 倉皇として , 古色蒼然たる [pale blue](../v4/2399.html) (#2399 蒼) ソウ( 倉 ), あおい … Parts: 艹, 倉 [godown](../v4/1630.html) (#1630 倉) (cf. 創造 [genesis](../v4/1631.html) (#1631 創)) … Similars: 青い [blue](../v4/1534.html) (#1534 青), 蒼い [pale blue](../v4/2399.html) (#2399 蒼), 瑠璃 [marine blue](../v4/2555.html) (#2555 瑠) … Story: If you have **Pale Blue** eyes in Japan, you can de _Flower_ lots of girls, and lots of girls will _Go Down_ on you.
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 30-3-2010(1): The _godowns_ had hanging baskets filled with **pale blue** _flowers_ which looked lovely set against the sea and sky.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 30-5-2007(41): When a giant drinks a cocktail, he needs a **straw** of large proportions. He hollows out a _tall_ _tree_ for the **straw** , and sticks a giant _flower_ on the rim of his drink.
column6: 2) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 26-1-2009(15): Story of three little pigs. First one built a house out of **straw** but it got blown down. Second one built a house out of _flowers_ but it got blown down. Third one built a _tall_ house out of _wood_. It was so tall, when the wolf blew it it fell back on the wolf, killing him instantly. The end.
column7: 3) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 14-10-2009(10): A flower that is as tall as a tree. **STRAW**.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 2-4-2007(6): High up in this very _tall tree_ grow _flowers_ that make wonderful **straw** matrasses.
column9: 5) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 28-11-2010(1): By using this **straw** as a blowpipe I can knock off _flowers_ growing on top of even the _tall_ est _tree_.

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 18-6-2007(30): **Turnip** _flowers_? Gross, but at least it's better than _nothing_ to eat.
column6: 2) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 16-1-2009(9): **Turnip** s just taste like nothing to me.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 15-11-2008(8): When **turnip** s grow, you see some _flowers_ coming out the ground and you'd expect to see _nothingness_ underneath it but there's actually a **turnip** growing there.
column8: 4) [[NeoGlitch](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NeoGlitch)] 14-11-2010(5): If you have ever played Super Mario Bros. 2, you know that the _flower_ you pull from the ground to reduce all your enemies to _nothingness_ is the **turnip**!
column9: 5) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 21-1-2009(4): While I was relaxing in the NOTHINGNESS of my HOT TUB, some punk threw **turnip** FLOWERS in it, and stank up the whole bath. [http://images.google.com/images?hl=en&q=turnip](http://images.google.com/images?hl=en&q=turnip).

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 14-5-2007(26): The **sweet potato** is a _plant_ that can be used in _various_ dishes quite well.
column6: 2) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 19-12-2008(15): The **sweet potato** is a _plant_ that has _various_ names. (So don't get it confused with "yam").
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(3): The **sweet potato** is a _flower_ that comes in _various_ forms: orange, purple, etc.
column8: 4) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 17-5-2008(3): Flower, various: My lovedoll loves the _various_ words of endearment I speak to her. In recent times, she fancies to be called after vegetables and started wearing _flowers_ in her hair. From today I decided to call her my **sweet potato** , wonder how she will react to that…
column9: 5) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 6-11-2010(2): I always remember this guy in Japan that used to drive a truck selling **sweet potatoes**. He had this really annoying loud speaker that would play a song and shout about how " [美味しい”](midori://search?text=美味しい”) his **sweet potato** es were. He would drive by my apartment and my work at all times of the day. It eventually pissed me off so much that I had a _ninja_ on stand by to kill him. "If I give the _word_ ," I told the _ninja_. The man found out though, and gave me some flowers, so I decided not to kill him.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(23): The idiot savant was thought to be a **quack** because he couldn't help but count the _number_ of _flowers_ he saw.
column6: 2) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 4-12-2008(23): I don't even know where Heisig got this keyword from. Using "thicket" instead: Picture a thicket with a large number of flowers.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 10-5-2010(19): Notes: Keyword "quack" was presumably chosen due to its use in the compound 薮医者 , but the general meaning of this kanji is bush/thicket. Also note that it mostly appears in its alternate form: 藪.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 13-1-2007(9): The **quack** travels around with a _number_ of impressive looking _flowers_ that are supposed to be good for something, but really don't work at all.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 12-11-2010(5): 薮医者 =藪医者 藪の中 =薮の中, 竹藪 =竹薮, 薮蛇 =藪蛇), 藪睨み [quack](../v4/2403.html) (#2403 薮) やぶ … Parts:艹, 数 (數）(cf 藪[Unicode-0x85ea](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/34282) (#34282 藪), ) … Note: Nelson: 4088, Spahn: 3k15.1. Usu written as 藪 with 婁 [Unicode-0x5a41](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/23105) (#23105 婁), not 娄[Unicode-0x5a04](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/23044) (#23044 娄) … Story: At the dawn of political correctness, a term was needed to replace the offensive term for a **Quack** :Bush Doctor. The result was **Thicket** Doctor, a man with any _Number_ of medicines made from _Daisies_.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 12-5-2007(45): In the temple were _two altars_. One of them had the usual array of _fl0wers_ , but the other was adorned with **garlic** , so that the locals could pray to keep the vampires out.
column6: 2) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 2-9-2010(6): **Garlic** _flowers_ were placed on the _two altars_ of the small village that had been ravaged by vampires in an attempt to drive them away.
column7: 3) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 1-7-2009(4): The Vampire approaches - You take out a _clove_ of **garlic** _2 show_ him you mean business.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 12-1-2010(2): In a mediaeval European crypt, two vampires are sleeping in coffins, side by side, upon _two altars_. The villagers have put the biggest bunch of **garlic** _flowers_ they could collect, atop the _two altars_ in an attempt to weaken the vampires and stop them from terrorising the community.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 5-9-2011(1): 蒜 = 大蒜 =葫, 野蒜 , 名 : 畔蒜 , [garlic](../v4/2404.html) (#2404 蒜) ひる, にんにく … Parts:艹, 示 , 示 (cf 示 [show](../v4/1086.html) (#1086 示), 嚇かす [menacing/upbraid](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2026) (#2026 嚇) … Story:For Vampires, person meat is 人肉 . To stop them put **Garlic** Flowers on the _Two Altars_ from one side to the other.

column5: 1) [[thairob](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thairob)] 6-8-2008(37): After eating all the **BRACKEN** FLOWERS on the CLIFF, the MOUNTAIN GOAT belts out a huge YAWN and takes a nap. Unfortunately he never wakes up as the **BRACKEN** is highly carcinogenic to mountain goats….
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(15): **Bracken** is a _flower_ that grows on _cliffs_ and resembles a _fish spine_ _lacking_ stability.
column7: 3) [[DavidZ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DavidZ)] 3-7-2009(8): This is the name of a city (わらび) in Saitama. The kanji is so difficult to write, the city government sells a t-shirt with the stroke order: <http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20090702p2a00m0na004000c.html>.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 8-5-2007(7): These unusual type of **bracken** _plants_ do not grow in the usual forest places, but actually high on a _cliff_. Because the area _lacks_ _mountaingoats_ , the plants aren't eaten by them.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 5-12-2009(2): _Lackin'_ the **bracken** to blacken: An old tale in the _mountain goat_ community has it that a wee goat may attain the black coat so much admired in the dominant discourse by eating the small _flowers_ of a particular variety of **bracken** that grows on a particular _cliff_. This Kanji depicts one who tried it, ate all the **bracken** he could hold, but, alas, he had the wrong cliff,  & therefore the wrong **bracken**. His coat has not changed  & he is in despair, still _lackin'_ the **bracken** to blacken.

column5: 1) [[cb4960](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cb4960)] 9-1-2009(37): _Military officers_ make for good fertilizer. So after a war the _flowers_ in the military officer's graveyard **grow plentiful**.
column6: 2) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 27-11-2007(18): This reminds me of the old Peter, Paul and Mary anti-war song, "Where have all the flowers gone?" The final verse talks about the graveyards of _military officers_ being the place where _flowers_ **grow plentiful**.
column7: 3) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 14-1-2009(6): The _military officer_ ensures his _flowers_ **grow plentiful** , because he will need a huge amount of them to offer [consolation](../v4/1096.html) (#1096 慰) when his soldiers die.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 12-1-2010(3): This reminds me of the famous WWI poem "In Flanders Fields", about _military officers_ who fell in battle. "We shall not sleep, though poppies **grow (plentiful)** In Flanders fields.".
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(2): Despite his notoriety, _flowers_ **grow plentiful** on the _military officer_ 's grave.

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 15-11-2008(42): **Madder red** is an extract from a _flower_ which was used as fake blood in _western_ films.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 16-9-2006(10): **Madder red** is a colouring agent that is acquired out of the roots of _plants_ that grow in the _west_.
column7: 3) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 11-1-2009(6): Madder is a _flowering_ plant, the roots of which are used as a coloring agent. The dyeing technique of **madder red** was formed in Turkey and India, both of which are _west_ of Japan. ^^ A good historical explanation of **madder red** is here: <http://www.colorantshistory.org/MadderRed.html> . Botanical information: <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madder> .
column8: 4) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 27-4-2010(1): **MADDER RED** is a dye traditionally made from the roots of _Rubia tinctorum_ , a _PLANT_ (= _FLOWER_ ) native to _WESTERN_ and Central Asia, i.e. the lands to the _WEST_ of China. This dye often produces the visually dominant color in what we call "oriental rugs", which, to the Chinese, must be, strictly speaking, " _OCCIDENTAL_ rugs". (<http://snipurl.com/madder>).
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 2-8-2008(1): _Clint Eastwood_ is brought to Japan as a mercenary guard along with Perry's fleet. One night, a group of bandits attacks and and _Clint_ gets into a firefight with dozens of Japanese ninja. Knowing he can't win, he looks around for something, anything - ah! Some **madder red**. He grabs the _flower_ and spreads it over his body, and then comes out. Knowing a bit of Japanese, he appeals for mercy: "I'm injured, I give up! See? _Aka_ (red)! _Aka, ne_! （The plant is pronounced アカネ）.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 10-2-2007(30): The **candle rush** doesn't bloom often, but when it does, the _flowers_ must be _perfect_.
column6: 2) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 29-1-2008(14): There was a **candle rush** because these scented candles were _perfect_ , smelling just like real _flowers_.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 15-11-2008(9): On valentines day (a.k.a. the **candle rush** ), people are rushing to buy candles and the _perfect flowers_ for their lover. Of course they do this all with a smile 莞爾 【かんじ】として.
column8: 4) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 10-6-2009(7): I prefer using "smiling" as keyword. Imagine her smile when you give her the perfect flowers.
column9: 5) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 11-1-2009(4): If you were wise in the middle ages, you wouldn't waste time collecting _flowers_ , you would spend your time collecting **candle rush** , the pith of which was _perfect_ for making candle wicks. See <http://www.rushlight.org/research/juncus.html> for a description. More information here: <http://sognogfjordane.kulturnett.no/sognfolkemuseum/Liv/Kulturlandskap/CULTIVATEDLANDS.htm> and a picture here: <http://sognogfjordane.kulturnett.no/sognfolkemuseum/Liv/Kulturlandskap/kultur33.jpg>.

column5: 1) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 17-11-2007(24): Debt **collector** s will even hustle _ghosts_ for the _flowers_ on their bodies' graves.
column6: 2) [[At0m5k](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/At0m5k)] 12-8-2009(18): This _demon_ is a bit of an oddball, he's a **collector** of rare _flower_ s, most of the time you can seem him trawling the graveyards looking for species that he doesn't yet have.
column7: 3) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 7-11-2010(4): A bad-ass demon slayer who **collects** demon heads… and flowers.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(3): The _ghost_ was a **collector** of _flowers_.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-1-2007(3): … And in the garden you can see the _ghost_ of a once famous _flower_ **collector**.

column5: 1) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 2-1-2009(35): **Sedge** is a flower (plant) that looks like grass, much like bureaucrats look a lot like real humans.
column6: 2) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 19-5-2009(20): **Sedge** is a very "boring" flower. It just looks like grass. So who would have such a _flower_ in his house but the _bureaucrats_?
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 7-1-2007(11): The _bureaucrats_ wanted all the **sedge** _plants_ in the district counted. Whatever will they think of next…
column8: 4) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 29-11-2009(2): **SEDGE** is a FLOWERING plant that is a lot like BUREAUCRAT. There are about 4,000 species of them and left to their own they'll continue to proliferate.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(2): The _bureaucrat_ tried smoking **sedge** _flowers_ because someone told him it looked like "grass".

column5: 1) [[At0m5k](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/At0m5k)] 12-8-2009(23): After breaking up with her boyfriend and ditching him, she threw the _flower_ s and _locket_ he gave her into the **ditch reeds**.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 13-9-2006(12): The lost _locket_ was found between the _flowers_ of the **ditch reed**.
column7: 3) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 31-5-2007(10): As soon as Iris decided to **ditch reed** she took off the _locket_ he gave her and tossed it along with the _corsage_ into the nearest ditch. Iris is quite a bitch to **ditch reed** on the night of the prom!
column8: 4) [[BladeWalker](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BladeWalker)] 12-7-2012(6): THANK GOD THIS IS THE LAST OF THE FLOWER KANJI IN RTK3. There were 65 of them! Time to **ditch** all these **reed** s, and seal all of these _flowers_ away in the _locket_ of your mind.
column9: 5) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 5-3-2010(2): Small tip: RtK3 is plagued with a number of altogether unremarkable plant keywords. So it might be useful to give the keywords themselves a secondary meaning based on homonyms (most of us do this anyway) So for me any kind of reed is **Elliot Reid** from the TV show Scrubs. If you've seen it, making up stories will be very easy.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 10-10-2007(21): Imagine a trail of brussel _sprouts_ along a _road_. You follow it, picking up each sprout and eating it as you go along. Eventually, after the last sprout, you find your reward – a milky **Way**.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 31-5-2007(18): A _road_ magically _sprouts_ up to show the chosen ones onto the **Way**.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 13-9-2006(8): _Sprouts_ are the one and only true **Way** if you are travelling the _road_ of becoming a vegitarian.
column8: 4) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 22-8-2011(2): (Inspired by Katsuo) Imagine an old master teaching you the " **Way** of the _sprout_ , by making you eat all the _sprouts_ along the _sprout road_.
column9: 5) [[dancingblade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dancingblade)] 16-7-2010(2): The **Way** of the Vegetarian is to follow the _road_ of _sprouts_.

column5: 1) [[hknamida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hknamida)] 6-1-2008(34): When you're following someone along a _road_ high atop a _mountain_ , it is easy to **track** them **down** , since all **tracks** lead **down**.
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 3-3-2010(13): Despite travelling all the _mountain roads and paths_ , no one could **track down** the Yeti.
column7: 3) [[HolyKotor](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/HolyKotor)] 29-10-2011(4): It was easy to **track down** the criminal hiding in the _mountains_ , because he built a _road_ leading straight to his hideout.
column8: 4) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 21-12-2008(2): The posse was able to **track down** Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, even on the _mountain roads_.
column9: 5) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 12-12-2008(1): **Track down, follow (a road), pursue.** When a person escapes, they often flee (or _move_ ) to the base of the _mountains_ in order to avoid being **tracked down** or pursued.

column5: 1) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 11-1-2009(57): There are _words_ written on the _road_ , but you have to **crawl** along to read them: 'If…you…can…read…this…you…look…silly…'.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 6-4-2007(28): Some of those amateur marathon runners at the end seem merely to **crawl** on the _road_ instead of running. They truly need _words_ of encouragement.
column7: 3) [[hknamida](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hknamida)] 6-1-2008(9): _Socrates_ , unused to running the marathon, **crawl** s pathetically down the _road_.
column8: 4) [[LloydGA](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LloydGA)] 1-7-2008(2): An anti- verbal abuse campaign. Volunteers carry big styrofoam words on their back as they run a marathon to represent the burden placed on children by their verbally abusive parents. Imagine standing at the finish line to see one of the runners **crawl** down the road with your favorite abusive word on his back, panting for breath. (Props to astridtops).
column9: 5) [[Sinologe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Sinologe)] 28-1-2010(1): No.11 **this** (zhe4) —— You _say_ " **this** " referring to something/ to let someone's eyes " **move** " on a certain thing. —— [http://www.yellowbridge.com/chinese/character- etymology.php?searchChinese=1&zi=%E9%80%99](http://www.yellowbridge.com/chinese/character- etymology.php?searchChinese=1&zi=%E9%80%99) —— **Are you looking for 这?** : <http://hanzimnemonics.blogspot.com/2010/01/mnemos-for-some-characters.html> ——.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(49): Due to _potatoes_ in the _road_ , there was a **detour**.
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 6-3-2010(15): A truck had spilt its load of _potatoes_ on the _road_ , forcing us to make a **detour**.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 26-7-2010(2): When you're on the _road_ to Sydney, take a **detour** via Robertson, NSW, to see the Big _Potato_ (affectionately known as the Big Turd). <http://www.australiantraveller.com/component/content/article/2227>.
column8: 4) [[ghinzdra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ghinzdra)] 6-4-2009(1): Now and then due to the CommonAgriculturePolicy issue farmers go on a demonstration throwing away their POTATOES to block ROADS …. a piece of advice : just take a **detour** before meeting them…your tires will be thankful… exemple :Berserk vol 04 : そのためには川沿いに迂回しやつらの背後から奇襲を仕掛ける .
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 11-3-2011(): 迂回 , 迂遠 , 迂愚 , 迂闊 , [detour](../v4/2415.html) (#2415 迂) ウ( 宇 ） … Parts:于, 辶 (cf: 芋 [potato](../v4/1655.html) (#1655 芋), 宇宙 [eaves](../v4/1656.html) (#1656 宇), 逗留 [standstill](../v4/2423.html) (#2423 逗)) … Story: It's not potatoes just randomly spilled in the road, it's the traveling hot _Potato_ vendors that are clogging the _Road_ so much that they are forcing **Detour** s all over Kagoshima (home of 芋焼酎 ) (Beans in the road however bring things to a complete 逗留 [standstill](../v4/2423.html) (#2423 逗)).

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 31-1-2007(31): It really **elude** s me why we have two kanji with the same keyword… this one and [deviate/elude](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1973) (#1973 逸). But lets intertwine their stories: The rabbit, who **elude** d capture ([deviate/elude](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1973) (#1973 逸)) on the _road_ , was finally caught when someone threw a _shield_ over it.
column6: 2) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 8-5-2008(14): The Spartan had to block the _road_ to stop the advancing enemy army, but he tried to **shirk** his duty and threw away his _shield_. That's suicide.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 23-3-2010(10): With [deviate/elude](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1973) (#1973 逸) already taken, Heisig changed the keyword for this one to **shirk** (= **elude** responsibility) in the 2nd edition. [from Corodon] STORY: Imagine a pre-battle speech, "Down that _road_ lies the enemy, raise your _shields_ and do not **shirk** ( **elude** your responsibility)". You can imagine the rest… "If you find yourself alone… riding in green fields with the sun on your face. Do not be troubled… for you are in Elysium, and you're already dead!".
column8: 4) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 28-12-2009(6): Could fabrice change the damn keyword to **shirk** already?
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 12-4-2012(3): Roman legions used to form an impenetrable formation called the testudo, where their _shields_ were held together like a tortoise's shell, protecting them from arrows and spears as they marched along the _road_. It was thus imperative that none of the soldiers **shirk** his duty, because if just one _shield_ was not held firmly in place, flaming projectiles could enter and destroy the formation. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File>:Testudo_formation.jpg.

column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 14-2-2008(38): Going out on the _road_ to use a _pointy_ (see my comments in 峰 [summit](../v4/1562.html) (#1562 峰)) part of my anatomy, is called a **tryst**.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 8-10-2006(31): While I was having a **tryst** with my secret lover on the _road_ , I had to quickly run towards the _bushes_ with my _walking legs_ , because my husband suddenly appeared.
column7: 3) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 17-5-2009(10): There is almost no chance to have a **tryst** when you walk the _road_ and show your _pubic hair_ (= bush under walking legs) to everyone .
column8: 4) [[manubear](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/manubear)] 10-8-2012(4): Seeing _pubic hair_ on the _road_ is a sure sign of a lovers' **tryst**! ( 巡り逢う ).
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(3): _Walking legs_ walk over a _Smart Car_ on the side of the _road_ where inside two lovers are having a cramped **tryst**.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 10-1-2007(40): On the long long _road_ through the desert, **far off** you can see a _condor_ flying…
column6: 2) [[shirahime](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shirahime)] 27-8-2008(17): The condor might seem like its **far off** in the distance now, but if you don't start running down the road you could be dinner.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 15-3-2010(1): While on the _road_ , I suddenly heard Andean panpipes playing. I looked up and saw a _condor_ **far off**.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(1): This _road_ to kanji mastery makes me feel like I'm _made of fail_ : everything always seems so **far off** in the distance!
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 3-8-2008(1): This is a pretty cool item you can get in _Mario Kart Road_ \- it's a little guy who rides a _vulture-shaped tram_ that traverses over the top of the track, and tells you how **far off** the other racers are. You simply speak into a little radio asking for the location of a certain racer - "Where's Mario?" "…uh, let's see…ah, there he is. Wow, you better get a move on if you want to place this race - he's really **far off** ".

column5: 1) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 3-3-2008(28): (From astridtops) **Faraway** (2nd edition keyword) from civilisation, there are no camping sites, so you can see people in a _pup tent_ near the _road_ doing some wild camping instead.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 12-12-2009(7): [+Katsuo] In **remote** areas you can pitch your _pup tent_ in the _road_ , as there is no traffic. To disambiguate 悠 [permanence/remote](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/958) (#958 悠) & 遼 [remote](../v4/2419.html) (#2419 遼), recall that 悠久 [ゆうきゅう] distinctly implies _permanence_ , while a _pup tent_ is by definition and design a temporary structure, particularly if it's pitched on a _road_.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 15-11-2008(5): When I was lost **faraway** from home, I put up a _pup tent_ on the side of the _road_ so that people driving by could see me.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 17-11-2006(4): (Another double with RTKI :(). In the **remote** area, there are no camping sites, so you can see people in a _pup tent_ near the _road_ doing some wild camping instead.
column9: 5) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-2-2007(): In **remote** areas you can pitch your _pup tent_ in the _road_ (as there is no traffic).

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 22-3-2007(32): When the _wealthy_ go on the _road_ , they always pretend to be pursuing **pressing** matters, so they speed along in their big BMW's.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(18): Those with _wealth_ speed down the _road_ as if they have some **pressing** matter to attend.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 12-1-2010(4): The _wealthy_ drive with the utmost arrogance and aggression when they're on the _road_ , because they act like their daily tasks are much more **pressing** than anyone else's.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 13-8-2008(3): [+astrid] Everyone is enjoying the _Mario Kart Road_ final race! Everyone is on the edge of their seats! As the racers enter the final lap, the black flag is flown, and the race is canceled. A voice comes on the loudspeaker: "Kart fans, we apologize - the race has been shut down for a **pressing** emergency." A large Rolls Royce - an obvious sign of _wealth_ \- rolls leisurely into view. A _wealthy, wealthy_ man sits in the back, saying, "sorry, but I have **pressing** matters and had to use this road".
column9: 5) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 11-1-2009(2): I had a **pressing** need for more money, so I took the _road to wealth_ and riches.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(40): _Beg_ in the _road_ **until** you get what you want.

column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 2-5-2007(7): "I'm going to sit here by the side of the _road_ , in front of the government building and _beg_ **until** they give me a pension", the war veteran said.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 8-11-2010(6): Hitchhiking: You stand by the _road_ , stick out your thumb, and _beg_ for a ride **until** someone picks you up.
column9: 5) [[paasan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paasan)] 18-7-2010(4): He was _begging_ on the _road_ **until** I drove over him by 'accident'.
