column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(11): I ripped a huge _bean_ fart, bringing our _road_ trip to a **standstill**.
column7: 3) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 17-1-2009(10): The traffic on the ROAD is at a **standstill** because someone left a bunch of TABLES laying there.
column8: 4) [[paasan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paasan)] 20-7-2010(2): Remember the scene to every _Mr. Bean_ shows where he would fall onto the dark _road_ only lit up by a single light, seemingly in an **standstill**? We all know how it went though, Mr Bean never comes to an **standstill** and his shows are just as great today as they were back then!! <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C18q__R9dwo>.
column9: 5) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 28-8-2009(2): A new MR BEAN episode, this time he gets dropped off naked in the middle of the ROAD highway , in a complete **STANDSTILL** unable get past the frenetic traffic.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(30): A _St. Bernard_ balances a bottle of _horned whiskey_ on his nose to get it over the _city walls_ as a **courtesy** to his exiled master.
column6: 2) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 19-5-2009(12): The 酋 [chieftain](../v4/2906.html) (#2906 酋) and his _St. Bernard_ practice common **courtesy** at the city walls: Every newcomer is kissed ardently. The women by the _chieftain_ , the men by the _dog_.
column7: 3) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 11-1-2009(11): (Tip: Horns + whiskey bottle = _Red Bull_ (see shakkun's story on [furthermore/waver](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1438) (#1438 猶)). Story: Please do not feed _Red Bull_ to the _St Bernard_ , as a **courtesy** to all of us who live within the _city walls_. Last time someone did that, he caused chaos everywhere and nearly destroyed the _city walls_.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 16-3-2007(5): As a **courtesy** , the Swiss had friendly _St. Bernard dogs_ walking around outside the _city walls_ with little vats with brandy to help stranded travellers. Well, these days the _Horned Whiskey_ corporation won the government contract, so the brandy has been exchanged by this brand of whiskey.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 24-11-2010(1): 鄭重 =丁重, 鄭箋 , [courtesy](../v4/2425.html) (#2425 鄭) テイ … Parts: 酋 [chieftain](../v4/2906.html) (#2906 酋), 大 , .阝 (cf 擲弾 [Unicode-0x638a](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/25482) (#25482 掊), 噂 [gossip](../v4/2161.html) (#2161 噂)) … Similars: 諄い [polite](../v4/2706.html) (#2706 諄), 鄭重 [courtesy](../v4/2425.html) (#2425 鄭) … Story: As a **Courtesy** to his visitors, Mr. Burns offers _Large cans of Red Bull_ , before he releases the hounds on them. (they should be able to get away because they get wings, but).

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 19-3-2007(27): On the _pinnacle_ of the secret government organisation, every **nook** and cranny of the pinnacle is under government control, even the _ricefields_. You can't even drop a _hairpin_ there without being noticed.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(14): Those _apprehensive_ when they reach the _pinnacle_ often find a **nook** to hide in.
column7: 3) [[ghinzdra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ghinzdra)] 21-9-2009(5): You want to find the **nook** where they hiding in the PINNACLE ? look I hate to ruin the mood but it would be like looking for a HAIRPIN in a whole FIELD . To put it midly I m slighlty APPREHENSIVE .
column8: 4) [[dancingblade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dancingblade)] 16-7-2010(3): (+astridtops) Every **nook** and cranny of _The Pinnacle_ is under government surveillance. It gives people a good reason to feel _apprehensive_ about visiting.
column9: 5) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 30-11-2009(3): With limited space, every **NOOK** and cranny has to be used at THE PINNACLE. There is hardly enough room between FIELDS to squeeze in a HAIRPIN.

column5: 1) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 11-2-2008(32): I entered the stable and felt an _icy_ chill. Yes, that _horse_ is **possessed** and the only way to deal with it is a stake in the _heart_!
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 15-11-2008(22): The _frozen horse_ still had a _heart_ beat, it must be **possessed**!
column7: 3) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 12-4-2008(10): "Is this thing **possessed**?" the Trojans wondered when they first encountered the Greek's _trojan horse_. "It feels _ice_ cold but there's definitely a beating _heart_ inside".
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 19-3-2011(3): 狼憑き , 憑かれる , 憑く , 憑依 , 憑き物 =憑物 [possessed](../v4/2428.html) (#2428 憑) ヒョウ, つく, つかれる … Parts: 冫, 馬 , 心 … Story: The original belief in possession came from the feeling of waking up from a dream and being unable to move. Thus a night _Mare_ when you wake in the night _Frozen_ , with your _Heart_ racing, is when people feel **Possessed**.
column9: 5) [[ientsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ientsu)] 2-8-2009(2): There is only one way to save someone **possessed** by a bad spirit. They have to eat the _frozen_ _heart_ of _Horse_.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-6-2007(53): You have to be _young_ at _heart_ to **attract** the opposite sex.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 5-6-2007(13): Take just one look at the junior idol video industry (or don't!) in Japan to understand how the _young_ **attract** the _hearts_ of the Japanese. ,-).
column7: 3) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 17-1-2008(5): Contrast with [attractive](../v4/430.html) (#430 嬌). Think of **attract** the verb as specific procedures or actions taken to **attract** the opposite sex. The _young_ and foolish think that pouring out your _heart_ is the way to **attract** the opposite sex, but more mature lovers realize that restraint, mystery and coyness do much more to **attract** a partner. Remember, **attract** the verb: things you do, behaviors that may change over time. (not the adjective [attractive](../v4/430.html) (#430 嬌)).
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 18-11-2010(3): 惹く , 惹起する , 注意を惹く , 惹き付ける , [attract](../v4/2429.html) (#2429 惹) ジャク( 若 ), ひく(now usu 引く ) … Parts: 若 [young](../v4/223.html) (#223 若), 心 (cf 匿う [hide](../v4/1692.html) (#1692 匿)) … Similars: 嬌声 [attractive](../v4/430.html) (#430 嬌), 惹く [attract](../v4/2429.html) (#2429 惹) … Story: trophy wives **Attract** , because they are _Young at Heart_ , they say. (I think it is not the young at heart that **attract** s them though.).
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 20-12-2006(2): People who are _young_ are often easily **attract** ed to each other, but they have a fickle _heart_ : some of them seem to think being with the same person more than a day is uncommon!

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 5-6-2007(37): **Without exception** , the _heart_ of every hunter starts beating like crazy as he comes upon the _tracks of an animal_.
column6: 2) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 22-12-2008(18): If you get addicted to playing _dice_ ( 番 ） **without exception** you will end up losing your _rice fields_ ( 田 ） so take my warning to _heart_.
column7: 3) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 2-8-2009(3): Furries, people whose _hearts_ beat like crazy when they see _animal tracks_ , are despised by all other factions/fandoms **without exception**.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 16-9-2008(3): If you look at the footprints of one of those really primitive _T-Rex_ s, you'll be astounded at how deep it is. But prepare for another astounding fact - each step, **without exception** , marks the loss of one animal's life (or heart). This is because the _T-Rex_ was such an inefficient animal that it required tons of energy to move - so it needed to kill at least one animal to move one step. So imagine tracking a _T-Rex_ and marking a _heart_ on a chart, and shaking your head at the massive waste of life…
column9: 5) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 31-1-2011(1): **Without exception** , all the braves must find the _animal tracks_ then eat the raw _heart_ of the beast in order to become a man. (The nuance of this kanji is "all").

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-2-2007(54): His _heart_ got tied in a _knot_ and he died **instantaneously**.
column6: 2) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 28-1-2009(9): Instead of Blood Clot, think of Blood KNOT, where if you get a Blood KNOT that goes to your HEART, you will die **INSTANTANEOUSLY**.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(6): A _knot_ in your _heart_ kills you **instantaneously**.
column8: 4) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 10-1-2009(6): A HEART will NOT **instantaneously** heal, forget, or get better.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 13-8-2008(2): This is an old Japanese metaphor for something that happens **instantaneously** \- "the time it takes for your _heart_ to _knot_ " (the un _knot_ ing is implied here). In other words, the time it takes for your _heart_ to beat. **Instantaneously** \- in a _heart_ beat.

column5: 1) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 15-5-2008(31): The caveman, introducing his **firstborn son** : "And this is _thing_ with _heart_. Come yesterday from woman's stomach.".
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(11): Everyone wants their **firstborn son** to have a good _heart_ and a big " _thing_ ".
column7: 3) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 19-4-2011(7): 惣菜 =総菜, 惣嫁 =総嫁, 惣社 =総社, [firstborn son](../v4/2432.html) (#2432 惣) ソウ, 名乗り : おさむ, のぶ, ふさ) … Parts: 物 [thing](../v4/1050.html) (#1050 物), 心 … Note: This does not mean first born son, that is 長男 . It is a name **firstborn son** s are often given. Other than name uses, this character is interchangeable with, and largely replaced by 総 [general](../v4/1366.html) (#1366 総). … Story: **Firstborn Sons** are in **General** , such important _Things_ that _Knot_ having one first is like a punch in the _Solar Plexus 心_.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 20-1-2007(4): Men have a special yearning for a **firstborn son**. It's a _thing_ of the _heart_.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 18-1-2010(3): The doctor told the new father that his **firstborn son** was born with a _cow heart_ , and that surgical intervention was necessary immediately. "I'll decide if surgery is necessary, and I believe it is _not_." replied the proud dad. The father was proved right in the end, and the **firstborn son** with a _cow's heart_ was successful in life and went on to study Japanese. Ladies and gentlemen, I have a confession, and an announcement to make: that **firstborn son** with a _cow's heart_ is me. ( _NOT_!).

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-6-2007(60): Nick XXX needs a heart transplant quick. He goes to a _meeting of butchers_ where one of them is about to chop up an ideal _heart_. Nick snatches away the heart from under the butcher’s knife – just **in the nick of time**. (note: replace XXX with a Nick you know).
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 26-11-2006(28): The guy who had a _heart_ attack at the _butcher's meeting_ was saved **in the nick of time**.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 6-3-2010(16): To ensure _healing_ 癒 , you must banish the _sickness_ 疒 **in the nick of time**.
column8: 4) [[mikemorr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mikemorr)] 2-1-2010(6): Depending on the font you're using, the top part of this kanji is either 兪 or 俞. 俞 (Yú) is a Chinese family name. If " _butcher's meeting_ " doesn't help you remember 俞 in [transport](../v4/289.html) (#289 輸), [rebuke](../v4/352.html) (#352 諭), [pleasure](../v4/628.html) (#628 愉), [healing](../v4/2037.html) (#2037 癒), and [in the nick of time](../v4/2433.html) (#2433 愈), think of a specific person with that name instead, such as 俞晴 (actress/singer Yu Qing), 俞琤 (HK radio personality Winnie Yu Ching), 俞逊发 (flutist Yu Xunfa), 俞飞鸿 (actress Faye Yu / Yu Feihong), or 俞鴻鈞 (fmr. ROC premier Yu Hung-Chun).
column9: 5) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(5): A guy at the _butcher's conference_ has a _heart_ attack, we called the ambulance just **in the nick of time**.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 17-11-2006(27): In this astrological tempel, a _sun_ is depicted, **overarching** the _Sign of the Hare_.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-4-2011(18): When the _sun_ shines during the _sign of the hare_ the hares go mad and have an **overarching** desire to jump over arches. Edit: More useful keyword: Main use of this kanji is for the star cluster "The Pleiades" (すばる in Japanese). Story: Which star cluster is **The Pleiades**? Well look closely and you can see a _hare_ hopping from one _sun_ to another.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 16-2-2010(13): This is the kanji for the Pleiades star cluster, read in Japanese as すばる. It's also a male and female given name. The car manufacturer gets its name from this. Story: The _sign of the hare_ in the Chinese zodiac refers, among other things, to the time of day corresponding to 5-7am. This is the time of day when the _sun_ rises, **overarching** the world with its magnificence and power. (For an extra visual image, imagine the _sun_ rising behind a giant pair of _hare's ears_.).
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(6): The **overarching** meaning of Easter _Sunday_ goes above and beyond the _sign of the hare_.
column9: 5) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 1-2-2010(2): As has been pointed out, this is the kanji for the **Pleiades** , or Seven Sisters, cluster. Legend tells us that Zeus changed the seven sisters into stars to save them from Orion, the hunter. What is not known is that in order to keep Orion off the scent, Zeus slapped the _sign of the hare_ beneath the _sun_. The ruse worked: Orion forgot about the seven sisters and has been looking for the hare ever since.

column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(3): I started making **progress** in my life when I stopped spending my _day_ being horny over _Star Wars_.

column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 16-8-2011(2): First Names: 長晟 (ながあきら), 晟 (あきら) [aglow](../v4/2438.html) (#2438 晟) セイ( 成 ), ジョウ( 成 ), あきら, あき, てる … Parts: 日 , 成 [turn into](../v4/361.html) (#361 成) (cf 城 [castle](../v4/362.html) (#362 城), 誠 [sincerity](../v4/363.html) (#363 誠), 大盛り [boom](../v4/1457.html) (#1457 盛), etc.) … Note: Name Only Kanji. … Story: Most peoples first view of _Japan 日_ is _Narita 成田_ airport **Aglow** with the neon signs common around Japan.

column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 30-10-2010(3): 昂騰 =高騰, 昂る , 昂揚 =高揚, 昂奮 =興奮[elevate](../v4/2449.html) (#2449 昂) コウ, たかぶる … Parts: 昴 -ノ…OR 日 , 卯 -ノ (cf: 抑える , 昴 ) … Note: Often replaced by 興 or 高 … Story: You have to truly **Elevate** to rip the ear off the _Japanese Sign of the Hare_ , that great 昴 [overarching](../v4/2435.html) (#2435 昴) sign that is spread over Japan, Like Michael Jordan in the Space Jam movie, skying up to rip the ear of the Bugs Bunny on the movie banner.

column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(4): A _whirlwind_ turned the _tree_ into **pickets**.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 1-9-2009(2): The _trees_ were going to **picket** the lumberyard with **picket** signs made of **picket** s, but a _whirlwind_ came along and blew the **picket** -sign **picket** s away.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 8-3-2007(30): The **holly** _tree_ has leaves which are always green. This is very practical in _winter_ , when so much isn't, so that's why it became very popular as christmas decoration.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(10): The **holly** is a _tree_ that lasts through _winter_ (aka the " **holly** days") (thanks herman).
column7: 3) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 24-1-2009(6): All the best **holly** -days are during the winters, x-mas, new years…emperor's birthday?
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 20-6-2007(2): _Winter_ is when I dress the _trees_ with **holly** and good Christmas cheer.
column9: 5) [[hirata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hirata)] 4-2-2013(1): Cute tsundere Hiiragi Kagami offers you a Christmas gift under the **holly** tree one winter night. Naturally, she's looking away from you in an attempt to hide her feelings. (The kanji is pronounced ひいらぎ, and is used in the last names of both of the Hiiragi sisters in Lucky Star.).

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 19-11-2008(27): The **citron** is relatively unknown overseas, but **citron** _trees_ are beginning to _sprout_ up everwhere in Japan.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 5-12-2009(8): In keeping with the move to greener autos Citroën has introduced its new line which instead of 油 [oil](../v4/1107.html) (#1107 油) runs on an extract from **citron** _trees_.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 30-4-2007(5): No, those things you see growing on the _trees_ are not _sprouts_ (which do not grow on trees). They're **citron** s.
column8: 4) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 19-2-2008(3): Never mind crashing into a _tree_ , a **Citron** 2CV would crash even if it hit a _brussel sprout_!
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(2): The **citron** is a _tree_ beginning to _sprout_ up in countries outside of Asia.

column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 14-6-2007(42): **Wooden bowl** s made of _wood_ have the _address_ of the maker on the on the side.
column6: 2) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 29-12-2008(13): This is a specially hand-crafted _wooden_ bowl. If you turn is over, you can see the _address_ of the craftsman on the bottom.
column7: 3) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 13-6-2007(4): 21st century conservationistic etiquette dictates that every **wooden bowl** be engraved with the _address_ of the unlucky _tree_ that died in its creation.
column8: 4) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 13-7-2012(1): I got a splinter from eating out of a **wooden bowl** , so I checked the _wood_ for the _address_ of the manufacturer so I knew where to go to complain.
column9: 5) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 22-12-2011(1): I made sure that all my WOODED BOWLS have my ADDRESS written on them.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(20): The _tree_ your _mother_ warned you about is the **hemlock**.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 20-6-2007(8): _Mother_ called me out to the _tree_ in order to partake of some delicious **hemlock** tea.
column7: 3) [[hakugeki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hakugeki)] 13-8-2011(7): This is not a poison **hemlock**! It is a tree from genus Tsuga (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsuga>, <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsuga>_sieboldii). According to Wikipedia "The common name **hemlock** is derived from a perceived similarity in the smell of its crushed foliage to that of the unrelated plant poison **hemlock**. Unlike poison **hemlock** (conium), the species of Tsuga are not poisonous." Story: In ancient Japan _mother_ s planted **hemlock** _tree_ in their gardens when child was born.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-10-2006(6): **Hemlock** is a plant with white flowers and finely divided leaves, and it produces the _mother_ of all poisons. But actually, there is also a _tree_ called **Hemlock** , which apparently grows in the US, on the west coast. I wonder if it is as poisonous…?
column9: 5) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 15-1-2009(4): I was playing on the **hemlock** _tree_ when some bark came off and I choked on some poisonous pieces of _wood_ , so my _mother_ performed the **Heimlich** manoeuvre.

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 25-11-2008(35): Give the **spindle tree** a spin, if you can guess where it lands _correctly_ , you'll get a prize!
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 19-3-2010(3): **Spindle tree** or Euonymus japonicus (botanical name). Far from being "spindly", this tree is bushy and evergreen, thus making ideal hedging for those seeking privacy. So if you want to be anonymous, "Euonymus" is the _correct tree_ to choose.
column7: 3) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 13-6-2007(3): **Spend a little** time in a **spindle tree** and I am sure you will come up with the _correct_ answer… eventually.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 14-2-2010(2): There's actually no such thing as the **spindle tree** , but it sounds like an appropriate name for a plant. Whenever young students are curious as to the name of an unusual _tree_ , they ask their teachers. If the teacher doesn't know the _correct_ name, the default answer they give is "…um, yeah that's a **spindle tree**." They usually follow it up with some difficult-to-decipher technical language, like "Yeah, the **spindle tree** is a dioecious evergreen monocotyledon. Native to Japan.".
column9: 5) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 11-1-2009(2): I always forget what a **spindle tree** looks like. When that happens, I have to check Wikipedia to make sure I'm looking at the _correct tree_.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(47): The **sacred Shinto tree** is a _tree_ of the _gods_.
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 14-3-2010(14): This kanji is a 国字 (こくじ) i.e. created in Japan. Logically it combines _tree_ 木 + _gods_ 神 giving us a "tree of the gods" ( **sacred Shinto tree** ). Note: 榊 (さかき) has 2 variants where middle element is either 礻or 示 .
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 28-12-2006(5): The **sacred Shinto tree** is of course a _tree_ that is dedicated to the _gods_.
column8: 4) [[hirata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hirata)] 4-2-2013(): Sakaki agrees to go on a date with you, so the both of you visit a shrine. She spends the entire time staring at the **sacred Shinto tree** , quietly making a prayer to the gods. Maybe you should have picked a better place! (The Sakaki here is from Azumanga Daioh, and her name uses the same Kanji.).
column9: 5) [[Haych](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Haych)] 6-11-2012(): I'm imagining the **sacred shinto tree** as a _tree_ that they use to communicate with the _gods_ like the Godswood in game of thrones.

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 20-6-2007(45): The **evergreen oak** is a _tree_ most _strict_ with its leaves: they must be **evergreen** , or else!
column6: 2) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 11-1-2009(13): A very _strict_ master dictates that the slaves must ensure that the **evergreen oaks** are ever green. One day a slave notices, to his terror, that one of them has turned brown! Not wanting to get buried up to his crotch in soil, he quickly pulls out a can of green spray paint and paints the entire _tree_. Even if that tree wasn't ever green before, it certainly is now!
column7: 3) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 24-1-2009(3): **Evergreen oak** s are TREES that are STRICTLY green.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 5-9-2011(1): 樫 =橿=槝=櫧, [evergreen oak](../v4/2491.html) (#2491 樫)？, かし … Parts: 木 , 堅 [strict](../v4/853.html) (#853 堅) … Note: The tree カシ is both 橿 [sturdy oak](../v4/2509.html) (#2509 橿) and 樫 [evergreen oak](../v4/2491.html) (#2491 樫) … Story: (Since 'strict' for 堅い is a mistake anyway): My Girlfriend calls me the **Evergreen Oak** , because I always have _Wood_ , and I am a _Slave_ to my _Crotch_ and my _Dirty, Dirty_ mind, and she makes these names from elements of kanji.
column9: 5) [[Corodon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Corodon)] 30-12-2011(): The **evergreen oak** isn't a _tree_ , _strict_ ly speaking. It's a shrubbery. (not true, but if it helps with remembering this kanji…).

column5: 1) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 5-9-2009(23): The tree of white lies is the Chinese white pine. The _tree_ of _truth_ is the **Chinese black pine**.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 13-6-2007(20): _Truth_ is that all **Chinese** secretly **pine** for **black** " _trees_ " if you get what I mean!
column7: 3) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 19-4-2008(6): This is the _tree_ of _truth_ (because you get true-to-life sculptures using it for bonsais). The **Chinese black pine** s to look like the rest of the Chinese, to be Chinese, and suspects he really is, so he goes to this _tree_ of _truth_ to find out. "Am I really Chinese?" he asks.
column8: 4) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 19-2-2008(6): The Chinese make _truth_ serum from the **Chinese black pine** _tree_.
column9: 5) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 14-6-2010(5): The old form, 槇 [Unicode-0x69c7](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/27079) (#27079 槇) is more common, and we should all use it.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 16-5-2007(21): The special brand _Horned Whiskey_ is riped in special oak caskets made of the **Japanese oak** _tree_.
column6: 2) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 3-8-2009(12): _Wood_ from the **Japanese oak** is very valuable. That's why the [chieftain](../v4/2906.html) (#2906 酋) demands that his house be made from the **Japanese oak**.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 14-2-2010(8): _Red Bull_ tastes different in Japan, because it's aged in _wooden_ barrels made of **Japanese oak**. Costs a lot more than the normal stuff, but it tastes better.
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 20-6-2007(3): Drink of _horned Japanese whiskey_ until you go and **croak** : we'll make sure to put you into a **Japanese oak**.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(2): [+astridtops] _Horned Whiskey_ is ripened and mellowed in special oak barrels made of the **Japanese oak** _tree_ , but of course planks from the _tree_ must be _glued_ together before the _revered_ whiskey goes into the [barrel](../v4/2506.html) (#2506 樽) 樽 .

column5: 1) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 14-2-2010(30): The tachibana, or **mandarin orange** , is a type of _tree_ which sometimes yields poor quality fruit. In such times, instead of simply _standing up_ and inviting customers to _make a deal_ , you must force the sale of your **mandarin orange** s by brandishing a _halberd_ and forcing the customer to _make a deal_ with you by purchasing your substandard fruit. [Note: along with 柚 [citrus tree](../v4/2482.html) (#2482 柑), this is used to describe all citrus plants - 柑橘類 かんきつるい means 'citrus fruit'.].
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 10-2-2007(9): The peddlar who likes to _make a deal_ stepped off his motorcycle helmet and took his _halberd_ to try and get some **mandarin orange** s off the _tree_.
column7: 3) [[At0m5k](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/At0m5k)] 15-8-2009(3): "Oh you like some **MANDARIN ORANGE** S? I sell you this whole _tree_ if you want, but why don't we _make a deal_ and I give you this _halberd_ as well. I have no use anymore." says the old asian farmer.
column8: 4) [[Corodon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Corodon)] 30-12-2011(2): Let's _make a deal_ – your **mandarin orange** _tree_ for my _halberd_. Sound fair?
column9: 5) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 21-11-2010(1): The reading of this kanji is たちばな, so I'm going to link it to the 戦国無双 characters of the same name. STORY: Ginchiyo Tachibana went to buy some **mandarin orange** s in a market. The vendor said he would _make a deal_ for her. Later, at the castle, she found out that they had been ripped off. Angry, she grabbed a halberd lodged in a tree. She then took the halberd and cut off the vendor's head (thus the top part of make a deal is gone).

column5: 1) [[Themistoclaus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Themistoclaus)] 25-2-2010(33): According to the Wikipedia article, **Japanese cypress** (hinoki) is grown for its high-quality _wood_ , which is used in the building of "temples, shrines, traditional noh theatres, baths" etc. So, this tree is vital to the construction of many of the major _meeting places_ in Japanese society. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamaecyparis_obtusa>.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 30-6-2007(8): The **Japanese cypress** is a good _tree_ to _meet_ at: the **Japanese** covers the atmosphere and the **cypress** presses on any spies. Hey, I tried.
column7: 3) [[cb4960](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cb4960)] 17-1-2009(6): Japanese science fiction company CyPress have the weekly staff _meeting_ under the **Japanese cypress** _tree_ (its symbolic).
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 25-10-2006(3): The **Japanese cypress** is for Japanese the favourite _tree_ for _meetings_ with their beloved.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 1-9-2009(1): In an ironic twist the **Cy Press** has agreed to publish my book on **Japanese cypress** _trees_. I have a _meeting_ with its founder, Cy, underneath one, to sign the deal.

column5: 1) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 30-12-2008(22): My _wife_ wanted a special place to **roost** , so I built her one - on the top of that _tree_.
column6: 2) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 4-12-2008(18): Better meaning is "habitat" since this doesn't imply anything bird or nest related. Usual habitat for the wife is in a wood structure of some sort (avoiding using house to keep it out of the kanji).
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 24-9-2006(11): His _wife_ wanted the chickens in the hen house to be housed properly, so she chopped up a _tree_ and made wooden **roost** s for them to sit on.
column8: 4) [[Machine_Gun_Cat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Machine_Gun_Cat)] 29-7-2009(7): If my wifes being a bitch I go and **roost** in a tree.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(2): A frustrated _wife_ makes the _tree_ her **roost**.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 6-10-2007(50): For **nestling** , the _west_ side of the _tree_ is best – otherwise you get woken up by the sun in the morning. Remember: West is best for your nest.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 13-6-2007(8): Its a secret that **Nestlé** chocolate syrup is drawn from chocolate _trees_ that are found in the _west_.
column7: 3) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 20-5-2009(4): When Germany was still devided, even the birds preferred to **nestle** in the _West-trees_ rather than in East-trees: Mainly because they did not support Communism.
column8: 4) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 24-1-2009(2): I **nestle** d comfortably in a TREE with a bottle of WHISKEY.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 13-10-2006(): In the _West_ , most birds like to **nestle** in _trees_ , but there are other parts of the world where a lot of the birds **nestle** on the ground.

column5: 1) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 15-4-2008(46): When you see **bellflower** s next to a _tree_ , ring them for _good luck_.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 16-10-2006(9): When you see **bellflower** s growing under a _tree_ , it means _good luck_.
column7: 3) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 13-7-2010(6): If you're climbing a _tree_ , it's _good luck_ to bring a **bellflower** with you, because then if you get stuck you can ring it to call for help.
column8: 4) [[Gwindarr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Gwindarr)] 13-6-2008(1): Alright, the **bellflower** tree has no flowers and no bells. In place of these are aerosol cans which bloom out of the tree and occasionally clink together which must be how the tree got its name.
column9: 5) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 9-2-2011(): We used to have lots of _trees_ and **bellflower** s in our home in Sydney. It was great until someone came with an aerosol can and destroyed everything.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 6-10-2007(60): A normal grove is 林 , so in a **temple grove** half the _trees_ have been removed and replaced by _soil_ (presumably for graves).
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 3-8-2008(2): [+Katsuo] A **temple grove** may look like any other grove from one side, but when you get closer, you realize that it is very special. A **temple grove** is for honoring patrons and special people to that temple. Each time someone dies, they are memorialized by first burying them above ground - which results in a bunch of _soil_ piled up, and then planting a huge _tree_ right in front of it, so that the _soil_ pile can't be seen from the front. That way, their bodies are still protected in the afterlife.
column7: 3) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 7-12-2011(1): This kanji depicts the creation of a **temple grove** \- it shows servants bringing in _soil_ into the temple, where the _trees_ will be planted.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 16-11-2010(1): 杜氏 , 杜撰 , 鎮守の杜 , 杜絶 =途絶 [temple grove](../v4/2500.html) (#2500 杜) ズ, トウ, ト, もり … Parts: 木 , 土 (cf 社 [company](../v4/1092.html) (#1092 社)) … Note: Important unrelated usage: 杜氏 **Master Brewer** … Story:A simple Zen **temple grove** : A single _tree_ with _soil_. in the Zen tradition, things are said by what is said as well as what is not said, and things have an esoteric and exoteric meaning. Thus the single tree stands for a grove (exoteric) as well as reading as it it were a forest (esoteric) .
column9: 5) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 10-2-2011(): There were not as many _trees_ as you might expect from a regular grove, but the _soil_ of the template grove was meticulously groomed.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 31-10-2006(24): All the grain that was spilled under the _tree_ looked like a _mosaic_ , but someone took a **grain rake** and disposed of it.
column6: 2) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 14-2-2010(12): Dad gave me a **grain rake** and told me to go and rake the grain, but since this is the most boring task in the whole world, I climbed a _tree_ and played with my _Rubik's cube_ instead.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 6-3-2010(2): The _wood_ used in this **grain rake** has a unique _mosaic_ grain pattern.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 21-11-2010(1): (Thanks Meconium) A monk who is sick of raking sand with his **grain rake** goes and hides in a tree and plays with a rubik's cube.
column9: 5) [[Panta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Panta)] 20-3-2013(): To me, raking grains/using a **grain rake** is about as tedious as solving a _Rubik's cube_. _Wood_ is used because you can't expect a tool for such a menial task to be made of metal.

column5: 1) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 12-4-2008(34): An **oar** looks a little like a _wooden tail_.
column6: 2) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 21-2-2008(15): An otter's _tail_ like an **oar** , which he uses to help move _trees_ into his dam.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 6-5-2007(4): He was making an **oar** for his rowing boat out of a _tree_ , but while he was working, he suddenly saw the _tail_ of a wild animal ready to jump on him and had to flee!
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 25-11-2010(3): 梶棒 , 梶の木 , 梶木 [oar](../v4/2502.html) (#2502 梶)かじ … Parts: 木 , 尾 … Note: Odd keyword. … Similar: 舵 [rudder](../v4/2674.html) (#2674 舵), 梶 [oar](../v4/2502.html) (#2502 梶) … Story: Old Style Japanese boats used the single rear **Oar** , making a ship look like it had a _Tree_ for a _Tail_. (IRL that is a 櫓 [turret](../v4/2508.html) (#2508 櫓), but hey).
column9: 5) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 20-11-2008(3): A doggy sits in a little _wooden_ boat, using his _tail_ as an **oar**.

column5: 1) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 22-5-2008(31): Tree, horse: At cooking school, I learned that there's always a relation between the item you will pestle and the size of the pestle itself. When I read in a cooking book that I had to mash up a _horse_ with a **wooden pestle** , naturally a tried to obtain a _tree_ to do the job.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 20-6-2007(11): Ah, nothing like using a **wooden pestle** to mash up some _horse_ meat on a Sunday _afternoon_.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 5-10-2006(5): At _noon_ she used a **wooden pestle** (made out of a _tree_ ) to prepare her lunch.
column8: 4) [[Miyumera](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Miyumera)] 4-1-2013(2): This **WOODEN pestle** used to make food at NOON. Think of a clock striking 12 noon and chiming.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 5-12-2009(1): That _horse_ was being a pest  & so I whacked him with a **wooden pestle** & knocked off his tail feathers.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 21-2-2007(44): _Wood_ of a certain _length_ can be used as a **cane**.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 28-3-2007(25): The village that made its living out of catching _fish_ above all was prone to be raided by pirates. So they made a watch **turret** out of _trees_ and would look every _day_ if the pirates were coming.

column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 9-12-2009(9): In a Japanese castle, the **TURRET** (やぐら) was made of WOOD and was far from the center of activity. To pass the time, guards would shoot at the FISH in the moat until the SUN went down.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(18): A **sturdy oak** was the _tree_ I tried to build with my _stack of pancakes and waffles_ , but it didn't turn out to be so sturdy.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 20-11-2008(15): How does an **oak** _tree_ become **sturdy**? By eating _pancake stacks_ for breakfast every morning. That's a **sturdy oak**.
column7: 3) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 13-6-2010(11): (NB: 橿 and 樫 [[evergreen oak](../v4/2491.html) (#2491 樫)] are basically synonyms, both referring to the tree called かし, or _Quercus myrsinifolia_. Therefore, I call 橿 **LIVE OAK** , a term that is synonymous with _EVERGREEN OAK_.) **LIVE OAK** s are the ideal _TREE_ s to use as _BORDER_ (畺 [Unicode-0x757a](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/30074) (#30074 畺)) markers.
column8: 4) [[Doodsaq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Doodsaq)] 13-11-2009(3): When asked the secret to its sturdiness which set it apart from typical oaks, the **sturdy oak** admitted that it's secret to its strengthening lay in eating double decker rice sandwiches.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 18-11-2010(1): 橿 [sturdy oak](../v4/2509.html) (#2509 橿) ？, かし … Parts: 木 , 畺( 一 , 田 , 一 , 田 , 一 ) (cf: 生薑 [Unicode-0x8591](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/34193) (#34193 薑), 彊 [strengthen](../v4/2240.html) (#2240 彊) … Similars: 樫 [evergreen oak](../v4/2491.html) (#2491 樫), 橿 [sturdy oak](../v4/2509.html) (#2509 橿) … Story: How did the _Tree_ get to be a such a **Sturdy Oak**? By eating Double Rice burgers, and lots of Ginger ( 生薑 ) to 彊 [strengthen](../v4/2240.html) (#2240 彊) himself.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 20-11-2006(35): **Escutcheon** s are noble _shields_ that depict the coat of arms of a family. They are usually made out of _wood_.
column6: 2) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 31-12-2008(5): **Escutcheons** are heraldic displays, often found on _shields_ and made of _wood_.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 15-2-2010(4): An **escutcheon** is an heraldic _shield_ used for display of a coat of arms, rather than for defence. Therefore, it is usually made out of _wood_ because it's easier to modify than steel.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 19-1-2007(21): A Japanese **hackberry** _tree_ is a type of tree that only has full foliage in the _summer_. It loses its foliage in the winter.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 20-11-2008(18): If you hack into the **hackberry** _tree_ with ur PC, you can program it to grow berries even in _summer_. What a cool hack!
column7: 3) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 1-12-2009(9): I threw my blackberry against a **hackberry** tree. It is the summer of the iPhone!
column8: 4) [[wilsoncb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wilsoncb)] 26-8-2010(8): If you hack into the **hackberry** tree, you can program it to think it's always summer, so that it never stops producing berries! Awesome!
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 29-6-2010(6): In case anyone finds this interesting, we've now had the trees for three seasons: Winter ( 柊 ), Spring ( 椿 ), and Summer ( 榎 ). What's the Autumn (楸) tree? Well, it's another way to write 梓 [catalpa](../v4/1498.html) (#1498 梓), albeit with a different reading (キササゲ vs アズサ). [catalpa](../v4/1498.html) (#1498 梓) also refers to the Japanese cherry birch, whereas 楸 exclusively means the catalpa. キササゲ can also be written with the ateji 木豇豆 or 木大角豆 .

column5: 1) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 31-12-2008(28): How do make a **bale**? Simple. You take a _tree_ , like the one on the left, and you _pent it up_ like the one on the right. Just like that.

column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 20-3-2007(6): I **bale** out of an airplane but my parachute doesn’t work. I see a _tree_ below which puts me in a _quandary_ : should I land in the tree or a nearby **bale** of hay.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 1-10-2010(5): 梱 , 梱包 , 同梱 [bale](../v4/2518.html) (#2518 梱) コン( 困 ), こり … Parts: 木 , 困 [quandary](../v4/579.html) (#579 困) … Note: Bad Keyword, fallout from mistakenly calling 俵 [bag](../v4/1547.html) (#1547 俵) instead of **bale** , and the fact that 束 [bundle](../v4/1664.html) (#1664 束) is already taken. … Story: You will find this almost always in 同梱 , which is the way of saying something comes free with the purchase of. So when you buy your _Tree_ you will be in a _Quandary_ (or not) when you find it comes with a **Bale** of marijuana.
column9: 5) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 21-6-2011(1): (+timcampbell): Are you in a _quandary_ regarding how to make a **bale** ? It's simple. You take a _tree_ , like the one on the left, and you _pent it up_ like the one on the right. Just like that. 梱包材 (こんぽうざい): packaging materials 梱包 (こんぽう): packing, crating, packaging 梱 (こり): wrapped package, **bale** [梱包材の回収・再利用](midori://search?text=梱包材の回収・再利用) : recovery and reuse/recycling of packaging materials 同梱 (どうこん): including something in a package.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 1-1-2007(25): A **loquat** is a tropical fruit _tree_ , that _compared_ to other trees has an odd seasonal pattern: it's fruit is ripe in late winter or early spring.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 20-11-2008(17): The **loquat** tree is very rare. To **loquat** e it, you need to _compare_ it to the _trees_ next to it.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 15-2-2010(6): If you _compare_ the unusual spelling of this _tree_ 's name to that of another orange fruit, the kumquat, you'll notice the similarity. This is because the -quat ending comes from the Cantonese pronunciation of the kanji 橘 （[mandarin orange](../v4/2494.html) (#2494 橘)）, which is read as _gwat1_. (This is true.).
column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(3): I _compare_ the **loquat** _tree_ to the hiquat _tree_ & decide I prefer the former.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 3-8-2008(1): I'm not sure if you jerks were aware of this, but it is considered extremely rude to touch the **ビワ** fruit (loquat) with your fingers - no ifs, ands, or buts. The traditionally accepted method of harvesting and eating the **loquat** is with two spoons. You hold the _two spoons_ together in one hand to pick it, and you then put the **loquat** in a plate or something and use one spoon to hold it in place, and the other to remove the skin and pit - then you can eat it. Please keep this in mind next time.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-11-2007(47): (Note: _ear_ \+ _city walls_ = [exclamation](../v4/2680.html) (#2680 耶)). I see a _tree_ with an _exclamation_ mark painted on it. "Why is that?" I think, "An _exclamation_ mark indicates danger, but it's only a _tree_ ". Then a coconut drops on my head. Ah, it's a **coconut tree**.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(11): A **coconut tree** drops a coconut on your head, causing you to make an obscene [exclamation](../v4/2680.html) (#2680 耶).
column7: 3) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 21-12-2007(2): A bare **coconut tree** is like an _exclamation_ point. A leaf-less stick of a _tree_ with a fallen coconut at the bottom.
column8: 4) [[didz13](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/didz13)] 19-6-2011(1): I imagine a Super Mario-like side-scroller in which there is a bonus stage where a big _tree_ throws coconuts with _question marks_ on them. Hit them to get coins and goodies!().
column9: 5) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 10-1-2012(): People sneaking into the city by silently jumping from a **coconut tree** over the _wall with ears_ (frame [exclamation](../v4/2680.html) (#2680 耶)).

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 20-6-2007(35): **Sandalwood** is the ideal _wood_ for a _podium_ : it's easy on your sandals!
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 19-6-2007(4): The gunslinger raises the smooth **sandalwood** grip of his revolver just as the corrupt "Big Boss" politician ascends his _podium_ for a victory speech.
column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 16-12-2009(3): **SANDALWOOD** is a TREE that is much preferred to dirt for making a PODIUM. It's aromatic and carves easily.
column8: 4) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 10-1-2012(): This is the image of a special product - **sandalwood** , or, as the name suggests, wood sandals. Try to focus on the sound they make on a wood _podium_ \- they're really noisy, and not comfortable at all.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 6-10-2011(): 寺檀制度 =檀家制度, 檀越の家 , 檀家 , 檀那 =旦那, 檀那寺 [sandalwood](../v4/2525.html) (#2525 檀) ダン( 壇 ), タン( 壇 ), まゆみ … Parts: 木 , 壇 [podium](../v4/587.html) (#587 壇)- 土 … Story: Bad keyword, historically important idea of 寺檀制度 **Mandatory registration with Temple to prove non Christianity During 徳川時代**. 檀家 , most importantly the 旦那 /檀那, had to put 宀 on, open eyes wide in reverence 回 , and burn the **Sandalwood** incense or lose their 寺請け status.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 6-2-2007(25): We were seeking shelter for the _rain_ under the **plotosid** _tree_ , but someone had put a _double snare_ there. As if that foul smelling tree wasn't enough trouble already.
column6: 2) [[cb4960](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cb4960)] 10-1-2009(18): ~~ Keyword should be **sumac** ~~ **Sumacs** are worthless _trees_. They don't protect from _rain_ so you shouldn't use them for a _ceiling_ \- and they stink so you can't use them to make _snares_.
column7: 3) [[marcmiddag](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/marcmiddag)] 16-8-2011(5): Keyword is wrong . I replace the keyword with "Deadwood". Story*I was collecting some deadwood when it started raining. I got closer to the tree to shelter myself from the rain, when I suddenly got snared by two branches, and it started strangling me! Guess the tree didn't wanted me to take his deadwood!! (thanks to_nihon) ちょざい 【 樗材 】deadwood —(Usually written using kana alone. ).
column8: 4) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 22-12-2007(5): **Plotosid** : Japanese bead tree. The beads of the **plotosid** _tree_ look like _rain_ drops that have been en _snared_ by its _two_ branches.
column9: 5) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 13-1-2009(4): According to my dictionary, this is a **sendan** , a **Japanese bead tree** that is not useless at all, it is sometimes used in the making of instruments and Buddhist statues and such. I was cutting down a **sendan** _tree_ to make myself a koto, when it started _raining_. I got closer to the tree to shelter myself from the rain, when I suddenly got _snared_ by _two_ branches, and it started strangling me! Guess the **sendan** wanted to **send an** obvious message: don't cut me down!

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 29-4-2007(28): The **zelkova** is a sort of elm _tree_ that is very good for making bonsais, setting a _standard_ for other trees, so to speak.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 31-5-2009(19): In the A to Z of _trees_ , the **zelkova** sets the _standard_ , because it begins with "Z" and ends in "A".
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 16-2-2010(6): AKA 欅. When the government decided that the **zelkova** would be the _standard tree_ to plant in public parks in Japan, the populace obeyed, and today the **zelkova** is the only _tree_ you will ever see in Japanese parks (at least, those well-kept enough to observe the national _standard_ ).
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(6): The **zelkova** is like the _standard tree_ people think of when they think of Japan.
column9: 5) [[hissatsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hissatsu)] 11-11-2010(1): Zee **zelkova** _tree's wood_ zets the _standard_ for fine furniture in Japan.

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 21-6-2007(39): Due its tendency to encrypt all its messages, the **cryptomeria** has been a fairly _prosperous tree_ whereas all the other _trees_ have already fallen prey to espionage.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(8): The **cryptomeria** （すぎ） is a _tree_ that enjoys _prosperity_ in Japan because it's written kanji is like an encrypted form of the more infamous スギ（ 杉 ） which causes hay fever.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 10-3-2010(3): The **cryptomeria** [すぎ - also written (encrypted) as 杉 [cedar](../v4/1713.html) (#1713 杉)] is a valuable timber _tree_ so growing them would naturally lead to _prosperity_.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 16-2-2010(1): Those whose families were _prosperous_ enough to provide them with a proper education will learn to take the three wild, stabbing strokes from the right hand side of 杉 and reassemble them into the more sophisticated and _prosperous_ form seen in this kanji. Similarly, in English, while many know the word " **cedar** ", and may refer to the 杉 as the Japanese **cedar** , those _prosperous_ enough to be educated further may learn the botanical name, **Cryptomeria** japonica.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(1): [+Megaqwerty] Because of its tendency to encrypt all its messages, the **cryptomeria** has been a _prosperous tree_ while the Ave Maria trees have fallen prey to espionage.

column5: 1) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 23-12-2007(33): _Cedar trees_ are so **copious** they only come in _groves_.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 21-4-2007(6): You'll find **copious** _cedar trees_ all over Japan. They're the most common _tree_ available.
column7: 3) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 29-7-2008(3): How to make a _grove_ : Take a sheet of carton, fold it, cut out one _tree_ in the _shape_ of a _cedar_ , unfold. You'll get **copious** amounts of _trees_ in no time.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 7-8-2009(2): _Cedar trees_ are so **copious** they only come in _groves_. (from Aerin). I use a pun to help cement this story in my mind. Cedar tree is スギ in Japanese, so I just remember あり過ぎ （ありスギ）=there are too many of them!
column9: 5) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 15-7-2012(1): Here's the dic.yahoo.co.jp definition for this kanji: [実質と外観とが並びそろってよいさま。](midori://search?text=実質と外観とが並びそろってよいさま。) The best non- cumbersone keyword I can come up with that matches this definition is **undeceptive appearance**. ========= **Undeceptive appearance** : Like _two trees_ with the same _shape_. They look the same, and they really are!

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-2-2008(42): One of my favourite pastimes is that I like to jump out of a _tree_ on my _pogo stick_ and try to land in a **bucket**. When successful it makes a very satisfying "clang". (Note: new primitive _pogo stick_ = _chop seal_ \+ _utilize_ , for explanation see my entry at [traffic](../v4/1408.html) (#1408 通).).
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 26-7-2009(5): As if in a cartoon, my _pogo stick_ got stuck in a _wooden_ **bucket** , causing me to fall over.
column7: 3) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 28-11-2010(3): 天水桶 , 風呂桶 , [bucket](../v4/2530.html) (#2530 桶) おけ … Parts: 木 , 甬 (cf: 甬[Unicode-0x752c](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/29996) (#29996 甬), 通り [traffic](../v4/1408.html) (#1408 通), 踊る [jump](../v4/1409.html) (#1409 踊), 痛い [pain](../v4/1690.html) (#1690 痛)) … Story: My _Pogo Stick_ worked well and I could jump high, so high in fact that I got stuck in a _Tree_. And the firemen had to come and pick me out of the tree with a rescue **Bucket**. But the pogo stick helps with my B-Ball, to the point I can score 10 **Bucket** s a game.
column8: 4) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 15-7-2012(2): I ran into a _tree_ when I was riding my _pogo stick_ while wearing a **bucket** over my head.
column9: 5) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 18-8-2010(1): 甬 [Unicode-0x752c](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/29996) (#29996 甬).

column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 5-2-2008(32): The 惰 [lazy](../v4/629.html) (#629 惰) way to draw an **ellipse** requires two _wooden_ pegs and some string (<http://tinyurl.com/252zgx>).
column6: 2) [[cb4960](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cb4960)] 17-3-2009(15): When tasked with planting the _trees_ to form a circle, the somewhat _lazy_ gardener just winged it (instead of measuring) and the result was an **ellipse** of trees.
column7: 3) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 1-1-2009(6): (re: Johnzep's story for _lazy_ ) When I went under a _tree_ to beat my _meat_ with my _left_ hand, my motions formed the shape of an **ellipse**.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(3): A _lazy_ _tree_ doesn't bother making its trunk and branches cylindrical because an **ellipse** is good enough.
column9: 5) [[Elphalpo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Elphalpo)] 15-7-2012(1): _Trees_ that are _lazy_ spend a lot of time lying down rather than standing up like most trees, and the force of gravity squishes them into the shape of an **ellipse**.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(21): The **star-anise** is an evergreen _tree_ kept in _secrecy_ for it's aromatic oil.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(11): Before **Anise** was a **star** she lived openly in town, but now that she is **star- Anise** she lives in _secrecy_ in the _woods_.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 13-3-2010(10): This kanji 樒 (しきみ・しきび) refers to Japanese **star-anise**. Its evergreen branches are popular for placing at graves. It’s very poisonous. The edible spice of the same name 八角 (はっかく) is from the closely related Chinese **star-anise** 大茴香 (ダイウイキョウ). Both species produce almost identical fruits. STORY: A batch of Chinese **star-anise** was adulterated with its poisonous Japanese namesake. Great _secrecy_ surrounds the incident. Was it an innocent _tree_ mixup or coverup?
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 21-6-2007(5): Behold! The last of the _trees_!
column9: 5) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 20-6-2007(4): _Secrecy_ surrounds China's Star Brand Mayonnaise aka " **star-anise**." What exactly gives it that zesty taste? The rumor I heard is that its from ground up evergreen _trees_!

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 21-6-2007(31): I _requested_ that the cat do something and he spit up a **furball**.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-5-2008(17): For her birthday, your pampered girlfriend's _request_ is, "Something made of _fur_ ". So you get the cat to cough her up a **furball**.
column7: 3) [[sboegema](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sboegema)] 5-1-2010(7): 毛球 = fur・ball 毬 【いが, かさ】burr, (chestnut) case, (pine) cone.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(2): The king was covered in _fur_ as the ball he _requested_ was actually a **furball**.
column9: 5) [[sirkne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sirkne)] 1-1-2013(1): The kids were using a **furball** as a playball. I requested that they get a real ball instead, but somehow it was more fun this way. Dictionary says [スポーツや遊びに用いる球。](midori://search?text=スポーツや遊びに用いる球。) [ゴム・皮・布などで作り，よく弾む。](midori://search?text=ゴム・皮・布などで作り，よく弾む。) ボール。 「―つき」 / "ball used in sports or play. a bouncy ball made of rubber, hide, cloth, etc.") Part of 毬藻 (まり・も, algae), which if you went to Hokkaido you'd remember from まりもっこり.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-2-2007(39): New primitive, let _futon_ = _feathers_ \+ _turkey_ (i.e. my futon is made with turkey feathers). Then: **Twinkle** , **twinkle** little star, oops my _futon_ is on _fire_.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(13): With a **twinkle** in my eye, I set my _turkey feather futon_ on _fire_ for no apparent reason.
column7: 3) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 23-5-2008(12): Tuesday is **twinkle** day. Or in kanji arithmetics: 火 + 曜 = 燿 + 日 .
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 5-2-2007(5): **Twinkle** **twinkle** … is that a star? No it's a _turkey_ with its _feathers_ on _fire_.
column9: 5) [[wilsoncb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wilsoncb)] 26-8-2010(3): I didn't want to pay 1000 yen to throw away my futon in Tokyo… So with a **twinkle** in my eye, I just set it on fire to dispose of it…

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 14-10-2006(26): The _fires_ outside the _puptent_ of the sentinel are **watchfire** s.
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 7-3-2010(7): Camping in the wilds can be fun but what about the big carnivores out there? So we have a **watchfire** and take turns at night, one asleep in the _pup tent_ while the other keeps the _fire_ burning brightly.
column7: 3) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 22-2-2008(5): **Watchfire** is what you must do if you light a _fire_ outside your _pup tent_ , in case it sets it alight.
column8: 4) [[NeoGlitch](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NeoGlitch)] 17-2-2012(2): How to make the perfect **watchfire** : 1. Fire 2. kagaribi (fuel used for sacrifices - true meaning of "puptent") 3. ??? 4. PROFIT!!
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 16-2-2010(1): What the hell is **watchfire** supposed to mean? Sounds like an accident at the fake Rolex factory. Make it **bonfire** (a _fire_ you have to _watch_ in case it gets out of control). Story: The dog _watched_ with _fire_ in his eyes as he saw his beloved _doghouse_ burning in the _flames_ of the **bonfire**.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(42): A _gigantic fire_ was started by the Olympic **torch**.
column6: 2) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 22-2-2008(5): The olympic **torch** is a _fire_ carried on a _gigantic_ journey from olympus to wherever the games are.
column7: 3) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 6-3-2010(2): After a **torch** caused a _gigantic fire_ (imagine something on the scale of the 'Great Fire of London'), the Maglite was developed.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 15-2-2007(2): If you're not careful with that **torch** , the forest around you will be set on _fire_ , and you'll have a _gigantic_ forest fire…
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 1-11-2010(1): 炬燵 =火燵, 置き炬燵 =置き火燵, [torch](../v4/2536.html) (#2536 炬) キョ( 巨 ) … Parts: 火 , 巨 [gigantic](../v4/856.html) (#856 巨) … Note: Once you have lived a winter in Japan, you will know what a Kotatu ( 炬燵 ) is. … Story: 懐中電灯 [lamp](../v4/165.html) (#165 灯) is a little bit of flame hung on a spike. A **Torch** is a _Gigantic Flame_.

column5: 1) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 22-2-2008(28): I'm really bad at making _fires_ , I needed kindling from a whole _grove_ of trees before I managed to **kindle** the _fire_.
column6: 2) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 23-12-2007(13): A _fire_ was **kindle** d by the insane arsonist under a _grove_ of trees. Unable to escape the ensuing inferno, he was burned alive.

column8: 4) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 2-2-2011(1): A _mommy_ is running around the room on _fire_ after his **moxa** treatment goes wrong. It takes a _long time_ for him to recover.

column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 23-12-2009(1): During 梅雨 (tsuyu - the rainy season) everyone on the train is **FANNING** themselves. It's as if their trying to remove the FIRE on their bodies with a FAN.
