column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(12): The _so-and-so_ from Mary Poppins was covered in **soot** because he was a _fire_ chimney sweep.
column7: 3) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 21-6-2007(7): Emerging from the _fire_ , he wiped off the **soot** from his suit and said, "Don't worry, honey, _so-and-so_ is now no-and-no.".
column8: 4) [[dancingblade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dancingblade)] 15-8-2010(4): Remember those **soot** balls in Spirited Away? They are just _so-and-sos_ who keep the boiler room _fire_ alive.
column9: 5) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 5-8-2009(4): A guy fell into the _fire_ and emerged completely covered in **soot**. It's impossible to tell who it is now, so we'll just refer to him as _so-and-so_.

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 21-6-2007(33): The _East_ are the best at [tempering](../v4/2030.html) (#2030 錬) because their _fires_ are the best at **firing**.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 5-2-2007(14): The process of **firing** , that is, glaze bricks or refine metals, is well known in the _east_ , and of course _fire_ is used for it.
column7: 3) [[einahpets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/einahpets)] 26-7-2012(2): **Firing** bricks （ 煉瓦 れんが）became really important in Chicago after the Great Chicago Fire - in this kanji you can see the _fire_ to the left and it stops to the _east_ because of the lake.
column8: 4) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 1-11-2007(1): **Firing** metals and pottery and bricks, esp. bricks. So you put out a FIRE and then have the chief smelter YAO MING of the EAST fire it, soot all over his face as he pulls out the fired bricks.
column9: 5) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(): If you try to smuggle drugs into the middle _east_ , they'll set all your drugs on _fire_ before handing you over to the **firing** squad.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 29-12-2006(23): After the _evening rice_ , the guest set out to entertain the children of the house with a **dazzling** show. He pulled a _wand_ seemingly from out of his _crotch_ and suddenly it appeared to be on _fire_! Ohs and ahs ensued.
column6: 2) [[Evangelo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Evangelo)] 11-12-2009(18): [+mantixen] (wand+night+crotch=pole dancer) The American pole dancer gave a **dazzling** dance and set the audience on fire. Literally.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-2-2008(11): Tip: The _wand + evening + crotch_ combination appears again in [repast](../v4/2798.html) (#2798 餐).
column8: 4) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(7): You're trying to prepare for a **dazzling** evening at your place for someone special. While lighting the _fire_ , you find a _magic wand_ next to the fireplace, "wow, I can use this to make this evening truly **dazzling**!" you say, so you use it on your _crotch_ to make it a decent size, then you use it to whip up some delicious _rice_ for you and your partner.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 29-7-2009(2): It was a **dazzling** Las Vegas show: an _American_ _stripper_ in a タヌき suit got ヌde while hanging upside down on a _magic wand_ pole with _fire_ shooting up all around her.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 27-6-2007(18): The cook just got a new set of pots and pans from the master of the house. Putting them on the _fire_ , they shined so much the **refulgent** shine blinded him until he blocked it from his view by holding up his _ladel_.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 25-2-2007(12): He used a _ladle_ to protect his eyes from the **refulgent** light of the _fire_.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 16-2-2010(7): This **miraculous** _ladle_ is so **refulgent** (resplendent and radiant) that it can start _fires_ simply by reflecting and focusing the light waves.
column8: 4) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 5-11-2007(5): Tip: Don’t confuse key word with [effulgent](../v4/2450.html) (#2450 旺).
column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 18-9-2010(3): The **refulgent** _fire ladle_ set both the eyes and mouths of diners on fire as the gleaming ladle's contents were quite spicy.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-2-2007(34): With an iron that has been in the _fire_ , _each_ beast is subjected to **branding**.
column6: 2) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 19-7-2009(12): **Branding** with FIRE - EACH animal.
column7: 3) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 10-12-2008(2): Farmers use **branding** to protect the property of their flock. They use an iron fresh out of the _fire_ to brand _each and every_ animal with the same **brand**. Thinking more abstractly, **branding** (or advertising) burns like _fire_ in the mind of _each and every_ person exposed to it.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 3-8-2008(2): (see [status](../v4/292.html) (#292 格)): The forest ranger finishes figuring out the status of _every_ tree in the forest. "Okays, " says the supervisor. "Now you to be out and **branding** all of these trees, for quickly!". The ranger does not want to do this - it's boring, and involves marking _each_ tree with tiny _fire_ s. Wait - here's an idea! Why don't I just set a fire at a few spots in the park? That way while one side is **branding** , the other side can be **branding** too! Hence no trees in this kanji - they're all burned down.
column9: 5) [[NeoGlitch](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NeoGlitch)] 13-12-2010(1): I'm **branding** with _fire - each_ animal in my farm (my cows, bulls, pigs, chickens, parrots, worms… oops, poor worms).

column5: 1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 21-6-2007(42): When _The Pinnacle collapses_ , there'll be plenty of **flames** for sure.
column6: 2) [[dtcamero](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dtcamero)] 17-2-2011(7): Fullmeyal alchemist: 焔の錬金術師 (ほのおのれんきんじゅつし).
column7: 3) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 18-9-2010(3): **Flames**! _Fire_ blots out _The Pinnacle_ and it _collapses_!
column8: 4) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 27-6-2007(3): Got any old **flames**? I sure do, and though they are _bound up_ in my memories of the _olden days_ , any time I am near them, those **flames** start to _fire_ up again.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 18-3-2011(2): 焔 =焰=炎, 焰の錬金術師 [flames](../v4/2546.html) (#2546 焔) ほのう, (ほむら) … Parts: 火 , 勹, 旧 /臼 (cf: 陥る [collapse](../v4/1315.html) (#1315 陥) … Note: As is the case with non-Joyo characters, the bit that is simplified ( 臼 to 旧 ), is commonly written both ways. The Flame Alchemist ( 焰の錬金術師 ) in FullMetal Alchemist is written in the old character form. Rather than thinking of it as two characters, just think of it as a font variation.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(39): If a _fire goes smoothly_ you will have **stew** in no time.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 15-10-2007(13): Tip: _tall_ and _complete_ can be combined into [go smoothly](../v4/3001.html) (#3001 亨).
column7: 3) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 1-2-2008(4): You must _smoothly_ stir the **stew** over the _open fire_.
column8: 4) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 22-9-2010(3): Cannibals make a **stew** with _tall_ _children_ over a _cauldron fire_. The **stew** is _complete_ when the arms come off with a fork.
column9: 5) [[peacemik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/peacemik)] 24-6-2011(2): (+gavmk, Katsuo): Recipe for "Tall Kid" **stew** : 1) Light _cauldron fire_ and add stock. 2) If _tall kid_ won't fit in cauldron, _lop off arms_. When cooking is _complete_ , you will have great **stew** (if all _goes smoothly_ ). 割烹 (かっぽう): cooking (esp. Japanese style) cuisine 割烹着 (かっぽうぎ): coverall, apron, cook's apron 割烹店 (かっぽうてん): restaurant 割烹料理 (かっぽうりょうり): Japanese cooking Note: _tall_ \+ _complete_ = [go smoothly](../v4/3001.html) (#3001 亨).

column5: 1) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 24-5-2008(20): Mysterious, crown, cow: In Kazad-dum, Gandalf had found a _mysterious crown_. It really helped his magic, but when they came back to Rivendell, he had become unresistable to the _cows_ (small side-effect). He tried to **tug** the crown off, but did not succeed…
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 11-6-2007(11): A _cow_ is engaged in a **tug** -of-war with a **tug** boat. _Mysteriously_ , the _cow_ is _crowned_ the winner.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(9): A _mysterious crown_ appeared on the _cow_ that wouldn't come off no matter how hard we'd **tug**.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 5-8-2009(4): This is a really bizarre image, but it helps me remember the placement of the crown radical. I imagine _Gandalf_ with a _crown_ inexplicably around his waist, with a _cow_ **tug** ging on it.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 13-3-2007(1): An _alien_ with a _crown_ **tug** s at a _cow_ , it wants to abduct the cow and put it into its spaceship!

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-1-2008(36): The _cow_ in this frame 牝 is filling a _spoon_ with milk from its udders, so it must be a **female animal**. (The _cow_ in the next frame 牡 is rolling around in the _soil_ and is, not surprisingly, a **male animal**.).
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(12): While the bull wants rough sex, the _cow_ would rather _spoon_ , I guess all **female animal** s are the same.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(7): _Cow_ s that give milk for your cereal _spoon_ are **female animal** s.
column8: 4) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 18-9-2010(3): A _cow_ is a **female animal** that fills your _spoon_ with ice cream, milk, yogurt, etc.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 17-2-2010(3): You have to _sit down_ beside a _cow_ to milk it. Make sure it's a **female animal** though - a male may let you do the same thing, but you sure don't want to drink the milk.

column5: 1) [[brose](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brose)] 11-3-2007(22): **Male animal** s are dirty pigs in English, but in Japanese they are _dirty cows_ ボ ボウ おす お- おん-.
column6: 2) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 16-8-2009(15): That _cow_ is staring at me and kicking up _soil_ … hold on that's a **male… animal…** Oh shit! Run!
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 4-10-2006(6): The **male animal** _cow_ is called a bull, and it likes to roll around across the _soil_.
column8: 4) [[dominikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dominikun)] 23-3-2011(2): German: Diese Kuh starrt mich an… scharrt mit den Hufen in der Erde… warte mal, ist das ein Männchen? Ein Stier? Mist, lauf!!!
column9: 5) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 25-12-2009(2): The **MALE ANIMAL** of the bovine (COW) species will fight to protect its SOIL.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 2-7-2007(24): The mechanism in my old grandfather clock suddenly broke with an almighty **chime** and one of the _jewels_ was thrown out through the window into a nearby _grove_ of trees. I'm now searching for the _jewel_ in the _grove_ while the clock continues to **chime** incessantly.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(15): The _king_ knew playtime in the _grove_ was over when he heard the clock tower **chime**.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(7): When the _king_ got lost in the _grove_ , he could easily find his way back to the castle by following the sounds of the **chime**.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 5-8-2009(3): The **chime** refers to the tinkling of jewels. Story: the _king_ got lost in the _grove_ , but we were able to find him by following the **chime** s from his copious amounts of jewelry tinkling together.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 24-11-2010(2): 琳瑯たる (tinkling sound of jade) [chime](../v4/2554.html) (#2554 琳) リン … Parts: 王 , 林 (cf 淋しい [solitude](../v4/2310.html) (#2310 淋)) … Similars: 琳 [chime](../v4/2554.html) (#2554 琳), 玲 [tinkling](../v4/2568.html) (#2568 玲) … Story: It's hard not to think of a wind **chime** , but this about carved wooden jewels of the wind **chime** itself, and not the wind. Of course there need to be _two wooden jewels_ in order to bang together to make the **Chime**.

column5: 1) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 14-3-2009(26): The _king_ was given two choices by the abductor: either the king gives him the **lapis lazuli** jewels, or he throws the king's _infant_ son into the _stream_.
column6: 2) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 30-7-2010(10): The king as an infant was washed away by the current to a beautiful island of **lapis lazuli** waters, the Ryuukyuu Islands 琉球 (Okinawa before annexation).
column7: 3) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 24-5-2010(7): This kanji should be "Ryukyu Islands" or something similar and 瑠 should be **Lapis Lazuli**.
column8: 4) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 10-5-2010(4): Contrary to [sulphur](../v4/763.html) (#763 硫) 硫 , which is ranked as a mere [stone](../v4/113.html) (#113 石) 石 , **LAPIS LAZULI** is a [jewel](../v4/256.html) (#256 玉). (Interestingly, **LAPIS LAZULI** _contains_ **SULPHUR**!). So, just replace **SULPHUR** 's _STONE_ 石 of 硫 with _JEWEL_ ⺩, to get a beautiful **LAPIS LAZULI**.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 2-10-2006(3): The _infant_ playing in the little _stream_ had suddenly found a number of **lapis lazuli** _jewels_.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 28-7-2009(17): The _king_ appreciated the _distinction_ of **burnish** ed jewels.
column6: 2) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 5-8-2009(13): The king's servant got lazy and didn't thoroughly **burnish** some of the king's many jewels, thinking "he won't notice the difference." However, the _king_ most certainly did notice the _distinction_ between the **burnish** ed jewels and unburnished ones: "Off with his head!!".
column7: 3) [[brendanmacdonald](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brendanmacdonald)] 16-10-2008(4): The KING's **BURNISH** ing skills earned him a DISTINCTION.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 25-11-2010(2): 切瑳 =切磋, 切瑳琢磨 =切磋琢磨, 瑳 [burnish](../v4/2559.html) (#2559 瑳) サ( 左 ) … Parts: 王 , 差 (cf 差別 [distinction](../v4/554.html) (#554 差)) … Note: Name Kanji pronounced SA. Compounds usually use the non-RTK 磋[Unicode-0x78cb](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/30923) (#30923 磋). .. Similars: 琢 [hone](../v4/2560.html) (#2560 琢), 瑳 [burnish](../v4/2559.html) (#2559 瑳) … Story: I **Burned** the _Left_ sleeve on my wife's _Wool_ coat, and now I have to give her _Jewelry_ to make up for it. Maybe that will **Burnish** my reputation with her.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 19-11-2006(1): He **burnish** ed his metal armor with lots of _jewels_ so that he could wear it with _distinction_.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(19): The _king_ realized he looked like a _pig_ and sought to **hone** his body through exercise.
column6: 2) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 2-7-2007(11): I **hone** my skills by skillfully separating real _jewels_ from the fake junk worn by fat _sows_!
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-10-2007(9): _King_ Henry VIII was keen on hunting wild boar. Here we see him first **honing** his skills on a _sow_.
column8: 4) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 25-2-2008(2): Much like making a Silk Purse out of a Sow's Ear, I'm unlikely to **hone** my skills to a level where I can make a _Jewel_ out of a _Pig's_ Testicle.
column9: 5) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 4-4-2010(1): "I'm trying to **hone** their minds!" the old teacher said. Dude, you're throwing _pearls before swines_.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 10-5-2007(25): The **coral** is not found in this _tome_ of _jewels_ since it's really not a mineral, but the remains of small animals.
column6: 2) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 23-8-2009(17): Neptune, _king_ of the sea has a special _tome_ containing all the different types of **coral**.
column7: 3) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 3-6-2009(10): The greet **coral** reef ( 珊瑚礁 ) forms a [palisade](../v4/2507.html) (#2507 柵) encrusted with the finest jewels the ocean ca offer.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 10-11-2010(2): 珊瑚礁 [coral](../v4/2561.html) (#2561 珊) サン … Parts: 王 , 冊 … Similars: 珊 [coral](../v4/2561.html) (#2561 珊), 瑚 [coral reef](../v4/2562.html) (#2562 瑚), 礁 [reef](../v4/558.html) (#558 礁) … Story: Since 珊瑚礁 usu. appears as a set. First we see 珊 [coral](../v4/2561.html) (#2561 珊) as just a Jewel in a coffee table Tome, then we see a 瑚 [coral reef](../v4/2562.html) (#2562 瑚) as the Jewel of the little _Lake_ in our living room (aquarium), finally we see the 礁 [reef](../v4/558.html) (#558 礁) as an actual living animal ecosystem.
column9: 5) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(2): It was written in a _tome_ that there were _jewels_ hidden in the **coral** by pirates.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 28-7-2009(22): The _king_ had a **coral reef** installed in his _lake_.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 29-3-2007(6): Under the light of the _moon_ , the adventurers secretly dived for the _old_ wreckage in the **coral reef** that would contain a fabled _jewel_.
column7: 3) [[Yesterbean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yesterbean)] 11-1-2010(4): Be careful not to get mixed up with [reef](../v4/558.html) (#558 礁).
column8: 4) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(3): After reading about the jewels which are hidden amongst the coral, only the most _uncivilised_ people would actually attempt to explore the **coral reef** to find _jewels_.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 4-8-2008(2): [+mcfate] Coral is one thing (it's really just a color), but **coral reef** as a _"jewel"_ is something totally weird. Actually, the _uncivilized_ (remember, these uncivilized people were the type to eat the _flesh_ of their _old_ ) people in China used to use this as money. They would wear bits of _coral reef_ as a jewel in hopes that they would never get _old_ , and thus have their _flesh_ eaten. Interestingly enough, this wasn't REALLY **coral reef** \- it was just junk from a nearby [lake](../v4/148.html) (#148 湖).

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(21): The _king_ wished he was as handsome as Fabio standing on the [edge](../v4/1167.html) (#1167 端) of a _mountain_ _combing_ his hair, but he realized he was **fortunate** in other ways.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 21-6-2007(8): How most **fortunate**! After gambling his life on the [edge](../v4/1167.html) (#1167 端), Indiana Jones discovers that the _comb_ is studded with countless _jewels_.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 22-4-2010(4): The _king_ went _mountain_ -climbing but dropped his _comb_ and it tumbled miles below. However, he happened to find it on the way back. How **fortunate**!
column8: 4) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 19-5-2009(3): It was **fortunate** that the _king_ was found after _combing_ the _mountain_. He fell from an [edge](../v4/1167.html) (#1167 端) and was injured, but alive. (combination of Megagwerty and mantixen).
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 16-5-2007(2): The actress standing on the [edge](../v4/1167.html) (#1167 端) of the _mountain_ , whose hair is always _combed_ into shape, is **fortunate** that her _jewels_ are not blowing off her neck in this harsh wind.

column5: 1) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 6-8-2009(17): I spent _a long time_ polishing the _king_ 's jewelry until it was all **jet** -black just like he ordered. Well, it felt like a long time, but it was actually just 9 minutes. (In addition to **jet** , this kanji is also used as 9 in legal documents.).
column6: 2) [[Machine_Gun_Cat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Machine_Gun_Cat)] 2-8-2009(14): Public airlines fly slow and take a _long time_ to arrive so the _king_ has a private **jet**.
column7: 3) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 21-6-2007(11): _Mummies_ are adorned with **jet** _jewels_ to connote death, or something. Oh, yeah, 'cause King Tut was a big fan of **jet** planes.
column8: 4) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 13-1-2009(3): (@ adrianbarritt) **Jet** Li has been the _king_ of martial arts for a _long time_.
column9: 5) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 6-1-2009(2): The _mummy_ is adorned with **jet** black _jewels,_ the symbol of death, and the afterlife.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 14-10-2007(42): He who possesses the **crystal stone** is the rightful _king_ of _England_.
column6: 2) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 17-2-2010(1): After a successful sell-out concert tour around _England_ , _Jewel_ sat down with a pipe made out of some kind of **crystal stone** and began to take drugs to unwind, first getting **stoned** and then smoking **crystal** meth.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 4-8-2008(1): [+Aerin] Pretty much everything in _England_ is fake. That includes the power of the _king_ (it's a queen now, I know, but still) - everything is handled by the real government, and that post is just a symbol. Appropriately, then, the PM gets all the real diamonds, while the royalty gets the **crystal stone** decorated items. **Crystal stone** , of course, is just a nice way of saying rhinestones.
column8: 4) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 2-2-2007(1): You can make fashionable _jewels_ out of **crystal stone**. Of course they are also sold in _England_ , London has a lot of jewellery shops.
column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 18-9-2010(): The **crystal stone** allowed Arthur to become the _king_ of _England_.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 12-6-2007(35): When the _king_ barks out his _orders_ , all the chandeliers and other ornaments in the palace start **tinkling**.
column6: 2) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 23-8-2009(4): The _king_ (having no real power) likes to give _orders_ to his family _jewels_ \- "Commence **tinkling**!". (Thanks to bodhisamaya).
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(4): The _king_ _orders_ the **tinkling** of jewels to help him take a tinkle himself.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 20-12-2010(1): Royal _orders_ from the _King_ are read aloud by the town crier: "If you sprinkle when you **tinkle** , be a sweetie, wipe the seatie!" These orders would stand the test of time until they would appear carved in bathroom stalls in present day times.
column9: 5) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 5-3-2008(1): The _king_ gives _orders_ not to be disturbed whilst he's **tinkling** in the toilet.

column5: 1) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 23-8-2009(35): First, we sow the _rice field_ , then we plant the _flowers_ , and **lastly** we plant the _corn_. (Stroke order and story in one).
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 3-3-2007(9): **Lastly** , let me mention that my _ricefield_ and _silage stack_ are amongst the top _ten_ in the country…
column7: 3) [[At0m5k](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/At0m5k)] 16-8-2009(7): This kanji is actually written in the following stroke order: rice field, flower, corn. Story: I was trying to teach an old farmer about crop rotation. He had been planting _rice in his field_ for decades and the field was getting depleted in nutrients. So I told him he should try planting different _flowers_ and then **lastly** some _corn_.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 12-11-2010(4): 畢生 , 畢宿 [lastly](../v4/2570.html) (#2570 畢) ヒツ, あめふり … Parts: 田 , 艹, 丰＊ … Stroke order: <http://bit.ly/b92Xy6> … Note: **Net Constellation** , one of the 28 Chinese Mansions, (Taurus).]. The RTK keyword comes from the compound 畢生 which means lifetime. … Story: First we plant the rice field, then we grow Flowers and Corn. **Lastly** , after a **Lifetime ( 畢生 )** of working in the fields, we are buried under them, under the Taurus constellation.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(4): **In the end** , people realized that my _splendid_ _rice field_ was nothing more than overgrown grass.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(27): _Ivy_ grows on the **paddy-field ridge** encircling the _rice field_ as opposed to the intra-field paddy ridge that divides it in half.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 23-1-2010(16): [+mantixen] The ordinary 畔 [paddy- ridge](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1204) (#1204 畔) dissects the _field_ by dividing it in _half_ , but the **paddy-field ridge** runs around the outside  & is covered in _ivy_. Disambiguate by noting that the hyphen in 'paddy-ridge' divides the word itself in _half_ (five letters each side) but 'paddy-field ridge' has five extra letters on the right, the ridge itself, in fact, the part covered in _ivy_.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 4-8-2008(3): This **paddy-field ridge** separates two paddy fields. The reason for it being made of _ivy_ is a bit pathetic, but necessary - it turns out that the two neighboring paddy field owners got in a bit of a fight over whose paddy field irrigation system was the best. Then both of them started insulting the others' systems, saying that they didn't want the others' dirty water in their field. So they put _ivy_ up between it, which sucks up all the water from the edges (which is why there is none).
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 8-11-2010(2): 畦道 [paddy-field ridge](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2571) (#2571 畦) (ケイ), あぜ … Parts: 田 , 圭 … Note: 圭 often means demarcation. … Similar Keywords: あぜ both 畔 [paddy-ridge](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1204) (#1204 畔), and 畦 [paddy-field ridge](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2571) (#2571 畦) ..1. 畔道 [paddy-ridge](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1204) (#1204 畔) is a phrase divided in half. A rice field is divided in half, half is field half is water. If you stand at the halfway mark, you are at the _Waterside_ ..2. 畦道 [paddy-field ridge](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2571) (#2571 畦) is not equally divisible in half, because piled with ivy. ..3. The Rice Field comedy tour, leaving them in Stitches, follows the 畷 [rice-field footpath](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2072) (#2072 畷).
column9: 5) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 6-8-2009(1): An improvement from the regular paddy ridge, the **paddy-field ridge** is surrounded by ivy.

column5: 1) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 6-8-2009(36): If you think wearing a wool sweater is **itch** y, just think of how _sheep_ must feel! They must be so _sick_ of wearing that **itch** y wool all the time!
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-2-2007(22): Scrapie is a _disease sheep_ sometimes catch. It causes them to **itch** so unbearably that they scrape themselves to death.
column7: 3) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 5-3-2008(11): I'm allergic to _Sheep_ , they make me **itch**. If I'm exposed to them for too long I'll even become _sick_.
column8: 4) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 7-1-2009(9): When the _caveman_ feels an **itch** , he grabs the nearest _sheep_ and rubs himself with it.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 6-9-2009(4): **Itch** . . . **Itch** . . . **Itch** -ewe! It's _ewe_ who gave me this _sheep_ ing _sickness_ again!

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(32): When your _sickness_ involves _inflammation_ , you will produce **phlegm** (perhaps in _phlegm_ ation?).
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 13-3-2007(17): If I'm _sick_ , and have an _inflammation_ of my lungs, I cough up a lot of **phlegm**.
column7: 3) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 24-5-2008(7): Caveman, inflammation: _Caveman_ had a very effective cure for _inflammations_. He just smeared a **phlegm** over the inflamed skin, bringing instant relieve.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 17-2-2010(4): After abaddon's excellent story: When the _caveman_ suffered a bad burn from playing with _fire_ , his skin would get very _inflamed_. His solution was to smear **phlegm** all over himself - this cured him of the _burning_ sensation of the _inflammation_.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 24-11-2010(2): 喀痰 , 血痰 , 痰壷 , 痰 [phlegm](../v4/2573.html) (#2573 痰) タン (cf 炎 ) … Parts: 疒, 炎 [inflammation](../v4/162.html) (#162 炎) … Story: The most disgusting firemen in the world: When they are healthy, they can't come into work. But when they are _Sick_ _Inflamed_ and full of **Phlegm** , they come in and spit **Phlegm** on double fires as a low tech fire fighting foam.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 3-2-2007(32): He had a curious form of **measles** : the red marks on his skin were all in the _shape_ of an _umbrella_. The doctors of course couldn't explain it…
column6: 2) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 6-8-2009(5): I'm _sick_ with the **measles**. Whenever I go out, I carry my _parasol_ to try and cover up the rash.
column7: 3) [[dancingblade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dancingblade)] 19-8-2010(2): A: "Hey, its a fine day today, why are you hiding under that _parasol_?" B: "Don't come near me! I'm _sick_ with the **measles**. It spreads with _parasol_ transmission!" A: "Are you sure it wasn't 'aerosol'?" B: "…" (cough).
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 17-2-2010(2): While _Bruce Lee_ was nervously waiting for his [check- up](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1724) (#1724 診) at the doctor's surgery, the _caveman_ , who was suffering from the **measles** , coughed all over _Bruce_. He tried to prevent the infectious microdroplets from reaching him by opening his _umbrella_ against the spray with lightning-fast reflexes. Unfortunately though, despite his quick response, _Bruce_ inhaled some droplets accidentally, and knowing his fate, sat down next to the _caveman_ for quick treatment.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(2): After his [check-up](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1724) (#1724 診), the monk was told he had the **measles** , probably from his measly attire given the weather conditions.

column5: 1) [[Nayelianne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nayelianne)] 20-9-2008(42): " _Hemorrhoids_ 痔 are the **sickness** suffered by people who sit in meditative poses for long periods at Buddhist **temples** 寺 ." ( Joseph De Roo's "2001 Kanji").
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 1-5-2007(6): **Hemorrhoids** is a _sickness_. Mnemonic 'holy **hemorrhoids** ' and picture a monk at a _Buddhist temple_. This is a word that kids find funny, pronounced ジ。.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(5): **Hemorrhoids** is a _sickness_ people at _Buddhist temples_ get from sitting down meditating for too long. It's kinda true.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 18-2-2010(4): " _Caveman_ try Buddhism. _Caveman_ spend a long time meditating at _temple_ with monks. _Caveman_ get **haemorrhoids**. Looking for other religion now. Might try Kabbalah.".
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(3): The _sickness_ most common at _Buddhist temples_ is **hemorrhoids** , perhaps from sitting too long.

column5: 1) [[billyclyde](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/billyclyde)] 1-11-2007(33): The SICKNESS called **cancer** works by self-replication, so that its bad GOODS grow more  & more until a vertiable MOUNTAIN of them forms on you– that's the tumor, the awful sign of **cancer**.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 6-9-2009(8): This is people _sick_ with **cancer** seeking alternative treatment from _goods_ of dubious repute at a remote _mountain_ clinic.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(6): The only cure for the _sickness_ they call **cancer** is a _good_ they sell at the top of that _mountain_.
column8: 4) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(4): People who are _sick_ with _cancer_ will buy _mountains of goods_ (medicines, fake cures/placebos) in order to try and cure themselves.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 18-2-2010(3): When the human race lived as _cavemen_ , our lives were simpler: we didn't eat processed, packaged _goods_ , we just ate fresh, natural food and breathed the clean _mountain_ air, and we had much lower rates of **cancer** compared with today. [Source: Journal of Palaeooncology].

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 12-5-2007(32): This _sickness_ seems to prey upon the _lowly_ of society mostly, and causes **paralysis** in its final stages.
column6: 2) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 24-5-2008(9): Caveman, lowly: _Caveman_ was just a _lowly_ Neanderthaler, trying to survive. But he had healing hands and people were brought in from far to have him cure their **paralysis**.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 29-10-2007(4): Tip: This contains the variation of _lowly_ that is also in [handmaiden](../v4/2196.html) (#2196 婢).
column8: 4) [[cb4960](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cb4960)] 18-1-2009(3): **Paralysis** of the penis is a _sickness_ that will make one's penis _lowly_.
column9: 5) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 5-3-2008(2): Those who are _lowly_ will suffer **paralysis** if they fall _sick_. It's the thought of all those doctor's fees.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 6-1-2007(24): Here you have a picture of him with his **apple of the eye** : you see him keeping an _eye_ upon his favourite _cow_ , while leaning on it with his _elbow_.
column6: 2) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 26-12-2009(11): Barnyard romance: The big bull winked with his EYE and let out a MOO ( 牟 2961) toward the cow and said, "Your the APPLE OF my EYE baby!".
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(8): An **apple of the eye** is something that makes your _eye_ want to ム like a _cow_.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 21-11-2010(3): 眸 =瞳[apple of the eye](../v4/2580.html) (#2580 眸) ひとみ … Parts: 目 , 牟 [moo](../v4/2961.html) (#2961 牟) … Note: 異体字 for 瞳 [pupil](../v4/437.html) (#437 瞳) … Story: There's the eye, and to get the rest you have to understand that in Japan you are the Cow's Moo, rather than the Cat's Meow.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 19-12-2009(2): _Eye_ , _moo_. Stupid _cow_ took a bite out of the **apple of the eye** , but I _elbow_ ed her & she spat it out with a small ム/ 牟 [moo](../v4/2961.html) (#2961 牟).

column5: 1) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 17-1-2009(36): If you see _mysterious_ things in front of your _eyes_ you're definitely **dizzy**.
column6: 2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 2-7-2007(10): When you see _mysterious_ stars from your _eyes_ , it's a sign that you're **dizzy** \- 眩暈 （めまい）。 Maybe becuase you're fighting off a _face hugger_ who has its tail round your neck!
column7: 3) [[brose](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brose)] 18-3-2007(7): _Gandalf_ uses his _eyes_ to make people feel **dizzy** ゲン カン げん.す くるめ.く まぶ.しい くら.む まど.う めま.い faint, **dizzy**.
column8: 4) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 30-8-2009(4): As soon as he _eyed_ around at the _mysterious_ person following him, next thing he knew he was seeing stars - completely **dizzy**.
column9: 5) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-2-2007(3): New lyric for Little Richard's song: You make me **dizzy** Miss Lizzy, with your _mysterious eyes_.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 14-1-2007(36): I threw my _dart_ at a **pheasant** during the hunt, but hit a _turkey_ instead.
column6: 2) [[oregum](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oregum)] 14-1-2009(5): A **pheasant** is like a small wild TURKEY except you can kill it with a DART.
column7: 3) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 22-5-2011(4): I tried to kill the _turkey_ with a _dart_ , but a **pheasant** , who was his good friend, jumped in between to save the turkey. **Pheasant** turned out to be just as good though.
column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 23-1-2010(3): I had the **pheasant** clearly in view when I threw the _dart_ but wouldn't you know it at precisely the wrong moment a _turkey_ ran between us  & became the 7th one down in RtK3.
column9: 5) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 30-12-2009(2): _Cupid_ may be the god of love, but he's also one rather spoilt child. We brought him a _turkey_ for dinner the other day, and he just sulked, saying he'd only have **pheasant**. What an ungrateful deity!!

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 31-1-2007(28): That carpenter can never remember where his tools are, so there is a _gigantic arrow_ pointing to his carpenter's square.
column6: 2) [[timcampbell](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/timcampbell)] 9-1-2009(15): I pin down my carpenter's square with a _gigantic dart_ to keep it from moving when I make my measurements.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 17-4-2007(7): My carpenter's square is hanging on that _gigantic dart_.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 7-8-2008(2): This is a pretty bizarre carpenter's square. Most carpenter's **square** s have two functions - holding straight, 90 degree angles, and measuring. This one has two more. One side is a long _dart_ \- so you can measure with it and also stick it in the wall so that you can get a straight vertical every time. The other side is a _dong_. There is an obvious use for this, but the official one is that it looks gross, so nobody will steal it (this is a big problem with carpenter's **square** s).
column9: 5) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 1-3-2012(1): This is a special kind of **carpenter's square** \- in the hands of the right carpenter, it can be used to deflect _giant darts_ , and as a killing tool. Perfect for the undercover carpenter.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 5-7-2007(16): Last time I was on _crag's list_ , I found someone selling an _aircraft carrier_ they carved out of _stone_! A crazy lawn ornament I suppose.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-1-2007(14): If you want to take all the _stones_ out of this **crag** , you'll need a large _carrier_.
column7: 3) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 13-12-2009(5): The carrier got stuck on a large stone, also known as a **crag**.
column8: 4) [[paasan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paasan)] 23-7-2010(4): This is the modern version of Noah's ark – As the water level declined (see, no water), the aircraft _carrier_ stranded on a big _rock_ , later to be found out to be a **crag**. And out of the carrier stepped two and two of each army vehicle there was and populated the earth once again.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 17-2-2010(2): The _aircraft carrier_ got stuck on a large _rock_ near **Crag** gy Island, home of Father Ted.

column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 22-10-2007(25): A **grapnel** is a small anchor with several hooks, used for anchoring small boats, or to pull up sunken objects (it looks very much like a grappling hook). The position of _stones_ underwater _determines_ where the **grapnel** will catch.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 17-3-2007(13): He was _determined_ to climb this _rock_ , so he used a **grapnel**.
column7: 3) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 21-12-2010(7): This reminds of Link's hookshot. The annoying thing about his **grapnel** was that it could only hook onto _rocks_ pre- _determined_ by the game's maker. Just think of how many frustrating puzzles you could skip over if it could grab onto anything!
column8: 4) [[NeoGlitch](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NeoGlitch)] 12-5-2012(1): If you ever played Zelda Wind Waker then you know the **grapnel** can only be hooked to special kinds of _stones_. The specific design of the stone (it usually has a white circle somewhere) _determines_ if you can use your **grapnel** on it or not.
column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 18-9-2010(1): The type of _stone_ a **grapnel** snags will _determine_ whether the climber lives or dies.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 3-11-2007(29): Notes: 珀 (not in Heisig) means "amber". Story for both: A bus is stopped at some traffic lights in Japan. Inside, _King_ Henry VIII and Barry _White_ are arguing over whether the lights are yellow or _amber_. The lights change to "Go", and Mick Jagger ( _stone_ ) then joins a new argument over whether the lights are blue or green. They compromise on **blue-green**.
column6: 2) [[hissatsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hissatsu)] 11-11-2010(12): The rarest form of _amber_ is a **blue-green** _stone_. (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_amber>).
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 11-8-2008(7): A 昔話 about why street lights in Japan are _blue-green_. In the old days, there was only one street light - and it was _amber_. When it was on, you had to stop - and when it was off, you could go (but slowly). So one day a salaryman was late for work and stuck at a long _amber_ light. He got impatient and threw a _rock_ at it. The light started to malfunction and flickered **blue- green**. People were confused - "what do we do? Stop? Go slowly?" "Uh..it means…go fast!!!" The end.
column8: 4) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 6-8-2009(4): Notes: 珀 (not in Heisig) means "amber". (Thanks Katsuo) **Amber** : The _king_ is above wearing _white_ , all his clothes must be dyed a deep **amber** color to show how wealthy he is. **Blue-green** : To augment his _amber_ robes, the king wears **blue-green** precious _stones_ as jewelry.
column9: 5) [[woelpad](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/woelpad)] 26-5-2008(3): There's only one occasion for which an [emperor](../v4/261.html) (#261 皇) will take off his _white_ tiara which distinguishes him from a mere _king_ , and that is when he's offered a **blue-green** jade _stone_.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 21-1-2007(23): This is not an ordinary _rock_ , if you look carefully you will _see_ that it is an ancient **inkstone**.
column6: 2) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 17-2-2010(8): A magical **inkstone** was made in ancient China that was able to mix invisible ink. When the ink dried, the surface it adhered to became invisible. Unfortunately, someone used it once and forgot to wash the _stone_ thoroughly afterwards, and when the ink dried the magical **inkstone** was never _seen_ again.
column7: 3) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 19-8-2009(6): **Inkstone** rubbed on ROCK allows you to SEE an image.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(5): A _rock_ that you often _see_ (in writing) is an **inkstone**.
column9: 5) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 13-12-2009(3): An **inkstone** is a stone you will see on every ancient Chinese writing desk.

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(20): In Bedrock, people had _business cards_ made of _rock_ and engraved using a **grindstone**. (Big ups to Katsuo).
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-6-2007(19): My _calling card_ is made of _rock_ , which is a bit inconvenient because it is so big & heavy. So I’m using a **grindstone** to grind it down in size.
column7: 3) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(5): **Grindstone** s, meet the **Grindstone** s, they're the modern _Stone_ Age family. . . . Fred handing you a _business card_.
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 17-2-2010(4): A salaryman stays up all night, working hard at the **grindstone** , making a stack of _business cards_ out of thin sheets of _stone_. He believes this gesture will give him the upper hand in business, and convince his associates that he is a hard worker who is able to keep his nose to the **grindstone** when necessary.
column9: 5) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 22-6-2007(2): I took the myriad of _business cards_ I had been forced to take over the years and put them to the force of the **grindstone**.

column5: 1) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 23-11-2008(53): **Teacup** s at the Japanese restaurant are usually made of stone and have the name and address of the restaurant written on them.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(9): Similarly to the [wooden bowl](../v4/2487.html) (#2487 椀), the **teacup** made of _stone_ has it's makers _address_ carved into the bottom.
column7: 3) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 11-10-2006(8): **Teacup** = 茶碗 （ちゃわん）. Pieces of _stone_ (?) that everyone has at their _address_.
column8: 4) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 25-5-2008(2): Stone, adress: **Teacups** for the tea ceremony are usually made out of _stone_. Since many students attend the tea ceremony course, everyone had to write their _address_ on the back side, to be able to distinguish between all these similar cups.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 5-12-2009(1): _Stoned address_ : What did you say was in that **teacup**? I drank it on Blind Faith: Oh, and I'm wasted, and I can't find my way home.

column5: 1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 5-7-2007(25): Those gremlins! At _night break_ they insist on coming out and _gluing_ _stones_ all over the place. These **obstacle** s make it nearly impossible for me to get to work!
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 22-3-2010(6): You [gain](../v4/876.html) (#876 得) 得 when you make forward progress. If you encounter a _rock_ , you _cannot go_ forward. Perhaps you can go round. This is an **obstacle**.
column7: 3) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 12-1-2009(4): The column of soldiers who were gaining on the enemy at nightbreak ran into an **obstacle** : huge stone in their way.
column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 29-10-2009(3): The **obstacle** course in addition to the regular _stones_ scattered about added a special **obstacle** at _nightbreak_ : they poured _glue_ all over the track.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 31-10-2010(2): 碍子 =がい子, 妨碍 =妨害, 障碍 =障害, [obstacle](../v4/2592.html) (#2592 碍) ガイ (usu. 害 [harm](../v4/1551.html) (#1551 害)) … Parts: 石 , 旦 , 寸 (cf 得る [gain](../v4/876.html) (#876 得)) … Story: Main use of this kanji (not replaced by 害 ) is for electrical insulators 碍子 , so: In _Japan_ , the preponderance of bare wiring in old homes, has made for a program of _Gluing Stones on the Floor_ as an **Obstacle** to electrical flow.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 6-1-2007(45): Mount Rushmore is a place in the US where the _heads_ of **illustrious** presidents are carved into the _stone_ of a cliff.

column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(6): The _stone heads_ at Mt. Rushmore are of **illustrious** historical figures.
column8: 4) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 6-3-2010(4): **Illustrious** people often have _stone heads_ (busts) made in their honour.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 25-11-2010(2): 碩学 , [illustrious](../v4/2593.html) (#2593 碩) セキ( 石 ), 名乗り : ひろ, ひろし, みち, みつ, みつる … Parts: 石 , 頁 … Story: Mount Rushmore: **Illustrious** Stone heads. Famous in illustrations.

column5: 1) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 6-9-2009(23): What _stone_ would make the best **whetstone**? I wandered _ten thousand cliffs_ in search of an answer.
column6: 2) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 22-6-2007(12): A **whetstone** so notorious that it had destroyed _ten thousand cliffs_.
column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 29-12-2009(4): If you have an unusually long sword you may need a special **WHETSTONE** to sharpen it. Find a large ROCK on the side of a CLIFF and then rub the sword against it about TEN THOUSAND times to produce a keen edge.
column8: 4) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 25-5-2008(3): Stone, cliff/10.000: That is the _cliff_ where those _10.000_ people have died (see also [horse chestnut](../v4/514.html) (#514 栃)). The guilty parties have been apprehended and the _stone_ block has been set ready for the beheading. A **whetstone** is used to sharpen the executioners' axe.
column9: 5) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 17-11-2006(3): That _cliff_ is made of a _stone_ type that makes very good **whetstone** s. And there is enough to make another _10.00o_.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 1-11-2007(36): Some **mill** s use an animal, typically an ox or donkey, to rotate the stone. But in this **mill** the _stone_ is being pulled round by a _turkey_.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 8-11-2006(5): I can tell you, it was a big mess when a _turkey_ accidentally came between the _stones_ of the wind **mill**. We had to clean the blood and feathers away for ages.
column7: 3) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(3): To create _turkey_ stock, you'll need to grind the turkey down using a _stone_ **mill**.
column8: 4) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 11-3-2010(2): _Stoned turkey_. We were _stone_ d & **mill** ing round the old **mill** when somehow he ended up snood-first through the **mill** _stone_ s. _Stoned turkey_ = _stone-ground turkey_ before you could say 八番目の死んだ七面鳥 .
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 6-3-2010(1): _Stone_ **mill** s are used to pulverise _turkeys_ in the local processing **mill**.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 23-3-2007(25): The beautiful woman has to **fend off** _honorable_ admirers every day, who want to drag her to the _altar_ and marry her.
column6: 2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 17-10-2008(11): Tired of **fending off** your pregnant girlfriend's remarks, you do the _honorable_ thing and take her to the _altar_.
column7: 3) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(2): The send off **fend off** rend off: At the end of the send off for the _honourable_ gentleman - his name was Madoff, if I recall - the only way I could **fend off** his advances was to rend off his _two small_ , well, you know, don't make me say it. Late that night I put them on the _altar_ in penance, but they rolled off.
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 22-6-2007(2): As the zombies broke into the church, I, the _honorable_ protagonist, **fended off** the waves while standing atop an _altar_ : you could have called it an _altar_ call, if you would.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 15-2-2007(2): The _honorable altars_ of Japan have to **fend off** the droves of visitors.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 15-2-2007(43): If you want _longevity_ , go to an _altar_ and **beseech** the gods.
column6: 2) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 25-5-2008(5): Altar, longevity: Having seen all his friends and family die so long ago, the ancient sage visited the _altar_ and **beseeched** the gods to put an end to his _longevity_.
column7: 3) [[tryllid](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tryllid)] 23-5-2011(2): Tithonus **beseech** ed the _gods_ to give him _longevity_ , but not eternal youth. Bad decision.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 24-11-2010(2): 祷る =祈る, 祈祷 =祈禱, 祈祷書 , 祝祷 , 黙祷 , [beseech](../v4/2598.html) (#2598 祷) トウ(cf 寿 ), いのり, いのる … Parts: 礻, 寿 [longevity](../v4/1565.html) (#1565 寿) … Notes: Spahn 4e14.2 … Similar Keywords: 拝む [worship](../v4/1564.html) (#1564 拝), 祈る [pray](../v4/1128.html) (#1128 祈), 祷り [beseech](../v4/2598.html) (#2598 祷) … Story: Having _Glued_ the _Altar_ to my _Bush_ in an unfortunately holiday decoration mishap, I **Beseech** the gods for a glue solvent.
column9: 5) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 10-3-2008(2): I went to the dark _altar_ and **beseech** ed the dark lord to take my soul in exchange for _longevity_.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 10-5-2007(27): Picture a Japanese _altar_ that contains **ancestral tablet** s, placed on the _right_ (on the left would be the incense).
column6: 2) [[dancingblade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dancingblade)] 20-8-2010(6): **Divine intervention** is what happens when things go _right_ at the _altar_.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 4-8-2008(5): On the lower _right_ of each _altar_ , there is a small **ancestral tablet**. Its purpose is to record all of the past converts to Buddhism - they are the ones who chose the _right_ path before you and should be respected.
column8: 4) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 15-12-2009(4): An **ancestral tablet** is always carried to the _altar_ in the _right_ hand.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 19-2-2010(3): During the Apple Special Event of January 2010, Apple devotees watched from their WiFi-enabled _altars_ as the messiah Steve Jobs descended from the clouds, holding the long-awaited **ancestral tablet** , the iPad, in his _right_ hand. [Anyone who clicks 'report' on this story is an Apple fanboi].

column5: 1) [[MeisterLlama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/MeisterLlama)] 29-11-2008(28): From <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinto>: Whenever a child is born in Japan, a local Shinto shrine adds the child's name to a list kept at the shrine and declares him or her a "family child" ( 氏子 ujiko?). After death an ujiko becomes a "family spirit", or "family kami" ( 氏神 ujigami?). Therefore, if your _family name_ is inscribed in the _altar_ , then you will become a **local god**.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 27-1-2007(18): The _altar_ dedicated to this **local god** has the _family names_ of all the villagers inscribed in it, so that the god knows whom he should favour.
column7: 3) [[hissatsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hissatsu)] 12-11-2010(5): The **local god's** _altar_ lists the _family names_ of all those under his purview.
column8: 4) [[Haych](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Haych)] 6-11-2012(1): The **local god** 's a cool guy. We go to the _altar_ to hang out. I used his _family name_ and he told me that that's much too formal and I should just his first name.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 7-10-2011(1): 神祇事務局 , 神祇官 =かみづかさ=じんぎかん, 祇園祭 , [local god](../v4/2600.html) (#2600 祇) ギ … Parts:礻, 氏 … Note: Often appears with the old full altar on the left. … Story: National gods, and 氏 gods, of course the **local god** s are the gods of local ruling Uji.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 30-1-2007(26): The **ancestral shrine** has an _altar_ that shows _little_ _reclining_ figurines of ancestors.
column6: 2) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 24-5-2010(14): Just a note: This is a rarely used kanji, the unsimplified version, 禰 , is far more common, and seeing as we're trying to be kanji masters, we'd all might as well use the traditional (correct) version.
column7: 3) [[chibimizuno](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chibimizuno)] 7-8-2009(5): In countries where ancestors are worshiped, _small_ children are taught to _lie down_ (prostrate themselves) at the _altar_ that is their **ancestral shrine**.
column8: 4) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 6-7-2007(3): In fact, _little Clark Kent_ was sent into space _reclining_ on the **ancestral shrine** of Krypton. Later he placed the _alter_ within his fortress of solitude.
column9: 5) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 22-12-2010(2): 禰[Unicode-0x79b0](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/31152) (#31152 禰) is the real version including let it be. STORY: Unless you want to piss off your ancestors, _let the altar in your **ancestral shrine** be_.

column5: 1) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 24-1-2007(25): Ancient Japanese officials collected their **salarium** in the shrines. A priest would collect their _rice grains_ with a _broom_ , and sweep it unto the _altar_ , where the officials could collect their rice.
column6: 2) [[Aerin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aerin)] 20-2-2008(11): Rather than cold hard cash, the _rice_ that the _altar_ boys could _sweep_ up became their **salarium**.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 21-2-2010(5): Since rice was a form of currency back then, _altar_ boys in the Catholic Church used to _sweep up_ and collect the _rice grains_ after a wedding, and considered it their **salarium** in exchange for their underage sex services.
column8: 4) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 22-5-2009(4): The **salarium** for the Japanes army is not money. They are paid with _videotapes_ (录, see record [record](../v4/1144.html) (#1144 録). The higher the rank, the longer and dirtier the film :-).
column9: 5) [[Shonb6570](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shonb6570)] 12-5-2011(2): This word is obsolete - It comes from the Roman era when soldiers were paid with salt, or rather, "salarium argentum", which means something like "salt money". Incoincidentally, it is where the term, "Worth your salt" comes from. Heisig's word choice for some of these is asinine. The Kanji means "salary" or "stipend".

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 25-11-2008(24): When the wheelchair-bound Felicity was healed at the _altar_ (by one of those healer priests), she was finally able to stand _upright_ and was overcome by **felicitation**.
column6: 2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 11-4-2007(10): On the special festival day, the _altar_ of the local shrine contains the **felicitation** s of local _upright_ citizens, thanking their local gods for doing such a good job.
column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 29-12-2009(3): When offering one's **FELICITATION** at the ALTAR, first bow, then stand UPRIGHT, then bow again, repeat again for good measure.
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 22-6-2007(2): And the _altar_ jumped and stood _upright_. "Hey, nice work there!" Such a **felicitation** is, admittedly, quite awesome.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(1): _Indiana Jones_ is " _upright_ " in **felicitation** at being reunited with his wife.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-7-2009(40): I use **balancing scales** to make sure everyone gets an _even_ amount of _Wheaties_.
column6: 2) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 21-2-2010(7): Before the technology of **balancing scales** was widely available, farmers used to sell their _wheat_ grain using the following method: customers would visit, and shovel as much _wheat_ grain as they could onto a giant _lilypad_. They were allowed as much as they could pile on, and they were charged according to the number of _lilypads_ they filled. This ensured that the greedy were punished, because if the lilypad sunk under the weight, they were still charged for the grain.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 31-3-2007(5): He didn't have a **balancing scales** to figure out how much his _wheat_ weighed, but he came up with a solution: he loaded a vessel with wheat and let it float in his _lily pond_ , and then he measured how deep the vessel would be in the water.
column8: 4) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 5-6-2009(1): Picture weighing wheat on a lilly.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 4-8-2008(1): This is the set of **balancing scales** that they use to figure out how much _Cap 'n Crunch_ to put into each box. They have a control weight off in the distance (you can't see it), and then a small _lily pad_. They pour an appropriate amount of _Cap 'n Crunch_ onto the _lily pad_ , and just before it starts to sink below water level, they know that's the proper amount.

column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 23-10-2007(28): **Millet** is a small grain whose importance was greater in prehistoric times. Nowadays, it has been supplanted in the West by _wheat_ , and in the East ("under the bamboo _umbrella_ "), by _rice_.
column6: 2) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 19-9-2011(3): 黍 , 砂糖黍 , 唐黍 , 黍団子 ( 吉備団子 ), 玉蜀黍 , [millet](../v4/2605.html) (#2605 黍) キビ … Parts: 禾, 人 , 氺… OR ノ, 漆 -氵 (cf: 漆 [lacquer](../v4/932.html) (#932 漆), 黎明 [tenebrous](../v4/2935.html) (#2935 黎), 膝 [knee](../v4/2461.html) (#2461 膝), 鳥黐 [Unicode-0x9ed0](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/40656) (#40656 黐)) … Note:Historical Radical [部首＃](midori://search?text=部首＃) 202 … Backwards Story: _Lacquer_ 漆 is actually made from **millet** : It's **Millet** with the _husk removed_ (-ノ), then mixed with _water_ (+氵).
column7: 3) [[perrin4869](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/perrin4869)] 3-10-2010(2): This kanji shows some people pouring _grains of rice_ , _wheat_ and **millet** all onto a single _umbrella_ …
column8: 4) [[paasan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/paasan)] 23-7-2010(1): Pranks painting the **millet** crops with a _drop_ of [lacquer](../v4/932.html) (#932 漆). As the water vapors, it leaves the **millet** poisonous, and people _drop_ everywhere from poisoning..
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 21-2-2010(1): _People_ who can't afford _wheat_ and live in climates too dry for _rice_ have to make do with **millet**. ( _Umbrella_ is really a _person_ primitive.).

column5: 1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 21-2-2007(64): The dude was so upset about going **bald** that he covered himself with a _wheat_ sack so that only his _legs_ were showing.
column6: 2) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 27-12-2010(4): A **bald** man uses some wheat as a toupee. The wheat is a bit long, so only his legs show underneath.
column7: 3) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 12-3-2007(4): Because the poor guy went **bald** , he made a big, big hat out of _wheat_ stalks. But it was so big, that it covered his whole torso, so that basically only his _walking legs_ were visible under it.
column8: 4) [[Corodon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Corodon)] 8-1-2012(2): Once, I had _wheat_ colored hair that came down to my _human legs_. Then I went **bald**.
column9: 5) [[Green](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green)] 23-8-2012(1): **Bald** Michael Jordan eats his _Wheaties_ , then jumps high into the air on his mighty _human legs_.
