column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 16-2-2007(48): You wanna drive a **Sanskrit ka**? Just _add_ it to the _road_.
column6: 2) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 11-3-2010(4): Ford didn't know what to call their next car, and it was ready to be released. A quick-witted Indian employee thought to himself, "why don't they just call it the 'car', so they can get this show on the _road_?" He raised his hand at the meeting and said, "I propose we call it the Ford **Ka**. No, not like 'car', the **Sanskrit ka** invokes a sense of reliability, safety, performance and beauty. _Add_ to that the fact that nobody will forget its name, because it's homophonous with the actual product!
column7: 3) [[kioku3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kioku3)] 24-9-2009(4): If you want to buy a **Sanskrit ka** (the top selling auto in India), you need to _add_ a little bakeesh to the price for the salesman. Only then will you see yourself driving that **Sanskrit ka** down the _road_. (thanks mantixen).
column8: 4) [[SimHuman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SimHuman)] 17-3-2010(3): The **Sanskrit ka** just seems to be a high カロrie version of the katakana カ. Hit the road, you bloated phonetic character.
column9: 5) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 5-10-2010(1): 釈迦 [しゃか] Buddha. "If you meet the Buddha on the _road_ , kill him." An _ad(d)_ for a car (Ka). This character is _add_ ed to the word for Buddha.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(13): To cut down on カロries, the _king_ _adds_ a **jeweled hairpin** to his coffee rather than sugar.
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 1-8-2010(12): This and [beaded hairpin](../v4/2963.html) (#2963 琲) only seem to occur in the word 珈琲 (コーヒー) where they are used phonetically. So, in practice, it might be easier to remember them as a pair and not worry about their literal meanings. STORY: For 珈 : An assassin _adds_ poison to the _king_ 's **coffee**. For 琲 : However, fearing a plot against him, the _king_ , summons a hapless convict from a _jail cell_ to sample the **coffee** first.
column7: 3) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 11-3-2010(6): When the Jewish _king added_ jewels to his **jeweled hairpin** he was lauded. When the Palestinian _king_ put beads on his 琲 [beaded hairpin](../v4/2963.html) (#2963 琲) he was jailed.
column8: 4) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 23-3-2011(2): I'm changing this to **coffee creamer** and the next kanji to **coffee** for obvious reasons. STORIES: 珈 The servant _added_ **coffee creamer** to the _King_ 's coffee. 琲 The _King_ likes his **coffee** black, so the servant went to _jail_.
column9: 5) [[Regular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Regular)] 17-11-2010(2): If my aunt adds a pe*is, she'll be my uncle. If the King adds a **jeweled hairpin** ,… she's a queen.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 4-11-2007(19): The _king_ is in the _jail cell_ and is trying to escape by picking the lock with his **beaded hairpin**.
column6: 2) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 7-6-2010(6): 珈 (2962) and 琲 (2963) are mainly used for their phonetic readings in 珈琲 コーヒー coffee. To help remember the word and the two kanji, the right sides of these two kanji can be read as "カロ"+"ヒ". Coffee, the _king_ of pick me up beverages, is low calorie.
column7: 3) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(3): When the Jewish king added jewels to his 珈 [jeweled hairpin](../v4/2962.html) (#2962 珈) he was lauded, but when the Palestinian _king_ (the beady-eyed one) put beads on his **beaded hairpin** he was _jailed_.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 26-10-2010(1): 珈琲 [beaded hairpin](../v4/2963.html) (#2963 琲) ヒー, ヒ, … Parts: 王 , 非 … Note: Inane Keyword. **Second Kanji of Coffee** or **Phonetic ヒー, or ヒ** in Kanji Joke names. 香琲工房 is the name of Suntory's coffee website, for instance. … Story: I went to burger _King_ and got my senior price Coffee. When I went for my second cup they dropped a **Beaded Hairpin** in my cup, and said that's what the **Second Kanji in Coffee** actually meant. I hate the _King_ now. So I _Goatse'd_ him and showed him a **Bearded Hairbutt**.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 11-3-2010(1): Every _king_ wants to _add_ a jewelled hairpin to their collection of crown _jewels_. No _kings_ want **beaded hairpin** s though, because they're _un_ cool.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 16-2-2007(27): It used to be that for a meeting [old] you'd _meet_ for a _day_ to get the _small_ details _pent in_. Even then such meetings were still held under the **Japanese cypress** [old].
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 26-3-2010(7): For **Meeting (old)** 會 at [Unicode-0x6703](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/26371) (#26371 會). _Pent- in + small_ is pictograph of "a pair of glasses with windscreen wipers" like something out of a joke shop. STORY: In the olden days we couldn't afford a roof, so we would _meet_ alfresco. Our _spectacles had built in wipers_ so we could continue working during inclement weather. The **meetings (old)** were long and would often last until _sundown_. Those were the days! Note: So for **Japanese cypress** (old) simply replace 会 in [Japanese cypress](../v4/2495.html) (#2495 桧) with 會.
column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 22-1-2010(3): Long ago, the **JAPANESE CYPRESS** [old] was the best TREE to have a MEETING. Even though everyone was PENT IN the rather SMALL area under the tree's cover, it was pleasant enough that they could be there all DAY.
column8: 4) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 5-9-2009(3): You wait as _days_ pass, _pent in_ a _little_ _wooden_ cage, until you are summoned for a _meeting_ with the _old **Japanese Cypress**_ in which she sets you free.
column9: 5) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 9-1-2010(1): Let the middle primitive of _meeting_ = _broken window_. The people meet to discuss the recent outbreak of _window smashing_ after the _sun_ goes down. Story: Even in the old days, people _met_ at the **Japanese Cypress**.

column5: 1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 9-1-2007(32): This is a picture of a horse cart ( 車 ) from which the reins ( 糸 ) go to the mouth ( 口 ) of the horse, in which is the **bit**.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(7): A bridle's bit was put in the _mouth_ of the horse and connected by _two threads_ back to the horse-drawn _car_.
column7: 3) [[dancingblade](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dancingblade)] 4-11-2010(2): Errata: Apparently this frame was supposed to refer to 鑾 = tinkling bell [Unicode-0x947e](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/38014) (#38014 鑾), but there's nothing wrong with the current keyword or the kanji, just the frame information.
column8: 4) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 5-9-2009(1): Spiderman and venom fighting atop a horses car, the driver mouths off "take your battle elsewhere!", and takes off the bridle's bit off the horse and throws it at them.
column9: 5) [[decals](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decals)] 23-3-2011(): In the old days, we used to put two _strings_ through the horses mouth and tie it to our _car_ (riage) to make a **bridle's bit**. Then we would open our _mouths_ and yell at the horse to get it going. Nowadays, we have to just promise the horse an apple if it moves. More humane I guess.

column5: 1) [[danie115](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/danie115)] 22-12-2008(59): The **abyss** [old] used to be the _water_ you were pushed into if you lost in the arm wrestling match. (the primitive to the right screams two guys arm wrestling on a table, any one else see it?).
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(3): Be careful on the _suspension bridge_ lest you fall into the _water_ of the **abyss** [old].
column7: 3) [[herman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/herman)] 3-1-2009(2): Two guys arm-wrestling over a watery **abyss** , loser ends up falling in.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 21-8-2011(1): チャレンジャー海淵 , 剣淵町 [abyss [old]](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2966) (#2966 淵) エン, ふち, … Parts:氵, 片 , 一 , [片＊](midori://search?text=片＊) (cf: 片道 [one- sided](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/1212) (#1212 片), 甘肅省 [Unicode-0x8085](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/32901) (#32901 肅)) … Note: 異体字 for 渕 [abyss](../v4/2325.html) (#2325 渕). Even though Heisig calls this the Old version of 渕 , 淵 is on the official name kanji list, and 渕 is not. … Story: 0ld bridge across the **Old **Abyss**** over Water from _One sided_ to the _Other Sided_ , with just _One_ ropeded.
column9: 5) [[snzzbk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snzzbk)] 8-1-2010(1): In the **old** days, people were serious about arm wrestling. Losing an arm wrestling match brought shame upon one's family for generations, so the defeated would often throw themselves into the _watery_ **abyss** rather than face a life of ostracism.

column5: 1) [[adrianbarritt](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/adrianbarritt)] 1-1-2008(24): _Mr T_ also knows that the Roman Numeral for _ten_ is **X**.
column6: 2) [[to_nihon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/to_nihon)] 18-3-2009(3): Mr. T gives ten reasons he looks up to Malcolm X, then wonders out loud what happened to the other IX Malcolms.

column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(): _Haruhi_ used to write the number _ten_ with the Roman numeral **X**.

column5: 1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 15-8-2008(24): This is actually the old **ten thousand** yen bill in Japan - _Jiminy Cricket_ surrounded by a wreath of flowers. It's pretty uncommon to see nowadays since it was only in print for a few days immediately after the war (MacArthur wanted a way to make sure that even the rich kept their atrocities in their consciences).
column6: 2) [[cb4960](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cb4960)] 16-2-2009(12): Your _flowers_ will not be safe if **ten thousand [old]** _Jiminy Crickets_ come to town.
column7: 3) [[Peppi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Peppi)] 24-5-2009(5): The **old **ten thousand**** Yen bill showed a _long tailed monkey_ 禺 with a _flower_ on his head. It was the pet of the emperor.
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(3): A man in a _straitjacket_ counts out **ten thousand** [old] _flowers_ for his imaginary girlfriend.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 26-10-2010(2): 壱萬 =一万, 都萬神社 , [ten thousand [old]](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2969) (#2969 萬) マン, よろず … Parts:艹, 禺 … Story: _Vern/Jiminy Cricket_ has a bad _Rose_ allergy: "I am really **Itchy Man** " he says. I tell him that is a really old joke, and he should stop.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 4-11-2007(28): I see lots of 10,000 yen notes just lying on the _road_ and think, "Should I stop and pick them up?" But then I realise they are _old 10,000_ 's (i.e. worthless) and decide I’ll just **pass through**.
column6: 2) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 24-1-2009(10): I wonder if I can **pass through** this _old road_ , it looks _10000_ years old.
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 15-8-2008(3): This is a secret **passthrough** in _Mario Kart Road_ \- it is a flower-lined, hidden tunnel, and an awesome way to **pass through** directly to the finish line and beat everyone! But there's a guard there - _Jiminy Cricket_ \- that won't let anyone through - saying that it's against his _conscience_. You try to pay him off with a bunch of money, and he won't budge. Then you remember an item you picked up - an old _１０万円Jiminy Bill_. Being a collector, he accepts and lets you **pass through**.
column8: 4) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 22-1-2010(2): When Moses was leading the Israelites thru the wilderness he asked a nearby ruler, "May we **PASS THROUGH** your territory? There's only about TEN THOUSAND of us and I promise we'll stay on the old ROAD.".
column9: 5) [[dubitable](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dubitable)] 16-10-2010(1): Reminds me of the Biblical proverb, easier than a camel to **PASS THROUGH** the eye of a needle than a rich man (with 10,000 yen, say) to **PASS THROUGH** the gates of heaven (via the ROAD-WAY).

column5: 1) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 24-5-2008(43): Fire, voiced - water: After the incident where the insect made a pitiful _voiced_ sound, you decide to free it. Immediately it is attracted to the **candlelight** and flies into the _fire_. Bugger!
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 21-11-2008(6): You were watching the poor insect bound up _voicing_ "Help me! Help me!" ([voiced](../v4/835.html) (#835 濁)), so you answered his calls for help by using a **candlelight** to set the evil spider on _fire_.
column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 23-12-2009(4): Drawn to the **CANDLELIGHT** by the allure of the FIRE, the moth momentarily VOICED it's demise because there wasn't any water to put it out.
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 25-6-2007(2): In order to get that _insect_ out of your throat (continuing from [voiced](../v4/835.html) (#835 濁), you use the _fire_ of a **candlelight** to scare the bugger.
column9: 5) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 2-4-2009(1): I go round with a **candle(light)** setting _fire_ to all the _spiders_. (Notes: 1. Let right side = "spider" because a _spider_ makes a _net_ to _bind up insects_ , 2. net = 罒 horizontal eye).

column6: 2) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 22-1-2010(8): An especially **TOUGH** form of discipline was used in old Japan. Criminals would be tied up or crucified on posts and put on DISPLAY and their blood would DROP onto the ROAD.
column7: 3) [[Neobeo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Neobeo)] 30-1-2009(3): The _display_ there says that this _really old road_ is still **tough** and can still be used.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 15-8-2008(3): This is the **tough** est part of _Mario Kart Road_. If you finish the game on the hardest mode, you get to fight a boss named, simply, **Tough** Guy. This guy drives around in a kart made completely of hard _gems_ , and has a _Shoop Da Woop Mouth_ mounted on the top of his kart. It's almost impossible to get anywhere near him, but if you can beat him, you get to select him in the normal game!
column9: 5) [[Gaignun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Gaignun)] 17-11-2011(2): The _road_ is where young, irresponsible males like to _display_ how " **tough** " they are. It is because of them that my car insurance premiums are so high!

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-10-2007(49): In **old** style street **lamp** s, to light the _fire_ you had to _ascend_ them.
column6: 2) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 21-11-2010(4): Think old style **lamp** s that you would light on fire and let them ascend to the skies.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(1): _Fire_ can _ascend_ from the ground and hang in a **lamp** [old].
column8: 4) [[hissatsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hissatsu)] 28-11-2010(): The _fire_ from my **trusty old **lamp**** lit the way during my _ascent_.

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 3-12-2008(34): In the old days, instead of having a micro- _computer_ sewn into the suit of the master spy, a whole computer was carried in the **back** of his cloak, although it was clearly obvious that he was a spy. "What's that um.. enormous computer doing in the **back** your cloak?".
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 22-3-2010(3): Modern spy apparel includes microcomputers sown into the **back** of the top hat and scarf as seen in [back](../v4/399.html) (#399 裏). However, in the **old** days, the coal driven _computer_ was so bulky it had to be hidden in the **back** of a bulky _cloak_. All these old spies masqueraded as hunchbacks.
column7: 3) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 11-3-2010(1): The invisible man using the _computer_ in [back](../v4/399.html) (#399 裏) could also travel through time. All he had to say was, "I want to be **back** in the **[old]** en days!" and he would be instantly teleported **back** [old]. All that would be left was the _cloak_ he was wearing, when he dematerialised, it fell down _beside the computer_ in a heap.
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 30-9-2007(1): Prior to donning a hat and cloak to protect his **back** , the evil cyborg simply kept a _cloak_ to the side to protect his **back** [old].
column9: 5) [[Panta](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Panta)] 23-3-2013(): In the old days top hats weren't that popular (think capitalism), but on the other hand, cloaks were more popular than they are now.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-10-2007(32): **Park** s in Japan are designed around water, rocks and trees. A _park_ with _flowers_ is considered to be an **alternate **park****.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(6): In the old days **park** s had more _flowers_.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(2): One alternate type of **park** has _flowers_ in it. Some do, some don't.
column8: 4) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 5-9-2009(1): If the **park** gets full, just use the alternate **park** you know the one with flowers.
column9: 5) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 7-3-2011(): **Park** s in Japan are very conservative. Add _flowers_ and they will call you [alternative].

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 3-12-2008(20): At an **alternative **shop**** you can buy strange items like _metal dogtags_ from wars, active grenades, torture sets, etc.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 8-12-2009(7): Understandable that the alternate **shop** is more successful than the regular 舗 [shop](../v4/1839.html) (#1839 舗): trendy _metal_ motif instead of that dingy cottage look.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(2): An alternate type of **shop** installs _metal_ upgrades to your _Segway_ like chrome rims and spinners.
column8: 4) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 30-9-2007(2): In the cottage, you give them _gold_ , they give you _dogtags_.
column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 17-3-2011(1): The **shop** [alternate] was sold for _gold_ by the _offspring_ since they had the other one anyway.

column5: 1) [[EusthEnoptEron](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/EusthEnoptEron)] 23-12-2008(23): The _bird_ got tired of the _mountain_ he lived on, so now he's flying away searching for an **alternative **island****.
column6: 2) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 14-6-2008(12): Mountain, bird: On the **alternative **island**** , _birds_ could just breed beside the _mountains_ instead of upon one. The hippies didn't do any harm.
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(2): On an alternate type of **island** , a _bird_ may roost beside the _mountain_ rather than on it.
column8: 4) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 20-3-2010(1): **Islands alternate** between those 島 with flightless _birds_ (no aerodynamic _tail feathers_ ) and those 嶋 having _birds_ with tail feathers (and the power of flight). The tail-less birds have migrated to the mountaintops to escape persecution from invaders (humans, cats etc.).
column9: 5) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 7-3-2011(): The _bird_ was going to land on the **island** , but then it saw the _mountain_ was for _birds_ into [alternate] music, so it swiftly pulled up its _tail feathers_.

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 3-12-2008(19): The **alternative **summit**** is so steep that the _mountain is above_ you rather than beside you. People usually just go with the regular **summit**.
column6: 2) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 31-3-2010(4): Logically, an **alternate** way to arrange the primitives for 峰 [summit](../v4/1562.html) (#1562 峰) is to have 山 on top where it rightfully belongs.
column7: 3) [[thecite](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thecite)] 4-10-2009(4): The couple have a _tryst_ just below the alternate mountain **summit** , where no one goes anymore.
column8: 4) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 14-6-2008(3): Mountain, walking through the bushes: The hippies didn't want to climb the entire _mountain_ and decided to go to the ' **alternative **summit**** ' which involved _walking through the bushes_ below the _mountain_.
column9: 5) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(2): An alternate type of environmental **summit** arranges the _mountain_ above the _walking legs_ and _Smart Cars_ necessary to reduce energy consumption and emissions.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 16-2-2007(31): A _grove_ now grows on the _soil_ of [old] **plains**.
column6: 2) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 2-12-2010(3): Only Names: Family names (Ishino 石埜 , Takano 高埜 ) Given names: (Nonoka 埜々香 , Yaya 埜々 ), 埜 [plains [old]](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2979) (#2979 埜) ヤ, の … Parts: 林 , 土 (cf: 禁止 [prohibition](../v4/1098.html) (#1098 禁) … Note: Freaking Rare Kanji, Name only, Not in Nelson, Spahn listing under 野 , IMEs won't even offer it as an option. … Story: Intentional Wordplay: We went hiking in Pacific _Grove_ , and found Amelia Erhart's **Old Planes** scattered in the _Dirt_. It turns out she never left California!.
column7: 3) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 11-3-2010(2): The **old **plains**** natives continue to inhabit the _groves_ & work the _soil_. The lucky ones are helped by their daughters  & sons who work the new 野 [plains](../v4/1596.html) (#1596 野) on computers & know already beforehand to whom & what they owe their joy.
column8: 4) [[Miyumera](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Miyumera)] 7-8-2012(1): Before computers and humans were around the **plains** were just GROVES OF TREES growing on SOIL.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 11-3-2010(): The **[old] **plains**** of Israel used to be barren and vast, in spite of the fertile _soil_. Thanks to modern irrigation technologies, the **[old] **plains**** are now covered in orange _groves_.

column5: 1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 8-1-2007(54): An ancient Japanese **dragon** , beautiful and terrifying. Here it is depicted standing on a piece of meat (its prey) and a description is written on the right margin. It is said to be like a snake that has three toes on its feet and can sometimes use its head as a flamethrower (kind of like a sling, but with fire instead of stones). (Note: The Japanese **dragon** has three toes, unlike other Asian **dragon** s. Asian **dragon** s generally don't breath fire, but Godzilla does, and it is supposed to be a **dragon**!).
column6: 2) [[shakkun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shakkun)] 2-7-2008(29): (insp by raulir) The ancient Japanese **Dragon** , now extinct, is depicted in a book of lore STANDING on a pile of freshly slaughtered MEAT. The column describes how the last Japanese **Dragon** was killed by a party of adventurers, who struck its SNAKE body simultaneously with a SLINGSHOT and THREE swords.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-9-2008(9): The **old **dragon**** places a _vase_ on top of the _moon_ for target practice and then tries to hit it using his special _slingshot_ made from a _snake_. It takes him _three_ shots: "Missed… missed… Got it!" (Note _slingshot_ & _snake_ share one stroke).
column8: 4) [[howtwosavealif3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howtwosavealif3)] 5-2-2011(5): 立 月 ト コ ひんまげ チョンチョンチョン → 龍 .
column9: 5) [[Crowfoot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Crowfoot)] 27-4-2008(4): First the young **dragon** s _attacked_ the old **dragon** to dethrone him, then they removed his _garments_ as a way of humiliation.

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 3-12-2008(18): An _old dragon_ 's _house_ enjoys a lot of **patronage** as a modern tourist attraction. (thanks mantixen).
column6: 2) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 14-6-2008(11): House, dragon [old]: The _house_ of the _old dragon_ was filled with art pieces: he was very active in **patronage** , i.e. supporting artists. (He had to do something with his hoard).
column7: 3) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(3): A Chinese _dragon_ 's _house_ enjoys a lot of **patronage** from would-be disciples.
column8: 4) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 7-4-2010(2): Show your **patronage** , by displaying an **imperial dragon** in the window of your _house_.
column9: 5) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 11-3-2010(2): Imagine a gimmicky souvenir shop. The owner makes money by ripping off tourists, and can't be shut down because the shop is also his _house_. He does have one cool thing though - an _[old] dragon_ figurine that sits beside the cash register, and when the shoppers leave, it says "THANK YOU FOR YOUR **PATRONAGE** " in an **[old] dragon** y voice.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(24): A Chinese _dragon_ flying overhead can cause **deafness** to your _ears_.
column6: 2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 3-12-2008(4): When the _old dragon_ roared into my _ears_ I suffered from a little **deafness**.
column7: 3) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 9-2-2007(3): Beethoven, due to his **deafness** , had a large collection of hearing aids. His favourite was one made from an _old dragon's ear_.
column8: 4) [[juandixonformvp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/juandixonformvp)] 17-9-2012(1): Imagine a Komodo Dragon flicking his tongue in your ear and his saliva and bacteria causing you to go deaf.
column9: 5) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 10-3-2011(1): 聾する , 聾唖 , 金聾 , 聾桟敷 , [deafness](../v4/2983.html) (#2983 聾)ロウ, つんぼ, みみしい … Parts: 龍 , 耳 (cf: 寵愛 [patronage](../v4/2982.html) (#2982 寵), 襲名 [attack](../v4/2025.html) (#2025 襲), 龍神 , … Story: Watching TV reporters, even with earphones in their ears, unable to report because of modern dragons (planes) flying _over_ head, makes one imagine a time long ago when _old dragons_ flying overhead brought **Deafness** to one's _ears_. Because of course they did not have earplugs long ago. All the guys who worked at the dragon airports back then went deaf.

column5: 1) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 14-2-2008(24): The **old **longing**** is a 欲 [longing](../v4/792.html) (#792 欲) of the _heart_.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(5): As you get old, you develop a _longing_ for a new _heart_.
column7: 3) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 14-6-2008(3): **Longing** , heart: The old man had supressed his **old **longing**** from his youth for many years, but nothing can stop _longing_ if it comes from the bottom of one's _heart_.
column8: 4) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 20-3-2010(1): **Longing of old** came from the very bottom of one's _heart_. In today's [longing](../v4/792.html) (#792 欲) the heart doesn't get a look in. Modern folk must be pretty shallow.
column9: 5) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 13-4-2007(): Same story as for [milk](../v4/729.html) (#729 乳) but this time **longing** [old] is **longing** with all your _heart_.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(18): A long time ago the Monkey King was kept in _prison_ under a _mountain_ **Point**.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 11-12-2009(8): It's an **old **point**** to say that land developers don't always provide full disclosure. Brochures touting the 'New **Point** ', an artificial hill atop the _mountain_ , fail to mention the notorious _prison_ on the **Old **Point**** just below.
column7: 3) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 17-3-2011(1): The **Point** [old] is a _prison_ under a _mountain_ where the Dementors are locked away.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 8-11-2010(1): Place/People names: 嶽川奈美子 , 嶽六所神社 , 嶽温泉 [Point [old]](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2987) (#2987 嶽) たけ … Parts: 山 , 獄 [prison](../v4/338.html) (#338 獄) … Similar Keywords: 岡本 [Mount](../v4/1961.html) (#1961 岡), 山岳 [Point](../v4/1330.html) (#1330 岳), 嶽 [Point [old]](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2987) (#2987 嶽) … Story: (using 山 as a intensifier as in 嵐 , etc.) The **Old **Point**** guard was forced to retire, got in a barfight, killed a man, and then he got sent to _Super Prison_.
column9: 5) [[gfb345](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gfb345)] 1-6-2010(1): What's the **POINT** of dropping a _MOUNTAIN_ on top of a _PRISON_? (placement) This may have made sense in the _old_ days, but not now.

column5: 1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 3-12-2008(21): Russia, an **old **country**** , has everyone _pent-in_ and drinking vodka saying "aaaaaaaaa". See mantixen's story, [a](../v4/2091.html) (#2091 或).
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(8): It used to be you were _pent in_ by _a certain_ **country**. Now we have global travel and dual citizenships.
column7: 3) [[ajaxw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ajaxw)] 22-12-2009(2): The range of old has been fenced in (pent-in) by advancement, destroying the old **country** western charm.
column8: 4) [[Satchmobgw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Satchmobgw)] 3-12-2012(1): There's still _a certain_ very old **country** that writes the kanji for **country** this way. (I'm looking at you China.).
column9: 5) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 14-6-2008(1): Pent-in, a: In _a certain_ **old **country**** (France, which is part of the 'old world'), prisoners are _pent-in_ under very bad hygenic conditions.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(27): The _body part_ that gets wet when you wade through the _sewers_ (a _crafted_ _flood_ underneath the _ground_ ) is your **shin** (thanks brian44).
column6: 2) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 13-2-2008(10): The right side actually has to do with a sort of undersround water tunnel, check any chinese hanzi dictionary and you will see <http://www.zhongwen.com/> .
column7: 3) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 16-8-2008(8): [+brian44] is right - so I'll try using the right primitive as _sewers_. I've been using Ninja Turtles and stuff though, so I'll have to use this as a series of narrow, long, lead pipes that bring _floods_ of water to the city. Here, someone has taken a lead _sewer pipe_ and hit you in the part of your _flesh_ that is most vulnerable to impact: your **shin** (after years of soccer/football, I can't think of the word **shin** without thinking of pain).
column8: 4) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 13-11-2007(3): I remember the right-hand half as "barge" – it's flat like a _floor_ , it's easy to _craft_ , and it will float above a _flood_ (it appears again later). It's dangerous to stand on a barge (too easy to fall off), or sit (might slide off) – it's best to rest on the _part of the body_ that is your **shin** s.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 29-1-2010(2): Easy if you have a friend named **Shin** , or can imagine one: he has his **shin** , the _body part_ homophonous with his name, stuck in a _sewer_. Poor **Shin**.

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(18): The _powerful_ stench coming from the _sewers_ is **formidable**.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 19-12-2009(7): [+mantixen] _Sewer power_ : **formidable** stench.
column7: 3) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 14-2-2008(4): The legendary _barge_ (see 脛 [shin](../v4/2989.html) (#2989 脛)) owned by Cleopatra was a symbol of her **formidable** _power_.
column8: 4) [[Haych](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Haych)] 11-11-2012(1): In lots of games like oblivion there is a _sewers_ level. You can meet some **formidable** foes down there, so you better make sure to have enough _power_ to take em down.
column9: 5) [[brendanmacdonald](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brendanmacdonald)] 22-1-2012(): The POWER of CRAFTING under WATER is **FORMIDABLE** \- you can build tunnels and all sorts.

column5: 1) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 14-6-2008(27): Old evil altar, sign of snake: In the ancient temple, they found and _old evil altar_ with the _sign of the snake_ imprinted on it. What evil could be **enshrined** within it???
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(7): An _altar_ with the _sign of the snake_ etched into it **enshrine** s a serpent god.
column7: 3) [[n1williams](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/n1williams)] 22-1-2010(3): At the OLD ALTAR of RTK 1 the SIGN OF THE SNAKE is forever **ENSHRINe** d in the hearts of those who persevered. (Thanks blannk).
column8: 4) [[Meconium](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Meconium)] 12-3-2010(2): The memories of reaching the [sign of the snake](../v4/2042.html) (#2042 巳) as well as the end of this book, with its _variant altars_ , floats and such will be forever **enshrine** d in my memory as minor victories, memorable achievements reached on my journey toward Japanese mastery.
column9: 5) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 30-10-2009(2): Image from a few months back: I am so happy to have reached the _sign of the snake_ that I **enshrine** it in a _very old altar_.

column5: 1) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 14-6-2008(25): Old evil altar, chihuahua with extra leg: They opened up the _old evil altar_ in the ancient temple. Nothing inside. But suddenly, their _chihuahua_ grew an extra leg, and started speaking in a strange language. Time for an **exorcism** , one would say.
column6: 2) [[blannk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blannk)] 5-12-2009(8): When grandma's _chihuahua_ developed the _extra leg_ we thought an **exorcism** in order. We did it on a _very old altar_. It was not successful.
column7: 3) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 4-2-2008(3): A _three- legged dog_ has an **exorcism** performed on a _cheap resin altar_ (see 祀 [enshrine](../v4/2992.html) (#2992 祀)). Note that the right-hand half of this character is the simplified Chinese form of "dragon" (犮, instead of 竜 in Japanese).
column8: 4) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(2): Your _friend_ , barking like a _dog_ , is put on the _altar_ for an **exorcism**.
column9: 5) [[Boy.pockets](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Boy.pockets)] 4-3-2011(1): Back in the _[old]_ days, before they knew about the birds and the bees, they put the poor little _chihuahua_ on the _altar_ (note [old]), and did an **exorcism** on his _third leg_.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 4-11-2007(28): People with _wooden legs_ are _renowned_ for **dither** ing over whether to decorate them with a _drop_ of paint or not.

Wait, it's **Dither**.
column8: 4) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 16-8-2008(2): This is _Chester'_ s girlfriend, _Chesty_. It's rather easy to tell who's who in person (check the name!) but in kanji form, the only way to tell is by looking for her tiny _drop_ earring that she always wears on the right. Anyway, here, she has been given the option of being free of puppetry and getting her own set of nice, solid, wooden _legs_! But she can't decide whether she wants to be independent yet, so she starts to **dither** about it - her _drop_ earring wobbles as she **dither** s…
column9: 5) [[wilsoncb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/wilsoncb)] 30-8-2010(1): The renowned author who had a peg leg was **dither** ing aout whether to get a tattoo (drop) on it - after all, as a renowned public figure, he had his image to consider… (thanks alucardchuu).

column5: 1) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(41): A _samurai_ wearing a _broken crown_ _crafted_ an _inch_ -thick _floor_ under which to hide with his _mouth glued_ , giving him **longevity** as his enemies failed to find him.
column6: 2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 16-8-2008(3): This is an old _samurai_ who's seen a lot of **longevity**. He has been sitting in the same spot, on his _torn Burger King Crown_ , for ages. He's something of a local landmark, so when a _construction site_ is set up around him, they simply put a _ceiling_ over his head and build around him. A gum company puts him in their CM for **Longevity** Gum. In the CM, he eats a stick of gum and rambles something foreign (he's actually saying - why are you putting this _glue_ in my _mouth_?).
column7: 3) [[howtwosavealif3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/howtwosavealif3)] 5-2-2011(2): 士 フ エ 一 [吋→壽](midori://search?text=吋→壽) （ 寿の正字 ） さむらいの笛は 1インチ.
column8: 4) [[kapalama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kapalama)] 19-10-2010(1): 新年の壽 [longevity [old]](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/2995) (#2995 壽) ジュ, ことぶき … Parts: 士 , 冖＊, 工 , 一 , 吋 [inch](../v4/2952.html) (#2952 吋) (cf. 範疇 [Unicode-0x7587](http://kanji.koohii.com/study/kanji/30087) (#30087 疇), 寿 [longevity](../v4/1565.html) (#1565 寿)) … Story: It is Kabuki when the samurai wear Makeup, but it is **Kotobuki** when they wear _Broken Crowns_ forged from _I-beams_ _one_ _inch_ thick.
column9: 5) [[alucardchuu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alucardchuu)] 23-8-2010(1): [+ dihutenosa] This is an old samurai who's seen a lot of **longevity**. He has been sitting in the same spot, on his torn Burger King Crown, for ages. He's something of a local landmark, so when a construction site is set up around him, they simply put a ceiling over his head and build around him. Despaired, he would like to tell his fellow villagers how many treasures will be destroyed by this massive urbanization movement, but the construction team put glue in his mouth so that he remains silent.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 11-11-2007(28): I **hesitate** to have a _wooden leg_ fitted as I'm not sure how it will affect my _longevity_.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(13): The man suffering from gangrene **hesitate** d a bit, but knew he'd have to choose the _peg leg_ if he wanted _longevity_.

column8: 4) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 14-6-2008(3): Wooden leg, old longevity: The samurai guarding the secret of _old longevity_ was **hesitating** to come out and get a new _wooden leg_ : the old one had rotted away under that clammy floor.
column9: 5) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 5-9-2009(2): I **hesitate** at buying that wooden leg because of the longevity may not match up to that metal leg.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 20-1-2008(19): A bit of _old food_ is stuck on one of my _mandalas_. What could it be? I scrape it off and taste it . . . Hmm, **bean jam** , I reckon.
column6: 2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-8-2009(9): Steamed **bean jam** dumplings were invented as a form of _Chinese take-out_ that could be eaten while meditating on a _mandala_ (thanks dihutenosa).
column7: 3) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 15-6-2008(6): Old food, Mandela: During his imprisonment, _Mandela_ was only given _old food_. Once per year, they gave him a treat: fresh **bean jam**. After this, you shouldn't visit _Mandela_ 's cell: to stinky! Old food primitive: (meeting, day, staples: The meeting took all day, do when we got out to have our dinner, only old food and the staples of the dinnerboxes were left. My colleagues are such gluttons!
column8: 4) [[CasualTatsumaki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CasualTatsumaki)] 9-2-2011(2): Sounds like the name of a hippie jam band, _eat_ ing hash manju and staring at a _mandala_. 肉饅頭 [にくまんじゅう] manju (steamed bun) with meat filling.
column9: 5) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 16-8-2008(2): For me, the _old food_ thing on the right just makes me think of the traditional Chinese version - so it's gonna be a _Chinese take-out box_. [+abaddon] When _Mandela_ was in prison, he was routinely starved and forced to go without food. Luckily, one of the guards took pity on him and would always give him the part of his lunch that he couldn't stand eating anyway - the little **bean jam** portion that came in the _take-out box_ with his Panda Express meal.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 25-8-2008(36): The _mouth_ on the left eats a whole _box_ full of _goods_ and then starts to **retch** them out again.

column8: 4) [[abaddon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/abaddon)] 15-6-2008(2): Mouth, old ward: The stench decomposing bodies in the _old ward_ made the apocalypse survivors nearly **retch** their innards from their _mouths_. column9: 5) [[koohiikun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/koohiikun)] 17-3-2011(): The _mouth_ on the left starts to **retch** after having a _cardboard box_ of _goods_ made with Monsanto ingredients.

column5: 1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 25-8-2008(28): The **snapping turtle** is ordering lunch at a restaurant, "I'll have the _shredded old eel_ – and make it snappy!". (Picture the waiter putting old eels through the shredder before serving them).
column6: 2) [[errtu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/errtu)] 30-9-2010(23): 3000… im so proud.
column7: 3) [[enryu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enryu)] 5-9-2009(8): (Note: Bottom 黽 means Green frog /industry. Check your Japanese dictionary.) Story - The **Snapping turtle** eats through _green frogs_ like a _shredder_ eats through paper.
column8: 4) [[dannyboy4885](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dannyboy4885)] 31-10-2012(2): Watch this link (39 mins, 20 secs in) and you'll never forget this kanji again! (Story coming soon!) [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q46lLez60PQ&feature=related](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q46lLez60PQ&feature=related).
column9: 5) [[gavmck](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gavmck)] 22-3-2010(2): 黽: _crown >tail>one>walking stick>one>back to back staples_. Turtles live a long time so a walking stick is no surprise. Remove the _staples_ and you have pictograph of a letter t (for turtle) with curved tail. The 2 _ones_ bridge crown and _tail/stick_ to create a pair of "eyes". Now put the _staples_ back again. The staples form a _mortar_. An upturned empty turtle shell could be used as a mortar of sorts. STORY: A **snapping turtle** would make a good bio- _shredder_.
